DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY ATTENDS INAUGURAL TAIPEI-OSAKA FLIGHT

TEXT.P: EVA Airways Corp. (EVA AIR) and Air Nippon on Wednesday jointly reopened the Taipei-Osaka route after a hiatus of 24 years, with first lady Tseng Wen-hui on board an Osaka-bound EVA AIR airplane as a VIP guest.

The inauguration at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport near Taipei was attended by outgoing Transportation and Communications Minister Tsai Jaw-yang, Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen, Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR) Chairman Lin Chin-ching and Shintaro Yamashita, director-general of the Taipei office of the Japan-based Interchange Association.
EVA AIR Chairman J.F. Chang, also among the 261 passengers on board his company's plane, will preside over a press conference at Kaigai Airport in Osaka after the airplane lands there.
EVA AIR and Air Nippon will jointly operate the Taipei-Osaka route by offering passengers seven weekly flights through code-sharing, according to the Taiwan-based EVA AIR.

The AEAR and the Interchange Association are semi-official organizations representing Taipei and Tokyo, respectively, to deal with bilateral exchanges in the absence of diplomatic ties between the Republic of China and Japan, which cut off official relations in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS RECEIVED 28TH MOST US FDI
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 31 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is 28th on the latest list of the worldwide economies that have received foreign direct investment (FDI) from the United States, dropping from 23rd on the previous list, according to an official report.

Figures in the report, released by the US Trade Representative's Office on Tuesday, show that Taiwan has received less US FDI than most other major economies in Asia, in spite of the fact that the island is the United States' 7th largest trade partner and the third largest exporter in Asia.

As of the end of 1996, Taiwan had lured a total of US$4.59 billion in FDI from the United States, up 7.1 percent from the year-earlier-level, according to the US statistics. Most of the capital was poured into banking, manufacturing and gross/retail industries.

Taiwan lags behind the other three Asian economic tigers in total US FDI, with Hong Kong, a former British colony, having gained US$16.02 billion in FDI from the United States; Singapore, US$14.15 billion; and South Korea, US$5.5 billion, the statistics showed.
Compared with other major Asian economies, Taiwan only tops mainland China, the Philippines and India in FDI from the United States.

The report pointed out that as of the end of 1996, the United States had made US$796.49 billion in FDI, up 11 percent from the level a year earlier. The greatest portion of the American funds, or 45.5 percent, went to the United Kingdom, Canada, the Netherlands, Germany and Japan, the statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONDON TO ESTABLISH TAIPEI OFFICE TO SEEK TAIWAN INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: London, March 31 (CNA) (By C.L. Ou & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Greater London Area has decided to set up a liaison office in Taipei to drum up Taiwan investment in the British capital city, sources with the London regional government reported on Tuesday.

The London First Center, a private and public sector partnership that provides free consultancy services to overseas companies considering London as a business and investment location, has decided to establish its Taipei liaison office in June this year and has appointed William Tang to be the new office's first representative.
The Taipei office, to be located on Keelung Road in downtown Taipei, will have three full-time employees.
The new center is expected to intensify competition among the various regions in Britain that see Taiwan as an important source of foreign investment.

Like London, other regions in Britain -- including Northeastern England, Northwestern England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales -- have all dispatched personnel from their respective development organizations to Taiwan for investment promotion.

William Tang, a Chinese-British official who has worked in Taipei for seven years as a representative of the Northern England Development Company (NDC), said the London First Center will cooperate closely with the NDC's Taipei office in an effort to sharpen Britain's competitive edge in the Taiwan market.

The Greater London Area, which boasts 30 of the 91 Taiwan companies that have relocated business operations to Britain, is a commendable choice for Taiwan companies because of its well-established infrastructure and sound financial and legal service systems, Tang said.
Among the Taiwan firms already in the Greater London Area are Liton Electronics, CMC Magnetics and ADI Corp., he added.

Michael Charlton, managing director of the London First Center, said that since its establishment in 1994, the center has helped 150 companies from around the world to set up affiliated operations in London. Given that Taiwan is one of Asia's economic powerhouses and is continuing to enjoy an economic boom, the founding of a London First Center in Taipei is only natural, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US AMBASSADOR TO M'LAND CHINA DISCUSSES CROSS-STRAIT TIES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 31 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: James R. Sasser, US ambassador to mainland China, reiterated on Tuesday that the US government would be delighted to see Taiwan and mainland China resume negotiations as soon as possible.

Delivering a keynote speech before a gathering on US-mainland Chinese relations sponsored by the Asian Foundation here, Sasser repeated the US policy on cross-strait relations -- that disputes between Taiwan and mainland China should be peacefully resolved by the Chinese people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and that the sole peaceful approach is to hold talks.

Sasser said he is optimistic that Taiwan and the mainland will resume talks in the near future, noting that both sides have expressed a willingness to do so. However, he added, it remains to be seen under which terms the two sides would reopen talks.

Asked about whether US President Bill Clinton will give way to Beijing's terms for joining the World Trade Organization (WTO) during his planned visit to mainland China in June, the ambassador said he believes that Washington will stick to its stance by handling the issue as a purely business matter that has nothing to do with politics.

Noting that the two sides need to hold additional negotiations on relevant issues regarding Beijing's WTO bid, Sasser revealed that he hopes Zhu Rongji, who became mainland China's new premier last month, will visit the United States this autumn.

Expressing his belief that Asian economies, including that of mainland China, will become stronger and more vigorous in the 21st century, Sasser said the United States is willing to partner itself with Asian countries so as to help them obtain even greater development.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL MAY SET UP HUGE MANUFACTURING PLANT IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Intel, the world's leading maker of chips for personal computers, may invest up to A$6 billion (US$4.03 billion) in Australia if the Coalition government under Prime Minister John Howard is willing to offer tax concessions to the US company.

A company spokesperson told CNA Wednesday morning that Intel President and CEO Craig Barrett and executives in Intel's Asia-Pacific and Australian operations will hold a meeting in Sydney with Howard and other Australian ministers to discuss the possibility of setting up a huge Intel plant in Victoria.

The Australian Financial Review, Australia's largest business daily, on Wednesday quoted sources close to the deal as revealing that Intel will be looking for a positive signal from Howard that Australia is serious about attracting high-tech investment.

Intel is impressed with Australia's decision to introduce a manufacturer-in-bond scheme, which allows the import of some goods free of duty and sales tax. But Intel is expected to ask the Australian government to give the company a favorable taxation treatment on its Australian revenues because the company plans to export 98 percent of the products it would make in Australia, the sources said.
Howard believes such huge investment projects from foreign companies such as Intel will help boost his bid for a second term as prime minister, political analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE DOLLAR SEEN FALLING BELOW US$0.65 IF YEN DOESN'T MAKE GAINS

TEXT.P: The Australian dollar is expected to further drop drastically to as low as 60 US cents in the next few months due to weaker Asian demand for Australian goods and a weak Japanese yen, foreign exchange dealers said.
They said the US dollar is now buoyant against major currencies, including the Australian and Japanese currencies because of the strong American economy.

The Australian dollar closed at 66.34 US cents Tuesday, down 0.34 US cents from Monday's closing level. Meanwhile, the US dollar gained ground against the Japanese yen, closing at 132.73, up 1.5 yen from Monday's level.

The dealers predicted the Australian dollar could drop to between 65 and 60 US cents in the second half of this year because the Asian currency crisis will start affecting the Australian economy as a result of the weaker demand for Australian products and raw materials such as coal, iron ore, other minerals and grains.
They are now tipping the US dollar to rally to at least 135 yen because hopes are fading for a resurgence in Japan's tired economy despite the huge fiscal stimulus package Tokyo announced recently.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE PM GOH TO ATTEND ASIA-EUROPE MEETING IN LONDON

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong will leave for London Wednesday night to attend the second Asia-Europe Meeting (ASEM), which opens Thursday.
He will be accompanied by Minister for Foreign Affairs S. Jayakumar, Minister for Finance Hu Tsu Dow and other senior officials, said a statement from the Prime Minister's Office.

Leaders of 25 countries in both Asia and Europe will be attending the three-day summit-level meeting. ASEM, which was developed from a proposal Goh made in 1994, was inaugurated in Bangkok in March 1996 to promote dialogue and engagement between Asia and Europe.

Discussions on the Asian financial crisis are expected to feature prominently in the agenda during the London meeting and a separate statement on the Asian crisis will be issued, reflecting the importance both Europe and Asia attach to the matter, according to reports from London.

The leaders will consider endorsing action plans to enhance trade and investment between Asia and Europe. An Asia-Europe framework for political, economic, cultural and people-to-people cooperation is also expected to be adopted, reports said.
The leaders will also discuss initiatives for cooperation in various fields, such as culture, the environment, education and health.
Goh is scheduled to return to Singapore on April 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYDNEY MORGUE STAFF PLUNDER CORPSES FOR MONEY, VALUABLES

TEXT.P: Half of the staff of a morgue in Sydney could face criminal charges after an investigation discovered they had plundered corpses for money, jewelry, clothes, telephone cards and even shoes in a culture of corruption lasting 10 years.
The Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) said in a report that most of the assistants were involved in the corrupt conduct known as "ratting."

It said 13 morgue employees out of a staff of 16 and two undertakers had acted corruptly. Eight employees and the two undertakers will be referred to the director of public prosecutions for possible perjury charges and conspiring to arrange false testimony to the ICAC.
The undertakers even bribed morgue employees up to A$150 (US$101) each to refer families of the dead to a funeral home, the ICAC said.
ICAC Commissioner Barry O'Keefe described the practice as "an affront to our society."
"It was disgraceful behavior," he said. "What they did was systematically offer bribes to morgue employees to steer business their way."

The ICAC investigation found that the assistants would conduct a mock search in front of police and government contractors for valuables. Once they had left, the assistants thoroughly searched and looted the corpses, the commission said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE BARRIERS REMARKABLY REDUCED: US REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 31 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan's "unfair barriers" to US exports has remarkably reduced last year, and only a few issues remain to be tackled, the office of the US Trade Representative (USTR) reported on Tuesday.

The USTR dedicated only five pages to Taiwan's trade barriers in its 1998 National Trade Estimate Report on Foreign Trade Barriers, compared with the previous two years' 11 pages. The five-page "accusation" is the shortest complaint the US government has filed against Taiwan over trade in the past few decades.

Noting that the USTR has just completed the final round of bilateral trade consultations with Taiwan on the island's terms for joining the World Trade Organization, the report said that Taiwan now restricts US goods and services providers' market access in only three areas: import policies, intellectual property protection and government procurement.

In the previous year's report, the USTR had complained about Taiwan's trade barriers in six major areas: import policies, intellectual property protection, government procurement, the service sector, investment restrictions, and Taiwan's tobacco and liquor monopoly.

Regarding import policies, the report singled out Taipei's policies on medical equipment and pharmaceuticals imports as one of the major sources of disputes between the two sides over the last two years. Nearly one-fourth of the 1998 report on Taiwan focused on this issue.

Although Taiwan is currently America's third largest overseas market for medical equipment and pharmaceuticals, the USTR complained that Taiwan's Central Health Insurance Bureau has adopted a pricing system on medical equipment that goes against ordinary people's interests and is in opposition to the principles of transparency, predictability and openness.

On the pharmaceutical pricing system, the USTR grumbled about Taiwan's "overprotection" of its domestic pharmaceutical makers and "excessive restrictions" on the registration of new foreign producers and new foreign brands of prescription medicine.

The 416-page USTR annual report singled out Japan and the European Union as the United States' top priorities in market-opening efforts, dedicating 50 pages and 30 pages, respectively, to the two economies' trade barriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.031 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.829.
The greenback opened at 32.871, and was traded between 32.805 and 32.882.
The interbank trading reached US$295 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AUSTRALIAN PM SEES MAJOR CALAMITY WHEN MAINLAND CHINA REPLACES US AS SUPERPOWER

TEXT.P: Mainland China will eventually replace the United States as the global superpower and this could "trigger a major calamity" for the world, Australia's former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser warned on Monday.

In a speech to a UNESCO conference on education in the 21st century in the Asia-Pacific region, Fraser said: "There is now one superpower, which has claimed a great moral and democratic victory over communism and which, as a consequence, has become more assertive in promoting values which are thought to advance American interests.
"We know quite well that at some point, the Chinese economy will pass that of America. No great power has ever enjoyed seeing another climbing up the greasy pole to displace it.
"The possibility of significant problems between America and China is real and in our part of the world, it is not difficult to point to issues which could trigger a major calamity," he added.

The Australian Associated Press reported that Fraser is one of a 30-member council of former heads of government from around the world formed in 1983 to discuss globalization and problems of population and the environment.
Fraser said there was and still is a cultural divide that needs to be addressed.
"Tolerance between cultures and religions, between geographic regions, is often a scarce commodity. It needs promoting and supporting," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRANCE SAID WILLING TO COOPERATE IN GRAFT PROBE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, March 31 (CNA) (By M.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Visiting ROC Legislator Parris Chang said here on Tuesday that the French authorities have expressed a willingness to cooperate with Taiwan in a probe of graft allegations surrounding France's 1991 sale of six Lafayette-class frigates to the island.

Chang, of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), along with a legislative delegation including several lawmakers from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the tiny opposition New Party, arrived here on Sunday to investigate the allegations.
According to French press reports, about two-thirds of the US$500 million allegedly paid in commission for the US$3 billion frigate deal were paid to go-betweens from Taiwan and mainland China.

Chang stressed the importance of finding out the true facts of the case and that the relevant French authorities have expressed a willingness to cooperate closely with the delegation, but the DPP lawmaker was reluctant to reveal the content of the just-concluded two-day meeting between the two sides.

Chang, also a member of a task force set up recently under the ROC Ministry of National Defense (MND) to probe a recent series of scandals involving ammunition depot construction projects for the country's Combined Services Forces (CSF), said Taiwan should establish an institutionalized military procurement process with European countries just as it has done with the United States, in order to eradicate irregularities.

Since the Military Procurement Bureau under the CSF has recently been placed under the direct management of the MND, Chang expressed the belief that the legislature will now be able to effectively monitor military procurement.

Chang and other members of the delegation are scheduled to depart Paris on Wednesday for Strasbourg in eastern France, where they will hold seminars with members of the European Parliament-Taiwan Friendship Association to exchange opinions on enhancing bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BECOME WORLD'S LARGEST NOTEBOOK PRODUCER

TEXT.P: Taiwan might end up being the largest beneficiary of the Asian financial crisis, officials from the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said in Taipei on Wednesday.

Numerous orders for notebook computers are now flowing into Taiwan in the wake of the financial impact which has forced Japan and South Korea, two of the world's largest computer makers, to sub-contract most of their production to Taiwan computer manufacturers, the officials said.

The financial storm which has swept across most of Asia from the middle of last year has resulted in a general drop in regional currencies, which has led to many Asian producers suffering higher production costs and lower profits.
Japan and South Korea appear to be suffering the most, since they can no longer enjoy the benefits of self-production due to a global demand for low-priced computers.

This trend has forced them to hand over many of their orders to Taiwan, another of the world's largest computer manufacturers, in order to reduce the burden of their inflated production costs, the IDB officials said.
Taiwan's economy, bolstered by healthy economic fundamentals, remains one of the few Asian countries to have suffered relatively little damage from the financial turmoil.

Taiwan also has wide experience in the field of OEM computer manufacture, and is the largest outside contractor of several heavyweight computer producers worldwide, including Compaq, IBM, Hewlett-Packard, Fujitsu and NEC.

According to IDB statistics, the worldwide production volume of notebooks currently stands at around 14 million units per year. Some 35-45 percent of this amount originates in Taiwan, making the island the second-largest notebook maker in the world behind Japan.
Since the beginning of this year, a number of Japanese manufacturers, including Toshiba Corp., have asked their Taiwan contractors to take over notebook production.

The IDB officials said the surging orders are expected to not only boost Taiwan's general income from industrial output, but also to push it into first position in the worldwide notebook manufacturing sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ENHANCE FRIENDSHIP WITH SAUDI ARABIA

TEXT.P: James W. C. Wang, new representative of Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Saudi Arabia, said Wednesday that to strengthen friendly relations with the kingdom is in the interest of the nation.

The newly appointed envoy said at a meeting of the Foreign Affairs and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee of the Legislative Yuan that Saudi Arabia is an important country, and that he will do his best to promote the friendly relations between the two countries.

Taiwan imported US$1,904 million worth of commodities from Saudi Arabia in 1997. Exports to the kingdom totaled US$491 million in the same year. Taiwan imports 190,000 barrels of crude oil from Saudi Arabia per day.

Riyadh switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1990. The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Riyadh and Jeddah were established in 1992 to promote substantive relations between the two countries.
It is necessary to promote trade and economic relations between the two countries in order to develop long-term and mutually beneficial relations, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: C.F. Koo, chairman of the Republic of China's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), stressed on Wednesday the importance of cross-strait dialogue, predicting that talks between the SEF and its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will be resumed in the near future.

Koo said after attending a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Central Committee meeting that the SEF, a quasi-official body set up to handle cross-Taiwan Strait contacts in the absence of official ties with mainland China, will send a letter to the ARATS later this week containing the names of the SEF representatives which will be sent to the mainland for preparatory consultations.
He added that the representatives will be either Shi Hwei-you, SEF secretary-general, or Chang Liang-jen, SEF deputy secretary-general.

The SEF wrote recently to the ARATS agreeing to send a delegation to mainland China. The letter said "appropriate personnel" will be dispatched in mid-April, or at a time suitable to ARATS officials, for consultation and planning.
The ARATS replied via letter on March 26, welcoming the SEF move and inviting the SEF to present a concrete agenda for talks.

The first round of talks between Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, which took place in Singapore in 1993, were suspended in 1995 by Beijing in protest over ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States.

On Feb. 24, Taipei received what it termed a "positive" proposal from the ARATS, suggesting that preparations begin for political dialogue and the resumption of negotiations on cross-strait technical and economic issues.

Prior to that type of discussion, further exchanges and contacts between the two sides are necessary, the proposal said, adding: "We welcome a visit by Koo at an appropriate time. Officials at the appropriate level can make the necessary preparations through an exchange of visits."

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC MAY ADJUST OIL PRICES IN JULY: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday that if international oil prices continue to drop and if the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) reaches its profit target, domestic oil prices can be adjusted downward in July. Wang made the remarks in response to interpellations by Taoyuan County Legislator Chiu Chui-chen of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and Taipei City Legislator Chen Han-chiang of the opposition New Party, who wanted to know why domestic oil prices have not been lowered despite a decline in international oil prices. The minister pointed out that the adjustment of oil prices is under continuous assessment. When international prices dropped recently, he said, the CPC originally considered the possibility of lowering domestic prices. However, two days before the decision was made to lower prices, international crude prices soared by US$2.00 per barrel, resulting in a temporary halt to the adjustment plan.

During each fiscal year, the CPC is legally entitled to a certain amount of profit. According to Wang, the CPC still needs an additional NT$5 billion to reach its legal ceiling for surplus in its fiscal 1998 budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH ECONOMIST WINS PROFESSOR LEE TENG-HUI PRIZE AT CORNELL U.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 31 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: British economist Ravi Kanbur was on Monday named the first winner of the "Professor Lee Teng-hui Prize in World Affairs" by Cornell University, in Ithaca, New York.
Kanbur is an expert in the economic problems, such as inequality and poverty, faced by developing countries, according to a press release from the university.
He has served as chief economist and economic counselor to the senior deputy governor of the World Bank, and also writes editorials for many well-known economic periodicals around the world.
Kanbur earned his doctorate from Oxford University in England, and has carried out research in Oxford, Princeton University and Chicago University.
The prize, set up in 1994 with a US$2.5 million donation from supporters of Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, will enable Kanbur to teach at Cornell for one year, beginning from April 1.

Lee Teng-hui, who received his doctorate in agriculture economics from Cornell in 1968, made a high-profile visit to his Alma Mater in 1995. The first US trip by an ROC president despite the absence of official ties was hailed by Taipei as a diplomatic coup.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE CAN PRACTICE DEMOCRACY: ROC PM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 31 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's experience shows that Chinese people are eminently capable of practicing democracy, and that democratic values fit in well with Chinese culture, Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said in an interview with an American reporter entitled "Taiwan's Experience Shows China Can Adapt to Democracy."
"Cultural factors will no longer serve as a persuasive excuse for autocracy," he told Patrick B. McGuigan, whose interview with the ROC leader was published on Wednesday in The Daily Oklahoman.

Siew said that Taiwan's experience with democratic reforms has proved that the argument -- that there is no democratic tradition in China, and that democracy is therefore not suitable for China -- is clearly flawed.

He reasoned that since 1987, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in Taiwan has been promoting democratic reforms and emphasizing the concept of popular sovereignty. "This has been well received by the public in Taiwan and praised throughout the world."

Siew said that this proves that Chinese can "rapidly adapt to a democratic system without causing social instability," adding that he believes that with Taiwan's proven success in instituting democracy, there is no reason why mainland China, with the same cultural background, should not also be capable of a similar achievement.

He added: "The true reason why the mainland has not yet implemented democracy has nothing to do with Chinese people rejecting it, but rather because under Beijing's totalitarian rule, people are not allowed the opportunity to choose a different system."

During the interview, the premier also mentioned that there are differences between Confucianism and the Western concept of democracy. Traditional Confucian thought emphasizes "humanism," believing a ruler must consider and take care of the basic needs of the ruled.
He cited an example which states that while under Western democracy, a ruler must have the consent of those ruled, similar concepts do not exist in Confucianism.

If traditional Chinese culture has helped build democracy in Taiwan, Siew said, he believes one of the distinguishing qualities of Chinese culture is "its ability to incorporate a diversity of characteristics from other cultures."

He told McGuigan that history shows that the Chinese people are accepting of and able to learn from different value systems. Accordingly, although the values of democracy are not the focus of Chinese Confucian culture, "having understood that democracy is a global trend that meets the needs of human nature, we are very pleased to study and accept it," the ROC premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US RELIGIOUS LEADERS SAID HAVING BEEN DECEIVED BY BEIJING

TEXT.P: Several clergymen of Chinese descent in Rome said Tuesday that the three American religious leaders who visited mainland China in February have been deceived by communist Chinese leaders.

A three-member delegation of American religious leaders made a 20-day visit to mainland China in February to study freedom of worship there. The three religious leaders are Rabbi Arthur Schneier, president of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation; Archbishop Theodore McCarrick of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, and the Rev. Don Argue, president of the National Association of Evangelicals. During the visit, they failed to visit the 30 "religious prisoners" they had planned to see. They spent most of the time in visiting the places Beijing officials wanted them to see, the clergymen said.
They issued statements soon after the visit, saying that the Vatican should establish diplomatic relations with Beijing in order to put religious persecution on the Chinese mainland to an end.

The clergymen, who declined to be named, said communist Chinese officials are smart in propaganda and are notorious for their skill to fool foreigners by giving false presentation and deceiving information.

If US religious leaders want to find out the real condition of religious freedom on the Chinese mainland, they have to do it through "private channels," and try to understand the true nature of the Communist Party of China.

Some worshippers from the underground churches in mainland China have said recently in Rome that they have suffered from more than 20 years of religious persecution because of their loyalty to the Vatican.

They said that they were disappointed to hear that some officials of the Holy See are advocating the establishment of diplomatic relations with communist China, and that they would be psychologically unable to accept the communist-controlled "patriotic churches" in mainland China after the establishment of diplomatic relations.

The Chinese communists see religion as "rulers' opium" to numb the people, and believe that God shall be overthrown by the historical power of the proletariat, the worshippers from mainland China said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 49.66 points to close at 9,041.5.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 9,160.68 points, and saw a low of 9,041.5 at closing time.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 254 to 162, with 78 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 2.51 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$136.47 billion.

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with pulp and paper shares moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.2 percent, construction shares at 0.9 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 9 percent, textile issues at 0.6 percent, electrical shares at 0.4 percent, and both cement stocks and those in the plastics and chemicals category at 0.1 percent.

The 10 listed companies experiencing the largest turnovers in Wednesday's trading were: Formosan Rubber Group; Taiwan Fertilizer Co., Ltd.; Winbond Electronics Corp.; Picvue Electronics; Tycoon Group Enterprise; China Petrochemical; Cilicon Integrated Systems Corp.; Mitac International Corp.; Taiwan Tea Corp.; and Wus Printed Circuit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE BUDGET REJECTED BY LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office budget for fiscal year 1999 was rejected in a preliminary review at the Legislative Yuan on Wednesday, as a gesture of dissatisfaction with ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
It was the first time in ROC history that legislators have refused to screen a Presidential Office budget.

At a joint conference of the legislative judiciary and budget committees, a proposal to refuse to screen the budget was passed by a 9-2 vote, with most of the legislators on hand representing the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Less than 20 minutes later, the budgets for the National Security Council and the Academia Historica, two institutions under supervision of the Presidential Office, met the same fate.

When the joint meeting opened on Wednesday morning, DPP Legislator Su Huahn-dji proposed that the Presidential Office budget of over NT$980 million (US$29.87 million) be rejected on the grounds that President Lee should take responsibility for a recent series of aviation disasters and military scandals.

Su claimed that because of pressure from Lee, Premier Vincent Siew did not remove Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsay Jaw-yang at an earlier date, and has been unable to demand that Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling step down over a snowballing military-related string of scandals.

Su went on to remind his colleagues that it was Lee who engineered the National Assembly's move to strip the Legislature of powers to check the Executive Yuan during last year's constitutional reform.

The opposition legislator Shu thus proposed to immediately suspend all discussions and reject the budget. Despite strong protests from ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Liu Kwang-hwa, meeting chairman Lin Chou-shui of the DPP put the motion to suspend discussion to a vote. It was approved by 10-1 vote, with the support of New Party Legislator Lee Ching-hua. Immediately following, the move to reject the Presidential Office budget was passed by 9 votes to 2 votes.

DPP Legislator Chiu Chui-chen further proposed that the National Security Council budget of NT$120 million and the NT$140 million Academia Historica budget be rejected as a means of expressing anger over what he called Lee's meddling with Premier Siew's power to decide his cabinet members. The proposal was also supported in two successive votes.

The KMT caucus later condemned the moves, vowing to reverse the meeting's decisions. According to screening procedure on budgets at Legislative Yuan, the budgets rejected in the first reading will be sent directly to the Conference of Joint Committees for a second reading. As the KMT is the largest party in the Legislative Yuan, the budgets are expected to be approved without meeting much difficulty.

Secretary-General to the President Huang Kun-huei, who was present at Wednesday's meeting without having a chance to defend the president, said that the Presidential Office helps to carry out public policies, and that if its budget is eliminated, the citizens of the ROC will be the ultimate losers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 16TH IN COMPUTER USE
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 1 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan had over 2.57 million computers in operation as of 1996, making it the world's 16th largest computer-using country.

According to statistics made public by the American Electronics Association, the United States is the country using the most computers in the world, followed in order by Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Canada, Italy, Australia, South Korea and mainland China.

The report predicted that by the year 2000, the number of computers in use in the United States will reach 161 million units, while the European Union member nations are expected to have a combined total of 132 million computers, with the Asian Pacific region hosting 108 million units and Latin America with 16 million.
It also said that the number of computers in use in Taiwan will increase to 5.21 million units by the year 2000, with a ratio of 232 computers for every 1,000 persons.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM NOT IN SUPPORT OF LEE'S PROPOSED VISIT TO PALAU

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday that he is not in favor of President Lee Teng-hui visiting Palau.

Hu made the remarks in response to press queries about local media reports that Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the Business Management Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT), is pushing for Lee to tour Palau in May to preside over the inauguration of a KMT-invested hotel in the western Pacific republic.
"If consulted, I will recommend that the president not go," Hu said.
The KMT Business Management Committee, the business arm of the ruling party, rejected the accuracy of the reports in a press release later in the day.

Also denying the reports, Foreign Ministry Spokesman Roy Wu said that his ministry has so far received no instructions, nor has itself had any plans, to make arrangements for the "vacation diplomacy" foray by the president.

Trade and economic relations between Taiwan and Palau have been growing recently along with the exchanges of visits by ranking officials of the two sides. But there have been no indications that the two nations plan to forge formal diplomatic ties anytime soon.

In October 1995, then Vice Foreign Minister Fang Chin-yen visited Palau to attend a ceremony marking the first anniversary of Palau's independence. Two years later, Minister Without Portfolio Shirley Kuo flew to Palau as the special envoy of President Lee for the inauguration of Palau's President Kunio Nakamura.

Nakamura visited Taipei in March and August 1995, and again on May 18, 1996, when he attended the swearing in of Lee as the first popularly elected president of the ROC and officiated at the opening of the Palau's honorary consulate in Taipei.
But officials with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs have complained that Palau has been wavering in its attitude about entering into full diplomatic ties with the ROC.
They are of the opinion that it would make no sense for President Lee to visit Palau before official ties between the two nations are established.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVATION ARMY'S WEEKLY FEATURES AUSSIE PM IN APRIL FOOLS JOKE

TEXT.P: An April Fools' Day joke in the Australian Salvation Army's weekly that claimed Australian Prime Minister John Howard wants to abolish Easter holidays because Australia is now a multicultural country isn't getting laughs from everyone.

Thousands of copies of the weekly featuring the Howard joke are being distributed to Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania. But more than 20,000 other copies of the publication are being pulped in New South Wales, Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory because the joke is regarded as in "bad taste."

"I feel we tied April Fools' Day with Easter in a tasteful way. But I accept that other territories have the right to make their own decisions, and I have no problems with that at all," the weekly's editor-in-chief Pam Trigg said in Melbourne.
The weekly said Howard stated it is "inappropriate in a multicultural society to provide a special holiday for one religious celebration and not for the holy days of other religious groups."

The weekly said it was only joking and that it had tried to marry the story with an Easter message. Many would find it equally unbelievable that Jesus Christ would show such "extravagant, foolish love for us" that he was prepared to die "the most degrading and dishonorable death possible at that time" for humankind, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-KOREAN JOINT VENTURE TO BE LAUNCHED IN SEOUL

TEXT.P: A joint venture between Taiwan and South Korea in a risky investment field will be launched on April 8 at a reception in Seoul.

Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the Business Management Committee of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), is expected to host the reception in his capacity as chairman of the KMT business flagship China Development Corporation (CDC), which is the co-owner of the newly formed CDC & MBS Venture Capital Co. Ltd.

Among the 200-odd dignitaries invited to take part in the inauguration ceremony will be South Korean Economics Minister Lee Kyu Sung. Financial details of the joint venture will be disclosed at a press conference on April 8.

Liu had reportedly visited South Korea many times before Asia's regionwide financial woes swept through the country late last year, with the dual purpose of prying open South Korean markets and warming up bilateral ties with Korean political groups on behalf of the KMT.
Relations between former allies Taiwan and South Korea have been strained since 1992, when Seoul abruptly switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

Bilateral ties began to thaw after the financial crisis drained South Korea's foreign reserves late last year and forced leaders to look to cash-laden Taiwan as a possible source of foreign investment. The election of Kim Dae Jung, who promised to better relations with Taipei during his campaign, as South Korea's president at the end of 1997 also contributed to the improved climate.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T PERMIT REQUIRED FOR INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Wednesday stressed the importance of obtaining government permission for Taiwan investments on the Chinese mainland.

In an interpellation at the Legislative Yuan, Yeh Chu-lan, an opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislator representing Taipei City, asked the minister whether Y.C. Wang, chairman of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), had violated government policy with his decision to pursue an investment project on the mainland.

The tycoon announced on Sunday that the FPG will temporarily back off its investment in a US$3 billion thermal power plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, by selling 60 percent of the shares it controls to a foreign company in the United States. But he added the FPG will buy back the shares after the ROC government eases current restrictions under its "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy.

In his reply, Minister Wang said that Y.C. Wang is required to obtain ROC government permission in order to invest in projects on the mainland. He added that under such a premise, if the government were to permit ROC nationals to directly invest in the mainland in the future, the FPG could certainly do so. And in that event, not only can it buy back its shares in the Zhangzhou thermal power plant, it could also invest in other projects.

After hearing the minister's reply, Legislator Yeh criticized the FPG chairman's business maneuver by saying, "Human weakness can always find excuses to ignore God's commandments and listen instead to the more attractive words of the Devil."

DOC.HEADLINE: LIN ASSUMES NEW POST AS TRANSPORT MINISTER

TEXT.P: Newly sworn Minister of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Lin Feng-cheng on Wednesday vowed to improve flight safety in Taiwan.

Lin, who has previously served in the Cabinet as a minister without portfolio and as the interior minister, said at the changeover ceremony that he will set up a task force to be responsible for an overall review and checkup of local airline companies.
The ceremony was held under the supervision of Minister Without Portfolio Huang Ta-chou. Lin received the seals of office from outgoing MOTC head Tsay Jaw-yang.
Outlining other priorities on his agenda, Lin said that his ministry will play its part in helping the government achieve the goal of making Taiwan an Asia-Pacific operations center.

Tsay, who submitted his resignation on Monday as a gesture to take responsibility for a spate of recent aviation disasters, said on the same occasion that he was thankful for the support and assistance his colleagues extended to him during his nearly two-year tenure. Tsay assumed the MOTC ministership in June 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CENTRAL COMMITTEE PLENARY SESSION IN THE OFFING

TEXT.P: A plenary meeting of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Central Committee is set to convene in late August for the purpose of showcasing the party's candidates in yearend elections for the Legislature and mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, KMT sources said.

KMT Vice Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi on Wednesday chaired a preparatory meeting which brought together relevant party officials and set the venue and date for the proposed gathering, to be held at Taipei International Conference Center from Aug. 22-23.
It will be the second plenary meeting of the 15th KMT Central Committee.
The plenary session is expected to elect members of the Central Standing Committee, the party's policy-making body, and to allocate political work to party members who serve in public office.
Premier Vincent Siew, and KMT Secretary-General John Chang are expected to give separate reports on the agendas for the central government and the party.
The main task of the session will to bestow the party's mandate on candidates running on the KMT ticket in hopes of boosting their election chances.

In a departure from tradition, party officials will suggest that the presidents of the Control Yuan and the Judicial Yuan not be invited to attend the session, although the holders of those offices are usually KMT heavyweights.
The move is a gesture to accommodate public calls for the two governmental branches to exercise greater independence, party sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE ECON. MINISTER TO WOO JAPANESE INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yin Chi-min is scheduled to lead a Republic of China investment promotion mission to Japan on Sunday to woo investors there to Taiwan's high-technology industries.

Yin's visit to Japan is considered timely, coming amid reports that Tokyo is preparing to introduce a US$123 billion economic stimulus package later this month in an effort to rekindle the flagging Japanese economy, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Friday.
According to MOEA tallies, Japanese investment in Taiwan, which is mainly focused on high-tech manufacturing, has grown steadily over the past several years.

The Japanese channeled some US$850 million into Taiwan in 1997 for various investment projects, posting a whopping increase of 60 percent from the previous year. Japanese investment in Taiwan totaled only about US$200 million in 1993.

More Japanese companies in semiconductor, information technology and electronics manufacturing are considering the relocation of operations to Taiwan to take advantage of the island's skilled work force and relatively competitive production costs, according to MOEA officials.
Yin and his group will call on relevant Japanese government officials as well as trade and industrial leaders during their stay in Tokyo and Osaka.
Meanwhile, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the MOEA on Friday announced a six-pronged initiative to correct Taiwan's chronic trade imbalance with Japan.
The latest statistics from the ROC Directorate-General of Customs show that Taiwan posted a record trade deficit of US$1.81 billion with Japan in March, the highest single-month figure ever.

That performance pushed the island's trade deficit with Japan in the first quarter of 1998 to US$4.73 billion. BOFT officials said the gap is expected to widen further if the sluggish Japanese economy does not emerge from the shadow of a crippling recession.

The officials said several key factors will make it difficult to narrow the imbalance, including fewer Japanese orders for Taiwan-made electrical machinery and related tools, for years the backbone of local exports to Japan, because of the depreciation of the Japanese yen.

In addition, Taiwan pork product exports to Japan were devastated following the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease at Taiwan hog farms in March 1997. And greater demands for Japanese know-how and equipment by Taiwan's manufacturing industries have increased local imports from Japan.
To help narrow the persistent trade gap in favor of Japan, the BOFT devised six measures as follows:
-- Continuing to host Taiwan product exhibitions in Japan;
-- Establishing more after-sale service centers and distribution hubs in Japan for Taiwan-made products;
-- Strengthening publicity efforts in Japan for Taiwan-made products; and

-- Continuing attempts to remove Japanese trade barriers to Taiwan products and expediting negotiations with Tokyo over the resumption of Taiwan shipments of grape and processed meat products to Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR MISSING AFTER FISHING BOAT CATCHES FIRE, SINKS

TEXT.P: Family members of a missing fisherman from Keelung, northern Taiwan, asked the government on Friday to help them find their loved one and three of his companions.

The fisherman, identified as 36-year-old Chen Tsun-chui, was the chief engineer of the Keelung-registered "Chin Hsin 22" fishing vessel, which sank Monday night south of the Zhoushan Islands, off mainland China's eastern coast, after a fire broke out.
Four of the six persons onboard remain missing, with only the captain, identified as Tsai Wuan-tsai, and a mainland Chinese fishing worker named Lin Chih-ming, being rescued.
Tsai told CNA that he and Lin had reached Keelung on Thursday. When discussing the incident, Tsai, who appeared highly distraught, said the engine room of his boat had caught fire on Monday evening.

After failing to control the fire, the crew abandoned the vessel by jumping into the sea, he said, adding that he and Lin were rescued by a mainland fishing boat after drifting for more than 20 hours.
Tsai said he was unaware of the whereabouts of the other four crewmen after leaving the sinking boat.
Chen has a wife and three young children.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 TAIWAN FIRMS ACCUSED OF PATENT INFRINGEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 9 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: California-based Oak Technology Inc. filed a complaint with the US International Trade Commission (ITC) on Thursday, accusing five Taiwan companies of infringing upon its patented CD-ROM driver controllers production technology.

Oak also demanded in its appeal that the US government ban imports of CD-ROM drivers manufactured by the five Taiwan companies with pirated Oak technical expertise and personal computers equipped with those drivers in accordance with US Customs law.

The ITC, a federal body, must decide by May 8 whether to launch an investigation into the matter. The probe will take at least 15 months to complete, unless the parties involved settle their disputes privately beforehand.
The five companies facing the accusations are United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), Lite-On Technology Corp., Lite-On Group, MediaTek, and Aopen.

Complaints by Oak against major Taiwan electronics companies have taken many twists and turns. It first filed a grievance with the ITC on July 22, 1997, accusing nine companies, including Winbond and UMC of Taiwan and seven others in Singapore and Malaysia, of infringing upon two Oak patents related to CD-ROM controllers. A week later, UMC managed to reach a settlement with Oak, which then withdrew its complaint.

For its part, the ITC decided on Aug. 19 last year to start probes into the Oak allegations against Winbond. Before long, Oak came forward again, accusing UMC of violating their previous agreement. It claimed that UMC had continued producing and selling CD-ROM controllers with pirated Oak expertise through an unlisted company, MediaTek. Oak filed a breach of contract lawsuit against UMC in a US federal court last October.
Meanwhile, Oak reached an agreement with Winbond earlier this week over the patent rights dispute, in which Winbond agreed to pay an unspecified amount of royalties to Oak.

But on Thursday, Oak unexpectedly took new action against UMC and four other Taiwan firms, asking the ITC to investigate alleged patent infringement and to ban import into the United States of all related products manufactured by those companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK TRANSACTION TAX EXPECTED TO HIT RECORD

TEXT.P: Revenues generated from the stock transaction tax are expected to top a record NT$120 billion (US$3.65 billion) in fiscal year 1998, sources from the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Friday.

The MOF collected NT$94.85 billion (US$2.88 billion) in revenues from transactions on the stock market in the first three quarters of the current fiscal year, which began on July 1, 1997, representing a stunning 165.8 percent of the projected goal of NT$57.2 billion set for the same period.

Based on a conservative estimate of an average NT$12 billion in daily transactions on the Taiwan Stock Exchange for the remainder of the current fiscal year, tax revenues generated from the stock trade are expected to easily reach NT$120 billion for FY 1998, breaking the previous record of NT$110 billion posted in FY 1990, said Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the MOF's Department of Statistics.

Total national tax revenues amounted to NT$146.1 billion (US$4.44 billion) in March alone. Intakes from nearly all tax categories, including customs tariffs, commodity taxes and business taxes, have shown remarkable increases in the past month, the only exception being revenues from incremental taxes on land value as a result of a sluggish real estate sector in recent months, Hsu said.

As of the end of March, the island's overall tax revenues amounted to NT$985.4 billion (US$29.95 billion) for the first nine months of FY 1998, which ends on June 30, marking an increase of NT$117.4 billion (US$3.57 billion) over the corresponding period of the last fiscal year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIL CODE LEGAL RESIDENCE PROVISION DECLARED UNCONSTITUTIONAL

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices (COGJ) on Friday declared unconstitutional a Civil Code provision concerning the designation of a married couple's legal residence.
Article 1002 of the Civil Code stipulates that a wife shall take the domicile of her husband as her legal residence, unless otherwise agreed by the parties involved.

According to a COGJ interpretation issued on Friday, the provision is contrary to the spirit of Article 7 of the ROC Constitution, because it fails to take into account the wife's right to choose her legal residence as well as the particular needs of specific couples.
Article 7 of the Constitution says: "All citizens of the Republic of China, irrespective of sex, religion, race, class or party affiliation, shall be equal before the law."

The council made the interpretation at the request of Chen Li-feng, an ROC citizen who asked the council earlier this year to clarify whether a Taiwan High Court verdict based on the Civil Code provision concerning her legal residence violates Article 7 of the Constitution.

At Friday's COGJ meeting, the 15 participating grand justices unanimously agreed that the Civil Code stipulation regarding a wife's legal residence is unconstitutional. The meeting was presided over by Judicial Yuan President Shih Chi-yang.
With the council's ruling, the Civil Code provision will be invalidated within a year.
The COGJ interpretation also maintains that even if a couple do not establish a joint legal residence, husband and wife are nevertheless under mutual obligation to live together.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HELP BUSINESSES DEAL WITH DUMPING CHARGES

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Friday that it has worked out a series of measures to help businesses cope with dumping charges.
BOFT officials noted that between January 1997 and March 1998, a total of 28 separate cases involving dumping charges have been filed by foreign countries against Taiwan products.
This is in contrast to only six cases filed against Taiwan manufacturers over a two-year period from 1995 to 1996.

The officials also cited statistics from the United States indicating that, since 1995, US businesses have filed a total of 69 cases accusing foreign producers of dumping goods in the US market. Among them, 10 complaints involved products from mainland China, followed by nine cases against Japanese goods. Taiwan and South Korea each were involved in seven cases.

To help businesses cope with mounting allegations of dumping activities, the BOFT has worked out a package of short-term measures, which will involve providing information and consultation services, the holding of seminars to provide technical guidance, and assistance from the ROC's overseas offices.

Long-term measures include encouraging businesses to establish sound accounting systems to prevent exported products from being sold below fair value in overseas markets, and to set up legal affairs departments that can keep abreast of the latest international trade regulations so as to avoid dumping charges, BOFT officials said.

The officials noted that while carbon steel tubing, stainless steel wire rods, along with bicycles and their parts, have been frequent targets of dumping charges in the past, information products are rapidly becoming another problem area. They cited the example of Taiwan static random access memory (SRAM) chip manufacturers and fax machine exporters that are facing dumping charges in the United States and Europe Union, respectively.
The BOFT officials said that information industry enterprises in Taiwan must be on special guard against dumping charges.

The government will encourage local semiconductor businesses to sign with their foreign counterparts agreements aimed at stepping up the collection and exchange of data on production and distribution to help reduce the number of dumping cases, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WARNS AGAINST VISITING BRUNEI BECAUSE OF HAZARDOUS HAZE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Friday warned that haze has blanketed Brunei and much of Kalimantan Island, and urged people to avoid visiting that area until the situation improves.

Tsai Jung-hsiang, MOFA deputy director for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said at a news conference that the Air Pollution Index (API) in Brunei has risen since mid-March to 500, well into the "hazardous" category, while visibility in that Southeast Asian country has dropped below one kilometer.
An API above 100 is classified as "unhealthy," while one above 200 is "very unhealthy" and above 300 is "hazardous."
The haze caused by forest fires has risen to critical levels, Tsai said, recommending that Taiwan people avoid traveling to the affected area until the harmful smog disperses.
Brunei is one of the favorite sightseeing spots for Taiwan tourists.
Citing reports from the MOFA's representative offices in the Southeast Asia region, Tsai said last year's forest fires that were exacerbated by drought have not all been extinguished yet.

He told reporters that according to satellite data, there are at present about 5,000 separate fires, mostly in Kalimantan. The stricken area, including a wildlife preserve, covers a total of 150,000 hectares.

The official, citing an assessment by Indonesian environmental authorities, said the fires are expected to be more widespread this year than before. If the fires aren't efficiently controlled, they could spread to another 15,000 hectares of land, the assessment warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW ACCUSES BEIJING Of FAILURE TO FACE REALITY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday accused Beijing of being incapable of facing the reality that Taiwan and mainland China are two separate political entities administered by different governments.
He said this failure is the key factor causing the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to remain deadlocked in a chronic political impasse.

Siew said that political separation across the Taiwan Strait is not a permanent condition, and the fact that Taiwan and mainland China are ruled by separate administrations is not the primary obstacle to unification of the two sides.
Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Siew said that, as it takes two to tango, both sides must make the best of every opportunity for improved relations.

Taipei's termination of the Temporary Provisions for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion in May 1991 highlighted the reality of Taiwan's political separation from the mainland, Siew pointed out, adding that this recognition has since served as a basis for seeking improved relations with Beijing.

While it is a fact that both Taiwan and the mainland comprise China, it is also an undeniable truth that the two sides are administered under separate political entities. Neither of these conditions should be disregarded when the issue of cross-strait relations is addressed, Siew asserted.
Siew urged the Beijing authorities to temporarily set aside sovereignty disputes and concentrate instead on efforts to improve cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Market (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 36.29 points to close at 9,054.02.

Dealers said the market was influenced by rising stock prices in the United States at the beginning and opened high, but that later the index was pulled down by suspicion and worry about the performance of the electronics sector in the first quarter of this year.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 9,178.16 and experienced a low of 8,992.09.
Losers edged gainers by 213 to 212, with 72 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 2.38 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$138.36 billion (US$4.21 billion), dropping from the previous session, which saw a total of 3.29 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$171.47 billion.

Half of the eight major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemical issues at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, electrical stocks registered a loss of 0.9 percent, followed by bank and insurance issues at 0.5 percent and construction shares at 0.1 percent. The textile category remained unchanged.

The listed companies enjoying the 10 largest turnovers in Friday's trading were Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Picvue Electronics, United Micro Electronics, Winbond Electronics Corp., ACER, Formosan Rubber Group, MAG Technology, Lealea Enterprise, Ta Jung Transport and ASE.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S MARCH UNEMPLOYMENT RATE 8.5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Canada's unemployment rate was 8.5 percent in March, a slight improvement from the previous month's 8.6 percent.
Statistics Canada reported that during the month, some 18,000 new jobs were created, all in the private sector.

The agency called March a month of "consolidation," with the country's big job machine Ontario taking a break, Alberta loosing some jobs, while regular outsiders Quebec and British Columbia were doing rather well.
The long decline in public sector employment continued last month, as governments dumped another 21,000 workers, according to the agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TO HELP THAILAND WHETHER ECONOMIC CRISIS

TEXT.P: Diane Marleau, Canada's minister for international cooperation, announced Thursday that Canada will help Thailand meet the challenges of its current economic crisis.
Marleau will make the official announcement on Friday, during ceremonies opening the new Canadian embassy at Abdulrahim Place in Bangkok, Thailand.

"Thailand has made significant progress in addressing the economic and social challenges facing its people," Marleau said. "Canada's contribution will assist the Thai government in continuing this important work."

The Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA), which Marleau supervises, will support the work of special task forces established by the Thailand Development Research Institute (TDRI) to recommend solutions to the current economic and social problems plaguing Thailand.

CIDA will contribute C$1 million, of which C$500,000 will go to support the TDRI's work in developing new policies for balanced development and to foster future partnerships with Canadian institutions. The remaining C$500,000 will be allocated to the country's restructuring activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEES FOREIGN TOURIST ARRIVALS FALLING

TEXT.P: Australia expects to attract 5 percent fewer tourists this year because of the Asian economic crisis, which will cost the country US$530 million in revenue, according to the Tourism Council of Australia (TCA).

TCA managing director Bruce Baird said the number of tourists coming from Asian countries other than Japan will fall by 25.5 percent from the 1997 figure of 1.35 million to a shade over 1 million in 1998.
He said the decline in tourist arrivals this year will be the first drop since 1989, when strikes by Australian pilots caused the number to drop.
He said the biggest drop of tourist arrivals will be from Indonesia and South Korea where the numbers are expected to fall from 160,000 to only 48,000 and from 234,000 to 70,000, respectively.
Tourists from Taiwan, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand will also drop considerably, he said.
Tourists from Japan, the biggest market for Australia, will rise slightly to 817,000 this year from last year's 814,000, he said.
He said the number of tourists from mainland China is expected to rise by 30 percent, offsetting some of the losses from other Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE RISES WITH JOBLESS YOUTH SURGING

TEXT.P: Australia's unemployment rate in March rose to 8.2 percent from 8.1 percent in February with the jobless rate of young people under 20 leaping to 29.2 percent from 26.4 percent, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).

There were 13,100 people in the 20-and-under age group joining the ranks of the unemployed, bringing the total number of unemployed youth to 94,300, or 16 percent, throughout Australia, according to the official figures.
Job vacancies are at an all-time high but indicators show a more gloomy outlook for the unemployed over the next year, ABS officials said.

Employment, Education and Training Minister David Kemp conceded that youth unemployment was "far too high." He said there were no problems with the federal government's job creation policies and he blamed the sluggishness of the job market on waterfront workers, who are currently on strike.
"Australia is not going to get the jobs we have a right to expect in the export industries while we have wharves that don't work," he said.
But he said the government was still on track to achieve its budget forecast of 8 percent unemployment by June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA TO REINSTATE RIGOROUS ID CHECKING FOR AIR PASSENGERS

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has asked domestic airlines to rigorously implement identification verification processes at check-in counters for all boarding passengers, effective Friday.
CAA officials said the step was necessary to increase flight security as well as to protect the legal rights of passengers.

Statistics showed that between 1993 and 1997, a dozen people were found to have sneaked into Taiwan aboard planes from the mainland, while three people flew from Taiwan's offshore islands to illegally enter the mainland.

Although only a small number of stowaways was found to have entered or departed Taiwan proper through Penghu in the Taiwan Strait, where ID checks for boarding passengers are not required, CAA officials said that security loophole poses a potential threat to society.
The officials noted that before 1993, passengers were required to show ID cards when purchasing air tickets, reporting to check-in counters and prior to boarding their flights.

The multiple checks were deemed to be a source of inconvenience for passengers, and the CAA later dropped the preboarding verification requirement, except for flights to and from Kinmen and Matsu, two islands off the coast of mainland China.

While the CAA has never formally scrapped the check-in counter ID requirements, hectic flight schedules have caused most domestic airlines to become lax in enforcing the regulation. As a result, the occurrence of passengers other than the original ticket holders boarding planes on domestic flights has become increasingly commonplace.
Statistics show that 35 million passengers take domestic flights every year, and the number is increasing.
CAA officials noted that in case of accidents, lack of proper verification could cause problems in securing the legal rights of passengers.

CAA has therefore decided that verification procedures must be rigorously implemented from now on. Otherwise, the airline companies will face stiff fines of between NT$600,000 and NT$3 million (US$18,180 and US$90,910), a business suspension or even the revocation of operating licenses.

The decision to rigorously enforce the regulations came in the wake of a controversy over whether a certain passenger was actually aboard the ill-fated Formosa Airlines plane which crashed last month off Hsinchu, killing all 13 persons.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN WATERFRONT WAR INTENSIFYING

TEXT.P: The waterfront battle between Patrick Stevedores Ltd. and union workers is intensifying with the company being forced to airlift its nonunion labor to thwart a blockade by protesting unionists.

Patrick, one of the two leading stevedoring firms in Australia and the center of the dispute with the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA), on Thursday chartered helicopters to airlift newly hired nonunion workers to docks at Port Botany near Sydney after its staff and workers were chased into the terminal amid a shower of bricks, stones and water from hoses turned on them by tugboats.

Patrick is expected to charter more helicopters to airlift its replacement workers if similar incidents happen at other major ports where the company operates, according to chief executive Chris Corrigan.

He said, "If anyone is looking at the footage of security guards and dogs (patrolling the terminal) and wondering why they're there, (it is because) there is violence being perpetrated against our employees."

Patrick's nonunion workers are scheduled to begin stevedoring its first vessel, owned by the Australian National Line, on Sunday. And then other workers will follow suit at other major ports, including Melbourne, Brisbane, Townsville and Fremantle.
Patrick has ignored a federal court injunction which is designed to stop the company from hiring contract workers.

After failing to blockade the operations of Patrick, MUA's national secretary John Coombs said his union will launch a fresh wave of legal moves against Patrick, Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith and the National Farmers Federation's stevedoring companies.
Coombs said the MUA and its members plan to block ships to Patrick's docks in a bid to force a backdown.
"We intend to make sure Corrigan's got no business, got no ships, got no cargo, moving over his ports," he said.

If his legal action fails again, Coombs said, the MUA will rely on the London-based International Transport Workers Federation using its clout to warn shippers not to berth in Patrick's terminals in other countries where the company has operations.

At a press conference Thursday in Canberra, Prime Minister John Howard accused the MUA of hindering waterfront reforms and said the union organization had ill-served its members. Therefore, the MUA has to face the consequences, he said.
Analysts said the battle between Patrick and the MUA and other unions is expected to continue escalating until some kind of solution is found. No one can predict when the war will end, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SAFETY VIOLATION DISCOVERED AT WARNER VILLAGE CINEMA

TEXT.P: Building safety inspectors with the Taipei City Government conducted a surprise spot check of safety facilities at the Warner Village Cinema on Friday, but did not discover any negligence or irregularities.
The unannounced safety inspection followed Wednesday's tragic incident at the cinema, in which a woman's head became wedged between the ceiling and an escalator handrail.

The officials with the Office of Safety Standards under the city government's Bureau of Public Works said they found no violations of safety regulations after completing a thorough inspection of the cinema's emergency exits, firefighting equipment, construction materials, fire protectation zones, escalators and other related safety facilities.
The officials said new warning signs have also been erected between the ceilings and escalators at the cinema, and that all escalators are operating normally.
As no irregularities were discovered, the officials said, the bureau might have no legal basis to become involved in handling the recent tragic incident.
Lai Hung-yin, 20, was making her way up to a third-floor screening room at the new cinema complex when the incident occurred at about 7:00 p.m. Wednesday. She has since been in a deep coma.
The Hsinyi precinct under the Taipei City Police Headquarters has transferred the case to prosecution authorities. The cinema management faces a charge of involuntary or unintentional injury.

Following the accident, criticism arose as to whether the cinema complex had been satisfactorily examined by government inspectors. Taipei City Government officials said the building had passed all the required safety checks and met rigorous safety standards.
The Warner Village Cinema opened shortly before the Chinese New Year holiday in late January.

A senior cinema executive was quoted by the local press as saying that Warner Village's concern at this point is helping the injured girl and family. The executive said the cinema currently has representatives with the family and will contribute substantially to the girl's medical costs and welfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX EVASION BEHIND LARGE FOREIGN ENTERPRISE DEFICIT: REPORT

TEXT.P: Foreign enterprises in the Chinese mainland commonly dodge taxes there by running superficially in the red, according to a report from a mainland Chinese news service.

An official investigation in mainland China revealed more than 70 percent of foreign firms there have been operating at a deficit, but the fact that few of them have withdrawn their capital from the Chinese mainland indicates that these deficits are actually a means of dodging taxes, remarked the China News Service on Thursday, adding that this is a problem that must be taken seriously.

Statistics based on foreign enterprises' income tax data, which was gathered by the State General Administration of Taxation under the State Council, show that 54.07 percent of foreign enterprises were in the red in 1993, with that figure escalating to 63.28 percent in 1994 and 70.29 percent in 1995, the news service reported, noting that in some provinces the levels reached between 80 and 90 percent.
Foreign enterprise investments ran a total deficit of 55.24 billion Chinese yuan (US$6.67 billion) in 1996, a 48.69 percent increase over the previous year's level, according to the report.
Many of these deficits, however, are artificial and aimed at avoiding taxes, it said.

Tax authorities monitored more than 47,000 foreign enterprises in 1991-1995, and found that these dodged a total of 4.2 billion yuan in taxes, said the report, which noted that these firms accounted for only about 25 percent of the total number of foreign enterprises doing business in the Chinese mainland during that period.

The report attributed the huge number of foreign enterprises reporting deficits to how foreign businesses are taxed. Because taxes on foreign enterprises are levied starting from the "profit year," firms have been postponing this time by increasing investment costs and underreporting profits, resulting in deficits that are actually superficial, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN IN TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The US dollar fell NT$0.102 against the New Taiwan dollar to close at NT$32.845 Friday on the Taipei foreign exchange market.
Turnover amounted to US$300.5 million.
The greenback opened Friday at NT$32.911 and experienced a high of NT$32.935 and a low of NT$32.810.

DOC.HEADLINE: FU CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT DISARMAMENT MEETING

TEXT.P: Taipei County Legislator Fu Kun-cheng from the opposition New Party on Friday urged authorities from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to hold a meeting on peaceful disarmament in order to lower their rising defense budgets.
Fu made the remarks at a state affairs forum at the Legislative Yuan.

According to Fu, the most concrete way for the two sides to show they are sincere in wanting to improve cross-strait relations would be to attend a cross-strait disarmament meeting, which he said would create a peaceful and friendly environment under which Taiwan and mainland China could work for the well-being of Chinese people on both sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC DEPUTY HEAD TO VISIT US

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China Deputy Director Shea Jia-dong will leave for the United States on Sunday at the head of a nine-member delegation.

While there, Shea will take part in seminars in Washington, D.C., New York and Chicago sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute and American Institute of Banking and meet with representatives of the local academic and business communities to exchange opinions with them on issues related to the Asian region's financial crisis.

Shea and the other delegates -- including officials from the Economic Planning and Development Council and the ministries of Finance, Economic Affairs and Foreign Affairs -- are scheduled to return on April 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE AIR FORCE RECEIVES ADVANCED F-16 JET IN US

TEXT.P: Singapore has received the first of its new C/D version of the F-16 Fighting Falcon -- a superior jet fighter that will extend the capability of the Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF), The Straits Times reported Friday in a dispatch from Fort Worth, Texas.

The sleek fighter is the first of Singapore's purchase of a full squadron of 18 F-16C/Ds under a 1994 order made with the US-based Lockheed Martin. The remaining 17 are scheduled for delivery at regular intervals over a period of more than a year, the report said.
During the roll-out ceremony in Fort Worth, Texas, on Thursday, Lt. Gen. Bey Soo Khiang, the chief of Singapore's defense force, said that the acquisition was a "quantum leap" for the RSAF.

"The addition of the multi-role F-16C/D to the RSAF's Order of Battle represents a quantum leap in the capability of the RSAF to achieve our superiority over the skies of Singapore and contributes to the ability of the SAF (Singapore Armed Forces) to fulfill its mission," he was quoted as saying.

"The aircraft, with its superior performance characteristics, technologies and capabilities, will not only greatly extend the operational envelope of the RSAF but also usher the RSAF into new dimensions of air warfare."
A flight demonstration of the F-16 followed the ceremony, the report said.
In Singapore, the Defense Ministry said in a statement that the purchase is a step in the "ongoing modernization" of the RSAF.
The RSAF has been gearing up for the new-generation F-16C/D, one of the most sophisticated fighters in the world and used by Israel, South Korea and the US Air Force and Navy.
