Singapore pilots, engineers and technicians have been training on all aspects of the fighter -- using leased F-16C/D aircraft -- since January 1996 at the Luke Air Force Base in Phoenix, Arizona.
Bey also highlighted the value of training in the United States.

"Besides providing RSAF pilots with the expanse of training airspace they cannot find back home, the opportunity to fly the F-16C/D in a quality environment of good training areas and facilities, and realistic training programs and exercises, allows the RSAF pilots to attain high professional standards in F-16C/D flying and operations," he said.

He told The Straits Times that the RSAF had evaluated various aircraft -- including the F-18 -- for over a year from 1994 but concluded that the F-16C/D was "a superior aircraft" and "markedly different."
Compared to the earlier F-16A/Bs, the C/Ds have stronger wings, more powerful engines and better avionics.
Besides the 18 F-16C/Ds ordered earlier by Singapore, a second purchase of 12 more was made in 1997, bringing the total potential fleet to 30 F-16C/Ds for the RSAF.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA PROCESSING TIME FOR ALIEN WORKERS TO BE SHORTENED

TEXT.P: The visa processing time for legal foreign workers will be substantially shortened in the near future, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

Chu Chien-yi, director-general of the MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs, told a news conference that the ministry is establishing computerized foreign workers information systems at its representative offices in five Southeast Asian countries -- Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia and Vietnam.

"When those systems are completed by the end of June, the visa processing time for foreign workers will be shortened from the current one month to only about seven days as our offices in those Southeast Asian countries will be able to contact responsible government agencies at home through Internet or E-mail in handling all related paperwork," Chu said.

At present, about 250,000 foreign laborers are legally working in Taiwan, contributing much to Taiwan's major construction projects. About 136,000 of them come from Thailand, 103,000 from the Philippines, 15,000 from Indonesia and 1,000 from Malaysia.

Chu said as the government is also expected to open the domestic job market to Vietnam in the future, the MOFA will also establish a similar foreign worker information system at its office in that country.

Currently, local employers must first file visa applications with the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) for foreign workers they intend to hire. The CLA will then send all related documents to the MOFA's offices in relevant Southeast Asian countries. The procedures usually take one month to one-and-a-half months to complete.
"With the completion of the computerized information networks, the CLA will be able to send papers and other related data to our overseas offices through E-mail, and vice versa," Chu explained.

In addition to shortening the visa processing time, Chu said, the new systems will also allow the MOFA's offices in the five Southeast Asian countries to contact with the CLA, the Bureau of Entry and Exit, as well as other relevant govenrment agenices through Internet. "By so doing, we'll be able to exchange dynamic information about foreign workers in our countries."

The new systems are also expected to facilitate passport inspection at airports, prevention of fraudulent use of passports, tracking of health bills of foreign laborers and prevention of entry of illegal workers, Chu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAO PROPOSES COOPERATION BETWEEN NEW PARTY, KMT

TEXT.P: Taipei City Legislator Kao Hui-yu from the opposition New Party suggested on Friday that her party and the ruling Kuomintang should cooperate in the upcoming Taipei mayoral election as well as in the 2000 presidential election.

Speaking at a state affairs forum at the Legislative Yuan, Kao pointed out that the KMT is in the embarrassing position of still not having a candidate for the Taipei mayoral election to be held at the end of this year.

Kao said that since those opposed to incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party expect the KMT and New Party to cooperate, the ruling party should back New Party candidate Wang Chien-shien's run for Taipei mayor in exchange for the New Party's support of the KMT candidate in the 2000 presidential election.

Kao claimed that if her idea is followed, the New Party will surely win the Taipei mayoral election this year and that the KMT will have a better than 80 percent chance of retaining the presidency in 2000. This would be the best form of "co-rule," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPREHENSIVE INVESTIGATION INTO ALLEGATIONS IN PRIMARIES: DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, April 10 (CNA)) The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday decided that more evidence is required before it can dismiss one of its members on charges of cheating in the primary elections held on March 29 to select DPP candidates for a variety of year-end elections.

The DPP Central Standing Committee said after a meeting that as the allegations against incumbent Taipei City Councilor Liao Ping-liang for his part in the scandal might not be an isolated case, they decided that it would not be fair to punish Liao at present.

The meeting also decided that the major opposition party should conduct a thorough review and check the qualifications of the DPP voters in Taipei City, Taipei County and Kaohsiung City, the three regions that are home to most DPP members. Should any more irregularities be discovered relating to the primaries, the party is determined to impose severe punishment on those found responsible for the cheating, the committee stressed.

Before the meeting took place, it had been widely expected that in order to show the party's determination to root out irregularities in the primaries, the DPP leadership would accept suggestions made by a DPP anti-bribery special task force that Liao be kicked out of the party and the case be handed over to the prosecutor's office.

Task force officers revealed on Thursday that acting on information supplied by DPP member Hsu Yang-ming, who is seeking DPP candidacy in the year-end legislative election, they found that Liao had collected the national identification cards of 235 DPP members and had changed the domicile addresses on the cards to addresses in his constituency -- the eastern district of Taipei City -- thus enabling them to vote for him.

They claimed that most of the domicile addresses were found to be either those of Liao's service offices or those of Liao's wife's houses. After the balloting, the members were given money and asked to apply for new ID cards.

Liao, who is seeking reelection as city councilor in the eastern district of Taipei City and who won the most votes in the primaries, was present at the meeting to defend himself. Besides submitting evidence to prove that at least part of the accusation is untrue, Liao said that he is totally innocent, although he admitted that some of his aides might have been responsible for the counterfeiting.

As part of an effort to address the problem of irregularities in the primary elections, the DPP has worked out a reformed nomination system under which public opinion polls will make up 75 of the nomination process, while the primaries will only account for the remaining 25 percent. Meanwhile, the party's annual membership fee, payment of which is a prerequisite for voting in the primaries, will be cut from NT$1,000 to NT$100.

The DPP held the islandwide primaries on March 29 to select candidates for the year-end legislative elections as well as for the mayorships and city councils of Taipei and Kaohsiung. Over 60 percent of the 84,000 eligible DPP members turned out to vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO BOOST EXPORTS TO US AND EUROPE

TEXT.P: Amid declining exports to neighboring Asian countries, local economists have urged the government to take measures to spur shipments to the United States and European countries.

Affected by shrinking exports to Japan, South Korea and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states in recent months, Taiwan suffered a first-quarter trade deficit of US$70 million in 17 year, a stark contrast to the US$1.8 billion trade surplus posted in the same period of 1997.

As it will take time for Japan and the ASEAN countries to rebound from the current economic downturn, economists said Taiwan shipments to those countries may not increase in the short term, adding that the government should move to boost domestic demand and spur exports to the US and European countries as a way of maintaining stable economic growth.

Analyses carried out by the International Monetary Fund and the Economic Intelligence Unit show that Thailand and Indonesia are expected to post negative economic growth for 1998, while South Korea will see zero growth, and only Malaysia will chart a 2-percent economic growth rate this year.
The sharp currency deprecations of the last few months, while they might have helped boost the exports of Southeast Asian countries, have also reduced import demand from those same countries.

Compared to year-earlier figures, Thailand saw a drop of 8.6 percent in imports in December 1997, while its imports in January plunged by 29.8 percent. Imports by South Korea fell by 39.6 percent and 29.5 percent in January and February, respectively, while Indonesia witnessed a reduction of 17.3 percent in imports in December of last year.

Sluggish local demand in Southeast Asian countries has also resulted in declining demand for machinery facilities from Taiwan and has affected Taiwan businesses' willingness to invest in those countries, economists pointed out.

T.C. Chen, professor of economic science at National Taiwan University, opined that the government should target the US and European countries, rather than Japan and other Asian countries, in its efforts to increase exports.

The US economy, which has improved steadily for the last seven years, is expected to remain stable in the years ahead, Chen said, adding that the European Union countries, fueled by the imminent introduction of a common European currency, are also enjoying improved economic fortunes.

Since the Asian financial crisis is expected to continue taking a heavy toll on Taiwan exports in the coming months, Chen said Taiwan should turn the situation to its own advantage by exploring the possibilities of shipments to Western countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE REAPPEARS IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Executive Yuan on Friday announced a course of action to strengthen measures designed to prevent the spread of several new cases of foot and mouth disease (FMD) which have reappeared in southern Taiwan's Tainan County.

The measures include the use of eartags to prove that piglets have been vaccinated against the disease, and hog raisers who violate the regulation will face fines of between NT$10,000 and NT$50,000. In addition, from August, hogs without the eartags will be prohibited from going to auction or slaughter.

The announcement was prompted by a report received on April 7 by the Tainan County animal disease prevention office from the Tainan County pork market on a number of pigs which had arrived at the market with symptoms resembling FMD. Later diagnosis by the Taiwan Research Institute for Animal Health confirmed the disease as Type O FMD.

Chen Bao-ji, director of the Animal Industry Department under the COA, said on Friday that after tracing the infected pigs back to their farm of origin, it was discovered that the farm in question has been under investigation, and that the pig farmer, who failed to produce vaccination papers, will be subject to a fine of between NT$10,000 and NT$50,000.

Chen noted that starting from the end of May, the COA will strictly enforce a disinfecting program on pork markets and pig-transport vehicles islandwide, adding that based on past experience, the marketplace and vehicles are the most important integers governing the spread of FMD infection.

According to a report released by the COA on March 19, the FMD epidemic which ravaged hog farms islandwide one year ago has caused estimated losses of NT$43.9 billion (about US$1.33 billion) for Taiwan's pig-rasing industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH VISITING MALAWI FM

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui told visiting Malawi Foreign Minister Dr. Mapopa Chipeta on Friday that he is unable to visit Taiwan's African allies this year because of his tight domestic schedule, but promised to make the trip "at an appropriate time."

Chipeta, who arrived with his wife in Taipei on Monday for a six-day visit, met with Lee at the president's office on Friday, where he presented a letter from Malawi President Bakili Muluzi extending an invitation for Lee to visit his country.
Chipeta expressed thanks to Lee for the help rendered by the Republic of China to his country since the two countries forged official ties in 1966.
He said he hopes Taipei will encourage its businessmen to invest in Malawi and use the country as a doorway to the African continent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED PUBLIC REACTION TO ARRIVAL OF BUDDHA RELIC

TEXT.P: Although political leaders who took part in the grand religious ceremony to greet the arrival in Taiwan of what is believed to be a tooth of the Buddha on Thursday defended their participation, more than one third of the respondents to a public opinion poll opposed the politicians' involvement in the activity.
More than 50 percent of those polled believed the politicians took part in the ceremony with a cynical hidden agenda of making some personal political capital out of the event.
However, most dismissed fears that the politicians' involvement will stir up a popular fad for Buddhism.

Opinion on whether the arrival of the tooth in Taiwan will bring peace and prosperity to the island was divided equally, with about 30 percent saying that it will and the same percentage saying that it won't.

Although 32 percent of those polled said they believe the presence of the relic will check the prevailing trend of violence on the island, only 25.8 percent think the building of a temple to house the tooth is warranted, while 34.6 percent oppose it and 37.6 percent have no opinion.

The poll also found that 44 percent of those interviewed feel the enthusiasm for religion triggered by the holy relic and a recent tour around the island by the Tachia Matsu -- the goddess of the sea in Chinese mythology -- will contribute to the island's social reform.

The Buddha tooth was brought to Taiwan by a local temple with great pageantry on Thursday. Government leaders, from Premier Vincent Siew on down, flocked to greet it at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

Although they argued that the arrival of the tooth is to ensure peace and prosperity for the country, critics said politicians should avoid taking part in religious activities in their official capacities.
The survey, conducted via telephone by a local cable TV station, interviewed 897 adults on Thursday and Friday with a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REBUTS FINANCIAL CRISIS CHARGES BY MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The ROC government on Friday rebutted an accusation by mainland China that Taiwan is taking advantage of the Asian region's financial woes to further its political agenda, stressing that Taiwan will continue to offer assistance to crisis-hit countries on a mutually beneficial basis.

Roy Wu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, described as a serious distortion of facts recent accusations by mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji and his deputy Qian Qichen that Taiwan is trying to damage mainland China's relations with its diplomatic allies amid the current Asian financial upheaval by deliberately allowing the New Taiwan dollar to depreciate.

The mild depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar is a natural result of current trends and is also a clear reflection of Taiwan's free market economy, which Wu said is far beyond comparison with mainland China's controlled economy.

Taiwan's aid proposals to neighboring countries hard hit by the economic turmoil which broke out in July 1997 were worked out based on humanitarian considerations and have won enthusiastic responses from the countries concerned, Wu said, adding that contrary to Beijing's accusations, they were not raised with any intention of blocking mainland China's ties with those countries.

The ROC, as a constructive member of the global village, is willing to provide substantive assistance to help those countries over their current difficulties, and will continue to do so in the future under the framework of free market regulations, for the mutual benefit of all concerned, Wu stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD TAKE PRECAUTIONS AGAINST POSSIBLE DRAM DUMPING CHARGES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs warned on Friday that US firms might file dumping charges against Taiwan-made dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips after scoring a victory in their fight against Taiwan's alleged dumping of static random access memory (SRAM) chips in the US market.

Chen Jui-lung, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), said that the US International Trade Commission (ITC) will on Saturday unveil the reasons why on April 1 it upheld a ruling of the US Department of Commerce (DOC) which subjects Taiwan's SRAM chip makers to a variety of punitive dumping tariffs.
Chen said that after the US Department of Commerce publishes the ITC report, the punitive duties on Taiwan's SRAMs, ranging from 7.59 percent to 113.85 percent, will go into effect.

According to the ruling, the SRAMS produced by Taiwan's Winbond Electronics will be subject to a 102.83 percent punitive tariff, while those from United Microelectronics Corp. will receive a tariff of 93.87 percent, Alliance Semiconductor Corp.'s SRAMs will suffer a 50.58 percent tariff and such chips from Integrated Silicon Solution Inc. will receive a 7.59 percent punitive tariff. Texas-Acer Instruments, Best Integrated Technology and Advanced Microelectronics will be subject to a 113.85 percent punitive tariff, while all other Taiwan SRAM makers will receive a 41.98 percent punitive rate.

Chen said that US and European Union chip makers are waiting for publication of the ITC report to decide on their chances of bringing dumping charges against Taiwan-made DRAMs. The report will state whether the ruling was based on concern over a potential threat to US SRAM makers or on fears that Taiwan's alleged dumping has already caused substantial harm to the US SRAM industry.

The BOFT will help local SRAM makers to appeal the case in the US Federal Court of International Trade within 30 days of the report's issue, Chen said, adding that if the ruling was based on a concern about a potential threat, Taiwan makers will stand a better chance of overturning the verdict.

Chen warned that as the US makers are very likely to file dumping charges against Taiwan's DRAMs, which are expected to deal a far more serious blow to Taiwan if the charges stick, Taiwan DRAM makers should take measures to respond to such a scenario.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER WELCOME TO INVEST IN HIGH-TECH LOW-POLLUTING INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai on Friday welcomed German chemical giant Bayer AG to invest in high-tech low-polluting industries in the central Taiwan county, three weeks after Bayer abandoned a NT$50 billion petrochemical project there.

Liao, who insisted that Bayer Taiwan's proposed project to produce toluene di-isocyanate (TDI) in a facility to be constructed in the Taichung Harbor area be subjected to a referendum, thus forcing the project to be scrapped on March 18, arrived in Taipei on Friday afternoon to visit Bayer Taiwan to try to sell his idea.
Liao considers the TDI project to be a high-polluting industry.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party county magistrate said that if Bayer Taiwan invests in high-tech low-polluting industries, the local government will provide the company with the necessary assistance.

Liao pointed out that his opposition to the TDI project and his decision to hold a referendum was only fulfilling campaign promises he made to his constituents, adding that other investment cases will not necessarily be subjected to referendum.
He received a very lukewarm response from Bayer officials.

John Chen, deputy general manager of Bayer Taiwan, reaffirmed that Bayer Taiwan has no intention of continuing with the TDI project in Taiwan and that the company has no other investment plans for Taiwan.

Chen said that although the Taichung harbor district land lease contract for the setting up of the TDI plant has been approved by the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, the contract has not been signed, and it will be up to the parent company in Germany to decide whether the company will lease the land.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'LIVE AND FIGHT' LEE TELLS SIGHT-IMPAIRED SOCIAL WORKER

TEXT.P: Although different people are blessed with different natural talents, "life is nothing but a series of struggles" to overcome inborn limitations, President Lee Teng-hui told a handicapped government-certified social worker on Friday.
Lan Chieh-chou, who suffers a serious sight impairment, is a clerk at the Examination Yuan. He earned the highest score in the government's examination for social workers this year.

In a meeting with the president, Lan expressed thanks to the government's policy of employing handicapped people and offering them the chance to take part in government examinations for professionals.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL RECEIVES AIRPLANE BOMB THREAT

TEXT.P: An unidentified telephone caller warning that an explosive device had been put aboard a China Airlines (CAL) airliner bound for Hong Kong caused Chiang Kai-shek International Airport authorities to immediately ground the plane and conduct an intensive search of the aircraft.

Flight No. 617 was scheduled to take off at 8:15 p.m., but when boarding had already been completed and the plane was waiting to take off, the Cathay Pacific Airways counter at the airport received an unidentified telephone call saying there was a bomb on the plane.
CAL staff immediately informed the police, who towed the plane off the runway to check and evacuate all 73 passengers and their luggage.

Latest reports said a preliminary investigation had failed to discover any explosive device on board the craft, but the search was continuing, while the passengers were taken to the nearby Transit Hotel to await a Saturday morning flight to Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI UNDAUNTED IN CROSS-STRAIT EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Undaunted by Beijing's cold shoulder, Taipei has decided to go ahead with an initiative calling for joint cross-strait efforts to help Southeast Asian countries weather the regional financial crisis.

A Taipei mission to be headed by Shea Jia-dong, deputy governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC), is scheduled to leave on Sunday for the United States on a 12-day publicity tour to drum up American support for the initiative.

In a Friday seminar on the Southeast Asian financial storm and cross-strait cooperation, Shea said Taiwan is both capable of and serious about engaging in a salvation mission to help its Asian neighbors, but at present, he added, the major hurdle to the mission lies in the US attitude rather than in Beijing's opposition.
Shea asserted that no country in the world has the right to deprive the countries of Southeast Asia of seeking aid from Taiwan in times of difficulty.
Beijing's willingness to call off its boycott of Taiwan's initiative would be beneficial to all parties concerned, he noted.

Meanwhile, he stressed that the CBC does not intend to drag down the value of the New Taiwan dollar to stimulate export growth. If there are no adverse factors on international monetary markets, the CBC will continue to safeguard the NT dollar in order to avoid causing a domino effect on other Southeast Asian currencies.

Tien Hung-mao, director of the Institute for National Policy Research, who was also present at the seminar, voiced his support for the mission's upcoming US trip, saying that it is essential for Taiwan to make itself heard internationally, since mainland China receives most of the attention from world media, and dominates the Chinese voice.

As example of this, Tien lamented the fact that the Taiwan initiative, voiced by both President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew several days ago, received scant attention from the international community.

Chen Po-chih, a professor of economics at National Taiwan University, pointed out that Beijing's willingness to set sovereignty disputes aside and cooperate with Taiwan would benefit not only the trouble-ridden Southeast Asian countries, but also cross-strait relations.
Beijing's refusal to even consider the initiative, he added, is an infringement on the overall interests of the countries of Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WARSHIP HITS MAINLAND CHINESE FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: One of the four warships of the ROC Navy's "87 Friendship Fleet" sideswiped a mainland fishing boat on Saturday, delaying the fleet's opening to the public at Keelung Harbor by one hour, according to a press release from naval headquarters.

Warship No. 530 crashed into the stern of the mainland fishing boat Minlianyu No. 0953 at 4:08 a.m. at a site 6.5 nautical miles northwest of the Pengchiayu Islets, off the northern coast of Taiwan, while sailing from Suao Harbor to Keelung Harbor in heavy fog, the press release said.

The fishing boat was damaged and began taking on water after the collision. Two of the fishing vessel's crew members sustained slight injuries, while the warship suffered only minor scratches to its starboard side.
The No. 530 put 25 crewmen aboard the fishing boat to help it pump out the water and called in another warship to tow the crippled fishing boat to Keelung for repairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE AFFAIRS HEAD VISITS JAPAN

TEXT.P: Minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chiao Jen-ho embarked on a three-day visit to Japan on Saturday.
He will meet with representatives of the Chinese communities in Tokyo and Yokohama, as well as with reporters from Taiwan.
It is Chiao's third overseas trip since he took office on Feb. 5.
He has already visited the United States and the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS `HALF RESOLVED'

TEXT.P: The countries of Southeast Asia have waded through the worst of their turbulent financial woes, according to Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) Business Management Committee. He said on Saturday: "Asia's financial crisis has been half resolved."

Liu made the remarks at a seminar sponsored by a Hakka-dialect broadcasting company in Taipei, which centered the discussion on raising the competitiveness of Taiwan's enterprises. Liu has recently returned from a tour of Southeast Asian countries to investigate their investment environments, during which he managed to secure several joint venture contracts.

Although the overall economic situation in Southeast Asia has now somewhat stabilized, several fundamental problems still haunt the region and need to be resolved, Liu observed, adding that in light of the fact that the basic economic outlook is still not sound in Southeast Asia, there is a long way to go before the situation is sufficiently improved.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND CONCERNED ABOUT DROP IN TAIWAN TOURISTS, IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: New Zealand is concerned about a downturn in the number of tourists and immigrants from the Republic of China on Taiwan, Frank Lin, ROC representative to that country, said on Saturday.
Lin said that although the two countries do not maintain formal diplomatic ties, the ROC is currently New Zealand's seventh-largest trading partner and its sixth-largest source of tourists.
However, bilateral trade between Taiwan and New Zealand has declined steadily since 1995 and the numbers of Taiwan tourists and immigrants have also seen a downward streak.
"The trends have caused concern among New Zealand officials," said Lin, who returned to Taipei earlier this week for home consultations.
According to Lin, New Zealand has issued immigration permits to more than 35,000 ROC nationals over the past 10 years, and about 70-to-80 percent of them have actually moved to New Zealand.

"As most Taiwan immigrants have capital, professional expertise and experience, they have become an increasingly important force in New Zealand society," the de facto ROC ambassador to New Zealand said.

Lin further said the country attaches great importance to its substantive ties with the ROC. In addition to sending cabinet ministers to visit Taiwan and stationing an ambassadorial-level career diplomat here, New Zealand is also mulling new measures to boost relations with Taiwan.

Lin said New Zealand's Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a Taiwan Information Paper in April 1996 which acknowledged that ROC-New Zealand relations can no longer proceed totally outwith an official framework. "It's no longer a problem for staff members of (the Taipei) representative office there to meet with New Zealand officials or parliamentarians to discuss matters of mutual concern," he pointed out.

According to New Zealand government tallies, tourist arrivals from Taiwan totaled 65,000 in 1995, but the number declined to 55,000 in 1996, further dropping to 45,000 in 1997. Each Taiwan tourist spends an average of NZ$2,500 (about US$1,387.5) in New Zealand. Against this background, Lin said, the decline in tourist arrivals from Taiwan is causing widespread concern.

Worse yet, immigrants from Taiwan have also decreased in recent years. "Some New Zealand officials think the decline might have something to do with the anti-Asian immigrant rhetoric of some candidates during New Zealand's 1996 parliamentary election," Lin said.

In fact, Lin said, both the government and people of New Zealand welcome Taiwan immigrants, tourists and investors. "Wellington Mayor Mark Blumsky has said on many occasions that ROC nationals are welcome in his country," Lin said, adding that Blumsky is scheduled to visit Taiwan next year to attract Taiwan tourists and investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY CONCERNED ABOUT CHINESE TORNADO VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Although no Chinese people were reported to have been victims of the tornado which ripped through the southern US state of Alabama recently, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs still instructed its office in Atlanta, Georgia, to convey its condolences to the Chinese community there.

The ministry on Saturday quoted a report from its Atlanta office saying that while there were no Chinese casualties of the tornado which claimed the lives of 32 people on Thursday, some Chinese residing in the stricken area have sustained property damage and are lacking electricity and water.
The ministry said it has instructed its Atlanta office to monitor the situation closely and provide assistance to those Chinese who are in need.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRPORT POLICE EXHAUSTED AFTER DOUBLE BOMB THREAT INVESTIGATION

TEXT.P: Police at the Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport had an unusually exhausting Saturday night when they had to conduct comprehensive safety checks to decide whether two bomb threats targeting international flights operated by local airliners were hoaxes.

The first bomb threat came at around 8:15 p.m. when the Cathay Pacific Airways counter at the airport received an unidentified telephone call, claiming that a bomb had been placed on the Hong Kong-bound China Airlines (CAL) flight 617. The aircraft with 73 passengers aboard was on the runway preparing for takeoff.
Airport police immediately had the plane towed off the runway to allow a thorough investigation to take place, while the passengers were taken to the nearby Transit Hotel.

After an intensive search of the aircraft and passengers' luggage, police determined at 10:30 p.m. that the bomb threat was a hoax, and after a nearly three-hour delay, the plane departed for Hong Kong at 11:50 p.m.

However, as police were busy handling the CAL bomb threat, another unidentified telephone call reached the airport police station at 8:40 p.m., this time claiming that EVA Airways flight No. 016 and Thai Airways flight No. 766 were to be hijacked.

Although a check revealed that there was no Thai Airways flight No. 766, the EVA Airways flight No. 017 was scheduled to take off for Los Angeles at 11:50 p.m. A thorough check was conducted to make sure no explosive device had been placed aboard the aircraft and the flight was permitted to depart for Los Angeles at 11:50 p.m. as scheduled.

Police said they have launched an investigation into the identities of the men who made the phone calls, warning that anyone who is caught carrying out hoaxes that might endanger flight safety will face up to three-year jail terms or fines of up to NT$1 million.

Local airlines have been troubled by a series of hoax bomb threats over the past few weeks. The last such hoax occurred some two weeks ago on March 29, when the CAL counter at the Shungshan domestic airport received a call claiming that there was a bomb aboard a Taipei-Kaohsiung flight which was already airborne. Earlier that same day, a bomb threat had forced a Macau-bound TransAsia Airways flight to return to Hsiaokang International Airport at Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESENT EXCHANGE RATES FOR NT$, JAPANESE YEN ACCEPTABLE: LIU

TEXT.P: The present exchange rates of the New Taiwan dollar and Japanese yen against the US dollar -- currently about 33 and 130, respectively, to the greenback -- are reasonable and acceptable, said Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the Taipei-based China Development Corp., on Saturday.
Liu made the remark when he attended a seminar sponsored by a Hakka-dialect broadcasting company. The seminar focused on raising the competitiveness of Taiwan's enterprises.

The foreign exchange rate of the NT dollar has been greatly affected by the recent dramatic ups and downs of the yen. Liu said Japan should be capable of defending the value of its currency and that he believes the present exchange rate of 130 yen for one US dollar is reasonable.

Regarding whether a lower yen would put pressure on the NT dollar and the mainland Chinese yuan to depreciate, Liu said as long as the Japanese yen remains stronger than 140 to the US dollar,the NT dollar and mainland Chinese yuan are not likely to be affected.
However, said Liu, should the yen fall past that level, the NT dollar and mainland Chinese yuan would feel pressure to depreciate.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND RITUAL FOR PEACE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A grand Buddhist gathering to celebrate the recent arrival of a tooth of Buddha and to pray for peace was held on Saturday at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei, with over 10,000 Buddhists from around the island and overseas present.
Premier Vincent Siew presided over the religious gathering, which was sponsored by the International Fokuang Association.

Vice President Lien Chan also took part in the historic assembly on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui to pay homage to the sacred relic, which is believed to be one of three teeth of Buddha left on earth after the sage's cremation.

As horns and drums played solemnly and followers of Buddhism filled the air with musical chanting, the tooth, kept in a delicate pagoda-shaped reliquary, was escorted slowly to a temporary altar in the hall by 40 Tibetan horn-playing monks, another 150 monks from the island, members of the delegation that escorted the Buddhist relic from Bangkok to Taiwan, and other escort teams from around the island.
Lien presented incense and then said prayers for the happiness of the people living in Taiwan and the prosperity of the country.

He told the audience that the relic represents the spirit of the four virtuous attitudes of Buddha -- loving-kindness, compassion, sympathetic joy and equanimity -- and that these also symbolize the perfect ethic that led to the sage's enlightenment.

Lien expressed his thanks to Fokuangshan and its abbot Hsin Yun for sharing the priceless treasure with all the people of Taiwan, adding that the activity of receiving and venerating Buddha's tooth can not only promote the spiritual reforms initiated by President Lee but also encourage ethical religious belief and help build a stable social environment.
Prior to Lien's prayer and speech, the Siew opened the prayers for peace by reciting four wishes.

Siew said he hopes that the loving-kindness and compassion that the relic of Buddha embodies can make the country prosper, and that its miraculous powers can bring peace and stability to the community, its wisdom and spirit of equity can help the spiritual purification of humanity, and its joy and freedom can lead to world peace.
Siew, a devout Buddhist, said when a prayer is made sincerely, it will be answered.

A number of legislators and heavyweight officials -- including senior presidential advisers Koo Chen-fu and Wu Poh-hsiung, Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao and Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng -- participated in the activity.
The ritual concluded after a ceremony in which people took an oath to practice the "three goods" espoused by Master Hsin Yun: to speak good words, keep good thoughts and have good acts.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA PRIVILEGES TO BE REINSTATED FOR TAIWAN VISITORS TO JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 11 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The government in Tokyo decided on Friday to uphold an amendment bill on Japan's acknowledgment of the validity of Republic of China passports and resuming 72-hour visa-free privileges for Taiwan visitors.

The government will go ahead with relevant arrangements to implement the amended entry and exit statutes, which are aimed at simplifying the entry process for visitors from Taiwan, on the premise that the amendments do not affect relations across the Taiwan Strait, said Foreign Minister Keizo Obuchi at a press conference on Friday.
Obuchi said he fully understands Beijing's concern over the issue but stressed that the amendments, which are purely businesslike in nature, in no way alter Japan's stance toward mainland China.

The amendment bill is expected to be raised for discussion at the current session of the Japanese Diet, according to an official from the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs. If the amendment is passed quickly by the Diet, there is a good chance that the new regulations will be implemented at the end of April, he added.

The revision is being seen as a significant step towards the resolution of Japan's "overstretched visa handling operations," which began after the ROC cut diplomatic links with Japan on Sept. 29, 1972, when Tokyo recognized Beijing as the sole legitimate government of China.

Since then, the Japanese government has never treated ROC passports as valid official documents, which means Japanese immigration authorities can only grant ROC tourists "entry certificates" to visit Japan, rather than visas.
In 1990, furthermore, Japan also abolished the 72-hour visa-free privileges that it had previously extended to Taiwan tourists in transit through Japan.
These measures placed an intolerable burden on the operations of Japan's authorities in charge of applications submitted by ROC passport-holders.

The Japanese government's move was only made possible after intense lobbying by an influential group of pro-Taiwan lawmakers who have been pushing for better civilian ties between Taiwan and Japan, prompting the Law and Foreign Affairs Committee of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to pass a resolution in a joint session on March 19 to improve Japan's visa and passport policy toward Taiwan visitors.

Statistics from the Japanese Entry & Exit Bureau show that 859,000 Taiwan tourists visited Japan in 1997, up by 100,000 from the year-earlier level. The popularity of Japanese tours among Taiwan people has forced the Japanese embassy in Thailand, which is authorized to deal with entry applications from ROC citizens, to also appeal for simplification of the processing operation.

The lawmakers called on the Tokyo government to amend relevant statutes to allow for the resumption of 72-hour visa-free privileges and changes in the method of issuing entry documents to Taiwan visitors.

Under the new regulations, ROC passports will be considered valid documents, and visa stamps will be printed directly into the passports themselves, rather than being stamped on separate "entry certificates" as is currently the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CIA CHIEF TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former US Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) Director James Woolsey and four other American military and intelligence experts are scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Monday for a brief visit.

Parris Chang, an opposition legisaltor-at-large representing the overseas Chinese community, said here on Friday that he has arranged the visit with a view to help the people of Taiwan better understand the development of delicate triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations and work out strategy to cope with increasingly closer Washington-Beijing ties.

Chang, who also serves as the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party's representative in the United States, said Washington-Beijing relations have improved significantly since mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin made a state visit to the US late last October. "Such a development could endanger Taiwan's diplomacy and security in the long run," he warned.

During their visit, Woolsey and other American intelligence experts will meet with ROC President Lee Ten-hui and senior government officials to exchange views on the possible impact on Taiwan of mainland China's military buildup in recent years as well as Taiwan's strategy to address such challenges.

The four other visitors are Dr. Michael Pillsbury, who once served as a deputy assistant secretary of defense; Dr. Gordon Oehler, a former director of the CIA's technology transfer evaluation center; Dr. Kent Harrington, a former head of the CIA's Asian intelligence department; and William Wright, a retired vice admiral who once served as an Asia-Pacific affairs division chief at the US Department of Defense.

Chang said all the visitors have played an important role in the US research of mainland China's military development. "I'm convinced that the information or opinions provided by them will help Taiwan better understand mainland China's future military development strategy as well as America's Asia-Pacific policy," he added.

Dr. Michael Pillsbury, who once studied Mandarin Chinese in Taipei in the 1970s, is currently a senior researcher with the Atlantic Council and an adviser to the Department of Defense. A report issued by the Defense Department earlier this year, which warned that mainland China might ignite a military conflict due to misjudgement of the US stance, was authored by Pillsbury.

He pointed out in the report that cultural difference is likely to make mainland leaders not afraid of America's deterrence force in the foreseeable future. Therefore, Pillsbury said, the US Defense Department and intelligence agencies should mull how to cope with mainland China's misjudgement of the situation.

Meanwhile, former CIA Director Woolsey once visited Taipei in the spring of 1996 when mainland China conducted a series of live-fire war games and missile tests in waters near Taiwan to intimidate local voters in the run-up to the island's first-ever direct presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRIAN DAILY PUBLISHES INTERVIEW WITH ROC PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, April 11 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The mass-circulation Austrian daily Die Presse on Friday published an interview with the Republic of China's Premier Vincent Siew in which he made a strong case for Taiwan's approach to mainland China and disclosed how the island has managed to keep clear of the regional economic crisis.

Siew was quoted as saying that Taiwan wants to exchange views with mainland China but hopes Beijing realizes the fact that the ROC is a legal entity out of its jurisdiction and should be treated accordingly.
Taiwan welcomes cooperation in any form with mainland China, so long as it is based on the principles of equality and mutual respect, he said.

Siew told Die Presse's reporter Helmut Hetzel, who conducted the interview during a recent trip to Taipei, that he would like to visit Beijing, but only in his capacity as ROC premier, a condition entailing the recognition of Taiwan as a political entity separate from the area under Beijing's control.

Regarding ties between Beijing and Washington, Siew said these should not affect the Taipei-Washington relationship, and that the presence of two US aircraft carriers near the Taiwan Strait during the peak of the 1996 cross-strait crisis, when Beijing test-fired live missiles into waters around the island, fully reflected US concerns about stability in the strait.

The premier said that in his view, the sharp difference in size between Taiwan and mainland China makes the formula used to reintegrate East and West Germany inapplicable to the two sides of the strait.

He appealed for international support, including that of the European Union, for Taiwan's eight-year-old bid to enter the World Trade Organization and its efforts to join the United Nations, stressing the island's democracy and its economic clout.
As to the regional financial woes that swept many of Taiwan's neighbors, Siew said his administration's priority of economic stability is the main reason the island's economy wasn't overcome as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE LABOR DISPUTE CAUSING DELAYS TO FOREIGN SHIPPING (I)

TEXT.P: The stand-off between an Australian stevedoring company and the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA) has caused many delays in shipments and inconvenience to foreign shipping companies.

In an interview with the CNA, Frank Chang, representative of Taiwan's Yang Ming Transport Corp. in Sydney, said Yang Ming's ships plying between Australia, Japan, and South Korea have been disrupted due to strikes by Australian waterfront workers against the Patrick Stevedore Co.

There have been some delays in shipments between Taiwan and Australia, Chang said, adding that P&O Ports' terminals have been overwhelmed by container cargoes that have been rerouted to avoid Patrick's ports.
Patrick and P&O Ports control about 95 percent of the container and the car transport markets in Australia.

The shipment delays have caused considerable impact on Australia's exports, and analysts say if the problem cannot be resolved in the near future, the image of Australia as reliable exporter could be damaged.

Australia is fighting an uphill battle to reform its inefficient waterfront industry, but the country's radical maritime unions, backed by international labor groups and the opposition Labor Party, are determined to resist the tide.
The reformists come from some big stevedoring and shipping firms because they are fed up with the MUA monopolizing the waterfront sector for more than a decade.
The coalition government under Prime Minister John Howard has had an agenda to reform the industry since it won the general election in March 1996, ending the 13-year reign of the Labor Party.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has also expressed its support for any action that will improve waterfront efficiency.

Analysts said the MUA and its members are so inefficient that they only handle an average 18.5 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) per hour, much lower than the international standard of 25 TEUs per hour.

Shipping companies said that compared to Asian countries, the 18.5 TEUs are very low because the average figure in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Singapore and Malaysia ranges from 27 to 35 TEUs per hour.
"How can Australia compete with other countries, especially Asian countries, in the world market if its exporters have to suffer such low handling rates at Australian ports?" one analyst asked.
"The cargo handling volume at Australian ports is an industry joke among shipping and stevedoring firms in Asia, and Australia has become a third-rate country in this respect," another said.
Maritime wages in Australia are much higher than in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Korea and other Asian countries.
Moreover, cargo handling at Australian ports is overmanned thanks to the MUA monopoly, causing unreasonably high costs for Australian stevedoring firms, according to the analysts.
It was apparently with this in mind that Patrick Stevedores tried to raise cargo handling to 25 TEUs through its MUA workers, but the workers would not cooperate, preferring their current rate.
After talks broke down in March, MUA workers staged a series of strikes in Patrick's terminals, causing the company to lose business and resulting in delays in cargo handling for its clients.
Patrick then sacked its entire workforce of 1,400 full-time workers and 600 part-time employees throughout Australia on April 8.

The mass lay-off, the first of its kind in the history of Australian industrial relations, sparked immediate and widespread protest and anger from the MUA, which succeeded in getting a federal court injunction ordering Patrick to reinstate the dismissed workers.

Patrick ignored the injunction and employed secretly trained scab labor to handle its stevedoring at terminals in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, and Fremantle, using private goons and attack dogs to keep the sacked union workers out. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE LABOR DISPUTE (II)

TEXT.P: To counter the MUA picket lines, Patrick chartered helicopters to airlift its scab workers into the terminals, prompting MUA National Secretary John Coombs to say that his union will launch a fresh wave of legal moves against Patrick, and against Workplace Minister Peter Reith.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), the biggest union in this country, has expressed its strong support for the MUA while opposition leader Kim Beazley has criticized Howard's coalition government, saying: "The result of this (sacking) is going to be a sense of insecurity among Australian workers, and devastation to the family lives of 1,400 Australian workers."

The MUA has also received support from the London-based International Trade Federation and the International Transport Workers Federation, the Brussels-based International Trade Union, and from Japanese and Dutch union members.
These foreign union groups said they will boycott Patrick's operations in foreign ports so that the company cannot do business outside Australia.
But Reith said the Australian government will seek legal action against these foreign union groups to prevent them from undermining Patrick's operations.

Last week, John Howard accused the MUA and its members of hindering government efforts to reform the waterfront, saying that reform is necessary to create jobs, boost Australian exports and increase competitiveness.
He declared that his government is prepared to stand up to the MUA in the interest of Australian jobs.

If the government is truly serious in its support for Patrick in its fight against the MUA and its many supporters, including some of the world's most powerful union organizations, then the reforms might be achieved, otherwise, Australia will lose the chance of reforming the waterfront for at least another generation, some analysts say.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA YING-JEOU AGAIN URGED TO ENTER TAIPEI MAYORAL RACE

TEXT.P: Former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou on Saturday refused to comment on another call urging him to run in the Taipei mayoral election slated for the year-end.

In its annual meeting on Saturday, the Society for Strategic Studies of the Republic of China passed a motion to encourage the popular former justice minister to run as the ruling Kuomintang's challenger to incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party.

Ma, who has denied on numerous occasions the possibility of his entering the Taipei mayoral race, was present at the meeting as a guest to deliver a speech. He declined to comment on the call after the meeting.
The motion listed reasons why its members believe Ma Ying-jeou, now a deputy professor of law at National Chengchi University, should change his mind and contest the Taipei mayoral election.
It said that Ma should run to comply with the people's will, as a variety of public opinion polls have shown Ma enjoys more support than Chen among the residents of Taipei.

It went on to say that Ma should respond to his party's will since the KMT's Taipei committee has expressed the hope that Ma will represent the party and recover the post of Taipei mayor that the KMT lost some three years. The motion also urged Ma to run on the grounds that his father, Ma Ho-ling, also supports his candidacy.
Ma Ho-ling has said that if the people, the KMT and society ask his son to enter the Taipei mayoral race, then Ma Ying-jeou has no reason to say no.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND JOURNALISTS WELOCME TO VISIT TAIWAN FOR NEWS COVERAGE

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese journalists are welcome to cover news events in Taiwan, ROC government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said on Saturday.

Chen made the remarks in response to a United Daily News (UDN) report that major mainland news media plan to send reporters to Taiwan for long-term news coverage in line with the development of substantive relations across the Taiwan Strait.

The paper quoted mainland sources as saying that each mainland news organization is expected to assign several of its journalists to work in rotation now that Taiwan has yet to open its doors for mainland media to post resident correspondents on its soil.

The report said major central-level mainland media, including Xinhua News Agency, China News Agency, the People's Daily and China Central Television Station, are drawing up personnel dispatch plans, which will then be sent to mainland authorities in charge of Taiwan affairs for approval.
"With Taiwan's support, it won't be a problem for mainland media to send journalists to Taiwan to work in rotation," a mainland official was quoted as telling the UDN.

Commenting on the report, Chen said promoting cross-strait news exchanges has been the ROC government's established policy. "It is also one of the eight priority tasks of the Government Information Office (GIO)," he noted.

The GIO director-general further pointed pointed out that the government has long asked mainland China to allow Taiwan media post resident reporters on the mainland. Beijing, however, has been reluctant to agree to the proposal.

Noting that Taiwan is an open society, Chen said Taiwan will be delighted to see mainland media send more journalists to cover news events on the island and to give more timely, accurate reports on various aspects of developments and lives here.

Meanwhile, Mainalnd Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh said Taiwan has opened its doors for mainland journalists to come for news coverage since September 1991. But so far only slightly more than 100 mainland media professionals have visited Taiwan for sightseeing or coverage of specific news events.

In contrast, Chang said, Taiwan media have been far more active in covering mainland news events. Major Taiwan news organizations, including CNA and UDN, have regularly sent their staff reporters to work in rotation on the mainland. Taiwan media have also consistently given detailed, updated reports on the latest mainland news events, market trends or everday lives. "In comparison, mainland media have seldom run in-depth reports on Taiwan. They have even often given misleading or biased reports on the current Taiwan situation," Chang noted.
Against this background, Chang said, the MAC welcomes the reported mainland plans to send more journalists to Taiwan for news coverage.

Under current Taiwan regulations, mainland reporters can file applications with the GIO for permission to cover news on the island. Each mainland reporter can stay here up to two months. At present, mainland reporters must file applications one month before their scheduled arrival dates. Starting July 1 this year, the processing time will be shortened as the Bureau of Entry and Exit has decided to offer single-stop services for prospective mainland visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: NYE'S PROPOSAL FOR CHANGE IN US CHINA POLICY CRITICIZED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Two experts at the Heritage Foundation on Saturday rebutted the proposal made by former US Assistant Secretary of Defense Joseph S. Nye that the US government should clear its current China policy of ambiguity, stressing that such a move would cause disaster rather than prevent it.

Kim Holmes and Stephen Yates said in a jointly written letter published in Saturday's edition of the Washington Post that the proposals in Nye's "Taiwan Deal," which was carried in the March 8 edition of the same prestigious newspaper, would not serve to bring Washington, Taipei and Beijing back from the brink of disaster as he had claimed.

Nye had proposed that the United States should urge Taiwan to forswear any steps toward independence and that Washington should state, as a matter of US policy, that it would not recognize or defend Taiwan should the island declare independence. In return, he said, Beijing should agree to give the Republic of China more "international living space."

The two experts at the foundation said that although Nye believes the deal would "bring Washington, Taipei and Beijing back from the brink of disaster allegedly brought on not only by the 'ambiguity' of US policy but by the demands of Taiwan's democratic government for more international recognition," the agreement would "not prevent disaster, but it certainly could cause it."

"If implemented, the initiative would increase the chances of conflict, embolden the Chinese to pressure the Taiwanese, isolate Taiwan and drag the United States into the middle of a negotiating process that it intentionally, and wisely, has avoided," they said.

Holmes and Yates said that Taiwan today is a democracy with a market economy and is a threat to no one, "while the other party in the dispute, the People's Republic of China, is an authoritarian one-party state that proliferates weapons of mass destruction and is a potential threat in the region."
"Why would the United States want to side with Beijing?" they asked.

They noted that if the United States gets involved directly in mainland China's campaign to prevent independence in Taiwan, it will have tipped the balance against Taipei. "The effect would not be to 'preserve democracy and peace' but to discredit democracy and create instability," they said.

"Once the United States interposed itself between Beijing and Taipei, it would involuntarily become a party to prolonging rather than resolving the conflict. This would set up the conditions for the deterioration of cross-strait relations, first by emboldening the mainland Chinese and then by frightening and possibly radicalizing the Taiwanese," they said, warning that if war breaks out in the Taiwan Strait, the United States, the chief mediator, might be dragged into it.

Beijing authorities would no doubt agree to such a new deal, Holmes and Yates said, adding, however, that there is little doubt that the government and people of Taiwan would not support it. "They would find it unfair that Taiwan must 'forswear independence' even though Beijing does not 'forswear the use of military force.' Beijing does not promise to promote Taiwan's participation in international organizations; it only 'will not oppose' Taiwan's participation in some organizations," the experts said.

"If the real challenge for the United States is simultaneously to preserve democracy and peace, the best way to proceed is not to isolate a democracy on behalf of an authoritarian one-party state, but to counter Beijing's efforts to isolate Taiwan internationally and, as required by the Taiwan Relations Act, assist Taiwan in deterring potential military aggression," they said.
"The best way to preserve peace and democracy is not for the United States to intercede on Beijing's behalf, but to urge both sides to settle their differences peacefully," they concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S LARGEST WAVE BASIN BEING BUILT BY CHENG KUNG U.
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, April 11 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University (CKU) is currently building the world's largest wave basin in the coastal An-nan district of Tainan to help bolster Taiwan's standards of coastal structure testing and the evaluation of relevant engineering projects.

Researchers at CKU's Hydraulic Engineering Institute will use the giant wave basin -- a long reservoir 180 meters in length, 80 meters in width and 1.5 meters in depth -- to conduct experiments on topographic changes and sediment transport for the Formosa Group on a contract basis, said institute director Professor Huang Huang-huei.

The experiments will be performed using an army of irregular wave makers in the basin in order to find out how the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant that Formosa Plastics is developing in the Yunlin Offshore Industrial Zone in central Taiwan will affect the shoreline there, said Huang.
The building of the An-nan wave basin will efficiently expedite topographic change and sediment transport experiments in the coastal area, he said.

Huang noted that CKU has engaged in such experiments with smaller equipment for six years under the auspices of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, which supports the development of the Sixth Naphtha Cracker.
The experiments in the new basin will be carried out for 25 years and be financed mainly by the Formosa Group, he said.

Meanwhile, a wave flume, touted as the world's second longest, is also being built opposite the wave basin at the new CKU campus in An-nan, mainly for the performance of sand liquefaction experiments and to learn more about the impact earthquakes have on beachfront structures and about the safety of harbor installations, according to Huang.
The 300-meter wave flume will be 24 meters shorter than the world's longest one in Hannover, Germany.
Huang joked that the wave flume, once operational, could be a cradle for nurturing world-class boat racers.
Both the wave basin and the wave flume, key projects in CKU's hydraulic engineering experimental plant being built on the An-nan campus, are expected to be completed and become operational in July.
CKU is developing the new campus in a vast coastal area of 75 hectares. Land-reclamation work has so far been completed on 11 hectares, said Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAN RELIGION PREVENT SOCIAL ORDER FROM WORSENING?

TEXT.P: The arrival in Taipei, the capital of Taiwan, on Friday of a priceless religious relic -- a tooth of Buddha -- has lifted the spirits of Buddhists islandwide but also prompted criticism that the elaborate activities surrounding the arrival are promoting superstition.

Thousands of followers of Buddha, including a number of celebrities and political heavyweights, greeted what they regard as one of the world's most precious relics with reverence and an ancient ceremony, in which long-haired women scattered flowers and placed their hair on the ground as the reliquary containing the holy tooth passed by to show their highest respects to it.

A high-profile mission headed by Fokuangshan's abbot Hsin Yun -- comprising over 200 devout Buddhists, including Senior Presidential Adviser Wu Poh-hsiung and Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Dun-yih -- escorted the sacred relic from Bangkok to its Taipei destination, Fokuangshan's branch temple near suburban Taipei's Sungshan Train Station. It will available there for three months for local people to venerate before being moved to another shrine at Fokuangshan until a temple is built in suburban Taipei to house it.
Despite an ecstatic welcome from well-wishers from around the country, the grand procession from the airport to branch temple encountered a small roadblock.

Dozens of members of a local political party rushed onto the road, blockading the procession. They scattered leaflets and held up protest flags and slogan boards, telling those lining the procession route, "We want a new country, not an old Buddha's tooth."

Criticism of the religious event has been seen not only on the streets but also in the Legislative Yuan, mass media and Internet. Arguments both for and against the magnificent activities surrounding the relic's arrival have centered on the appropriateness of political leaders' passionate involvement in religious events.

Premier Vincent Siew, Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan, Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh and Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen were among those greeting the arrival of the relic at the airport, while Vice President Lien Chan took part in a large-scale Buddhist ritual in Taipei on Saturday to celebrate the arrival of the tooth and to pray to Buddha for the country's peace and prosperity.

About 1,200 years ago, the Tang dynasty emperor Hsien Chung ordered a similar activity, attempting to save China from decay by sending out parties to search for Buddhist relics, according to Chinese historic literature.

The documents indicate that the prestigious legislative leader Han Yu (A.D. 768-824) tried to stop the attempt by submitting a written admonition to the emperor that censured the planned act as absurd.
The upright official's report also reproached the emperor for using useless and unrealistic medicines to cure a sick country.

The admonition was successful in getting the emperor to call off the costly mission, said two members of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, who criticized the current government for supporting something that an ancient sage had stopped.

One of the two assemblymen, Chen Kuo-chung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, asked Provincial Department of Civil Affairs Chief Chen Chin-Hsin at a assembly meeting on Thursday, "Can a tooth save a sick society?"

Premier Siew, who has been accused of helping plant superstitions on the island over his participation in events relating to the holy tooth, defended himself by saying that as a devout Buddhist, his support of the activities for greeting the tooth was to show his respect for the sacred relic.
He said that such religious activities teach respect for many cultures and can help prevent morality from fading and the social environment from deteriorating.
Echoing Siew's defense, Interior Minister Huang stressed that ethical religions never have a bad impact on society but rather can contribute to peace.
"Disturbed minds can usually be calmed by a religious power," he said, adding that Taiwan is now conducting spiritual reforms and that these can be achieved through religious activities.
On Saturday at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei, a magnificent gathering was held to celebrate the arrival of Buddha's tooth and to pray for peace and the prosperity of the country.
Thousands turned out for the ceremony, hoping that the miraculous powers many believe the relic contains will bring them better lives and the country strength and stability.
Does the tooth have such powers? Will the prayers be answered? Several scholars in Buddhism stressed recently that it's more important.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WELCOMES JAPAN'S REINSTATEMENT OF VISA PRIVILEGES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China welcomes the Japanese House of Councilors' approval of a bill on recognition of the validity of ROC passports and resumption of 72-hour visa-free entry for prospective Taiwan visitors, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Saturday.

The Japanese upper house passed the bill amending Japan's current entry and exit statute on Friday. The amendment bill is also expected to clear the House of Representatives, or the lower house of the Japanese Diet, in the near future.

"We hope the Japanese Diet will pass the bill during its current session so that it can be implemented soon to facilitate tourist, civilian and commercial exchanges between Taiwan and Japan," Roy said.

Under the newly amended regulations, ROC passports will be considered valid documents, and visa stamps will be printed directly into the passports themselves, rather than being stamped on separate "entry certificates" as is currently the case.

The Japanese government referred the amendment bill to the Diet on March 24 as part of its effort to cut red tape. "We welcome this bill because it will contribute to growth of bilateral relations and exchanges in the absence of diplomatic ties," Wu noted.

Tokyo's decision to amend its current entry-exit statute is being seen as a significant step to simplify its "overstretched visa handling operations," which began after Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing on Sept. 29, 1972.

Since then, the Japanese government has never treated ROC passports as valid official documents, which means Japanese immigration authorities can only grant ROC tourists "entry certificates" to visit Japan, rather than visas.
In 1990, Japan also suspended its 72-hour visa-free privileges to Taiwan tourists in transit through Japan.
These measures placed an intolerable burden on the operations of Japan's authorities in charge of applications submitted by ROC passport-holders.
Japan took the step to improve visa services only after intense lobbying by an influential group of pro-Taiwan lawmakers who have been pushing for better civilian ties between Taiwan and Japan.
Statistics from the Japanese Entry & Exit Bureau show that 859,000 Taiwan tourists visited Japan in 1997, up by 100,000 from the year-earlier level.

The popularity of Japanese tours among Taiwan people has forced the Japanese embassy in Thailand, which is authorized to deal with entry applications from ROC citizens, to also appeal for simplification of the processing operation.

Pro-Taiwan Japanese lawmakers called on the Tokyo government to amend relevant statutes to allow for the resumption of 72-hour visa-free privileges and changes in the method of issuing entry documents to Taiwan visitors. (By Sofia Wu) ENDITM ZCZC CEP021 04-11-98 SPENDING NO CURE FOR 'JAPANESE DISEASE': ANALYST
Ottawa, April 10 (CNA) A Canadian analyst suspects that the Japanese economic disease has no easy cure and may even be permanent.
Richard Gwyn, who writes regularly for the mass-circulation Toronto Star newspaper, on Friday cited a sign that's been appearing in Japanese classrooms this school year: "Let Us All Be Individuals."
"A call to individualism that appears in every classroom at the same time?" Gwyn asked. "How do you achieve individualism by ordering everyone to act like individuals?" he questioned.

He observed that convincing the Japanese to behave in an un-Japanese way is a great challenge now confronting Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and -- the real power in Japan -- the bureaucrats and industrialists.

The nation that had been dubbed "Number One" is infected by what's being called "the Japanese disease." This year, for the first time in more than two decades, its economy will actually shrink. Real estate values are down by a third. Last week, Moody's downgraded its rating for Japanese banks to D, the same level as for Third World banks, Gwyn pointed out.

He said that many experts, including US President Bill Clinton and the World Bank, are right in their diagnosis of what's needed to cure Japan's ills, which have gone on now for eight years: massive spending.
But their prescription may be faulty, he cautioned. With so much in savings, both personal and national, Japan already has all the spending power it needs.

The Japanese, however, are behaving in a thoroughly Japanese way, he said. After all those post-war decades of hard work and self-sacrifice, the Japanese people have lost -- more accurately, never acquired -- the western habit of wild consumerism, he said.

It doesn't help that the entire economy is structured to discourage consumer spending in order to emphasize exporting, he noted. The way this is done is by massive bureaucratic regulation. According to the Japanese Fair Trade Commission, the country ranks 35th in the world, even behind Russia, in the proportion of its economy that's controlled by bureaucratic regulation -- 30 percent as against just 7 percent in the United States, he cited.

There's another factor that's probably the most important of all, he continued. As a result of small families and of nil immigration, Japan is now the oldest society in the industrialized world. "Old societies are conservative ones. So they don't spend wildly. Small houses -- the result of the intense regulation of land use -- further discourage people from piling up consumer goods," he pointed out.

Hashimoto has promised a "significant" cut in taxes to encourage people to open their pocketbooks, Gwyn noted, but added, however, that the Japanese have been Japanese for too long for them to be able to change their character and turn into free-spending consumers.
"You'd have to guess, that's to say, that the 'Japanese disease' is permanent," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU, RUSSIA REACH TEXTILE ACCORD

TEXT.P: The European Union (EU) Commission has reached an agreement with Russia to end quotas on imports of textile products, the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) said in a report on Friday.
The accord by the commission must be approved by EU countries to take effect.
If approved, the agreement will abolish in May EU quotas on imports of a range of Russian textile products, including cotton and linen fabrics, and Russian quotas on imports of EU carpets.
"This is a major step forward for EU-Russia trade in textiles," the commission said. "Like all good agreements, this one will be to the mutual advantage of both parties."
EU imports of textile products from Russia were worth 210 million European Currency Units (XEU) in 1996, the WTO report said.

EU exports of textile products to Russia were worth XEU700 million in 1996. EU exports of carpets to Russia -- the only EU textile exports affected by Russian import quotas -- accounted for XEU200 million of the total.
On March 19, Russia imposed a one-year limit on imports of EU carpets. The limit amounts to XEU93 million.
Under the draft agreement, Russia will abolish that limit and the 15-member EU will abolish all its quotas on imports of Russian textile products beginning May 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE WATERFRONT WAR EXPANDING TO SECOND FRONT

TEXT.P: The Australian waterfront battle looks set to expand to a second front now that Australia's largest stevedoring firm, P&O Ports, has joined Patrick Stevedores in demanding talks on work-practice reform with the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA).

MUA National Secretary John Coombs accused P&O Ports Friday of taking the advantage of the industrial turmoil between the MUA and Patrick to demand talks on waterside reform, local media reported Saturday.

He described the P&O Ports' demand as "absolutely unrealistic" because the MUA and its members are engaged in a waterfront war with Patrick Stevedores, the second largest employer in Australian ports.

Patrick has sacked all of its 1,400 full-time workers and 600 part-time workers and started using non-union workers to do stevedoring for the company, the first time such a situation has occurred in Australia in about 100 years.
P&O and Patrick control about 95 percent of Australia's waterfront and transport operations between the two of them.
More troubles are expected in the coming days because Patrick intends to use non-union labor to load and unload cargoes at its terminals in Sydney, Melbourne, Fremantle, Brisbane and other ports.

In the meantime, the Australian government has established a legal team in London to sue international union officials under British law if they try to induce shipping companies to break contracts and boycott Patrick Stevedores' operations or shipments.

Two union groups in London -- the International Transport Workers Federation and the International Trade Federation -- have expressed support for the MUA and the sacked workers and have threatened to boycott Patrick so that the stevedoring company cannot operate in Britain or other foreign countries.

Waiting on the sidelines is SeaLand Inc. of the United States. SeaLand's Australian operations general manager Andy Andrews told the mass circulation newspaper The Australian that the US company would be interested in taking over Patrick's loading operations at major Australian ports if Patrick wants to sell them.
"We would consider going into Patrick's ground. We would not rule anything out in the break bulk operations," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 120 ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS TO BE SENT TO MATSU

TEXT.P: The government will send 120 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants from southeastern Fujian Province to the offshore island of Matsu, where they will await repatriation.
The decision was made following three months of nonaction by mainland authorities over the return of illegal immigrants in Taiwan.

Some 90 illegals held at the Hsinchu Detention Center and 30 others detained in Ilan have been notified that they will be sent to Matsu. It is known that four hijackers, including Liu Baocai, who are currently on parole after serving jail terms in Taiwan, were not among those on the list.

Although mainland Chinese authorities picked up over 200 illegal immigrants on the eve of the Lunar New Year in late January, they have since failed to respond to requests to pick up additional detainees.
With the recent roundup of several groups of illegal mainlanders in northern and northeastern Taiwan, occupancy at the Hsinchu and Ilan detention centers has soared.

And with the coming of summer, crowded conditions in the two detention centers pose potential hygiene and management problems. So the government has decided to transfer some of the detainees to Matsu in order to facilitate their return to the mainland as soon as repatriation efforts resume.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF RAILWAY PASSENGERS ON RISE

TEXT.P: Following a series of major air accidents since the beginning of this year, the railway has again become the most popular means of long-distance transport among travelers islandwide.

According to the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA), the number of railway passengers has posted an average 30 percent rise in the first three months of the year on an annual basis, and its first-quarter income also increased by 11 percent over the same period of last year.

The Taipei-Kaohsiung route has seen the largest growth in terms of the number of travelers during the first quarter, with the daily average passenger load rising to 2,509, from 1,848 recorded in the same period of 1997. The number of passengers on the Taipei-Tainan route also increased by 28 percent to a daily average of 2,021, while the growth rate for the Taipei-Taichung route stood around 14 percent, TRA tallies showed.
A TRA official attributed the newfound popularity of rail travel to the string of air crashes seen in February and March, as the largest increases have been registered on long-distance routes.
Kaohsiung, in southern Taiwan, is the island's second most populous city, while the central city of Taichung is the third largest.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TRADE: STRONG WTO BID
