TEXT.P: In Taiwan's most dramatic success to date in attempts to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), Taipei reached a far-reaching trade liberalization agreement with Washington on Feb. 20 and narrowly missed an accord with the European Union (EU) a week later.

Out of 26 WTO signatories which have requested bilateral talks, Taiwan has now reached deals with all but two, the EU and Switzerland. Suddenly, the organization's members are faced with the surprising scenario of Taiwan joining before mainland China.

To be sure, hurdles remain. Negotiations with the EU and Switzerland must be finalized, and only 17 of the 26 WTO signatories have formally signed a second set of agreements with Taiwan addressing its terms of entry. Further down the road, a vote by two-thirds of WTO contracting parties, and ratification by Taiwan's Legislature, will be necessary for formal membership.

If all goes well, and if a WTO working party scheduled for May 8 resolves some of the remaining issues, optimists hope that Taiwan can join the organization by year's end -- and before Beijing, according to a report of the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU).

Until recently, accepted wisdom held that mainland China must come first, otherwise there would be a diplomatic furor. Beijing considers Taiwan a renegade province and consistently opposes its formal involvement in international diplomatic or economic organizations.

But lately, senior officials have flouted Beijing's primacy, the EIU report said. Richard Fischer, US deputy trade representative, has told mainland Chinese officials directly that Taiwan's bid will not be tied to Beijing's accession.

Likewise, WTO Director-General Renato Ruggiero has repeatedly insisted that Taiwan's bid does not depend on mainland China, saying, "At the World Trade Organization we are not, fortunately, ruled by political principles."
To date, Beijing has been firm and consistent in its opposition to Taiwan's early membership. Its protests could yet become hysterical if it looks like the WTO is ready to accept Taiwan.

Regardless, Taiwan's progress plays into the WTO's interests. Trade negotiators can use the threat of Taiwan's membership to prod the mainland's moribund efforts at trade reform. Beijing may yet enter first, but in the meantime, the WTO is cleverly inducing both sides to accelerate their trade concessions, the EIU report pointed out.

Whatever the timing of its entry, Taiwan has already included major trade concessions in its bid. Only bilateral trade in agricultural products -- namely trade in pork, rice and chicken -- will be opened regardless of Taiwan's accession. Liberalization in other areas, listed below, will be triggered by Taiwan's entry into the WTO.

-- Chemical and pharmaceuticals. By the year 2002, with some exceptions by 2004, Taiwan agreed to eliminate tariffs on raw materials and pharmaceuticals while cutting rates for intermediary substances to 5.5 percent and manufactured chemicals to 6.5 percent.
-- Financial services. In the area of banking, insurance and securities, Taiwan guaranteed full market access and national treatment for US companies by 2000.

-- Government procurement. Taipei also agreed to abide by international transparency norms on government bidding processes. This covers US$15.4 billion of planned infrastructure projects, including telecoms, power and rail transport projects.
-- Industrial tariffs. Taiwan agreed to lower industrial tariffs from the current 6.5 percent to 4.9 percent by 2002 and to 4.7 percent by 2004.

-- Motor vehicles. Taiwan agreed to reduce tariffs on imported small vehicles to 20 percent, to eliminate a 9 percent subsidy on domestically designed auto components, to cancel local content requirements on auto parts and to ease restrictions on car leasing (effective over a 10-year period). Taiwan granted the United States rights to sell 158,000 cars annually, increasing by 20 percent per year thereafter. Taiwan also agreed to lower the ceiling for local parts in auto manufacturing to 40 percent from 50 percent by the end of 1998.

-- Privatization of monopoly board. Taiwan is selling off the state monopoly that controls sales and distribution of alcohol and tobacco, a change which will eliminate discriminatory treatment of imports of these goods. Tariffs on spirits will be eliminated by 2000; tariffs on beer will go by 2005. Tariffs on wine will fall to 10 percent by 2002.
-- Telecoms. The interconnection fee of NT$1.60 (five US cents) per minute that state-run Chunghwa Telecom charges private cellular phone operators will go down to NT$1.15 per minute in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG HAS GOOD REASON TO BE VIGILANT AGAINST BEIJING

TEXT.P: Beijing has stumbled in Hong Kong, giving people there good reason to be vigilant over their future, a major Canadian newspaper commented Saturday.

The Globe and Mail said common sense dictates that mainland China has many reasons to be on its best behavior in Hong Kong, one of which being that Beijing has its eye on a "much bigger prize than Kong Kong."

"If there is any prospect at all of enticing Taiwan back into a single China, it is only through making a success of the administration of Hong Kong and respecting the Basic Law, the region's constitution," the Mail said in an editorial.
The editorial pointed out that it is precisely with regard to the Basic Law that Beijing may have recently made a major blunder.

It noted the Basic Law includes an article stating that all central government offices "shall abide by the laws of the Region." Yet this week, it added, one of the last acts of the outgoing, Beijing-appointed legislature was to grant an exemption from the region's laws to the agents and offices of the Beijing government.

The mainland Chinese government claimed it is merely a housekeeping measure conferring on the new government the same immunities enjoyed by the British Crown under the colonial administration. Reason to doubt this claim is offered by both the reason for the legislation and the method of its adoption, the Mail pointed out.

Emily Lau, a former legislator, had officially requested the file compiled on her by the semiofficial Xinhua News Agency. Xinhua refused to produce the file, and the government refused to prosecute under Hong Kong's privacy laws. Instead, the retroactive exemption for all central government agencies was passed.

"It looks like a conscious decision to remove the actions of Beijing's servants from the scrutiny of independent courts and accountability under the law," said the editorial. And the impression is only reinforced by the unseemly haste with which the law was adopted, it stressed.
All three readings of the exemption law occurred in one day in spite of vocal opposition of the bar association, the law society and many other groups, it noted.

In conclusion, the daily said it is too early to tell whether incidents like this are precursors to a slow, insidious change in the nature of Hong Kong's institutions. "Hong Kong people, however, have good reason to be vigilant," it advised.

DOC.HEADLINE: DELEGATION TO EXPLORE TRADE OPPORTUNITIES IN 3 ASIAN NATIONS

TEXT.P: A delegation left Taiwan on Sunday for a weeklong visit of three Asian nations to explore business opportunities there.
The delegation, comprised of more than 30 local corporate executives, will visit South Korea, Thailand and Malaysia to seek merger opportunities with local enterprises in the three nations.

A spokesman for Core Pacific Securities, which is leading the delegation, said that in the wake of financial storm that swept through Asia in mid-1997, businesses in South Korea, Thailand and Malaysia were hard hit by high interest rates and a tightening of credit. As those businesses are readjusting investment plans, and are eager for influxes of foreign capital, a number of lucrative merger opportunities for Taiwan investors have appeared.
The delegation arrived in Seoul on Sunday night, where members will meet South Korean trade officials and visit major enterprises there.

The delegation will then head to Bangkok on Wednesday night for meetings with Thailand's vice premier and trade officials. The group will also explore trade opportunities in the local finance, steel, electronics, petrochemicals and real estate industries.
On Friday, the delegation will arrive on its last stop in Kuala Lumpur where it is scheduled to inspect the finance, insurance, steel, leisure, shopping mall and construction industries.

Core Pacific said that Taiwan has sound business management and ample capital, which have allowed it to emerge from the financial crisis largely unscathed. It said that now is the best time for local businesses to expand by buying into enterprises in the three neighboring countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FMD OUTBREAK COSTS FOOD INDUSTRY US$1.81 BILLION

TEXT.P: The outbreak of food-and-mouth disease (FMD) at Taiwan hog farms in March last year has cost the local food industry nearly NT$60 billion (US$1.81 billion), the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said on Sunday.
IDB officials estimated that the domestic food industry will need at least seven years before production is restored to pre-epidemic levels.
The officials noted that overall annual production for the food industry dropped to NT$495.8 billion (US$15.02 billion) in 1997 from NT$555.6 billion (US$16.82 billion) the previous year.

The FMD outbreak has most affected the meat processing, feed and frozen food sectors. Taiwan exports of pork products to Japan were halted following a ban on those items by Tokyo as a result of the epidemic, causing losses of over NT$40 billion (US$1.21 billion).

The domestic market imported NT$93.3 billion worth of food products last year, surpassing the value of food exports for the first time. The amount of food exports as a percentage of total exports also dropped to 12 percent from 17 percent last year.

The local food industry poured NT$38.9 billion (US$1.18 billion) into mainland Chinese and overseas markets last year, the highest level seen in five years and surpassing its local investment of NT$38.7 billion (US$1.17 billion).

The IDB predicted it will be almost impossible for pork exports to return to the level seen before the outbreak of FMD last year. With the local market demand showing limited growth, prices for raw materials increasing steadily, and businesses possessing limited capacity to conduct research and development, it will be difficult for the domestic food industry to recover.

The officials said the value of imported food items could top NT$100 billion (US$3 billion) this year. With its expected entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), Taiwan's market will be opened wider and the ratio of imported foods will increase, they predicted.
The officials said that with rising land prices, and soaring labor costs, the willingness of local food industry enterprises to invest in Taiwan will be lowered.
In comparison, local food industry businesses, lured by the emerging market in mainland China and its cheaper land, raw material and production costs, will increasingly seek opportunities there.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO HELP TAIWAN FIRMS FIGHT AGAINST SRAM CHARGES

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said Sunday that his ministry will help local firms lodge an appeal in the US Federal Court of International Trade for reversal of a ruling to impose anti-dumping duties on Taiwan-made static random access memory (SRAM) chips.

In the face of an announcement expected next week by the US Department of Commerce that punitive tariff rates will be levied against the Taiwan companies, Wang said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), after thorough consultations with local SRAM makers and industry associations, has decided to challenge the ruling by the US International Trade Commission (ITC). The commission recently upheld an earlier judgment that Taiwan SRAM firms should be subject to US anti-dumping duties, ranging from 7.59 percent to 113.85 percent.
Wang said the MOEA will do its best to help Taiwan firms conduct relevant judicial processes and clearly convey their position to the ITC.

Attributing the root cause of charges by US competitors that Taiwan SRAM makers sold products in the United States below fair market value to differences in calculating production costs, Wang said Taiwan will ask the ITC to review the case based on "generally accepted accounting procedures."

Under ROC law, after-tax dividends delivered by a company to its employees are not viewed as part of the workers' wages, thus resulting in lower production costs for Taiwan SRAM makers, the economic minister elaborated.

Wang went on to say that the MOEA will help local firms set up an internationally recognized accounting system as soon as possible and push them to forge joint venture partnerships with foreign counterparts as a way of reducing the recurrence of such incidents.

Wang also expressed concern at news reaching here over the weekend that the United States and the European Union are likely to raise anti-dumping charges on Taiwan-made dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips as well. He said the impetus of the potential threat will be greater than that for the SRAM charges, as DRAMs are one of Taiwan's major export items, adding that the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the MOEA will continue to closely monitor developments.

BOFT Director-General Chen Ruei-long urged Taiwan businesses to quickly follow the lead of US and Japanese firms in establishing a system to counter anti-dumping charges from overseas competitors. Such a system, which would involve detailed analyses of production costs and pricing policies, will help them respond rapidly and effectively to those accusations, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUP LASHES OUT AT MINING IN TAROKO NATIONAL PARK

TEXT.P: An environmental group on Sunday lashed out at the government for allowing marble mining in Taroko National Park in eastern Taiwan, saying it has destroyed the beauty of the world-class scenic area.

Liu Ming-lung, secretary-general of the Environmental Quality Foundation, displayed a series of photographs depicting the battered landscape at the park as a result of the mining, saying he can no longer bear to witness the damage being done there.

Liu said the latest data shows there were 22 mining areas, involving 4,039 hectares, in operation in the national park as of the end of 1996. Among them, 16 have received approval to extend their mining privileges.
He lamented that one of Taiwan's natural scenic wonders has become a center for the mining of marble.

The most outrageous case, Liu said, was a decision by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to extend the privilege of the Retired Servicemen's Engineering Agency (RSEA) to mine marble near one of the Taroko area's most beautiful spots, Swallow's Grotto.

He noted that the 22 mining sites were all established before the designation of the area as a national park, but criticized the fact that many operators have been allowed to extend their mining privileges since that time.

Liu said that only six approved operators are actually engaged in mining operations, while 13 have declared a moratorium, and the RSEA has never begun work at three mining areas where it holds privileges.

Liu claimed that, in fact, operators are not interested in mining at all. Rather, he said, they are biding their time in hopes of receiving a huge sum of money as compensation once the government announces a ban on mining in the Taroko National Park.
Liu urged the MOEA not only to stop issuing new licenses, but to revoke those licenses already in effect as well.
He said the RSEA, as an agency under the Executive Yuan, has a special responsibity to set an example by halting mining activity in the national park.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TRIPLE-WIN' PLAN PROPOSED TO HELP SE ASIA

TEXT.P: High-ranking officials of the Republic of China on Sunday called on authorities from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to meet as soon as possible in an attempt to help Southeast Asian nations through their financial troubles.

The proposal for what was called a "triple win" situation was made jointly by Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD); Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC); and Shi Hwei-yow, secretary-general of Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Speaking at a seminar sponsored by the Asia Pacific Industrial Management Research Council, Chiang suggested that the SEF, through consultations with its cross-strait counterpart, should invite Chinese mainland authorities and representatives from countries in Southeast Asia to hold a meeting as soon as possible to discuss the regional economic and financial situation.

The CEPD chief said participants of the meeting should work together to assist the Southeast Asian nations by helping them to issue government bonds in accordance with the resolutions passed at a meeting of an ad hoc group under the APEC Business Advisory Council (ABAC).

According to those resolutions, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and nations that have not been so severely hit by the financial turmoil, including the United States, Hong Kong, and Japan, should jointly provide guarantees to allow Southeast Asian countries to issue government bonds and hold regional financial forums to work out channels for multilateral consultations.

Chiang noted that, as Taiwan is part of Southeast Asia with US$37 billion in investments and close trade ties to countries in the region, the recent financial firestorm there has also had a big influence on Taiwan.
He added that, from an economic angle, joint efforts with mainland China in helping Southeast Asian countries are a "triple win" strategy.

Wu agreed that such a proposal can bring benefits to Taiwan, mainland and Southeast Asia. He proposed that the SEF contact the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to introduce the idea and to seek its inclusion on the agenda for a meeting with ARATS at the end of April.

Shi noted that cross-strait dialogue has been suspended for more than three years and that the SEF and ARATS have exchanged letters six times since February this year, with no concrete results. He attributed the lack of progress to the absence of specific goals for talks, and said the Southeast Asian financial meeting might help to ease hostilities.

Both President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew had earlier presented the idea of cross-strait cooperation to assist Southeast Asia, which has given rise to heated discussion among political affairs analysts and economists.

A delegation of scholars and government officials led by Shea Jia-dong, deputy governor of the Central Bank of China, left for the United States on Sunday to rally international support for the initiative.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLED FORMER MILITARY OFFICER ARRESTED

TEXT.P: ROC Navy authorities confirmed on Sunday that a former military officer who sneaked back to Taiwan from mainland China in early April has been arrested and is currently being detained at a military base in Tsoying, Kaohsiung County, according to the China Times Express on Sunday.

The report said military investigators are looking into why Wu Miao-huo returned to Taiwan after fleeing to the mainland aboard a ship in 1974, and whether he received training as a special agent while in the mainland.

Acting on tips, military investigators arrested Wu on April 9 as was attempting to register his domicile with Tahu Township authorities in central Miaoli County, the report said, adding that Wu, currently a military serviceman on active duty in mainland China, entered Taiwan on a mainland Chinese passport.

Under ROC law, military officers who flee to mainland China will be subject to execution if caught. But as Wu has lived on the mainland for more than 20 years, capital punishment is no longer applicable to his case, the report said.

It noted that relevant authorities are conducting a full investigation into Wu's motives for sneaking back to Taiwan and will make a decision on whether to expatriate him or to file legal charges, pending results of the inquiry.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE ROCKS LANYU ISLAND

TEXT.P: The Seismology Center under the Central Weather Bureau said on Sunday that an earthquake of magnitude 4.2 shook Taiwan's offshore Lanyu Island.
The temblor, with its epicenter located 28.4 kilometers southeast of Lanyu, struck at 7:52 a.m.
The underground center of the quake was located 20 kilometers under the sea surface.
There was no damage or casualties reported from Lanyu, where the temblor was recorded at magnitude 4.0.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR WARNS OF PLA SPYING ON ROC MILITARY DRILL

TEXT.P: Intelligence data shows mainland China may attempt to spy on a major military exercise that Taiwan plans to conduct later this month by simultaneously staging a submarine drill, Legislator Trong R. Chai warned on Sunday.

Chai, a Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker representing Chiayi, quoted "reliable intelligence sources" from the United States as saying the mainland Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) is planning to conduct a Kilo-class submarine combat drill in waters near eastern Taiwan. The drill will be timed to coincide with the Republic of China's massive "Han Kuang No. 14" joint-forces exercise along the eastern coast of the island.
The PLA submarines may take advantage of the drill to sneak into ROC territorial waters, putting Taiwan's air/naval defense and antisubmarine capabilities to the test, Chai warned.

Chai said that, according to the information he has obtained from "authoritative" US intelligence sources, one cutting-edge Kilo-class 636 submarine the PLA has recently secured from the Russian Federation, will join two other more conventional Kilo-class 877 submarines in the drill.

The PLA's choice of waters off eastern Taiwan for the maiden active-duty operations of its most advanced submarine, at a time when the ROC is conducting joint-forces war games, is a blatantly provocative move, Chai noted. He urged ROC military authorities to pay close attention to the scenario.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Monday declined to comment on Chai's allegations, on the grounds that the MND does not comment on intelligence-related speculation.

A Navy source reported on Monday that foreign warships and naval vessels, including submarines, from mainland China, the United States, Russia and Japan, have on occasion sailed near or passed through the Taiwan Strait on Taiwan's west side and the Pacific Ocean off the island's east coast.

In cases where the foreign military vessels were in proximity to but not inside the 12-mile zone around Taiwan demarcating ROC territorial waters, the ROC Navy remained on standby, keeping the passing objects under close surveillance but taking no action, the source revealed.
According to the MND, the Han Kuang No. 14 exercise will be held under low profile between late April and early May in coastal Hualien, eastern Taiwan.
The MND is intentionally keeping publicity surrounding the drill to a minimum so as to avoid adding fuel to tensions across the Taiwan Strait, observers said.

Unlike previous Han Kuang exercises, no demonstrations of advanced weaponry systems and military equipment or public displays of the armed forces' combat capabilities will be made during the upcoming drill, the MND sources said.

The 14th installment of the Han Kuang series will focus on testing the ROC military's air/naval defense tactics, electronic warfare capabilities, and command-and-control operations, the sources noted.
No government officials, lawmakers or media representatives will be invited to witness the drill, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, US MEET ON IPR CONSULTATIONS

TEXT.P: A four-day trade consultation meeting between Taiwan and the United States on disputed issues related to intellectual property rights (IPR) opened here on Monday.

Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-General Chen Ruei-long, Taiwan's chief delegate in the meeting, said Taiwan should not be placed back on the United States' annual "Special 301" list, as both the ROC government and the private sector have effectively implemented efforts in line with ROC laws to protect US intellectual property over the past year.

Chen said he will clearly explain this point to the US side and reiterate Taiwan's firm determination to continue carrying out such efforts during the course of the meeting, which will also be attended by officials from the ministries of finance, interior, education and foreign affairs, and representatives from the Directorate General of Customs.

David Burns, a senior official of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) office in charge of Asia-Pacific affairs who arrived here on Saturday, said that the United States has not yet made a final decision on this year's Special 301 list and that the major purpose of his current visit to Taiwan is to look into what efforts the ROC has made in protecting US intellectual goods and what remains to be done.

The United States is expected to make public this year's Special 301 list by the end of this month. Countries found to lack adequate IPR protective measures for US products will be named on the list, becoming subject to punitive trade sanctions.

A 1998 report on trade barriers released recently by the USTR showed that the number of Taiwan-made pirated goods seized by customs agents around the United States in 1997 was up more than 100 percent from 1996, raising concerns here that Taiwan may be once again cited by US trade officials on the Special 301 list.

Expressing concern that Taiwan's international image could be seriously tarnished if the island reappears on the list, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said it will present a concrete package of action guidelines to show Taiwan's determination in cracking down on commercial piracy in an effort to stay off the blacklist.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Sunday that relevant trade authorities will jointly set up a special task force to restructure the government's monitoring system for Taiwan exports as a way of effectively stemming outbound shipments of pirated goods and spare parts.

In addition to proposing that the United States and Taiwan sign an accord for the exchange of data on preventing commercial piracy, the BOFT will step up product inspection on companies with a record of IPR infringements, while exports by those companies will also be subject to stricter requirements, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF AUTHORIZED TO HANDLE CROSS-STRAIT INITIATIVES ON SE ASIAN CRISIS

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will be authorized to contact Beijing to enable mainland Chinese authorities to better understand the latest Taiwan initiative on joint cross-strait efforts to help Southeast Asian nations, sources from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Monday.

The SEF, a quasi-official intermediary body, will be authorized to send a letter to the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), the SEF's Beijing-based counterpart, to inform authorities there of details of the initiative, said Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman and spokesman for the Cabinet-level MAC, Taiwan's top agency in charge of formulating the government's mainland Chinese policies.

The initiative, presented by President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew in separate venues on April 7, calls for cross-strait cooperation to help Southeast Asian countries weather the recent financial turmoil in the region.

Upon spelling out the initiative, Lee stressed that the appeal is purely economic in nature without any political intentions. The ROC president looks forward to a positive response from Beijing to Taipei's goodwill proposal, Sheu noted.
The SEF will approach the ARATS "in black and white," so as to remove any possibility that Beijing could consider the initiative as merely "empty talk," Sheu continued.
Sheu, however, declined to specify when the letter will be sent, saying only that it will be delivered whenever the Beijing authorities make a positive response to the aid proposal.

In responding to the initiative, Sheu noted, mainland officials are welcome to voice their opinions and to forward suggestions of any kind. The meetings Taipei has proposed to convene involving officials from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and the Southeast Asian countries need not necessarily be held under the APEC framework, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TOUGHEST ON COMBATING SOFTWARE PIRATES

TEXT.P: Singapore has the best record in the Asia-Pacific region for combating software piracy, according to a survey by a leading Swiss business institute.
For three consecutive years, the International Institute for Management Development (IMD) has ranked Singapore as the top Asian nation in the protection of intellectual property rights.

In its latest survey, the institute ranked Singapore ahead of countries like Denmark, Austria, France, Japan, Australia, Belgium, Great Britain and Israel, in stamping out software piracy, The Straits Times reported Monday.
A copy of the survey report, which was published late last year, was made available to the Singapore-based newspaper only recently.
The IMD is the second institution in recent months to have ranked Singapore highly for its intellectual property protection.
Last October, the Hong Kong-based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy praised Singapore as having the toughest stand on software pirates in the Asia-Pacific.
Last year, Singapore police conducted 560 antipiracy raids in the city-state.
In many cases, the raids were conducted together with the Business Software Alliance, Software Publishers Association and Motion Picture Association.
The market value of pirated software seized last year was close to S$4 million, the Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB) said.
A TDB spokesman said that the Singapore government has already put in place a comprehensive program to protect intellectual property rights.
The elements include strong laws to protect owners and a set-up under the police aimed at assisting owners in raids.
"We also have an efficient and expeditious court procedure to facilitate enforcement, as well as stiff penalties," the spokesman was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE STEVEDORE FIRM WINS INITIAL BATTLE AGAINST MARITIME UNION

TEXT.P: The Australian government and Patrick Stevedores Ltd., a leading stevedoring company in Australia, have won the initial round in a tug of war against the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA), which is described as an inefficient but powerful union group in this country.

Patrick on Sunday succeeded in unloading all the containerized cargo aboard a vessel belonging to the government's Australian National Line at Port Botany near Sydney, marking the first time in 50 years that a merchant ship had been unloaded by nonunion workers on the Australian waterfront.
Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith told reporters that it was a decisive victory for the government and Patrick Stevedores.

But the MUA and its members are expected to continue their protest and picket lines along the terminals belonging to Patrick in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Fremantle in West Australia and other ports around the country.
Patrick chief executive Chris Corrigan said the successful unloading of containerized cargo in the Sydney port was the "final nail in the MUA's campaign to destroy my company."
But waterfront industry experts believed the confrontation between Patrick and the MUA will continue in the foreseeable future despite the initial success of the Australian government and Patrick.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA WORKS OUT HOG FARMING POLICY

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Monday that it has worked out a policy for the local hog industry in anticipation of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Chen Pao-chi, director of COA's Animal Industry Department, said the government will target operators raising between 1,000 and 5,000 hogs, and will help smaller hog farms close their operations.

Chen said that after Taiwan's entry into the WTO, locally produced pork should account for at least 60 percent of the domestic consumption of that product. To protect local pork producers from the onslaught of imported goods, the COA will assist larger-scale hog farms that can remain competitive, while phasing out smaller operations.

He noted that Taiwan's hog farms having between 1,000 and 5,000 hogs hold an advantage over smaller operators, adding that such farms account for 40 percent of the local pork operators and form the backbone of the domestic hog industry.
Chen said the COA will encourage the phasing out of hog raising operations that involve less than 200 animals.
He stressed, however, that the main priority of the ministry's plan will be to assist those hog farmers who can remain competitive in the pork industry.
He said the COA will also encourage small-scale chicken farms to close by offering subsidies of up to NT$2 million (US$60,600) for each farming household that opts to cease operations.

The COA estimates that production costs for pork should be held to under NT$3,800 (US$90.9) per 100 kilograms, while those for chicken should stay below NT$25 (US$0.75) per kilogram, if producers hope to compete with imported pork and chicken meats.

Meanwhile, COA Chairman Peng Tso-kwei on Monday again asked hog farm owners to rigorously implement a vaccination program, in order to ward off another outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD), such as the one that devastated the local hog population last March.

Peng's remarks followed reports last week that a hog farm in southern Tainan County has been i nfected with the highly contagious FMD, forcing the destruction of 49 animals that were afflicted with the disease.
After an investigation, agricultural officials found that the farm's stock had not been inoculated against FMD.
To avoid a resurgence of the FMD epidemic, Peng has again urged hog farm operators to vaccinate their herds.
Peng said that starting from Aug. 1, only those hogs that have ear tags showing they have been inoculated will be approved for sale on the market.
He said that before the threat of FMD has passed, locally produced pork will be primarily for domestic consumption. It is estimated that about 6 million hogs will be required to meet local needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSTITUTE TO STUDY SOUTHEAST ASIAN ECONOMY MULLED

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said on Monday that the setting up of a Southeast Asian Economic Institute is being planned to study the overall economic and industrial structure in the region to help the government in its decision making and to provide private businesses with an investment guide.

Liu made the remarks at a seminar co-sponsored by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) and the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research on the prospects for economic development in Taiwan and Southeast Asia, and the influence of overseas Chinese on regional economic development.

He noted that Southeast Asia is a region with a large Chinese population and heavy investment from Taiwan. He said the proposed institute will focus its studies on the development of Chinese communities in the region and their relations with the people, politics, cultures and religions of the various countries in which they reside.

OCAC Vice Minister Ko Wei-hsin noted that out of 57 million overseas Chinese worldwide, the 54 million overseas Chinese living throughout Asia, with estimated total assets of US$1,000 billion, tend to be very successful entrepreneurs.

Ke said the economic might of overseas Chinese has become a formidable force not to be ignored, emphasizing that the study of economic trends in the region is high on the government's list of priorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATE OF MARINE DEFECTOR TO BE DECIDED BY JUDGES: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The fate of a former ROC Marine Corps officer who returned to Taiwan earlier this month after defecting to mainland China 23 years ago will be decided by military judges, Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling said on Monday.
Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan Defense Committee meeting, Chiang said the crime committed by Wu Miao-huo, 48, is punishable by death under the Republic of China's military law.
But the minister added that it is up to the judgment of a military court whether Wu should be given a capital sentence.

Wu was a first lieutenant with a Marine Corps amphibious reconnaissance unit stationed on the ROC-held Wuchiu islet off the southeastern mainland coast when he defected to mainland China in 1974 on a speedboat.

According to ROC military regulations, defection to the mainland is punishable by death, but the offense is subject to a 20-year statute of limitation. However, as Wu was an active-duty military officer when he defected, the charges in his case are valid for up to 25 years. Thus, Wu still faces possible execution.

Police authorities said Wu secretly returned to Taiwan in early April as a national of the "People's Republic of China." Military prosecutors arrested him at his father's home in Tahu, Miaoli County, last Friday.
Wu is currently under custody at a naval detention center in Kaohsiung's Tsoying district for questioning to determine the motives behind his return.

Military prosecutors in charge of the case were quoted by local media as saying that they are trying to ascertain whether Wu had come back on any particular mission. Rumors have it that Wu was assigned the task of assassinating certain political figures in Taiwan. He was also said to have received intelligence training on the mainland, but military authorities declined to comment on all such reports.

Wu's father, Wu Ah-hsin, said on Monday that his son had come back simply for a family reunion. "Miao-huo has returned to see me and other family members," the elder Wu said, adding that his son is unlikely to carry any special mission because he did not try to conceal his identity when entering the island using an identification card issued by mainland Chinese authorities.

Wu Ah-hsin, a Hakka farmer, said his son had mostly stayed at home since his return and never touched on any sensitive issues. Wu said he hopes the military authorities will inform him of his son's current condition. "Military authorities have not contacted me since they arrested Miao-huo several days ago," he said sadly.

Local press reports said Wu Miao-huo had been awarded a 10,000 yuan cash reward by mainland authorities for his defection. Wu claimed he was recently working as an engineer at a chemical plant in the northwestern mainland province of Shanxi. He reportedly has established a family there and has two children.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIANS LOSE OVER US$3.3 BILLION IN SLOT MACHINES

TEXT.P: Thousands of Australians, including immigrants from Asia, lost more than US$3.3 billion through gambling by slot machines in fiscal 1996-97, according to the results of a survey printed by the mass-circulation newspaper The Australian on Monday.

The survey shows Australian residents in New South Wales led other states and territories with a total loss of US$1.69 billion; followed by residents in Victoria, US$967 million; Queensland, US$345 million; South Australia, US$2.43 million; the Australian Territory Capital, US$79 million; Northern Territory, US$11 million; and Tasmania, US$3 million.
The 1996-97 loss by Australians in gambling on slot machines compared to the loss of US$3.07 billion in 1995-96, according to the same survey.
Western Australia is the only state that still bans slot machines in hotels and clubs as well as in casinos.
The survey shows the figures did not include slot machines installed in the 13 nation's casinos outside Western Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENTS URGE JIANG ZEMIN TO LEARN FROM HU YAOBANG

TEXT.P: Dissidents in a southern province of mainland China sent a co-signed letter to mainland China's President Jiang Zemin last Saturday urging him to learn from the spirit of justice of Hu Yaobang, the late General Secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC), and to proceed with political reform.

Twelve dissidents in Zhejiang Province called for a redress of the injustices served on the June 4th pro-democracy movement, and for political reforms, including a lifting of the ban on organizing political parties and newspapers.

Those who co-signed the letter were Mao Guoliang, Wang Dunghai, Wang Yuotsai, Wu Gaoxing, Yeh Wenxiang, Zhao Wangmin, Zhen Daxiang, Jin Xiouyuan, Huang Zhdao, Zhang Jinlin, Cuei Jianchang and Fu Quan, according a report from the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and the Democratic Movement in Mainland China.

April 15th marks the ninth anniversary of Hu's death, and his courage in reversing miscarriages of justice, as well as his spirit of bold reform, is still deeply impressed on the people, said the letter.

In contrast to the "four modernizations" in industry, agriculture, technology and national security proposed by the Beijing authorities, the dissidents proposed their own "four modernizations" which named press liberalization, the adoption of multiparty politics, administration according to the rule of law, and the separation of the armed forces from the control of the CPC."

In addition, Lin Xinshu, a dissident from Fujian Province, published an open letter to the Beijing authorities on April 8. Lin was released on March 19 after almost a month in detention for objecting to the nomination of former premier Li Peng as chairman of the National People's Congress, mainland China's parliament.
In his letter, Lin urged the authorities to permit freedom of speech, redress the June 4th pro-democracy movement, and release dissidents Wang Dan, Sheng Lianching and Yang Chinghun.
Following the publication of his open letter, Lin has been preparing for his arrest, which could come at any time, said the information center.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP SHARPLY ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, sliding 190.91 points to close at 8.863.11.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 9,014.74 but experienced a steep decline, breaking the "psychological barrier" of 9,000.
Dealers attributed the decline to apprehension over rumors about mainland China's pending military exercises, coupled with a sharp drop in prices for electronics issues.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 357 to 88, with 49 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 2.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$124.36 billion.

Seven of the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks sliding the most at 4.0 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 2.9 percent, textile issues at 1.8 percent, pulp and paper stocks at 1.7 percent, cement shares at 1.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.1 percent, and bank and finance stocks at 0.5 percent.
Only the construction category registered a gain, moving up by 0.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.15 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$32.995.
The greenback opened at 32.817 and was traded between 32.817 and 33.023.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$343.50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICE OF NT DOLLAR SAID COMPETITIVE

TEXT.P: Perng Fai-nan, governor of The Central Bank of China, said on Monday that the present level of the new Taiwan dollar is already highly competitive, and that the bank will honor the foreign exchange rates decided by market supply and demand.

He made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in reply to interpellation by Legislator Hung Chi-chang from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), who asked whether the defense of NT dollar rates by the central bank will jeopardize Taiwan's import and export trade in the wake of the depreciation of the Japanese yen, which has placed quite heavy pressure on the NT dollar.

Perng noted that during the first two months of this year, Taiwan's unsatisfactory export situation resulted in trade deficits, but pointed out that the situation improved in March, removing the necessity of resorting to currency devaluation to stimulate exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN AIRPORT TO BE UPGRADED, NOT TO BE CLOSED

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has no plans to close the Kinmen Airport and will take immediate steps to imporve its safety facilities, a senior aviation official said here on Monday.
CAA Deputy Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng made the promises while meeting with Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai and Legislator Chen Ching-pao at the Kinmen County Government.

Chang was visiting the offshore frontline island to clarify his recent remarks made after a spate of domestic air disasters that the Kinmen Airport doesn't meet safety standards and that it's "pure luck" there haven't been flight accidents here.

Chang's remarks have prompted a large number of tour groups to cancel their plans to make sightseeing trips to this offshore defense outpost in the past few weeks, dealing a serious blow to Kinmen's tourist industry which is instrumental to the county's economic well-being.

Chang asked Kinmen County Magistrate Chen to convey his sincere apology to all Kinmen folks, saying he felt regret that he had made such inadvertent remarks. "I should have expressed my opinions more precisely and prudently."
Chang assured Chen that the Kinmen Airport will not be closed. "Moreover, the CAA will adopt measures to renovate its facilities and make it one of the safest domestic airports."

For his part, Chen said air traffic is Kinmen's most important link to the outside world. "Your earlier comments on Kinmen airport facilities have prompted nearly 100 tour groups to cancel their travel plans," Chen complained, adding that 14 percent of the county's population make their living on tourism-related services. "A sharp downturn in tourist arrivals could spark economic turmoil on this tiny island."

Chang pointed out that the Kinmen Airport was adapted from a military airfield. Like Taipei's Sungshan Airport, the Kinmen Airport is classfied as a "special airport" which is subject to stricter safety standards, including weather conditions and more rigorous training requirements for pilots.
"As long as all CAA-set safety standards are faithfully followed, there won't be any problems for aircarft to take off from or land at the Kinmen Airport," Chang claimed.
However, he admitted that some potential elements, particularly forest windbreaks and military facilities near runways, may affect the airport's flight safety.

Chang said the CAA will cooperate with the Kinmen County Government and the Kinmen garrison command to remove all potential hazards. "The CAA will also install a highly advanced transponder landing system (TLS) and a glide path system at the Kinmen Airport to increase flight safety."

Chang further said the CAA will study the feasibility of either expanding the Kinmen Airport at its present site or relocate it to Hsihung in the future to meet the demand of the local tourist industry.

The Kinmen island group, which lies closer to the southeastern mainland Chinese coast than to Taiwan, is one of Taiwan's most important defense outposts. It has become a popular travel destination since it was opened to civilian tourists a few years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSOMNIA? CHECK THE LIVER, SAYS CHANGHUA DOCTOR
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, central Taiwan, April 13 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Changhua-based doctor of traditional Chinese medicine who relates insomnia to deficiencies in liver function, on Monday urged adults suffering from chronic insomnia to have their livers checked.

Dr. Chuang Yi-ming of Changhua's Hsiuchuan Memorial Hospital said the reasons for insomnia are little-known, but according to his diagnostic experience, he said, liver and psychological problems are major culprits.
Citing the case of a 45-year-old woman, Chuang said the patient, who had suffered chronic insomnia and relied for years on sleeping pills, was diagnosed to have a "liver deficiency complex."

After about 20 days of treatment, the patient's chronic symptoms, including insomnia, headache, fatigue, stiff neck, stomach disorder, bitter mouth and dry throat were cured, and she was able to give up the sleeping pills.

Chuang pointed out that most patients with liver problems don't have good circulation, as the blood has difficulty passing through the liver smoothly, causing pressure to the upper half of the body and leading the patient to develop symptoms similar to his sample case.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY DENIES REPORTS ON FOOD AID TO INDONESIA, NORTH KOREA

TEXT.P: The Foreign Affairs Ministry on Monday denied local news reports that the Republic of China government is considering providing food aid to Indonesia and North Korea.
The reports said that Indonesia and North Korea, which are facing serious food shortages, have asked Taiwan to come to their relief.
According to the reports, the government is being very cautious in its handling of the matter, which is under the authority of the Foreign Affairs Ministry.
The reports went on to say that the ministry is considering selling rice to Indonesia at a very low price.
However ministry officials dismissed the reports as unfounded speculation, and denied any knowledge of plans for food aid.

They also denied that their ministry has worked out any concrete plans to assist Southeast Asian countries embroiled in the current financial crisis, although the Central Bank of China has decided to provide loans to Taiwan investors in Southeast Asian countries through local banks with branches in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER FIRM ON RESIGNATION DECISION

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao on Monday was standing firm on his decision to resign after submitting an oral resignation to Premier Vincent Siew.

Government spokesman Chen Chien-jen, the sole government official present at a 30-minute meeting between Siew and Liao in the afternoon, said the justice minister remained firm in his intention to resign from the post and asked Siew to approve his resignation despite the premier's efforts to retain Liao in office.

Describing the atmosphere of the meeting as "serious," Chen said he was unsure whether Siew's efforts to retain Liao have been effective, but added that it was apparent that the two men failed to reach consensus on the issue.

Chen said the premier had high praise for Liao's abilities and performance over the past 22 months, and encouraged him to remain in the post in order to make a greater contribution to the country and society. But a firm Liao insisted on leaving, and asked Siew to help "fulfill his wish."
Liao was quoted by Chen as saying that because of family factors, he hopes to be able to shift to other areas in order to devote himself to social welfare activities and his teaching career.

According to Chen, Liao denied that his offer to resign has anything to do with the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) plan to field him in the December mayoral election in Kaohsiung City or personnel changes in the Investigation Bureau, which is under the jurisdiction of the Justice Ministry.

A local newspaper had reported on Monday morning that Liao, potentially one of the most popular KMT candidates for the end-year mayoral election in Kaohsiung City, might shortly resign from office and would not accept any further assignments from his superiors, including running in the mayoral race in Taiwan's second-largest city.

According to the front-page story carried by the United Daily, Liao admitted that he has considered quitting politics in order to devote himself to his family, educational and social welfare activities. The justice minister was quoted by the newspaper as saying that he would not accept any arrangements for his participation in the year-end mayoral election.
The report said Liao's family welcomes his decision with "open arms," and that he was considering tendering his resignation to Premier Siew at a proper time.
The report was indirectly confirmed by Liao later on Monday morning at an inquiry session at the Legislative Yuan.
Admitting that he is under heavy pressure, Liao said his decision was not made rashly and that he wishes to shift his energies to other fields.
Speaking later in the meeting, the justice minister said the idea of quitting politics has been on his mind for a long time, as he has had almost no family life since assuming the post.
Now that the operations of the Justice Ministry are running on track, Liao said that the time has come for him to leave.

According to public opinion surveys, Liao, 52, has been one of the country's most popular cabinet members since becoming justice minister in June 1996 on a platform of a continued crackdown on organized crime and gangsters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOLD ANNUAL JOINT MILITARY EXERCISE IN LATE APRIL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense confirmed on Monday that the annual joint military exercise will take place in late April and early May in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.

The exercise, codenamed Han Kuang No. 14, is aimed at testing the armed forces' air defense system, electronic warfare capability, and command, control and communication system functions, according to a statement released by the defense ministry.

The statement indicated that the routine annual exercise will start with a "sand table," or computer simulation exercise, followed by a live fire maneuver to test the feasibility of the sand table exercise. The maneuver will serve to review and streamline the nation's combat plans to ensure the island's security.

The exercise will not feature a display of military weaponry and equipment, it said, adding that no government officials, people's representatives or reporters will be invited to witness the maneuver.

The statement stressed that the defense ministry and general staff headquarters are taking a low-key attitude toward this year's annual exercise in an effort not to increase tension across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE IMPORT-EXPORT REGISTERS SURPLUS

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Monday that during the first three months of this year banks received US$29.42 billion worth of foreign exchange from exports and paid out US$28.93 billion for imports, resulting in a surplus of US$490 million.

The CBC statistics show that during March alone, the foreign exchange revenue from exports totaled US$10.08 billion, an increase of 4.7 percent in comparison with the same month of last year, while expenditures on imports amounted to US$10.07 billion, a rise of 18.4 percent compared with the same period of last year.
The central bank attributed the growth in exports to gains in the electronics sector and the increase in imports to an influx of electronics spare parts and military products.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF DEPUTY SECRETARY-GENERAL INVITED TO VISIT BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said on Monday it has received a faxed letter from its mainland Chinese counterpart inviting its deputy secretary-general to visit Beijing next week to arrange for a visit to the mainland by SEF Chairman C. F. Koo.

"The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) informed us today that it welcomes our deputy secretary-general to visit Beijing on April 21-22 to exchange views on a long-talked-about visit to mainland China by SEF Chairman Koo," the SEF said in a news release.

The ARATS said in its letter that Koo is welcome to head a delegation to visit the mainland or to attend a seminar to be co-sponsored by the two organizations. "We'll also be glad to hear your opinions about future bilateral exchange plans or the agenda to be discussed," the ARATS said.

The letter was a response to SEF's message faxed to the ARATS on April 3 suggesting that its deputy secretary-general visit the mainland in the second half of April to discuss technical details concerning the resumption of regular cross-strait dialogue which Beijing unilaterally broke off in mid-1995.
SEF officials said they are pleased to receive a positive reply from the ARATS and will arrange for its deputy secretary-general to visit the mainland soon.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies founded by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAITI'S PRESIDENT PREVAL TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Monday that President Rene Preval of the Republic of Haiti will arrive in Taipei on April 21 for a four-day visit at the invitation of President Lee Teng-hui.
The Haitian president, who was popularly elected more than two years ago, will be accompanied by his wife and Haitian Foreign Minister Fritz Lonchamps, among others.
During his stay in Taiwan, Preval will exchange views with Lee on the current international situation, as well as matters of mutual concern between Haiti and the Republic of China.
A joint communique will be signed after the meeting of the two leaders, according to an MOFA news release.
Preval, who is an expert in agriculture and horticulture, will also meet with related government officials and visit various economic and social establishments, especially rice and tea plantations.
Preval and his entourage will leave Taiwan April 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S TRADE DEFICIT WITH SOUTH KOREA MAY ZOOM TO US$4 B.
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, April 13 (CNA) (By Y. C. Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's trade deficit with South Korea is likely to soar to more than US$4 billion this year, ROC Representative to South Korea Lin Chun-hsien said on Monday.
Lin made the forecast while meeting with a delegation of senior business executives from Taiwan.

Despite the absence of diplomatic ties, Lin said, trade between Taiwan and South Korea has continued to grow rapidly. But Taiwan has consistently incurred a deficit in its trade with South Korea in recent years. The trade imbalance exceeded US$2 billion in 1997 and is expected to zoom to US$4 billion this year.

Lin said South Korea has been hit hard by a financial crisis. As a result, its demand for Taiwan products is not expected to increase significantly this year. Nevertheless, Lin said, South Korea's financial crisis has provided good opportunities to buy into major South Korean enterprises.

"Because of their special national character, it won't be easy to operate joint-venture businesses with Koreans," Lin noted, adding that straightforwardness is a special Korean trait. "If prospective investors understand this, there are still room for cooperation with Koreans."

The 37-member delegation was organized by Taiwan's Core Pacific Group with a view to seek possible investment or joint-venture opportunities in South Korea as many KOrean conglomerates are being plagued by cash shortages.

Lin Ke-ming, leader of the delegation and president of Core Pacific Securities Co., said Taiwan has suffered huge trade dificts with South Korea, indicating that Korean products are very competitive in the Taiwan market. "We hope to seek investment opportunities in South Korea's electronics, construction, financial services and petrochemical industries," he noted.

The mission, which arrived in Seoul on Sunday, was the first foreign group to visit here for market inspection. The Korean government, business and media have all attached great importance to its arrival.

The delegation met with Korean Minister of Industry and Energy Park Tae-young and Minister of State for Trade Han Duk-soo on Monday. The Korean officials have briefed Taiwan visitors on South Korea's current interest rate levels, stock market situation, investment regulations, the general invesmtnet climate and other related issues.

Later in the day, the group met with senior executives of Dong-Ah and Samsung groups to discuss possible cooperative deals. The mission is scheduled to meet with officials of other Korean business groups, including Hanhwa, Tongyang and Jinro, on Tuesday.

Mission members include chief executive officers of major Taiwan firms, such as Core Pacific Group, China Petrochemcial Development Corp., Hong Tai Electric Industry Corp. and Chiao Lung Construction and Development Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO DONATE NT$45 MILLION TO DANCE TROUPE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's electronics giant Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSM) will be donating NT$45 million (US$1.4 million) to a local dance troupe, the Cloud Gate Dance Theater, in a move aimed at boosting local cultural development.

TSM Chairman Morris Chang signed a written promise Monday that commits his firm to contributing NT$45 million over the next three years to the Cloud Gate Dance Theater Fund, which finances the troupe.

Chang said at the brief signing ceremony that he has always declared that if Taiwan wants to become a scientific and technological powerhouse, it has to boost its cultural development and quality of life to attract talent from around the world.

The cash donation reflects TSM's concern for social development and is part of the firm's efforts to give something back to the society that has helped it grow into a world-class semiconductor manufacturer, he said.

Yuan T. Lee , president of Academia Sinica and honorary head of the Cloud Gate Theater, played a key role in the deal. He introduced Chang to the troupe's founder and general art director Lin Huai-min two weeks ago and brokered the agreement.

Lin, who was on hand at the ceremony, said TSM's donation is the largest the group has received and that it will encourage the members of the troupe, which was set up 25 years ago with the goal of putting the island on the world map of the performing arts.

After a quarter-century of study and practice, the theater is coming of age and standing on its feet, Lin said, adding that it deserves a share of society's resources. He said he hopes to raise NT$200 million (US$6.5 million) to finance the troupe.
Interest from the fund will be used to set up a permanent dance studio and a second troupe, both of which will be aimed at being valuable cultural assets for Taiwan, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLASTICS FACTORY APOLOGIZES FOR BLAZE

TEXT.P: Nan Ya Plastics Corp., a subsidiary of the Formosa Plastics Group, on Monday apologized for a blaze that broke out late Sunday in its factory in Kaohsiung County.
Nan Ya spokesman Wu Chai-chou said that a preliminary investigation revealed the fire might have been caused by chemicals stored at the factory which burst into flame because of high temperatures.
Wu said that the exact amount of damage was being calculated, adding that all of the facilities in the damaged plant, Nan Ya's No. 4 factory in Jen Wu Township, Kaohsiung County, were insured.

Nan Ya currently has four production bases on the island, with the PVC plastic sheets the firm produces commanding 60 percent of the local market. The Jen Wu No. 4 factory had been producing NT$140 million in goods per month, one quarter of the firm's total monthly production value.

The fire broke out at 5:30 p.m. Sunday and triggered several explosions before being brought under control four hours later. By the time that firefighters were able to put out the flames at 7 a.m. Monday, the facilities, covering more than 3,300 square meters, had been almost completely destroyed.

The heavy smoke from the fire covered the entire neighborhood, which prompted police to temporarily close off a section of highway next to the factory for safety reasons, as visibility had been severely affected.
No casualties were reported in the fire, but two residents were sent to the hospital because of feeling uncomfortable after inhaling the thick smoke.

Over 100 residents living near the factory protested in front of the factory on Monday morning, saying the plant had endangered their lives. The angry residents scuffled with police when they began pelting the gate of the factory with eggs.

The residents set up tents in front of the factory to show their determination to fight against the factory until their demands were met. The protesters have asked Nan Ya to strengthen industrial safety measures, buy each resident in the area fire and accident insurance, and handle the compensation issue immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMF ADJUSTS WORLD GROWTH RATE DOWNWARD TO 3.1 PERCENT FOR 1998
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicted in its latest report that, buffeted by the Southeast Asian financial turmoil, the world economic growth rate will drop to 3.1 percent this year, the lowest level in five years.

The report on the prospects of the world economy said that Taiwan's 5 percent annual growth is the highest among the four Asian tigers, but that this rate still only enables the island to secure the 26th position in the world.

Due to the financial crisis in Southeast Asia, the IMF adjusted the world annual growth rate downward 1.2 percent compared with its projection made last October. The annual growth rate for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations recorded the sharpest modification -- from 5.4 percent to negative 2.7 percent.

The IMF forecast a 1.8 percent economic growth rate for the four Asian tigers this year, the lowest level since the end of the World War II and marking the first time in years that the growth of the four Asian tigers is expected to be lower than that of the world as a whole.

Taiwan is expected to post an annual growth rate of 5 percent this year and 5.2 percent next year, while Singapore will record 3.5 percent growth this year and 5 percent next year, Hong Kong 3 percent this year and 4.3 percent next year, and South Korea negative 0.8 percent this year and 4.1 percent next year.

As for mainland China, its projected growth rate fell to 7 percent this year compared with 1997's 8.8 percent and 1996's 9.7 percent. Meanwhile, the inflation rate on the mainland is predicted to rise to 2 percent from last year's 1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CIA HEAD ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: R. James Woolsey, former director of the US Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), arrived in Taipei on Monday for a private visit.
Woolsey and three US intelligence and military experts were greeted at the airport by their local host, Legislator Parris Chang.

Chang said that Woolsey, who served as head of the CIA between 1993 and 1995 under US President Bill Clinton, will call on President Lee Teng-hui as well as other government leaders to exchange views with them on the threat that Beijing's growing military strength poses to Taiwan and how the island should respond.
The views of Woolsey and his entourage will further Taiwan leaders' understanding of Beijing's military policy and Washington's policy in the Asia-Pacific area, said Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMF: NT DOLLAR DOWN 7.6 PERCENT SINCE JULY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: An analysis by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) says that the New Taiwan dollar depreciated by 7.6 percent in real terms in the nine months between July 1997 and this March.

According to the most recent IMF report, in the past three quarters the US dollar has virtually and effectively appreciated 9.4 percent, with the British pound up 9 percent and the Japanese yen rising 2.1 percent, though the yen also depreciated 11.5 percent against the US dollar during the same period.
Although the effects of the Asian financial turmoil have not been severe in Taiwan, the island's currency nonetheless fell 7.6 percent in real terms during the last three quarters.
In the same period, mainland China's yuan appreciated 7.3 percent and Hong Kong's dollar rose 14.3 percent in real terms, which seriously curtailed both locations' export competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: US BAN ON SHRIMP TRADE A TRADE BARRIER

TEXT.P: Thailand and three other Asian countries have won a significant victory at the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) in a dispute with the United States over shrimp exports.

A WTO panel in Geneva said on Monday that Washington has no right to ban imports from shrimp-producing countries that fail to properly protect sea turtles. The decision confirmed a preliminary ruling issued last month.
Thailand, the world's largest shrimp exporter, had challenged the ban, along with Malaysia, India and Pakistan, saying the ban, based on US domestic law, is a trade barrier forbidden under WTO rules.

The issue was largely academic for Thailand, 80 percent of whose shrimp are farmed rather than being caught at sea. But Thai authorities pursued the case on principle, saying countries cannot block trade by imposing their laws outside their borders.
Even if Washington appeals the decision, Asian countries are confident of winning, the WTO report quoted Krirk-Krai Jirapaet, Thailand's ambassador to the WTO, as saying.
If Washington does not file an appeal within 60 days, it must either change its law or negotiate fines to be paid to the WTO, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND POURS COLD WATER ON ALLEGATIONS OF M'LAND SUB MOVES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Monday responded indirectly to allegations that Beijing's newly acquired submarines will monitor Taiwan's forthcoming military drill off the island's eastern coast, noting that such a move would be contrary to Beijing's general way of training and commissioning its military vessels.

However, the ministry's terse one-paragraph statement stopped short of rebutting directly opposition legislator Trong R. Chai's claims that Beijing is to send its Russian-made Kilo 636-class submarines to international waters off Taiwan's east coast to keep an eye on the island's annual military maneuvers slated for sometime next month.

Chai, attributing his information to US intelligence authorities, said Beijing's move is aimed at testing both Taiwan's anti-submarine tactics and the possibility for its submarines to penetrate Taiwan's defenses.

Although the ministry cited its policy of not commenting on intelligence operations, it also assured the public in the statement that the armed forces always keep a close watch on Beijing's military movements and that Taiwan's defense forces will never be caught off guard.

Meanwhile, a US defense official told CNA in Washington that he knew nothing about Beijing's alleged submarine drills and described as "virtually none" the possibility that the US government would ever leak such information to a Taiwan opposition lawmaker.
The official, who requested anonymity, said whenever intelligence information is relayed to a foreign country, this is done through official channels, and that he is therefore informed in such cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND FISHING BOAT WAITING FOR REPAIR

TEXT.P: A mainland fishing boat that collided with a Navy ship over the weekend is waiting for repairs at a shipyard in Keelung, northern Taiwan, a Navy spokesman said on Tuesday.
The Navy ship was sailing from Suao on the east coast of Taiwan to the port at Keelung on Saturday when it collided with the mainland boat in heavy fog.
The collision left a hole in the fishing boat, which was later towed to the Keelung shipyard.

The spokesman said that the China Cooperation Register of Shipping has completed a damage assessment on the mainland vessel and the Navy will ask a private shipping company to undertake the repair work.

As for the cause of the incident, the Navy will ask relevant agencies to conduct an investigation and will manage follow-up matters through the Straits Exchange Foundation, a semiofficial body set up to help handle contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The spokesman said 15 mainland fishermen on the boat at the time of the collision have remained on the vessel. The craft was allowed to anchor in Keelung the same way mainland fishing boats are allowed to anchor in Taiwan ports on humanitarian grounds under emergency situations.
The Navy has provided the fishermen with food, water and electricity. Telephones have also been installed so the fishermen can communicate with their families in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP INVITES US CONGRESSIONAL AIDES TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A delegation of top aides to several influential members of the US Congress left for Taiwan on Monday for a weeklong fact-finding visit.
The visit was organized by the representative office in the United States of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The DPP representative office said it is the first of a series of similar visits the party will organize in the coming months to help the US Congress understand the importance of American assistance in defending Taiwan against possible Communist Chinese attacks.

"The visit is also part of our efforts to push for the passage in the next congressional session of a proposal demanding the US executive branch to include Taiwan within its theater missile defense (TMD) system," a staff member with the DPP office here said, adding that the DPP also hopes the visit will help promote US congressional support for Taiwan's bids to join the World Trade Organizations, the International Monetary Fund and other major international organizations.
The delegation comprises top assistants to Senators Robert Torricelli (D-NJ) and Robert Bennett (R-Utah) and Congressman Amo Houghton (R-NY).
While in Taipei, the delegation will pay visits to the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council.
Lin Kuo-wei, a secretary with the DPP representative office here, is accompanying the US congressional mission on its Taipei trip.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Parris Chang, who concurrently heads the DPP office in the United States, is now accompanying former US Central Intelligence Agency Director James Woolsey and four other American military and intelligence experts on a visit to Taipei.
