DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POSTS WORLD'S 14TH HIGHEST ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR 1997
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate of 6.8 percent in 1997 was the world's 14th highest level, a report on the global economic prospective released Monday by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) shows.

According to the report, the Republic of Georgia (11 percent), the Republic of Estonia (10.9 percent), and the Republic of Belarus (10 percent) -- three federal republics of the former Soviet Union -- grabbed the top three spots in world economic growth rate last year. Mainland China ranked the fourth with an 8.8 percent economic growth rate.

Affected by the Asian financial crisis, the report forecast that the world economy will only grow by 3.1 percent in 1998, with the Group of Seven industrial countries estimated to post an average 2.3 percent and developing countries expected to register 4.1 percent.
Taiwan's economic growth rate has been adjusted downward to 5 percent for 1998, the lowest level for the island in 16 years but the highest rate among the four Asian tigers, according to the report.
The IMF predicted that the four Asian tigers -- Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea -- will chart an average 1.8 percent in annual growth this year, the lowest increase since World War II.
A ranking IMF official said he does not believe the clout of the four Asian tigers has faded and forecast that among the crisis-plagued economies, South Korea will recover most quickly.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY ADMITS NEGLIGENCE IN HANDLING DEFECTOR'S CASE

TEXT.P: The Navy General Headquarters (NGH) on Tuesday admitted negligence in handling an inquiry into whether a former ROC Marine Corps officer who defected to mainland China some 24 years ago is still on a Navy wanted list.

Lee Chih-li, director of the NGH's legal affairs department, made the confession after the defector's father Wu Ah-hsin accused the ROC military of having deliberately set a trap to apprehend his son.

Wu on Monday displayed to the local press a letter from the NGH sent to him last year saying the Navy had not issued a warrant to arrest his son, Wu Miao-huo. "After receiving this letter, I came to believe that the defection charges against my son had been invalidated. Under this assumption, I let my son return to Taiwan earlier this month for a family reunion," the elder Wu claimed.

Shortly after his return, Wu Miao-huo was arrested by military police. He is now under custody at a naval detention center in Kaohsiung's Tsoying district for questioning about motives behind his return.

Commenting on the elder Wu's allegations, Lee stressed that it may have been negligence, but not a conspiracy, for the NGH to have issued such a letter to Wu, a Hakka farmer residing in Miaoli County in northern Taiwan.
Lee recalled that Wu sent an inquiry to the Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Jan. 19 last year asking whether the ministry's arrest warrant against his son remained valid.

Lee said the MND issued its arrest warrant against Wu Miao-hou on June 17, 1974, about three months after the then Marine Corps lieutenant defected to the mainland on a speedboat from the ROC-held Wuchiu islet, off the southeastern mainland coast.
As more than 23 years had passed, Lee said, MND officials were unaware of the existence of an arrest warrant against Wu when they received Wu Ah-hsin's inquiry last year.

The MND then transferred the letter to the NGH legal affairs department. Lee said although the Navy also issued an arrest warrant against Wu in October 1974, his name was not included on an annually published list of fugitives because of negligence on the part of staff members.
As a result, Lee said, the NGH legal affairs department wrote to Wu's father last year, saying his son was no longer being sought by naval authorities.
"I myself as well as other NGH staff members in charge of this case were to blame for the negligence," Lee confessed at a news conference.

Lee said he has reported the case to Navy Commander-in-Chief Adm. Wu Shih-wen and asked to be punished for his oversight. Other relevant NGH staff members will also be disciplined in accordance with military regulations, he added.
Asked whether the NGH's negligence would lead to a more lenient sentence for Wu Miao-huo, Lee said he did not think so.

According to ROC military law, defection to Communist China is punishable by death. And, as Wu was an active-duty officer when he defected, the charges in his case are valid for up to 25 years. Thus, Wu still faces possible execution.
There has been much speculation concerning the reasons behind Wu's defection. Lee said military prosecutors will conduct a thorough, prudent investigation into the case before giving a verdict.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO PUSH FOR LABELING OF CHINESE MEDICINES

TEXT.P: The Department of Health will push for the labeling of Chinese medicines within six months, a DOH official said on Tuesday.

Chang Chung-gwo, newly installed chairman of the DOH Committee of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacy, made the remarks after he toured the famous gathering spot for practitioners, vendors and users of traditional Chinese medicine on Tihua Street in downtown Taipei.

Chang went to several medicinal shops in the area to learn more about how the vendors sell, label, display and store their products. He noted that some of the medicines are stocked in bulk quantities inside large bags with tags informing customers of the prices, but providing no additional information. Other shops offer the same product in sealed packets containing smaller doses of the medicine.
It is estimated that over half of the traditional Chinese medicine in Taiwan is now sold in the small-sized sealed packages.

Chang noted that there are currently no regulations requiring shop owners to label medicinal products in the manner that food items are packaged to provide consumers with clear, pertinent information. This lack of legislation, he said, has contributed to rampant counterfeiting of Chinese medicines and poses a potential threat to public health safety.

Chang said his committee will promote a system of uniform product information labeling for Chinese medicines within six months. A standard label will include the name of the medicine, major components, package size and weight, the date and place of production, date of expiration, as well as the name of the manufacturer and the importer, where applicable.

He said that in the future, products will be tested for the presence of heavy metal trace elements, pesticide residue and microorganism count. In addition, product stability, shelf life and storage methods will also be the focus of routine checks at local medicine shops.
It is known that once the measures are implemented, herbal medicines from the Chinese mainland will be affected most.

Hsu Chin-sung, president of the Chinese Medicine Commerce Association, said that 90 percent of the herbs and other plant and animal ingredients for traditional medicines found in Taiwan originate from mainland China. The rest, mainly such products as ginseng, hippocampus and pepper varieties, come from South Korea, the United States, Vietnam and Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORENSIC EXPERT BRINGS MORE ANALYSIS RESULTS ON LIU PANG-YOU CASE

TEXT.P: Chinese-American forensics expert Henry Lee said on Tuesday that he has brought the result of his latest analysis on the brutal murder of former Taoyuan County Magistrate Liu Pang-you.
But Lee, who was here to attend an annual meeting on firefighting, would not reveal the results of his analysis or say whether it may help solve the high-profile murder case.
Liu and seven others were shot to death in an execution-style slaying at his official residence in the morning of Nov. 21, 1996. The cold-blooded murders shocked the nation.

Lee, considered one of the world's leading forensics experts, has been solicited by the National Police Administration to help with the investigation. Lee had previously gone to the murder scene to collect evidence, which he then took the back to the United States for analysis at his laboratory in the state of Connecticut.

Police said that his reconstruction of crime scene has thrown much light into the case. Among other things, he has established the order in which the nine victims were killed. Lee also said that the perpetrators of the crime wore gloves, a conclusion which differs from the findings of the police task force.
Teng Wen-chang, who survived the attack but suffered a massive head wound, has been unable to recall details of the event and has been of little help to police investigators.

Lee met with Ting Yuan-chin, director-general of the National Police Administration, and Yang Tzu-ching, director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau, on Tuesday morning to exchange views on the results of his analysis.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MISSION ON JAPAN VISIT OVER REGIONAL FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: A high-profile delegation from Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) left for Japan on Tuesday for a five-day visit aimed at seeking innovative strategies to address the current Asian financial crisis.

The delegation, headed by DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, will meet with Yoshiro Mori, executive council chairman of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, as well as many influential Japanese parliamentarians.
On Wednesday, the DPP mission will attend a seminar on Asian financial and economic woes to be sponsored by Japan's opposition Democratic Party at a convention hall in the Japanese Diet building.

During the seminar, Hsu will deliver a speech on the East Asian economic crisis and possible remedies. Liu Tai-ying, chairman of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang Business Management Commission, will also give a keynote speech on the overall financial situations in the region's three Chinese economies -- Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong.
Dozens of Japanese Diet members and scholars are also expected to present their views on related topics at Wednesday's seminar.

The outspoken DPP chairman has consistently preached that Taiwan should seek to play a role in resolving the current Asian financial crisis through international cooperation. Hsu said prior to his departure that he hopes his Japan visit will help win Japanese support for Taiwan's bid to upgrade its international profile.

During its stay in Japan, the DPP delegation will also meet with top leaders of other Japanese opposition parties, including the Liberal Party and the Komeito as well as chief executives of a pro-Taiwan group in the Japanese Diet.

Members of the delegation include Sisy Chen, former director of the DPP's Culture and Information Department; Chen Sheng-hung, a Taipei City councilor; and Hsiao Mei-chin, director of the DPP's International Affairs Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, sliding 98.53 points to close at 8,764.58.
Dealers said that although a rebound had been expected after the declines of the past few days, after mid-session a downward trend reappeared on the market, with all major categories losing ground.
The bourse opened at 8,906.44 and experienced a high of 8,910.14 and a low of 8,738.91.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 375 to 78, with 39 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 2.10 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$107.67 billion (US$3.26 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session, which saw 2.35 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$124.36 billion.

All eight major categories suffered losses, with textile shares moving down the most at 2.2 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.6 percent, pulp and paper stocks at 1.5 percent, cement shares at 1.2 percent, both bank and insurance issues and construction stocks at 1.1 percent, electrical shares at 0.9 percent, and plastics and chemical issues at 0.7 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Tuesday's trading were Ever Fortune Industry, Pacific Construction, United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, International Bills Finance, Wan Yu Paper, Picvue Electronics, Fubon Insurance, Kinpo Electronics and MAG Technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER STRESSES DESIRE TO RETAIN JUSTICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that he will do his best to retain Justice Minister Liao Chen-hao, who submitted a formal written resignation to Siew in the morning after revealing on Monday his intention to do so.

Stressing that he will not allow such a capable cabinet member to leave, the premier said he believes that Liao will consider withdrawing the resignation given the current situation in society and his sincere desire to retain him.
Fielding questions at an interpellation at the Legislative Yuan, Siew also appealed to people not to politicize the matter or view the development as a political wrangle.
Liao's decision to resign is simply because of a "personal need for change" and should not be seen as a "conspiracy," Siew said.

Denying criticisms from lawmakers with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party that his administration is on the verge of "falling apart," Siew said he will seek to convince Liao to retain in the post in order to make greater contributions to the country and society.

Siew admitted that he has been busy handling a series of major incidents since assuming the post eight months ago, but he said he does not think that his administration is facing a "crisis." The premier added that he feels ashamed of nothing because all he wants is to serve the people and the country.

Liao is the second minister to resign in the last 30 days, following Tsay Jaw-yang leaving the top spot in the Ministry of Transportation and Communications last month. The justice minister said on Monday that he was considering quitting politics for quite a while because of family factors.

Meanwhile, State Public Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa said he and more than 20 prosecutors from prosecutors offices islandwide will call on Liao at Liao's office in the afternoon to express their desire that the minister stay to continue his crackdown on organized crime and underworld activities.
According to public opinion surveys, Liao, 52, has been one of the country's most popular cabinet members since assuming the post in June 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.043 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at the day's low of 32.952.
The greenback opened at 32.992, and had a high of 33.15.
The interbank trading reached US$322 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PARTICIPATES IN US$1 BILLION LOAN PACKAGE TO THAILAND

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is one of 17 countries that are providing a loan of US$1 billion to boost Thailand's exports after the country has experienced a financial crisis since July last year.
Thai exporters will be able to draw upon the international loan from April 16 through the Export-Import Bank of Thailand in order to purchase raw materials, officials here said.

According to official Thai News Agency, lead arrangers of the syndicated loans are 10 international financial institutions, namely ABN-AMRO Bank, Bank of Nova Scotia Asia, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, Bangque National de Paris--Singapore Branch, Barclays Capital, Citicorp Investment Bangkok (Singapore), Development Bank of Singapore, DKB Asia and the Industrial Bank of Japan.

The 10 lead arrangers are joined by 54 international financial institutions from 17 countries, namely the Republic of China, mainland China, Japan, Singapore, the United Arab Emirates, Australia, Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Austria, Spain, the United Kingdom, Canada, the United States and South Africa.

Officials at the Thai Prime Minister's Office said that the total commitment raised by the lead arrangers involves more than US$1.4 billion, but that Thailand intends to borrow only US$1 billion, or 40 billion Thai baht.
The international loan agreement was signed on April 1, 1998, in the presence of Thailand's Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai.

Representing Thailand in signing the loan agreement was Pridiyathorn Devakula, president of the Export-Import Bank of Thailand, and Mitsuo Sato, president of the Asian Development Bank (ABD), who inked the agreement on behalf of the ADB and the international banks joining the facility program.
Thailand Finance Minister Tarrin Mimmahaeminda represented the country's Ministry of Finance as guarantor for the Thai side. The accord is also guaranteed by the ADB.
The purpose of the facility is to improve the accessibility of credit for export-oriented businesses, Thai officials said.
The EXIM Bank of Thailand will extend the loans to exporters through qualified Thai commercial banks and the Industrial Finance Corporation of Thailand.

The conditions for loan extensions are to be set by the ADB. The facility has a five-year repayment period. The annual interest rate charged by the ADB is 6.93 percent, and that charged commercial lenders is 0.80 percent over the London Interbank Offered Rate of six-month deposits in US dollars.
The loans extended under the program are intended to finance raw materials purchased by exporters who will be able to borrow the facility from April 16.
In the face of the current economic slump, exports are seen to play a key role in stimulating the country's economy, Thai officials said.

However, liquidity crunch is a major problem, making it difficult for exporters to buy raw materials to manufacture for export. The reason is that Thai commercial banks and financial institutions have been cautious about extending credit to businesses, they explained.

The Ministry of Finance officials said that this co-financing loan facility will be the first Thailand is to receive from the international banking community after it experienced a financial crisis beginning in early July last year.
It shows confidence in the Thai economy by the international money market and signals the recovery of the Thai economy, they stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUGH KWAN APPOINTED SUPERIOR JUDGE FOR LOS ANGELES COUNTY

TEXT.P: California Governor Pete Wilson announced the appointment of Rugh A. Kwan as superior court judge for the County of Los Angeles, another major promotion of Chinese Americans in the judicial system of California.

Kwan, 42, of South Pasadena, has been a municipal court judge of the East Los Angeles Judicial District, County of Los Angeles, since 1995. Previously, she was a deputy city attorney for the Los Angeles City Attorney's Office from 1981 to 1995.

Kwan, a Hong Kong native, moved to the United States in 1970, and earned a bachelor's degree from the University of Southern California in 1978 and a juris doctorate from the University of California, Hastings College of the Law, in 1981.

Kwan is a member of the California Judges' Association, National Association of Women Judges and the Municipal Court Judges' Association. She is also a member of the Asian Pacific Bar Association of California and the Southern California Chinese Lawyers' Association.
Ming Chen, justice of the California Supreme Court and also appointed by Gov. Wilson, is the first Chinese-American ever to hold the highest position in California's judicial system.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPACT OF ASIAN MONETARY CRISIS ON M'LAND CHINA UNDERESTIMATED
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 14 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The impact of the Asian financial turmoil on mainland China has been so great that the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) said it expects Beijing to revise its forecast for the mainland's 1998 economic growth from 8 percent down to 7.2 percent.
Economic statistics released by mainland China's State Statistical Bureau under the State Council indicate that the OECD's estimation is correct, said the Paris-based newspaper Le Monde on Monday.

According to the statistical report, the industrial product growth rate was 8.2 percent in the first quarter of this year, far below the 11 percent rate of the same period of 1997. The mainland's annual economic growth rate was 8.8 percent in 1997.
Industrial products had an 11.3 percent growth rate in January 1998. The rate plummeted, however, to 4.9 percent in February, though it climbed to 9 percent in March.
Although the mainland's industrial products scored a 13 percent growth rate in 1997, the rate in the last quarter of that year had declined to 9.6 percent.

Mainland China's economic development has been export-oriented. Growth in the export sector, however, slowed to 12.8 percent in the first quarter of this year, down from 20.9 percent in 1997, indicating that the impact of the Asian monetary crisis that broke out in July last year has spread gradually to the mainland.

Mainland China's import sector has also been affected by Asia's financial troubles. The mainland's imports from other Asian regions in the first quarter of 1998 increased 7.3 percent, including an 11.6 percent increase in imports from South Korea and a dramatic rise of 33.5 percent in imports from Thailand, the statistical report indicated.

Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji stressed during his visit to Paris last week that Beijing will not devalue the yuan. In order to minimize the impact of the economic sluggishness in Asia, Beijing turned parts of its exports in the first quarter to regions other than Asia, with a 17 percent increase in exports to regions other than Asia, including a 40 percent raise in exports to Central America.
The Beijing authorities are fully aware of the importance of a sound financial system in getting rid of the impact of the Asian currency crisis, said the Le Monde.

Beijing is planning to overhaul its financial systems within three years, restructure state-owned enterprises, stimulate internal markets and invest in construction projects on a huge scale, including the building of public housing, schools, hospitals and public service projects, the French daily reported, adding that all of this will be aimed at achieving the expected economic growth level.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG JIAXUAN LEAVES S'PORE AFTER SHORT VISIT

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan left Singapore for Beijing Tuesday after a brief visit here.
Tang, who flew into Singapore from Jakarta Monday afternoon, was making his first visit to Singapore since his promotion to foreign minister last month

He called on Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong shortly after arrival Monday afternoon. Later, he also called on Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew and had a meeting with Foreign Minister S. Jayakumar, who hosted a dinner for him Monday.
Before coming to Singapore, Tang had been in Jakarta on a three-day working visit to Indonesia.
During his stay there, he held talks with Indonesian President Suharto and Foreign Minister Ali Alatas.

He also offered aid to the financially battered country, including US$3 million worth of grants for medicines, export credit worth US$200 million over two years and an offer to increase barter trade between mainland China and Indonesia, said reports from Jakarta.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE MILLIONAIRE OFFERS FUND FOR HUMAN CLONING

TEXT.P: A retired Australian has announced he will establish a A$3 million (US$2 million) fund for research into human cloning.

The Australian Financial Review, Australia's leading business newspaper, reported Tuesday that Paget Sayers has run an advertisement in the daily that he would support funding for "human cloning research."
Sayers said he is interested in advancing cloning to the point of making copies of human bone marrow, skin and organs for medical purposes.
Describing himself as a "facilitator" of funding for cloning projects, Sayers emphasized that he is not talking about cloning whole humans.

Sayers, 68, who became wealthy in the giftware trade, is known for having espoused a number of radical causes. He attracted attention when he visited North Vietnam at the height of the Vietnam War and proposed importing North Vietnamese cigarettes into Australia to illustrate the point that Canberra was not officially at war with Hanoi. In 1996, while a euthanasia debate raged across Australia, he proposed building a suicide hospice in Sydney.

Sayers said he and his friends could provide more money for the cloning projects so that such work could provide medical benefits, including an end to the steadily increasing cost of human organs for transplant operations.
Sayers is now running the newly created Einstein Institute for Social Studies from his home in Sydney.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANDEAN NATIONS WANT FREE TRADE IN SERVICES BY 2005

TEXT.P: The presidents of South America's Andean nations agreed to work toward free trade in services within their five-nation bloc by 2005, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Tuesday.
In the Ecuadorian coastal city of Guayaquil, the Andean Community presidents signed an accord to work out a framework to begin negotiations on free trade in services within the first half of 1998.

The Andean Community groups Ecuador with Colombia, Bolivia, Peru and Venezuela. With a total population of 102 million people, it is South America's second largest bloc after MERCOSUR, which is dominated by the region's two giants, Brazil and Argentina.
The presidents also signed a joint declaration calling for multilateral cooperation to fight drug trafficking.
The community has experienced strains in recent years, and Ecuador and Peru fought a brief border war in 1995.

The Andean nations are due to sign a free trade deal with MERCOSUR in the next few weeks, before their leaders head to Santiago, Chile, to help launch negotiations for a free trade area throughout North, South and Central America, the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA PRAISES BIZ MIGRANTS FROM ROC FOR JOB CREATION

TEXT.P: Business migrants from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia and South Africa have invested large sums of money in Australia that have created more job opportunities for Australians and contributed a lot to the Australian economy, Federal Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said.

Ruddock said the five locations were Australia's top sources of "business skills migrants," accounting for 80 percent of all such arrivals. Business migrants from Hong Kong took the lead with 27 percent, followed by Indonesia, 19 percent; Taiwan, 16 percent; South Africa, 11 percent; and Malaysia, 7 percent.

In a news release faxed to CNA Tuesday, Ruddock said the latest data from the survey of business skills migrants who arrived during 1994-95 looks at their progress 36 months after their arrival in Australia.
He said businessmen from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia and South Africa have invested almost A$300 million (US$197 million) in businesses in Australia.

"The number of jobs created by business migrants investing in existing Australian businesses has doubled -- each migrant is creating an average of 14.9 additional jobs, up from 7.4 jobs in the previous survey," he said.

"The number of migrants successfully engaging in business also continues to grow, with some 88 percent of arrivals currently in business, up from 78 percent in the previous survey of 1993-94 arrivals," he said.
"About 45 percent of these are in wholesale trade, 14 percent are in retail trade, another 14 percent are in business and property services and 10 percent are in manufacturing," Ruddock said.
He said a total of 4,143 business migrants (excluding family members) have arrived in Australia under the business skills class since it was introduced in 1992.
"The government believes these migrants will continue to improve and strengthen their position in the marketplace over time with great benefit to the Australian economy," he said.

Business analysts, however, said the official figures do not fully reflect the actual data from business migrants. Business migrants from Taiwan alone have invested at least A$1 billion since the early 1990s, they said.
Business migrants will continue bringing Australia economic benefits and contributing to job creation, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCIENTISTS LEARN HOW FLIES ESCAPE FROM SWATTING

TEXT.P: Flies have stick-tape feet, elastic wing hinges and a navigation system to enable them to escape from a swat in less than 30 milliseconds, according to American and Australian scientists.
US researchers have discovered the secret of the guidance system that enables the buzzing pest to bob and weave so skillfully, according to a report in Tuesday's edition of The Sydney Morning Herald.

Two tiny, drumstick-shaped organs called halteres respond to visual and physical cues as they stabilize and steer so-called "true" flies, Dr. Michael Dickson and his colleagues at the University of California at Berkeley and DePaul University in Chicago reported in the journal "Science."
The scientists said flies with their halteres removed quickly crash to the ground.

Australian Museum entomologist Dr. Daniel Bickel said the halteres, which evolved from the hind wings of primitive flies, orient the insects in flight, much like the gyroscope in a modern aircraft's autopilot.
The beating of a fly's wings is controlled by separate "flight muscles" attached to the thorax or front part of the insect's body, Bickel said.
The flight muscles cause the thorax to vibrate up and down, he said.
The resulting contraction and compression of the thorax moves the wings, which are "hinged" to it by a rubbery material called resilin.
"Resilin is the most highly elastic substance found anywhere," Bickel said.

Dickinson and his team revealed the dual mechanism of the halteres by tethering flies inside a chamber. They observed that muscles controlling the halteres stiffened or "fired," depending upon whether the flies "saw" vertical, sideways or diagonal patterns of moving stripes.
Bickel agreed with their conclusion that the halteres serve as a "major control center or relay station" for visual or physical messages to change the direction of flight.
He said the fly's foot pad glands coat the tips of hairs on its six feet with a light adhesive. To unstick itself, the fly must lift its feet by starting at one end of each foot.
"It's like peeling a piece of sticky tape," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAI HSIAO-YEN'S DEATH ANNIVERSARY MARKED

TEXT.P: One year after her only child's kidnapping and murder, local television celebrity Pai Ping-ping said she has found comfort only by dedicating herself to the campaign for a more secure living environment here.
Pai published a book recounting her daughter Pai Hsiao-yen's tragic death and the incident's impact on her hearts and minds on Tuesday to mark the first anniversary of Hsiao-yen's murder.
Pai told a news conference that proceeds from the book, titled "Fly Bravely! My Dear Daughter," will all be donated to police for purchasing an ambulance in hopes to save more lives.

The popular actress-TV hostess said she earnestly hopes her daughter's death will help awaken local people to fight crime and create a safer and more harmonious living environment. "I also hope my daughter's soul will finally lay to rest," an emotional Pai added.
In remenbrance of her daughter, Pai has set up cultural foundation to promote children's and adolescents' physical safety and well-being.

Pai said at Tuesday's conference she feels regret that the only surviving mastermind of Hsiao-yen's kidnapping-murder, Chen Chin-hsing, still refused to disclose the source of the large quantities of firearms previously possessed by him and his accomplices.
"Although Chen had made a public apology to me during a court hearing over Hsiao-yen's death, I couldn't believe he truly repents his sins until he reveals the source of his firearms," Pai stressed.

Hsiao-yen was a 17-year-old senior high school student when she was kidnapped near her home in Linko on the outskirts of Taipei on April 8, 1997. The kidnappers originally demanded a record ransom of US$5 million, but they never showed up to pick up the money. Her chained and naked body was discovered in a ditch in Wuku, Taipei County about 10 days after her murder on April 14 last year.

Hsiao-yen's tragic death, following two other high-profile murder cases reported in late 1996, shocked the nation and sparked a public outrage over the government's inability to curb the mounting crime rate. Two massive-scale demonstrations were staged in Taipei last May to push the government to take effective measures to stem crime and bring to justice all suspects involved in all those cold-blooded criminal cases.
Under intense police efforts, two of the three masterminds of Hsiao-yen's kidnapping-murder, Lin Chun-sheng and Kao Tien-ming, committed suicide in separate shootouts with police last year.

The only surviving key suspect, Chen Chin-hsing, surrendered to the police last November after a 24-hour standoff at the residence of a South African diplomat in suburban Taipei. Chen took hostage the South African diplomat and his family. Though the diplomat and one of his daughters were unintentionally injured by Chen in the process, his wife, youngest daughter and a baby in the family's care were released unharmed.
During their run, Chen and Kao Tien-ming also committed many other crimes, including the murder of three persons at a Taipei plastic surgery clinic and a series of rapes.

Chen was given unprecedentedly harsh sentences by the Panchiao District Court on Jan. 22, 1998, including five death sentences, two life terms in addition to 59 years and six months in prison. Chen has appealed his case to the Taiwan High Court, whcih held its first hearing on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL VISIT TO MAINLAND POSSIBLE THIS MONTH: MAC

TEXT.P: Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said on Tuesday that a visit to Beijing later his month by a deputy secretary-general of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) is highly possible.

Lin said there is a good possibility that the SEF will dispatch a deputy secretary-general to Beijing on April 21-22 in response to a proposal put forward by its Beijing-based counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
The proposal came in a message from the ARATS to the SEF on Monday, suggesting a meeting to discuss relevant issues which would pave the way for a visit by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu to mainland China.

Although the date proposed by the ARATS is only one week away, Lin said the SEF will very likely dispatch a deputy secretary-general to Beijing at that time, which is also very close to the fifth anniversary of the historic first meeting between Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.
However, Lin was reluctant to disclose which of the two SEF deputy secretary-generals will be appointed to embark on the mission.
Koo and Wang met for the first time on April 29, 1993 in Singapore, marking the first contact between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in more than 40 years.
The SEF and the ARATS are semiofficial organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to deal with bilateral exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.

Regular SEF-ARATS talks were unilaterally suspended by Beijing in 1995 after ROC President Lee Teng-hui paid a visit to the United States in the summer of that year. Beijing interpreted Lee's historic visit as a move towards the promotion of Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES CANADIAN LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday received a group of Canadian members of Parliament (MPs) and reiterated the Republic of China's determination to realize national reunification in accordance with a gradual, sequential plan.

Accompanied by Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan, the Canadian MPs, including Gar Knutson, Celine Hervieuxipayette, Inky Mark, Charles Hubbard, Stan Dromisky, Pauline Picard and Devinder Malhi, paid a courtesy call on Lee at the Presidential Office, where they exchanged views with the ROC officials on issues of mutual concern between the ROC and Canada.

Lee told his guests that in addition to having had rapid economic development, the ROC on Taiwan has been very successful in various reforms, and that people on Taiwan not only have wealthy lives but also enjoy full democracy and freedom.

Taiwan attained these achievements in a relatively short period of some 50 years, the president pointed out. He said the ROC would like to share the invaluable "Taiwan experience" with the Chinese mainland and other countries in the world.

The visiting Canadian MPs, who said they were deeply impressed with Taiwan's political, economic and social development, agreed with Lee that the "Taiwan experience" could serve as a model to others. They also expressed their hope that in addition to strengthening their current economic and trade relations, Canada and the ROC can also enhance their cultural exchanges.
The visitors also expressed concern over cross-strait relations and asked about Taiwan's current challenges.

In his reply, Lee reiterated that there has been no change in the ROC's determination to seek national reunification. The president, however, also pointed out that there are still large gaps between both sides of the Taiwan Strait in their political systems as well as in the ways of life of their inhabitants.

He said that the ROC government devised the "Guidelines for National Unification" in the hope of achieving the peaceful reunification of China gradually, in order to let those on both sides of the strait enjoy political freedom, democracy and an equitable distribution of wealth.

The president also said that the ROC is a sovereign state and said that it therefore expects to be able to join international organizations and to make its own contributions and give feedback to the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROFESSOR DEFENDS HIS ARTICLE'S REFERENCES
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, April 14 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Professor Li Chia-wei of National Tsinghua University on Tuesday defended the form of references to Taiwan in his essay published in the US periodical Science in March, saying that they do not run counter to the Republic of China's national policy.

Li and mainland Chinese paleontologist Chen Junyuan jointly discovered the oldest-known fossils of complex animal life forms, known as "pre-Cambrian sponges with cellular structure," earlier this year in Guizhou, southern mainland China.
The two scientists identified sponge remains and animal embryos in the 580-million-year-old Early Vendian Doushantuo phosphate deposit in central Guizhou.
Their finding has moved back the date of the earliest appearance of complex and varied forms of life on earth by 40 million to 50 million years.
The finding is poised to supply important data toward understanding the mystery of evolution's "big bang," known as the Cambrian explosion.

"Our discovery of the oldest animal fossils, including sponges and various kinds of animal embryos, indicates there were probably varieties of animals belonging to several known phyta that lived 40 million to 50 million years before the Cambrian explosion," Li said in an interview with Taiwan media in February.
The important discovery -- published simultaneously in separate reports in the March issue of Nature, a British journal, and Science -- look set to rewrite the history of life on the planet.

The journal Science, however, was castigated on Tuesday by the New Nation Front, a pro-Taiwan independence political group comprising several members of the Legislative Yuan, for identifying Li as being from "Taiwan, China."

The New Nation Front, organized by six ex-members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, blasted Li for using funds from the ROC National Science Council to conduct his research with mainland Chinese scientists but then "not using Taiwan's name."

In response, Li, now deputy president of National Tsinghua University, discounted the fact that the article in Science identified him as an expert from the "National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, Taiwan, China" and the National Museum of Natural Science, which he formerly headed, as being in "Taichung, Taiwan, China."
Likewise, the article identified the mainland Chinese paleontologist as an expert from "Nanjing, China," Li noted.

Li said he followed a tacit understanding that when an academic report involves cross-Taiwan Strait issues, the authors choose to define or interpret the meaning of "one China" differently. While Taiwan-based academics have their own interpretation of "one China," their counterparts in mainland China have another, he added.
Li said he does not think that the references in the Science report to "Taiwan, China" infringe upon the ROC's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO REDUCE PRICES

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced on Tuesday that from midnight, April 15, domestic prices of oil products will be reduced by an average of 1.51 percent.

The price reductions will affect consumer prices as follows: high grade gasoline -- cut from NT$18.4 to NT$18.2; unleaded 95 gasoline -- down from NT$18.2 to NT$18; unleaded 92 gasoline -- down to NT$17; high-grade diesel oil -- NT13; and ordinary diesel oil -- NT$11.8.
Household liquefied natural gas (LNG) will be cut from NT$11.33 to 11.11 per kilogram, while LNG for cars will be reduced from NT$10.9 to NT$10.8.

According to the CPC, as of the end of March this year, the company's cumulative surplus in fiscal year 1998 amounted to NT$11.03 billion, which, compared to the budget goal of NT$16.55, means there is still a shortfall of NT$5.52 billion.

However, due to a decline in international oil prices and the stability of the new Taiwan dollar, participants in an oil price advisory group meeting held on April 10 expressed their optimism on future oil price trends.
Prompted by this optimism, and in order to reflect the decline in oil prices, the CPC said it decided after careful consideration to adjust domestic prices of oil products downward.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC DISAGREES WITH IMF FORECAST FOR TAIWAN'S CPI GROWTH

TEXT.P: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has estimated the annual growth rate of Taiwan's Consumer Price Index (CPI) will hit 4 percent this year, but local officials disagree.

Officials of the Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Tuesday that after taking into consideration the fluctuation of the new Taiwan dollar, they forecast a 3 percent rise in the island's CPI this year.
The forecast is based on the fact that despite price hikes for foodstuffs, especially vegetables, caused by Typhoon Herb in 1996, Taiwan's CPI growth only reached 3.07 percent for that year.

Seasonal demands and currency fluctuations are two major factors which decide changes in consumer prices, the CBC officials said, adding that the latter tend to have less impact on consumer prices than on wholesale prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: STEADY YEN IS BENEFICIAL TO NT$, SAYS KMT BUSINESS MANAGER

TEXT.P: A steady Japanese yen is beneficial to Taiwan's currency, and if the yen rebounds in the future, it will in turn make room for the new Taiwan dollar to appreciate, Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT) Business Management Committee, said on Tuesday without elaborating.

Liu, who made the remarks before departing for Tokyo to take part in a meeting, noted that if the yen plummets substantially in the future, the NT dollar will have difficulty maintaining its value. Again, he did not elaborate.

However, the ruling KMT's top business manager stressed the unlikelihood of the yen depreciating further, given the fact that major world economic watchdogs such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) have reached a tacit consensus that maintaining financial stability in Northeast Asia and Southeast Asia is essential if another financial storm is to be avoided in the region.

Meanwhile, commenting on the latest IMF forecast which projected Taiwan's real economic growth for 1998 at 5 percent, Liu admitted that Taiwan's economy has to some extent been affected by the Southeast Asian financial meltdown, but stressed that it will definitely be no problem for Taiwan to achieve growth of at least 5 percent this year.

In a report on global economic prospects released on Monday, the IMF forecast that Taiwan's economic growth rate for 1998 will be adjusted downward to 5 percent, the lowest level for the island in 16 years but the highest rate among the four "Asian tigers."
The IMF predicted that the four "Asian tigers" -- Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea -- will chart an average 1.8 percent annual growth this year, the lowest increase since World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CALLS FOR CUSTOMS MONITORING DATA EXCHANGE ACCORD

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Tuesday called for the signing of a memorandum or an accord on the exchange of customs monitoring data with the United States in order to bolster cross-border crackdowns on intellectual property rights (IPR) infringements.
Taiwan made the proposal during the second day of a bilateral trade consultation with the United States on disputed issues related to IPR protection.

During the meeting, the US delegation, led by David Burns, a senior adviser to the US Trade Representative (USTR) office, accused the ROC government of failing to trace sources of commercial piracy, and the Taiwan customs authorities of failing to stop pirated goods from being shipped abroad, serious charges which could see Taiwan be placed back on the US' annual "Special 301" watch list this year.

The Special 301 list is expected to be published by the end of this month. Countries found to lack adequate IPR protective measures for US products will be listed, making them subject to punitive trade sanctions.

Burns quoted a recently released 1998 USTR report on trade barriers as saying that the number of Taiwan-made pirated goods seized by customs agents around the United States in 1997 was up more than 100 percent from 1996.

Burns also noted that while the USTR plans to include Paraguay on this year's Special 301 list, US customs authorities found that a number of pirated goods from Paraguay actually originated from Taiwan, prompting the US to cast doubt on Taiwan's export monitoring system (EMS).
The Taiwan-US IPR trade consultation meeting opened in Taipei on Monday and will run until Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA FISHERMEN COMPLAIN OF ROUGH TREATMENT

TEXT.P: A group of fishermen from mainland China involved in a maritime dispute with the ROC Navy on Sunday have complained of mistreatment by Taiwan coast guards and have demanded compensation from the Taiwan authorities.

In a letter to Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) quoted the fishermen from Fujian Province as saying that Taiwan coast guard officers roughed them up when they were returning to their home port after escorting a sister fishing boat to a Taiwan port for repair.
The SEF and ARATS are semiofficial agencies set up by Taipei and Beijing respectively to deal with cross-strait affairs in the absence of official relations between the two sides.

Crew members of the "Minglianyu No. 0953" said they were en route from Keelung to Fujian when they were intercepted by Taiwan coast guard patrol boat No. 706. Five of the 15 crewmen were beaten up by officers from the patrol boat.
The letter asked the Taiwan authorities to hold the coast guard responsible for the incident, compensate the mainland fishermen, and guarantee that such mistreatment will never happen again.

The Minglianyu No. 0953 was accompanying its sister ship, Minglianyu No. 0954, to Keelung Harbor after the latter was hit by a Taiwan warship in heavy fog on Sunday. The navy called in a barge to tow the damaged vessel to Keelung for repair.
The Minglianyu No. 0954 and its 16 crew remained in Keelung while the repairs were carried out.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPINAL CORD INJURY TREATMENT

TEXT.P: Researchers at the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis have discovered how cells called oligodendrocytes, which insulate the axons of neurons, might die after catastrophes in the central nervous system.

They also found that compounds that block glutamate's destructive action reduce stroke-related injury of oligodendrocytes in culture. These findings appeared in the March 1998 issue of Nature Medicine.

More recent work has revealed that these compounds, called AMPA receptor antagonists, also protect white matter in the injured spinal cord. The compounds are being examined in clinical trials to evaluate safety, and it soon might be possible to test their effectiveness against central nervous system damage.

"Preserving the function of just a small fraction of the damaged long cables that go down the spinal cord could provide meaningful improvement in day-to-day function for people who sustain spinal cord injury," says John McDonald, assistant professor of neurology at the School of Medicine and director of the Spinal Cord Injury Unit at Barnes-Jewish Hospital.

In the early 1980s, researchers at Washington University in St. Louis discovered that glutamate, a chemical messenger that neurons squirt onto other neurons, turns into a killer when it floods onto neighboring cells from ruptured neurons. They named this phenomenon "excitotoxicity" because glutamate can overexcite receptors on nearby neurons, opening channels that admit lethal amounts of calcium. These receptors are called NMDA receptors because they can be stimulated in the laboratory with a glutamate mimic called NMDA.
Subsequent experiments convinced the neuroscience community that oligodendrocytes are invulnerable to glutamate damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISH SPECIES DISAPPEARING FROM TAIWAN'S RIVERS

TEXT.P: About 20 percent of Taiwan's indigenous river fish species have become extinct because of pollution, and fishing with poison and electricity, according to a survey by a local scholar.

The increasing amount of leisure time enjoyed by Taiwan's population, which has seen more and more people converging on the island's rivers for swimming, boating, camping and fishing during holidays, has further threatened fish stocks, according to the survey by Lin Yao-shun, professor of botany at the National Taiwan University.

Lin, who authored the survey after spending a year studying the creeks of Nanshih and Tungho in Wulai, Taipei County, found that there are only eight fish species left in Nanshih, which was previously infested with native fish species, while only seven species survive in Tungho.
The alarming decrease is also apparent in other Taiwan rivers, further illustrating the rapid disappearance of native fish species.
Of the some 150 fish species recorded in Taiwan, 20 percent have already been wiped out by overfishing and pollution, said Lin.

In the two creeks studied by Lin, it is common to see people fishing with poison, electricity or nets. Most of their catches end up on the tables of local restaurants catering to tourists, according to the survey.
Although poisoning and electrocution of fish is illegal in Taiwan, offenders are never caught by law enforcers, said Lin in his survey.

Increasing leisure time also threatens fish stocks as hikers and picnickers contaminate rivers, altering the temperature and volume of water flow, which in turn disrupts fish breeding patterns, said Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW REJECTS JUSTICE MINISTER'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday turned down Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao's bid to resign, said Cabinet secretary-general Chang Yu-hui.
Chang said Siew also instructed him to do his best to persuade Liao to stay in office, noting that his boss had high praise for Liao's performance.
Liao tendered a formal letter of resignation early that morning, following an oral resignation he delivered during a meeting with Siew on Monday.

Liao was quoted by government spokesman Chen Chien-jen as telling Siew that he hopes to devote himself to social welfare activities and his teaching career, as well as to spend more time with his family.

According to Chen, Liao denied that his intention to resign has anything to do with the ruling Kuomintang's plan to field him in the December mayoral election in Kaohsiung City, or with personnel changes in the Investigation Bureau, which is under the jurisdiction of the Justice Ministry.

Public opinion surveys show that, Liao, 52, has been one of Taiwan's most popular cabinet ministers since taking office as justice minister in June 1996 on a platform of a continued crackdown on organized crime and gangsters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MILITARY `BARELY ADEQUATE', SAYS FORMER CIA CHIEF

TEXT.P: Former US Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) Director James Woolsey said in Taipei on Tuesday that Taiwan's lobby in the US legislature is inadequate, and that the ROC Ministry of National Defense (MND) apparently lacks comprehensive planning for military procurement.

Woolsey, who is visiting Taipei with four other American military and intelligence experts, said that only after visiting Taipei in person has he come to realize that the MND's patterns of strategy and military procurement are actually 20 years out of date, leaving Taiwan's military barely capable of coping with modern trends.

Asked whether Beijing might continue to exert pressure on the US to reduce sales of weaponry to Taiwan, Woolsey noted that Washington has no plans at present to alter its arms sales policy regarding Taiwan.
Whatever the PRC demands, Woolsey said, the United States will continue to sell "adequate" arms to Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act.
He suggested that Taiwan bolster the establishment of a missile defense system, saying that only by developing this type of system can Taiwan effectively secure the island's security.

Woolsey pointed out that the ROC government, particularly its representative office in the United States, has failed to lobby the US Congress, so that there is no pressure on the US legislature to push for more military sales to the island.

Woolsey and the four other American visitors -- Dr. Michael Pillsbury, a former deputy assistant secretary of defense, Dr. Gordon Oehler, a former director of the CIA's technology transfer evaluation center, Dr. Kent Harrington, a former head of the CIA's Asian intelligence department, and William Wright, a retired vice admiral who once served as an Asia-Pacific affairs division chief at the US Department of Defense -- are here at the invitation of Parris Chang, the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party's representative in the United States.

They were invited to Taipei to help the people of Taiwan better understand the development of the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing trilateral relationship, and to help work out a strategy to cope with increasingly close Washington-Beijing ties, said Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CATHOLIC ORGANIZATION ISSUES STATEMENT ON NAME CHANGE

TEXT.P: The Chinese Regional Bishops' Conference, a Catholic organization in Taiwan, on Tuesday issued a statement clarifying the recent change of its Chinese name.

The organization, comprised of bishops from the Taiwan area, recently changed its Chinese name to "Taiwan Chiao Chu Chu Chiao Tuan" from the original "Chung Guo Chiao Chu Chu Chiao Tuan," although its English name remained unaltered.

The statement pointed out that the decision was made within the Taiwan Catholic church after discussion and an opinion poll, that the name-change has nothing to do with politics, and that it was made to streamline the administrative operations and future work of the Taiwan Catholic church and to root the Catholic church more firmly in Taiwan.

According to the statement, the opinion poll was conducted before Most Rev. Paul Shan, Bishop of the Catholic Diocese of Kaohsiung, was elevated to archbishop by the Holy See. The poll shows that more than 83 percent of local pastors, parish priests, nuns, and Catholics in general, supported the change of name.

Meanwhile, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official dismissed a report that the change of name may be related to the Holy See's alleged intention of establishing ties with mainland China. He also suggested that the media should spend less time making wild and unfounded reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT INSPECTION MISSION ARRIVES IN THAILAND
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, April 15 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A 50-member investment fact-finding delegation composed of representatives of leading Taiwan enterprises arrived here from Seoul on Wednesday to seek investment opportunities in this Southeast Asian country.

As Thailand badly needs an infusion of foreign capital and investment after being dragged into the center of the Asian financial crisis, relevant local authorities are placing great importance on the delegation's visit.
The delegation will focus its inspection visits on the local silicon wafer, shopping mall, hotel and real estate industries while here, the second leg of its current Asian tour.
The delegation is scheduled to proceed to Malaysia on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
