DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IC PRODUCTION EXPECTED TO TOP US$4.5 B. IN 1998

TEXT.P: With a total of 17 silicon wafer manufacturing plants operating on Taiwan, the island's IC production is expected to top NT$150 billion (US$4.57 billion) in 1998, up a whopping 44 percent from the previous year, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) reported on Wednesday.

Taiwan's IC industry churned out NT$105.3 billion worth of products in 1997, marking a relatively hefty growth of 15 percent from the preceding year. The value translated into a 3 percent share of the global IC market, as compared with 2.4 percent posted in 1996, said a spokesman for ITRI's Electronic Research and Service Organization (ERSO).

According to Chen Hsing-hsiung, deputy general manager of ERSO, the IC production value, tentatively put at around US$4.6 billion for 1998, could be much larger if related foundry services, packaging technology and testing engineering are counted in.

IC manufacturing -- with foundry services, packaging technology and testing engineering included -- will undoubtedly become the flagship of Taiwan's electronics industry, which is in turn the backbone of Taiwan's industrial development, Chen said.
In 1997, Taiwan's electronics sector churned out NT$247.9 billion (US$7.56 billion) worth of products, an increase of 30 percent from the year-earlier level.
The figure is predicted to grow further by a stunning 48 percent to NT$360 billion (US$10.97 billion) this year, according to an ERSO estimate.
Chen attributed the buoyancy in the electronics industry's performance to operational expansions in existing manufacturers and a continual influx of newcomers.
Chen explained that he called the island's IC industry growth of 15 percent last year "relatively hefty" because of how this figure compares to those of other major IC making countries.

The world's IC industries generally experienced a slump in 1996, down a record of 9 percent from the previous year. Although they regained some momentum in 1997 by securing an average growth of 4 percent, their performances were considered slow in contrast with Taiwan's continued growth over the past several years, Chen pointed out.
Taiwan, the world's largest semiconductor maker in foundry service, now dominates 45 percent of the global foundry service business, as compared with 35 percent a year ago.

The remarkable increase in foundry service is mainly because orders from leading IDM companies -- including such big names as IBM and Intel, which design, manufacture and test ICs -- have continued to grow, according to Chen. Last year, about one-fourth of Taiwan's foundry services were conducted for IDM firms, and the ratio is expected to grow to between 30 percent and 35 percent this year.

Taiwan's IC industry, however, is not free from troubles. As compared with the overall production, which commanded about 9 percent of the global IC output last year, the IC industry's transaction value was relatively low, commanding about only 4.4 percent of the world's total.

Chen attributed the low transaction value to several factors, including Taiwan's manufacture of low-added-value IC chips, its taking up of low profit-margin foundry services and its production of other relatively low-priced IC items.

He also pointed out that Taiwan's IC industry must seek to innovate its production pattern, and upgrade its research and development levels if the island is to survive the "third semiconductor industry revolution."

DOC.HEADLINE: TATUNG SELECTS CA'S UNICENTER TNG

TEXT.P: Computer Associates International Inc. (CA) of Long Island, NY, announced Tuesday it has signed a global agreement with Tatung Corp., Taiwan's leading vendor of workstations and PC servers, under which Tatung will use CA's Unicenter TNG to manage its worldwide operations.

Under the new agreement, Tatung will adopt Unicenter TNG to integrate its PC-based global information technology infrastructure, including monitoring its overseas factories. Unicenter TNG's management of multiplatform environments will enable Tatung to integrate heterogeneous and distributed servers, databases, application systems and network architectures in its worldwide offices and manufacturing sites.

"We recognize the fact that in the coming century, our ability to compete and satisfy our customers will be increasingly contingent on having a robust, reliable computing and communications infrastructure," said Tatung President W.S. Lin in a CA news release. "Unicenter TNG will be a key strategic technology for Tatung because it will enable us to maximize the performance of that infrastructure while minimizing our long-term cost of technology ownership."

The release said that Unicenter TNG can lower operation costs and raise productivity, a critical component to Tatung's global logistic system. In addition, it said, Unicenter TNG features -- such as software delivery, network management and "advanced help desk" -- will help Tatung's MIS staff to maximize the efficiency of their IT resources and leverage control of their global network for competitive advantage.

Last fall, Tatung agreed to bundle CA's Unicenter TNG Framework with all its UNIX and Windows NT servers at no additional cost to customers, and to resell Unicenter TNG through its Computers and Communications Business Division. In addition, Tatung's Institute of Technology was authorized to incorporate CA's enterprise management methodology and technologies into its standard curriculum.

CA is the world leader in mission-critical business software. The company develops, licenses and supports more than 500 integrated products that include enterprise computing and information management, application development, manufacturing and financial applications. CA employs over 11,000 people in 160 offices in 43 countries and had revenue of US$4.5 billion in calendar year 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPELLED CANADIANS ACCUSE MEXICO OF TRYING TO BURY ATROCITY PROOF

TEXT.P: Two Canadian women expelled from Mexico told a press conference in Montreal Tuesday that the Mexican government wants to get rid of witnesses who can talk about repression in Chiapas.

Julie Marquette and Sarah Baillargeon were arrested and deported over the weekend. Marquette said, "It's clear they (the Mexican authorities) don't want people to see what's going on. They don't want the rest of world to have proof of what they're doing."

The two Quebec women insisted their role in Chiapas was "strictly passive" and that they were not serving as political activists in any way. They said they were there only to observe the respect of human rights.

But what they observed from last Thursday until their arrest was anything but respect, Marquette claimed. The thousand or so people in a village had formed an autonomous village administration; the two Canadians were invited, along with 30 other Mexicans and foreigners, to observe.

Marquette said soldiers arrived by night -- about as many police and soldiers as the villagers -- and rounded up the Zapatista sympathizers and burned houses; they also arrested the observers and smashed their cameras and video equipment, she said.
Marquette, 21, and Baillargeon, 24, said they were treated like criminals after their arrest in the southern state of Chiapas. They added they were refused water, food and freedom.
Marquette said she will never remain silent after this experience. She called on the government of Canada to address the issue of human rights abuses in Mexico on a government-to-government basis.
The two were in Chiapas for Salut Le Monde, a Montreal-based human-rights group. They are among 12 people deported on charges of trying to help the aboriginal people create an independent state.
Mexico has accused the observers of meddling in its internal affairs. It said it was defending national sovereignty.

Canada's Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy said earlier he disapproves of the way the expulsions were handled. He said he plans to ask his Mexican counterpart about the deportations during a regional summit next weekend in Santiago, Chile.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER COURTS JAPANESE INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 14 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Visiting Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming of the Republic of China said on Tuesday that high-tech Japanese companies should take advantage of the current situation to invest in Taiwan.

Stressing that the recent Asian financial crisis has had only a limited impact on Taiwan, Yin said this is because of Taiwan's solid industrial base, the ROC government's liberalization policies and the island's flexible small and medium-sized business sector, adding that Taiwan's high-tech sector -- including the biochemical, pharmaceutical and aerospace industries -- will continue to grow.
Speaking at a news conference here, Yin said he expects Japan's investment in Taiwan to reach a new high this year, noting that the figure surged to US$850 million in 1997.

Turning to Taiwan's expanding trade deficit with Japan, Yin attributed the phenomenon to Taiwan's growing importation of key parts and components from Japan, and he expressed the hope that the ROC's mounting trade imbalance with Japan would narrow with the increased establishment of joint venture partnerships between companies of the two countries.

The vice economics minister also called on mainland China not to politicize the motives of Taiwan's aid proposals for crisis-hit Southeast Asian countries, saying that doing so would not help resolve the problems. "Helping needy neighboring countries is tantamount to helping ourselves," he noted.
Yin arrived in Osaka on Sunday at the head of a 20-member trade delegation. The delegation then proceeded to Tokyo on Tuesday and is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 PERCENT PAY RAISE FOR GOV'T WORKERS CLEARS LEGISLATIVE HURDLES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Finance and Budget Committees on Wednesday in a joint session passed an overall central government budget plan for FY 1999 that includes a 3 percent pay raise for the island's public functionaries.
Public servants, including government employees, military personnel and teachers, will get a 3 percent pay raise next fiscal year, which begins on July 1, sources from the Legislative Yuan reported.
The 3 percent pay raise, decided after evaluating the government's financial capabilities and relevant factors, will cost the government NT$11.82 billion (US$358 million) in the next fiscal year.

Meanwhile, the two committees also screened the plans for financing the "Second Reserve Fund" and subsidies for the provincial and city governments. All plans were passed without any budget cuts whatsoever.

The Second Reserve Fund, devised for emergency aid purposes, was allocated NT$9.6 billion (US$293 million) for FY 1999, some NT$3.5 billion (US$107 million) more than in the preceding year, mainly to cover possible aid to Southeast Asian neighbor countries to help them weather the regional financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC DEPUTY GOVERNOR MEETS US DEPUTY TREASURY SECRETARY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 14 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A visiting senior ROC banker on Tuesday urged the United States to support a Taiwan initiative to help battered Asian economies under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Shea Jia-dong, deputy governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC), made the appeal while meeting with US Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers.
Shea told Summers that the Taiwan initiative doesn't require Asian governments to provide funds. "They only have to serve as an underwriter," he noted.

According to the proposal, the central banks of battered Asian economies issue the US dollar-denominated bonds for sales in APEC countries to raise funds for repaying their short-term foreign debts or financing major development projects.

APEC groups 18 economies -- Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, mainland China, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the US.
Shea said the proposal is mainly aimed at absorbing private capital to help cash-strapped Asian countries revitalize their economy.

In addition to the central banks of the bond issuing countries, Shea said the Asian Development Bank (ADB) as well as private and state-owned banks of APEC economies willing to join the program can also serve as underwriters for such bonds. "By so doing, the bonds will be able to attract even more investors," he said, adding that the ADB once floated Dragon bonds in Taiwan, which had received good market response.

Shea told Summers that the APEC Business Advisory Council already approved this Taiwan initiative at its annual meeting held in early March in Mexico. Several APEC members, including Malaysia and Indonesia, have also expressed keen interest in the project.
In response, Summers said he has never heard of this proposal, adding he is willing to carefully study its feasibility.

Summers further said the US will be willing to throw its support behind any special Taiwan initiatives to help its Asian neighbors in case those programs are acceptable to the international community.

Stephen Chen, ROC representative to the US, told Summers that the Republic of China cannot participate in many international relief programs and economic cooperation conferences. For instance, the US didn't invite Taiwan to attend a meeting of central bank governors and finance ministers from 22 economies, also known as G 22 meeting, to be held in Washington, D.C. later this week.

Noting that the ROC is willing and can afford to join various international cooperative programs, Chen said he hopes the US would support its bid to enter major international financial and economic organizations.
For his part, Summers suggested that the ROC more actively contact all countries around the world to explore bilateral or multilateral cooperative programs in various fields.
Summers further said he has on many occasions helped clarify some misunderstandings about the New Taiwan dollar's devaluation last October.

Fred Bergsten, director of the Washington-based Institute for International Economics, once accused Taiwan of having intentionally allowed its currency to depreciate, asserting that the devaluation was totally unnecessary and violated every norm of international cooperative behavior.
Summers said he disagreed with Bergsten's view and has helped clarify such misunderstandings.

Shea, heading a high-profile delegation of finance and economics officials, arrived in Washington, D. C. on Sunday. Shea's mission is to seek opportunities for Taiwan to join international financial cooperative programs.

On Monday, Shea and other mission members also met with Lawrence Meyers, a governor of the US Federal Reserve System, to exchange views on a range of issues, including the possible impact on Taiwan's economic growth of the Asian financial crisis, the greenback's future moving directions and the development of single European currency.
Following its Washington visit, the group will also travel to New York and Chicago to meet with American financial experts and bankers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROPOSES IMPROVED EXPORT MONITORING SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Wednesday proposed to make comprehensive amendments to Taiwan's export monitoring system (EMS), in an effort to stay off the US' "Special 301" watch list of countries not doing enough to stem intellectual property rights (IPR) infringements.
The proposal was made during the second day of a bilateral trade consultation meeting with the US on disputed issues related to IPR protection.

The US delegation, led by David Burns, a senior adviser to the US Trade Representative (USTR) office, accused Taiwan of being the US' second-largest source of pirated goods in the world in 1997, behind only mainland China, serious charges which could see Taiwan placed back on the Special 301 list this year.

Having discovered that the number of Taiwan-made pirated goods seized by customs agents around the US in 1997 was up more than 100 percent from 1996, and that some popular "Nintendo" video game software from Paraguay actually originated in Taiwan, the USTR began to cast doubt on the executive efficiency of Taiwan's EMS since 1992, according to Burns.
The Taiwan delegation, headed by Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-General Chen Ruei-lung, promised to see to it that Taiwan's EMS is immediately bolstered and improved.

The measures will include increasing the Directorate General of Customs' responsibility for cracking down on IPR infringements and violations, conducting all related inspection work in customs offices, and changing the "pass first, inspect later" pattern for all 17 categories of US-bound computer software products into a pattern of "inspect first, pass later."
The new EMS will also impose 100-percent inspections on export products from companies with a prior record of IPR infringements, Chen noted.
The US is expected to publish this year's Special 301 list by the end of this month. Countries found to lack adequate IPR protective measures for US-bound products will be named on the list.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE COPS DETAIN 22 UNION WORKERS FOR BLOCKING CARGO LOADING

TEXT.P: Australian police have detained 22 sacked workers of Patrick Stevedores Ltd. for blocking trucks carrying containerized cargoes for loading at the company's terminal at Port Botany in Sydney.

A police spokesman said thousands of former workers of Patrick, accompanied by their spouses and children, staged a picket line near the port, blocking the way for trucks to load cargoes at Patrick's terminal.
It is understood the 22 detained workers will be questioned for blocking the cargo loading, but it remains to be seen whether they will be charged.
Australian Prime Minister John Howard on Wednesday defended the police action and condemned the picketers.

The sacked workers, mainly members of the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA), were supported by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), Australia's biggest union group, and scores of university students.

ACTU assistant secretary Greg Combett on Wednesday accused the Australian government of conspiring with Patrick to sack MUA member workers, saying the ACTU "will support the MUA all the way through" in its protest against the firing of the union workers by Patrick.
Both the MUA and Patrick are suing one another at the federal court.

The MUA is suing Patrick for unlawful sacking and wants all 1,400 fired workers to be reinstated. But Patrick is suing the MUA for unlawful picket lines in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Fremantle and other ports to block cargo loading.
Labor industry analysts believe the showdown between Patrick and the MUA will continue in the coming week or even months until a compromise is reached between them.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed low on the Taipei Stock Exchange on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 42.73 points to close at 8,807.31.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 8,887.06 and experienced a low of 8,720.87.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 221 to 202, with 68 stocks remaining unchanged.

A total of 2.13 billion issues changed hands on a market turnover of NT$108.01 billion, an increase from the previous session which saw 2.10 billion shares change hands on a market turnover of NT$107.67 billion.

Five of the eight major categories registered losses, with cement stocks moving down the most at 0.5 percent, followed by foodstuff shares and plastics and chemical issues at 0.4 percent, pulp and paper stocks at 0.3 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.2 percent.
Meanwhile, the electrical category gained ground, moving up by 1.5 percent, followed by construction issues and textile shares at 0.2 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Wednesday's trading were: Ever Fortune Ind.; Yueh Loong Co., Ltd.; Microtek International, Inc.; Picvue Electronics; International Bills Finance; Formosan Rubber Group; United Micro Electronics; Far Eastern Silo & Shipping Corporation; Chu Wa Wool; and Silicon Integrated Systems Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY EXERCISES SEEN RENEWING CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS

TEXT.P: Military exercises by Taiwan and mainland China are expected to renew tension between the two sides, according to a mass circulation newspaper in Australia Wednesday.

In a dispatch from Beijing, The Sydney Morning Herald's correspondent David Lague reported that mainland China will conduct military exercises near the Taiwan Strait this week and that the Republic of China's Defense Ministry will conduct exercises later this month.

In an article headlined "Two Chinas Rattle High-tech Sabres in Taiwan Straits," Lague quoted military analysts in Beijing as predicting that the exercises could renew tension between Taiwan and mainland China because the Taiwan Strait is one of the world's most dangerous flash points.

The daily reported both Taiwan and mainland China will test new high-tech weapons and tactics in the exercises, which are clearly aimed at fighting a war across the 160 km of water that separate the two rivals.
Mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) will mount massive military exercises to boost its capability to fight high-tech wars, the daily reported.
The daily also reported Taiwan will mount similar military exercises later this month.

Military analysts believe Taiwan now still holds the edge in technology over mainland China, but they note that the PLA has been shopping for new fighters, artillery, tanks, communications, warships and radar.

Tension between the two sides has receded since early 1996 when the United States sent two aircraft carrier battle groups to the South China Sea to deter mainland China from attacking Taiwan when Beijing was conducting missile tests near the island, the daily reported.

However, the risk of a military clash remains a threat to regional peace as support for independence remains strong in Taiwan while Beijing refuses to rule out the use of force if the island declares its independence from the mainland, the daily reported.

The daily reported that the United States, which is determined to boost its ties with mainland China, has warned Taiwan's independence movement by sending senior defense officials, including William Perry, Gen. John Shalikashvili and Brent Scowcroft.

The US officials told Taipei that Washington would not support Taiwan if it declares independence because it would bring the United States into direct confrontation with mainland China, the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCOTTISH, AUSTRALIAN SCIENTISTS SEE CLONING AS POTENTIAL LIFESAVER

TEXT.P: Cloning technology may one day provide a cure for quadriplegia, paraplegia, serious illnesses such as malaria and Parkinson's disease, and may also be able to save the lives of thousands of people awaiting organ transplants, according to Scottish Professor Ian Wilmott, who stunned the world last year when he introduced "Dolly" the sheep, the first mammal to be created through cloning.
Wilmott and a group of other scientists are currently in Australia to discuss cloning at a scientific meeting at Monash University in Melbourne.

Dolly is expected to make headlines again soon when she gives birth because she is now pregnant, Wilmott told reporters on Tuesday. "She is now coming up to two years old... normal breeding age. So she is pregnant," Wilmott said.
Wilmott said he opposes the cloning of humans and is comfortable with a British law that prohibits human cloning.
"If you were to make a copy of somebody, I don't think you are treating that child as an individual. So it's a sort of a child abuse story," he said.
"I have not heard of a reason for cloning a person which I find attractive, ethically acceptable," he added.
But Wilmott said there is a clear distinction between cloning a human being and producing cells in order to treat diseases.
He said breakthroughs following on from the cloning of sheep may eventually cure many diseases in humans.

Professor Alan Trounson, deputy director of the Institute of Reproduction and Development at Monash University, agreed, predicting that one day a human will be cloned for "very, very good medical reasons."
"I think it's a fact of life that everything has both a good side and a bad side," he added, pointing out that it will be up to society to determine how far cloning will go in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS HIGHLIGHTS S'PORE'S STRENGTHS, SAYS LEE

TEXT.P: The Asian economic crisis has highlighted Singapore's strengths as a center for high-tech, high value-added manufacturing, Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Tuesday.
He pointed out that the regional crisis may have given Singapore breathing space for a few years, but as neighboring economies recover, they will emerge as leaner and stronger competitors.

The government is committed to ensuring that the manufacturing sector remains a major pillar of the Singapore economy for the long term, he said at the opening of a S$1.3 billion (US$810 million) semiconductor plant in Singapore by Japan's Hitachi and Nippon Steel Corp. Tuesday.

To keep Singapore's manufacturing sector vibrant, Lee pointed to three strategic thrusts: building capabilities through science, technology and innovation; manpower resource management; and building outstanding companies by nurturing local enterprises.
However, he said, manufacturers must embrace innovation to seek new business opportunities and areas of growth.
The government is also looking into further infrastructure and facilities that would help foster more research and development and innovative activities, he added.
And to encourage what he termed "techno-entrepreneurs" to set up in Singapore, he said the government is exploring ways to assist start-ups.

Suggestions include encouraging start-ups to offer alternative forms of remuneration, such as stock options and setting up an additional platform for those with good technologies, but no track record, to raise funds from the public.

Looking beyond financial incentives to give the economy a competitive edge, Lee said: "We also need to create an environment that nurtures creativity, where rules and regulations are not beyond what is necessary. An environment that is conducive to calculated risk-taking and is tolerant of 'intelligent' failure."

He hailed the opening of the Hitachi Nippon Steel silicon wafer fabrication plant as a milestone for Singapore, being the first such plant here involving majority stakes from two leading Japanese corporations.

The plant -- which will make 64-megabit dynamic random access memory computer chips -- is a joint venture between Singapore's Economic Development Board (which will control 30 percent of the company), Japan's electronics giant Hitachi (35 percent) and engineering conglomerate Nippon Steel (35 percent). It will employ 600 engineering professionals and skilled workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE STOCK MARKET HITS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: The Australian stock market, buoyed by US banking mergers, rose further Wednesday morning after hitting a record high Tuesday, while the Australian dollar hit a three-month low Tuesday and headed further down against the greenback early Wednesday, market analysts said.

They said the bank merger mania in the United States has encouraged Australian investors to buy banking shares in this country, bringing the All Ordinaries Index to a record high of 2840.9 on Tuesday, up 35.1 points from Monday's closing level. The index rose another nine points in morning trading Wednesday.

"The stock market is bullish because the bank merger mania has thrilled many Australian investors," one analyst said, adding, "They believe the mania will have a far-reaching impact on the banking industry in Australia."
"There is much room in our stock market for further expansion as the index remains relatively low now," another said.

But the Australian dollar dropped 0.64 US cents further after plunging to a three-month low of 64.90 US cents on Tuesday, down 1.05 US cents from Monday's closing level, foreign exchange dealers said.

They attributed the plunge of the local currency to a string of factors, ranging from the waterfront dispute between Patrick Stevedores and the Maritime Union of Australia, to an expectation of further interest rate cuts.
The dispute has and is delaying shipments as more and more ships are forced to wait for both loading and unloading their cargoes in major Australian ports, they said.

"The waterfront dispute is turning off international investors. The international community perceives that our own backyard problems are now more sharply in focus. They are adopting a wait-and-see attitude now," one dealer said.

Businessmen hope that the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will reduce banking interest rates further so that Australia can improve its competitive edge in the world market. The RBA made five interest rate cuts between July 1996 and July 1997, bringing the official rate to 5 percent from 7.5 percent.

Dealers believe the Australian dollar could drop further if the waterfront problem continues to worsen. They expect the Australian currency to drop to 63.20 US cents, which is the 11-year low it hit earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIAO STANDS FIRM ON RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao said on Wednesday that his decision to resign was made after thorough consideration and that his intention to leave the post remains unchanged.

Liao, who took a four-and-a-half day leave beginning on Tuesday after submitting a formal letter of resignation to Premier Vincent Siew that same day, made the remarks via fax in answer to reporters' questions.

Stressing that he is determined to quit politics in order to devote himself to social welfare activities, the popular justice minister also expressed appreciation for concern and encouragement from President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Siew, and the general public.
Liao also said he would think over a suggestion by Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei that he remain in the post, but added that he remains firm in his decision to leave.
Huang called on Liao on Tuesday night on behalf of the president, to encourage him to stay in order to continue serving the country and the people.
Meanwhile, Liao's official resignation was turned down by Siew, who instructed that Liao's resignation letter should be returned to his office.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLANS FOR MAINLAND CHINESE MEDIA PERSONNEL TO BE BASED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Although the idea of sending reporters to Taiwan for long term news coverage has been mulled by the mainland Chinese news media, "no plan has yet been mapped out," in this regard, according to a Beijing-datelined story from the Hong Kong-based Wen Wei Bao on Wednesday.

The story centered on an upcoming 10-day visit to Taiwan on April 17 by a 16 member delegation comprised of heads and representatives of mainland China's 11 central government-level media, at the invitation of the Cultural Foundation of Taiwan's United Daily News.

The delegation is scheduled to visit some 20 media organizations in Taiwan, including the Taipei-based Central News Agency, the Central Daily News, and the China Times. They will also visit the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a quasi-official intermediary body set up to handle exchanges between Taipei and Beijing in the absence of official ties between the two sides.

The delegation will be headed by Xie Hong, deputy editor-in-chief of the Communist Party of China's (CPC's) official mouthpiece the People's Daily, according to the Wen Wei Bao. He will be advised by Li Guoan, director of the Information Bureau of the Propaganda Department under the Central Committee of the CPC, who is also vice chairman of the All China Journalists Association; Zhang Minching, director of the Information Bureau of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, who is also chairman of the board of the China Journalists Association; and Feng Xiwang, deputy director of the CPC Central Office for Overseas Publicity, who is also the deputy editor-in-chief of the Five Continents Communication Center.

The aim of the trip is to focus on journalistic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, but matters concerning sending reporters to Taiwan for long term coverage will not be discussed, stressed the daily.

High ranking administrative or working staff from the Xinhua News Agency, the Economic Daily, the Guangming Daily, the Workers' Daily, the Peasants' Daily, the China Youth News, the China Law Daily, and the China News Service will be among the other members of the delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: YANG MING SHIPPING COMPANY TO JOIN NEW WORLD'S ASIA-MED SERVICE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Yang Ming shipping company is expanding its relationship with The New World Alliance (TNWA) with the deployment of vessels on its Asia-Mediterranean service, The Business Times of Singapore reported on Wednesday.

A joint statement from Yang Ming and TNWA -- which comprises shipping companies from Singapore, South Korea and Japan -- said that beginning "later this year" Yang Ming will participate in the Asia-Mediterranean service as a vessel operator, the report said.
A spokesman for Yang Ming's Head Office in Taipei said that they have yet to decide how many vessels the company will deploy on the service, the report added.
TNWA members currently operate eight 2,413 twenty-foot-equivalent unit (TEU) container vessels on the route.
The deal is an extension of a cooperation pact announced by Yang Ming and TNWA earlier this year, the report said.
The decision to join the TNWA on the Asia-Mediterranean route sees Yang Ming bring to an end its five-year cooperation program with France's Compagnie Maritime d'Affreitment (CMA) on the same route.
The Yang Ming spokesman said that the new deal will enable the carrier to offer better-quality service to its customers in Japan.

The TNWA Asia-Mediterranean service calls at Pusan Port in South Korea and the Japanese ports of Kobe, Nagoya and Yokohama before sailing on to Taiwan and then the Mediterranean via the Middle East, whereas the joint service with CMA originated in Taiwan and did not call at any Japanese ports.
Yang Ming has also established a vessel-sharing agreement with China Ocean Shipping Co. and K-Line on the trans-Atlantic trade route, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, TAIWAN REACH CONSENSUS ON CRACKING DOWN ON PIRATED GOODS

TEXT.P: Trade officials from the United States and Taiwan on Wednesday reached consensus on cracking down on pirated goods from Taiwan entering the US, on the third and last day of a round of consultations on US intellectual property rights (IPR) infringements.

The US delegates, led by David Burns, a senior official of the US Trade Representative (USTR) office, promised to provide data every quarter from US customs concerning IPR infringements for Taiwan's reference.
The US side will also provide complete information on 165 cases involving counterfeit products originating from Taiwan last year.

Taiwan's chief negotiator Chen Ruey-long of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said the information provided by the US will allow the government to learn what kinds of pirated goods were seized by US customs officials and how they violated US trademark, patent, or copyright laws.
Chen said the government will then be able to take action to plug loopholes in the laws regulating the export of goods, which will have a positive effect on combating the export of pirated goods.

He reemphasized the fact that the government and private sector have made a great deal of effort to ensure IPR protection. "Taiwan attaches great importance to IPR protection, and cherishes its image in the international community," Chen said.
He expressed the hope that the US will not put Taiwan back on the "Special 301" list because of the IPR issue.
To increase the efficiency of the crackdown on counterfeiting, Taiwan also promised to strengthen its export monitoring system (EMS), which is also of serious concern to the US, Chen said.

The US negotiators noted that while the USTR plans to include Paraguay on this year's Special 301 list, US customs found that a number of pirated goods from Paraguay actually originated from Taiwan, prompting the US to cast doubt on Taiwan's EMS.
The US will decide by April 30 whether to list Taiwan among countries that fail to adequately protect IPRs. Inclusion on the list would subject Taiwan to punitive retaliatory trade sanctions.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM DOESN'T WANT TO SEE TAIWAN PLACED ON SPECIAL 301 LIST

TEXT.P: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei has expressed concern to the office of the US Trade Representative over the possibility that Taiwan will be placed on the "Special 301" watch list, which is to be announced by the end of the month.

AmCham President Jeffrey Williams told US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky in a letter dated April 13 that the chamber has noted that a number of company and industry representatives in the US have asked that Taiwan be designated as a priority foreign country or be put back on the Special 301 watch list this year.

Saying that AmCham was pleased that Taiwan was removed from all Special 301 lists in late 1996 and was able to avoid being named to any category in 1997, the president expressed worry that Taiwan will be listed as a copyright violator because of its deficient efforts to curb intellectual property rights infringements.

The chamber agreed that more effort should be made by Taiwan to improve its laws and enforcement measures on IPR, he said, adding that putting Taiwan back on one of the Special 301 lists at this time would not be a good idea as it would be counterproductive to the overall ongoing efforts by both the Taiwan side and US government and industry to improve IPR in Taiwan.
He stressed that while continued monitoring of Taiwan's progress in the area of IPR protection should be carried out, there is no need to return Taiwan to one of the Special 301 lists.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEARCH FOR MISSING F-16 GOING ON

TEXT.P: All available evidence still does not fully ascertain that a F-16 jetfighter which lost contact during a routine training flight on March 20 crashed into the sea, a senior intelligence official said on Wednesday.

Yin Chung-wen, director of the National Security Bureau, was quoted by opposition New Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang as having made the statement at a closed-door Legislative Yuan Defense Committee meeting.

Yin told lawmakers present at the meeting that the security bureau basically respects the views of the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) on the possible fate of the aircraft and pilots aboard.
Both the AFGH and the MND said the twin-seat F-16 from the Chiayi air base was most likely to have crashed into seas off Penghu, an island group lying off the southwestern Taiwan coast.

However, Yin said neither the wreckage of the plane nor any oil spill has so far been discovered in waters near where the aircraft was supposed to have crashed. "So at the moment, we still do not have adequate evidence to justify claims that the fighter crashed into seas," Yin was quoted as stating at the meeting.

Yin promised that his bureau will employ all resources at its disposal to assist in search of the warplane and the two Air Force officers aboard -- flight instructor Maj. Wen Chin-sung and trainee Capt. Chang Chia-cheng.
"Yin was very cautious and prudent while talking about the issue. I support his reserved attitude," Lin said.

Lin recounted a Cold War-era incident to caution military authorities to exercise wariness in handling the case to avoid being misled by any Communist Chinese tricks. In the 1950s, a US U2 reconnaissance plane was shot down during a high-altitude flight in the air space of the now-defunct Soviet Union.

Shortly after the incident, then US President Dwight D. Eisenhower said the plane had intruded into the Soviet air space by mistake. But a few days later, Gary Francis Powers, the U2 pilot, publicly admitted on Soviet television that he was engaging in a secret monitoring mission.
Meanwhile, rumors have it that the missing F-16 plane has appeared in the southern mainland Chinese city of Guangzhou.
MND officials said they would not comment on such unfounded reports. They quoted an analysis by an MND-AFGH joint task force as indicating that the plane was most likely to have crashed into seas.

Following a comprehensive study of the loyalty, character, daily lives and family backgrounds of the two pilots aboard, as well as of the flight path and all radar records showing the entire process from the start of the plane's flight until the disappearance of its signals, the officials said, the task force has few reasons to conclude that the plane had been commandeered to rival mainland China.
Moreover, the officials said they see no reasons for Beijing authorities to conceal the news should the F-16 really have defected to the mainland.

For one thing, the officials said, the missing plane was not the most advanced F-16 C/D version. It is not difficult for the mainland to obtain information about software and hardware on the F-16 A/B fighters.

The officials said what mainalnd China really wants is intelligence about the ROC Air Force's combat strategies or tactics. The two pilots' ranks are, however, not high enough to allow them access to such information, the officials asserted.

In addition, the officials said, neither side of the Taiwan Strait any longer offers financial incentives or other rewards to defecting military officers from the other side. Against this background, the officials said, chances that the two F-16 pilots have defected are slim.

The officials further said the military has not given up its search and rescue operations, adding that the MND is also investigating the whereabouts of the plane through various intelligence channels.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE URGES FULL SUPPORT FOR KMT CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, who is concurrently chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), on Wednesday called for full party support for the KMT candidates which will be fielded in the election of the national legislature at the end of this year.

Lee issued the directive at a Central Standing Committee meeting on Wednesday which approved the first-wave namelist of candidates to be fielded for nine election areas. He ordered the KMT Organizational Affairs Department and related agencies to coordinate with local KMT units islandwide and make all-out efforts to help the candidates win the election.

The namelist consists of 22 candidates, of which 12 are incumbent legislators, six are incumbent members of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, two are incumbent members of Taipei City Council, one is an incumbent member of the National Assembly, and one holds no official position.
The first batch of KMT candidates are:
Penghu County: Legislator Lin Pin-kun.
Taipei City No. 2 election area: Legislators Chen Hung-chi and Pan Wei-kang; Taipei City Councilmen Chen Hsueh-seng and Lee Ching-an.
Hsinchu City: Legislator Lin Cheng-tse.
Hsinchu County: Legislator Chen Yung-chin.
Chiayi City: National Assemblyman Huang Hui-min.
Nantou County: Taiwan Provincial Assemblyman Chang Ming-hsiung.
Kaohsiung County: Legislators Lin Yuan-san, Siew Chin-lan, and Wang Jin-pyng; Taiwan Provincial Assemblyman Chung Sao-ho and Kaohsiung citizen Lin Yi-shih.
Lowland Indigenous Peoples: Legislators Chuang Chin-shen and Chang Jen-syang; Taiwan Provincial Assemblymen Lin Cheng-eh and Yang Jan-fu.
Highland Indigenous Peoples: Legislators Kao Yang-shen and Chuen Wen-sheng; Taiwan Provincial Assemblymen Tseng Hua-teh and Lin Chun-teh.
KMT spokesperson Huang Li-chin said after the meeting that the candidates were fielded after considering factors such as their images, powerbases, actual strengths.
The second batch of KMT candidates to run for the election is expected to be approved at the end of April or the beginning of May.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.024 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.928.
The greenback opened at 32.891 and was traded between 32.891 and 32.949.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$173.50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.024 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.928.
The greenback opened at 32.891 and was traded between 32.891 and 32.949.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$173.50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP TO EXPLORE LATIN AMERICA FOR INVESTMENT OPPORTUNITIES

TEXT.P: The first of five delegations will depart later this month to inspect the investment climate in six Latin American nations, Kao Chin-yen, chairman of Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), said on Wednesday.

Kao said the delegation, comprised of 10 food industry executives, will leave on April 29 to explore investment opportunities in basic foods and retailing industries in Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador, Dominica, Costa Rica and Panama.
The second delegation will depart June 10 to explore opportunities in the construction of new city and towns as well as highways and bridges.
After the delegations return, they will immediately convene a meeting to discuss the details of forming of an investment holding company in the region.

The company is the brainchild of President Lee Teng-hui, who first proposed the idea after his visit to Latin America last September. Lee later urged Kao to mobilize domestic enterprises to invest in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN TO VISIT COSTA RICA

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan is scheduled to leave Taipei on either May 3 or 4 to San Jose via New York and Miami to attend the inauguration of Costa Rica's newly elected President Miguel Angel Rodriguez.

During his stay in Costa Rica, Lien will represent ROC President Lee Teng-hui in attending President-elect Rodriguez' inauguration on May 8. He will also meet with Taiwan investors and members of the overseas Chinese community in the Central American country.

Lien and his wife will be accompanied by Foreign Minister Jason C. Hu, Deputy Secretary-General to the President Su Chi, Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien, and Ling Shiang-nung, vice chairman of the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan, among others.
In addition, a group of industrial and commercial entrepreneurs will also organize a mission to coincide with the vice president's trip.
Meanwhile, Chao Tze-chi, president of the World League for Freedom and Democracy (WLFD), also revealed that WLFD will hold a Latin American regional meeting in Costa Rica.

This will be Lien's third overseas trip after visiting Singapore in January and Jordan and Malaysia in March this year. The vice president and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taiwan in mid-May.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-NUCLEAR ACTIVISTS DEMAND CLOSURE OF N-POWER PLANTS

TEXT.P: A local anti-nuclear alliance on Wednesday staged a demonstration in front of the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council (AEC), calling for closure of Taiwan's three existing nuclear power plants.
The Taiwan Anti-Nuclear Action Alliance also demanded that the council revoke a permit for a controversial fourth nuclear power plant now under construction.

A spokesman for the alliance further blamed the AEC for failing to revise the domestic radiation exposure dose limit in accordance with new standards set by the International Committee of Radioactive Protection (ICRP) in 1990.

Taiwan still follows the per capita annual radiation dose limit of 5 mSv. set by the ICRP in 1977. In fact, the spokesman said, the ICRP reduced the limit to 1 mSv. per person annually in 1990. "The council should immediately lower the domestic radiation exposure ceiling to 1 mSv to conform with the ICRP standard and better protect local people's health," he urged.
The spokesman also condemned the AEC for its inability to stem the use of radioactive steel plates and bars in construction of residential buildings on the island.

Several private residences constructed between 1993 and 1994 were recently found to contain contaminated steel bars. "Six years have passed since the first batch of radioactive homes were discovered. What has the council done to improve the situation?" he asked.

The first group of radioactive homes were mostly built between 1982 and 1984. More than 180 additional radioactive buildings have been discovered over the past years, and many of these structures were constructed between 1987 and 1992.

"Since the AEC has required all local steel mills to install radioactivity monitoring equipment starting in 1992 and such facilities have also been installed at all toll stations along the Sun Yat-sen Expressway, how can residential buildings constructed in 1994 contain contaminated steel bars?" the spokesman said. "We demand to know whether the AEC has performed its supervisory duties faithfully and whether it has discovered the culprits behind these problems."

As nuclear waste from the three existing nuclear power plants is believed to be the primary source of radioactive contamination, the spokesman said the three plants should be closed as soon as possible to resolve the "hot houses" problem once and for all.

The alliance has designated April as anti-nuclear awareness month. It has planned a series of activities to enlist support for its cause, including a large-scale parade in Taipei scheduled for April 26 to mark the 12th anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in the now-defunct Soviet Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PORT SETS RECORDS IN CONTAINER HANDLING

TEXT.P: The Port of Singapore Authority Corp. (PSA) has set two new records in the area of container handling so far this year, in terms of the number of containers handled in a single month and on a single-vessel call.

In March, the PSA set a new record for the number of containers handled in a single month -- 1.31 million twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs). This is the highest monthly throughput recorded so far since containerization began at the Port of Singapore in 1972, the PSA said on Wednesday.

The previous record was established in October 1997, when PSA handled 1.27 million TEUs in that month. The record throughput handled last month was 10 percent higher than the throughput handled in March last year.

On April 2, the PSA also set another new record -- the largest number of containers handled during a single-vessel call -- with 5,600 TEUs being loaded and unloaded from the 6,600-TEU Susan Maersk at a vessel rate of 125 moves per hour, the authority said.
On average, the PSA handles about 2,000 TEUs for a third-generation vessel.

The PSA's overall annual average container rate for 1997 is 88 moves per hour, which is the fastest in the world, the authority said. The average turnaround time for a vessel with 1,000 containers at the PSA is about 11 hours, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER MEETS FORMER CIA HEAD

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew expressed the hope that the United States will continue to sell high-performance defensive weapons to Taiwan in line with the Taiwan Relations Act.
Siew made the remark when he met James Woolsey, former director of the US Central Intelligence Agency, here on Wednesday.

Siew noted that the Republic of China has made substantial progress in democratic development and advancement of human rights in the past decades. He said this not only serves as a model for other Asian and Pacific countries, but also exerts a positive force for political reform in the mainland China.

To safeguard the well-being of Taiwan people, as well as the peace and stability of the Asian Pacific region, he urged the United States to continue selling weapons to the ROC so long as Beijing continues to refuse to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
Siew expressed cautious optimism on whether the ongoing economic reforms in the mainland will be successful.

Siew noted that new mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji, in embarking on an ambitious overhaul of state-owned enterprises and the agricultural sector, will be forced to lay off over 20 million workers from unprofitable state-run businesses alone. He said chronic mass unemployment will result in destabilization on the mainland.
The premier also said that although Zhu has achieved initial success in controlling inflation in the mainland economy, many uncertainties lie ahead.

Siew said Beijing's reforms in agriculture must involve more than simply the upgrading of productivity. Educational reform is also an urgent need as most of the peasants in the mainland are illiterate, and it will be a daunting task to provide them with new knowledge and technical skills, he said.

On the role Taiwan can play in the financial crisis currently afflicting Asia, Siew said Taipei is willing to provide assistance. However, he emphasized that the problems cannot be solved by any individual country, but rather through multilateral mechanisms.

Siew reiterated the proposal that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should work together to discuss with Southeast Asian nations to find means by which to ensure financial stability and sustainable economic growth in the region.
Woolsey, who served as head of the CIA between 1993 and 1995, arrived here Monday for a private visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DIPLOMAT URGES AUSTRALIA TO BOOST EXCHANGE OF VISITS BY OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: A diplomat from the Republic of China on Wednesday urged the Australian government to encourage "frequent visits by cabinet-level officials" between the two countries in order to help facilitate bilateral trade and investment.

Speaking at a conference in Melbourne held under the theme "Expanding Horizons: Taiwan and Australia's Future," Benjamin Liang said despite the end of diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and Australia 27 years ago, trade and investment relations between the two countries "have thrived."

He cited several investment ventures, including Dual Technologies, D.G. Technologies, Da Hsing Winery, High-tech Quartz and Newspaper Recycles, that have been successfully implemented since he became the director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Melbourne 21 months ago.
He said two-way trade between Taiwan and Australia totaled US$4.2 billion in 1997 with Australia enjoying a large trade surplus.
He told Australian participants at the meeting that Taiwan has made enormous reforms by eliminating nontariff barriers and lowering tariffs in recent years.

The ROC government has also made considerable concessions to Australia, including the first import of 2,000 Australian-made cars, a 40 percent cut of tariff differentiation faced by Australian beef, doubling the quota of Australian apples, and first-time access for stone and citrus fruits in Taiwan.

But if Australia wants to get bigger market share in Taiwan, Liang said: "I feel that the Australian government could encourage frequent visits by cabinet-level officials to Taipei and vice versa either as individuals or as officials. This is most important for furthering networking and understanding."
He reminded Australia government officials not to "take Taiwan's Australian dollars market for granted."

"Have high officials visit Taiwan and attend activities such as the Joint Conference of Australia-Taiwan Business Council and the ROC-Australia Business Council to enhance substantive relations between Taipei and Canberra. I certainly hope that Canberra will continue to work with us to promote these objectives," he said.
As the ROC continues its efforts to move forward in its economic liberalization and globalization, "Taiwan's presence in international community should not be denied," he said.

Other speakers at the conference were Prof. Bruce Jacobs, director of the Center of East Asia Studies of Monash University; Ron Bowden, a member of the Legislative Council who serves as the chairman of the Taiwan-Victoria Parliamentary Friendship Association; and his vice chairman, Noel Naughan, also a member of the Legislative Council; and Jeff Turner, trade director of the Australian Business Center in Taipei.
The conference was sponsored by the Australian Institute of International Affairs in Melbourne.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN NEIGHBORS URGE JAPAN TO CUT TARIFFS

TEXT.P: Southeast Asian countries and South Korea are calling on Japan to lower or abolish customs duties on a range of items and to boost domestic demand, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Wednesday.
Japan's imports from Asia have fallen steeply at a time when countries affected by the currency crisis are trying to rebuild their economies through exports.

According to the WTO report, Indonesia and Malaysia are pressing Japan to lower customs duties on plywood. Thailand is calling for preferential treatment on jewelry and foodstuffs, such as pork and chicken. And the Philippines would like to see a cut in duties on tropical fruit including papayas, pineapples and bananas.
Neighboring South Korea is asking for lower tariffs on processed foods.

These countries are also calling on Japan to agree to abolish import tariffs on marine and forest products by June this year as part of the voluntary liberalization programs put forward at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum last summer.

Japan's imports from members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations have fallen 10 percent to 20 percent on an annual basis in recent months, after stagnating since the currency crisis hit Thailand last July, the WTO report said.
US Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin and other Western officials are also putting pressure on Japan to open its markets to products from Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN CHAN MEETS FORMER US CIA HEAD

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Wednesday told visiting former US Central Intelligence Agency Director (CIA) James Woolsey that the Republic of China and the United States share the same aspiration for democracy, freedom and human rights, and have maintained long-term friendly ties.

Lien said that the ROC has become one of the youngest democratic countries in the world after having carried out democratic reforms over the past several years. Saying Taiwan is willing and able to help other countries, Lien asserted that it is a gross injustice that Taiwan has been ignored internationally due to its refusal to accept communism as a political system and lifestyle.

Lien told the former CIA head that Taiwan is glad to see the process of constructive engagement between the United States and mainland China. But, he said, the ROC also hopes Washington can develop relations with Taipei that are on a parallel with its ties with Beijing.

On the possibility that Taiwan might be placed on the "Special 301" watch list for its alleged failure to offer sufficient intellectual property rights protection, Lien said that Taiwan values its trade and economic relations with the United States, adding that such conflicts are common among trade partners. The vice president expressed optimism that solutions to the IPR protection issue can be worked out.

Lien also touched on cross-strait relations. While urging the mainland authorities to resume the long-stalled dialogue between Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits and Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation, Lien pointed out that Taiwan does not hold any predetermined stance on the meeting and does not exclude the possibility of negotiating any issue.

Lien reiterated that competition between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should be in comparison of political systems instead of in military confrontation, adding that the Chinese have the right to choose the lifestyle they want. The vice president voiced confidence that "Time is on our side."

Woolsey praised the substantial progress Taiwan has made in democratic reform, economic development and human rights protection. He also suggested that Taiwan strengthen its communications with the US government and the Congress as part of efforts to upgrade bilateral relations.
Woolsey, who served as CIA head between 1993 and 1995 under President Bill Clinton, arrived in Taiwan on Monday along with four intelligence and military experts for a private visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA APPROACHED TO PROVIDE NEWS TO OVERSEAS CHINESE MEDIA

TEXT.P: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), said on Wednesday that the OCAC will ask the national news agency to provide news to overseas Chinese media.

Fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan, Chiao said that the ministry has approached the Central News Agency (CNA) to provide fast and reliable news to Chinese-language media outlets in various parts of the world.
New Party Legislator Chou Yang-shan said that the overseas Chinese community is a formidable force and he urged the ROC government to avail itself of its resources.

Chou and his colleagues Huang Chin-lin, Ko Yu-chin, Wu Huei-tsu and Tsai Sheng-pan co-sponsored a motion asking the OCAC to approach the CNA about providing news to overseas Chinese media. They said that would contribute greatly to the understanding of overseas Chinese around the world about the political and economic situation in Taiwan.

The OCAC said information it has collected indicates that overseas Chinese media are often unable to get fast and accurate news about Taiwan, frequently relying on "grapevine" sources, hearsay or even mainland Chinese propaganda organs.

The commission concluded that it is an urgent task to step up news services to overseas Chinese media groups in order to counter the onslaught of Chinese-language news being launched from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA LAUDS PRESERVATION EFFORTS ON LANYU SCOPS OWLS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) on Wednesday acknowledged the efforts by a domestic soft drink giant in helping to preserve the scops owls of Lanyu Island.
The Hey Song Corp. donated a check for NT$1.05 million (US$31,020) to Academia Sinica, the most prestigious research institute in Taiwan, to assist its research on Lanyu's endemic scops owls.
COA Chairman Peng Tso-kwei said the owl species only breeds on the small island of Lanyu, off Taiwan's southeastern coast. Their population has dwindled to about 1,000.
Peng said the Lanyu scops owl has been listed by the World Conservation Union as an endangered bird, and has also been declared as a protected species under local laws.

The bird is nocturnal and carnivorous, feeding primarily on insects. The species requires special living conditions, and if its environment were to undergo dramatic changes, its survival would be threatened, the COA chairman said.
Peng stressed that Lanyu scops owls are the precious assets of all people in Taiwan. He urged the public to donate money for the research and preservation of the rare and endangered birds.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY EXCHANGES NOT A FOCUS OF CLINTON-JIANG AGENDA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 15 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Despite increasing military exchanges between Beijing and Washington, military issues are not expected to be a centerpiece of the agenda for a forthcoming summit meeting between the top leaders of the two countries, Pentagon sources said on Wednesday.
Because of Beijing's resistance, the sources said, military exchanges between the United States and mainland China are still far from close and face many restrictions.

As a result, the sources said, military exchanges will be only one of the many topics for discussion when US President Bill Clinton makes a state visit to the mainland to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in late June.

Noting that Beijing still resists strategic-level military contacts with Washington, the sources said no military agreements are expected to be signed during Clinton's mainland visit. Nor will Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen be among Clinton's entourage.

The sources further said armed forces-related topics to be touched upon in the upcoming Clinton-Jiang summit meeting will focus on cooperation in disaster relief or rescue operations as well as in investigations into the fate of American servicemen listed as missing since the Korean War in the early 1950s.
The sources said Washington has been promoting exchanges of visits by high-ranking military officials in hopes of pushing the People's Liberation Army to increase openness and transparency.
The United States also hopes more personnel exchanges will help reduce the risk of misunderstandings or accidental conflicts, the sources said.

Under this policy, arrangements were made for mainland Defense Minister Chi Haotian and Logistics Department Director Wang Ke to visit the US Pacific Command in Hawaii and several military academies during their respective US trips in December 1996 and in early April this year.
In contrast, the sources said, mainland China is still reluctant to open its strategic military installations to US observers or to arrange for them to meet with its combat unit commanders.

It marked a breakthrough when Cohen was offered access to an air force command center in Beijing during his January visit to the mainland, the sources said. During that visit, Cohen also signed an agreement with the mainland, aimed at avoiding naval conflicts resulting from unfamiliarity with each other's operational procedures or principles.

Another mainland military top brass, Zhang Wannian, who serves as vice chairman of the Central Military Commission of the Chinese Communist Party, is also scheduled to visit the United States on May 5-21.

Washington-Beijing relations were strained during the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis, but their engagements, including military exchanges, have gradually resumed and become ever closer since Anthony Lake, then White House national security adviser, made a visit to Beijing in the autumn of that year.
