DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA NOTES 'SYSTEMIC PROBLEMS' IN MAINLAND CHINA'S TRADE REGIME

TEXT.P: The Canadian government said Tuesday that despite the immense opportunity that the Chinese mainland presents, there are "a number of significant systemic problems and practices" impeding access to that market.

In a trade policy report, Ottawa listed such obstacles as the mainland's high import tariffs and nontariff barriers, inappropriate standards and investment hurdles, as well as the inability to appeal rulings by Beijing officials through a judicial review process and a lack of transparency on the part of the communist regime.

High tariffs on imports are one of the principle impediments to Canadian exports, said the report titled "Opening the Doors to the World: Canada's International Market Access Priorities 1998." It was released by International Trade Minister Sergio Marchi.
"A common problem with the Chinese market is a lack of transparency and the inconsistent application of laws, regulations and import practices," the report pointed out.

In customs procedures, for example, it is not uncommon for the same product to be subject to different levies in different ports. "This makes for uncertainty in the calculation of export costs and impedes the establishment of consistent, long-term commercial ties," it said.
Another key issue is the application of standards, it added, as there are continuing concerns that standards and requirements for statutory inspection are being used as impediments to market access.

Canada, it stressed, is attempting to obtain a transparent list of those standards, in the context of discussions with mainland China and through the WTO accession process. Canada is also working to identify those standards that are disguised barriers to trade or unnecessary impediments to imports, it said.

Earlier this year the Canadian government released its "China and Hong Kong Trade Action Plan," stressing that Canada's policy approach "takes full account of the reality of China's rapidly growing importance in world affairs."

Canada, it said, considers an economic partnership with mainland China to be a "key element supporting long-term relations and encouraging further integration in global and regional political and economic institutions."

Mainland China is Canada's fifth largest export market. It is third largest if the Hong Kong Special Administration Region is included. In 1997, Canada's combined exports of commodities to the Chinese mainland and Hong Kong reached C$3.78 billion (US$2.64 billion), with imports from the two areas totaling C$7.55 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUSHKIN MUSEUM COLLECTIONS TO BE DISPLAYED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The curator of the Pushkin Fine Arts Museum of Russia, Irina Antonova, arrived in Taipei on Thursday to publicize an upcoming exhibition of the renowned collections from the Pushkin.
The museum is famed as the enclave of pivotal Western European art collections acquired by Russians during the reign of Catherine the Great.

The exhibition, to be held at the National Museum of History (NMH) sometime later this year, will mark the largest-scale painting exhibition in Taiwan from any Russian museum. It will turn a new page in cultural exchanges between the two countries, said NMH Director Huang Kuang-nan.

According to Huang, the Pushkin Fine Arts Museum and the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, better known as the Winter Palace Museum, are two most prestigious museums in Russia, with equal clout in art circles.

The pearls of the Pushkin collections are mainly from the czarist era, with objects from the period when Catherine the Great reigned over Russia between 1762 and 1796 being the centerpieces, Huang said.

During the czarist times, he said, Russian officials were sent to Europe every season on shopping binges to procure highly valued paintings which accumulated within the walls of the Pushkin Museum through the centuries.
The celebrated Pushkin painting collections, masterpieces ranging from the 16th century to the 20th century, include great works by Rembrandt, Botticelli and Rubens.
Paintings by 19th and 20th century masters including Gauguin, Matisse, Picasso, Cezanne and Monet, also are found in the Pushkin collections, Huang noted.

This will not be the first time for the NMH to cooperate with Russia in presenting cultural exhibitions. More than three years ago, the NMH sponsored an exhibition of Silk Road Buddhist artifacts from Khara Khoto, one of the important West Asian cultural collections housed at the State Hermitage Museum.
The NMH also tied a sisterhood knot with the Moscow Museum of Eastern Ethnic Cultures recently for cultural cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMAN MURDERED IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should open dialogue soon on measures to protect the personal safety and property of Taiwan businessmen in the mainland, Lee Ching-ping, deputy secretary-general of the semiofficial Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said on Thursday.
Lee made the remarks after reports said that Taiwan businessman Yeh Jung-fu, 44, of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, was killed at his residence in Quanzhou, Fujian Province, on Tuesday night.

Yeh's wife, who was in the home at the time of the attack, was said to be safe under police protection after being briefly abducted by the assailants. No further details as to the cause of Yeh's death are available as of press time.

Lee said the SEF has asked a Taiwan business association in Quanzhou to help Yeh's family learn the facts of the incident and to handle related matters. SEF will also send a message to its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to request help in the investigation of the murder case.
Reports said that security forces in Quanzhou had nabbed one of the two suspects and that the other one was still at large.
The SEF is now helping two of Yeh's children and other family members prepare necessary papers to travel to the mainland, Lee said.
Meanwhile, Interior Minister Huang Tzu-wen also said Yeh's case highlights the need for both Taiwan and mainland authorities to list crime fighting as a top priority once cross-strait talks resume.
Huang said he believes the top agenda item in cross-strait talks should be the prevention of smuggling activities involving guns and drugs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALMOST HALF OF TAIWAN IMMIGRANTS IN CANADA HOLD UNIVERSITY DEGREES
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, April 15 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Nearly half of all Taiwan immigrants in Canada between the ages of 25 and 44 are graduates of universities or other institutions of higher learning, according to official Canadian statistics.

The statistics indicate 45 percent of Taiwan immigrants in that country within the 25-44 age group hold bachelor or higher educational degrees, while 43 percent of the immigrants from mainland China have university-level degrees.
The percentages rank just behind those for immigrants from the United States and the Philippines in Canada within the same age group, according to the statistics.

The tallies show 55 percent of the American immigrants aged 25-44 are graduates of universities or other high-level learning institutions, standing in the top position on the list. They are followed by the 48 percent of those degree-holders who resettled in Canada from the Philippines.
Currently, there are 10,500 Taiwanese immigrants in Canada within the age group under study. Of that number, 51.7 percent of males and 40.8 percent of females hold university-level degrees.

The number of immigrants from mainland China amounts to 32,600. Among them, 49 percent of the males and 39 percent of the females are graduates, with most holding degrees in scientific and technical fields, the statistics indicate.

Although the number of US-born residents with graduate degrees is the highest among all immigrant groups, the percentage of science and technology graduates is the lowest, the figures show. Degree-holders in those fields from Taiwan and mainland China top the list.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA TO VISIT TAIWAN AT YEAR'S END

TEXT.P: Tibet's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, was said on Thursday have confirmed a return visit Taiwan at the end of this year at the invitation of the Chinese Buddhist Association.

The visit, like his first appearance here in March 1997, will be purely religious in nature, a spokesperson for the Dalai Lama said. He will preach Tibetan Buddhism without scheduling any official or political activities during the 10-day stay, the spokesperson for the Tibetan liaison office in Taiwan said.

Kesang Takla, director of the Tibet Religious Foundation of H.H. The Dalai Lama, and the first representative in Taipei from the India-based Tibetan government-in-exile, said the Dalai Lama will concentrate his teachings on the Vajra Abhisecana, one of the supreme Buddhist rites administered by holy personages as a release from calamity and preparation for the next life.

The Tibet Religious Foundation was officially established Thursday on Keelung Road in eastern Taipei. Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui attended an inaugural ceremony marking the organization's opening in the afternoon.
During the Dalai Lama's first visit to Taiwan in March last year, his messages of love and compassion and his personal charisma attracted massive crowds islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S LARGEST NAVY SHIP DECOMMISSIONED

TEXT.P: The ROC Navy held a grand ceremony at the Hsinpin naval wharf at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan on Thursday to mark the retirement of its largest logistical service ship Yu Tai.

The naval repair ship, launched in 1944, first served in the US fleet and was transferred to the ROC Navy in 1975. During its 23 years of service here, the Yu Tai has played a critical role in logistical services, including naval fleet repair, refueling and spare parts supply.

Hundreds of naval officers who had served on the Yu Tai and their families were invited to attend its decommissioning ceremony, which was presided over by Yeh Chu, head of the logistical service fleet under the Naval Fleet Command. Among the participants were the Yu Tai's nine previous captains.

Speaking on the occasion, Yeh said the Yu Tai has contributed much to the Navy over the past two decades. It has taken part in more than 40 military exercises and seven overseas friendship promotion missions. It once sailed to Saudi Arabia, South Africa, Singapore, Indonesia and Fiji for goodwill visits or offering aid and medical services.

The 16,000-ton Yu Tai ship is reputed as a floating factory. It has a well-endowed workshop and a large warehouse. It can also serve as an emergency medical center in addition to offering repair, refueling and maintenance services for seaborne warships.

The ship stands 191 feet high, with a length of 492 feet and a width of 73 feet. Equipped with machineguns and other weaponry systems, the ship can accommodate 247 persons. Over the past 23 years, it has logged more than 183,900 nautical miles.

Following its retirement, Yu Tai will be auctioned off and dismembered, naval authorities said, adding that its functions will be assumed by a large fuel-ammunition supply ship now in service with the Navy.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAN ON ELECTRONIC DEVICES ON PLANES REAFFIRMED

TEXT.P: Cellular phones are banned on planes and passengers who violate that regulation will be dealt with severely, Chang Chia-chu, vice minister of transportation and communications, reaffirmed on Thursday.
Chang made the remarks after reports said that a woman on a domestic airliner had used a cellular phone in mid-flight earlier this month.

The woman, surnamed Wu, was reported to aviation security officials by another passenger on the UNI Airlines flight from eastern Hualien to Taipei on April 5. The passenger reported that Wu had used her cellar phone onboard the plane, an act which could endanger the safety of others.

Aviation authorities traced the woman, who admitted to using the cellular phone but said she only operated the device when the plane had safely landed and was taxiing on the runway. She claimed to have never used the phone while in mid-flight.

But Chang said civil aviation regulations clearly state that flight crews and passengers should not use electronic devices that could disrupt the planes' communications, whether the aircraft is taking off, in mid-flight, landing or taxiing on the runway.
Those who violate the regulations will be subject to up five years' imprisonment, mandatory community service or a fine of up to NT$150,000 (US$4,545), Chang said.
If the charges against Wu can be substantiated, she could become the first person to be punished in Taiwan for violating the ban against using electronic devices aboard aircraft.

Rigorous implementation of prohibitions against such devices, set to begin on May 1, is one of a series of measures aimed at increasing aviation safety announced by the Civil Aeronautics Administration in the wake of a spate of air disasters in recent months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA SEES PROTECTIONIST PRESSURES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Canadian government report said that trade dependency has given Taiwan "strong impetus to trade and market liberalization," though "domestic political pressures in this vibrant democracy" continue to result in protectionist and discriminatory market access conditions.

The report, released by Canadian International Trade Minister Sergio Marchi on Tuesday, noted that Taiwan is a "major exporter and a major source of investment for the region, particularly to China and Southeast Asia," and is becoming "an important regional importer."
The report, titled "Opening Doors to the World: Canada's International Market Access Priorities," does not seem pleased with Taiwan's market access for several Canadian products.

Though a tentative deal was reached late last year between Ottawa and Taipei over Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), outstanding details are "yet to be clarified by Chinese Taipei," it said.
Taiwan has yet to commit itself to open up its market to Canadian agricultural, industrial and services products before a formal conclusion of bilateral negotiations, according to the report.

The report expressed displeasure over Taipei extending preferential access to the United States for meat items "of export interest to Canadian suppliers" for the period preceding its WTO accession, noting that Taipei did this in early 1998, "subsequent to the tentative conclusion of our bilateral accession talks."

"This incremental discrimination facing Canadian products in the Chinese Taipei market must ... be resolved for Canada to officially conclude the bilateral market access negotiations with Chinese Taipei," it stressed.

The policy report said that a commitment to equitable access for all high-quality Canadian beef was not forthcoming from Taiwan. "Canada will continue to press Taiwan to end this discriminatory practice," it said.

Those thorny issues aside, "the past year saw outstanding financial services issues resolved satisfactorily in both the banking and insurance sectors," the report continued. It expressed pleasure over Taipei's offers for basic telecommunications services, as well as for advanced telecom and environmental services.
The report further pointed out that Canada's negotiations with Taiwan over joining the WTO Agreement on Government Procurement have "progressed well."

It said Taipei has concluded bilateral negotiations with most of the 26 trading partners over WTO accession, and the focus of the talks will likely shift to the multilateral stage, where the Working Party Report and Protocol of Accession are still to be negotiated.

Taiwan is Canada's fourth largest Asia-Pacific export market, accounting for some 6 percent of Canada's total exports to the region. In 1997, Canada exported C$1.57 billion (US$1.1 billion) worth of goods to Taiwan, making it Canada's ninth largest export destination overall. During the same year, Canada's commodity imports from Taiwan amounted to C$3.47 billion. The two-way trade hit the C$5 billion-mark for the first time last year.

The Canadian government expects Canadian exports to Taiwan will grow further in 1998 due to the continued growth in the economy. Taiwan is among Canada's stronger non-NAFTA destinations for value-added products and a growing market for agricultural and agri-food products, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRILATERAL BALKAN SUMMIT MEETS IN TURKEY

TEXT.P: Turkish President Suleyman Demirel will join his Bulgarian and Romanian counterparts for a two-day trilateral Balkan summit that begins Thursday in the Turkish Mediterranean province of Antalya, the Turkish Foreign Ministry announced in a statement.

The president will be accompanied by a high-level delegation including Foreign Minister Ismail Cem when he meets Bulgarian President Petar Stoyanov and Romanian President Emil Constantinescu for the trilateral summit. The first summit of the three leaders was held in Varna, eastern Bulgaria, last October.

According to the Foreign Ministry statement, the idea behind the trilateral summits is to develop a close cooperation that will help advance the peace and stability the Balkan region yearns for, and boost economic ties between the three countries.
The leaders are also expected to discuss security concerns such as the situation in Kosovo, organized crime, money laundering, terrorism, and drug and arms smuggling, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADER URGES BEIJING TO PROTECT TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: A business leader on Thursday urged mainland China to map out details for a comprehensive plan to protect Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland.

Chang Ping-chao, president of the Business Development Foundation of the Taiwan Strait, made the remarks in the wake of the murder of Taiwan entrepreneur Yeh Jung-fu, 44, in Quanzhou, Fujian Province, on Tuesday.

Chang said Taiwan has been asking mainland authorities to sign an agreement to provide guarantees for protecting Taiwan residents doing business there since the early 1990s. But he said the requests have been denied on the pretext that such agreements could only be signed among sovereign nations.

Mainland China's State Council, responding to strong demands from Taiwan businesses, has mapped out investment protection regulations for Taiwan people. But after criticism that the measures lacked substance, Beijing has drafted a set of revised regulations and invited Taiwan businessmen to express their views.

Chang said that at present only about a dozen provinces and cities in the mainland have worked out regulations to protect Taiwan businessmen, and that the security afforded therein applies only to those individual areas, rather than to the entire mainalnd.
He expressed hope that Beijing can devise a comprehensive set of regulations and set up a uniform window of communication with Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland.
Chang stressed that top priority should be given to the guarantee of personal safety for Taiwan residents living and working in various cities and provinces around the Chinese mainland.

He also advised Taiwan businessmen to exercise caution when in the mainland, saying that they should respect local workers, be careful in their words and actions, and avoid behaving like swaggering nouveau riche.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS FROM PROCESSING ZONES SURGE

TEXT.P: Despite an overall trend toward sluggishness in the global economy, Taiwan's processing zones run by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) continue to enjoy good performances in foreign trade.

The total value of imports and exports in three processing zones on the island reached more than US$1.98 billion in the first quarter of this year, up around 3.1 percent from the same period of last year, according to the Kaohsiung-based Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA).

Of that amount, exports claimed the lion's share at over US1.78 billion, up 3.2 percent from the previous year. The figure shows that the processing zones gained a strong competitive edge after making a transformation from low-end industrial manufacturing to high-tech operations.

Meanwhile, the successful switchover from labor-intensive industries to more automated production has also contributed to the resolution of severe labor shortages that had previously plagued the processing zones.

EPZA statistics show there are currently over 60,000 workers employed by the three export processing zones, located at Kaohsiung and Nanchi in southern Taiwan and at Taichung in the central part of the island. The three zones face a combined shortage of 1,400 workers, a figure far smaller than that seen before the transformation.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO UNIFY DOUBLE-TRACK TAX SYSTEMS WITHIN TWO YEARS

TEXT.P: In line with the principle that taxes should be levied equitably, mainland China is to unify its taxation of domestic and foreign investments by the year 2000, an official with the mainland State General Administration of Taxation under the mainland State Council disclosed.
This development indicates that the Beijing authorities will not be likely to continue to use the favored tax policy put in place more than 10 years ago to attract foreign investments.
Officials related to the matter remarked that conditions for Beijing to unify the taxation of domestic and foreign investments are now basically ripe.

In order to coordinate the implementation of the policy for unifying the income tax on domestic and foreign enterprises, experts in Beijing have suggested that matching reform measures should also be launched.

These measures, the officials said, should include enlarging certain market areas for the entrance of select foreign investment, unifying the financial and wage systems of domestic and foreign enterprises, setting charging systems and standards that are applicable to both domestic and foreign investments, building a social security system that will put domestic and foreign investments on the same footing, and giving domestic and foreign enterprises the same regulations concerning recruiting workers.

Since the Chinese mainland began opening itself to the rest of the world in 1979, there have been many measures adopted to attract foreign investments. The favored tax measure is the most attractive of these.

The differences in how domestic and foreign enterprises are treated under the double-track enterprise income tax system have come to be harmful, according the Hong Kong-based Wen Wei Bao on Wednesday.

After the double-track income tax is abolished, foreign investment enterprises will obtain "citizen treatment" step by step, and the competitive environment for domestic and foreign investments will be equalized gradually, said the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed low on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, declining 27.1 points to close at 8,780.21.
Dealers said the market, which registered its lowest turnover since Jan. 13, was dominated by a wait-and-see sentiment.
The bourse opened at 8,855.79 and experienced a high of 8,859.09 and a low of 8,773.09.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 241 to 182, with 70 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$90.49 billion (US$2.74 billion), a steep decrease from the previous trading session, which saw a total of 2.13 billion shares change hands on a market turnover of NT$108.01 billion.

Half of the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks moving down the most at 1.0 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.8 percent, construction shares at 0.6 percent and cement stocks at 0.5 percent.

Meanwhile, the pulp and paper category registered a solid gain, moving up 2.0 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 0.5 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.4 percent, while plastics and chemical shares remained unchanged.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers during Thursday's trading session were Ever Fortune Industry, Yieh Loong Co. Ltd., Taitung Business Bank, Microtek International Inc., Yieh-Hsing Enterprise, Chung Hwa Pulp Corp., Hung Fu Construction, Picvue Electronics, United Micro Electronics and Silicon Integrated Systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.06 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$32.988.
The greenback opened at 32.974 and was traded between 32.960 and 33.050.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$317 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SETS UP ANTI-COMPUTER CRIME CENTER

TEXT.P: The Public Prosecutors Office of the Taiwan High Court on Thursday set up an anti-computer crime center to fight cyber crimes on the island.

A consultant committee, comprising computer and judicial experts, was formed simultaneously to take charge of the establishment of policies aimed at preventing crimes that use computers or other electronic devices, according to the office.

The center, supervised by Public Prosecutors General Wu Yin-chao, will mobilize law enforcement personnel in crackdowns on crimes on the Internet, including the illegal sale of weapons, drugs and pornographic photos. The number of cases of these crimes has been mushrooming in Taiwan.

The center will also provide training courses for law enforcement personnel to sharpen their ability to fight cyber crimes. Moreover, prosecutors expert in computer crimes will be stationed in the center to take charge of investigating criminal cases in the sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG BUYERS SEEK COMPENSATION FROM TAIWAN PROPERTY DEVELOPER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 16 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Seven representatives of a group of Hong Kong property buyers delivered a petition on Thursday to the Chung Hwa Travel Service, Taiwan's representative office here, asking Taiwan authorities to help them seek compensation from a Taiwan property developer which closed up shop and disappeared after taking their money.

The petition was received by a Chung Hwa section chief, who said the Republic of China government is paying close attention to the incident and will contact the relevant authorities in order to gain a more complete understanding of the matter.

An official with a local workers union, surnamed Soong, who helped submit the petition to Chung Hwa, told CNA that the Leili Development Corp., a property developer based in Taiwan, is accused by the Hong Kong buyers of financial fraud.

According to Soong, a total of 108 Hong Kong people signed purchase contracts with a branch office of Leili here in 1995, agreeing to buy property built by the company in the central Taiwan city of Taichung.

They each paid an initial down-payment followed by monthly payments during the construction of the 32-story residential building. However, when Leili failed to complete the building by the end of 1997 as scheduled, its branch office in Hong Kong was found to already have shut down and its operation in Taiwan was also reported to have ceased.

The Hong Kong buyers then dispatched representatives to Taiwan in a bid to get to the bottom of the matter and to seek help from ROC lawmakers, but their efforts were fruitless, which led them to raise the case with the Taiwan authorities in Hong Kong, Soong said. He added that they will call a meeting on Friday to decide whether to again send representatives to Taiwan to seek compensation or take legal action.

Soong said the 108 Hong Kong buyers have paid Leili more than HK$10 million, but pointed out that the actual figure may be much higher, as some other local residents who also purchased the Leili property might have not contacted his union.

Soong called on the ROC government to help the Hong Kong people resolve the case and said Taiwan should take legal action to offer full protection for Hong Kong residents wishing to buy real estate on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC: BEIJING'S REACTION TO TAIWAN INITIATIVE 'TOO PASSIVE'
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 16 (CNA) (By F.M. Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Beijing's reaction to Taiwan's latest initiative to invite mainland China to cosponsor a meeting with officials from Southeast Asian countries on possible resolutions to the current regional financial turmoil was "too passive," Taiwan's top official in charge of mainland Chinese policies told a Japanese daily newspaper on Wednesday.

Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Republic of China's cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), in an exclusive interview with Asahi Shimbun, called for an early resumption of the cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue that Beijing suspended unilaterally in 1995.

On resuming the cross-strait dialogue on general affairs or technical issues, Chang said Taipei is expected to make the decision before the end of this week and will inform Beijing who Taipei will dispatch to the mainland for the new round of talks.

To begin the cross-strait dialogue by reopening talks on technical issues would be meaningful in two ways, Chang noted, explaining that it would represent the resumption of the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue and that it could pave the way for C.F. Koo, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), to visit mainland China.

Koo's mainland visit was agreed to during the first ice-breaking rendezvous between Koo and his Beijing counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in Singapore in April 1993, Chang added.

During the historic meeting, Taipei and Beijing laid a framework for regular dialogue and contacts between the SEF and ARATS, the two quasi-intermediary bodies authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official contacts between the two archrivals.

Which SEF officials Taipei chooses to send to Beijing for the new round of talks, probably later this month, is not a matter subject to Beijing's prior "understanding," said Chang, adding that the SEF's only obligation is to supply ARATS with the names of the SEF representatives.

Chang said that since Beijing suspended the cross-strait dialogue in the summer of 1995 following President Lee Teng-hui's landmark visit to the United States, which Beijing interpreted as a move promoting Taiwan independence, Lee, former Premier Lien Chan and incumbent Premier Vincent Siew have made a total of more than 110 offers for talks, holding out an olive branch to the Beijing authorities and calling for the resumption of the cross-strait dialogue.

The calls fell mostly on deaf ears until recently, when the Beijing authorities made gestures favorable to the easing of cross-strait tension, paving the way for the possible resumption of the cross-strait dialogue, he said.

Chang emphasized that it was Beijing that had turned down the dialogue initiatives, and that Taipei, for its part, had always been eager for the SEF to be able to arrange for Koo to visit the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE PITCHES CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION TO FORMER CIA DIRECTOR

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui told visiting former US Central Intelligence Agency Director James Woolsey on Thursday that the Republic of China's offer to Beijing to cosponsor a meeting among Southeast Asian states on the regional economic crisis is not political and has no hidden agenda.
He said he regrets that Beijing has stonewalled the proposal out of suspicion of Taipei's motives.

Lee challenged Beijing on April 7 to set aside the cross-Taiwan Strait feud and join forces with Taipei in helping neighboring states survive their financial woes. The goodwill gesture, however, has met with silence from Beijing.

Lee called on Washington to treasure its ties with Taiwan while engaging Beijing, citing Taiwan's strategic importance as well as its aggressive pursuit of democracy, freedom and justice, which he noted are values also espoused by the United States.
Lee also emphasized at the meeting the importance of resuming the cross-strait dialogue in order to iron out differences and avoid misunderstandings.
He reiterated that since the Republic of China has long been a sovereign nation, it is absolutely unnecessary to declare Taiwan's independence.
Woolsey, who led the CIA from 1993 to 1995 during the first administration of US President Bill Clinton, arrived in Taiwan on Monday for a private visit.

Also at Thursday's reception were four members of Woolsey's entourage, Vice Adm. William Wright and Drs. Kent M. Harrington, Gordon C. Oehler and Michael Pillsbury, all of whom are intelligence experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW WARNS AGAINST MINING IN NATIONAL PARKS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Thursday that mining inside national parks is counter to government policy and the needs of the nation, and that it should not be permitted.

Siew made the remarks at a cabinet meeting in which a couple of bills were discussed. He stressed the importance of safeguarding all national parks and demanded that all related government agencies pay attention to this need and adhere to policies governing conservation.

On Sunday, a coalition of environmental groups lashed out at the government for allowing marble mining in Taroko National Park in eastern Taiwan, saying this has destroyed the beauty of the world-class scenic area.

Commenting on the protests launched by the conservationists and ecologists, Siew said that with the coming of the 21st century, the conservation of the environment has become one of the topics of the most concern for not only the Republic of China but also the whole world.

The premier cited Yangmingshan National Park as an example of the government's policies and foresight. According to Siew, if there had been no planning of national parks in the past, people would not be able to enjoy such wonderful and natural spots as Yangmingshan, located to the north of Taipei.
In addition to Taroko and Yangmingshan, Taiwan also has Kenting, Yushan and Shei-Pa national parks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIBETAN GOVERNMENT-IN-EXILE CONSIDERS PROPOSING HK MODEL TO CHINA

TEXT.P: After decades of attempts to gain autonomy from mainland China, the Tibetan government-in-exile in Dharamsala, northern India, is considering proposing a "Hong Kong model" to Beijing that would give Tibet similar status to that of the former British colony.

In an exclusive interview with the CNA on Thursday, Professor Samdhong Rinpoche, chairman of the 46-member Tibetan parliament, said the idea of the Hong Kong model will be raised by the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, and discussed by his parliament.
"I believe the Hong Kong model will be workable for the autonomy of Tibet because it is a democratic system based on the (Hong Kong) Basic Law," he said.

Mainland China has for many years rejected the Dalai Lama's proposals for self-rule in Tibet because Beijing lacks self-confidence, he said, adding that mainland China has ceased dialogue with the Dalai Lama since 1993.

He said the Tibetan government-in-exile hopes Beijing will resume the dialogue so that the Dalai Lama can negotiate the autonomy issue. "We would use the Hong Kong model if we are given the chance of dialogue with China," he said.

He said that since the takeover of the Chinese communists in the mainland in 1949, the Beijing regime has sent Han Chinese to settle in Tibet and has controlled the indigenous population through various types of torture.
"This method of control is so harsh and inhuman and Tibetan people cannot accept that," he said.
In 1959, there was a major uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet, the failure of which forced the Dalai Lama to flee from Tibet to India, where he set up his government-in-exile.
Samdhong Rinpoche said Tibet is not seeking independence from mainland China. Instead, the Tibetan government-in-exile is seeking genuine autonomy.
"Tibet will still benefit from Chinese protection," he said, "because we don't have the material infrastructure and China could provide that."
However, he also said that if Tibet is given self-rule or autonomy, Han people sent to Tibet after 1959 would not be allowed to interfere with Tibetan affairs.
Samdhong Rinpoche is currently on a month-long visit to Australia.
He appeared before the Australian Parliamentary Human Rights Sub-committee in Canberra on Thursday. The sub-committee inquires into the regional dialogue on human rights.
Before coming to the Australian national capital, he visited Sydney and from Canberra he will go to Melbourne for a short visit before going to his final destination -- Tasmania.
In Tasmania, he will give a three-week lecture at the University of Tasmania before winding up his visit on May 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRAIT CRISIS COST US$23 BILLION: REPORT

TEXT.P: The military exercises and missile tests mainland China held from late 1995 to 1996 to rattle Taiwan cost the island a staggering US$23 billion, The Straits Times on Thursday quoted a Taipei economic think-tank as reporting.

The Taiwan bourse and the financial market were the first to react to the crisis that erupted in the Taiwan Strait, noted the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER) in its "Impact of China's Literary Attacks and Military Intimidation in 1995 and 1996 on Taiwan's Economy."

"Within half a month of the start of the cross-strait crisis, the stock index fell 1,000 points, the Taiwan dollar saw a drop of NT$1.50 against the US dollar and the public was fearful and anxious," the Chinese-language report was quoted as saying.

Between July 21 and 26, mainland China fired a number of surface-to-surface missiles into international waters off the Taiwan coast. According to Dr. Chou Ji, director of the CHIER's Economic Outlook Center who coordinated the report, the effects were almost immediate.

He told The Straits Times: "The psychological effect of the crisis on the public and its impact on the financial market were felt very quickly. This was particularly so as the crisis hit when the region was at peace."
In response to the shock, Taipei initiated a series of moves to shore up its stock market and stabilize its currency at around NT$27.50 against the dollar, the report said.
"It was a costly but necessary endeavor," said Dr. Kuan Chung-ming from National Taiwan University's Economics Department, one of eight researchers involved in the report.
"The factors that caused the violent fluctuations in the markets were not normal market forces at work and the government was right to intervene," he said.
The research team argued that the Taiwan bourse and money market had already shown signs of fatigue, and that Beijing's intimidation merely precipitated the dip into a cyclical trough.
The report also pointed out that Taiwan was able to adjust and adapt to the crisis very quickly.

With the help of the government's defense measures, the situation was effectively controlled and by the time Taipei held its first presidential election in March 1996, the financial markets were relatively calm, although trading in the stock market was thin, the report said.
"What ultimately helped the quick recovery was the realization -- both at home and abroad -- that China's war games were not aimed at destroying Taiwan or its economy," Dr. Kuan was quoted as saying.
"Beijing's purpose was political and its message was that so long as Taiwan does not declare independence, China will not take drastic measures," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES PLANE FOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has donated a Cessna U206 anti-poaching aircraft to help stop poachers preying on endangered African wildlife.

At a ceremony held Wednesday at the Santa Monica Municipal Airport, Los Angeles County, California, Stephen Chen, ROC representative to the United States, presented the gift to the Wilderness Conservancy, a US-based nonprofit organization dedicated to ending poaching in Africa.

Back in 1996, the ROC government began a new phase of dedication to the cause of stamping out poaching when it donated an American Champion Super Scout spotter plane to be used in South Africa's Kruger National Park and it's neighboring countries. Wednesday's second, larger donation represents the ROC government's increased dedication to the cause.

According to the Wilderness Conservancy, poaching has reached such severe levels that certain wildlife populations have been utterly decimated in several African countries. Poaching remains commonplace because of traditional Asian medicine's demand for rare animal parts.
The ROC was once among the most-criticized countries in the world for not doing enough to stop the traffic of these materials into Taiwan, but the government now imposes stiff penalties on offenders.

DOC.HEADLINE: CURTAIN LOWERED ON MINISTER'S RESIGNATION DRAMA

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao said on Thursday that he will return to work next Monday, ending a three-day period of media speculation over his resignation.
Liao, who tendered a tearful resignation on Tuesday, told a news conference that after three days of soul-searching and talks with his superiors, he has decided to stay on in his post.

"During the past few days, I found that the public has high expectations for a crime-free society. Taiwan is still far from being an island governed by the rule of law. I think I must stay on to continue the fight against organized crime," Liao said.

The minister also expressed his heartfelt gratitude for concern extended to him by his superiors and various quarters of society over the past few days. "I will redouble my efforts to repay their kindness," he vowed.

Accompanied by his wife, Liao paid a visit to Vice President Lien Chan early Thursday morning. During their 30-minute meeting at Lien's home, the vice president was quoted as having encouraged Liao to continue his anti-crime crusade.
"During the talks, the vice president asked me to come back to work, as our country's law and order still needs strengthening," Liao said.

Liao, one of the country's most popular Cabinet ministers, assumed his current post some two years ago during Lien's tenure as premier. He has gained much acclaim and popular support for his intense anti-crime, anti-corruption campaign.

After trying to resign on Tuesday, the respected crime fighter was quoted by the press as blaming his decision on lawmakers with links to the underworld who put pressure on the government to remove him, but he gave no details and provided no other reason for his action other than that he wished to devote himself to activities outwith the political arena.

Upon receiving Liao's resignation letter, Premier Vincent Siew had a long talk with Liao, asking him to remain in the Cabinet to fight crime and work for the people's well-being before returning his resignation letter and giving him a three-and-a-half-day leave to mull his decision.

Liao's move caused grave concern in the government, the Legislative Yuan and among the public. President Lee Teng-hui met with him on Tuesday evening, when, in addition to inquiring about his reasons for wanting to resign, Lee also clearly asked Liao to change his mind on the grounds that the government needs his devoted service.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE WHEAT EXPORTS TO TAIWAN SEEN RISING STEADILY

TEXT.P: Australia expects a steady increase in its wheat exports to Taiwan in fiscal 1997-98, the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) said Thursday.
In an interview with CNA, an AWB spokesman said Australia exported about 63,000 tonnes of high-protein wheat to Taiwan in fiscal 1996-97, up from 35,000 tonnes in 1995-96.
"We believe there is still room for a steady increase in our wheat exports to Taiwan," he said.
But he said Australian wheat exports to mainland China will fall further after a massive decline in 1996-97, when Australia only exported 150,000 tonnes compared to 2.2 million tonnes in 1995-96.

"We are afraid that we have to sell less wheat to China again this year because there will be a bumper crop again in the mainland," he said. Mainland China used to be one of Australia's biggest wheat markets.
Taiwan imports about 1 million tonnes of wheat from the United States, Canada and other countries, he said.

The spokesman said wheat production in 1997-98 is estimated at about 19 million tonnes, 14.5 million tonnes of which will be exported to more than 50 countries -- with Iran, Egypt and Indonesia among Australia's major markets.

This compares with a record harvest of 23.6 million tonnes and a record export of 19 million tonnes in 1996-97. In 1995-96, Australia produced 16.7 million tonnes of wheat and exported 13.2 million tonnes of the output, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLA FACES STREAMLINING OF REGIONS

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Central Military Commission is considering streamlining the People's Liberation Army (PLA) in line with plans to reduce government and Communist Party bureaucracy, according to the South China Morning Post.
Military sources said one or two of the seven military regions could be abolished.

The sources said the Beijing Military Region -- which covers, in addition to Beijing and Tianjin, the provinces of Hebei and Shanxi and the Inner Mongolia autonomous region -- is one of those likely to be dismantled.

However, the sources added that the Beijing Garrison, a unit under the Beijing region with exclusive responsibility for guarding the capital, would be strengthened. Other units in the Beijing region would be absorbed by neighboring military regions.

It is understood that apart from the need to simplify the PLA's structure, mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, chairman of the military commission, believes the loyalty of the Beijing Garrison would be better assured if it was separated from the region.
The garrison includes elite units responsible for the safety of top party and government leaders as well as of major offices in the Zhongnanhai party headquarters.
A Beijing military source said, however, it is unlikely that military regions would be renamed "war zones" as had been reported earlier.

In addition, new units could be set up to realize the goal of "winning regional warfare under high-tech conditions." A unit handling advanced equipment such as space and laser weaponry could also be established.
Diplomatic analysts said the details of the restructuring will be finalized in two to three months.
They said the plan will not affect senior officers or PLA personnel handling sophisticated facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO URGE ADB TO HELP SE ASIAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said on Thursday that the Republic of China will try to persuade the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide guarantees to help Southeast Asian countries reach early stability in the wake of the recent financial turmoil which has swept the region since the middle of last year.

Speaking at a seminar at the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, Chiang pointed out that a lobbying mission will leave next week for Manila to visit ADB headquarters, where it will urge the ADB to provide guarantees to assist Southeast Asian nations in issuing government bonds.
He suggested that the institute invite its counterparts on the opposite side of the Taiwan Strait to discuss cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in assisting the affected countries of Southeast Asia.

Meanwhile, CEPD Vice Chairman Schive Chi suggested that the government should use its foreign exchange reserves wisely to help solve the issues of local enterprises in their overseas financing, as well as provide export insurance to facilitate imports from Southeast Asian countries.

Speaking at the ROC-USA Economic Council, the CEPD deputy chief said the ROC government can strengthen international financial cooperation by signing cooperation agreements with the central banks of the relevant countries; at the same time, the ROC government should study the feasibility of joining APEC nations to provide guarantees for government bonds issued by Southeast Asian countries.
Turning to the private sector, he suggested that private enterprises seeking investment and cooperation opportunities in Southeast Asia should consider the risk factors involved very carefully.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF ASKS FOR ARATS HELP TO PROBE MURDER OF TAIWAN BUSINESSMAN

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) sent a message on Thursday to its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- asking for its help in resolving a murder case involving a Taiwan businessman.

Speaking at a news conference after learning of the incident, SEF Deputy Secretary-General Chang Liang-jen urged the ARATS to help arrest the killers and provide the victim's family with necessary assistance to help them through the aftermath of the tragedy.

The body of Yeh Jung-fu, 44, a knitted garment maker from the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung, was discovered by his wife at their house in Quanzhou, Fujian Province, on Tuesday night. She was abducted by her husband's killers, who broke into the house, but she later escaped and reported the case to local police.

Quanzhou public security authorities said they have already nabbed one suspect and are searching for the other two accomplices, who remain at large. The three alleged assailants were reported to be employees at Yeh's factory.

Citing SEF statistics, Chang said that more than 160 similar incidents involving the personal and property safety of Taiwan businessmen in mainland China have been reported over the past seven years since the founding of the SEF. He stressed that Taiwan and the mainland should place the issue of Taiwan businesspeople's interests and personal safety high on the agenda if the two sides resume talks.
The SEF and the ARATS are semiofficial organizations representing Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.
Meanwhile, Chang said a group of Taiwan tourists who were reported by a local newspaper to have been detained by mainland authorities are scheduled to return to Taiwan on Monday.
Slamming the report as "untrue," Chang said the 22 Taiwan tourists are currently in Shanghai.

A local newspaper reported on Thursday that a group of Taiwan tourists had been detained in mainland China after the owner of a Taipei-based travel agency closed up shop and escaped with their clients' payments.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF VICE MINISTER LEAVES FOR US TO ATTEND APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Yen Ching-chang, vice minister of the Ministry of Finance (MOF), left Taipei for Washington, D.C. on Thursday night to attend an Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum vice finance ministers' meeting.

Yen said prior to his departure that the meeting, to be held on April 18-19, will discuss such topics as the Asian financial turmoil, as well as financial management. He added that the meeting will serve as a preparatory meeting for the APEC financial ministers' meeting to be held at the end of May.

Meanwhile, the Foreign Exchange Department of The Central Bank of China (CBC) revealed on Thursday that CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan will lead a mission to Geneva, Switzerland, to attend the annual council meeting of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to be held from April 29 to May 1, in order to strengthen exchange and cooperation with ADB member countries.
Perng will be accompanied by Jeffrey L.S. Koo, chairman of the Chinatrust Commercial Bank, among others.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICE OF DALAI LAMA OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Tibet Religious Foundation of the Dalai Lama, a representative office of Tibet's exiled spiritual leader, on Thursday formally opened its new offices on Keelung Road in southern Taipei City.
President Lee Teng-hui, who met with the Dalai Lama during his first visit to Taiwan in March last year, was on hand to extend his congratulations.
The president was presented three times with a traditional Buddhist "hata" as a token of the highest respect by foundation chairperson Kesang Takla.
Sonan Dob Gyal, senior minister of Tibet's government-in-exile, attended the ceremony on behalf of the Dalai Lama and the people of Tibet.

Sonan stressed at the ceremony that the Dalai Lama hopes to solve the Tibetan problem through non-violence and reciprocity, as taught by Buddha. He added that Tibet's god-king also hopes that Taiwan's government and people, like the international community, will provide support in realizing the wishes of the people of Tibet.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUTUAL AGREEMENT BEING STUDIED BY TOKYO AND BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Asahi Shimbun newspaper reported on Thursday that Tokyo and Beijing are studying ways to prepare a statement of mutual agreement on the occasion of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's planned tour of Japan this September.

The paper quoted an official from Japan's Foreign Ministry as saying that Beijing has expressed a positive attitude toward the preparation of such a statement in the form of a joint communique or joint press announcement.

Mainland China has issued joint statements recently on the occasion of summit meetings with leaders of other countries, including the United States and Russia, aiming to demonstrate its achievements in top-level diplomacy, and it hopes to have the same effect with Jiang's tour of Japan, the paper noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIR TO OPEN DIRECT FLIGHTS BETWEEN KAOHSIUNG AND HO CHI MINH CITY

TEXT.P: EVA Airways Corp. (EVA AIR) announced on Thursday that it will begin operating three weekly direct fights between southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City and Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City, starting on June 11.

The Kaohsiung-Ho Chih Minh City route will become EVA AIR's seventh international route departing from Kaohsiung since the carrier's announcement late last year that it intends to develop Hsiaokang International Airport into a southern Taiwan transportation hub.
EVA AIR, Taiwan's second-largest aviation company, said it will use MD-90 planes to provide cargo and passenger services on the route.

The company already operates direct flights between Kaohsiung and Jakarta, Singapore-Penang, Macau, Surabaya, and Kuala Lumpur. With the entry of another two planned new routes -- Los Angeles and Ho Chi Minh City -- in the coming months, the carrier will have an even more comprehensive air traffic network spreading out from the southern port city.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CELLULAR PHONE VIOLATION ON AIRCRAFT REPORTED

TEXT.P: A woman was accused on Thursday of violating a ban on the use of cellular phones aboard aircraft, the first such charges to be brought in Taiwan's aviation history.

Aviation police said that they have transferred the case to the Taipei Prosecutor's Office, which will investigate the first violation of the ban on using electronic devices aboard aircraft and might charge the violator, identified as Wu Yu-chuan.

The aviation regulations state that flight crews and passengers are prohibited from using electronic devices that could disrupt aircraft communication systems while on board, with violators facing up to five-year jail terms, or mandatory community service, or fines of up to NT$150,000 (US$4,545).
Wu was reported by another passenger on the UNI Airlines flight from eastern Hualien to Taipei on April 5 to aviation security officials for using her cellular phone on the flight.

Although Wu admitted using the phone, she claimed she waited until the plane had landed safely and was taxiing to a halt before operating the device. However, her informer insisted that the phone call was made while the plane was still airborne.

Rigorous implementation of the prohibition on such devices is one of a series of measures taken by aviation authorities to improve flight safety in Taiwan in the wake of a spate of air disasters in recent months which have claimed the lives of more than two hundred people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY-ROC ECONOMIC MEETING TO TAKE PLACE IN TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, April 16 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: The 10th Paraguay-ROC economic cooperation meeting will be held in Taipei at the end of the month.

Paraguayan Minister of Trade and Industry Atilio Fernandez, at the head of a 13-member delegation comprised of high-ranking government officials and business executives, will arrive in Taipei on April 22. They are scheduled to depart on April 29.

The two-day meeting will be jointly presided over by Fernandez and ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang. Discussions will center on strengthening bilateral cooperation in investment and trade, and between small- and medium-sized businesses of the two countries.
While the delegation is in Taiwan, they will also visit the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and the China External Trade Development Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING IRISH MP COMMENTS ON HISTORIC PEACE DEAL

TEXT.P: Visiting Deputy Speaker of the Irish Parliament Rory O'Hanlon said on Thursday that the Irish Republic's foreign policies will not be influenced by the recent Northern Ireland peace pact.

O'Hanlon said that the peace deal, which will see Northern Ireland remain part of Britain but will give Dublin a say in its affairs for the first time, will have a deep impact on Northern Ireland, relations between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, and ties between Britain and the Irish Republic.

O'Hanlon, who is also chairman of the ruling Republican caucus, stressed that the peace pact, which will be put to referenda in Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic in May, will benefit all parties if it is put into effect, adding that US President Bill Clinton also made a valuable contribution to the working out of the agreement.

Asked if the deal will influence the Irish Republic's foreign policy and whether it will lead to any breakthroughs between the Irish Republic and Taiwan, he replied that his country's foreign policy will not be influenced by the historic agreement.

O'Hanlon refused to comment on the possibility that Taiwan and mainland China might be able to sign a similar peace agreement to end the cross-Taiwan Strait dispute, saying that he is not in a position to answer questions related to political issues in Asia.

However, he did say that there is ample room for the Irish Republic and Taiwan to improve bilateral cooperation in trade, investment and education, adding that during his visit here, he has gained the impression that many Taiwan businessmen are interested in exploring the investment opportunities in his country.
O'Hanlon claimed that the Irish Republic, with its young, high-quality workforce, is a good location for high-tech industries to set up production bases.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND NEWS MEDIA GROUP ARRIVING

TEXT.P: A news media delegation from mainland China arrived here via Hong Kong on Friday for a 10-day visit.

The 16-member delegation, comprised of executives of major news organizations as well as three officials in charge of publicity, is the largest as well as the highest-level media group from the mainland to visit Taiwan in recent years.

Xie Hong, leader of the delegation and deputy editor in chief of the People's Daily, said upon arrival at the CKS International Airport that he hopes the visit will promote news exchanges and cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Xie also said that the opening of offices in each other's territory by media organizations in Taiwan and the mainland will be inevitable. But he added that the pace of such exchanges will depend on the degree of effort put forth by both sides.
Mainland media have a keen interest in the recent proliferation of media outlets in Taiwan and in the fierce competition here, Xie indicated.
He said the visiting delegation wants to learn more about the media development here and is planning to visit major newspapers, magazines, and TV and radio stations during its stay in Taiwan.

The delegation will also take part in a series of seminars on news exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, and on Monday will call on the offices of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a semiofficial body set up by Taipei to handle civilian exchanges with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BE INVITED TO JOIN ADB-INITIATED EAST ASIA FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 17 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be invited to join an East Asia financial forum to be formed under the auspices of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), according to a news briefing issued by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) on Thursday.
The press release said the Manila-based regional bank plans to propose the formation of an East Asia financial forum at its annual board meeting to be held in Geneva late this month.

The members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) will form the backbone of the proposed forum, but such non-ASEAN economies as Taiwan, mainland China, South Korea and Japan will also be invited to join the group, the IMF news briefing said.

It quoted a report carried in Singapore's Business Times as saying the forum, if established, will strengthen financial policy coordination among major economies in the region as well as supervise the region's economic development with an aim to ensure regional financial stability and economic well-being.

The Singaporean daily said ADB Governor Mitsuo Sato is expected to make the overture at a luncheon he will host in Geneva on April 28 in honor of finance ministers and central bank governors of the ASEAN countries and South Korea, all of which will be founding members of the new organization.

Taiwan, mainland China and Japan will be admitted into the forum shortly after its inauguration, the paper said, adding that the four non-ASEAN economies will be included mainly because drastic fluctuations of the currency of any of these countries will inevitably trigger chain reactions throughout the region.
ASEAN groups Brunei, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.
As the proposed new regional financial forum will neither include the United States nor any other Western country in the Pacific region, the report has caused IMF concern.
IMF governors reportedly worry that the proposal is designed to curb the IMF's involvement in addressing the Asian financial crisis which has plagued many countries in the region since last summer.
The IMF has reiterated on many occasions that it must play a central role in helping battered Asian economies tide over their current financial woes.

At an IMF provisional committee meeting on Thursday, US Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin called on support for the strengthening of IMF functions in resolving international or regional financial crises.

The IMF, an affiliate of the United Nations, is currently convening its spring board meeting in Washington, D.C. Taiwan lost its IMF seat in 1980 when mainland China was admitted into the organization.
