DOC.HEADLINE: CPC UNVEILS CREATIVE PRIVATIZATION PLAN

TEXT.P: The state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), in a daring and unprecedented move, has decided to give up most of its non-refining operations in a bid to reshape the veteran, but competition-threatening firm.

The CPC's brash chairman, Chen Chao-wei, who demonstrated his business genius and outspoken management style as head of the Taipei Rapid Transit Co., announced on Friday that the CPC will transfer all non-refining businesses, including security and public safety, transportation, and gas station operations islandwide. Those activities have a combined business potential worth at least NT$10 billion (US$305 million) annually.

Chen described the plan as a creative initiative that benefits all. Shares in the affected CPC operations will be all offered to private investors through open bids and to current CPC employees who will be forced to retire under the company's privatization plan.
The plan, Chen stressed, will not only help upgrade operational efficiency, but will also boost the willingness to take early retirement among senior CPC employees.

Chen attributed stiff resistance to the company's privatization on the part of the CPC staff to a failure to see a silver lining in the shakeup and to the previous CPC management's inability to come up with viable plans to revitalize the company.

Despite the fact that CPC's annual personnel costs were a titanic NT$24 billion (US$732 million), equivalent to 7.3 percent of the company's annual business transactions and almost double of that of major international oil companies, Chen described the CPC as a "dust-covered golden bowl."
Chen said the corporation is indeed capable of providing a positive working atmosphere for its staff as well helping retiring personnel to experience a "second spring" with new job opportunities.

Citing a long list of CPC business operations, Chen noted that the company maintains 22 oil reservoirs and storage tanks islandwide, which cost NT$1.7 billion (US$52 million) annually for safety maintenance alone.

Ocean-going oil tankers and liquefied natural gas (LNG) transport vessels owned or leased by the CPC cost some NT$9 billion (US$274 million) each year to carry supplies to Taiwan. Domestically, the CPC operates some 300 tank trucks which distribute the products islandwide, generating transactions worth several billion New Taiwan dollars a year.

Meanwhile, under its new business plan, CPC envisages a series of bold and potentially lucrative initiatives for gas station operations. The plan includes an islandwide franchise system for gas stations which are currently losing money.

Former CPC employees will have the option to invest in the franchises on a leasing basis. The franchise stations, if located in rural areas, will be allowed to engage in side businesses, such as car washes or convenience stores, to supplement income.

The independently operated gas stations, if located on idle CPC properties, can also be developed into CPC business centers, with ground-level gas station services, upstairs offices and overhead parking areas. Similar operations in Japan have proven highly lucrative.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO UNVEIL WHITE PAPERS ON HOG, CHICKEN RAISING

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will soon unveil its white papers on hog and chicken raising in anticipation of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

In discussing the reports Friday, COA officials noted that Taiwan's poultry industry is expected to face pressure from US imports. Accordingly, the council has assessed the impacts of the foreign products on Taiwan's poultry industry both before and after it joins the WTO.

To facilitate the island's bid to enter the WTO, Taiwan has agreed to accept 5,000 tons of US-produced pork bellies, 10,000 tons of chicken, 5,000 tons of beef offal and 7,500 tons of pork offal, for import starting June 1.
Chen Pao-chi, director of the COA Animal Industry Department, warned that the poultry industry will soon begin to feel the pinch of US imports.

But Chen said the council will seek to ensure a viable domestic poultry industry. He added that persuading owners of small-scale and noncompetitive chicken and hog farms to shut down will be one of the measures adopted to achieve that goal.
Chen said that the COA will invite scholars, experts and representatives of the poultry industry to continue consultations on how to establish a competitive poultry industry in Taiwan.

In view of the expected onslaught of US chicken meat, especially imported drum sticks, which are favored by local consumers and can be produced at NT$45 per kilogram cheaper than the domestic variety, COA officials said chicken producers in Taiwan will definitely feel the impact.

The COA will attempt to keep the overall prices for unprocessed chicken meats at between NT$25 and NT$27 per kilogram, so that consumers can enjoy cheap products and chicken farm operators can earn reasonable profits.

Commenting on the hog raising industry, COA officials said Taiwan has also made a concession to the United States by agreeing to allow imports of 5,000 metric tons of US pork bellies and 7,500 metric tons of pork offal prior to its WTO entry.
The officials said, however, that local hog industry should be able to withstand the losses resulting from the imports, expected to be around NT$700 million (US$21.21 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECON. GROWTH FOR 1998 ADJUSTED DOWNWARD TO 5.95 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Affected by the regional financial meltdown in Southeast Asia and by economic stagnation in Japan, Taiwan's projected economic growth for 1998 will be readjusted downward to 5.95 percent, the Chung-hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) said on Friday.

The private economics think tank predicted in December that Taiwan's 1998 annual economic growth would top at least 6.37 percent, perhaps reaching as high as 7.1 percent. That estimate was made on the premises that the Asian financial turmoil would cease to ravage the region and that no major natural disasters would occur in Taiwan the following year.

CIER economists, describing Taiwan's economy as a "small-scale, open system," said it has failed to stay completely unscathed by the Asian financial upheavals in the first quarter of this year even though the domestic economic performance was basically healthy.

Sluggish foreign trade during the first quarter dragged Taiwan's economic growth down in the period. But, on the strength of brisk domestic consumption and private sector investment, the island's economy could still maintain a growth of 5 percent or above in the first quarter of this year, the economists forecast. Final figures for the period have yet to be released by the government.

Domestic investment in 1998 is seen to carry the momentum experienced last year by posting a rise of around 11.21 percent. With the beginning or expansion of several key projects, involving the sixth naphtha cracking plant, islandwide transportation networks, an industrial park in southern Taiwan, telecommunications market opening, reconstruction of housing for military dependents, and privately operated power plants, Taiwan's domestic investment is expected to chart an impressive growth of 18.14 percent this year, they forecast.
Meanwhile, the think tank said the island's inflation growth will probably be well controlled at around 2.72 percent this year, as compared with previous estimates of 3.34 percent.
Stable prices due to ample supplies of raw materials on international markets and lower prices for crude oil have combined to keep inflation at a mere 1.55 percent through the first quarter.
Although the growth of inflation will be limited this year, the expected 2.72 rise is higher than the negligible 0.9 percent level seen in 1997, the CIER experts pointed out.
The New Taiwan dollar, meanwhile, is forecast to mildly fluctuate at around NT$32.5 against one US dollar for the rest of the year, they added.
The CIER also predicts that Taiwan's economy will expand by 6.39 percent in 1999 under the preconditions that the Asian financial storm passes and that most of the economies in the region recover.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAN JYH-HORNG TO BECOME DEPUTY SECRETARY-GENERAL OF SEF

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday morning approved the nomination of Jan Jyh-horng, currently the director of the Research and Planning Department of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), to the post of deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

The SEF is expected to fax a letter to its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Friday afternoon to inform the Beijing-based body that the SEF would like to send Jan to Beijing to help in the resolution of protocol matters prior to the visit of a Taiwan delegation.

Jan is the first MAC official nominated to join the high-ranking working staff of the semi-official SEF since the SEF's founding seven years ago. His appointment indicates that the MAC and SEF will interact closely, something that should be helpful to the teamwork of the Taiwan negotiators as a whole, said Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman and spokesman of the MAC, on Friday.

ARATS sent the SEF a letter dated April 13 that suggested one of the foundation's vice secretary-generals travel to Beijing on April 21 or 22 -- or any other time that would be convenient for both sides -- to discuss a future visit by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu or to exchange views concerning the SEF and ARATS cosponsoring a seminar.

Sheu declined comment on when Jan will leave for Beijing to pave the way for the "ice-breaking journey." However, he stressed that since the MAC has authorized the SEF to respond to Beijing's offer, the foundation will surely indicate the appropriate time for Jan's visit in its letter to ARATS.
Jan's visit will focus mainly on protocol affairs involving Koo's future trip and it is unlikely that substantial issues will be discussed, Sheu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP SHARPLY ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 160.72 points to close at 8,619.49.

Dealers said the market declined along with stock markets in the United States, Japan and Hong Kong, with electronics issues plunging the most and causing the index to drop below the lowest point of the previous fluctuation wave.
The bourse opened at 8,724.65 and experienced a high of 8,796.65 and a low of 8,589.31.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 241 to 182, with 70 stocks remaining unchanged.

A total of 21.68 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$114.09 billion (US$3.46 billion), an increase from the previous session, which saw a total of 1.77 billion shares change hands on a market turnover of NT$90.49 billion.

Seven of the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical issues plunging the most at 3.4 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 2.0 percent, construction stocks at 1.6 percent, both cement issues and textile shares at 1.5 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.3 percent and pulp and paper issues at 1.2 percent.
Meanwhile, the bank and insurance category remained unchanged.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers during Friday's trading session were Ever Fortune Industries, Taitung Business Bank, Taichung Business Bank, United Micro Electronics, Winbond Electronics Corp., China Manmade Fibers, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Silicon Integrated Systems Corp., Picvue Electronics and Macronlix International.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA TO LIFT SOME IMPORT RESTRICTIONS

TEXT.P: India is to lift import restrictions on 340 items in an apparent effort by the Hindu nationalist-led government to signal its intention to continue trade liberalization, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Thursday.

India was simplifying and decentralizing bureaucratic procedures for exporters, and making it easier for companies in key export sectors to import capital goods with duty concessions, the WTO report said.

While major Indian exporters organizations hailed it as "export friendly," Bibek Debroy, a New Delhi-based international trade expert, was quoted as saying that India's trading partners were unlikely to be impressed with what he called a half-hearted attempt at trade liberalization.

While the new government -- led by the Bharatiya Janata Party -- has lifted restrictions on some paper products, textiles and chemicals, Debroy said many of the newly liberalized items, such as fish, wooden dolls and hairbands, were "easy items" which were neither particularly important nor controversial, the WTO report said.
It would be tough to convince the WTO that India was serious about phasing out import restrictions, Debroy was quoted as saying.

In an agreement with trade partners such as Australia, Japan, the European Union and Canada, India has five years to phase out all its remaining import restrictions while a dispute with the United States on the same matter still remains.
The trade liberalization policy shows the new government is "going to reform but the reforms are going to be very, very slow," the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLUEBERRY HOLDS KEY TO HEALTHY LIVING

TEXT.P: If you want to live a long and healthy life, eat more blueberries as Canadian bears do, researchers said Wednesday.

They told the annual meeting of the Wild Blueberry Association of North America in Halifax that the humble wild blueberry has antioxidant qualities that may hold the key to cancer prevention, protection from cardiovascular disease, and retarding the effects of aging.
The conference heard reports that natural pigments called anthocyanins, along with other phytochemical compounds, have been found to be responsible for the tiny blueberry's healthy punch.

US Department of Agriculture scientist Ronald Prior found that blueberry contains the highest antioxidant capacity among 40 fruits and vegetables tested, though it still lags behind its European cousin, the billberry.

Willy Kalt, a horticulturist who works for Agriculture and Agri-food Canada in Nova Scotia, said the blueberry is a superstar in terms of oxidative capacity. "If you want to choose fruits for their antioxidant capacity, blueberries are head and shoulders above a lot of the other commercial fruit you might look at," he said.

University of Illinois researcher Mary Ann Smith has conducted a study which shows that components in blueberries inhibit an enzyme that contributes to the onset of cancer. Cranberries and lingonberries were found to be of similar benefit.
Most of the world's blueberry industry is confined to the US state of Maine and Canada's Atlantic seaboard. Ontario and Quebec also produce some blueberries.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL CHIP COUNTERFEITING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: Police busted a computer chip counterfeiting ring in northern Taiwan on Friday, confiscating NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) worth of bogus Intel chips and arresting four masterminds involved in the case.

Intel Corp. of the United States filed a complaint with Taiwan's National Police Administration (NPA) earlier this year, saying customs authorities in many countries, including Germany, have discovered container-loads of bogus Intel chips. The world's largest maker of computer central processing units (CPUs) said it suspects all those ersatz products were originated in Taiwan.

Responding to the complaint, the NPA's Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) formed a special task force to probe the case. Acting on tips, CIB officers managed to nab four key suspects in Hsichi, Taipei County and Taoyuan on Friday morning.
The investigators also seized large quantities of counterfeit Intel CPUs at the suspects' hideouts. The market value of those products were estimated at more than NT$100 million.

Initial investigations show that the suspects first purchased cheap slow-motion CPUs and then had those products' model numbers and trademarks removed at a still undiscovered underground factory. The products would then be stamped with Intel trademarks and model numbers, and sold as Intel high-speed CPUs for huge profits.

CIB officials said the counterfeiting ring had employed highly advanced machinery and sophisticated technology in its operations. Intel has dispatched its Asian affairs executives and a team of lawyers to look into the case.
Police authorities said they suspect there are other accomplices involved in the operations. "We'll continue search for all other suspects still at large," said a CIB official.

The official further said it is encouraging that the ring was broken at a time when the United States is threatening to rank Taiwan among countries which fail to provide adequate protection for American copyrights and patents. Countries on the US "Special 301" watch list face possible retaliatory trade sanctions for alleged infringement upon intellectual property rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PM ACCUSES NSW PREMIER OF BACKING WATERFRONT WORKERS

TEXT.P: Australia's Prime Minister John Howard on Friday accused New South Wales Premier Bob Carr of supporting sacked waterfront workers by failing to prevent the protesting workers from blocking trucks carrying cargo to Port Botany in Sydney.
Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith on Friday also accused the protesting waterfront workers of breaking the law and trying to hold Australia hostage.

At Fremantle Port in Western Australia, about 140 police confronted 400 sacked waterfront workers and detained nine of them because they refused to move away from the picket line where 38 trucks carrying cargo were blocked.
In Sydney, however, no arrests were made on Friday because about 500 sacked workers overwhelmingly outnumbered the 30 policemen who had detained 22 protesters a day earlier.
The NSW police were reluctant to make any arrests because they did not want to repeat the actions of officers in Western Australia.

In Melbourne, 45 containers containing cars of Toyota Australia for export were blocked from being loaded at the terminal operated by Patrick Stevedores, the company which fired the union dockworkers.
In Newcastle and Brisbane, the situation was similar, with cargo moving nowhere because of picket lines manned by the sacked workers.
The workers ignored court injunctions which forbade them from setting up picket lines at Patrick Stevedores' terminals in major ports around Australia.
The current dispute was triggered after Patrick, one of the leading stevedoring firms in Australia, sacked all its 1,400 workers last week.
The showdown between Patrick and the sacked workers, mainly the members of the Maritime Union of Australia, is accelerating and will begin to have an impact on Australia's exports if it continues.

Toyota Australia on Friday warned that the company would cease production of cars for export if the confrontation continues. A company spokesman said Toyota would be forced to lay off about 2,500 workers if the waterfront confrontation does not end soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRELIMINARY REPORT DEBUNKS ITALY'S 'MIRACLE CANCER CURE'

TEXT.P: A preliminary report by four Canadian doctors to Canada's federal government Thursday does not endorse what has been hailed as a miracle cancer cure in Italy.
But desperate patients said the doctors are rushing to judge the treatment by Dr. Luigi Di Bella, fearing a negative report could deprive them of access to a potential cure.
"Nobody is against anything," stressed Dr. Victor Fornasier, a Toronto pathologist and leader of the medical team sent to Italy last month.
"The evidence we saw was very, very skimpy. The data we were presented with was not the sort of data that we would accept here (in Canada) as being objective," he pointed out.
Giancarlo Florio, founder of the Pro-Di Bella Association, warned the doctors are speaking "in haste," which he said will prompt more patients to head to Italy for the treatment.

Florio said his group represents 6,000 cancer patients and their families across Canada and is growing daily. "I'm getting people calling from all over Canada," he said Wednesday, after The Globe and Mail published a letter to the editor written by one of the team's doctors.

In his letter, Hamilton oncologist Andrew Arnold said it would be premature to support Di Bella's drug and hormone treatment because the delegation did not get proof that it works. Arnold said he felt obliged to speak out publicly weeks before the team was to report to Ottawa because of public pressure for quick answers.

Fornasier said Arnold was only trying to protect vulnerable patients by giving them more information. "The difficulty we're having is we have patients who are on, or should be going on, therapy but are questioning whether they should not be instead going on the Di Bella treatment," Fornasier said.

The Canadian group spent one day with the 85-year-old physiologist during their weeklong mission. "I don't think they spent enough time in Italy," Florio said. "We're looking at 40 years or more of work. To spend a few days to evaluate it, I think is unfair."

But Fornasier said evidence, not time, was the problem. "I don't think being there any longer would have made a difference. It would have been more of the same." In their report, the four doctors recommend the government wait for results from clinical trials currently under way in Italy.
The report also recommends ways the government can better respond in the future to alternative therapies for other diseases that are bound to appear, Fornasier said.
The final report will be submitted to Health Minister Allan Rock by the end of April.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.03 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$33.018.
The greenback opened at 32.950 and was traded between 32.950 and 33.045.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$224 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOINT AID NEEDED TO HELP SAVE YEN FROM DROPPING: CBC
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 16 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan financial heavyweight said that if the depreciation of the Japanese yen isn't stopped, the weakened currency will soon drag down the New Taiwan dollar and then impact the Hong Kong currency and the mainland Chinese yuan, sparking an overall financial disaster.

Sheu Jia-dong, deputy governor of the Republic of China's Central Bank of China (CBC), gave the warning in a brief interview with CNA Thursday in New York. He stressed that the economic problems Japan faces are so severe that Tokyo can no longer solve them on its own.
Sheu said that joint aid provided by international financial organizations and rich countries is the only way for Japan to escape its difficult position.

Sheu, along with ROC Bureau of Monetary Affairs chief Sean Chen, took part in a conference Thursday sponsored by Saint John's University in New York to speak about the ROC's effective measures in dealing with the Asian financial crisis.

Other ROC officials attending the meeting were Thomas M.F. Yeh, chief for the Economic Research Department under the Council for Economic Planning and Development; Cho Shih-chao, deputy director general of the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs; and Shih Tsuen-hua, director of the CBC's New York representative office.
A number of American economic and financial scholars and experts also participated.
During the conference, titled "How Taiwan is Weathering the Asian Financial Crises," Sheu addressed Taiwan's existing currency policy and economic prospects.

He also defended the CBC for allowing the depreciation of the Taiwan currency, saying that this was aimed at the ROC having sufficient foreign exchange reserves in case its national security is threatened.

The CBC's acceptance of market forces resulted not only in a vigorous drop in the value of the NT dollar but also disorder in Hong Kong's financial markets, prompting Beijing to charge Taipei with conducting a political conspiracy.

Sheu told the American financial scholars at the conference that during the first three months after the Asian financial crisis broke out last July, the CBC spent approximately US$7 billion of its foreign exchange reserves to defend the NT dollar.

The effort, however, failed to save the Taiwan currency from falling, the deputy CBC governor said, adding that the situation forced his bank to let the local unit follow market forces in order to stop sacrificing the country's reserves on an "impossible mission."

Sheu reiterated the necessity of the ROC preserving its foreign exchange reserves, explaining that since Taiwan is not a member of either the International Monetary Fund or World Bank, it cannot afford financial or political crises that could endanger its survival.

He noted that in June 1995, when Beijing conducted live missile tests in waters near Taiwan, the government used around one-fifth of the country's foreign exchange reserves to maintain the island's financial stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TAIWAN INVESTORS VICTIMIZED ON MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The personal safety and property of Taiwan businesspeople operating in mainland China are facing increased threats, as more of them are falling victim to criminal elements there, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) reported on Friday.

Liao Yun-yuan, director of the SEF's Department of Economic and Trade Service, said the SEF assisted in handling 27 cases involving Taiwanese businesspeople being victimized on the mainland last year, while the number of such cases has already reached 19 in the first three and a half months of this year.
Among those incidents, five Taiwanese businesspeople were murdered, six went missing and the remaining eight were either arbitrarily detained by mainland authorities, kidnapped or blackmailed.

On Tuesday, Yeh Jung-fu, a Republic of China national who ran a garment factory in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian, was murdered. His wife was abducted by Yeh's killers, who broke into their house in Quanzhou on Tuesday night, but she managed to escape later and reported the case to mainland police.

"We are no stranger to this kind of tragic case," SEF's Liao said. "A similar tragedy also occurred during the Chinese New Year holiday in late January. Liu Kwang-chao, a Taiwan investor who ran a factory in Guangdong Province in southern China, was abducted and then murdered by workers at his plant on the lunar New Year Day. Many SEF staffers were forced to cut short their New Year holiday to help handle the case."

Citing SEF statistics, Liao said 162 similar incidents involving the personal and property safety of Taiwan businesspeople in mainland China have been reported over the past seven years since SEF's founding. In addition, 428 trade and property disputes involving Taiwan businessmen on the mainland have also been reported during the same period.

Liao attributed the increasing safety threat to Taiwan businesspeople mainly to the changing economic climate on the mainland. "Rapid economic development and urbanization in mainland China's coastal provinces have resulted in a sharp increase in population in the region as well as in criminal activities. And cash-rich Taiwan investors have become a major target of mainland criminal elements," he noted.
According to SEF tallies, most criminal cases involving Taiwan victims took place in Guangdong, Fujian and Hainan provinces, all of which accommodate a large number of Taiwan-invested firms.

Liao said mainland China has attracted more than US$190 billion in direct foreign investment. Of the amount, 66 percent came from Hong Kong, Taiwan and Macau. "Mainland authorities should take effective measures to protect Taiwan investors' personal and property safety in addition to protecting their legitimate business interests," he urged, adding the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume talks as soon as possible in order to pool their wisdom and energy to fight crime and protect people's safety and well-being.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFO EXCHANGE ON MILITARY DRILLS WITH M'LAND WELCOME: SIEW

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday that he would welcome the two sides of the Taiwan Strait exchanging information on their military exercises to help establish mutual trust and avoid unnecessary military confrontation.
Siew made the remarks in response to questions by Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party at the Legislative Yuan.
The premier said that in view of the current state of cross-strait relations, he is in favor of exchanging information on military exercises with Beijing.

Siew stressed that the establishment of a mutual trust mechanism would make military maneuvers between the two sides more transparent and could help avoid misunderstandings that could trigger real combat.

He noted that in 1991 the government terminated the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion and said it would not seek to resolve cross-strait problems by military means.
Taiwan's military focus has shifted to the solidification of the island's defenses, Siew noted. He lamented the fact that Beijing, however, has yet to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

He stressed that the government's policy to maintain cross-strait peace and stability remains changed, and said that he would welcome the building of a mutual trust mechanism to aid national development and the well-being of the people.
The establishment of mutual trust would ease hostility and tensions and would contribute to the peace and stability on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the premier said.
He said that although Taiwan people should be on guard about Beijing's military exercises along the southeast coast of the mainland, there is no need to overreact.
The Ministry of National Defense is keeping abreast of mainland military movements and will keep the public informed about the situation, he said.
Siew's remarks came on the heels of a denial by Beijing that it would launch large-scale military maneuvers. Beijing announced that it would only hold routine training program drills.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN COUPLES DO NOT SUPPORT JOINT BANK ACCOUNTS: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of people in Taiwan are career-minded and prefer to marry late nowadays, and while most of those who are married do not support joint bank accounts, they still prefer to jointly manage money in the family, according to the results of a recent poll.

Most married couples in Taiwan opt to co-manage their household finances, while their counterparts in Indonesia and South Korea choose to let the wives be the financial ministers, the latest public opinion poll conducted by MasterCard International shows.

According to the "Asian Ideals" survey, which reveals Asians' views on marriage, only 28 percent of Taiwan respondents said wives should be the financial rulers of the house and a mere 6 percent said husbands should be in charge of the finances, the lowest figure among all Asia-Pacific economies, the survey shows.

The survey, which MasterCard International conducted in December 1997 by questioning more than 5,000 adults in 13 nations and areas in the Asia-Pacific region, sought Asian views on marriage, family and relationships.
Regionally, the survey found, 50 percent were in favor of joint bank accounts for married couples, while 38 percent were not in favor and 11 percent were undecided.

Support for a joint account was highest in Australia (73 percent), India (72 percent), the Philippines (70 percent), Singapore (63 percent) and New Zealand (62 percent), and lowest in Thailand (39 percent), Indonesia (30 percent) and Japan (11 percent). Most people in Taiwan joined the naysayers' camp, with only 31 percent of the respondents in favor, the poll shows.

When asked to choose between money and happiness, the overwhelming choice across Asia was happiness (55 percent), followed by money and happiness equally (38 percent). Fewer than 10 percent of respondents in each country, except Japan, considered money more important. The Japanese were the only consumers to put money ahead of happiness -- by 21 percent to 13 percent.
In comparison, 77 percent of surveyed Australians said happiness comes first, the highest ratio among all Asians, and 50 percent of the Taiwan respondents ranked happiness above money.
Another sign that today's Asians have become more modern and career-oriented: 51 percent of those surveyed announced they would like to remain single.

Thai and Indonesian singles were by far the most inclined to say they would like to remain unmarried (93 percent and 80 percent, respectively). Taiwan people and Hong Kongers were similarly inclined, albeit to lesser degrees (65 percent and 60 percent, respectively). Those less inclined to a preference for staying single included Filipinos (32 percent), Japanese (30 percent), Indians (28 percent) and Malaysians (22 percent), the poll found.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1ST FUTURES EXCHANGE OPENS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange (TAIMEX), the country's first futures exchange, opened on Friday at the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei Hotel.

Premier Vincent Siew sent a congratulatory note to TAIMEX Chairman H.T. Lin, expressing the hope that the establishment of the exchange will be a milestone in Taiwan's efforts to become a financial hub in the Asia-Pacific region and will bring the country closer to setting up a more comprehensive financial system.

With the approach of the new millennium, Lin said, he is committed to establishing an effective and fair futures exchange in Taiwan which will market a variety of new futures products and promote the globalization of the local futures market.

Responding to a reporter's question as to when the TAIMEX will formally launch trading, Vice Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said it will become operational after the futures transactions tax draft bill has passed the Legislative Yuan.

Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Lu Daung-yen said the TAIMEX is expected to begin operations in May, as the government and the legislature have already reached consensus on officially opening the local futures market to the general investing public as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WANTS REMAINING KHMER ROUGE LEADERS BROUGHT TO JUSTICE

TEXT.P: Australia on Friday joined the United States and Thailand in demanding an autopsy on the body of former Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot, responsible for the murder of some two million Cambodians, and Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said Canberra wants to see other senior Khmer Rouge leaders brought to justice.
In a statement faxed to the CNA, Downer stated: "The apparent death of the infamous Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot brings to an end one of the most shocking chapters in recent history.
"We would, along with others in the international community, including the United States and Thai governments, prefer that an autopsy be conducted to prove his death conclusively," the fax read.
It continued: "Many, including the Australian government and the people of Australia, remain committed to seeing other senior Khmer Rouge leaders brought to justice."

Australia has been strongly supportive of Cambodia in its efforts at reconstruction, and continues, through its active role in the "Friends of Cambodia" group, which Australia was instrumental in establishing, to help bring peace and stability to the country, Downer added in his fax.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUHARTO FULLY BACKS AUSTRALIA'S ASEM ENTRY: ENVOY

TEXT.P: In an effort to repair the damaged relations between Canberra and Jakarta, Indonesia's ambassador to Australia on Friday said President Suharto fully supports Australia's bid to enter the Asia-European Summit (ASEM).
A statement from Ambassador Sastrohandojo Wiryono said: "There has been no change in Indonesia's support of Australian entry into the ASEM."

Earlier this month, however, Indonesian Vice President J.B Habibie was reported to have supported Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad in vetoing Australia's entry to the body when he attended an ASEM meeting in London.

Australia was angry with Habibie's support of Mahathir because Prime Minister John Howard and Foreign Minister Alexander Downer had tried very hard to help Indonesia get better deals with the United States, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in the IMF bailout of the world's largest Islamic country from its financial crisis.
In addition, Australia has also provided credit funds for its exporters, allowing them to continue exporting to Indonesian importers who lack the cash to make their payments.
Howard on Friday played down the rift between Australia and Indonesia, saying relations between the two countries must be based on mutual respect.
The 10-member ASEM is responsible for bridging economic and other relations between Asia and Europe.
Australia has tried hard for the last two years to enter the ASEM, but has failed repeatedly, due mainly to Mahathir's veto.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW HAPPY ABOUT JUSTICE MINISTER'S DECISION TO STAY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday that he is glad Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao accepted his request to stay on the job, and that both President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan had, upon his request, joined in the efforts to retain Liao.

Siew made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in answer to interpellation by Taipei City Legislator Yen Ching-fu of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. The premier had high praise for Liao's performance in safeguarding law and order and in leading the crackdown on organized crime since becoming justice minister.

After Liao submitted a formal written resignation to Siew on April 14, the premier asked Chang Yu-huai, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, to return the resignation and try to persuade the justice minister to stay.

Commenting on Liao's letter of resignation, Siew said the justice minister may have tired of his job because of work pressure. He added that the public concern that followed the resignation's announcement shows Liao's performance has gained unanimous affirmation from the people.
Siew said he is happy Liao eventually decided to accept his request to stay on the job and continue to serve the country and society.
"This is the result that everyone was hoping for," the premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TEXTILE TRADE MISSION VISITS TURKEY

TEXT.P: A Taiwan trade mission, representing 18 textile machinery, dye and fabrics manufacturers, is participating in a series of trade fairs in Turkey between April 16-25, Peter Wen-Jung Huang, director of the Istanbul office of the Taiwan Trade Center, said in a news conference Thursday.
The group, organized by the China External Trade Development Council, will also visit three different textile manufacturing centers in Turkey, Huang said.

Taiwan and Turkey both are leading manufacturers and exporters of textile machinery and fabrics. However, Huang said, "The textile industries of Turkey and Taiwan do not compete with each other but complement each other, since each has different specialties."

Among textile industry items, Taiwan sells Turkey textile dyes, synthetic filament yarns, knitted and crocheted fabrics, and sewing machines. Turkey, in turn, exports polyester, viscose and cord fabrics, leather and woven products and uncombed cotton to Taiwan, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EASTERN MULTIMEDIA, US WEST LAUNCH STRATEGIC ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Eastern Multimedia Corp. forged a strategic alliance with US West Inc. on Thursday in Taipei, a significant deal that is expected to upgrade cable TV services in Taiwan.

A contract signing ceremony was held Thursday at the Lai-Lai Sheraton Hotel in Taipei, with Eastern Multimedia Chairman Wang Ling-lin and Tom Parun, chairman of Asian operations for US West, in attendance, along with a number of other executives from the two enterprises.

Wang said during the ceremony that under the agreement, US West will provide its modern expertise and experience in the establishment of advanced cable and telephone networks in helping Eastern Multimedia upgrade its current broadband communications systems.
US West Inc., founded in 1984, is the parent company of two major groups: US West Communications and MediaOne Group (formerly US West Media Group).

MediaOne Group, one of the largest broadband communications companies in the United States, is involved in domestic and international cable and telephone services, international wireless operations, and directory and information services, while US West Communications provides telecommunications services in 14 US western and midwestern states, according to US West.
US West Inc. has some US$39.8 billion in total assets. The enterprise giant, which currently employs 69,000 people, had an operational income of around US$15.4 billion last year.

In 1993, US West forged a strategic alliance with Time Warner to provide all of the latter's cable television, telephone and entertainment services. The company became the third largest cable TV system business in the United States after buying out Continental Cablevision in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DENIES REPORT OF PREMIER CHANGE

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office on Friday denied emphatically a local newspaper report which alleged that President Lee Teng-hui is considering removing Premier Vincent Siew from office following the year-end legislative election.

The Presidential Office said in a press release that "President Lee has given a very high appraisal of Premier Vincent Siew's performance" and that the report by the Independence Evening Post is "totally groundless, speculative and irresponsible."
It also called on media personnel to check their facts more carefully in the future in order to avoid unnecessary trouble and problems.

The Independence Evening Post reported in its Friday edition that Lee is considering sacking Siew following the island's legislative election slated for December, because of discontent over Siew's handling of a series of major incidents over the past two months. Siew assumed the premiership on Sept. 1, 1997, taking over from incumbent Vice President Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA PROTESTS INDONESIA'S ASEM VETO

TEXT.P: Australia has lodged a protest with Indonesia over Vice President J.B. Habibie's support of a veto of Australian entry into the Asia-Europe Summit (ASEM), expressing anger because Canberra has played a vital role in helping Indonesia in its financial crisis dealings with the United States, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer told Indonesia that he was "personally hurt" by Habibie's actions at the ASEM summit in London this month because the Indonesian vice president was unduly influenced by the anti-Australian sentiment of Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.

Mahathir has repeatedly opposed Australia's ASEM entry for the last two years, thwarting Canberra's attempts to become a member of the organization which is a key body through which Asia and Europe are seeking to develop closer economic ties.

Australia acknowledges that Habibie did not specifically speak out against Australia's ASEM admission, but he did discuss the issue with Mahathir, when he reportedly said that the ASEM needs quality not quantity, and that the body should consolidate its membership.

"The question of expansion is not one we are pursuing at present," Habibie was quoted as saying to Mahathir. This ruled out Australia's entry, officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Australia told The Australian Financial Review, Australia's leading business daily, in an exclusive interview on Friday.

They said Downer was particularly irked because of his strong personal efforts to help Indonesia. He made unscheduled visits to Washington recently to urge the United States, the World Bank and the IMF to be more flexible in their demands for economic and financial reforms in Indonesia.
Downer's efforts enabled Indonesia to renegotiate with the IMF for a better deal.

Australian protests were directed to Indonesian ambassador to Australia Sastrohandojo Wiryono, but Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas denied that Habibie supported Malaysia in vetoing Australia's ASEM membership.
Australia will now be unable to join the ASEM before its third meeting in Seoul in the year 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS WILL BE BIGGEST WINNERS IN MILK IMPORTS

TEXT.P: Chen Bao-ji, director of the Animal Industry Department under the Council of Agriculture (COA), said on Friday that milk consumers will be the biggest winners after the Republic of China enters the World Trade Organization (WTO).

According to Chen, cheaper milk from Australia and New Zealand is expected to find its way into the Taiwan market in the first year of the ROC's WTO entry, when 100,000 tons of milk in liquid form will be allowed into the country.

Milk production costs in both Australia and New Zealand are about 30 percent to 40 percent lower than in Taiwan, and the COA predicted that Taiwan's milk market will be dominated by milk products from the two countries, which means that consumers will have the choice of buying high-quality milk from abroad at lower prices.

Chen pointed out that Taiwan currently produces an annual total of 330,000 tons of milk. He predicted that imported milk will reach 20,000 tons by the year 2004, and that these imports will have a heavy impact on the domestic processed milk market, although fresh milk will be less affected due to transportation time and marketing networks.

However, the COA predicted that the competition from imported milk will force local dairy farmers to upgrade their fresh milk and lower prices, providing a win-win situation for the island's consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND EAGER FOR TAIWAN INVESTMENT AS ISLAND LOOKS SOUTHEAST

TEXT.P: Mainland China is in dire need of money from Taiwan if it wants to maintain an economic growth of 8 percent this year, but Taiwan investors have been going shopping in the industrial and financial sectors of cash-strapped Southeast Asia instead.

In a feature article covering almost two-thirds of the business page in Friday's edition of the mass circulation newspaper The Australian, Geoff Hiscock, the daily's Asia business editor, said though mainland China regards Taiwan as a renegade province, it also recognizes the island as an important source of foreign capital that Beijing doesn't want to lose.
Hiscock said Taiwan businessmen have invested at least A$35 billion (US$2.3 billion) in mainland China in the past decade.
"China needs Taiwan's money more than ever if it is to keep on target for 8 percent growth in 1998," Hiscock said.

He quoted Dr. Wang Jian-chyuan, a fellow researcher at the Chung Hwa Institute for Economic Research in Taipei, as saying that Taiwan is fortunate to have close economic ties with mainland China and the United States.

He said Taiwan has survived the worst of the Asian crisis because it is structurally different and its business cycle is different. He said most Taiwan companies are small and medium-sized, unlike those in Japan and South Korea, where big corporations dominate.

Many small and medium-sized companies have to rely on their own funds because it is difficult for them to borrow money from banks, Hiscock noted, adding that these firms are known for being very flexible in their operations as well as for their lack of offshore debt.

He said that while most companies in Asia are facing hardships from the Asian crisis, Taiwan companies -- like their US, European and Australian counterparts -- are looking to invest in the industrial and financial sectors in Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia.

Leading the commercial charge are Chinatrust Ltd., the flagship firm of the Koo family business empire, and the China Development Corp. (CDC), the investment arm of Taiwan's ruling party, the Kuomintang.

Hiscock reported the CDC is buying 52 percent of Bangkok First Investment and Trust for US$15 million and may lift its existing 10 percent stake in Indonesia's Tamara Bank. It has also signed a memorandum of understanding with the Malaysian financial group Rashid Hussain Bhd and is looking at a steel investment with Malaysia's Amsteel Mills.

He said that under Jeffrey Koo, Chinatrust has set itself a goal of becoming a global Chinese bank. Its merchant bank arm, KG Investments, has already made one acquisition in 1998 through a purchase of a 44 percent stake in Securities One, the brokerage firm of failed Thai financial group Finance One Plc., for 2.1 billion baht (US$52.55 million).
These are just the first waves of what could be a Taiwan money tsunami in 1998.

He said that by June, Taiwan's economic planners expect to have a war chest of A$920 million (US$613 million) for a new investment holding company in Southeast Asia and that the CDC is taking the lead in forming this company.
And Chinatrust itself has a A$600 (US$400) million direct investment fund, he added.
Together, CDC and Chinatrust will have a combined and formidable A$1.5 billion (US$1 billion) of buying power, Hiscock said.

He reported that P.K. Chiang, chairman of the ROC Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), led a group of Taiwan businessmen on a successful visit to Southeast Asian countries early this year.

Hiscock quoted Thomas Yeh, director general of the CEPD, as saying that the new wave of Taiwan investment in Southeast Asia is part of Taipei's "Go South" policy, which aims to diversify Taiwan investment away from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR YEN CHIN-FU TO VIE FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Legislator Yen Chin-fu announced on Friday that he will enter the race for the chairmanship of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Yen announced his bid during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session.
Just before posing a question to Premier Vincent Siew, Yen said he will take part in the May 24 DPP chairmanship election.

A self-confident Yen said he has the ability and a strong sense of mission which qualifies him to run for the post. "If I'm elected, I will lead the DPP in promoting the well-being of my fellow countrymen and set a model for the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

Yen became the third DPP politician to formally announce his bid for the party's chairmanship. The other two hopefuls are Lin Yi-hsiung, a senior party adviser, and Chang Chun-hung, a DPP legislator-at-large and head of the pro-independence party's largest Formosa faction. Incumbent DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang has said he will not seek reelection.
During Friday's interpellation, Yen also asked Siew whether his KMT is prepared to form a coalition Cabinet following the year-end legislative election.
"I'm convinced that we'll face a legislature where no political party controls a majority following the next legislative election scheduled for late this year," Yen claimed.

In response, Siew said such a scenario is only Yen's personal forecast, but Yen immediately reminded Siew that the DPP has already managed to take control of more than half of the island's city mayor and county chief posts following last November's local elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY DOWNPLAYS VATICAN CONTACTS WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Friday that the Vatican has usual contacts with mainland China because freedom and human rights in the mainland are among the pope's concerns.

Officials with the ministry said that the government and people of the Republic of China should not be too "sensitive" about the engagement between the Vatican and the mainland, adding that nowadays countries in the world like to explore opportunities for developing ties with other governments.

They said Pope John Paul II has shown concern for peace, freedom, prosperity and human rights throughout the world and that it is natural that he is also concerned about the Catholics in mainland China.

The officials made the remarks after the Holy See's Secretary of State Jean-Louis Tauran said on Thursday that the Vatican and mainland officials have usual contacts in third countries. They noted, however, that he added that these haven't led to any substantial breakthrough in Vatican-Beijing relations.

Tauran said that it is a good thing that the mainland is becoming aware of the importance of the Vatican as a partner in the international community. He added, however, that "in the field of religion, a normalization of relations with the Vatican is not yet a priority for China."

Foreign officials noted that Beijing has set two conditions for a normalization of relations between the mainland and the Vatican: that the Vatican not interfere with religious affairs in the mainland, including the appointment of bishops, and that the Holy See severs its formal ties with the Republic of China. These conditions are believed to be totally unacceptable to the Vatican, the officials added.

Currently, Catholics in the mainland are obliged to be members of the Chinese Catholic Patriotic Association and renounce their loyalty to the pope. There are an estimated 10 million pro-Vatican Catholics in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAVID HO NAMED ACADEMIA SINICA CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: Dr. David Ho, the Taiwan-born American who invented the drug cocktail therapy for AIDS sufferers, said on Friday that he is happy and proud to have been chosen as a candidate for membership of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic institute.

The doctor named as Time magazine's 1996 man of the year pointed out that if he is given the honor of membership of Academia Sinica, he will have greater opportunity to cooperate with Taiwan's academic and medical circles in conducting basic research on AIDS and related viruses, and therefore to contribute his share to the Taiwan community.

Meanwhile, Shih Yao-tang, commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Department of Health, said on Friday that among the island's more than 1,500 AIDS patients, more than 800 have adopted Ho's drug cocktail therapy.
Shih made the remarks at a Taipei seminar where Ho was the guest speaker.
Prior to the seminar, Ho and Shih paid a courtesy call on Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong at his Taipei office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 3RD BEST LOCATION FOR INVESTMENT: BERI SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been ranked third on a list of the world's best investment locations, behind only Switzerland and Singapore, the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported on Friday.

In the latest report by the US-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI), Taiwan placed third among 50 countries in terms of profit-making opportunities, and was ranked as the best investment site in Asia next to Singapore, the officials said.

The ranking in BERI's March assessment is the same as those in the March, July, and November BERI reports of 1997. The prestigious organization issues investment risk assessments of 50 major economies around the world three times each year.

The BERI assessment, or the Profit Opportunity Recommendation (POR) rating is based on three criteria: operation risk index; political risk index; and remittance and repatriation factor. Countries are evaluated in each category separately before a final cumulative assessment is made.

In terms of operation risk index, Taiwan and Singapore placed second, behind only Switzerland. The operation risk is related to a country's trade and investment environment, which is evaluated by 105 managing executives from around the world.

In the category of political risk index, Taiwan came in fifth position, behind Switzerland, Singapore, Austria, and Norway. Political risk evaluates the political and societal conditions of each country and is evaluated by 75 members of BERI's standing committee.
Taiwan ranked third in the remittance and repatriation factor, behind only Japan and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREDRICK CHIEN TO SPEAK ON ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: As Taiwan launches a campaign to promote the notion that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should jointly help Southeast Asian nations to recover from the recent financial crisis, Dr. Frederick Chien, Speaker of the National Assembly of the Republic of China, will convey a strong message to the American people that Taiwan will spare no effort to support its neighbors.

At the invitation of the prestigious Heritage Foundation, a right-wing US think tank, Chien will speak before the foundation's 13th "Public Policy Seminar" on the Asian financial crisis and Taiwan's position on the issue. Chien and his wife arrived on Thursday at San Francisco Airport en route to Palm Springs in Southern California, where the seminar will be held.

Chien indicated that in his 20-minute speech before some 400 participants, he will analyze the recent Asian economic turmoil from the economic angle, but added that the subject of Taiwan's initiative to work with mainland China to help Southeast Asian nations will certainly be brought up later during a question-and-answer session.

The former foreign minister and US representative declined to comment on whether he has been asked by the ROC government to promote its latest overture, but said he knows very well the position, attitude and thinking of President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew, the two major forces behind the idea.

Chien said Taiwan's initiative is sure to receive a positive response from the international community, since the Asian financial crisis is still the dominating issue for all the nations of the Pacific Rim and beyond, as well as international financial institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONEY MORE IMPORTANT THAN HUMAN RIGHTS WHEN DEALING WITH MAINLAND CHINA: EU

TEXT.P: The European Union, which is always a strong proponent of human rights, is following the lead of the US and Australia by softening its human rights stand in favor of trade and economic links with mainland China.

Mass circulation newspaper The Australian on Friday ran an article in which it says that the tone of the first EU-mainland China summit in London earlier this month was significantly different to the discordant voices of the past, when disagreement over mainland China's human rights record invariably left a blot on their relationship.

The article, headlined "Never Mind Civil Rights, Money Matters," said the EU has gone down the track taken by Australia and the US -- that is, it is much better to engage mainland China in positive and friendly discussions than to alienate it.

The US renewed mainland China's most-favored nation status without tying it to human rights conditions two years ago, while Australia set up a channel for bilateral dialogue to discuss human rights with mainland China last year after refusing to support a Danish-sponsored condemnation of human rights in mainland China at the UN Human Rights Commission meeting in Geneva last June.

The article says the EU's new approach to engaging mainland China follows a series of failures on the human rights issue because Beijing has never taken kindly to outside interference in its human rights record.
The EU, like the US and Australia, has learned that to risk annoying mainland China is to deny itself business opportunities in what is potentially the largest consumer market in the world.
The article says this shows that, in an increasingly materialistic and pragmatic world, there's little room for idealism or moral principles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOLD TRADE FAIRS IN 11 ALLIED COUNTRIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday that the Republic of China will hold or take part in trade fairs in 11 countries with which it maintains diplomatic ties as part of efforts to strengthen friendly ties with those nations.

Liu Yi-ming, deputy director of the MOFA's Economic and Trade Affairs Department, said that as mainland China is still trying to woo the ROC's allies in Central and South America and Africa -- ROC diplomatic strongholds -- in an attempt to isolate the island internationally, the government will undertake a series of measures designed to strengthen ties with these countries. Holding or attending trade fairs is considered to be an effective way of doing this, he noted.

Liu said that from July this year, Taiwan will hold or attend trade fairs in Panama, Paraguay, Honduras, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Dominica, and Dominican Republic, in Central and South America, as well as in the African countries of Malawi, Swaziland, Senegal, and Burkina Faso.

He said that the China External Trade Development Council will be responsible for the project, adding that the MOFA hopes that Taiwan businessmen will increase their investment in these countries to help further solidify bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES IMPROVEMENT IN US-MAINLAND CHINA TIES

TEXT.P: An official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday that Taipei is delighted to see the recent improvement in bilateral Washington-Beijing ties, as long as the US' engagement with mainland China does not hurt the parallel development of two-way relations between Taiwan and the US.

Shen Lyu-shun, director of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, said that although US President Bill Clinton said after his meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in October that Washington will develop parallel relations with both Taiwan and mainland China, Taiwan still needs to pay close attention to the impact on Taiwan of the second Clinton-Jiang meeting slated for the end of June.

He stressed that so long as Taiwan's interests are not jeopardized, Taiwan will welcome improved ties between the US and mainland China, since they will lead to greater stability and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region.

Speaking at a public hearing held by New Party Legislator Chen Yi-hsiung, Shen said that Washington, based on the foundation laid by the previous Clinton-Jiang meeting, is hoping to continue with efforts to improve its overall relationship with Beijing during the upcoming meeting between the two heads of state.

According to Shen, Washington is also expecting to convince Beijing to play a greater role in helping Southeast Asian countries through the current financial crisis and take measures to reduce its huge trade surplus with the US. In addition, Clinton is expected to discuss the issue of weapons proliferation with Jiang.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said Washington and Beijing are unlikely to sign a formal accord stating Beijing's "three no's" policy toward Taiwan during the June summit, as there remains strong opposition among the US private sector to Washington's engagement with mainland China.
Lin also said he expects the mainland to become more flexible in its dealings with Taiwan because of a more stable Beijing leadership.
However, Cheng Tuan-yao, a professor at National Chengchi University, warned the government of possible negative effects on Taiwan caused by the Clinton-Jiang meeting.

According to Cheng, bilateral relations between the US and mainland China are currently at the "honeymoon" stage, since a record high of 135 US congressmen visited mainland China last year and many US academics and scholars have been "brainwashed" by the Chinese communists into thinking that anything beneficial to the US and the mainland will also be good for Taiwan.
The ROC government should do something to clarify these American misunderstandings, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGERS ARRESTED FOR TRYING TO BRING GASOLINE ABOARD AIRCRAFT

TEXT.P: Three airline passengers were arrested on Friday and are currently being interrogated by aviation police at eastern Taiwan's Hualien Airport for attempting to smuggle bottles of gasoline onto an aircraft.

The three passengers, who all work for the same company in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, were discovered to have four bottles of gasoline in their bags when they were undergoing security checks before boarding a TransAsia Airways flight to Kaohsiung at 5:30 p.m.

However, the three contended that the bottles of gasoline were samples they had been using for a demonstration at an exhibition sponsored by Chinese Petroleum Corp. Because they were too late to have their luggage checked in when they reached the TransAsia counter, they had to bring the luggage with them as hand baggage, they claimed.
They also told police that they had reported the gasoline to the security personnel before undergoing the security check, but said the security personnel immediately took them to the aviation police.

The security personnel, however, had another version of the events, saying that the three passengers said nothing about contraband until the bottles were discovered. Aviation police are investigating the case.

Security has been especially tight at airports islandwide over the past few weeks following a series of air traffic accidents and incidents. There has been speculation that a recent unexplained fatal crash might have been caused by an explosive device on the plane, while a man attempted to commit suicide aboard a domestic flight a few weeks ago by sprinkling smuggled gasoline in the plane and setting fire to it.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL APPRECIATES TAIWAN'S CRACKDOWN ON BOGUS CHIPS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, April 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: World microchip giant Intel Inc. of the United States on Friday expressed gratitude to Taiwan's law enforcement authorities for their crackdown on a computer chip counterfeiting ring and for confiscating US$3 million-worth of bogus Intel Pentium II chips.

While praising Taiwan police and expressing appreciation for the haul, Intel reiterated its determination to cooperate with law enforcement authorities around the world to eradicate counterfeiting of its products.

Taiwan's National Police Administration (NPA) was tipped off by Intel, the world's largest maker of computer central processing units (CPUs) earlier this year about alleged counterfeiting of Intel chips in Taiwan. The NPA consequently formed a special task force to probe an alleged counterfeiting ring suspected of forging Intel's latest-generation CPUs.

In Friday's action, the NPA's Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) raided five locations in northern Taiwan, nabbing five suspects and confiscating thousands of bogus Intel CPUs and tools for making them. The forged products were estimated to have a street value of about NT$100 million (US$3 million).
Initial investigations show that the suspects first purchased relatively low-end Pentium II 233 CPUs and then removed their identification marks at a still undiscovered underground factory.

The products were then inscribed with new model numbers and identification using laser technology, describing them as the latest high-speed Pentium II 266 or Pentium II 300 CPUs, models which could fetch NT$12,000 (US$366) and NT$18,000 (US$549) apiece, respectively.

CIB officials said the ring had employed highly advanced machinery and sophisticated technology in its operations. Other masterminds are believed to be behind the operation, and police will continue to track down all the suspects still at large, according to a CNA report from Taipei on Friday.

An Intel spokesman would not identify which country or area in the world is accused of being the source of the greatest volume of counterfeited Intel chips, saying only that bogus Intel CPUs have in the past also been found in other Asian countries, Europe and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-EU MEETING TO OPEN TUESDAY IN TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 17 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An annual economic and trade consultation meeting between the Republic of China and the 15-member European Union (EU) will open in Taipei next Tuesday, diplomatic sources here said on Friday.

Gerard Depeyre, a deputy department chief in charge of foreign trade at the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, will leave for Taipei on Sunday to attend the meeting. Depeyre will be accompanied by another EU official in charge of Taiwan affairs, Peter Guillford, on his Taipei visit.

The agenda for the meeting will include market opening, tariff concessions, crackdowns on commercial piracy, and financial service market deregulation, as well as the promotion of investment and bilateral industrial and technological cooperation.
The two sides will also exchange views on their strategies for coping with the fallout from the recent Asian financial turmoil and their current general economic situations.

Even though Taiwan and the EU finalized negotiations over terms for the ROC's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in late February, they are still divided on some trade issues, particularly Taiwan's tariff systems for liquors and compact cars. The two sides have yet to sign a formal agreement on Taiwan's WTO accession terms.
EU officials are expected to take advantage of the upcoming annual trade meeting to discuss these remaining issues with their Taiwan counterparts.

For its part, Taiwan is expected to express its concern about the EU's anti-dumping policy and measures, as a number of Taiwan products, such as portable fax machines, bicycles, automobile audio equipment, nuts and screws, synthetic fibers and monosodium glutamate, have either been slapped with prohibitive punitive duties or have been subject to anti-dumping investigations over the past six months.
