DOC.HEADLINE: MONGOLIA URGED TO GRANT TAIWAN VISITORS VISA-FREE PRIVILEGES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of Mongolian and Tibetan affairs on Saturday urged the Mongolian government to grant visa-free privileges to Taiwan visitors as a method of helping to accelerate bilateral exchanges between Mongolia and Taiwan.

Kao Koong-lian, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, said that although Taiwan visitors are currently given 30-day landing-visa treatment with a valid invitation from any Mongolian organization, Ulan Bator is being urged to scrap visas for Taiwan visitors altogether.

Taiwan residents make an average of five million trips abroad every year, Kao noted. In comparison, the number of Taiwan visitors traveling to Mongolia averages only about 500 per year so far, a minuscule proportion of the total, he said.

Kao said his commission will continue to promote exchanges with Mongolia, a former province of China which gained independence earlier this century. In 1990, the Mongolian Communist Party yielded its monopoly on power. A new constitution took effect on Feb. 12, 1992, and a democratic alliance won legislative elections in June, 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: UK SPIRITS INDUSTRY PRESSING TAIWAN FOR UNIFORM WHISKY TAX

TEXT.P: The UK Scotch Whisky Association has raised its voice again, calling on Taiwan to introduce a uniform tax rate for all spirits, irrespective of origin or type, in the hope of securing an equal footing for Scotch whisky in the Taiwan market.

Tim Jackson, a spokesman for The Scotch Whisky Association, said on Friday that the association has approached Hugh R. McMahon, a member of the European Parliament representing the Glasgow area, to voice its concern.

McMahon in turn has written to EU commissioner for Foreign Trade Sir Leon Britten, asking him to reject what he called a Taiwanese "interim" offer on whisky taxation, as this would give Japanese, American, Canadian, Indian, Belgian and French whiskeys a US$3.66 tax advantage over a bottle of scotch.

Under current legislation, other imported whiskeys in the Taiwan market are subject to a lower monopoly tax rate of NT$198 per liter compared with scotch and Irish whiskey, which is taxed more than double, at NT$440 per liter.

Jackson expressed the association's unhappiness over this discrepancy, saying it puts Scotch whisky in a disadvantageous position. In 1997, the value of Scotch whisky exported to Taiwan was some US$104 million, the second-largest UK export to Taiwan, but the figure has been falling since 1995.

According to Jackson, as a result of recent EU-Taiwan WTO market access negotiations and high-level UK-Taiwan, Taiwan has indicated that it will do its best to ensure enactment and implementation of the draft "Tobacco and Alcohol Tax Law" (TATL), which will embrace a uniform tax rate of NT$185 per liter for all spirits from Jan. 1, 1999; and failing which, a uniform rate of NT$198 will apply from that date until such time as the TATL takes effect.

Jackson added that Taiwan has offered to apply an "interim" tax arrangement for, among other things, whisky, to reduce the current tax rate of NT$440 per liter for scotch and Irish whiskey to NT$285 per liter, between the EU's signature of a WTO market access agreement and Jan. 1, 1999.

A Taiwan representative in London said, however, that they are not aware of what Jackson called the "interim" tax arrangement, let alone the "uniform" rate of NT$198 or even NT$185. The Taiwan representative expressed serious doubts about Jackson's version, but declined further comment, saying that Taiwan has sent a package to the EU commission for consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: OECD TO HOLD WORKSHOP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) will hold a workshop in Taipei for the first time on April 20-21, the National Science Council (NSC) reported on Saturday.
The seminar will focus on discussing national innovation systems in selected catch-up economies, including South Korea, Austria, Hungary, Mexico, Spain and Taiwan, the council said.

NSC officials said the OECD, which acts as a think tank for rich industrial nations, decided to convene the workshop in Taipei only after strong lobbying from the NSC. Taiwan hopes to become an OECD observer member before being admitted as a full member.
As Taiwan has a reputation as one of the four Asian Dragons with brilliant economic achievements, the officials said, the OECD has invited the nation to join its catch-up economies research program.

In addition to exploring national innovation systems in the above-mentioned six countries, the participants will also discuss their national development strategies and major reform programs during the two-day meeting.

NSC Chairman Huang Chen-tai will deliver a report on Taiwan's "virtual center" program, which is aimed at studying and drafting national science-technology development policies and strategies. Several local scientists will also present papers on science and technology-related topics to offer the participants from Europe and Asia-Pacific countries a glimpse into Taiwan's national innovation system and relevant development projects.

The OECD was founded in 1961 to promote the economic and social welfare of its member countries, and to stimulate and harmonize efforts on behalf of developing countries. Its recommendations are not binding but can play a role in shaping its members' economic policies.

OECD members in 1997 were Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, Mexico, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, Portugal, South Korea, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO CONTINUE PARALLEL ENGAGEMENT WITH ROC, MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 17 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: ROC Representative to the United States Stephen Chen said on Friday that the US should continue to develop relations with Taiwan on a parallel track with its ties with mainland China.
Chen made the call amid concern that the recent improvement in bilateral Washington-Beijing ties might hurt the parallel development of bilateral US-Taiwan relations.

In a speech entitled "Parallel Engagement: Taipei's Concept of US-Mainland Relations," at the World Affairs Council in Dallas, Texas, Chen stressed that a parallel engagement policy with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will meet long-term US interests, as well as help maintain prosperity and peace in the Asia-Pacific region.

Chen, who became head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the US last October, said the people of Taiwan understand that full-engagement between the US and the mainland will bring the US substantial political, economic and strategic benefits, which will in turn prompt the mainland to be a more responsible member of the international community.

Chen said that the US understands there is no reason to ignore Taiwan, a powerful economy willing to contribute to the international community. When the US develops relations with Taipei that are parallel with its ties with Beijing, it will encourage Taiwan to further develop a free and democratic system which will serve the best interests of US and Taiwan, and also help promote regional security and prosperity, Chen claimed.

According to Chen, the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979 has provided a legal framework for the US to develop parallel relations with both Taiwan and mainland China. In the past 19 years that the US has had full diplomatic ties with the mainland, relations between the US and Taiwan have also progressed. This kind of engagement policy has created a "three-wins" situation, he noted.

He stressed that the parallel engagement policy represents confirmation of the achievements Taiwan has made in its trade, economic, political and societal sectors. He also expressed the hope that the US can maintain the parallel engagement policy and apply it to regional and global issues.
This was Chen's first visit to Dallas since assuming his current post. The overseas Chinese community and Taiwan businessmen in Dallas were scheduled to host a party in Chen's honor on Friday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAN IS TO ACCOMPLISH PROCEDURAL ARRANGEMENTS FOR MUTUAL VISIT

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng's Beijing trip will be seen as successful if he can resolve procedural matters relating to reciprocal visits between the Taipei-based SEF and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), said Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman and secretary-general of the SEF, on Friday.
Jan is scheduled to visit Beijing on April 22 for consultations on matters of protocol regarding the visit of a Taiwan delegation to mainland China.

Jan, currently the director of the Research and Planning Department of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), was formally nominated by Premier Vincent Siew on Friday morning to the post of SEF deputy secretary-general, making him the first MAC official to join the high-ranking staff of the semi-official SEF since its founding seven years ago.
Contacts between the SEF and the ARATS have been suspended for almost three years, thus giving Shi high expectations of Jan's upcoming Beijing trip.

The reason for the trip has been defined as "procedural discussion" by Shi, who is hopeful that it will not only lead to the restoration of the agreements reached in the past, but will also serve to express his hearty welcome to a visit to Taiwan by Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the ARATS.
The SEF delegation with Jan at its head is slated to leave for Beijing at 8:30 a.m. on April 22 traveling via Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW, JUSTICE MINISTER LIAO MEET

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew met on Saturday with Minister of Justice Liao Cheng-hao, welcoming Liao's return to the Cabinet to work for the nation and the people.

Government spokesman Chen Chien-jen described the atmosphere of the hour-long meeting as "amicable," adding that Liao also expressed regret that his resignation, which was later withdrawn, had been the cause of grave concern for Siew and among the public.
Chen said in a press conference that Siew attaches importance to team spirit, morale and ethics in the Cabinet, as those values are important to societies, nations, groups and individuals.

Chen denied that an Executive Yuan statement made after Liao's decision to withdraw his resignation on Thursday was intended to admonish Liao. The statement said that Liao's resignation had caused "considerable impact on the morale and image of the Cabinet," calling for "respect for administrative ethics and the safeguarding of team spirit" after the conclusion of the matter.

Thanks to President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan, Liao changed his mind and agreed to return to the Justice Ministry, the spokesman said, but stressed that it was Premier Siew who asked the president and vice president to help talk Liao out of his determination to step down.

Siew was quoted as saying that his Cabinet, which he has dubbed the "Action Cabinet," is not afraid of heavy workloads or pressure, and that he believes that what the Cabinet has been endeavoring to accomplish will be felt by the people.

The popular justice minister first revealed his intention to step down from his post on Monday. Later in the day, Siew and Lee met separately with Liao to try to retain him. But he still tendered his official resignation on Tuesday. Liao's decision to scrap the resignation was made shortly after a meeting with Lien on Thursday.

Liao has received high approval ratings in a variety of public opinion polls for his determination and brilliant performance in cracking down on gangsters and maintaining law and order. There were strong calls from the public and from legislators regardless of their party affiliation for him to stay.

The meeting between Siew and Liao was seen as a gesture to mend any rift or discord between them in the Cabinet. Liao did not notify Siew of his decision to withdraw the resignation in person before he made the announcement in a press conference on Thursday. After the announcement, Liao rushed to the Executive Yuan to report this to Siew, but his request for a meeting was refused on the ground that Siew was receiving other guests.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS PROTEST TUITION HIKES

TEXT.P: More than 100 students from Taiwan's nine state and private universities took their grievances to the streets on Saturday to protest a government plan to raise tuition fees from next semester.

The students, shouting "Down with high tuition policy," "No raise for three years," and "Annual hikes make us sick," surged up to the gates of the Ministry of Education (MOE), where they wanted to meet Education Minister Lin Ching-chiang to voice their anger over the alleged increase in tuition fees.

After waiting for about two hours in front of the MOE gates, which police blocked them from entering, the students met with Vice Education Minister Yang Kuo-tsu, who promised to look into the proposed plan, and signed his name on a giant poster of a check to endorse its "no raise for three years" message.

Yang said the MOE is planning to invite legislators, academics and other relevant specialists to form a committee to study exclusively the appropriateness of any readjustment in tuition fees for higher education, and work out a standard formula for readjustment.

The students, temporarily satisfied with Yang's promise, said they will come back and stage another rally if tuition fees for the fall semester, which will be announced by the MOE in May, are found to have been increased.
Rumors have been circulating that the MOE is planning to raise college and university tuition fees by some 5 percent starting this fall, prompting students to take their anger to the streets.

Minimum tuition for students in state-run universities in Taiwan is now about NT$24,000 per person per semester, while fees in private institutions start from around NT$50,000. The figures do not include fees for medical schools and other departments of specialist study.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.014 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday, closing at NT$33.032.
The greenback opened at 33.006 and was traded between 33.006 and 33.049.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$59 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAILS WSC MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: Senior ROC government officials on Saturday expressed welcome to a World Semiconductor Council (WSC) decision to admit both sides of the Taiwan Strait next year.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said Taiwan's semiconductor industry will gain greater access to trade information and technological expertise following the island's entry to the non-governmental world semiconductor trade promotional organization.

The WSC passed a resolution at its second annual meeting held in Carlsbad, California on Friday, inviting Taiwan and mainland China to attend its 1999 annual meeting as full members on conditions that the two Chinese economies scrap tariffs on semiconductors as soon as possible and support all activities sponsored by the WSC and the Government Consulting Mechanism.
Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said joining the WSC will help boost the development of Taiwan's already vibrant semiconductor industry.

Taiwan is now the world's fourth largest semiconductor producer after the United States, Japan and South Korea. Its 1996 annual production reached US$8.4 billion and total investment amounted to US$19 billion. Taiwan is expected to replace South Korea as the No. 3 supplier soon.

With its strength in the industry, Taiwan was admitted to the Global Government Forum (GGF), a government-to-government international organization to coordinate policies on the semiconductor industry, earlier this year. Minland China is still not a GGF member.
The WSC, founded in August 1996, is a private forum dedicated to promoting development, trade and investment in the semiconductor industry as well as removal of tariff trade barriers.

Lin said a seat in the WSC will enable local semiconductor makers to better understand the regulations and development directions of the global semiconductor market. "It is also expected to help avert recurrence of a scenario that occurred several years ago. In the past, Taiwan's static and dynamic random access memory chips production once suffered a dramatic slump because of patent disputes."

Lin further said mainland China's entry to the WSC is also good news for Taiwan as it will push the mainland to remove tariff barriers and thus facilitate sales of Taiwan-made semiconductors to that vast market.
The WSC currently have four full members -- the United States, Japan, the European Union and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC, ROC VYING FOR OVERSEAS CHINESE SUPPORT

TEXT.P: A report published by the Canadian Security and Intelligence Service (CSIS) says mainland China's "next major foreign policy goal will be to create the conditions for reunification with Taiwan on its own terms."

"With this in mind, both the People's Republic of China and the Republic of China are intensifying their efforts to garner the financial, technical and political support of overseas Chinese around the world," the report points out.

It advises Canada to "exercise vigilance" to ensure that the rights and freedoms of Chinese Canadians are not threatened, as the divide and rule tactics that characterize Beijing's united front work will form the basis of this campaign.

Authored by Ottawa-based analyst Holly Porteous, the paper was published by CSIS in its Winter, 1998 issue of "Commentary." The editor notes it reflects the personal view of the author and does not imply CSIS authentication or endorsement.

Porteous says Beijing has been applying the lessons it learned from Hong Kong to Taiwan. He quoted Taiwan officials as saying mainland China is employing united front techniques to strangle support for groups supporting Taiwan's independence and to create conditions for reunification.

His paper, entitled "Beijing's United Front Strategy in Hong Kong," explains that united front work is a combination of isolating the enemy and forging alliances. In the context of Hong Kong, it has sought to win over leaders from every sector of society, including academics, the media, youth and civil servants.

In the case of Taiwan, the paper says, nurturing economic ties has the added benefit of helping to create a constituency for reunification. Taiwan has been the second-largest foreign investor in mainland China, behind only Hong Kong, according to 1994 figures cited by the paper.
Overseas Chinese are a major target for Beijing's united front work, which has "pitted the PRC against the Republic of China in a fight for investment and political support," according to the paper.

It points out that mainland China has sometimes asked for more than just money from overseas Chinese. "Inducing Chinese abroad, by threat or by appeal to patriotism, to conduct economic and technical espionage, is also an aim of united front work," it notes.

With the first stage of the Hong Kong handover transition now complete, Beijing will focus on maintaining a steady state as political and economic relations with Hong Kong are solidified, and turn its attention to wooing Taiwan, it observes.
Eager to achieve a smooth transition in Hong Kong, Beijing has placed too great an emphasis on alliances with Kong Kong's corporate barons, political toadies and criminal elements, the paper says.

As a disenfranchised middle class demands greater representation of its interests, Beijing risks seeing its carefully crafted united front fall apart, it adds. It warns that if Beijing fails to address the alienation of the middle class, there is a "potential for political instability in the territory."

In conclusion, it says that although the successful implementation of the "one country, two systems" policy in Hong Kong is not likely to cause Taiwan to agree to reunification under mainland China's current conditions, its failure "will surely" scotch any chance of bringing Taiwan into the fold peacefully.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY IN HONDURAS INAUGURATES ROC CONSULATE-GENERAL
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, April 17 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to Honduras C.Y. Chang and Eroe Page, governor of Cortes Province, on Friday jointly cut a ribbon to formally inaugurate the Consulate-General of the Republic of China at San Pedro Sula, 250 km north of Tegucigalpa, capital of Honduras.

In an address during the ceremony, the ROC envoy said the establishment of the ROC Consulate-General at San Pedro Sula will further fortify the existing ties between the ROC and Honduras and strengthen mutual understanding between the people of both sides.
Chang also spoke highly of the designated consul-general, Eduardo Chen.
Chen, a career diplomat, has previously served at the ROC Embassy in Paraguay, the ROC Representative Office in Chile, and the ROC Embassy in Honduras.
More than 60 Chinese and Honduran dignitaries, members of the diplomatic corps, and overseas Chinese community leaders witnessed the ribbon-cutting ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: C.F. KOO DONATES US$10 MILLION TO US UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania on Saturday announced that it has received a US$10 million donation from Taiwan's business tycoon C.F. Koo and his sons, Chester and Leslie.

The gift will support planning and construction of a new 300,000 square foot academic facility which will accommodate a range of pioneering curricular, teaching, and technology initiatives at Wharton.

The Koo family has strong and long-standing ties to Wharton. Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, was awarded Wharton's Dean's Medal in 1991. In 1992, Koo, also a senior adviser to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, received an honorary doctoral law degree from the University of Pennsylvania in recognition of his work toward encouraging economic cooperation in the Pacific Basin. His sons also received their MBA degrees from Wharton.

The family has endowed two professorships at the school and has supported the development of Wharton's executive education program in Taiwan. They also offer three US$25,000 scholarships for Taiwan students wishing to attend Wharton.

The new building is being designed by the award-winning architectural firm of Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates PC, New York, which has received critical acclaim for its work with both educational and corporate clients including IBM, the University of Oxford, Stanford University and Goldman, Sachs & Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN INSURANCE FIRM WINS MAINLAND CHINA LICENSE

TEXT.P: Australia's Colonial Insurance, with the help of lobbying by former Prime Minister Paul Keating, has emerged the winner of a battle to obtain a license to sell life insurance in the huge mainland China market, beating rival company National Mutual Insurance.

The People's Bank of China on Friday advised Colonial's Beijing representative that the company, 80 percent Australian-owned, had won the license, according to a report by The Australian, a mass-circulation daily, on Saturday.

National Mutual failed to win a license, despite intense lobbying by former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, and the daily quoted insiders as saying that the reason was due to Hawke's stance following the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre in mainland China.

Hawke condemned Beijing for the atrocity and granted temporary residence to more than 50,000 Chinese studying in Australia in 1989. Most of these students eventually won permanent residence in Australia.
Under mainland China's rules, Colonial must find a local joint venture partner before it can start operations, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE SETS NEW RULES TO STOP SOFTWARE PIRACY

TEXT.P: The Singapore government has introduced new regulations aimed at stamping out software piracy at the source.

The new rules allow only manufacturers approved by the Singapore Economic Development Board to import mastering and replication equipment for CDs, CD-read only memory (CD-ROM), video CDs, digital video discs and DVD-ROMS.

Makers of optical discs -- including compact discs and video CDs used for computer software and movies -- are now compelled to obtain licenses to import the equipment needed to manufacture master copies and duplicate the discs.
One of the conditions for approval is an undertaking not to violate intellectual property rights.

Those who violate this condition will have their licenses to manufacture revoked, according to a joint statement issued Friday by the Ministry of Trade and Industry, the Trade Development Board (TDB) and the Economic Development Board.
Approved manufacturers also need TDB approval to transfer the equipment to another company, re-export it after use or dispose of it as scrap.
And those who import the equipment for re-export must first obtain approval from the TDB.
The TDB said its officers might conduct random checks to verify that the regulations are complied with.
Those who flout the regulations face fines of up to S$100,000 (US$62,344) or three times the value of the goods, whichever is greater, as well as a maximum two years in jail.
Subsequent violations will attract jail terms of up to three years and fines of up to S$200,000 or four times the value of the goods.
In a related move Friday, nine Singapore optical disc manufacturers signed a code of conduct in which they undertook to help in the fight against piracy by ensuring copyrights are protected.
Singapore police have recently cracked down on many vendors of illegal copies of copyrighted software.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRENADA MINISTER OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Grenada's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Legal Affairs and Local Government Raphael Fletcher will arrive in Taiwan on Saturday for a week-long visit, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Francisco Hwang, director of Central and South American Affairs at the MOFA, said that Fletcher first visited Taiwan in 1996, adding that the Caribbean minister has always been friendly to the island and has spoken up for the Republic of China in the General Assembly of the United Nations as well during a variety of occasions.

During his stay here, Fletcher will meet with President Lee Teng-hui, Premier Vincent Siew, National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien, Foreign Minister Jason Hu and Education Minister Lin Ching-Chiang.
To recognize his contribution to the promotion of bilateral relations between the ROC and Grenada, Fletcher will be decorated by Hu on Monday.
Fletcher is scheduled to depart Taiwan on April 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices surged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 106.45 points to finish at 8725.94.
The bourse opened at 8666.09 and experienced a high of 8725.94 and a low of 8543.47.
Gainers outnumbered losers 219 to 200, with 68 remaining unchanged. In all, 2.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$125.71 billion (US$3.81 billion).
Electrical engineering issues rose the most at 3.7 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.9 percent; foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent; and both cement issues and textile shares at 0.1 percent.
Financial shares dropped 0.6 percent, while both plastic and chemical shares and paper and pulp stocks edged down 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN CLAIMS SHE WAS VICTIM, NOT CONSPIRATOR

TEXT.P: A woman charged with having harbored the criminal trio responsible for the kidnap and murder of high school student Pai Hsiao-yen claimed innocence on Saturday, saying that she should be treated as a victim.

The defendant, surnamed You, admitted that between last June and August she had harbored Chen Chin-hsing, Lin Chun-sheng and Kao Tien-ming while the three were fugitives, but stressed that she had done this because her life had been threatened.

In a court hearing at the Panchiao District Court on Saturday, You said that Chen broke into her house and raped her last June. At that time, Chen and his two partners were Taiwan's most wanted men over their involvement in the kidnap and murder of TV celebrity Pai Ping-ping's 17-year-old daughter last April.

You, who made a living before her arrest by selling niches for cremains, said that Chen had given her about NT$900,000 (US$27,270), which she used to rent houses and buy a used car for them, as well to buy mausoleum niches. You didn't report the events to police until last August when Lin committed suicide during a gun battle with police.

Chen, however, who was present at the court hearing to explain what became of the NT$5 million he and the others got from the kidnap of Taipei County Councilor Tsai Ming-tang during their days on the run, said that he had given most of his NT$1.66 million share to You to "compensate" her.

Judges at the court said that they will investigate further the flow of the ransom money, including how much You had been given and what she had done with the money, to help them weigh her responsibility in having harbored the trio.

Chen, the only survivor of the notorious trio, surrendered to the police last November after a 24-hour standoff in suburban Taipei at the residence of a South African diplomat, where he had taken the diplomat and his family hostage. Lin and Kao committed suicide during separate shootouts with police in August and October, respectively.

Chen received sentences of unprecedented severity from the Panchiao District Court in January, including five death sentences and two life terms, in addition to 59 years and six months in prison. Chen has appealed his case to the Taiwan High Court, which held its first hearing on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE PROBING MASTERMIND OF INTEL CHIP COUNTERFEITING RING

TEXT.P: Five suspects involved in an Intel microchips counterfeiting ring were released on bail on Saturday after being questioned by prosecutors.

Prosecution authorities said the five men, who were arrested by police on Friday, were only "downstream processors" in the criminal counterfeiting operations. They have asked police authorities to continue investigation into the case in order to bring to justice "upperstream" masterminds.
Officials with the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said they suspect that the Intel chip counterfeiting was a cross-border crime, with top masterminds still staying offshore.
Lin Yung-yu, one of the suspects nabbed on Friday, told CIB agents that all finished bogus computer chips were airlifted to a Hong Kong businessman, surnamed Yen, through an express delivery company.

According to the five suspects' correspondence records, CIB investigators said they suspect there might be US-based businesspeople involved in the case, who might have given orders to Hong Kong-based Yen.

Initial investigations show that the suspects first purchased relatively low-end Intel Pentium II 233 central processing units (CPUs) and then removed their indentification marks and model numbers at an underground factory.

The products were then inscribed with new model numbers and identification using laser technology, describing them as the latest high-end Pentium 266 or Pentium II 300 CPUs, models which could fetch NT$12,000 (US$366) and NT$18,000 (US$549) apiece, respectively. Intel Inc. of the United States is the world's largest CPU maker.

Acting on tips, police raided five hideouts in northern Taiwan early Friday morning and managed to nab the five suspects as well as large quantities of forged Intel microchips and tools for making them. The seized goods were worth more than NT$100 million (US$3 million) in market value.

Industry sources said with upgrading of Taiwan's computer technology, similar counterfeiting or forgery cases are expected to continue increasing in the years ahead. They urged the government to revise the current regulations and impose harsher penalties on violators in order to deter such criminal activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF WILLING TO HELP HANDLE DAILY AIR CASE

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said on Saturday it is willing to assist in search for the bodies of two crew members aboard a Daily Air helicopter which crashed into the sea off Penghu on March 2.

The SEF, a semi-official body authorized to handle exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official ties across the Taiwan Strait, made the statement after a mainland fishing boat reportedly had salvaged the wreckage of the crashed Daily Air chopper and the remains of its crew members.

The SEF once faxed a message to its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), on March 19, asking it to help search for the wreckage and the pilots' bodies.
If necessary, SEF officials said they will contact the ARATS again for its assistance in reclamation of the pilots' remains.

The body of the chopper's pilot Liu Han-chieh and parts of the plane wreckage were already salvaged, but the remains of co-pilot Lin Ming-lai and cockpit captain Chiang Ching-chuan as well as the chopper's "black box" have not been discovered.

Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen was quoted by the United Evening News as having confirmed that a maritime police squadron stationed in Penghu did receive a phone call Friday night from a mainland fisherman saying his fishing vessel, while operating in the open near Penghu, had discovered the wreckage of the Daily Air chopper and the remains of its two crew members.

However, Huang added that Penghu maritime police have so far not seen any mainland fishing boat in waters near Penghu, an island group off the southwestern Taiwan coast. "So we still cannot confirm what the mainland fisherman had claimed in his Friday's phone call," Huang said, adding that police would not get involved in negotiations between the mainland fisherman and Taipei-based Daily Air Corp. over the issue. Nevertheless, Huang said, police will probe whether the mainland fisherman has really discovered the wreckage or the pilots' bodies.
The mainland fisherman, identified only by his family name Chang, reportedly has demanded that Daily Air pay him US$50,000 in cash in exchange for the wreckage and the crewmen's bodies.
A daily Air spokesman said the company would give payment only if the mainland fisherman has reclaimed the chopper's "black box" or the crewmen's remains.

The spokesman said the company has contacted the mainland fisherman. "The mainland fisherman didn't clearly said he had discovered bodies of the two crew members. We suspect he might have only salvage some pieces of the plane wreckage," the spokesman said.

He further said post-crash investigations have almost been finalized. "We currently only need the black box to support our judgements on the cause of the crash," the spokesman said. The black box refers to a flight information recorder and a cockpit voice recorder. The device can help understand the situation of the aircraft as well as pilot operations before a flight accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: YANGTZE RIVER STURGEON SUCCESSFULLY BRED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Yangtze River sturgeon, a fish endangered in its native habitat in mainland China and valued for its tasty caviar, has been successfully bred at a fish farm in northern Taiwan.

Hsu Chieh-li, the owner of a fish farm in Wulai, a town to the south of Taipei known for its cool and sweet spring water from the mountains, announced recently that he has been able to breed the rare Yangtze River sturgeon, better-known as the Chunghua sturgeon, and that he had sold some of the largest ones, weighing about 35 kilograms apiece, for some NT$200,000 (US$6,000) per head.

Hsu, who also raises rainbow trout, a freshwater delicacy, said he imported some 200 very young Chunghua sturgeon from the United States four years ago in an effort to raise the endangered but highly sought-after species.
Since most of the 5-centimeter baby fish are now 130 cm long and could sell for about NT$200,000 apiece, he is poised to reel in a fortune in sales.

Hsu said he expects to find out whether the sturgeon in his farm will end up caviar producers or not in about two years. Mainland Chinese claim that Chunghua sturgeon produce caviar and isinglass superior to those of fish from the Black Sea, he noted, adding that if he finds this is true of his fish, he will start another business as a caviar seller.
The Yangtze River sturgeon, technically a freshwater shark, is a large, ganoid relic freshwater fish belonging to the family Acipenseridae of the Northern Hemisphere.

Sturgeon caviar is considered one of the world's best. The globe contains only seven species of sturgeon -- with the Chunghua sturgeon, native to the Yangtze River, and Shih's sturgeon, found in the Amur River on the border between Russia and mainland China, being the two most treasured.
The Chunghua sturgeon, which can grow up to 6.2 meters long, is facing the threat of extinction in the wild due to the development of the Three Gorges Dam on the Yangtze River.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPANY MAKES IMPRESSIVE GAINS IN AUSTRIA

TEXT.P: A phthalic anhydride (PA) production plant in Austria that was near bankruptcy when it was taken over by Taiwan's Dahin Group three years ago has become a profitable business, providing encouragement for more Taiwan firms to invest in Europe's manufacturing sector.
The Dahin Group purchased Atmosa Petrochemie GmbH in Schwechat, Austria, in April 1995, the first time a Taiwan petrochemical firm had made an acquisition in a member state of the European Community.

Although Taiwan firms were already active in Europe at that time, most of them were engaged in marketing rather than production. The acquisition also made Dahin the first Taiwan company to invest in manufacturing in Austria.

The Austrian investment project was thus a brave step for Dahin, a listed company with an accumulated capital investment amounting to NT$1.6 billion (US$48.5 million). Since its establishment, Dahin has expanded its market from Taiwan to mainland China, Japan, Europe and the United States.

Dahin purchased Atmosa's existing PA production facilities at the Schwechat petrochemical park near Vienna after a brief but intense evaluation in the spring of 1995. The production facilities had been closed for two years after long years of operating at a deficit.
Since the purchase, the plant has been revitalized and made into a profitable business. Within two years, the annual production capacity was boosted from 38,000 tons to 50,000 tons.

A Dahin executive disclosed that the US$20 million that the company spent to acquire the plant was only about one-fourth of the amount that would have been needed to establish a new plant of the same capacity, adding that the purchase was a good business decision.

While the plant's performance has come to be praised by Austria's Economics Ministry, Dahin has responded by expressing its satisfaction with the investment climate in Austria. Although the cost of labor is much higher in Austria than in Asia, the country has a number of advantages, including high worker productivity and low interest rates, the executive said.
One reason Dahin made the investment in Austria is the stable demand for PA in the international market.

In 1996, about 45 percent of Atmosa's production was shipped back to Asia. Last year, the company's share of markets in Europe -- specifically in Italy, France, Germany and Eastern Europe -- showed considerable growth.

Businesses in Eastern and Southeastern Europe have shown great interest in entering cooperative agreements with Dahin, with some companies already having made contacts toward this end. If everything proceeds smoothly in Dahin's discussions with firms in Slovenia, the group's next European project may be realized there, the executive said.
Dahin's main production facilities are now located in Taiwan, mainland China, Thailand and Indonesia, but Atmosa's success has given the petrochemical group courage to branch out beyond Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA FUNDING 3 DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS IN M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Canada on Friday announced support for three projects in mainland China that will help reduce poverty in rural regions, heighten women's awareness of their rights and train telecommunications engineers.
Dianne Marleau, Canada's minister for international cooperation, made the announcement after signing cooperation agreements with the government of mainland China during a visit to Beijing.

"Poverty reduction requires a comprehensive approach. That is why we propose projects that consider the many aspects of poverty," Marleau said. Canada is offering greater access to basic health care services and increasing food production, hoping this will improve the living conditions of the poor in rural mainland China.
Canada estimates that 270 million mainland Chinese live on less than US$1 a day. "Most live in isolated, rural regions ... like Ningxia, Gansu, Shanxi and Guizhou," a government release said.

The Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA), operating under Marleau's department, will provide up to C$5.7 million (US$4.07 million) in funds for the five-year project. Canada's Mennonite Central Committee (MCC), one of the project partner's, will contribute another C$900,000.

The second project, designed to make women aware of their rights, will be promoted through training programs and a public information campaign. CIDA will contribute up to C$5 million to the Association of Canadian Community Colleges, which will manage this five-year project.

The third initiative supports the development of a telecommunications network through the mainland Chinese Ministry of Posts and Telecommunication. Newbridge Networks Corp. and the Advanced Engineering Training Institute of Carleton University, both in Ottawa, will train mainland Chinese engineers in the technology of developing digital networks. These engineers, in turn, will be qualified to train others.
CIDA's contribution to the initiative of up to C$1.2 million in funds is matched by a C$1.1 million contribution by Newbridge Networks Corp. and Carleton University for the three-year project.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONORAIL PLANNED FOR JFK AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Concluding a 14-month study, the New York/New Jersey Port Authority on Thursday approved plans to build a US$1.2 billion monorail to link JFK International Airport with the A train and the Long Island Railroad (LIRR).

Officials said that if opposition from city officials and airlines is overcome, they expect a circular rail route connecting the nine terminals at JFK to be completed by 2002, along with the extension to the Howard Beach station of the A line.
Meanwhile, the hookup with the LIRR's Jamaica station should be completed by 2003.

The US$1.2 billion project will be funded through two sources: US$930 million from the US$3 surcharge for each departing plane passenger and US$300 million from the Port Authority's capital budget, officials said.
The Board of Commissioners officially OK'd the plan, awarding the US$930 million design and construction portion of the project to Perini Corp., Bombardier Transit Corp. and Shanska USA.
But New York City Mayor Giuliani's office blasted the announcement.

"This project cannot begin until a final agreement is reached with the city, " said Anthony Coles, Giuliani's senior adviser. "The mayor must be certain that the project will be in the best interest of all New Yorkers, not just the Port Authorities," he said, adding that "at present, a final agreement has not been reached and, by making this announcement prematurely, the Port Authority, once again, is placing its own priorities over the priorities of New York City."

The Washington-based Air Transportation Association also opposes the plan and has filed a suit attempting to block use of the passenger surcharge, arguing the money can't be used for non-aviation purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTARCTIC MELTDOWN ESCALATES AT TERRIFYING PACE, SCIENTISTS SAY

TEXT.P: The collapse of the largest ice shelf group on the Antarctic Peninsula is escalating at a terrifying pace, and scientists have confirmed the loss of another 200-square kilometer mass of ice in the region.

The scientists said about two-thirds of the 12,000-square km Larsen Ice Shelves now threaten to break off, and that the latest loss may be "the beginning of the end" for these shelves, according to a report Saturday in the mass circulation newspaper The Australian.

Scientists are yet to decide whether to blame humans or a natural fluctuation for the rapid warming of the region's climate that has resulted in mounting losses of ice shelves in recent years from the Larsen group, which runs much of the length of the peninsula's east coast and west coast ice shelves, the daily reported.
Antarctica annually sheds millions of tons of ice from shelves that grind down from the continental ice cap to float on the ocean then break up to form huge icebergs, the daily said.
The British Antarctic Survey has linked an unusual rise in air temperature to the alarming shelf losses.
Led by Dr. David Vaughan, the survey scientists pinpointed a zero-degree temperature gradient over the peninsula each January as the limit of viability for ice shelves.
But they found this line had moved south over the past 50 years as the climate of the peninsula warmed by 2.5 degrees Celsius -- several times the global average.

Scientists said over the past two years, ice shelf break-offs have escalated. Last year, Professor Helmut Rott of the University of Innsbruck calculated the total loss of the Larsen group ice shelves at 5,600 square km.
In the latest finding, researchers from the University of Colorado analyzed satellite images taken over the past two months and pinpointed the break-off of a chunk 40 km long and five km wide.
"This may be the beginning of the end for the Larsen Ice Shelf," said Ted Scambos, one of the researchers.

He said there is not enough evidence to find a "smoking gun" yet. But he warned that "ice shelves appear to be good bellwethers for climate change since they respond to change within decades, not centuries."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PM: WATERFRONT DISPUTE DIVIDING NATION

TEXT.P: Australia's Prime Minister John Howard has admitted the worsening waterfront dispute is dividing the nation, while Patrick Stevedores Ltd., one of the two leading stevedoring firms at the center of the showdown, has threatened to shut down five regional port operations if the Federal Court forces it to reinstate its fired union workers.
Howard said Friday that the waterfront dispute is dividing Australia because "it is part and parcel of solving the challenge to our economic future."
He told a Melbourne radio station that "this idea -- 'well, all right, we will never do anything through fear of upsetting somebody'" is a recipe for "seeing the country go down the drain."
Howard came under fire after police in Melbourne, Sydney and other port cities detained hundreds of unionist protesters.
He was later confronted by 450 demonstrators who threw eggs, apples and tomatoes when he arrived at a luncheon in Melbourne Friday.

In the meantime, Patrick issued a warning Friday after the company suffered a severe blow in the British High Court, which lifted a temporary injunction restraining the International Transport Workers Federation (ITF) from pressuring shipping companies to boycott Patrick's non-union facilities in Australia.

The ITF is one of the international labor union groups behind the support of the Maritime Union of Australia, which is now using its thousands of members to block Patrick's operations in Melbourne, Sydney, Perth, Brisbane, Newcastle, Cairns and other ports.
Patrick Stevedores, which fired all 1,400 of its full-time union workers and 600 part-time workers last week, threatened to shut down its operations at several ports throughout Australia.

The sacking triggered a national blockade of Patrick's operations in major Australian ports, disrupting cargo movement at the ports and delaying shipments of both exported and imported cargoes between Australia and its trading partners abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLAIMED WRECKAGE OF CRASHED HELICOPTER TO BE SCRUTINIZED

TEXT.P: Authorities here will determine late Sunday whether a mainland Chinese fishing ship has in fact retrieved the wreckage and the remains of crewmen from a Taiwan helicopter which crashed into the sea last month.
The mainland fishing boat, under escort by Taiwan marine police, is moving slowly toward Makung Harbor at the offshore island of Penghu.

Officials of Daily Air Corp., whose helicopter crashed into the sea off Makung as it approached a drilling platform, reportedly have boarded the mainland ship and are preparing to scrutinize the wreckage.

The officials said that as fishing nets are tightly wrapped around what is claimed to be the wreckage of the helicopter, it will take time to untangle them and determine what the fishermen have actually found.

The fishing boat reported on Friday that it had retrieved the wreckage and remains of the crew from the crashed helicopter. The mainland fishermen contacted Taiwan marine police stationed in Penghu and asked Daily Air to pay US$50,000 to get them back. As the fishing boat towed the wreckage, it incurred some damage to its hull and began taking on water.
The Taiwan marine police vessel met up with the damaged fishing boat on Saturday and escorted it toward Makung.
Daily Air officials said they would have to view the wreckage to see if it contained the bodies of two missing crewmen and the aircraft's black box before discussing a monetary settlement.

The Bell-412 helicopter, carrying pilot Liu Han-chieh, co-pilot Lin Ming-lai and engineer Chiang Ching-chuan, crashed into the sea when it approached a drilling platform off Makung, Penghu, on March 2.

Pilot Liu's body was retrieved shortly after the incident, but extensive search operations to find the remaining bodies and the black box containing cockpit voice recordings and flight data have been fruitless.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONALS IN MOSCOW WARNED ABOUT PERSONAL SAFETY
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, April 19 (CNA) (By H.K. Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in Moscow has asked Taiwan businessmen and students here to be on guard for their personal safety after reports said xenophobic skinheads in Moscow plan to engage in a new wave of racially motivated attacks.

The Representative Office in Moscow for the Taipei-Moscow Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, the de facto ROC embassy in Russia, had sent urgent bulletins to Taiwan students and businessmen in the wake of a threat by skinhead gangs saying they would target Asian students for beatings on the birthdays of Adolf Hitler and Vladimir I. Lenin on April 21 and 22, respectively.
This is the first time that the Moscow office has issued an urgent warning instructing Taiwan people to take precautions for their personal safety since it was inaugurated in 1993.

The skinhead gangs initiated a wave of violence targeting Asians living in Moscow about a year ago. Cases of assaults against students from mainland China, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan have been reported.

Although some skinheads have been jailed for the attacks, they usually spend only a short time behind bars, and in many instances have sought revenge of those persons who reported them to the authorities.
It is known that embassies and representative offices of other Asian nations here have all issued similar warnings to their nationals.
One Taiwan student, surnamed Lin, was attacked by skinheads in front of a prestigious foreign language academy in mid-March, arousing serious concern among the overseas Chinese community here.
Taipei Representative James Chang recently invited the Moscow police chief to discuss ways to stem the skinhead violence with representatives of Taiwan businessmen and students.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE FINANCE MINISTER ATTENDS APEC MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang is currently attending a meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum which began here on Saturday.

During the two-day vice ministerial-level meeting sponsored by Canada at its embassy in Washington, D.C., Yen and his counterparts will discuss the financial situation in Asia and study the feasibility of setting up a financial monitoring system among APEC countries.
Yen, who arrived here on Friday, has already visited the US delegation at the Treasury Department to exchange opinions on relevant issues.
He may raise an aid proposal initiative at an appropriate time during the course of the meeting if discussion moves in that direction.

Shea Jia-dong, visiting deputy governor of the ROC Central Bank of China, said Wednesday during a meeting with US Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers that Taiwan is interested in seeking US support to help crisis-hit Asian countries issue US dollar-denominated bonds for sale in APEC countries under the organization's framework.

APEC groups Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, mainland China, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL'S A BLOW TO PAULA AND MONICA

TEXT.P: By a 4-to-1 ratio, Americans have unfavorable opinions of Paula Jones and Monica Lewinsky, a Fox News/Opinion Dynamics poll found.
The nationwide survey of 902 registered voters also showed continuing high marks for President Bill Clinton and low marks for independent counsel Kenneth Starr.
The poll found 63 percent have a generally unfavorable opinion of Jones, who sued Clinton for sexual harassment -- while only 13 percent viewed her favorably.
Sixty percent of those questioned have an unfavorable opinion of Lewinsky, the former White House intern at the heart of the Sexgate scandal, compared with 15 percent who regard her favorably.
The survey also showed that 49 percent disapprove of the job Starr is doing and 29 percent approve.
But 68 percent approve of the performance of Clinton, while 26 percent disapprove.

However, Catharine MacKinnon, a University of Chicago law professor and one of the nation's top feminist law scholars, said on the Cable News Network on Friday a judge in Arkansas was "wrong" to toss out Paula Jones's case against Clinton and urged the appeals court to reinstate it.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF OVERSEAS CHINESE TOPS 33 MILLION

TEXT.P: The number of overseas Chinese stood at 33.24 million at the end of 1997, statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) show.

The latest OCAC census on Chinese people residing abroad points out that 26.91 million ethnic Chinese, or 81 percent of the total, live in Asia, followed by America with 4.73 million and Europe with 940,000. About 540,000 overseas Chinese reside in Oceania and 120,000 live in Africa.

Oceania posted the largest annual increase in Chinese population in 1997 at 7.54 percent, while Europe and America charted growth of 4.33 percent and 4.15 percent, respectively, the census indicates. Africa saw a rise of 3.69 percent in Chinese population last year, while Asia registered the slightest increase among regions.

According to the OCAC's new definitions, overseas Chinese include Republic of China nationals residing abroad and ethnic Chinese naturalized into other nationalities. Chinese people living in Hong Kong are no longer considered overseas Chinese.

Meanwhile, a survey commissioned by the OCAC shows that most Taiwan emigrates in the United States chose to settle there because of considerations of "personal career development" and "children's education." "Searching for a good living environment" and "post-graduation stay" are also cited, while "a deteriorating public security" at home was also listed by a small percentage of the respondents.

The OCAC explained that it chose US-based Taiwan emigrates for the survey because a large percent of overseas Chinese reside in America and the Chinese population there is steadily increasing. Results of the poll will be referred to the ROC government for future policymaking in relevant fields, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GORE MAKES DONATION TO CHARITY

TEXT.P: Republicans on Friday ridiculed Vice President Al Gore as "Vice President Scrooge" for donating just US$353 to charity last year on his salary of US$197,699.

"Who pays for Gore's charities? You do!" declared a flier from the Republican National Committee claiming the vice president is pushing US$125 billion in new government spending -- but won't ante up for charity himself.

In a further embarrassment to Gore, the New York Post reported Saturday that video has surfaced showing an impassioned vice president as he urged a volunteerism summit last spring saying, "We're going to pitch in as individual Americans and do what we can."

And late-night comics jumped into the act as Jay Leno ridiculed Gore's charity contributions as amounting to 96 US cents a day, adding that Gore is replacing the Make a Wish Foundation with a new one: "Keep Dreaming."

Political analysts say the flap raises anew the question of whether Gore has a political tin ear since he knew his returns would become public -- and gave about half the $695 given by an average family. The average in the $200,000-a-year bracket is $8,000.

President Bill Clinton and wife Hillary -- whose income totaled $569,511 -- gave $270,725 to charity last year, most of it royalties from Mrs. Clinton's book, but $8,000 of it came from the president's salary.
Like Clinton, Gore lives in a taxpayer-funded mansion, and his household staff is provided by tax money.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLAIR ARRIVES IN SAUDI ARABIA

TEXT.P: British Prime Minister Tony Blair arrived in Jeddah on Saturday for a two-day official visit to Saudi Arabia. He was welcomed by the Crown Prince Abdullah in the Jeddah International airport.
Blair was coming from Egypt and it is his first visit to Saudi Arabia since he won the general election in the United Kingdom last May.
During his stay, Blair will talk with King Fahd and Crown Prince Abdullah on bilateral relations, the situation in the Persian Gulf and the Middle East peace process.

While in Cairo, Blair said that the European Union would do its best to revive the deadlocked negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians and that he hoped its effort would be met constructively.
Saudi Arabia expects that Europe, particularly Britain, will play a more active role in pushing forward the Middle East peace process.
Blair is expected to leave for Jordan on Sunday and to Israel and the West Bank afterward.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISGIVINGS CITED ON ANNIVERSARY OF CROSS-STRAIT TRANSSHIPMENT OPENING

TEXT.P: On the first anniversary of the opening of offshore transshipment services between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, shipping companies on Sunday expressed misgivings about prospects for the trade.
Statistics have shown a dramatic decrease of 37 percent in the volume of transshipped goods in the first quarter of this year from the previous one.

Marine sources said that some companies which applied to operate offshore transshipment services have never followed up. Only Yangming Marine Transport Corp. and Uniglory Marine Corp., which have profitable transoceanic shipping routes to support them, are still holding on.

The mainland Chinese freighter Sheng Da arrived at the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung on April 19, 1997, after departing from the mainland port of Xiamen, becoming the first ship to ply the once-prohibited route.

Sources said shipping companies were upbeat then, thinking that the Sheng Da's voyage had opened a new era in indirect shipping between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and that mainland China would open more ports to engage in cross-strait indirect shipping following the major breakthrough.
But those expectations evaporated after mainland authorities explicitly stated that no more ports besides the one at Xiamen and another at Fuzhou would be opened.

Uniglory Marine officials said the dramatic drop in business in the first quarter was closely linked with the financial crisis in Southeast Asia. With purchasing power in the region declining, cargo bound for Southeast Asia from Fuzhou and Xiamen via Kaohsiung also plunged.
They said the company had to make up for losses arising thereof by relying heavily on shipments to and from the United States and Europe.

Yangming officials said that its volume of transshipped cargo managed to see growth in the first quarter. But as the volume of cargo from the mainland to other places is far greater than that from Kaohsiung to the mainland, the company often has a large number of empty containers going to Xiamen, causing operational costs to swell.
To cut costs, Yangming is planning to build small container ships to handle regional shipping, they said.

The Kaohsiung Port Authority had estimated that transshipped cargo volumes at Kaohsiung Harbor in 1998 would increase sharply from the 120,000 TEUs recorded last year. But judging from the fact that the first quarter saw only 20,000 TEUs of transshipped goods, they have adjusted that estimate downward.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOOK PURCHASES BY TAIWAN PEOPLE RANKS 16TH IN WORLD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D.C., April 18 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan people are the world's 16th most prolific purchasers of books, according to statistics by the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).
The Washington Post, quoting the statistics released by the UNESCO, reported on Saturday that spending on books by various nations provides a glimpse into the cultural quality of different societies.
According to the statistics from 1995, people in Norway spend an average of US$137 on book purchases annually, followed by Germans at US$122 and Belgians at US$117.
Rounding out the top 10 by country were Switzerland (US$114), Austria (US$101), the United States (US$97), Singapore (US$89), Japan (US$84), and both Denmark and New Zealand (US$81).
The Netherlands was 11th with US$78, followed by Spain (US$76), Australia (US$66), and the United Kingdom and South Korea (US$63).
The figures showed that Taiwan people spent an average of US$31 annually for book purchases, standing at 16th in the world, trailing only Singapore, Japan and South Korea among Asians.
People in mainland China on average spend only US$2 dollars for buying books in a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO HEAD DOESN'T WANT MAINLAND CHINESE CURRENCY DEVALUATION

TEXT.P: World Trade Organization (WTO) Director-General Renato Ruggiero hopes mainland China will not devalue its currency while Asia is going through a wrenching adjustment to its financial crisis.

"We hope China will keep the position it has stated that it will not devalue its currency and it will keep its market open," Ruggiero was quoted in the WTO report as saying upon arriving at the interim committee meeting of the International Monetary Fund.

Ruggiero said faster mainland Chinese structural reforms could increase its chances of joining the WTO, although there is no quid pro quo between this and Beijing's currency policy, according to the WTO report.
"A speeded restructuring of its economy this year will certainly facilitate the entry of China to the WTO," he was quoted as saying. "We wish it would be as fast as possible."
"The accession to the WTO is in relation to the capacity of China to commit to the obligations of the WTO," Ruggiero said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRECKAGE FROM CRASHED HELICOPTER IDENTIFIED AS SUPPORT RUNNER

TEXT.P: A piece of wreckage salvaged by a mainland fishing ship has been identified as the support runner of a crashed helicopter belonging to Daily Air Corp., company officials said on Sunday.
The officials said that no sign of either the remains of two missing crewmen or the black box, the flight data and cockpit voice recorder, was found along with the wreckage.

Accordingly, the officials said, no cash reward will be offered to the owners of the fishing vessel which found the piece of wreckage. However, Daily Air will reportedly extend compensation for a fishing net which was damaged in the salvage effort.

Fishermen aboard the mainland boat, who contacted Taiwan marine police stationed on the offshore island of Penghu on Friday, said they had salvaged the wreckage of the crashed chopper and possibly the bodies of two missing crewmen. They had demanded a reward of US$50,000 from Daily Air.
The mainland vessel, which began to take on water after incurring some damage in recovering the support runner, was found by marine police on Saturday and escorted back to Makung on Sunday.
The boat is no longer in danger of sinking, but will remain in Makung for repairs.
The Bell-412 helicopter, carrying pilot Liu Han-chieh, co-pilot Lin Ming-lai and engineer Chiang Ching-chuan, crashed off Makung on March 2.
Only the body of pilot Liu was found. The other two men and the aircraft's black box are still missing despite extensive search efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRAIT PEACEFUL UNIFICATION ASSOCIATION SET UP

TEXT.P: The Strait Peaceful Unification Association, a civic organization aiming at promoting exchange, reciprocity and peaceful unification across the Taiwan Strait, was formally inaugurated in Taipei on Sunday.
The opening ceremony was presided over by Liang Su-yung, president of the association.

On hand to extend their congratulations were Wang Tso-yung, president of Control Yuan; former Premier Hau Pei-tsun; Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC); former OCAC Chairman Tseng Kwang-shun; Chen Li-fu, former senior advisor to the president; and Hsu Li-nung, former national policy advisor to the president, among others.
Liang explained at the meeting that his organization, based on the desire for peace, not war, will promote the peaceful unification of China under the following three principles:
-- Marching toward peaceful unification under the principle of a single China;
-- No independence for Taiwan, and no resort to force by the mainland.
He said the association will dedicate itself to the following tasks:
-- Promoting peaceful interaction and positive interchange between people on both sides of the strait.
-- Protecting the rights and interests of Taiwan businessmen, and enhancing cross-strait economic relations by advocating the immediate opening of trade, navigation and postal communications.
-- Engaging in various activities for peaceful cross-strait unification and a renaissance of Chinese culture.
-- Ending cross-strait hostilities and signing a peace treaty.
In his speech, Wang said it is easier for the two sides of the strait to make peace than to go to war. He stressed Chinese should not fight Chinese.

Former Premier Hau stressed in the ceremony that promoting cross-strait democratic unification should be the common mission of the entire Chinese people. He added that the principle of a single Chinese nation has been put forth in the Guidelines for National Unification.

According to Lee Huan, senior advisor to the president, the biggest barrier to cross-strait unification is the one-party dictatorship in Communist China. He said the past atrocities on the mainland, such as the reign of terror by the Red Guards and other political and social campaigns, were the results of errors made by a handful of leaders in the Chinese Communist Party.
Chen Li-fu, honorary president of the association, said he believes the unification of China should be accomplished on the basis of a shared Chinese culture between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND MISSION DUE TO SELL WATER SUPPLY PLAN

TEXT.P: A nine-member delegation of mainland Chinese officials arrived in Taipei on Sunday to attend a seminar on planning and development of water resources across the Taiwan Strait.
The delegation was led by Chen Guoliang, a section chief of the water supply and planning task force of Fujian Province, which lies opposite Taiwan.

A pro-Beijing newspaper based in Hong Kong pointed out that mainland China attaches much importance to the seminar and that the visiting delegation includes officials from the central government's ministries of finance and water resources, and the State Planning Commission.

Mainland China's Water Resources Minister Niu Maosheng was quoted by the newspaper as saying that cross-strait joint efforts in planning and developing water resources are of great significance to both Taiwan and mainland China, as how to conserve and use water resources is one of the most important agenda for all countries in the face of the new millennium.
Niu was reported as hailing the concerted efforts, especially between Taiwan and Fujian, as "practical" because of the close links in climatic and hydraulic patterns between the two sides.

According to the report, water resources authorities with Fujian Province carried out a test on April 9, involving the use of large rubber bags to transport fresh water from Weitou Bay outside Jinjiang City to a mock destination -- the Taiwan-controlled Kinmen Island.

The result showed that the vessel dragging large rubber bags containing more than 200 tons of fresh water could move as far as 9.2 nautical miles, while the actual distance between Kinmen and Weitou is only 5.6 nautical miles, the report said. It added that the successful test proved Fujian has the ability to provide water to Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands before construction of underground channels for transporting water between the two sides is completed.
Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, which lay closer to Fujian Province, have been hard hit by a drought in recent years.
Taiwan and the mainland jointly held a seminar in July 1995 in Fuzhou, the capital city of Fujian Province, to find ways of fighting drought and floods.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGIONAL CRISIS DRAWS SINGAPORE, MALAYSIA CLOSER

TEXT.P: The regional economic crisis has drawn Malaysia and Singapore closer by making clear the need for them to work together and the gains from doing so, the prime ministers of both countries said Saturday.

Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad expressed the similar views in their speeches at the official opening ceremony of the Second Link, a new crossing bridge between Singapore and Malaysia.

Both leaders cited the joint opening of the 1.9-km crossing, which links Tanjung Kupang in Johor, Malaysia, and Tuas in Singapore, as an "important milestone" in bilateral ties and pledged to boost bilateral cooperation further.
Goh said that opening the new S$1.5-billion bridge during the current period of economic turbulence showed that "cooperation is the way to go."
The construction of the Second Link was "testimony to the achievements that we can attain by putting our hearts and minds together," he said.

A bilateral commitment to cooperate was all the more important in these difficult times, he said, noting that the financial turbulence that had hit the region had caused currencies to depreciate, weakened economies, cut asset values sharply, and eroded confidence in several economies.

"This shared pain shows how inter-linked our destiny is. But the regional crisis has also made us work even closer together. As a result, we will emerge stronger from our tribulations... As close neighbors with historical ties, Singapore and Malaysia have much in common, and much to gain from working together. Troubled economic times have made this clearer," Goh said.
He declared the new bridge a "symbol of a new phase in the Malaysia-Singapore relationship."

Expressing a similar view in his speech, Mahathir said he was very heartened that the crisis had brought the two sides closer in trying to resolve their problems, "despite the recent hiccup" in bilateral ties.
He was referring to the souring of ties following a remark by Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew about crime in Johor last March.

Mahathir said: "Frequent consultations and discussions have made us more aware of the sensitivities and the problems that we face. Of more importance is the fact that it had made us more aware of the strengths that both possess and how these can be harnessed for the benefit of our peoples."

"I wish to reiterate here that Malaysia values its links with Singapore and has always regarded Singapore and Singaporeans as friends," he said. Later, the two leaders signed their names on a gold plaque and cut a ribbon to declare the crossing officially open.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC IMPORTS FROM HUNGARY UP CONSIDERABLY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's imports from Hungary in 1997 grew by 232 percent over the 1996 level, indicating the efforts of the ROC to balance two-way trade with that East European country, ROC Representative to Hungary Rock Leng said Sunday.

In 1997, two-way trade between the ROC and Hungary amounted to US$196.4 million, up 56.2 percent from 1996 levels. The ROC's imports from Hungary totaled US$61.1 million against its exports amounting to US$135.3 million. The ROC continued to enjoy a favorable balance.

Leng pointed out that relations with the European Union and neighboring countries have the priority of Hungary's external relations policy. However, the Hungarian government has initiated some effort in developing markets in Asia in recent years, witnessing the prosperity in the Asian Pacific region.
Hungary is the ROC's second largest trade partner in East Europe, next only to Poland. In 1997, ROC-Hungary trade accounted for one-fifth of the ROC's trade with Eastern Europe.

In 1990, the Taipei Representative Office in Budapest was set up, marking the first representative office of the ROC in the formerly socialist countries in Eastern Europe. The office has coordinated with Hungarian economic and trade authorities to reduce trade barriers between the two countries by signing agreements regarding product inspection certification and cooperation in regulating customs tariffs.

Since the early 1990s, many Taiwan businessmen have visited Hungary; however, not many have set up permanent offices there. Among the less than 20 Taiwanese firms, mostly in Budapest, the majority are engaged in export-import of consumer goods and sales of computers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABU DHABI MISSION ARRIVES FOR TRADE TALKS

TEXT.P: A seven-member trade mission from Abu Dhabi arrived in Taipei on Sunday to seek cooperation opportunities with Taiwan business enterprises.
A business opportunities discussion forum, arranged by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center from 2:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m. on Monday.
A CETRA spokesman said that members of the Abu Dhabi mission, organized by the Abu Dhabi Chamber of Commerce and Industry, are engaging in such fields as investment, chemical and trade services.
They are interested in such Taiwan industries as electronics, electric circuit plating, foodstuff processing, petroleum, gas, and petrochemical raw materials.

The spokesman said the Abu Dhabi mission, with its rich capital, is seeking technological transfer through joint ventures with Taiwan enterprises to develop commerce and industries in Abu Dhabi, the United Arab Emirates and the Persian Gulf area.
The mission also hopes to enhance cooperation with Taiwan in sea transportation services.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERT SOLICITED TO HELP TRACE SEIZED DRUGS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has recently invited an expert from the United States to speak on techniques by which to trace the sources of seized drugs, officials said on Monday.

Drug Enforcement Center (DEC) officials under the MOJ's Investigation Bureau said the ministry had solicited the help of Robert Bianchi, director of the Special Testing and Research Laboratory of the US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), to help build a data bank on drug-related information.
DEC officials said the data bank will help law enforcement officials to trace the sources of drugs seized from traffickers and to identify overseas accomplices and smuggling routes.

The officials noted that authorities in the United States and Europe have developed sophisticated techniques to detect the origins of illicit substances from the raw material stage and to identify the various methods used to process and transport them.

They said that the United States has been using these methods for over 25 years, noting that DEA has determined that a majority of illegal drugs coming into that country come from four major regions, namely Southeast Asia's Golden Triangle and areas of southern China, Turkey and Afghanistan in West Asia, Mexico and South America.
They noted that US anti-drug authorities have relied heavily on laboratory analysis to identify international drug rings operating behind drug traffickers around the United States.

The officials said the DRC is aware that many drugs circulating in Taiwan come from Thailand, Hong Kong and Vietnam, and that the main processing centers for the narcotics are located on the Chinese mainland and in the Golden Triangle. However, at present they are unclear about the origin of drugs coming from other regions.
