DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINESE PER CAPITA GNP LAGS FAR BEHIND TAIWAN'S
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D.C., April 19 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's per capita gross national product (GNP), averaging US$750 in 1996, was less than one-seventeenth that of Taiwan, which stood at US$12,838 in the same year, a report from the World Bank shows.

With the US$750 per capita GNP level, the mainland was listed among the world's 53 low-income economies, even though it was the seventh largest economy on the globe in 1996, with a total GNP of US$906.1 billion, according to the latest World Bank Atlas.
The per capita GNP figures, published in the World Bank Atlas every spring, are an important index revealing the individual wealth enjoyed by people in various nations.

According to the Atlas, mainland China's 1996 per capita GNP of US$750, represents an increase of US$130 from that of 1995. In comparison, Taiwan's per capita GNP amounted to US$12,838 in 1996, outpacing mainland China by a factor of 17.
Taiwan has been ranked as one of the world's high-income economies since 1991, when its per capita GNP hit US$9,636, according to the World Bank.
Mainland China became the world's seventh largest economic entity in 1993, behind the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain and Italy.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORD PLANS ASIA-PACIFIC PARTS SUPPLY CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Ford Motor Corp. of the United States plans to set up an Asia-Pacific distribution and resourcing center in Taiwan, the China Times reported on Monday.

Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), confirmed that the world's second largest automaker has such an investment plan, but added that several East Asian countries are also wooing Ford and its multibillion-dollar investment project.
Ford's Taiwan affiliate, Ford Lio Ho Motor Co., however, would not confirm the existence of the project, saying it has no comment on the China Times report at the moment.

According to the report, Ronald Goldsberry, a Ford vice chairman in charge of the service department, visited Taipei last week to explore the feasibility of establishing a resourcing and distribution center on the island.

During his visit, Goldsberry was said to have met with Schive to discuss technical details related to the proposed investment project. He reportedly also held wide-ranging talks with chief executive officers of Citibank and the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei to with a view to better understand the general market situation here.

The report further said Ford is scheduled to call a board meeting in the near future to make a final decision on the project. Thailand is said to have offered very attractive incentives aimed at luring Ford to set up its new regional resourcing and distribution center on its soil.

Schive said Ford's new investment project complies with the basic concepts of Taiwan's much-touted Asia-Pacific regional operations center development plan. "We therefore will do our utmost to talk Ford into choosing Taiwan as its new investment destination."

According to Ford's plan, it will pour at least NT$10 billion (US$303 million) for setting up an auto parts resourcing and distribution center at a suitable place in East Asia, with mainland China as its main service target.

If Ford ultimately decides to locate its resourcing center in Taiwan, it will use the island as its auto parts and components purchase, assembling and distribution center. Some components from the United States or Europe will also be assembled in Taiwan into large parts packages.
Meanwhile, if the project proceeds smoothly, Ford may upgrade the resourcing center into its Asia-Pacific auto maintenance and parts supply center.

CEPD sources said the Ford project is expected to help boost the development of the domestic auto parts center-satellite supply system and related service industries, such as merchandise distribution and shipping.

Although Ford's initial capital investment will be only about NT$10 billion, the sources said, the project is expected to bring about NT$50 billion to NT$100 billion in peripheral effects to Taiwan annually.

Taiwan's Taichung Harbor, Kaohsiung Harbor and Changpin coastal industrial zone are among the likely sites. As Germany's chemical giant Bayer was recently forced to abandon a long-planned investment project at Taichung Harbor because of strong opposition from the Taichung County Government, CEPD sources said Ford may exclude Taichung Harbor from its target list to avoid any unnecessary political interference.

CEPD officials said they are confident Taiwan can beat out Thailand in winning Ford's new investment project by virtue of its solid economic fundamentals, favorable geographical location, modern shipping and port facilities, a 500,000-unit domestic auto market and a robust auto parts industry.

Taiwan's auto parts production reached NT$150 billion (US$4.55 billion) in 1997, second only to Japan's in terms of both quality and scale, the officials said, adding that Taiwan's auto parts maker has another competitive edge: the ability to produce diverse types of parts in small quantity.

Taiwan's main disadvantage lies in uncertain relations across the Taiwan Strait, but the CEPD officials said they have assured Ford that ties with mainland China will improve rather than worsen in the years ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPE-BASED MAINLAND DEMOCRACY GROUPS WELCOME WANG DAN'S RELEASE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 19 (CNA) (By M.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese pro-democracy organizations based in Europe on Sunday issued a joint statement welcoming the release of Wang Dan, one of the most prominent dissidents in mainland China, earlier in the day.

The statement, co-issued by the Chinese Alliance for Democracy and the Alliance for a Democratic China, hailed Wang's character, farsighted vision and academic achievements. It also praised him as a role model and the most representative figure among the younger generation of the mainland Chinese democracy movement.

It lauded Wang's long-term efforts in advocating democracy on campus while studying in Beijing University, attributing that as a prelude to the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests, in which Wang played a key role in the student-led movement for greater democracy in the mainland.

The statement charged that Beijing's recent expulsion of dissidents into overseas exile is part of a plot to crush the pro-democracy movement in mainland China. It urged mainland democracy activists living abroad to cherish their past efforts and to unite together for a better future in the mainland.
Wei Jingsheng, another leading mainland Chinese dissident, was released on medical parole to the United States by Beijing last year.

Wang, 29, was arrested in July 1989 and sentenced to a four-year jail term following the military crackdown on June 4 of that year against the Tiananmen protesters. The assault resulted in heavy loss of life and scores of injuries to the unarmed student demonstrators. He was detained again in October 1996, and sentenced to 11 years in prison on a charge of "counterrevolutionary activity."
Wang was freed by Beijing on medical parole on Sunday, and was put on a direct flight for Detroit, where he is currently undergoing a series of medical checks at the Henry Ford Hospital.
Wang is said by his family to have suffered from chronic headaches, long-term inflammation of the throat and a possible brain tumor.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS HEAVYWEIGHTS ON WHIRLWIND LOBBYING TOUR

TEXT.P: P.K. Chiang, chairman of Taiwan's Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), flew to Manila on Monday morning to discuss a plan to provide guarantees for government bonds issued in economically battered Southeast Asian countries.
Chiang, Taiwan's top economic planner, was accompanied by Jeffrey Koo, a Taipei-based business magnate and chairman of the Financial Crisis Task Force of the APEC Business Advisory Council (ABAC).

Chiang and Koo will exchange views with officials from the Manila-based Asian Development Bank (ABD) to drum up support for a Taiwan-led initiative that would enable struggling Asian economies to issue the US dollar-denominated bonds for sale in member nations of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum. Funds raised by the issues would be used to repay short-term foreign debts or to finance major development projects.
The visit to ADB headquarters comes as a concrete move to implement four resolutions recently passed by the ABAC Financial Crisis Task Force, according to Koo.

One of the resolutions called on ADB members which have been less affected by the Asian financial turmoil, such as the United States, Hong Kong and Japan, to jointly provide guarantees for financially battered Asian countries in issuing government bonds to help revitalize their economies.

Other resolutions made by the ABAC task force included the founding of a regionwide financial forum, working out a multilateral formula for negotiating financial rescue packages, and devising methods to help hard-hit economies tide over the financial storm that has swept the region since July last year.

Both ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew recently proposed that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait co-sponsor meetings with Southeast Asian officials to discuss concerted efforts for halting the regional financial meltdown. Those proposals have touched off heated debates among politicians and economists at home and abroad.

Shea Jia-dong, deputy governor of the Central Bank of China, recently led an ROC mission to the United States to drum up support for Taiwan's initiative to have Asia's healthier economies underwrite government-bonds issued in cash-strapped neighboring countries.
Chiang is scheduled to return to Taipei late Monday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS JAPANESE DIETMEN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui reaffirmed the necessity of the Republic of China government's "no hurry, be patient" policy toward Taiwan investment on the mainland when he met with a group of visiting Japanese lawmakers on Monday.

Lee said the policy does not aim to restrict investment in the mainland. Rather, the government is asking Taiwan businessmen who want to invest more than US$50 million in the mainland to exercise greater caution and to follow relevant regulations, he said.
Lee stressed that the policy of caution is aimed at protecting the interests of Taiwan businessmen.

The president also said that Taiwan has emerged intact from financial crisis which swept through Asia beginning in mid-1997. He attributed steady growth witnessed in the wake of the storm to Taiwan's sound economic structure.
Lee added that the ROC is willing to help other Asian nations solve their financial problems.

The four Japanese dietmen who called on the president -- Kamei Shizuka, Hiranuma Takeo, Aso Taro and Eto Sheishiro -- are all members of the Liberal Democratic Party. They were accompanied by Lin Chin-ching, chairman of the Taipei-based Association of East Asian Relations, and ROC Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Tzu-dan.
The visitors lauded the economic development achieved in Taiwan under Lee's leadership.

The ROC president expressed appreciation for their support, saying that although there are no formal relations between Taiwan and Japan, civilian exchanges have been close. He expressed hope that the lawmakers' visit would help promote cooperation between the two neighbors.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO CONTINUE PROTEST AGAINST ADB NAME CHANGE

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) on Monday reiterated the Republic of China's opposition to a change of its membership designation in the Asian Development Bank (ADB), saying it will continue to protest the unilateral action.

CBC officials said Taiwan delegates to the 1998 ADB annual meeting, slated for April 30-May 2 in Geneva, Switzerland, will stage a protest again this year against the ADB's alteration of the ROC membership designation in 1986.

The officials, however, did not elaborate on how the protest will be presented during the ADB meeting, saying only that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will be responsible for organizing the action.
The ADB changed the ROC's designation to "Taipei, China" after mainland China was admitted to that body in 1986.
The ROC, a founding member of the regional financial organization, rejected the change and has since taken part in ADB meetings under protest.

CBC officials said the name change is particularly unacceptable as Hong Kong will take part in the upcoming ADB meeting as "Hong Kong, China." This development can be equated to a downgrading of the ROC to a status similar to that of Hong Kong, which since July 1, 1997, has been a special administration region of mainland China, the officials noted.
In recent years, Taiwan delegates have voiced complaints against perceived unfairness in the name change during speeches at ADB meetings.

Discounting rumors that Taipei plans to use offers of cash aid to financially battered Asian economies as a bargaining chip to win back its formal name in the ADB, CBC officials said financial aid and membership designation are two completely different issues.

Newly appointed CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan will lead a 15-member Taiwan delegation to the upcoming ADB meeting. Perng filled a vacancy left by Sheu Yuan-dong in March after Sheu was killed in an air crash.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PRO-DEMOCRACY BODIES LAUD RELEASE OF DISSIDENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, April 20 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Organizations founded by pro-democracy overseas Chinese congratulated mainland China on its release of prominent dissident Wang Dan, but warned on Sunday against Beijing's intrigue.

The Alliance for a Democratic China and the Democratic China Front, two active organizations founded by pro-democracy overseas Chinese, proclaimed that the release of dissidents Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan and their departure from the mainland shows that Beijing has obviously been following the former Soviet Union's policy for dealing with dissidents -- releasing them into exile in foreign countries.

The two organizations called for the upholding of the democratic momentum which has been built up over the decades by numerous Chinese people who have been willing to sacrifice themselves to uphold the basic ideals of freedom and democracy, and warned against intrigues by the authorities in Beijing.

The Alliance for a Democratic China and the Democratic China Front are scheduled to hold an international meeting in Toronto, Canada, as well as to co-sponsor a seminar on the quality of mainland China's opposition parties on May 23. Wei and Wang will both be invited to attend the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANCE OF 'RED TIDE'` POLLUTION SAID SLIM

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Monday the "red tide" pollution which has devastated Hong Kong fisheries is unlikely to occur in Taiwan waters.

COA officials stressed that no cases involving the red tide have been reported in Taiwan to date, although neighboring Hong Kong has experienced the worst onslaught of the phenomenon in years, suffering a severe blow to its fishing industry.

The officials said, however, that to prevent similar a situation from occurring here, they would step up water quality control in the local aquacultural industry and heighten scrutiny of imported marine products.

The officials said that the red tide, which induces a buildup of microscopic plankton that gives a reddish tinge to the water and deprives affected areas of oxygen, occurs in closed or half-closed bodies of water or in bay areas such as those around Hong Kong.
They said strong currents flow around Taiwan and noted the island has never had reports of red tide pollution, adding the chances of that occurrence are slim.

Although red tide will not pose a direct threat to Taiwan, the COA officials said that they will be on guard against possible pollution. They called on customs authorities to be alert for smuggled seafood items from Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP SHARPLY ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed low on the Taipei Stock Exchange on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 217.38 points to close at 8,508.56.
Dealers said the market was affected by uneasy sentiment over electronics stocks, triggering heavy selling pressure.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 8,741.95, and experienced a closing low of 8,508.56.
Losers outnumbered gainers 376 to 56, with 52 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.97 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$123.4 billion, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.17 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of 125.71 billion.

Seven of the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical issues plunging the most at 4.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks and construction shares at 1.5 percent, bank and insurance issues at 1.4 percent, textile stocks at 1.2 percent, and cement issues and foodstuff shares at 1.1 percent.
Only the pulp and paper category saw an upturn, registering a gain of 0.3 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Monday's trading were: A.S.E.; ACER; United Micro Electronics; Mitac International Corp.; Winbond Electronics Corp.; Macronix International; Silicon Integrated Systems Corp.; Taiwan Semiconductor manufacturing; Kuo Feng Corporation; and CIS Technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENT'S RELEASE LINKED TO CLINTON-JIANG MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 19 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Former US ambassador to mainland China James Lilley said on Sunday that Beijing's decision to release jailed dissident Wang Dan is closely linked to the upcoming summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

As the Clinton-Jiang meeting, slated for late June, is only eight weeks away, Lilley said, Wang's release on Sunday is obviously linked to Beijing's efforts to increase engagement with the United States. The Chinese communist regime is very aware that dissidents forced to live in exile abroad are eventually forgotten, thus arousing fewer repercussions from the international community.
In addition to Wang, Beijing has released several other prominent political dissidents over the past few years, including Wei Jingsheng, Dai Qing and Fang Lizhi.

The China expert was quoted by the Washington Post in a Beijing-datelined story on Sunday as saying that although the pro-democracy movement has spread from the campus to the state-run business sector in mainland China, it is still too dramatic to say that the Clinton administration's engagement with Beijing has been effective.

Meanwhile, Nancy Pelosi, a top US lawmaker from California and a strong critic of the mainland's human rights record, issued a statement on Sunday welcoming Wang Dan's release, but warning: "We must remember that the Chinese regime's actions have nothing to do with democratic reform."

If Beijing wishes to be viewed as freeing its political prisoners, the dissidents should be allowed to stay in mainland China and speak freely about political reform at home, Pelosi said in the statement.
The lawmaker also urged Clinton to take advantage of his planned visit to mainland China in June, to "pursue the release of the countless political prisoners who remain in jail."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND MEDIA EXECUTIVES MEET KEY TAIWAN NEGOTIATOR

TEXT.P: A group of mainland Chinese media chief executive officers met with Shi Hwei-yow, one of Taiwan's leading negotiators with Beijing, on Monday.

Shi, vice chairman and secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), extended his hearty welcome to the mainland news media delegation, saying its visit is yet another sign of a thaw in stalled relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that the two sides had reached a consensus on the strengthening of cross-strait news exchanges during the first "Koo-Wang" meeting held in Singapore in April 1993, Shi said he hopes news exchanges will be included in the agenda for future cross-strait talks.

Shi also expressed the hope that Beijing will seriously consider the possibility of allowing Taiwan's news organizations to set up representative offices and post resident journalists on the mainland, as well as the reinforcement of cross-strait news verification services.
"News verification can help avoid unnecessary cross-strait misunderstandings or adverse impacts on normal economic activities on both sides," Shi noted.

For his part, Xie Hung, leader of the visiting media delegation, said mainland China also looks forward to increasing news exchanges and cooperation with Taiwan. "We hope Taipei's SEF and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan (ARATS) will work hand in hand to accomplish their lofty mission of promoting cross-strait exchanges and cooperation in various fields, including journalistic affairs."

The SEF and ARATS are semiofficial bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties. SEF Chairman C.F. Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan held a historic meeting in 1993, also known as the first "Koo-Wang" meeting, to lay a framework for regular cross-strait dialogue and exchanges.

Beijing, however, unilaterally suspended contacts in mid-1995 to vent its anger at a visit to the United States by ROC President Lee Teng-hui, which it regarded as a veiled move to promote Taiwan independence.

After a nearly-three-year stall, Beijing has finally agreed to resume SEF-ARATS contacts. The SEF's new deputy secretary-general, Jan Jyh-horng, is scheduled to visit Beijing on April 22-24 in a bid to end the impasse in bilateral talks. Jan concurrently serves as the planning department director in the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's mainland policy. Observers have said the arrangement suggests that Taiwan has ended a ban on official contacts with Beijing.

Commenting on reports that mainland China may restrict the number of Taiwan journalists allowed to cover Jan's upcoming mainland visit, Xie said the reports may not be true as such a move would violate the fundamental principle of encouraging cross-strait exchanges.

In fact, cross-strait news exchanges have been unbalanced. Over the past few years, Taiwan journalists have made thousands of visits to the mainland for news coverage, while only about 100 mainland reporters have come to Taiwan.

Xie and 15 other mainland media executives, who arrived in Taipei last Friday for a nine-day visit, are the most senior media personalties to visit Taiwan since mid-1995. The group paid a visit to CNA Monday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADVANCED X-RAY MACHINES CAN DETECT BOMBS IN LUGGAGE

TEXT.P: Several major airports in the United States and Europe are now using advanced X-ray machines for quick identification of hidden explosives or drugs in passengers' luggage during check-in.

The new system, designed by the US company Vivid Technologies, is based on technology designed originally for measuring bone density in humans, said Paul Hurd, the company's technical marketing manager.
The system was one of several on display at the fourth Asia Pacific Aviation Security Conference and Exhibition held in Singapore last week.

Hurd said that the system captures the image of any suspicious object, highlights it in red and then flashes it on the computer of the screening officer, who can then start looking for other bomb components such as trigger mechanisms, fuses or wires.
The new system, which can screen up to 1,500 bags per hour, will soon also be installed at the new airports in Kuala Lumpur and Hong Kong, Hurd said.
The Singapore authorities are also looking into the possibility of installing a similar system at Singapore's Changi Airport, he said.
Older X-ray machines, including those currently used at Changi Airport, show the contents of a bag without indicating to the machine operator if any items may be suspicious.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUGGIERO: BEIJING MUST ABIDE BY WTO RULES

TEXT.P: The World Trade Organization (WTO) virtually ruled out the possibility that mainland China can join the body without conforming to its expanding system of rules and discipline, according to reports from the world trade body Sunday.

Dismissing the notion that the Chinese mainland should be treated as a special case, WTO Director-General Renato Ruggiero indicated that its application may remain stalled until the body is convinced that Beijing will faithfully adhere to the rules, the WTO report said.
"Sometimes we hear of the need for flexibility, but why should we be flexible for and not for other countries," the WTO report quoted Ruggiero as saying.
Ruggiero said WTO applicants are required to adopt the entire body of WTO rules as a "single undertaking," and cannot merely pick and choose which they would like to abide by, the WTO report added.
Ruggiero's remarks were practically an echo of the US position on Beijing's WTO accession which US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky reiterated recently.

Barshefsky said mainland China's accession will be a "slow and deliberate process." It has to "live up to commercial standards" in all the areas covered by WTO rules, including agriculture, intellectual property rights, information technology and telecommunications and financial services, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAN'S RELEASE SHOULD BE TREATED CAUTIOUSLY: SEF

TEXT.P: With regard to whether mainland China's release of prominent dissident Wang Dan marks an attempt by the authorities in Beijing to begin to make amends for their reaction to the June 4, 1989 pro-democracy demonstration in Tiananmen Square, Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman and secretary-general of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), has observed that the matter should be treated cautiously and monitored closely.
The 1989 demonstrations were political events under international scrutiny, Shi said, adding that the Beijing authorities should therefore treat them in a proper and comprehensive matter.

Taiwan has in the past had its own problems with dissident blacklists, Shi pointed out, adding however that after a decade of political democratization and economic reform, those problems have all faded into the mists of history.

The high-ranking SEF official remarked that Taiwan's political and economic development should be worthy of reference by the Beijing authorities, warning that if mainland China's economic reforms are not matched by political reforms, there will be little room for the economic reforms to develop.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S FOREIGN DEBT TO RISE

TEXT.P: Australia's gross foreign debt is expected to jump by 45 percent to US$316 billion by fiscal 2001-02 from the current US$219 billion, according to Canberra's Access Economics.

In a five-year forecast released on Sunday night, Access Economics warns: "Australia faces its most hostile environment in over a decade, with calendar 1999 looming as a particularly dangerous time for business because its domestic demand for imports is on the rise and its exports to Asia are falling."

The forecasting body said: "Given the possibility that drought may decimate the next wheat crop at the end of 1998, the current account may be back in the Banana Republic range by late 1998 or early 1999."
However, good news is that Australia's unemployment rate is expected to drop by about 7 percent early in 1999 from the current rate of 8.2 percent.

Access Economics predicted that Australia's gross domestic product will rise by 3.5 percent in fiscal 1998-99, up from 3.25 percent as targeted by the government, but the group added that GDP growth will slow to 2.4 percent in 1999-2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.011 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$33.043.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 33.01 and had a high of 33.07.
The interbank trading reached US$285.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: `MILLENNIUM BUG' WILL BE AS BIG AS ASIAN CRISIS: BUSINESS WEEK

TEXT.P: The impact of the "millennium bug" will be as large as the Asian financial crisis and is shaping up to have a profoundly negative effect on the US economy.

In a special report, The Australian Financial Review reported the bug could cut half a percentage point off growth in 2000 and early 2001 in the US economy. This would be the same as the expected economic damage from the current Asian financial turmoil.
"The millennium bug will certainly hurt the economy and it could be a real killer if more of the problems are not fixed," said DRI chief economist David Wyss.
All told, the bug could cost the US about US$119 billion in lost economic output between now and 2001, he said.
Some analysts even worry that the bug could send the US economy into a recession.
But much of Asia is distracted by its economic crisis and dangerously unprepared for the computer bug, they said.
However, the impact on the Asian region may be softened by its relatively low reliance on computers, they added.

In Australia, the specter of the computer bug meltdown has prompted civil defense authorities to prepare for a national emergency while the business world ponders how to work around a breakdown in essential services.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-SINGAPORE TRADE DOWN 6.46% IN MARCH

TEXT.P: Bilateral trade between the Republic of China and Singapore declined by 6.46 percent in March compared to the same month of last year, according to figures released by the Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB) on Monday.
The total value of ROC-Singapore trade in March amounted to S$1.341 billion (about US$838.4 million), a decrease of S$92.7 million from the total amount recorded for March 1997.

In the first quarter of this year, however, the total value of bilateral trade stood at S$3.763 billion (about US$2.35 billion), an increase of S$198.3 million, or 5.56 percent, over the figure recorded for the January-March period of last year, according to the TDB data.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAVID HO CALLS ON ACADEMIA SINICA PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Dr. David Ho, the Taiwan-born American chemist who invented the much-vaunted drug cocktail therapy for AIDS sufferers, on Monday paid a courtesy call on Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest-level academic institute.
Ho, who was named as a candidate for membership of the august body on April 17, was briefed by Lee on recent developments at Academia Sinica.

The doctor named as Time magazine's 1966 man of the year later delivered a speech at a seminar on AIDS research before an audience of more than 200 people from the Institute of Biomedical Sciences and the Institute of Zoology, in addition to the Institute of Molecular Biology, where the seminar was held.

Ho said that currently he has no plans to collaborate with Academia Sinica, which engages in only limited research on AIDS, but he did not rule out the possibility of future cooperation with the institute, once it devotes more resources to AIDS research.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S TOTAL TRADE UP BY 4.2% IN MARCH

TEXT.P: Singapore's total trade at current prices increased by 4.2 percent in March over the same month of last year, with its value totaling S$33.041 billion (about US$20.65 billion), the Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB) said on Monday.

Exports in March grew by 9.9 percent, with non-oil domestic exports and non-oil re-exports increasing by 10.8 percent and 14.3 percent, respectively, while oil domestic exports weakened by 14.1 percent, according to TDB figures.
Singapore's imports in March declined by 1.1 percent as a result of a drop in oil imports, the TDB said.
It said the total value of exports in March amounted to S$16.968 billion, while that of imports amounted to S$16.073 billion.
On a monthly basis, non-oil domestic exports increased by 9.6 percent in March, lower than the average growth of 11.5 percent in the first two months of this year.

While domestic exports of integrated circuits and printed circuit boards assembled continued to expand steadily by 21.2 percent and 26.4 percent, respectively, shipment of disk drives was weak, increasing by only 2.6 percent.

Non-oil re-exports increased by 13.9 percent, reflecting strong growth in non-oil re-exports to the United States and European Union, which was partially offset by declines in non-oil re-exports to Malaysia and Thailand, the TDB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO HOPEFULS REGISTER TO RUN FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: The race for the chairmanship of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) shifted into high gear on Monday, with two hopefuls completing their registrations as candidates.

Legislator Yen Chin-fu, representing the Taipei-South constituency, registered first, followed shortly afterward by DPP chief adviser Lin Yi-hsiung, accompanied by incumbent DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang.

Yen said self-assurance and a strong sense of mission prompted him to enter the chairmanship race. "If I'm elected, I'll push for internal DPP reforms and I'll also do my utmost to lead the party to power," the outspoken lawmaker said confidently.

For his part, Lin issued an open letter to all DPP members, expressing his concern about intraparty squabbling over alleged irregularities related to party primaries for the year-end elections for the Legislative Yuan, the Taipei and Kaohsiung city councils and the mayorships of the two cities.

Lin said that if he succeeds in winning the DPP chairmanship, he will convene a seminar on the party's rejuvenation. "I hope to foster intraparty consensus on reform programs through open debate," he stressed, adding that his priorities will include recruiting new members and adjusting the party's structure and membership quality. "Under my leadership, the DPP will project a new image and take on the challenges of the three year-end elections with innovative strategies and tactics."
Speaking on the same occasion, incumbent DPP Chairman Hsu said he earnestly hopes the various party factions will refrain from interfering with the chairmanship election.

"I myself will stay away from the race. I hope all factional leaders and heavyweights will follow suit. Let us make the chairmanship election a gentlemen's race and let our party members vote as they please," Hsu urged.
This will be the first time the DPP chairman is elected directly by the party members, who are estimated to number slightly more than 80,000.
The registration period will last for five days, and before the voting takes place on May 24, the DPP headquarters is expected to hold three rounds of televised debates for all the candidates.

A third likely candidate, Legislator-at-large Chang Chun-hung, didn't show up as expected to register. Chang, a former DPP secretary-general and prominent member of incumbent Chairman Hsu's dominant "Formosa" faction, is widely considered to be Lin's strongest opponent if he decides to run.

But Chang said on Sunday that he is still soliciting opinions from leading party figures before deciding whether to throw his hat into the ring. One of his close friends said on Monday that he will make his decision before the April 24 deadline for registration.

Some senior DPP members have advised Chang not to enter the race as they hope to see Lin win the chairmanship. "They hope Lin's high moral stature and clean image will facilitate the streamlining of party discipline and promotion of intraparty unity and harmony," a DPP official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNCILOR CONCERNED ABOUT TEENAGE MOTHERS

TEXT.P: A Taipei City councilor said on Monday that statistics show that teenage mothers give birth to some 15,000 babies in Taiwan each year, with Taipei accounting for around 650 such cases.

During an interpellation session at the Taipei City Council, Councilor Chen Hsue-sheng of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) cited statistics published in the latest issue of the "Population in Taiwan" report, and questioned if the Taipei education authorities are aware of the seriousness of the problem of unplanned pregnancies in schools and on campus.
Chen said that he had already asked the Taipei Education Bureau in writing about the issue of "student mothers," but said the reply he received stated that no such cases have been discovered.

Chen demanded that the education authorities take measures to address the issue of the increasing number of teenage mothers, such as providing on-campus sex education programs. He also said that the education authorities and school authorities should implement programs to help students return to their studies after they have given birth, to avoid the problems caused to society by drop-out mothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD WILLING TO HELP WITH LAND DEVELOPMENT IN TAICHUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Monday that it will continue with plans to develop the parcel of land leased by the Germany-based Bayer Group near Taichung Harbor in central Taichung County.

CEPD Vice Chairman Schive Chi clarified that Bayer has only terminated its first-phase development project for the site -- establishing a toluene di-isocyanate (TDI) plant -- and that the company might still put the lot to some other use.

Schive said the CEPD would welcome Bayer or any other company wishing to set up a stronghold on the land, as long as their investment projects fall in line with the government's Asia-Pacific business operation hub plan. He added that the CEPD is willing to help with the development of the lot, which is owned by the Taiwan Provincial Government.

The Bayer Group announced in December that it was relocating its proposed TDI plant to Bay City in Texas, the United States, after the then newly elected Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai insisted on holding a public referendum to decide the fate of the project in Taiwan.

But Schive pointed out that the contract by the German chemical giant to lease the land has been referred to the Executive Yuan for final approval, since the central government has not received formal notification from Bayer canceling the project. The Bayer contract passed the Taiwan Provincial Assembly in February.
If Bayer plans to set up another type of facility on the land, it will have to conduct a new assessment of the environmental impact of any such facility, the CEPD vice chairman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST INDUSTRY HIT BY ASIAN CRISIS

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis has so far cost about 17,000 jobs in Australia in the past several months and the country is now bracing for the worst, with more job and business losses expected in the coming months.

The Tourism Council of Australia (TCA) revised its earlier target of foreign tourist arrivals with a 5 percent decline, which a TCA spokesman said will cost more than US$530 million in revenue losses and the loss of 40,000 jobs in Australia.

The losses will be felt by many businesses, including duty-free retailers, tour operators, hotels and restaurants, thanks to a decline in tourist arrivals from South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia, Taiwan, and Malaysia, and slow growth from Japan, the Philippines and New Zealand.

Between October and December 1997, Thailand led other Asian countries in the decline of tourist visitors to Australia, with a drop of about 45 percent, followed by Korea, at 26 percent, Indonesia, at 22 percent, Taiwan, at 10 percent, and Malaysia, at 6.5 percent, according to the TCA.
The TCA spokesman attributed the decline in the number of foreign tourists to Australia to the Asian economic meltdown.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ENVOY TO UN: LONG WAY TO GO FOR FREE, FAIR ELECTION IN CAMBODIA

TEXT.P: "We still have a long way to go to ensure a free and fair election in Cambodia on July 26," said Bill Richardson, the US ambassador to the United Nations, on Sunday in Bangkok after attending a meeting between the ASEAN Troika and the Friends of Cambodia.
Richardson called the meeting "good" and "constructive" but stressed that there are still "some political elements to be settled before a free and fair election."

Meanwhile, Philippine Foreign Minister Domingo Siazon, who is chairman of the ASEAN Troika -- which consists of the Philippines, Thailand and Indonesia -- said in a press conference that those in the meeting were generally positive about the preparations for the election.
The foreign ministers of the ASEAN Troika nations flew to Seam Reap in northern Cambodia on Sunday to see King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia and returned to Bangkok the same evening.
The Friends of Cambodia comprises the United States, Japan, the European Union, France, Australia and others.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE RETAIL SALES PLUNGED 17 PERCENT IN FEB.

TEXT.P: Singapore's retail sales, excluding cars, plunged 17.1 percent in February over the same month last year, thquitquitquitquitquit-year fall since the regional financial turmoil began last July.

The retail sales index, measured at current prices, dived by a hefty 30.2 percent compared with January due to lower spending after Chinese New Year and Hari Raya and the shorter month of February, the Singapore Department of Statistics said Sunday.
The year-on-year fall in retail spending in February was due in part to a higher base a year ago.
The two festivals were celebrated in February last year but in late January this year.

In January this year, "everybody had spent whatever they needed during Chinese New Year and Hari Raya. And with the economy being so bad, they did not spend much after that," explained a department store retailer.
"And in past years, we have had Indonesians coming here to shop during the Hari Raya holidays. This year they didn't," the retailer added.

The overall retail sales index, including motor vehicles, fell by a smaller 9.7 percent in February from a year earlier as car sales surged 45 percent over the period. This represented the sixth consecutive drop in the index since September last year.
However, the index slumped 32.6 percent in February from the preceding month as car sales shrank 41.3 percent, according to data released by the Department of Statistics.
This was a sharp turnabout from the robust 66.2 percent growth in car sales in January from December.
Total retail sales were valued at an estimated S$1.55 billion (about US$1 billion) in February compared to January's figure of S$2.3 billion.
Analyzing on a year-on-year basis, shops selling textiles, clothes and "personal effects" suffered the biggest fall in sales at 32.5 percent.
Next were department stores and supermarkets, where cash registers rang in 20.5 percent less business.
Business at general provisions shops also fell 19.1 percent.
Furniture and household equipment stores experienced a 6.7 percent slide in business.
However, petrol service stations managed a 2.3 percent increase in sales.
The catering trade index at current prices posted a 5.3 percent year-on-year decline in February.
Restaurants were the worst hit, with business sliding 12.2 percent.
Fast food outlets saw a smaller 1.1 percent fall in sales while sales at other eating places dipped 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY STUDENTS YEARN FOR OVERSEAS TRIPS

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of Taiwan's college students are looking forward to an overseas pleasure trip before their graduation, according to the results of an opinion poll released on Monday.
The poll of 598 students selected from 12 universities and colleges in northern Taiwan found that one out of every two undergraduate students have traveled abroad at least once.
The survey results also show that 61.5 percent of the respondents are hoping that their traditional pre-graduation jaunt will take them off the island.

The most favored travel destinations are the United States, Canada, Japan and Europe in that order, according to the survey which was conducted by the Journalism Department of National Chengchi University on March 23-26.

A total of 84 percent of those surveyed said they look forward to making sightseeing trips to the US, Europe, Japan, New Zealand and Australia, while less than 10 percent said they want to journey to mainland China or Southeast Asia.

About 60 percent of those who yearn for an overseas leisure trip cited increasing experience and expanding mental horizons as their main motivations; 14 percent said they hope to enhance their proficiency in foreign languages; and 10 percent said they want to go abroad mainly because they had already traveled to all domestic sightseeing spots.

As many as 56 percent said they hope the traditional pre-graduation jaunt will be longer than a week, and 63 percent said the reasonable expense for such a trip is about NT$30,000 (US$909.09). Forty-three percent said they will ask their parents to finance their pre-graduation jaunts, while 28 percent said they will moonlight to earn needed funds.

Despite a spate of air disasters reported here in recent months, only 4 percent said they would not take overseas trips because of worry about flight safety. In contrast, more than 60 percent said a lack of funds is the biggest obstacle to their overseas travel plans.

In case they are required to take pre-commencement jaunts at home, nearly all respondents favor a round-the-island journey. Eastern Taiwan and Penghu, an island group off southwestern Taiwan coast, are among the most popular domestic tourist destinations, according to the survey results.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA ASKED TO PRESERVE VALLEY OF BUTTERFLIES

TEXT.P: Taipei City Legislator Yeh Chu-lan of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party on Monday asked the Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Executive Yuan to help preserve the area in Meinung, Pingtung County, known as the "Green Valley of Yellow Butterflies."

Yeh made the request at the Legislative Yuan during a review of the COA's budget. She told COA Chairman Peng Chuo-kui that the COA should voice opposition to the building of a dam in Meinung because of the need for soil conservation and for the preservation of the ecology there.
The proposed dam would flood the valley and destroy the world-class butterfly reservation, Yeh said, adding that this would make the government "the laughingstock of the international community."

In his reply, Peng said that the COA voices its opinion on development projects affecting the environment, and that in the case of the Meinung reservoir construction project, the COA will express its view in its assessment of the impact the dam would have on soil conservation and the ecology of the region.

To help solve the problem of water usage in southern Taiwan, the Ministry of Economic Affairs decided to revive the long-shelved Meinung reservoir development project. However, the news spread and has drawn strong protests from Meinung residents.

Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming said that although the proposed industrial zone in Tainan County and the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park are expected to have no water supply problems before 2006, only the construction of a large-scale reservoir can end the water supply problem that afflicts all of southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PER CAPITA GNP RISES TO 23RD GLOBALLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's total gross national product (GNP) was the 19th largest in the world for the third consecutive year in 1996, while its per capita GNP during the same period was the world's 23rd highest, up three notches from the last evaluation, according to figures from the World Bank.

The soon-to-be-issued latest edition of the World Bank Atlas shows that the world's top 10 economies for 1996 were the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy, mainland China, Brazil, Canada and Spain.
The 11th to 20th positions were taken by South Korea, the Netherlands, Australia, India, Russia, Mexico, Switzerland, Argentina, Belgium and Sweden, in that order.

Taiwan is not listed in the World Bank's atlas since the island is not a member of the international financial organization. But according to statistics released by the Republic of China's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Taiwan's total GNP for 1996 reached US$274.6 billion, which should make it stand between Argentina and Belgium, making it 19th in the world. Meanwhile, Taiwan's per capita GNP of US$12,838 during the same period should give the island the 23rd position globally in this area.
The top 10 economies in terms of per capita GNP in 1996 were Switzerland, Japan, Norway, Denmark, Singapore, Germany, Austria, the United States, Belgium and France.

Taiwan's per capita GNP was Asia's fourth highest in 1996, after only Japan, which was No. 2 in the world; Singapore, No. 5; and Hong Kong, No. 13. Meanwhile, the island's total GNP was the fifth largest in Asia, behind Japan, which was No. 2 in the world; mainland China, No. 7; South Korea, No. 11; and Indonesia, No. 14.

Taiwan has been ranked as one of the world's high-income economies since 1991, when its per capita GNP hit US$9,636. Ever since then, the ranking of Taiwan's per capita GNP has been on the rise, with Taiwan's position moving up from 28th in 1994 to 26th in 1995, and then to 23rd in 1996.

If the "Chinese Economic Sphere" -- comprising Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong -- were taken together, it would constitute the world's fifth largest economy, with a combined GNP of US$1.33 trillion that would trail only the United States, Japan, Germany and France.

Although mainland China was listed as having the world's seventh largest economy, its per capita GNP of US$750 is less than one-seventeenth of Taiwan's. The mainland was listed among the world's 53 low-income economies, which have per capita GNPs lower than US$785.
The lowest-income country was Mozambique, whose per capita GNP stood at only US$80.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADB CHIEF BACKS HELPING MALAYSIA RELEASE GOV'T BONDS

TEXT.P: The president of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), Mitsuo Sato, has expressed his support for Taiwan's proposed program to bail Malaysia out of its financial troubles.

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, revealed Sato's support for the plan in Taipei on Monday after returning from a visit to the ADB's headquarters in Manila, the Philippines.

Together with Jeffrey Koo -- the head of the crisis task force under the business sector arm of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, the APEC Business Advisory Council -- Chiang called on Sato Monday morning. They discussed Taipei's expressed willingness to help economically troubled Southeast Asian countries issue government bonds.
Chiang said he believes the plan will help those countries free themselves as quickly as possible from their difficult economic situations caused by the regional financial crisis.

Chiang noted that while showing support for the proposal, Sato also said that Malaysia is the Southeast Asian country now most badly in need of aid, and that the ADB will offer it guarantee services, based on the model used in Thailand, so Kuala Lumpur can release government bonds.
The ADB has endorsed over US$600 billion of the government bonds Bangkok has released since the outbreak of the financial storm last July.
Demand for these guaranteed bonds has been larger than the supply since their release.

Encouraged by the market's response, Sato expressed the hope that a mechanism that can help Southeast Asian countries issue government bonds to collect money for economic recovery will be established, Chiang mentioned.
He revealed that the ADB will discuss the matter with Koo, who has been asked to submit a report on the planned mechanism during the upcoming APEC ministerial meeting on finance on May 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW RECEIVES GRENADA FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Monday received Grenada Foreign Minister Dr. Raphael Fletcher and expressed his gratitude to Grenada for the strong support it has shown for the Republic of China in the international arena.

Accompanied by Francisco L.Y. Hwang, director of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Central and South American Affairs Department, Fletcher, who also serves as chairman of Grenada's ruling New National Party, paid a courtesy call on the premier at his office.

Siew told his guest that the frequent exchange of visits by high-ranking officials and the realization of a series of cooperative projects between the two countries indicate that bilateral relations and the ROC-Grenada friendship have become closer and firmer.

When asked about Taiwan's development experiences, Siew said he believes that the island's experience in the fields of agricultural processing, fishing and animal husbandry, as well as in tourism promotion, could be conducive to Grenada's overall economic development.

Siew also told Fletcher -- who is in charge of foreign affairs, judicial affairs and domestic affairs in Grenada Premier Keith Mitchell's Cabinet -- that education has played an important role in Taiwan's development, noting that the island is densely populated and its land area and resources are limited.
Pointing out that education has long been one of the ROC government's top priorities, Siew said that Taiwan's experiences in this field could serve as a reference for Grenada.
This is Fletcher's second visit to Taiwan since 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-PROFILE MAINLAND MASS MEDIA DELEGATION VISITS CNA

TEXT.P: A visiting 16-member delegation of mainland Chinese mass media chief executive officers on Monday visited the Central News Agency (CNA), where they received a warm welcome and attended a seminar to exchanges views on the promotion of cross-strait exchanges of mass media personnel and news reports.

CNA President Bill Wang stressed in the seminar that the cross-strait exchange of news reports is one of the most effective ways to promote understanding between people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Wang also hailed the visit by the high-profile mainland mass media executives as an important event in the exchange of media personnel across the Taiwan Strait.
Xie Hong, leader of the delegation and deputy editor-in-chief of the People's Daily, expressed thanks to CNA for welcoming them as if they were "brothers."

Ho Ping, assistant to the editor-in-chief of the mainland's official Xinhua News Agency, noted that Xinhua issues news stories throughout the world in seven languages, including Chinese, English, Russian, Spanish and Arabic, but he said that his agency regrets it does not have a branch office in Taiwan.

Ho said that although Xinhua does distribute stories about Taiwan, they are based on "secondhand" information. He expressed the hope that some day Xinhua will have personnel stationed in Taiwan to cover the island firsthand as well as to write more stories about it.
Xie and 15 other mainland media executives arrived in Taipei last Friday for a nine-day visit. They are the most senior media personalties to visit Taiwan since mid-1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONCERNED ABOUT EXPECTED DRAM DUMPING ACCUSATION

TEXT.P: During the upcoming trade and economic conference between Taiwan and the European Union (EU), Taipei will try to head off an expected joint accusation that the island is dumping dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips.

The meeting will open in Taipei on Tuesday and feature talks between representatives of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the European Commission about a number of issues, including Taiwan's bid for membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The EU is one of the three remaining WTO contracting parties that have yet to conclude discussions with Taipei on the island's WTO membership requirements.

MOEA officials revealed they worry that the US International Trade Commission's recent ruling that Taiwan manufacturers have been dumping SRAM in the United States will prompt Washington and the EU to work together on an accusation that the island is dumping DRAM.
The officials said that their ministry has thus decided to raise its concerns over the anticipated accusation in the upcoming conference, hoping the EU will regard the case objectively.

The meeting will also see discussions on Taiwan and the EU signing agreements on issues including the abolition of dual taxation on income from aviation transportation and the mutual certification of laboratories, according to the MOEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES TO RECRUIT STUDENTS FROM SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: A dozen universities in Taiwan will hold a series of higher education exhibitions in Southeast Asia next month to recruit students there, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said on Tuesday.

Education officials noted that the 12 universities, including National Taiwan University, National Cheng Kung University, National Sun Yat-sen University and Fu Jen University, will send representatives to Malaysia, the first leg of the Southeast Asian tour, in early May.

The officials noted that representatives from the United Kingdom, the United States, France, Australia, and New Zealand have held similar exhibitions here in recent years to recruit Taiwan students to study in their countries.

In view of the trend toward international education, the MOE said it will also promote the extension of university education beyond national borders. The officials said the ministry had invited local universities to discuss the idea, and received an enthusiastic response from the 12 schools.
The institutions have chosen Malaysia, home to many National Cheng Kung University alumni, as the first stop on its recruitment drive.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECEIVES US$10.19 BILLION IN EXPORT ORDERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan received export orders worth US$10.19 billion in March, down 2.74 percent from the same period last year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Tuesday.

MOEA officials said the March figures pushed Taiwan's total first quarter export orders to US$28.27 billion. They added that orders from Asian countries have dropped by nearly 17 percent during the period from the first quarter of 1997, as a result of financial turmoil affecting the region.
With shrinking export orders, the officials said the rate of Taiwan's overall economic growth this year will depend mainly on demand in the domestic market.

They noted that fallout from the Asian financial crisis has lowered manufacturing sector growth to 5 percent in the first quarter of 1998, down from 9.36 percent in the previous quarter. But compared with the decline witnessed in South Korea, Taiwan's manufacturing is still sound, they added.
The officials said that several uncertainty factors lie ahead, including possible currency fluctuations in Asia, which they said could affect the export orders.

However, they said that on the strength of an expected boom in the information industry and a number of major investment projects which are scheduled to get under way in the manufacturing industry, export orders in the second half of the year should pick up.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO MAINTAIN BID FOR SUBMARINE PURCHASE

TEXT.P: The ROC government will not withdraw a bid to acquire advanced submarines for beefing up its naval defense capabilities, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) reaffirmed on Tuesday.

The ministry made the statement after an American defense news weekly reported that the United States will continue to reject Taiwan's requests for the purchase of conventional submarines, but will consider selling advanced anti-submarine arsenals to the island.
The ministry declined to directly respond to the reports, saying it is the military's policy to avoid comment on media coverage relating to arms deals.
Nevertheless, the ministry stressed that the Republic of China needs submarines to enhance its defense capabilities in the face of mounting military threat from rival mainland China.
The MND further said the cost for deploying anti-submarine weaponry systems is usually more than tenfold the price of a submarine.
An ROC military delegation, headed by Deputy Chief of the General Staff Lee Chieh, is currently in Washington, D.C., to attend an annual arms procurement meeting with American military brass.

Quoting Pentagon sources, the US Defense News weekly reported in its latest issue that the Clinton administration is considering selling to Taiwan sophisticated anti-submarine helicopters and radar systems, including Apache attack helicopters for coastal defense and the Aegis radar system now in service with the US Navy for long-haul monitoring of submarine activities. The Aegis radar system can be installed on Taiwan's Noxas-, Perry- and Lafayette-class frigates to upgrade their anti-submarine capabilities.
The Defense News further said the United States may also agree to sell P-3 Orion anti-submarine aircraft to Taiwan. But the weekly added that Taiwan has yet to broach such a purchase request.

Meanwhile, it quoted unnamed US government sources as reporting that the Clinton administration will continue to ban sales of diesel-powered submarines to Taiwan. The United States is also unlikely to allow its shipyards to arm a foreign-built submarine for sale to Taiwan, the weekly said, adding there are no plans at present to sell high-performance AIM-120 medium-range air-to-air missiles and the advanced versions of Maverick air-to-surface missiles to Taiwan.
