DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGE OF POWER NOT TO AFFECT ROC-PARAGUAY TIES: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, April 20 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Agustin Liu, the Republic of China ambassador to Paraguay, said on Monday that the holding of an annual economic cooperation meeting between the two countries in the run up to this country's May 10 presidential election is an indication that bilateral cooperation will not be affected by the transition of power.

After bidding farewell at the airport to a high-level Paraguayan delegation heading to the 10th ROC-Paraguay Economic Cooperation Conference, slated for Thursday and Friday in Taipei, Liu told CNA that the visit to Taiwan is significant at a time when the transition of power is taking place in Paraguay.

The set policy of the ROC government, the ambassador said, is to assist Taiwan businesses in establishing production and trade centers in Paraguay in order to explore opportunities in the Southern Common Market.
As Paraguay is keen to lure Taiwan investment, Liu said the meeting will allow the two countries to formulate mutually beneficial cooperative projects.
Meanwhile, the 13-member delegation, led by Paraguayan Industry and Commerce Minister Atilio Fernandez, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Wednesday for a weeklong visit.

The group will visit President Lee Teng-hui and other ranking government officials, including Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang, Foreign Minister Jason Hu, and Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY DEFENDS LAFAYETTE FRIGATES' PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: The Navy General Headquarters (NGH) on Tuesday defended the anti-submarine capabilities of its newly acquired Lafayette-class frigates, saying their equipment is among the world's most advanced.

The NGH was commenting on a newspaper report which questioned the Lafayette frigates' combat capabilities. The report claimed that the French-built warship is not equipped with torpedo detectors and that its sonar system can only monitor movements of old-fashioned five-propeller submarines.

In response, the NGH said the Lafayette-class frigates are armed with state-of-the-art torpedo monitoring and warning systems which can effectively detect various types of surface and underwater vessels, including both nuclear-powered and conventional submarines.

Moreover, the NGH said, anti-submarine warfare calls for three-dimensional combat strategy and tactics. It requires oceanographic, seabed geologic and hydrological knowledge, and success in anti-submarine warfare hinges on a number of key elements, including manpower, equipment, experience and the establishment of a sound-sampling databank.

The NGH further said the highly sophisticated sonar system installed on the Lafayette frigates can accurately detect the positioning of an incoming torpedo based on the noise emitted from its propellers.

Noting that soundwave databanks play a crucial role in anti-submarine warfare, the NGH said all countries classify such assets as top secret and do not share the information. "Following years of efforts, the ROC Navy has managed to establish a large sound-sampling databank," the NGH said, adding that Taiwan residents should not doubt the Navy's defense capabilities, including its anti-submarine capacity.

Taiwan struck a US$2.8 billion deal with France in 1992 for the purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates as part of its 10-year military modernization plan. The frigates, also reputed as "stealth" warships for their special hull design and ability to evade radar detection, have all been commissioned into service in the ROC Navy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSENT TO EXILE FOR PARENTS' SAKE: WANG DAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 21 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Wang Dan, the 29-year-old mainland Chinese dissident who has just been exiled to the United States on medical parole, said that he only consented to this arrangement for his parents' health and their peace of mind.
Wang, a leader of the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement, made the remark in an exclusive interview published in the Hong Kong-based Oriental Daily News on Tuesday.

Wang noted that during his days in the Jinzhou Municipal Prison, Liaoning Province, his parents had to travel over land and water from the faraway capital of Beijing to visit him, which he said made him worry about their safety and health. In order to get rid of this pressure, according the daily, Wang succumbed to the harsh reality and wrote to the mainland Ministry of Justice, asking to be transferred to a prison in Beijing. He then prepared for being exiled "on medical parole."
"Each time I saw my parents travel so far to visit me, I felt so sorry for them," said Wang.
Wang said he hopes his mother will get a visa to meet him in the United States in two months.
Commenting on his eight years in prison, Wang said that reading a lot helped broaden his horizons and enrich his knowledge and so was what he treasured most during those years.

Wang was one of the leaders of the 1989 student movement in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. After he was imprisoned, it was reported that he refused to accept medical parole to leave mainland China. The fact that this ended up being how he left mainland China had sparked much speculation in Hong Kong's media about the real reasons behind his departure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONCERNED ABOUT JAPANESE ECONOMY

TEXT.P: P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said on Tuesday the ROC government is concerned about economic development in Japan.

Chiang made the remarks after the Swiss-based Institute for International Management Development unveiled a report that lists Taiwan 16th in the world in terms of national competitiveness, surpassing Japan's 18th ranking for the first time.

Chiang said although the showing reflects well on Taiwan's efforts over the past year, he nevertheless believes that a continuing slump in Japan, which has long been the locomotive of regional development, will have a profound spillover effect on Taiwan's economic and trade performance.

Noting that Tokyo has unveiled a series of economic stimulus measures, including an unprecedented 16 trillion yen (US$120 billion) incentive package earlier this month, Chiang said the effects remain to be seen. He noted that some Japanese lawmakers have said the government's remedies have come too late.
Meanwhile, with an eye on Tokyo's actions, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) will map out a plan by the end of the month to promote trade opportunities for Taiwan businessmen.

BOFT officials said money earmarked for public-sector spending under the measures announced in Japan can prove lucrative for Taiwan's telecommunications, communications and environmental protection industries, while a tax cut plan under that package will increase the Japanese public's purchasing power for Taiwan-made consumer goods, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS GRENADA FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui told Raphael Fletcher, Grenada's minister of foreign affairs, legal affairs and local government, on Tuesday that the Republic of China is willing to provide its development experience to the Caribbean nation.
Lee made the remarks while he was introducing the economic development of the nation to Fletcher at the Presidential Office.
Lee said that the island has successfully transformed itself from an agrarian society to an industrial one, and that this is the result of efforts by the government and the private sector.

He noted that Taiwan is continuing to enjoy steady growth despite the Asian financial turmoil that began to sweep through the region in mid-1997, and he attributed this to the island having a sound economic structure.

The president said that half a century ago Taiwan's economy was based on agriculture, but he noted that electronics and machinery have come to replace rice, bananas and sugar as the backbone of Taiwan's exports.
These developments demonstrate that the nation has followed the right path, Lee said, adding that Taiwan is willing to share its experience with Grenada.
Fletcher arrived here Sunday for a six-day visit. During his stay here, he has also visited the Synchrotron Radiation Research Center in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG'S RELEASE SEEN AS POSITIVE STEP FOR HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The US government on Monday described as "a good thing" the release of prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan, and indicated that Washington would keep up pressure on Beijing to improve its human rights record.

Answering questions at a regular press briefing, State Department spokesman James Rubin pointed out that the United States has long urged the Beijing government to release political prisoners like Wang, who had been imprisoned twice since 1989.
"To the extent that this release ... indicates a willingness on the part of the Chinese government to respond to our urgings on human rights, that is a good thing, " he said.

It has been widely speculated that the decision to release Wang was carefully timed in order to create a cordial atmosphere for Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's visit to Beijing later this month and for President Bill Clinton's summit meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in June.
To this, Rubin said that if these meetings gave the leaders in Beijing a reason to do something that they might not otherwise wish to do, "then our engagement is working."
There is also fear that, by making well-known leaders of the pro-democracy movement leave the country, the Beijing authorities have managed to divert attention away from the human rights agenda.

Rubin said, however, that it was preferable for Wang and Wei Jingsheng, another well-known mainland Chinese dissident released last November, to be out of prison. "They are in the United States where they are able to speak out freely, and that is certainly much better than ... when they were in prison languishing and unable to speak freely."

While welcoming the release of Wang and Beijing's apparently greater tolerance of dissent, Rubin said the US government believed that there were many other political prisoners in mainland China. "There is a long, long way to go if China is to enter the mainstream of nations that provide democratic freedoms to their people, " he said.
Rubin made the remarks as Wang was spending his first full day of freedom in the United States and as doctors at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit gave him a clean bill of health.

The 29-year-old former student leader of the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement arrived in Detroit on Sunday from Beijing after being released from prison and sent into exile by the mainland authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEMENS ORGANIZES HIGH-SPEED RAIL TEST RIDE

TEXT.P: The German-based Siemens company will organize a test run for the Taiwan High-Speed Railway Consortium (THSRC) on May 4 on a section of rail between Guettingen and Hannover.

A spokesman for Siemens told CNA that about 200 guests from Taiwan, Germany and France will be invited to take the test ride, including Republic of China's Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Feng-cheng and Germany's Economics Minister Guenter Rexrodt.

The geographical features of the section between Guettingen and Hannover are considered similar to those of the planned high-speed railway in Taiwan. The guests will also experience the ride on a specially designed train which features German-made ICE locomotives and French-made TGC coaches.

Construction on the 345-kilometer high-speed railway, which will run from Taipei in northern Taiwan to the southern city of Kaohsiung, is expected to start in July. The THSRC, the general contractor for the project, comprises the European firms Siemens and GEC Alsthom, as well as Taiwan's Continental Engineering Corp., Fubon Group, Evergreen Group, and Pacific Electric Wire and Cable Group.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNITED STATES SET TO APPEAL WTO RULING

TEXT.P: The United States is all set to appeal the recent World Trade Organization (WTO) ruling in favor of India and other countries on shrimp farming, according to reports by the Geneva-based world trade body Monday.

India had complained to the WTO panel last year that its shrimp exports had been badly hit since the United States imposed an embargo in October 1996 under a unilateral law requiring shrimp nets to be fitted with a special device to protect sea turtles.
India said it is opposed the embargo as "a matter of principle," claiming the US law represents a form of trade barrier.

"Shrimp is one of the significant items on our export list. Shrimping is a labor-intensive industry that employs hundreds of thousands of people," an Indian diplomat said. The US demand, he said, "would have had a significant impact if allowed to stand."
US officials, stating that Washington is likely to appeal the preliminary ruling, said they were also deliberating several other options.
Those options include simply disregarding the report, which would lead to fines, or other punitive measures against offenders of the US turtle protection law.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP AGAIN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed low on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 68.36 points to close at 8,440.2.
Dealers said the market was affected by a heavy drop in industrial shares but that a gain in electronics stocks checked the fall of the index, which plunged more than 100 points after mid-session.
The bourse opened at 8,513.53 and experienced a high of 8,596.21 and a low of 8,371.64.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 367 to 81, with 35 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 2.37 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$139.72 (US$4.23 billion), increasing from the previous trading session, which saw 1.97 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$123.4 billion.

Seven of the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper shares plunging the most at 2.1 percent, followed by construction stocks at 2.1 percent, cement issues at 1.7 percent, textile shares at 1.6 percent, both foodstuff stocks and bank and insurance issues at 1.4 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 1.0 percent.
Only the electrical category saw an upturn, registering a gain of 0.4 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Tuesday's trading were ASE, Ever Fortune Industries, ACER, Compal Electronic Inc., United Micro Electronics, Kuo Feng Corp., Mitac International Corp., Winbond Electronics Corp., Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and Chuntex Electronic.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN SAID HELPFUL TO CROSS-STRAIT EQUILIBRIUM

TEXT.P: Arms sales to Taiwan can help maintain stability in the Taiwan Strait, and allow both parties in the dialogue over the future of one China to participate as equals, Peter Brookes, a staff member with the US House International Relations Committee, wrote in the latest issue of Defense News weekly.
The White House is holding its annual talks with Taipei in Washington to discuss what types of armaments should be sold to Taiwan.

In light of recent events, including the upcoming summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, there is concern this issue will become overly politicized and the White House may decide to curtail arms sales to Taiwan in a gesture of political goodwill to Beijing, Brookes noted.
But he said any decision of this sort would set a dangerous precedent, be inherently bad policy and potentially destabilize relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Last year, the joint statement issued at the conclusion of the official US visit by Jiang Zemin emphasized that the Taiwan issue is "the most important and sensitive central question" in relations between Washington and Beijing.

While the United States reiterated its adherence to the "one China" policy set forth in a series of communiques, it did not mention the Taiwan Relations Act. That legislation stipulates the United States will "provide Taiwan with arms of a defensive character" to "enable Taiwan to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability" in an effort "to help maintain peace, security and stability in the Western Pacific."

Brookes opined that a deviation from this long-standing policy, and attempts at a grand bargain on Taiwan promoted recently by some former US government officials, increases the likelihood of further upsetting the political and military balance of power across the Taiwan Strait, and of involving the United States in unnecessary hostilities between mainland China and Taiwan.

The United States, in accordance with public law and prudent policy, should continue to provide Taiwan with the necessary defensive arms to ensure the future of Taiwan will be determined by peaceful means, wrote Brookes.

A failure to allow Taiwan to continue to procure high-quality American military armaments will permit Beijing to further isolate Taipei and increase mainland China's perception that the Taiwan question can be resolved through military force if necessary. The promotion of this ill-founded belief is dangerous to all parties, he added.

Brookes stressed that the United States should be resolute in its message to Beijing that, in accordance with US law and policy as embodied in the letter and spirit of the Taiwan Relations Act, the future of Taiwan will be settled peacefully. "Continuing defensive arms sales to Taiwan sends that message and helps assure its likelihood," he concluded

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SEEN AS MAKING STRATEGIC MOVE BY FREEING WANG

TEXT.P: Mainland China, in dire need of foreign capital and technology to maintain economic growth, is seen as making a strategic investment by releasing its most prominent political dissident ahead of a visit by US President Bill Clinton in June.

In an editorial headlined "China Makes a Strategic Investment" on Tuesday, mass-circulation newspaper The Australian says that by releasing Wang Dan, as it recently did with Wei Jingsheng, Beijing can reap a useful feedback from foreign investment because overseas investors may be under the illusion that the Chinese mainland is also making some progress on political reform after its relatively success in economic liberalization.

"But, at the national level, there is no real mood to hear a plurality of political views. Any liberalization is to do with the economy, where the emphasis is keeping growth at high levels," the editorial says.

"China desperately needs to keep foreign investment flowing in; the deluge of money that rolled into China in the early 1990s has waned dramatically in the past two years and the Asian economic downturn of 1997-98 makes it even harder to win new capital," it says.

"In these circumstances, China has made a strategic decision to release Wang Dan. It knows its interests lie in creating a climate as devoid as possible of human rights issues before the June visit of US President Bill Clinton.

"Sending Wang into exile in the United States helps lower the temperature on that front, and offers Australian and other foreign businesses contemplating a China investment at least the illusion of progress on political freedom," it adds.

The editorial noted China is freeing Wang in order to marginalize the dissident leader of the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement, as it did to Wei. Beijing believes Wang will continue to be a symbol for pro-democracy supporters if it keeps the dissident in the mainland.
By exiling both Wang and Wei, Beijing will reduce its pressure on the political front.
But the editorial says both Wang and Wei can still use the Internet to keep in touch with their colleagues "on the inside" to keep up some pressure for real political liberalization.

In another editorial headlined: "Wang Free," by the mass-circulation Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday, it says the release of Wang Dan is designed to appease the United States because Bill Clinton is going to visit Beijing in June.

The editorial criticizes the mainland regime's hypocrisy in the Wang case. It says this is the second release of Wang, who was freed from prison in 1993 after serving four years only because Beijing was bidding for the 2000 Olympic Games.
But Wang was re-arrested and jailed again after mainland China lost to Australia in hosting the Games.
The editorial says the release is good news to Wang and his family. But the timing and circumstance of what really is his exile to the United States is "no cause for celebration."

"It is a cynical and manipulative act by a government so far unable to rule without fear and which regards its power to play with the lives of those it rules as more important than their basic human freedom," the editorial says.
It says Wang's offense has been to demand greater political freedom for mainland Chinese, and an end to official corruption and special privileges for the Communist Party elites.
"These are normal political demands and in a normal society it would not be forbidden to give expression to them," the editorial says.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.076 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at NT$32.967.
The greenback opened at 33.011 and was traded between 32.951 and 33.045.
The interbank trading reached US$348.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAN LOOKS FORWARD TO RETURNING TO M'LAND 'SOON'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D. C., April 20 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Newly released mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan told his mainland compatriots Monday that he is looking forward to returning to his homeland soon and "working together with you to build a democratic, civilized and prosperous China."
In a statement to Radio Free Asia, Wang expressed gratitude to his supporters in mainland China. The brief interview was the first he has given media since arriving in the United States on Sunday.

"It was your kindness and sense of justice that kept me going and kept me calm while I was in prison. Now I am free, but my heart is not at peace," he said in the interview at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit. "China is still a big knot in my heart that I can't forget."
At the end of the statement, he asked the mainland Chinese people to "continue to give the kind of support that you gave me to those who are still in prison."

Wang, one of the top student leaders during the massive student protests in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989, was serving an 11-year prison sentence when he was released on what the Beijing authorities described as medical parole.

Radio Free Asia is a private corporation established in 1996 to provide news and information to listeners in mainland China, Tibet, Vietnam, Burma, North Korea, Laos and Cambodia. Funded by grants from the US Congress, Radio Free Asia's mission is to be a forum for a variety of opinions and voices from within Asian nations whose people do not have full freedom of expression.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, SLOVAKIA TO SIGN MOU ON CUSTOMS COOPERATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the Slovak Republic have decided to sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on customs cooperation on Friday.

The decision was made after a meeting Tuesday between Jan De-ho, head of the Directorate General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance, and his Slovak counterpart, the visiting Jaromir Kaliciak, director general of Slovak Customs.

Accompanied by his colleague Alexander Vajda, director of Slovakia's international affairs office, Kaliciak arrived in Taipei on April 19 for a six-day visit. The two paid a courtesy call on Jan at his office and exchanged views on matters of mutual concern, including customs cooperation.

During their stay in Taiwan, the Slovak officials will visit the Board of Foreign Trade, Ministry of Economic Affairs and other related agencies. They will also make firsthand studies of the operations of the customs bureaus in Keelung, Taipei and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEXICAN 'WOLF MAN' ON SIX-MONTH TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Jesus Manuel Fajardo Aceves, a 24-year-old Mexican man whose face is shrouded in thick, dark hair, has been called a "wolf man" since his childhood becasue of his unique appearance.
The legendary "wolf man" is currently on a six-month goodwill visit in Taiwan at the invitation of the Guinness World of Records Museum in Taichung in central Taiwan.

According to the museum, Fajardo is a victim of hirsutism, a genetically inherited disorder which was passed down by his great grandmother. The museum said he comes from the world's only known family with living members who have the condition. His parents and daughter do not have the disorder.
Fajardo, who stands only 160 cm tall, met the local press at a news conference held at Taipei's Rebar Holiday Inn Crown Plaza on Tuesday.

Despite his extraordinary appearance, Fajardo said he is virtually a normal man who yearns for making friends with other people. Because of his hairy face, Fajardo said few of his Mexican compatriots would make friends with him.

Fajardo further said he takes great interest in reading, watching television, listening to music and playing football. He became a circus performer shortly after his graduation from a primary school at age of 13. With a scant income, Fajardo said he has been unable to continue his study. "One of my dreams is to receive higher-level education."

During his years as a circus acrobat, Fajardo once married a beautiful woman. But the marriage lasted for only two years. Before coming to Taiwan, Fajardo had lived together with his mother and five-year-old daughter in a Mexican village. His family now makes living on farming.
Fajardo said he is satisfied with his current living and has no intention to seek a change to his face. "I have got accustomed to my disorder. I have no plan to seek a cure."
Tai Sheng-yi, chairman of the Guinness Taichung museum, said Fajardo is a shy, quiet and polite man. "Although Fajardo looks a bit wild and weird, he has a decent demeanor."
Tai said the museum has prepared an European-style living quarter for the Mexican "wolf man." Local people are welcome to visit Fajardo during his six-month stay at the museum.
While here, Fajardo is scheduled to visit some ROC government officials. This will be his longest overseas trip. He once visited Japan and Brazil, but only stayed there for about two weeks.
Carlos Santos, Mexican representative to the Republic of China, who was also present at Tuesday's news conference, said he hopes Fajardo's visit will help boost bilateral cultural exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY DELEGATION TO ARRIVE IN TAIPEI ON WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: Paraguay's delegation to the 10th ROC-Paraguayan Conference on Economic Cooperation left Asuncion on Monday afternoon and will arrive in Taipei Wednesday night for a week-long stay.
The delegation, headed by Paraguay's Industry and Trade Minister Atilio Fernandez, is composed of 13 high ranking government officials, including Dario Peralta, Gerardo Lopez and James Spalding.

During their stay in the Republic of China, they will meet with ROC President Lee Teng-hui, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng, Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Lin Shiang-nung and other ROC government officials.
The delegation is scheduled to leave Taipei on April 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU FEELS IMPACT OF REGIONAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: Macau is currently experiencing a period of economic difficulties exacerbated by the regional economic and financial crisis, said Vitor Rodrigues Pessoa, Macau's secretary of economic coordination.

Pessoa told the some 100 delegates at the second day of the 54th meeting of the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific that "these difficulties have been particularly noticeable in the tourism sector, now the territory's main activity sector, as reflected in the drop in the number of visitors ... last year."
The Asian financial crisis, however, has not affected the stability of the local currency, Pessoa said.
"Given its peg to the Hong Kong dollar, it appreciated considerably in relation to other currencies in the region," he noted.

But Macau's exports have been affected by the strength of its currency. "In terms of the manufacturing sector -- which is almost entirely geared toward exports given the small level of domestic demand -- the competitiveness of the territory's products in the world markets has been clearly affected," he said.
The official said despite growth of around 8 percent in value in 1997, a slackening in exports is expected this year.
Macau is scheduled to end over four centuries of Portuguese rule and become a Special Administrative Region of mainland China on Dec. 20, 1999.
Beijing has pledged to allow Macau to retain its economic, social, executive, legislative and judicial systems for at least 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID SEEKING MORE US SUPPORT BY RELEASING WANG DAN

TEXT.P: Beijing will use mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan's release to press for more US support in the international debates over Taiwan and Tibet and in transfers of high technology, according to commentaries in the regional media Monday.
The freeing of Wang also shows Washington was right to stay "engaged" with Beijing, the commentaries said, noting that this brought about concrete negotiations leading to his release on Sunday.

Most Asian editorials pointed out that the release should improve Beijing-Washington relations and help mainland China gain more support from the United States in international debates over Taiwan and Tibet, as well as facilitate the technology transfers that mainland China needs to upgrade its fledgling economy, The Straits Times reported Tuesday.
Wang, 29, was freed on medical parole and sent directly from a Beijing prison to a US hospital in Detroit, Michigan, for a medical checkup. He was reported to be in good health.

Hong Kong's Chinese-language Ming Pao Daily News was quoted as commenting: "To enable the Sino-US ties to grow smoothly, Beijing needed to make some concessions by improving its human-rights record. The release of Wang Dan prior to Clinton's China visit in June is a gift for the US President, so that he can claim some credit from the American people."
On whether the move indicates Beijing has eased up on political dissent, the views were mixed, the report said.
Hong Kong's Sing Tao Daily said that the mere fact that Wang was released on medical parole does not prove that human rights have improved in mainland China.

But Malaysia's Sin Chew Jit Poh said in its editorial Monday that Wang's release demonstrates more flexibility on the part of mainland China's new leaders in dealing with dissidents and human rights problems, as compared to the past.
"It also reflects the positive results of China's reforms," the editorial was quoted as commenting.
Similarly, the Hong Kong Economic Journal said, the mainland Chinese authorities had made "a wise decision," no matter what their motives were.
It also said that the development shows that mainland China is more open now and that Beijing leaders have more confidence in themselves.
A South China Morning Post editorial said that mainland China's human rights situation is slowly improving.

"The pace of change may not be rapid. But nor is it glacial, as a combination of steady pressure ... and the emergence of a more pragmatic Beijing leadership begins to have its effect," it was quoted as commenting.

In Singapore, both The Straits Times and the Chinese-language Lianhe Zaobao, as well as Singapore television and radio stations, reported on Wang's release and his arrival in Detroit on Sunday. But the local media has not yet editorialized on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS INTERESTS SHOULD BE ON TALKS AGENDA

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Hsu Ke-sheng said on Tuesday that Taiwan and mainland China should hold talks to discuss the issue of the personal and property safety of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China.

Following the recent murder of Yeh Jung-Fu, a knitted garment maker from Kaohsiung, in Quanzhou, Fujian Province last week, Hsu said the government should seek to increase the protection of Taiwan business interests in the mainland through negotiation with the relevant mainland authorities.

The MAC official made the remarks here while presiding over a seminar for local businessmen based in southern Taiwan. More than 200 people, including members of the local business community and Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, took part in the event.

Although some local businessmen disagree with the government's "no haste, be patient" policy governing Taiwan investment in the mainland, Hsu said the policy is aimed only at high-end and infrastructure investment projects worth more than US$50 million, while other types of investment are not subject to the same regulations. The major purpose of the policy, he noted, is to strengthen Taiwan industries and protect the safety of Taiwan investors in the mainland.

Over the past ten years, Taiwan people have made a total of 13 million visits to mainland China, while the number of visits by mainland people to Taiwan has reached around 250,000, Hsu pointed out, adding that the mainland has become Taiwan's largest investment destination, absorbing 40 percent of Taiwan's total overseas investment.

With tensions escalating in two-way relations in recent years following the mainland's missile tests and military exercises in the Taiwan Strait, he called on local businesses to continue supporting the government's mainland investment policy and urged Beijing to resolve bilateral disputes peacefully.

Hailing Taiwan investors as the major force in promoting friendly cross-strait ties, Kaohsiung Mayor Wu for his part urged local entrepreneurs to engage in legitimate business in the mainland, thereby making it easier for the government to help protect their business interests there.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION INDEX KEEPS GROWING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Tuesday announced that the industrial production index for March this year has reached 137.99 points, the third-highest level of growth for a single month.

However, the MOEA statistics show that factors such as a reduction of exports to Southeast Asia and South Korea mean that the growth rate is only 3.9 percent up on the corresponding year-earlier level.

Compared with the same period of last year, the statistics show that the production index of manufacturing industries in March increased by 4.36 percent; water, electricity, fuel oil and gas industries were up 7.45 percent; while housing and construction industries plunged by 22.14 percent; and mining industries were reduced by 13.19 percent.

Comparing the first three months of this year with the same period of last year, growth was slower, with industrial production increasing by 4.48 percent, in which manufacturing industries increased by 5 percent, an average increase of 7.86 percent.

Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, attributed the increase in the production index of manufacturing industries to the 17.37 percent growth enjoyed by the electrical and electronics appliances industries, following double-digit growth last year.

Faced with the current trend toward low-priced computers, Chang said, manufacturers have expanded their production capacities to meet the growing demand for IT products such as semiconductors and notebook computers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 16TH IN WORLD COMPETITIVENESS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 21 (CNA) (By Maurus Yang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked 16th in the 1998 world competitiveness rating, moving up seven notches from its 1997 ranking, according to a report released by the Lausanne-based International Institute for Management and Development (IMD) on Monday.
Taiwan was two places ahead of Japan in the IMD World Competitive Yearbook annual rankings. Japan ranked 18th this year, down from ninth in 1997.

The Swiss institute compares the competitiveness of 46 economies by measuring economic strength, the domestic economy's openness to international trade, government efficiency, financial services, infrastructure, management, science and technology, education and training. The study defines national competitiveness as a country's ability to help keep businesses competitive.

Taiwan made progress in all but one category -- the domestic economy's openness to international trade or internationalization. Taiwan's "internationalization" ranking dropped from 30th in 1997 to 32nd this year. The slight drop might be related to a sharp decline in Taiwan's trade surplus, its restrictions on trade with mainland China and its currency's depreciation.

Taiwan performed best in the management and science-technology categories. Its ranking for management climed to seventh from 18th last year, and its rating for science-technology also advanced to seventh from 1997's 10th place.

Meanwhile, Taiwan ranked eighth in terms of economic strength in the IMD 1998 world rating, 14th in government efficiency, 19th in financial services, 26th in infrastructure, 18th in education and training.
The United States held on to its No. 1 place thanks to free market policies like privatization and a flexible labor market, the IMD report said.
Singapore and Hong Kong held second and third places this year, as they did in 1997. Mainland China jumped to 24th from 27th place in 1997. In contrast, South Korea plunged five places to 35th.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN GOV'T SHOULD SHOW SUPPORT FOR WANG DAN: DAILY

TEXT.P: A Canadian newspaper on Tuesday urged the Chretien government to show support for Wang Dan, the recently released mainland Chinese dissident.
"Let's call China's 'release' of dissident Wang Dan what it is: expulsion and exile, punishment for political speech," The Ottawa Citizen said in an editorial.

The Citizen called Wang a "pawn in a cynical game," noting that he is the second prominent dissident to be released (after Wei Jingsheng) shortly before planned meetings between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese leaders. Beijing hopes to buy favors from the West through the high-profile timing of such releases, it said.

Though the strategy has succeeded, the United States still speaks out about mainland China's situation, according to the editorial. Clinton said he believes mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is "on the wrong side of history" in suppressing the basic rights of mainland Chinese citizens, it noted. Clinton also met with Wei after his release, it pointed out.

Canada's prime minister, by contrast, spurned Wei during the dissident's recent visit to Ottawa, the Citizen said. And in November, Chretien refused to meet Harry Wu, another high-profile activist for more human rights in mainland China, it added.
The Citizen wondered whether Chretien will "snub" Wang as well.

It stated that Canadians believe their government has a role to play in defending human rights. "Here's an idea for the PM: Why not invite Mr. Wang for a visit and a handshake -- as the TV cameras roll?" the Citizen suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ONE OF ASIA'S LOWEST-RISK BUSINESS ENVIRONMENTS: SURVEY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 21 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the fourth-safest Asian economy in which to do business, behind only Singapore, Hong Kong and Japan, according to a respected Hong Kong public opinion poll company.

In its 1998 Comparative Country Risk report, the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd. (PERC) said: "The biggest change in our model has been the fall in risk in the Sino economies and the rise in risk in Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries" over the past year.
PERC attributed the lower risk in Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China to "the improved systemic and socio-political situation."
On the other hand, Indonesia and Vietnam have experienced the biggest deterioration in risk, said PERC, which advises corporations on business conditions in the region.

A total of 12 countries and areas in Asia were graded on the basis of such factors as market size, economic dynamics, systemic deficiencies, socio-political risks, corruption, level economic playing fields, bureaucracy and labor force quality.

Singapore, which has weathered the regional financial turmoil well, thanks to its strong fundamentals, was ranked as the lowest-risk country, with a score of 3.04 (on a country-risk scale of zero to 10, with zero representing the best possible grade).

Singapore was followed in descending order by Hong Kong, Japan, Taiwan, mainland China, Malaysia, South Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, India, and Indonesia, with Vietnam at the bottom with a score of 7.29, the PERC survey showed.
On corruption, Singapore and Hong Kong came out cleanest, while Indonesia and Thailand were rated as places where bribery of officials is most rampant.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FARMERS TO MOBILIZE MEN TO MOVE FARM PRODUCT FOR EXPORT

TEXT.P: Australian farmers, hit hard by the waterfront war, on Tuesday demanded that the government take tough measures against union workers picketing and blocking major ports throughout the country, and they vowed to mobilize men to move their farm products for export to Asia and elsewhere.

Wendy Crank, spokeswoman for the National Farmers Federation (NFF), said NFF members are determined to mobilize to break through the picket lines of fired union workers so that their produce can be exported.
NFF Chairman Don McGauchie called on Australian police to do "what they're required to do, and that is allow people to go about their lawful business."

"There is no right in a peaceful protest to block road access to people going about their ordinary and lawful business," he said in Brisbane, one of the major ports facing a wave of picket lines from the fired workers of Patrick Stevedores, one of the two leading stevedoring firms at the center of the waterfront dispute. Patrick fired all 1,400 of its full-time union workers and another 600 part-time workers less than two weeks ago.
The Victorian Supreme Court handed down a decision Monday to ban the blockade on the Melbourne Port and ordered police to remove the picketers.
But the Melbourne Port, like other ports, was unable to operate because the number of picketers greatly exceeded that of policemen, making it very difficult for police to move the protesting workers.
McGauchie said farmers are prepared to use their own trucks to get through pickets in Western Australia, New South Wales and Victoria by the end of this week.
Industry sources and government officials are worried that the NFF's "get tough stance" may result in bloodshed between farmers and picketers if the showdown gets out of control.
Prime Minister John Howard said Tuesday that he understands and sympathizes with the farmers' anxiety at being unable to export their farm produce.

Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith on Tuesday condemned the president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) for her active support of the sacked union workers blocking most of the ports across the country.

Public opinion polls on Tuesday showed that about 50 percent of people surveyed support Patrick's plans to improve the container handling rate at major ports. But the polls also showed that many do not support the way Patrick and the Howard government have treated the union workers.

Most of those polled did not approve of the illegal picketing strategy used by the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA), which is behind the powerful force against Patrick's and the government's waterfront reform efforts.

The MUA is supported by the ACTU, the biggest union group in Australia, and other union groups in the Down Under, as well as some international groups in the United States, Britain, Belgium and Japan.

On Monday, the waterfront dispute started taking a toll on P&O Ports, Australia's biggest stevedoring firm, when its union workers walked off their jobs for an hour to join the picket line at the Fremantle Port in Western Australia.
Both P&O and Patrick handle about 95 percent of containerized cargoes at major ports in Australia. Now P&O is doing some of Patrick's operations in addition to its own.
If more union workers from P&O Ports also walk off their jobs, then Australian exports and imports will be paralyzed, industry analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTNERSHIP FORGED TO TRAIN AVIATION TALENT

TEXT.P: Ho Ming-liang, deputy director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), said on Monday that the government and the private sector should work together to grab a slice of the lucrative global aviation market.

Ho made the remarks following a signing ceremony marking the establishment of an alliance to train aviation talent in southern Taiwan between the IDB and private-sector organizations, including the Aviation and Aerospace Institute under the Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University and the Air Asia Co., Ltd.

Sources familiar with the aviation industry estimate that the world's demand for passenger airplanes will hit around 4,000 units in the next 15 years, with Asian markets accounting for around 2,000 units. In terms of airplane manufacturing value, the US market will generate US$330 billion, while Europe and Asia will be worth US$200 billion and US$310 billion, respectively.

The sources forecast a serious shortfall in the manpower supply for the aviation industry in southern Taiwan in the coming years, which is the reason behind the MOEA's efforts to forge a partnership with the private sector to jointly cultivate new blood.

The MOEA is currently inviting the private sector to join forces in a capital increment plan for an airplane repair and maintenance center, which has been devised in line with the government's desire to set up a "special aviation industry complex in southern Taiwan" with the goal of building Taiwan into an airplane repair and maintenance hub in the Asia-Pacific region.
In addition, a planned "intelligent" industrial park to be located in Luchu township, Kaohsiung County, will also focus on the production of airplane key parts and components.

DOC.HEADLINE: DECLINING SOCIAL ORDER PROMPTS TAIWANESE PROTESTS IN SOUTH AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, April 21 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A group of more than 30 Taiwan manufacturers stationed in eastern South Africa will start a campaign Thursday to protest the fact that their property and personal safety have been put in jeopardy with the decline in social order in the country.

The move was prompted by a robbery and murder on Friday in the Isithebe industrial district in Natal Province, eastern South Africa, when a Taiwan businessman was shot dead after being robbed by three local persons at his factory.
The victim was identified as 47-year-old Wang Neng-shi, who set up the Chinatown Garment Manufacturers company in the industrial district, and employed around 400 South African people.

According to the Taipei Representative Office in Durban, in addition to the planned protest on Thursday in Isithebe, all the Taiwan-owned plants there will close for a week -- an act aimed at emphasizing to the local authorities that no time should be wasted in stopping the rot in the social order.

Taipei Representative Office Director Lin Sung-huan on Tuesday accompanied Wang's family and representatives of the Taiwan enterprises in Natal Province on a visit to the Natal police authorities and administrators of the Isithebe industrial district.
Wang said that during the visit they voiced their hopes that the industrial zone can be protected from crime and that the local police can arrest the three murderers as soon as possible.
The opposition Inkatha Freedom Party of South Africa also released a statement warning that the murder case will have a heavy negative impact on Natal's foreign investment and tourism development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO SIDES OF STRAIT STILL DIFFER DESPITE RESUMPTION OF TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China are to resume talks this week following a lapse of about three years, though no sudden breakthrough is expected because the two sides of the Taiwan Strait remain unable to see eye to eye, especially in terms of sovereignty, according to The Australian Financial Review.
In a dispatch from Hong Kong, the review's correspondent Rowan Callick reported that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are preparing for their first serious talks in three years.
He noted, however, that "after 49 years of separation, no sudden breakthrough is expected."

Each side has much to gain from regularizing relations, including making life easier for the thousands of Taiwanese managers supervising more than US$27 billion in investment in small and medium-sized businesses all over mainland China, he said.
He noted that the talks will begin modestly, with middle-ranking officials from the surrogate contact-making bodies established by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, meeting in Beijing this week.
"But the big picture presents a gap oceans wider than the Taiwan Strait," Callick said.

The mainland is offering Taiwan a status similar to that of Hong Kong under the "one country, two systems" structure, with the island being allowed to keep its own military, the daily reported. Under this plan, however, Beijing would have sovereignty over Taiwan.
On the other hand, Taiwan's goal is "democratic reunification," which would require the Chinese Communist Party to take its chances with competitors in democratic elections.

Beijing is eager to focus first on the big picture. Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin sees reunification as his route to a place in the history books and he doesn't need to consult anyone to cut a deal, the daily reported.

But the 21 million Taiwanese are in a different boat. President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China -- who has already booked his place in history as Taiwan's first directly elected leader -- saw his party suffer a devastating loss in mayoral and county head elections last November when the independence-inclined Democratic Progressive Party won 72 percent of the seats.

The daily said the ROC's ruling Kuomintang staged a comeback in an ensuing poll for councilors but that the talks with mainland China will be a crucial issue in the parliamentary election in December.

The daily reported Taiwan has continued opening its market wider and that such economic clout is opening doors throughout troubled Asia, much to the irritation of Beijing, which has been seeking to leverage a role as the effective regional leader out of its defense of a strong currency that has helped prevent further economic collapse in the region.
The daily reported Beijing's adherence to the "one country, two systems" formula in Hong Kong helps its cause with Taiwan but will not convince Taipei to concede a return to provincial status.
The daily reported the Taiwanese are fully aware of the challenges mainland China still faces as it seeks to modernize.
Most Taiwanese were born on the island and feel that mainland China is like another country, the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON'S BEIJING SUMMIT `IDEAL' WTO TARGET

TEXT.P: The mainland China-US summit in June offers an "ideal target" to bring Beijing into the World Trade Organization (WTO), but negotiations still have a long way to go, according to a report on Tuesday from the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.
US President Bill Clinton is due to visit Beijing in late June for a summit with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

Meanwhile, US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky is scheduled to visit Beijing later this month, and US officials are urging Beijing to be ready for intensive and very significant negotiations during this visit, so that they can move as far down this road as possible -- ideally towards agreement.
Beijing is playing what it believes is a new trump card in its 11-year battle to join the WTO -- its public pledge not to devalue its currency and make the Asian financial crisis even worse.

Mainland China's leaders argue that Beijing is making a tough sacrifice by maintaining a strong currency and thereby making its exports less competitive, and they suggest that WTO entry should be a reward for this.
A week ago, Beijing's top WTO negotiator Long Yungtu attacked "certain members" of the WTO for "excessive requests" on Beijing's entry.
"Now it is time that the major WTO players demonstrate some degree of responsibility towards China's WTO accession," Long said in Geneva.
Long also played down hopes for a quick breakthrough, saying: "We cannot solve everything with a presidential visit."

The latest round of WTO negotiations in Geneva ended with little progress. Western trade officials expressed disappointment at mainland China's latest tariff cut offer and its failure to propose a further opening of its services market.
Mainland China has sought to enter the world trade body on the easier terms accorded to developing countries, but many WTO contracting parties say Beijing's economy is too large for such treatment.
US trade officials said WTO agreement "will require Chinese agreement to accession on terms that are commercially acceptable and commercially valid."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA DEVISES PROTECTIVE MEASURES FOR TAIWAN RICE

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Executive Yuan on Tuesday announced measures to narrow the gap between prices for imported and domestic rice.

The COA noted that under the protective measures, which are based on an agreement reached with the United States following consultations on joining the World Trade Organization (WTO), the upper ceiling for increased prices for foreign rice may reach as high as NT$23.26 per kilogram.

Taiwan must allow the import of foreign rice after entering the WTO, with the first year import volume amounting to 115,000 metric tons, rising to 144,000 metric tons during the third year, by which time the COA estimates that areas devoted to rice cultivation in Taiwan will have been reduced by 32,000 hectares.

To cope with the impact of the imported rice, the COA will hold a meeting every two weeks to review the implementation measures. According to the COA, after the implementation of the protective measures, importers will have to bear the cost of the price add-ons, in addition to paying import costs, customs taxes and transportation fees.

The price add-ons, ranging from NT$0.01 to NT$23.26, will be decided on the basis of the price-gap between the wholesale price of locally produced rice and the price of imported rice, and will be reviewed and readjusted every two weeks.
In order to further reduce the effect of imported rice on domestic foodstuff prices, the government will control about 60 percent of the imported rice.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOPEFUL OF BEING WORLD'S 5TH MOST COMPETITIVE ECONOMY BY 2000

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Tuesday didn't hesitate to show his complacency over Taiwan's improved international competitiveness, up seven notches to 16th place over last year.

According to the latest report published by the Lausanne, Switzerland-based International Institute for Management Development (IMD), Taiwan was the 16th most competitive country in the world in 1997, with stronger economic strength, higher government efficiency, improved business management and better science and technology development than a year ago.

Lien, who made raising Taiwan's national competitiveness one of his administrative goals during his premiership between February 1993 and August 1997, likened his pleasure at seeing Taiwan's rating improve to a father's pleasure at seeing his children's' school scores improve.

The vice president said sharpening a nation's international competitiveness is a task without limits or timetable. He urged all sectors of the nation to make concerted efforts to further raise the ROC's competitiveness, with the goal of making Taiwan the fifth most competitive economy in the world by 2000.

Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew also expressed satisfaction over the ROC's rising competitiveness, which is now even better than the neighboring economic superpower of Japan. Japan's rating dropped nine notches to 18th.

Siew attributed Taiwan's improved competitiveness to its ability to remain relatively unscathed by the regional economic turmoil in Southeast Asia, its strenuous efforts to bolster scientific and technological development, and the constant improvement in government efficiency.
He stressed, however, that Taiwan needs to heed the IMD revelation that the island should open itself further to international trade.

The IMD study compares the competitiveness of 46 countries and areas around the world by measuring economic strength, the domestic economy's openness to international trade, government policies, financial services, infrastructure, management, science and technology, education and training.
It defines national competitiveness as a country's ability to maintain business competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENTS RELEASE PART OF BEIJING PLOT

TEXT.P: Mainland China's regime is implementing economic reforms that have greatly increased many people's freedom to move, choose their own jobs and travel. But despite a few signs of liberalization, freedom of expression, association and belief remain tightly constricted -- a potentially destabilizing combination, commented The Washington Post in a Tuesday editorial.

The paper noted that it was front page news on Monday that mainland China had sent well-known dissident Wang Dan into American exile, just as democracy advocate Wei Jingsheng's release and exile last November was also front page news. But a steady flow of arrests between these two well-publicized releases didn't make the front pages around the country or even a mention in most newspapers.

Among those imprisoned who are not well-known in the West were Yang Qinheng and Father Lu Genyou. The former was sentenced in March to three years' hard labor, apparently for speaking on Radio Free Asia in favor of free unions; the latter, a Catholic priest, was reportedly arrested on April 5 while preparing to lead a mass, according to the editorial.

It added that Wang Dan's release was "part of a delicate unspoken deal" between the administrations of US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin. Clinton dropped America's customary sponsorship of a resolution on mainland China's human rights abuses at an annual UN conference. Jiang sent Wang Dan into exile. Now the way is clear for Clinton's visit to mainland China in June -- the first by a US president since the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989.

Wang Dan was a student leader of the peaceful protest that preceded that crackdown, and as a result was jailed until 1993. Like Wei, Wang Dan had the almost unimaginable courage to resume his pro-democracy activities immediately after his release, despite the near certainty that mainland China's communist regime would jail him again. It did, and he has spent the past three years in jail.

So there can be only joy that he is free, albeit in forced exile, wrote The Washington Post. Yet there is a danger, as mainland China bargains with its dissidents one by one, of losing sight of the thousands of prisoners of conscience who remain in jail or labor camps -- and of those who are added to the prison population week after week.

As Wang Dan wrote in 1995, before his second arrest, mainland China could minimize the danger of social and worker unrest by giving the public "a chance to express its dissatisfaction through democratic channels." But that would carry a different risk -- to the survival of the communist regime. "That's why the regime is still doing what it can to make sure Wang Dan's message won't be heard in his homeland," concluded the editorial.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKERS WANT JAPAN TO COMPENSATE WAR-TIME SEX SLAVES
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 21 (CNA) (By F.M. Chang & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation which has joined legislators from Japan, South Korea and the Philippines for a symposium on Japan's use of sex slaves during World War II, called on Tuesday the Japanese government to officially compensate the women and to issue a formal apology.

According to Alice Kao, a legislator representing Taiwan's opposition New Party, the ROC government has paid NT$1 million (US$37,000), with help from the island's private sector, to each of the surviving Taiwanese women who were forced to be euphemistically named "comfort women" to Japanese soldiers during the war.

The passing of time has left us very little time to give the former sex slaves real legal and moral compensation, Kao said at a press conference prior to the opening of the two-day symposium, hosted by the Japanese Lawyers Association.

Although Taiwan's former comfort women have been financially compensated by their government, Kao said, it is only just that the Japanese government see to it that legislation is passed to officially compensate all the surviving women from all over Asia, and to issue an open, formal apology for the atrocity.

Seven legislators and other representatives from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea and the Philippines at the symposium called at the press conference for the Tokyo government to come up with legislation for compensation, to openly admit Japan's war crimes, to publicize the "real history," and to have the Japanese prime minister issue a formal apology to all the women who are still alive.

According to the lawmakers, there are still 45 living in Taiwan, 152 in South Korea, and 169 in the Philippines, although there could be many more, since many of the victims have kept their silence over the years because of a deep sense of shame.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMANY IS ROC'S BIGGEST EUROPEAN TRADE PARTNER

TEXT.P: Germany remains the Republic of China's biggest trade partner among the countries of Europe, with ROC-Germany bilateral trade amounting to US$1.340 billion in the first two months of 1998, representing 22.4 percent of the ROC's total trade with Europe.

In the January-February period, ROC exports to Germany amounted to US$613.4 million against imports from Germany at US$727.4 million, according to statistics compiled by the Taipei Trade Office in Frankfurt, Germany.
ROC trade with Europe as a whole amounted to US$5.988 billion in the two-month period, accounting for 18.1 percent of the ROC's total foreign trade, and still lagging behind trade with America.

Trade with the European Union (EU) accounted for 89 percent of the ROC's trade with Europe during the period, amounting to US$5.329 billion. Among the EU nations, Germany, the Netherlands, France, Britain and Italy are the leading ROC trade partners.

In East Europe, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic took the lead in ROC trade, accounting for 79 percent of the US$125.7 million total. The potential for bilateral trade between the ROC and East Europe is yet to be fully explored, with trade volume accounting for only 2.1 percent of total ROC-Europe trade.

The trade office pointed out that trade between the ROC and Russia is expected to pick up with the establishment of direct flight links. ROC trade with member states of the Community of Independent States (CIS) in the January-February period amounted to US$250 million, accounting for 4.2 percent of the ROC-Europe trade.

Computers and related products remained the major ROC export items, followed by bicycles and motorcycles. Major items imported by the ROC from Europe included ICs and microelectronics products, radio and television transmission systems, and aviation equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP PUBLICITY CHIEF TO JOIN RACE FOR PARTY CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Sisy Chen, a controversial figure on the island's political stage, on Tuesday revealed that she will run in the May election for chairmanship of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Chen made the remarks during an interview with the United Evening News, in which she also revealed that she has decided not to take part in the year-end legislative election.
Instead, the former director of the DPP's publicity department said she will take part in the May campaign which she cannot possibly win.

Chen explained during the interview that her move to involve herself in the battle, which is expected to be harsh, is aimed at reminding all DPP chairmanship candidates that they should play the role of public opinion leaders.
The DPP heavyweight said that recently she has been disappointed that the desire for political power is overwhelming the country's largest opposition party.

Even if she is elected to serve in the Legislative Yuan, she will still not be able to do anything for the Taiwan public because any moves she makes there will appear to be only gestures, "like reading a bible in a circus," she claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAITI PRESIDENT VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Haiti President Rene Preval arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a four-day official visit.
The Haitian head of state was greeted at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport by Foreign Minister Jason Hu.
During his stay in Taiwan, Preval will call on ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew and will visit various agricultural establishments on the island.

Haiti is one of the 29 nations that maintain diplomatic relations with the Republic of China. In September, 1996, Haiti reached an agreement with mainland China to set up trade offices in each other's territory.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE FOREIGN MINISTER ON LIBERIA VISIT

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Tzu-dan left for Liberia on Wednesday for a 10-day official visit aimed at promoting friendship and cooperation between the Republic of China and the West African state.
During his visit, Wu will attend the first meeting of the ROC-Liberia Mixed Commission, which was founded shortly after Liberian President Charles Taylor's state visit to Taipei last November.
The mixed commission is authorized to chart the direction of future ROC-Liberian cooperation and craft out measures for Taiwan to assist Liberia in its post-civil war reconstruction work.

The ROC and Liberia resumed diplomatic ties in October 1989 after a 12-year hiatus. But a civil war erupted in Liberia late that year and factional confrontation didn't end until last July. The ROC has promised to help its African ally rebuild its battered economy.

The upcoming mixed commission meeting will focus discussions on how the ROC will assist Liberia in its national reconstruction as well as on ways to boost bilateral trade and cooperation in international affairs.

In addition to attending the meeting, Wu will pay courtesy visits to Liberian officials and parliamentary leaders, including President Taylor, speakers of the Senate and House of Representative, foreign minister and economic planning minister. He will also meet with ROC agricultural experts stationed in Liberia as well as ROC expatriates there.
Wu is accompanied by several officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other relevant government agencies. Wu's mission is scheduled to return to Taipei on May 3.
