DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDIA PROTEST AGAINST BEIJING'S COVERAGE RESTRICTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan journalists on Tuesday lodged a stern protest against Beijing imposing a limit on how many of them can cover the news surrounding a Taiwan representative's visit to Beijing, an event that may serve as a key to reopening the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.

Jan Jyh-horng, newly appointed deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the absence of formal contacts, left for Beijing Wednesday morning for consultations on matters of protocol regarding the visit of a Taiwan delegation to mainland China.

The Beijing visit of Jan, who is also director of the Research and Planning Department of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, is a major story in Taiwan because it marks the first contact between the SEF and its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), since Beijing unilaterally suspended the bilateral dialogue in the summer of 1995, 34 months ago.

The Beijing authorities, however, have restricted the number of Taiwan journalists allowed to cover Jan's mainland visit on the grounds that "the meeting venue is limited and it is difficult to arrange accommodations for large number of reporters."

As of Tuesday night, the Beijing authorities had given permission to only some 20 reporters and journalists from Taiwan's three broadcast television stations, including TTV, five of the island's cable TV channels, including TVBS, and several local print media, including CNA, to cover Jan's three-day visit in mainland China.
This number is only about half of the more than 40 applications submitted.

Jan, who is supposed to negotiate procedural matters relating to reciprocal visits between the SEF and ARATS, also expressed dissatisfaction over Beijing's limit on the number of journalists, saying that this will be the first issue he raises when he meets with relevant mainland officials for discussions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FINANCE MINISTER LEAVES FOR SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Paul C.H. Chiu on Wednesday left for Seoul, South Korea, for a conference on the impact of the financial storm on East Asia.

The conference will take place Wednesday and Thursday. Its sponsor, the Financial Times of Britain, has invited a number of ministerial officials in finance and economy from regional countries, as well as scholars and experts in the sectors, to join in discussions on the damage the financial attack has brought South Korea.
South Korea is one of the victims sustaining severe damage from the regional disaster, which started in mid-1997 and is continuing to affect the economic development of most Asian countries.

According to foreign reports, South Korean President Kim Dae-jung, Financial and Economic Minister Lee Kyu-sung and Transportation Minister Park Chung-soo, along with other high-ranking officials, will attend the conference and deliver speeches.
Chiu is scheduled to return home on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASUNCION MAYOR TO VISIT TAIPEI NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: Asuncion Mayor Martin Burt will visit Taipei in late May to attend the World Capitals Forum, slated for May 27, at the invitation of the Taipei City Government.
Burt will arrive in Taipei May 24 and stay there about one week.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPEASING BEIJING IS BIGGEST THREAT TO HUMAN RIGHTS: TIBETAN SPEAKER

TEXT.P: A competition among Western countries to appease mainland China is the biggest threat to human rights because they can only see the mainland as their largest market by ignoring mainland Chinese abuses and violations, a leading Tibetan has warned.

Professor Samdhong Rinpoche, speaker of the Tibetan Parliament in exile at Dharamsala in India, told the Melbourne-based mass circulation newspaper The Age that the biggest threat to human rights is "competition to appease mainland China."

The daily quoted the monk, who ranks behind only the Dalai Lama in the Tibetan government in exile, as saying: "People think China is the most convenient marketplace. Businessmen can do anything they want if they just bribe a few top officials."
He noted that in a shrinking global marketplace, the results of human rights violations would not be contained to mainland China.
He cited the visit of mainland Chinese leaders to Canada last year as an example, saying Canadian police broke up student demonstrations with tear gas.
"I was told that it was the worst thing done to peaceful demonstrators in the history of Canada," he told the daily.
The Tibetan cause is now being supported by leading Hollywood stars, including Richard Gere, Harrison Ford and Susan Sarandon.

But Samdhong Rinpoche said the support of ordinary people is as important in achieving freedom for Tibet. Although there is no economic benefit in supporting Tibet, "people are spending their own money, time and energy because they feel that it is a struggle between right and wrong," he said.
He told the daily that the young Panchen Lama, who has been in custody in mainland China for more than two years, should be set free because there is growing concern for his welfare.
"He is too small to be tortured and imprisoned in this way," he said.
He said the recent movies "Seven Years in Tibet" and "Kundun" are an indication that the West is more open to hearing about the Tibetan cause.
The films can help counter "misinformation" spread by Beijing, he said, adding that he believes the truth about Tibet will eventually prevail.

Samdhong Rinpoche, who fled to India after the failure of the Tibetan uprising against mainland China in 1959, also serves as the vice chancellor of the Institute for Higher Buddhist Studies in Varanasi, India.

He has given a series of briefings on Beijing's human rights violations and abuses in Tibet to Australian politicians and academics he met during his visits to Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne. He took up a three-week lectureship at the University of Tasmania on April 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUPERT MURDOCH'S MARRIAGE BREAKUP STUNS HIS FAMILY

TEXT.P: The breakup of the 31-year marriage of media magnate Rupert Murdoch has stunned his family and friends as well as financial markets in Australia and elsewhere.
The first public news that Murdoch and his wife Anna have separated was disclosed in a gossip column in one of Murdoch's newspapers, The New York Post.

The great lady of gossip, Liz Smith, wrote in her column: "It is with some personal sadness that I announce the amicable separation of Rupert Murdoch and his beautiful wife, Anna. The Murdochs say their situation is very painful and leaves them torn but they are attempting to work out their differences."
Australian media reported Wednesday that even Murdoch's mother was astonished to hear the news that her son was separating from his wife of 31 years.
"It's come as a big shock to us all," Dame Elisabeth Murdoch told reporters. "We're devastated, of course, because we are so fond of them both."
Murdoch's sister, Helen Handbury and Anna's brother, Hans Tory, were equally surprised, saying they knew nothing about the breakup until Tuesday.

The 53-year-old Anna and her 67-year-old husband, Murdoch, have confirmed that they are not living in the same place. Anna has gone back to England with her daughter, according to a report in Wednesday's edition of The Sydney Morning Herald.
The Murdochs have three grown-up children -- Lachlan, Elisabeth and James, all high-ranking executives in the Australia-based News Corp. empire.

The Australian Financial Review, Australia's leading business daily, reported Wednesday that the news of the breakup was a shock to the financial market and that market analysts predict the record recent gains in the shares of Murdoch's A$39 billion (US$26 billion) News Corp. empire in Adelaide will be reversed somewhat.
Analysts said investors in Australia and abroad are likely to push the share price down as the market digests such issues as succession and stock ownership in the wake of any financial settlement.
News Corp. shares ended 11 Australian cents lower at A$11.10 Tuesday. Analysts said the stock market has yet to react to the marriage split.
"This is the biggest piece of news on News Corp. that we've heard for a long time," one analyst told the Financial Review.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE STILL WORLD'S 2ND MOST COMPETITIVE COUNTRY

TEXT.P: Singapore has weathered the Asian economic storm successfully to retain its spot as the world's second most competitive country for the fifth consecutive year.

Singapore and Hong Kong were the only Asian entities in the new list of the top 15 most competitive economies in the world, compiled by the Swiss-based International Institute for Management Development (IMD).

The authoritative rankings of 46 economies worldwide, released Tuesday, gave Singapore 84 points, with the United States coming out on top with 100, The Straits Times reported Wednesday. Hong Kong, in third place, mustered only 69 points.
The Republic of China was ranked 16th, seven steps higher than its 23rd spot in the previous rating.
Troubled Japan fell to 18th, from the ninth spot it occupied last year. It was ranked as the second most competitive economy worldwide just five years ago.
The United States, as No. 1, was "exceptional" in terms of competitiveness, according to the top Swiss business school.
The three city-economies -- Singapore, Hong Kong and ninth-placed Luxembourg -- continued to perform remarkably well, said the IMD in releasing its keenly-awaited annual scoreboard.

"Singapore has been less affected than its neighbors by the Asian crisis, but will certainly be impacted by the general slowdown in the region's environment," said Professor Stephane Garelli, director of the world competitiveness project at the IMD.
Although Hong Kong maintained its third slot, it "has nevertheless lost some ground in comparison to Singapore, perhaps due to transition uncertainties," Garelli said.

He noted that everything was in place for US competitiveness: seven years of continuous economic expansion, unemployment at a 24-year low, inflation at a 30-year low and stock exchange indices that had roughly tripled since 1991.

"The United States is strongly installed in its position as the most competitive nation in the world. Privatization, deregulation, flexibility in the labor market and especially massive investment in new technology has worked," he observed.
The IMD's findings, published in the annual World Competitiveness Yearbook, rank the ability of a nation to provide an environment that sustains the competitiveness of enterprises.

The study covers 259 criteria grouped under eight competitiveness input factors: domestic economy, internationalization, government, finance, infrastructure, management, science and technology, and people.
International statistics and survey data from 4,300 business policy-makers worldwide polled this year were used to arrive at the latest rankings, the report said.

For Singapore, the most significant change is that it came out on top in the "people" category, in which it was placed fifth last year. This category covers availability and qualifications of human resources.
In the domestic economy factor, it rose to second from third previously.
Singapore maintained its No. 1 position under "government" and No. 2 under "internationalization" factors.
But its rankings under the "finance and infrastructure" sectors fell.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT SEES BARRIERS TO CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION WEAKENING

TEXT.P: The head of a Canadian think tank said Tuesday that barriers to cooperation between Taiwan and mainland China under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum will begin to weaken and diminish.
In an interview with CNA, Dr. William Saywell, president and CEO of the Asia-Pacific Foundation of Canada, said that the economies of Taiwan and mainland China have gradually become integrated.

With the new leadership in Beijing focusing its efforts on economic growth, there will be greater cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as Taipei and Beijing become more and more pragmatic, Saywell said.

Taiwan's entrepreneurs not only have invested huge amounts in mainland China but also are buying assets in such Southeast Asian countries as Thailand and Indonesia, he pointed out, saying that this is an indication of Taiwan's solid financial strength.

Saywell and other foundation executives were in Ottawa for a seminar on Asia's financial crisis. Prominent representatives from government agencies, academia, business and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) focused discussions on the human and social dimensions of the current crisis. They also exchanged views on what Canada can do to help alleviate the human suffering in the region.
Some experts warned that the economic crisis in Indonesia, magnified by a severe drought, could develop into a "major human crisis" with problems of starvation and a breakdown in social services.

Other policy makers, NGO leaders and officers of international financial institutions were more optimistic that programs now in place under the International Monetary Fund will lead to a slow recovery.
However, all agreed that the future of the Suharto government is a major uncertainty hanging over the recovery. "Indonesia could blow" was the assessment of one analyst.

The seminar was organized by the Asia-Pacific Foundation, a national non-profit body established by an Act of the Parliament of Canada in 1984. Its mandate is to promote stronger ties between Canada and the Asia-Pacific region by providing high-quality research and information products and services for policy makers, businesspeople and educators across Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY DENIES SPRATLYS MISSILE SPEEDBOAT BASE REPORT

TEXT.P: The ROC military on Wednesday denied a newspaper report that it will build a missile speedboat base in the disputed Spratly archipelago in the South China Sea.

The Navy General Headquarters (NGH) dismissed the report as "sheer speculation," saying the the Navy has not set aside budget for such a project in its work plan for the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1, 1998.

The NGH said in a press release that the Navy only has a makeshift wharf on Taiping Island, the largest island in the Spratly chain. The pier, completed in 1984, was partially damaged by a tropical storm in 1990. The wharf has never been fully repaired, but the damage has not hindered shipment of military supplies or equipment to the Taiwan-held island in the Spratlys.
Nevertheless, the NGH said, the Marine Corps Headquarters has recently made an overture on repair and renovation of the wharf to save manpower in military supply transportation.

"The Navy headquarters is still evaluating the return on investment of the repair project," the NGH said, adding that even if the project is implemented, it will not include the establishment of a missile speedboat base or wharf on Taiping Island as the media had reported.

Construction projects in the Spratlys are usually deemed highly sensitive because the island chain is claimed wholly or in part by Brunei, mainland China, Malaysia, the Philippines, Vietnam and Taiwan. The Spratlys, a cluster of some 60 islets, are believed to lie amid valuable gas and oil deposits, and also strddle important international shipping lanes.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Market (TAIEX), with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 196.31 points to close at 8,636.51.

Dealers said the market was encouraged by big increases in prices of science and technology shares on Wall Street, with both electronics issues and industrial stocks rebounding and enjoying large gains on the local bourse.
The market opened at 8,553.16 and experienced a low of 8,526.1 before closing at the day's high of 8,636.51.
Gainers outnumbered losers by 424 to 49, with 20 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 2.16 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$130.57 billion (US$3.95 billion), decreasing from the previous session, which saw 2.37 billion shares change hands on a market turnover of NT$139.72 billion.

All eight major categories gained ground, with electrical stocks moving up the most at 3.4 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 2.7 percent, textile issues at 2.6 percent, pulp and paper stocks at 2.4 percent, both cement shares and foodstuff issues at 1.8 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 1.4 percent and construction shares at 1.0 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Wednesday's trading were Liton Electronic, Ever Fortune Industries, ASE, Chuntex Electronic Co., ACER, Mitac International Corp., Compal Electronic Inc., United Micro Electronics, King-Wei Fiber and Clevo.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAN'S M'LAND TRIP NOT RENEWAL OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: BEIJING

TEXT.P: The visit of Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), to the Chinese mainland will be an exchange of views about activities across the Taiwan Strait, not a resumption of talks between the two sides, a mainland official involved with Taiwan affairs said on Wednesday, stressing that the talks should be restarted with political negotiations.
Whether this attitude will be a factor in the first formal cross-strait discussion since June 1995 is worthy of close attention.

Jan left for Beijing Wednesday morning at the head of a Taiwan delegation to discuss the resumption of cross-strait exchanges, reciprocal visits and dialogue. Meanwhile, a mainland Chinese official involved with Taiwan affairs said in Beijing via a Hong Kong-based newspaper, Wen Wei Bao, that the upcoming contact between the SEF and its counterpart, the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will just be an exchange of views about activities across the strait, not a restart of the talks.

The official said that a restart of the talks must involve political negotiations. "It is doubtless that political negotiations have always been and still are the most important task under our strenuous work," remarked the official, adding that "we will continue our effort to enhance the exchanges and cooperation between the two sides prior to the procedural discussions for the political negotiations."

He said he believes that since Jan's current trip to Beijing is aimed at paving the way for SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's mainland visit, the contact between the SEF and ARATS will be limited to protocol matters.

Nevertheless, he added that during the contacts and exchanges between the two semi-official intermediary bodies, an informal exchange of views on procedural discussions for political negotiations cannot be ruled out.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF'S MAINLAND CHINA TRIP TO PAVE WAY FOR HIGH-LEVEL VISITS

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Chang King-yuh, said on Wednesday that he hopes the visit by a Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) delegation to mainland China will help herald a new era in cross-strait exchanges.
Earlier in the day, SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng left for mainland China at the head of the eight-member SEF delegation.
Chang said the delegation expects to exchange opinions on procedural issues with the mainland Chinese side in order to pave the way for visits by higher-level SEF personnel.

Taiwan's stance is that bilateral negotiations should start from the point they had reached before being suspended in 1995 by Beijing, and that discussions on consensus reached in previous talks should continue, the MAC head stressed, adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should maintain contact to keep dialogue channels open.
Chang made the remarks following his attendance of a seminar on ways to strengthen contacts between Taiwan and Hong Kong people.

Jan's visit is the first of its kind in nearly three years after mainland China unilaterally cut regular talks between the SEF and its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- following a visit to the United States by President Lee Teng-hui in June 1995.

The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations authorized to deal with bilateral exchanges in the absence of direct government-to-government contacts. Taiwan and the mainland have been divided since 1949 after a civil war which saw the defeat of the Nationalist government by communist forces.

Speaking at a news conference, MAC spokesman Hsu Ke-sheng expressed the hope that Jan's visit will lead to the resumption of regular SEF-ARATS exchanges, adding that rekindling institutionalized negotiations is of great importance for both Taiwan and mainland China and that the two sides should reopen talks based on the foundation laid during previous negotiations.

Hsu welcomed the recent moves adopted by Beijing in response to Taiwan's repeated calls for a resumption of cross-strait exchanges, saying that the two sides should expand bilateral activities on a gradual basis.

He said Jan's mainland visit may suggest a warming of cross-strait ties, but pointed out that additional efforts will be needed if the two sides are to fully resume regular exchanges and negotiations. Taiwan sincerely desires that future developments in cross-strait relations can proceed in a positive direction under the framework achieved in the past, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHOTODYNAMIC THERAPY PROVIDES HOPE FOR LIVER CANCER VICTIMS

TEXT.P: A new photodynamic therapy (PDT) which has been proved clinically efficacious in the treatment of hepatitis and hepatoma in ducks may also be an effective cure for hepatitis and cancer in humans, sources in National Taiwan University's College of Medicine reported on Wednesday.

Professor Kao Ming-chien, head of the NTU medical research team which carried out the tests, said the new PDT treatment, which uses a laser to kill photosensitized infected cells, has been found to be effective in killing hepatitis virus and cancer cells in duck livers.

PDT, also known as photoradiation therapy (PRT), might also be an effective treatment for hepatitis and liver cancer in humans, as the DNA polymerase of the B-type hepatitis liver-tropic virus found in ducks is very similar to the virus that affects humans, Kao explained in a press conference on Wednesday held at the National Science Council, which sponsored the research.
Clinical trials on humans are expected to begin soon, providing a ray of hope for Taiwan's many hepatitis and hepatoma patients, as most existing treatments incur nasty side-effects, Kao noted.

According to medical records, roughly 80 percent of Taiwan's population have been affected by B-type hepatitis, with 15 to 20 percent of them ending up as carriers of the disease. An attack of hepatitis B causes severe scarring of the liver tissue, which very often leads to complications such as cancer in later life.
In Taiwan, as many as 5,700 people die of liver cancer every year, putting the affliction at the top of a long list of cancers which kill the people of Taiwan.

PDT treatment involves researchers injecting the subject intravenously with a photosensitive solution, most of which is discharged through the circulation within 24 hours while some remains in the infected or cancerous liver cells. The researchers can then identify the affected cells and use a laser to destroy them.
Following the PDT or PRT treatment on ducks, Kao said, as high as 82 percent to 99 percent of the hepatitis virus were killed, while 62 percent to 78 percent of the hepatoma cells were destroyed.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.032 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.999.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 32.943 and had a high of 33.018.
The interbank trading reached US$288.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF MISSION LEAVES FOR M'LAND FOR ICE-BREAKING VISIT

TEXT.P: A leading Taiwan negotiator left for mainland China on Wednesday for a low-profile visit to pave the way for resuming regular dialogue across the Taiwan Strait.

Jan Jyh-horng, a deputy secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said prior to his departure that his three-day Beijing visit is aimed at helping the two sides better understand each other's basic stance on future cross-strait ties.

Jan's visit was of great significance as it was the first high-level contact between the SEF and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), after a nearly three-year freeze on such kind of exchange.
While in Beijing, Jan said he will exchange views with ARATS officials on how to expand engagements between the two intermediary bodies to forge cross-strait rapprochement.

"We earnestly hope that the visit will eventually lead to reopening of institutionalized exchanges and consultations between the SEF and ARATS," Jan stressed, adding that he expects the visit to be an important step toward closer ties.
Jan was scheduled to hold a working dinner with ARATS Deputy Secretary-General Li Iafei on Wednesday to set the agenda for bilateral talks on Thursday.

Jan was accompanied by seven other SEF officials, including Hsieh Fu-yuan, director of the leagal service department; and Tsai Chin-mei, deputy director of the travel service department. The group is scheduled to return to Taipei on Friday.

Jan's visit was the culmination of months of letters exchanges, and came after Beijing dropped its insistence that Taiwan discuss sensitive political issues. Taiwan has consistently wanted to resume talks on practical issues, saying starting with the less sensitive topics could nurture the atmosphere for discussions on political matters at a later stage.

Beijing unilaterally suspended talks on practical issues with Taiwan in mid-1995 in anger over a Taiwan campaign to upgrade its international profile that cultimated in a visit to the United States by President Lee Teng-hui in June that year.
Though the road to cross-strait rapprochement is bound to be bumpy, Taiwan hopes Jan's visit will lead to a second summit meeting between the top negotiators from the two sides.

SEF Chairman C. F. Koo and his ARATS counterpart, Wang Daohan, held a historic summit meeting in Singapore in April 1993, better known as the first Koo-Wang meeting, to lay a framework for bilateral exchanges in the absence of official ties. A second Koo-Wang meeting was being planned at the time when Beijing unilaterally froze bilateral talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA, PARAGUAY YET TO DECIDE ON MATH OLYMPIAD

TEXT.P: Mainland China and Paraguay are the only countries among the 84 invited to participate in the July Mathematics Olympiad in Taiwan which have yet to decide whether to take part in the international competition.
A special commission dealing with preparations for the contest opened its third workshop in Taipei on Wednesday.

Huang Chen-tai, chairman of the ROC National Science Council, and Education Minister Lin Ching-chiang, jointly hosted the workshop, during which a report was released on the preparations to date by Chen Chao-ti, dean of the College of Science of National Taiwan Normal University and a member of the Institute of Mathematics of the Republic of China, which is sponsoring the competition.

Chen said that they have sent an invitation to mainland China's Mathematics Society, which responded by saying it is still awaiting official approval for the contest to go ahead in Taipei on July 10-21.

In Paraguay's case, Chen told the commission financial straits might be preventing the Central American country from participating, and suggested providing it with financial support to allow it to take part.

Walter E. Meintka, the visiting secretary-general of the consulting committee of the International Mathematics Olympiad contest, also attended the workshop, during which he said he is satisfied with Taiwan's preparations.

The contest for schoolchildren from around the world is aimed at discovering, inspiring, and challenging the students' potential in the scientific field, and to act as a cradle for leaders in the field of mathematics.
This is the first time that the ROC has been granted the right to sponsor the contest. Taiwan first took part in the annual mathematics competition in 1992.
Over the past six years, the island has ranked an average 10th position in the contest, with its best performance in 1993 when it reached fifth place.

The mathematics Olympiad was held for the first time 1959, and involved only four countries -- Czechoslovakia, Poland, former East Germany and host Romania. After more than 30 years of development, the number of participating countries has greatly increased, and there are also international physics and chemistry Olympiads, but they are held separately on different dates, with different nations taking part.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN ARRESTED FOR TRYING TO SMUGGLE FIREARMS

TEXT.P: A man was arrested Wednesday morning at Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport for trying to smuggle a large quantity of firearms into the country, aviation police said.

Police said the man, identified as 58-year-old Tseng Shou-yen, had returned to Taiwan from Los Angeles on an Eva Airlines flight when an X-ray machine disclosed 10 pistols, 19 magazines and 50 rounds of powerful ammunition hidden in his golf bags and luggage.

Police said they found it incredible that Tseng could make it through the system of security checks at the US airport carrying such a large quantity of firearms, and are currently contacting US security officials to learn more about how he was able to evade airport security and board the plane.

Tseng said during an initial arraignment that he was commissioned by a Chinese friend in the US to bring the firearms to Taiwan. The friend told him that someone would collect the weapons from him once he arrived here.
Tseng was unable to say how much he was to receive for his part in the operation, nor would he provide police with the names of his Taiwan contacts.
Police said they are trying to trace local gun rings which may have been preparing to pick up the arms.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUTURE OF HUMAN RIGHTS IN HONG KONG REMAINS TO BE SEEN: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh said on Wednesday that Hong Kong's future regarding democracy and human rights remains to be seen, despite the fact that Beijing has not interfered a great deal in local affairs since the return of the former British colony to mainland China's rule in July 1997.
Chang issued the warning in a speech at a seminar on ways to enhance bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

The head of the Cabinet-level MAC, Taiwan's highest government agency in charge of the island's policy toward mainland China, said the long-term development of democracy and human rights in Hong Kong remains worrisome, pointing to the small number of seats reserved for directly elected representatives in the first post-handover legislative election slated for May.

Chang said the Republic of China government hopes Hong Kong will be permitted to retain its free economic system and high level of autonomy, allowing the local people to continue enjoying basic civic rights. But concern over the current political situation in Hong Kong has prompted the ROC government to maintain a low profile and service-oriented presence there, he noted.

In an effort to illustrate Taiwan's desire for increased exchanges with Hong Kong, Chang repeated a call urging the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government and the mainland authorities to install a special task force and set up institutionalized communication channels to deal with Taiwan.
In addition, he added that the ROC government would also welcome the establishment of a Hong Kong representative office in Taiwan to better serve people traveling between the two sides.

As Taiwan and Hong Kong have always maintained close links in almost every field, Chang stressed the importance of both governments making coordinated efforts with the private sector to enhance bilateral exchanges, he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAITI PRESIDENT GIVEN RED CARPET WELCOME

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan rolled out red carpet on Wednesday to welcome Haiti President Rene Garcia Preval at the start of his four-day state visit to the island.
Preval was accorded full military honors, complete with a 21-gun salute, at a ceremony presided over by ROC President Lee Teng-hui at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei.
In his welcoming speech, Lee said Preval's visit marks yet another milestone in the longstanding relationship between the two countries.
"We hope friendship and cooperation between our two countries will be further strengthened through increased exchanges of official visits," Lee added.

For his part, Preval expressed his gratitude for the hospitality the ROC government has extended to him. "Despite the geographical distance, the ROC and Haiti have enjoyed cordial relations as they share same political ideals and values."

Preval also expressed his admiration for the ROC's progress in democratic reforms, saying dialogue, peace, rationality, international law, freedom and human rights are the mainstream values of the present world.
Noting that the Taiwan private-sector's investment in Haiti has helped spur his Caribbean country's economic development, Preval said he hopes more Taiwan companies will invest in Haiti.

During his visit, Preval will chair a seminar to introduce Haiti's general invesmtent climate and tax incentives for foreign investors. "I hope my visit will help nurture new joint-venture or economic cooperative programs," Preval said, adding local textile and other labor-intensive industry operators are welcome to invest in his country.

Following the welcoming ceremony, Lee received Preval at the Presidential Office. They exchanged views on a range of issues, including the general international situation, regional developments and other topics of mutual concern.
The two national leaders also exchange decorations to express their mutual tribute and friendship. They will sign a joint communique reaffirming mutual commitment at the end of Preval state visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSILE TEST FIRING SHIFTED TO SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The army will from now on conduct its missile test firing in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County rather than at its previous testing range in the northern Taipei suburb of Tamsui, Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman Kung Fan-ting said on Wednesday.
Kung said Pingtung County's Chioupeng base will be used for testing for the first time on Thursday with the test firing of two Hawk missiles.
He stressed that the test firing of the low altitude air defense missiles is part of annual routine drills, and he urged the public not to speculate over the matter.

As the test firing comes at a sensitive time, with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait preparing to revive their long-stalled talks, the MND is handling the issue in a very low-key manner and is being open with its explanations of related details to the media.

Kung pointed out a number of factors which have rendered the old Tamsui missile testing range unsuitable, including the fact that civilian air and sea traffic has increased in recent years, making it harder to keep the test area clear during firing exercises.
In addition, land development for a new town in Tamsui has prompted the MND to shift its test firing range to the Pingtung base, which is in a more sparsely populated area.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FIRM ORDERED TO REINSTATE SACKED WORKERS TO END DOCK WAR

TEXT.P: The Australian Federal Court has ordered Patrick Stevedores Ltd. to reinstate all 2,000 union workers it fired and to stop using non-union labor in its major ports across Australia so that the current waterfront battle can be ended.
The court meted out the order Tuesday.

But Patrick, which is at the center of the dock war, immediately appealed against the court ruling, with the company's chairman, Chris Corrigan, calling the court order "unworkable" and saying that he now faces two groups of workers -- the reinstated union workers and the non-union workers.
"These are the preliminary views of a single judge," Corrigan said. "I believe His Honor (Justice Tony North) is wrong."

After hearing the Federal Court decision, the Federal Government under Prime Minister John Howard rejected the court judgment, saying the government will continue its hard-line approach to waterfront reform.

Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith said he is determined to bust the monopoly of the waterfront by the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA), the powerful union group behind the campaign against Patrick and the Howard government.
"The wharfies had won round one in front of Justice Tony North and ultimately lost it at the end of the day," Reith told reporters.
The MUA and its union members hailed the Federal Court decision Tuesday and they were jubilant with the initial victory in their fight against both Patrick and the Howard government.
But the jobs of the 1,400 full-time workers and 600 part-time laborers were still in doubt Wednesday despite the court order because Patrick is attempting to outflank the decision.
The weapon Patrick is using is that its four subsidiaries, which now technically employ the sacked workers, are unlikely to function -- even if Patrick offers them ships to load.
The four subsidiaries have become insolvent and will not get a cash flow from Patrick, which has shifted all its assets to the Lang Corp., its parent company.
The MUA workers said they will return to work at Patrick's terminals without pay for two weeks so the insolvent subsidiaries can get a cash flow going again.
Industry analysts said they believe the waterfront war will continue either at major terminals, which have become battlegrounds in the past two weeks, or in the courts.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PHONE CALLS RATED MOST EXPENSIVE AMONG 13 NATIONS

TEXT.P: Australia is the most expensive among 13 industrialized countries for both local and international phone calls, according to a new study by an independent analyst, NUS International.

While other countries have reduced their local and international call rates, Australia is one of the five countries that have maintained local phone call rates at peak levels, according to the survey, which covers the period between Feb. 1, 1997 and Feb. 1, 1998.

The cost of a three-minute local call in Australia was A$0.23 (US$0.15) in February 1998, unchanged from the same period in 1997. The rate for a three-minute international call was A$3.08 in Australia in February 1998, down 4 percent from a year earlier. Both were the highest rates among the 13 countries.
Belgium reduced its local call rate to A$0.20 in February 1998, a drop of 2.4 percent from the same period last year.
Britain has maintained its local rate at the same level as that of Belgium.
Trailing Britain in the local call category are Germany, Sweden, France, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Japan, Italy and the United States.
Canada was the only country in the survey providing free local phone calls.
In the international phone category, Australia took the lead as the most expensive country for international phone calls.
Japan came second in international phone call rates, with A$2.94 per three minutes in February 1998, down nearly 26 percent from the 1997 level.
Germany was third, followed by the United States, Italy, Belgium, New Zealand, the Netherlands, Sweden, Canada and France.
In the international phone call category, Britain was the cheapest, with only A$1.01 per three minutes.
The main reason behind the high cost of local and international phone calls in Australia is government protection for the state-owned Telstra.
Optus, a privately owned telecommunications firm, is trying to break through Telstra's monopoly and plans to offer cheaper local phone calls.
But industry sources said they believe even though Optus is expected to provide cheaper calls, the reduction will be limited, given the current level of government protection for Telstra.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO: CROSS-STRAIT CONTACT SHOULD BE RESUMED

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), on Wednesday called for a resumption of contact between the SEF and its Beijing-based counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
He made the remarks after attending a meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee.

Commenting on the departure Wednesday of a mission to the Chinese mainland led by SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng, Koo said he hopes the trip will bring a new atmosphere to cross-strait relations. He added that he believes Jan will be able to accomplish that goal.

According to Koo, in the process of ever-expanding contacts between SEF and ARATS, there should be many opportunities for exchanges of visits between the two sides. He indicated that he may also lead a mission to visit the mainland in the future.
The SEF chairman said that through such visits both sides may exchange views freely, allowing cross-strait negotiations to make an early return to the institutionalized track.

Meanwhile, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) under the Executive Yuan issued a statement on Wednesday expressing hope that Jan's visit can serve as "an important step forward" in improving cross-strait relations.

The statement noted that the chances for a resumption of the long-stalled dialogue with Beijing are good. However, it also pointed out that in order to reach the goal of full normalization of exchanges and broad-based negotiations, joint efforts from both sides of the strait are still needed.
According to the MAC, the Republic of China has continuously upheld the principles of peace, rationality, equity and reciprocity in seeking mutually respectful and beneficial cross-strait ties.

The MAC also expressed hope that relations across the Taiwan Strait will continue to march toward normal development, using the greatest areas of converging opinion as starting points. In this way, the council's statement said, the mutual trust which has been gradually eroded during the past two years of suspended contacts can be re-established.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCREASED COOPERATION URGED ON CROSS-STRAIT CRIME CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Hsu Ke-sheng said on Wednesday that the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) and the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will join forces to help resolve the case of a Taiwan businessman murdered in mainland China's Guangdong Province on Sunday.

The SEF, Taiwan's semi-official organization authorized by the Republic of China government to deal with mainland China in the absence of official ties, said it has not received a report from the victim's family and is seeking more information on the incident through the relevant channels.

A Hong Kong newspaper reported on Wednesday that Lai Ming-yih, a vice manager of a Taiwan-owned shoe factory in Dongwan, Guangdong Province, was killed on Sunday by four men from Taiwan at a downtown KTV parlor as a result of a quarrel over a waitress serving there.

According to the newspaper, one of the four men, reportedly members of Taiwan's Four Seas criminal gang, first opened fire at the ceiling and Lai was later seriously stabbed with a broken bottle during a fight with them.
Lai was rushed to a nearby hospital where he later died, while the four men fled the scene, according to the newspaper.

The newspaper said all four were arrested on Tuesday, and cited Guangdong public security officials who said the suspects might have come to the mainland to avoid detention by Taiwan police authorities.
CIB Director Yang Tzu-ching said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should increase cooperative measures to crack down on similar criminal cases.

Although Taiwan and the mainland signed the Kinmen Agreement in 1990 to handle the repatriation of criminals wanted by either side, Yang said the two sides still lack adequate channels for coordinated crime-fighting efforts.

If the four men are known criminals or alleged gangsters wanted by Taiwan police, the CIB, with the help of the SEF and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, will provide relevant information to mainland public security authorities to ensure they are brought back to Taiwan to face justice, Yang said.
Lai's remains came back to Taiwan on Wednesday afternoon on board a China Airlines flight.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE MANUFACTURERS URGED TO INVEST IN HAITI

TEXT.P: An official from the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce on Wednesday urged local textile manufacturers to invest in Haiti as an effective means of cutting operational costs.
Wang Chung-yu, convener of the association's Central and Southern American Affairs Committee, made the remarks in a seminar on trade and investment in Haiti on Wednesday.

Wang noted that Taiwan businessmen can take advantage of the Caribbean nation's superb geographical location, in proximity to both North and South America, to make inroads into new markets in those regions.
Taiwan exported US$11.125 million worth of goods to Haiti last year. The main items included woven and knitted wear as well as plastic products.
Taiwan imported only US$21,000 of goods from that nation in 1997, mostly coral, women's blouses and men's T-shirts.

Speaking on the same occasion, Vice Foreign Minister Francisco Ou conceded that Haiti, dubbed the "Pearl of the Antilles, is geographically distant from Taiwan. However, as it has no foreign currency controls and lies near the major US city of Miami, Florida, it holds plenty of potential for local businessmen.
Ou said local textile and manufacturing industries are most suited to investing in Haiti, adding that the ROC government can provide assistance in that regard.

Haitian President Rene Preval, who arrived here Tuesday for a four-day visit, said in the meeting with local manufacturers that participants at the recently concluded second Summit of the Americas had decided to discuss the creation of a regional free trade area in September.
Preval predicted such a zone could be established by the year 2005, and said Taiwan businessmen can have great trade opportunities if they invest now.
Haiti is one of the 29 nations that maintain diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRECKAGE FROM FUSELAGE OF FORMOSA AIRLINES DISCOVERED

TEXT.P: After more than one month of combing the seabed for wreckage from an ill-fated Formosa Airlines flight which crashed on March 18, a search team on Wednesday discovered part of the plane's fuselage in waters off Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan.

A Formosa Airlines spokesman said that the deep-sea search team from the United States located the wreckage early Wednesday some two nautical miles off the Nanliao Fishing Harbor in Hsinchu County. He indicated that the section of the fuselage is between 15 and 20 meters in length.

The seriously twisted metal portion of the Saab-340 plane can be clearly seen in video footage taken by the search team. The salvage work will begin on Thursday and is not expected to be completed until sometime Friday due to the size of the wreckage.

Authorities hope the portion of fuselage will help explain the cause of the crash because the aircraft's black box data recorder has yet to be recovered. Formosa Airlines said that it will continue efforts to locate the black box from the 36-seat airliner, which crashed only minutes after its takeoff from Hsinchu Airport, killing all 13 passengers and crew members onboard.

So far the rescue team has reclaimed about 17 pieces of wreckage of various sizes from the aircraft. Only small fragments of body parts of the victims have been recovered. This has led to speculation that the aircraft might have been hit in mid-air by an unidentified object.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR ALLIES LOBBY FOR ROC'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: Four ROC allies -- the Gambia, Grenada, Nicaragua and Senegal -- have respectively asked the World Health Organization (WHO) to grant observer status to the Republic of China on Taiwan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reported on Wednesday.

"The four allies have written to the WHO secretary-general earlier this month, asking him to include a proposal to grant observer status to the ROC on the agenda of the 51st annual WHO conference scheduled for May 11-16 in Geneva," the ministry said in a press release.

The four countries pointed out in their letters that the ROC and Brazil jointly took the initiative to push for the establishment of the WHO in 1948. The ROC, however, was forced out of the UN-affiliated organization in 1972, a year after it was expelled from the United Nations to make way for mainland China.

Despite its exclusion from the organization, the four allies said, the ROC has continued to abide by all WHO regulations and dedicate itself to international humanitarian relief and medical aid over the past 26 years. The ROC has also played an important role in upgrading the quality of medical services in Asia, the letters said.

Noting that health care is not a political issue, the four ROC allies stressed that such considerations ought not to play a role in international health issues, nor should politics be used to exclude members from the WHO. "In striving to attain the highest standard of international health and to achieve the objectives set by the WHO, every country has a role to play."

The WHO currently has 192 member states. Top health officials of all member countries are expected to attend the upcoming WHO annual conference. The ROC has been denied access to the annual WHO congress since 1972.

The ROC expressed its intention to become a WHO observer for the first time in 1997. Several of the ROC's diplomatic allies, including Senegal, jointly introduced a motion asking the WHO congress to pass a resolution inviting the ROC to attend its activities as an observer. Because of Beijing's strong opposition, however, the proposal was not included in last year's agenda.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said it will continue to press ahead with the WHO bid to exert the right of the ROC's 21.6 million people to take part in international activities, and to uphold the spirit, principles and universality of the WHO.

The ministry also called a meeting on Wednesday afternoon to discuss the strategy for promoting Taiwan's WHO bid. It also issued a series of promotional papers pleading for sensitivity by the WHO for the ROC's position.

One of the ministry-prepared position papers said the WHO has admitted as members such nonmember states of the UN as Switzerland, Tonga, Nauru, Tuvalu and Kiribati. It has also welcomed as observers the Holy See, the International Committee of the Red Cross, the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Sovereignty Military Order of Malta.

"Is there any rationale for denying the people of Taiwan, the ROC, basic human rights which are extended to the rest of the world, and any justification for preventing them from exercising their responsibilities as members of the global village?" the position paper asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR INDUSTRIAL POWERS TO PROPOSE NEW TRADE TALKS

TEXT.P: The trade ministers of the US, the European Union (EU), Canada and Japan are expected to agree during a forthcoming meeting to start a new round of multilateral trade talks, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Wednesday.
The ministers are scheduled to meet in Versailles, France, later this month.

Faced with the threat of possible protectionism in the wake of the economic turmoil in Southeast Asia, the world's major industrial powers will propose that the new negotiations should begin in May, when the WTO's second ministerial meeting will take place in Geneva.

Under the 1994 agreement outlined during the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade talks, negotiations to deregulate shipping and legal practices relating to agricultural trading, including tariffs on rice and services, are slated to begin in 2000, the WTO report said.

Japan's International Trade and Industry Minister Mitsuo Horiuchi will propose a new round of negotiations covering at least four areas including investment and tariffs on industrial products, in addition to the two on agricultural trading and services, the WTO report said.

The EU is expected to urge trade partners worldwide to widen discussions during the new round of talks to include issues such as employment, competition and the environment, and Canada is expected to echo the EU proposal, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PIRATES ARRESTED IN PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: A Philippine coast guard patrol has arrested five of ten suspected pirates holed up inside the engine room of a cargo ship from which they had ransacked some one million pesos-worth of spare parts and equipment, the coast guard's Manila headquarters reported on Wednesday.
Lieutenant Commander Tuazon said his men cornered the suspects aboard the 4,000 ton M/V Madrigal Harmony anchored in Manila's South Harbor, some 1.5 km offshore.
Tuazon said the suspects were in the act of gathering the rest of their loot when they were nabbed. Five other suspects hiding inside the ship's engine room were surrounded by coast guard patrolmen.
Tuazon said the suspects secretly boarded the vessel over the weekend and dismantled engine parts and accessories. Most of the loot was taken away aboard a motor boat.
The ship, which has been undergoing repair since September 7, 1997, was unmanned when it was boarded by the pirates. Only a small percentage of the stolen material has been recovered.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC GOVERNOR WILL SEEK TO REMOVE 'TAIPEI, CHINA' NAME AT ADB MEETING

TEXT.P: Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of China, promised Wednesday to do his best to change the "Taipei, China" designation used by the Republic of China delegation at Asian Development Bank (ADB) events at the upcoming annual meeting of that organization.
Perng, who will lead a delegation to attend the April 30-May 2 meeting in Geneva, Switzerland, made the remarks after attending a seminar in Taipei.
The ROC, one of the founding members of the ADB, was forced to change its title at ADB events to "Taipei, China" in 1986, in order to facilitate the admission of mainland China into the organization.
However, with the handover of ADB member Hong Kong to Beijing's control last year, the Hong Kong delegation will attend this year's and future meetings under the name "Hong Kong, China."
The ROC participants have said the similarity of that name with their own designation of "Taipei, China" is unacceptable.

In order to prevent the ROC's status from being equated to that of Hong Kong, it has been reported that the delegation headed by Perng will strive have the ROC's formal name reinstated for ADB membership.
Perng declined to express his personal view on the matter, but promised to spare no effort in securing a proper status for the ROC.
As for what proposal will be made by the delegation at the meeting, Perng said he cannot reveal details in advance. (Ben Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF MISSION ARRIVES IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 22 (CNA) (By Yang Huei-chen Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: A leading Taiwan negotiator arrived in here on Wednesday for a visit aimed at paving the way for a resumption of regular dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Upon his arrival at the airport, Jan Jyh-horng, a deputy secretary-general of the semiofficial Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and also head of an eight-member delegation from Taipei, was welcomed by Qiao Feng, director of the Secretary Department of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
Jan said he is pleased that high-level contacts between the SEF and ARATS can be resumed after a nearly three-year hiatus.

Beijing unilaterally suspended cross-strait talks on technical issues as well as the exchange of visits by SEF and ARATS officials to vent its anger over a trip to the United States by ROC President Lee Teng-hui in June 1995.
The current three-day visit is aimed at helping the two sides better understand each other's basic stance on the future exchange of officials from the intermediary bodies, Jan noted.

Expressing optimism that the journey can mark the beginning of a new era in cross-strait exchanges, Jan also said that by working together with the utmost sincerity, the two sides will "sweep away the cold winter and usher in the warm spring."

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSES OPPOSE TO PROPOSED PLAN TO CUT WORKING HOURS

TEXT.P: Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) on Wednesday opposed vehemently to a proposed plan to cut the working hours of labors to 40 hours per week.
CNFI officials said that the government has to wait for the time when the gross national product has reached US$20,000 before considering to adjust the working hours of civil servants and laborers.
The civil servants and laborers, starting from Jan. 1, this year, enjoy five-day work week every other two weeks.
The officials said that with labor shortage problems and limited amount of available foreign laborers, the management could not afford to provide a shorter working hour plan.

The officials said that the CNFI survey had found that if the revised Basic Labor Law would cut the working hours from the current 48 hours to 40 hours, it will mean that the annual leaves of the civil servants will increase from the current 96 days to 114 days, while the annual leaves of the labor would increase to 115 days from the current 71 days.
Such a dramatic change would be a blow to large enterprises, not to mention small- and medium-sized enterprises, they said.

Even a report by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that if a laborer's working hours cut to 40 hours per week from the current 48, it would incur a cost increase to the management of 15 percent on per laborer. The revised working hours would deal an even severe blow to over 80 percent of small- and medium-sized enterprises.
CNFI officials said that Taiwan could learn from the experience of Japan, which has taken 10 years to be able to implement five-day week in 1992.
They said that five-day week will not come in one leap, and that a longer adjustment period is needed to give the management and the labor time to adjust in reasonable stages.

They also refuted the rhetoric by the Council of Labor Affairs which said that Singapore could implement 44-hour per week and Japan could implement 40-hour per week to show that the management in Taiwan has been "unkind" to the laborers.

They noted that Taiwan has put a brake on importing more foreign laborers after only 300,000 foreign laborers. They are concerned that with serious shortage of foreign laborers in basic industry, the proposal to cut working hours would be tantamount to putting fuel on fires.
They had suggested that in reviewing to cut working hours per week, the government should also review its foreign laborer policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSES OPPOSE TO PROPOSED PLAN TO CUT WORKING HOURS

TEXT.P: The Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) on Wednesday vehemently opposed a plan to cut the standard workweek for laborers to 40 hours.
CNFI officials said that the government must wait until the per capita gross national product has reached US$20,000 before it can consider adjusting the working hours of civil servants and laborers.
Starting from Jan. 1 this year, public employees and laborers enjoy a five-day workweek on alternating weeks.
The officials said that with Taiwan's labor shortage problems and the limited amount of available foreign laborers, management cannot afford to allow fewer working hours.

They cited a report by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) which concluded that if working hours for laborers were cut to 40 hours a week from the current 48, a 15 percent increase in production costs per worker would be incurred by management. Accordingly, the shorter workweek would deal a severe blow to over 80 percent of small- and medium-sized enterprises, the report said.
CNFI officials said that Taiwan could learn from the experience of Japan, which took 10 years to implement five-day week, a process that culminated in 1992.
They said a five-day workweek should not be introduced in a single leap. Rather, a longer period is needed to give both management and labor reasonable time to adjust in stages.

The officials also refuted statements by the Council of Labor Affairs, which alleged that if Singapore could function with a 44-hour workweek, and if Japan can allow its workers to spend only 40 hours on the job each week, then workers in Taiwan are being abused by management.

They noted that Taiwan has placed a ceiling of 300,000 on the number of foreign laborers it allows, claiming that, given serious labor shortages in basic industries, the proposal to cut working hours would be adding fuel to the fire.
They suggested that in reviewing the proposal to reduce the standard workweek, the government should also review its policy on the import of foreign laborers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PARAGUAY ECONOMIC MEETING OPENS THURSDAY

TEXT.P: The 10th ROC-Paraguay Economic Cooperation Meeting will be held in Taipei on Thursday, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The two-day meeting will be jointly presided over by ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Paraguayan Minister of Trade and Industry Atilio Fernandez.

Discussions will center on bilateral cooperation in trade and investment and between small- and medium-sized businesses of the two countries as well as on agricultural cooperation and efforts in intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.

Economics officials said the fact that a huge haul of Taiwan-made counterfeit Nintendo video game products was seized by Paraguayan customs authorities last year highlights the need for the two countries to strengthen cooperation in cracking down on IPR infringement.

The officials pointed out that bilateral cooperative relations will be further upgraded when a Taiwan private-sponsored industrial park in Oriental City, Paraguay, becomes operational by the end of the year.

They also said that at the meeting they will urge Paraguayan authorities to tighten security in the industrial zone as part of efforts to attract more Taiwan businessmen to invest in that South American country.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR INDUSTRIAL POWERS TO PROPOSE NEW TRADE TALKS

TEXT.P: The trade ministers of the United States, the European Union, Canada and Japan are expected to agree during their forthcoming meeting to start a new round of multilateral trade talks, according to reports from the World Trade Organization (WTO) Wednesday.
The ministers are scheduled to meet in Versailles later this month.

Faced with possible threat of protectionism in the wake of the economic turmoil in Asia, the world's major industrial powers will propose new negotiations to begin in May, when the WTO's second ministerial meeting will be held here in Geneva.

Under the 1994 agreement outlined during the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade talks, negotiations to deregulate agricultural trading -- including tariffs on rice and services such as shipping and legal practices -- are slated to begin in the year 2000, the WTO report said.

Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry Mitsuo Horiuchi will propose a new round of negotiations covering at least four areas, including investment and tariffs on industrial products, in addition to the two on agricultural trading and services, the WTO report said.

The EU is expected to urge worldwide trade partners to widen discussions during the new round of talks to include issues such as employment, competition and the environment. Canada is expected to echo the EU proposal, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN ASKED TO ADDRESS SEX SLAVE ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 22 (CNA) (By Chang Fang-min and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: A meeting to discuss the issue of World War II-era sex slaves from Asian nations who were forced into service by the Japanese Imperial Army ended on Wednesday with a resolution requesting the government to address the lingering matter through legislation in the Diet.

The Japanese government was requested to admit the crime, make a formal apology to the women, provide compensation as soon as possible, reveal the historical truth in its educational textbooks, and pass necessary laws to implement those measures.

The decision was signed by Legislators Shih Ming-teh and Kao Hui-yu from the Republic of China, Wang Ching-fung, adviser to the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, a group of lawmakers from South Korea and the Philippines, and representatives from eight civic organizations from South Korea and Japan.
A copy of the resolution was presented to four officials from the Japanese Foreign Ministry who promised to deliver it to appropriate authorities.

Shih, who has frequently voiced his disappointment over Tokyo's refusal to directly address the issue, pointed out at a press conference after the meeting that Taiwan has no demands from Japan other than that justice should be done. He appealed to the Japanese people and media to express their concern over the problem.
Kao suggested that there should be a two-pronged solution to the lingering issue involving international lawsuits on one hand, and the passage of relevant laws in the Japanese Diet on the other.

The Republic of China has confirmed that there are 45 so-called comfort women still living in Taiwan who were forced into prostitution by the Japanese army during World War II. In South Korea there are 152 known survivors of the ordeal, and 169 in the Philippines. There are hundreds of victims in other Asian countries, not to mention the thousands of women who have since died.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA SEES OPPORTUNITY IN JAPANESE FURNITURE MARKET

TEXT.P: The trend that has seen more consumers in Japan purchasing metallic furniture for home decoration offers a great opportunity for Taiwan businesses in that sector to strengthen market presence there, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said.
Taiwan has been one of Japan's largest sources of imported furniture, although the products going to that country are mostly constructed of rattan and other woods, according to the council.

However, CETRA said the more traditional wooden items have slowly been replaced by modern-style furnishings constructed of metal over the past few years. Accordingly, trade figures show surging orders for Taiwan-made metallic furniture.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAN HOPES FOR EARLY RETURN TO MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D.C., April 22 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland dissident Wang Dan said in an interview that he hopes the day he can return to mainland China will come soon.
Wang made the remarks in an interview with the Voice of America before he left for New York from Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit on Tuesday.

The broadcast interview provided the first opportunity for millions of listeners in the mainland to heard his voice. He was released from mainland prison last week on grounds of poor health and sent directly to the Detroit for two days of medical evaluations.
Wang said, "I feel heaviness in my heart even though I have gained my freedom, because my real mission in life lies in China."
Saying he feels "responsible for the democracy and freedom of the people in China," Wang expressed hope of returning to the mainland as soon as circumstances permits.
"I hope that day will come soon, and only when that day comes will I be happy," the 29-year-old dissident said.
Wang Linyun, the mother of Wang Dan, said in an interview from the mainland that she was happy for her son's release, but at the same time felt sorrow because he had to go into exile.

She said that Wang had agreed to leave the mainland because he worried about the health of his parents and could not bear to see them travel the long distance from Beijing to the prison where he was confined in northeastern China to visit him.
The Voice of America provides global news broadcasts in 52 languages, including Mandarin Chinese, Cantonese and Tibetan.
Commenting on Wang's hope to return to the mainland, Beijing has implied that, should he return, he will be immediately imprisoned again.
