DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS RISING DISCONTENT WITH POLICY TOWARD M'LAND

TEXT.P: Discontent with the government's cautious policy toward rival mainland China has risen significantly in recent months, according to opinion poll results released on Thursday.

The telephone poll of 921 adults, conducted by the United Daily News (UDN) on April 20-22, found that the number of respondents who said they are dissatisfied with the government's mainland policy has increased by 6 percent compared with the level recorded in a similar survey taken in mid-February.
As many as 41 percent of those interviewed said they were not satisfied with the government's current mainland policy, while only 34 percent gave a thumbs-up to the government's stance.

The percentage of naysayers was the highest ever registered in UDN surveys on the topic. In contrast, the number of proponents dropped 4 percent. Twenty-three percent said they have no opinion about the issue.

The survey results also show there are more supporters than opponents for opening direct shipping services across the Taiwan Strait, adjusting the "no haste, be patient" policy, offering exchanges of military drill information and strengthening news exchanges.

Nevertheless, the survey found that many local people still worry about the possible adverse impact on Taiwan's national security of such sensitive areas of contact with the mainland as direct cross-strait shipping services and exchanges of military drill information.

Meanwhile, 46 percent said they are dissatisfied with the present pace of cross-strait exchanges, compared to 38 percent who defend the status quo. The majority of respondents, 72 percent, also said they hope cross-strait exchanges will increase further, while 10 percent prefer to see a cut in such exchanges and 5 percent want to see the status quo maintained.
On the upgrading of cross-strait interchanges, 62 percent said they support opening of official contacts, while 19 percent oppose the proposal.

Some 60 percent of those surveyed also said the government should ease its "no haste, be patient" investment policy toward mainland China, but 19 percent prefer to maintain the current policy of caution.

On the future development of cross-strait relations, survey results show that the local people remain split on the urgency of opening direct shipping services. While 40 percent feel an urgent need to open such services, a roughly equal number of respondents said they do not think the issue needs to be addressed immediately.

However, the number of respondents who favor an early opening of direct shipping services rose to 51 percent from 43 percent recorded in a similar poll conducted early last year. In contrast, the number of opponents declined from 37 percent to 32 percent.

The poll also found that 47 percent support Premier Vincent Siew's recent call for the establishment of a framework for exchanging military drill information with the mainland, but 35 percent were not in favor of his making the overture and 16 percent did not answer the question.

Asked whether Taiwan should allow mainland reporters to work here on a long-term basis, 56 percent said the dispatch of resident correspondents should be opened on a reciprocal basis; 7 percent said Taiwan could unilaterally take the initiative to open its door to resident mainland journalists; while 24 percent categorically oppose the notion.

On mainland China's recent decision to issue passports to Taiwan businesspeople, 42 percent said they would be unlikely to apply for a mainland passport even if they had business interests there; 29 percent said they would; and 17 percent they might apply.

As far as the US attitude toward the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is concerned, 62 percent said they feel the United States usually leans toward the mainland, while 10 percent said they feel the opposite and 9 percent said they think Washington upholds a neutral position.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL TO CENTER ASIA-PACIFIC TECH OPERATIONS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Intel Corp., the world's leading maker of chips for personal computers (PCs), will continue to support Taiwan as its technology hub in the Asia-Pacific region, a company spokesman said in Taipei on Wednesday.

John Davies, newly appointed general manager of Intel's Asia-Pacific operations who arrived in Taipei on Wednesday for a short visit, said the region is poised to become the global center for computer research and development.

Davies, who is also an Intel vice president, said Taiwan has been one of the most important operational bases in the Asia-Pacific area for his company, which will continue to utilize the island as its regional technology center.

Current Intel operations in Taiwan include marketing and sourcing as well as research and development of new products. The prime movers of the Taiwan-based Intel R&D efforts currently include a laboratory for desktop PCs and portable information technology (IT) products, and an application and manufacturing technology research task force.

Davies also disclosed that Intel chairman Andy Grove will make a four-day visit to Taiwan next month, when he will officiate at the 1998 Asia-Pacific High Technology Forum slated for May 11-12 in Taipei.

Several hundred representatives from high-technology companies in the region are expected to take part in the forum that will highlight the latest research and development trends in computer-related industries.

In addition to delivering a keynote speech to the forum, Grove, who founded Intel and turned it into a global computer chip kingdom, will also take time to meet with CEOs of leading Asia-Pacific IT companies during his stay in Taipei, according to Davies.

Davies said the Asia-Pacific's 17 percent growth rate in the PC market is the fastest in the world. Regional sales of PCs will exceed 11 million units this year, with the volume doubling to 22 million units over five years, he predicted.

Davies noted that the strenuous development of electronic infrastructures and proliferation of web users have become prevailing global trends, and that 60 percent of the world's motherboards and 40 percent of the PCs originate from the Asia-Pacific. "I cannot think of any reason that would prevent the Asia-Pacific region from becoming the worldwide PC development center," Davies said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG HWA BANK BUYS SHARES OF YAMAICHI HK

TEXT.P: The Chang Hwa Commercial Bank is speeding up the pace of its march toward globalization following its purchase of shareholdings from Japan's failed Yamaichi Securities brokerage house.
Chang Hwa, headquartered in central Taiwan's Taichung City, recently bought a 10 percent share of Yamaichi Securities' Hong Kong operations from the Taipei-based Core Pacific Group (CPG).
The purchase will not only increase the profile of Chang Hwa's Hong Kong operations, but will also help the bank expand into Southeast Asia, executives from the bank said.
They revealed plans to make an initial launch into the financial services sector in Thailand as a first step toward gaining a broader foothold in regional markets.
The CPG acquired the share capital of Yamichi International (HK) Ltd. late last year. The transaction marked the first overseas buyout by a Taiwan stock brokerage firm.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE DOWN IN MARCH

TEXT.P: The number of unemployed in Taiwan registered at 223,000 in March, indicating that the local jobless situation has taken a turn for the better, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said on Thursday.

DGBAS officials said the number of employed members of the nation's overall workforce hit nearly 9.3 million in March, up about 173,000 from the same month last year. Among those, the number of workers who are university graduates or post-graduates topped 1 million to reach 1.01 million.
The officials said the jobless rate in March was cut by 0.45 percent from the same period of last year, or by 0.47 percent with adjustment for seasonal factors.
The officials said unemployment eased in March because the numbers of jobless created by the completion of seasonal or short-term contracts and the closure or downsizing of businesses had decreased.

All age groups in the workforce also witnessed a decline in March unemployment figures. Among them, the jobless rate dropped to 6.05 percent in the 15-24 age group. The jobless rate for the 25-49 age group registered at 2.02 percent, down 0.4 percent from March 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CALL RATES SET TO DROP

TEXT.P: The rate of international calls will be cut starting May 1, according to Chen Yao, chairman of the Chung Hwa Telecommunications Co.
Chen made the remarks Thursday when he fielded questions at the Legislative Yuan.

He said rate cut will differ from region to region, noting that the reduction will be greatest for calls to Singapore, Japan and South Korea. Calls to those countries will see a cut of 20 percent for regular hours and a cut of 16.7 percent for discount hours.
Call rates to the United Kingdom, France and other European nations will also be cut by 20 percent and 14.3 percent for regular and discount hours, respectively.

Connections to New Zealand and Australia will be cut by 3.4 percent during regular hours, but will remain unchanged during discount hours, Chen said, adding that rates for those two nations are already low.
Chen noted that Chung Hwa has cut the rate of international calls twice in the past two years, and that Taiwan's rates were ranked 10th worldwide in terms of economy, cheaper even than in Hong Kong.

But with the financial crisis in mid-1997 resulting in the depreciation of several Asian currencies, Taiwan's call rates have become higher in comparison. Chung Hwa has therefore decided to cut the rate again, Chen added.
He also said that Chung Hwa would take a three-month evaluation period to determine whether to cut the rate for calls made by cellular phones.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK GOV'T TO REESTABLISH POLITICAL DEPARTMENT: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 23 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) plans to reestablish a colonial-era department to collect information for it and to coordinate with the intelligence systems of Beijing, said the Hong Kong-based Oriental Daily News on Thursday.

The reestablishment of the "Political Department" comes as no surprise, the daily pointed out, noting that mainland China's Ministry of State Security had earlier sent officials to Hong Kong to discuss the matter. The HKSAR government is currently testing Hong Kong residents' reaction to the measure in order to decide whether to establish the department openly or make it operate more surreptitiously.

Mainland China's Ministry of State Security has taken a direct role in the matter because the Beijing authorities believe that Hong Kong, as a gateway to mainland China, must do something to guard against potential enemies, according to the daily.

The idea of establishing a political department in the HKSAR has progressed to the point, the daily indicated further, that a study on the framework for the organization and its division of labor was already underway.

During Hong Kong's days under British rule, the police department had a "Special Branch" that outsiders dubbed the "political department." Although this branch was under the control of the police department in name, in reality it was responsible directly to the governor of Hong Kong and to British army intelligence.

During the colonial period, the Special Branch had up to 5,000 employees and a wide sphere of operations, including exchanging intelligence with the European and American intelligence agencies, engaging in counter-terrorism measures, monitoring Taiwan's activities in Hong Kong, evaluating the job-related ethics of the high-ranking officials of the Hong Kong government, screening the backgrounds of Hong Kong's policemen and protecting Hong Kong government VIPs.

After the Sino-British Joint Declaration was signed in December 1984, the British government decided to abolish the Special Branch. It was formally disbanded at the end of June 1995, thus depriving the Hong Kong government of intelligence collection.

The HKSAR government is expected to reestablish the political department after the model used in pre-handover Hong Kong, with the chief executive of the HKSAR, Tung Chee Hwa, in direct control of the agency, said the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMBIGUOUS PICTURE OF FREE SPEECH IN M'LAND CHINA: REPORT

TEXT.P: Nearly nine years after the Tiananmen Square massacre, intellectuals, dissidents and human rights officials paint an ambiguous picture of the state of free speech in mainland China, said The Baltimore Sun Tuesday.

The newspaper reported from Beijing that the world notices the high-profile release of prominent dissidents such as Wang Dan, sent into exile last weekend, but at the same time Beijing has been quietly ordering fresh arrests of their lesser-known comrades.

Monday, for instance, a Hong Kong-based human rights group announced that a mainland court sentenced democracy activist Wang Tingjin to two years in a labor camp for meeting secretly with a US-based dissident in February.

Some say that in the wake of Deng Xiaoping's death last year, Beijing seems more willing to let people discuss such issues as human rights and political reform. Others note that the authoritarian regime continues to jail those who directly challenge it and that it keeps a tight grip on the media.

The Sun noted that such is the murky nature of political freedom in mainland China that dissident Qin Yongmin can find solace in the fact that the government allows him to write a newsletter publicizing Beijing's continuing efforts to arrest and harass his fellow dissidents.

In university lecture halls and magazines recently, professors and writers have also been testing government limits by speaking out on the need for human rights and the need to develop a new system of government accountable to the citizens. Similar talk in the past resulted in harassment and jail.
Economist Mao Yushi, who recently spoke about the need for greater personal freedom to students at a Beijing university, called this "a very important change."
But other intellectuals remain skeptical, noting that the apparent thaw seems largely confined to college campuses and think tanks.

The Baltimore newspaper told its readership that over the decades, mainland China has experienced periods of openness only to be followed by crackdowns. It cited the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989, following Deng allowing people to hang posters on a Beijing brick wall -- dubbed "Democracy Wall" -- criticizing Communist Party policies in 1978, as an example.

The release of Tiananmen Square student leader Wang Dan is seen as a goodwill gesture two months before President Bill Clinton is to arrive in Beijing for a summit -- the first visit by a US president since the 1989 massacre. But Wang, like another dissident, Wei Jingsheng, had to agree to live in exile in the United States.

Furthermore, the newspaper pointed out, anyone looking for the most recent example of state media control need only look at the newspapers. No word of Wang's release has appeared in the Chinese-language press in Beijing, it said.

Shang Dewen, a professor of economics at Beijing University, who sent an essay to Jiang Zemin last summer about free elections and political reform, said he wants to put his ideas into a book but has been turned down by at least seven publishers, the report added, quoting Shang as saying, "They told me it's ahead of the time."

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed lower still on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, declining 22.55 points to close at 8,613.96.
The bourse opened at 8,624.82 and experienced a low of 8,586.06 and a high of 8,653.23.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 247 to 170, with 68 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.83 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$112.44 billion (US$3.40 billion), decreasing from the previous session, which saw 2.16 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$130.57 billion.

Five of the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper stocks declining the most at 1.1 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 0.8 percent, textile issues at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.6 percent, and cement shares at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, the foodstuff category gained ground, moving up the most at 0.3 percent, followed by both electrical stocks and construction shares at 0.1 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers during Thursday's trading were ACER, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, ASE, Chuntex Electronic Co., Mitac International Corp., Compal Electronic, Twinhead International Corp., United Micro Electronics, Jen Sian Construction and Kuei Hung Industrial.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEGOTIATOR CALLS FOR EXCHANGE OF HIGH-LEVEL VISITS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 23 (CNA) (By Tseng Chun-liang, Yang Huei-chen & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A visiting Taiwan official on Thursday called for the exchange of visits by high-level negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China and the resumption of dialogue between the intermediary bodies serving the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The remarks were made by Jan Jyh-horng, director of the Research and Planning Department of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC). Jan, recently appointed to serve concurrently as a deputy secretary-general of the semiofficial Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and is leading an eight-member ROC delegation in a meeting with officials from the SEF's Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
The rendezvous at Hotel Diaoyutai here marks the first SEF-ARATS encounter in nearly three years.

Jan, whose visit here is widely regarded as a litmus test of whether the regular cross-strait dialogue may be set to resume, has narrowed the focus of the visit to the search for a concrete timetable for an imminent meeting between SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow and his ARATS counterpart Tang Shubei.

In his opening speech, Jan pinpointed Taiwan's ideas about the desired course of cross-strait relations, saying that all achievements reached by the two sides should be treasured, and that active implementation of joint agreements is the only way of nurturing benign interaction.
Jan stressed the importance of expanding exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, which he said was part of an earlier consensus reached by the SEF and the ARATS.

More specifically, Jan said, Taiwan can organize groups of college students, senior journalists and business investors to visit mainland China, while Beijing can send media, educational, and cultural missions to Taiwan.

Jan also took time to spell out Taiwan's concerns over problems arising from increasing contacts between the two sides. He said there are presently more than 600 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants being detained in Taiwan, among whom many have been waiting for repatriation for up to two years.

Meanwhile, he said, mainland underworld figures have supplied Taiwan narcotics traffickers with as much as 1,000 kilograms of heroin and amphetamine annually, a problem which threatens to seriously undermine Taiwan's social order.
Such problems are definitely not conducive to better cross-strait relations, Jan stressed.

Li Yafei, who is leading the Beijing delegation at the discussions, also narrowed the focus of ARATS' agenda, saying that the two sides should fully exchange opinions on a possible visit to Beijing by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu.

Jan and his group are scheduled to meet with ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei at another Beijing hotel in the afternoon. Their itinerary for Friday morning has been kept open. The delegation is scheduled to depart Friday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICE-BREAKING TALKS DRAW MUCH FOREIGN MEDIA ATTENTION

TEXT.P: Despite mainland China's deliberate low-key approach toward the opening in Beijing of an ice-breaking meeting with Taiwan on Thursday, major foreign news media have given prominent coverage to the event.

Radio stations in several countries, including the United States, France, Singapore, Bratain, Australia, Canada and Japan, have reported the event in their regular news programs over the past two days.

The Voice of America said in a morning news program that the eight-member delegation to the current fence-mending meeting is the first group of negotiators from the island to travel to the mainland in nearly three years. The broadcast further said mainland China hopes to discuss political issues at the meeting, but the Taiwan delegation has insisted that nonpolitical practical matters be mulled first.

The British Broadcasting Corp. said a Taiwan delegation, headed by Jan Jyh-horng, a deputy secretary-general of Taipei's semiofficial Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), arrived in Beijing Wednesday for the first face-to-face talks between the two rivals in three years.

The Australian Broadcasting Corp. said mainland China received a semiofficial mission from Taiwan on Wednesday, marking the first direct cross-strait contact since mid-1995 when Beijing unilaterally cut regular dialogue with Taiwan in anger over an ROC President Lee Teng-hui's landmark visit to the United States in June that year. Beijing regarded Lee's visit as a veiled attempt to promote Taiwan independence.
French, Canadian, Singaporean and Japanese national radio stations also gave detailed reports on the event, saying it marks a significant step forward in stalled relations across the Taiwan Strait.

A CNA report from Beijing said correspondents of major Western and Japanese news organizations stationed in the mainland capital city, including Reuters, AFP and the Asahi Shimbun, have also shown keen interest in covering the event, although they were denied access to the meeting venue. Mainland authorities didn't grant them press cards.
Mainland China originally agreed to issue press cards to only a limited number of Taiwan media. It offered them additional permits only after a protest from a Taiwan journalists association.
Hong Kong media have also dispatched a large legion of reporters and photographers to cover the event.

In contrast, mainland Chinese news organizations have turned a cold shoulder to the event. Although a few reporters from the Xinhua New Agency and China News Service were sighted on some occasions, other major mainland media, such as the People's Daily and China National Radio, didn't dispatch reporters to cover the event.

Meanwhile, neither Xinhua nor China Central Television Station sent reporters to cover the opening session of the first meeting in three years of negotiators from Taipei's SEF and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Observers said mainland media's reserved attitude reflects Beijing's official stance on the first direct encounter between the two semiofficial intermediary bodies. "While attaching importance to the event, Beijing would keep it low-profile," a local observer noted.
The SEF and ARATS are authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.08 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at NT$32.991.
The greenback opened at 32.98, and was traded between 32.962 and 33.00.
The interbank trading reached US$260 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTORS PROTEST DETERIORATION OF SAFETY IN SOUTH AFRICA

TEXT.P: Taiwan investors based in South Africa took their indignation over the murder of one of their own to the streets on Thursday, protesting that country's worsening social unrest and the Pretoria government's lack of attempts to improve the situation, according to diplomatic sources in Durban.

Owners of the 27 Taiwan-run companies in South Africa's KwaZulu-Natal Province on Thursday mobilized some 3,000 people -- non-Chinese as well as Chinese -- to rally against the local government for its inaction over the murder of Taiwan textile merchant Wang Neng-shih, 47, on April 18.
The rally, which featured Wang's coffin being borne through the streets, struck a sympathetic chord with investors and businessmen from other countries, some of whom even joined the protest.
A CNN crew videotaped the scene, the sources noted.

Taiwan investors' anxiety over the worsening of South Africa's social order has reached a new peak with Wang's murder and has prompted the businessmen to consider moving their operations out of the country, probably to neighboring Swaziland or Botswana, the sources added.

One plant owner, surnamed Liu, said South Africa has become so unsafe that he has to carry guns with him when going out. Even a gun, however, is not necessarily sufficient protection, he added, noting that bandits in South Africa sometimes carry heavy weapons, such as AK-47s.
According to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, there are currently 620 Taiwan-financed companies operating in South Africa, involving some 30,000 people from the island.
The Taiwan investments, worth about US$1.56 billion, provide employment to 41,240 people, 85.8 percent or 35,384 of whom are local black people.

Even though Taiwan investments have been an important source of foreign capital for South Africa and have helped create a significant number of job opportunities in that country, Pretoria's reluctance to sign an investment guarantee agreement with Taipei and the country's worsening social order are poised to make rumors that Taiwan investors will give up on South Africa once and for all come true, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL TO PLAY VITAL ROLE IN APEC EDUCATION FORUM

TEXT.P: A Taiwan official will assume the post of international coordinator of the Education Forum under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in January 1999.

The APEC Education Forum, established in 1992, is aimed at providing an occasion for APEC education officials to exchange views on education issues and polices, as well as at promoting cooperation in and exchanges of education activities among the 18 APEC economies.
Lee Chen-ching, director of the Bureau of International Cultural and Education Relations under the Education Ministry, said that he is glad he will gain the post.

Lee will be the third person to be international coordinator of the Education Forum. The first person to hold that office was Alan Ginsburg, a director in the US Education Department, whereas the second was Savitri Suwansathit, Thailand's vice minister of education.

Lee was recommended by education officials from the United States and Thailand as international coordinator in January when the APEC Education Forum was held in Indonesia. He received an inquiry earlier this month about his willingness to succeed the Thai official and issued an affirmative reply.
Lee said that he is always available through e-mail, adding that he will do his utmost to provide services for education officials and scholars in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNUAL AIR RAID DRILL HELD

TEXT.P: The annual Wan An No. 21 air raid drill was held on Thursday in Taipei, involving a total of 64,000 Taipei City Government personnel.

Strict traffic controls were imposed during the 40-minute drill which began at 2:00 p.m. Vehicles were required to pull over and pedestrians on the street were required to take shelter, while domestic air flights were suspended.
Similar exercises were held simultaneously in other areas of northern Taiwan, including Taipei County and the cities and counties of Keelung, Ilan, Taoyuan, and Hsinchu.

A spokesman for the Taipei City Police Headquarters said the people of Taiwan still need to remain on guard against the threat of air raids from mainland China despite increasing exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in recent years.

The Chinese communists have never renounced the use of force against Taiwan, and mainland China's military strength has been increasing, with continued purchases of advanced weaponry and frequent war games involving all branches of the armed forces, the spokesman pointed out.
There are currently a total of 24,139 air raid shelters in Taipei, with a total capacity of 12.3 million people, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE RECEIVES GUINEA-BISSAU FIRST LADY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday received Isabel Romano Vieira, wife of President Joao Bernardo Vieira of the Republic of Guinea-Bissau, praising her for her efforts to help the poor.

Mrs. Vieira met Lee and his wife, Tseng Wen-fui, during a courtesy call at the Presidential Office. She was accompanied by Adelino Mano Queta, Guinea-Bissau's ambassador to the Republic of China; Hilia Barder, another of that African country's ambassadors; and Rui Barai, a representative of the Guinea-Bissau Red Cross Society.

Mrs. Vieira, who is president of the Red Cross Society of Guinea-Bissau, president of the Isabel Vieira United Friendship Foundation and honorary president of the Poor Children's Rescue Association, is visiting Taiwan to take part in activities sponsored by the Red Cross Society of the ROC.

In order to promote mutual understanding between the ROC and Guinea-Bissau, Lee suggested that, in addition to the bilateral cooperation on the governmental level, the benevolent institutions of both countries also enhance their exchanges.
He added that the ROC government is willing to work together with the people of Taiwan to provide humanitarian assistance to Guinea-Bissau.
After the meeting, Tseng hosted a lunch party at the Taipei Guest House in honor of the guests.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY TEST-FIRES HAWK MISSILES

TEXT.P: The ROC Army held a routine annual test-firing of HAWK (Homing All the Way Killer) missiles at a military base in southern Taiwan on Thursday.

The exercise, codenamed Wonderful Arrow No. 38, was held at the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology's Jeou-peng base at Hengchun, in the island's southernmost county of Pingtung. It was the first time that the military has opened the heavily camouflaged, tightly guarded Jeou-peng base to local media.

The exercise was designed to test the army's ability to counter an air attack from communist China and began with the hypothetical scenario that two Su-27 jetfighters from mainland China were mounting an attack on eastern Taiwan.
Army Commander-in-Chief Gen. Tang Yao-ming personally chose two of the 18 missile companies taking part in the drill to each fire one HAWK missile to intercept the invading warplanes.
Both the selected army units quickly completed security checks and fired their missiles to destroy drone planes 35 km off the eastern Taiwan coast. Both missiles scored direct hits.
Thursday's test-firing was the second stage of the Wonderful Arrow No. 38 drill. The first phase, in which two HAWK missiles were also fired, was conducted smoothly a few days ago at the same base.

HAWK missiles are designed for medium- and low-altitude air defense. The four HAWK missiles fired in this year's exercise were all third-generation missiles with upgraded reliability and survival rates to keep pace with modern electronic warfare methods. One of the most important features of the third-generation HAWK missile is its greatly improved radar system.

The army finished replacing all its older-generation HAWK missiles with the high-performance third-generation system late last year. In the 1997 missile test-firing drill, four HAWK missiles were fired, the first time the third-generation missiles had been fired outside the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU OK'S ANTI-DUMPING TAX ON FAX MACHINES FROM SIX ASIAN COUNTRIES
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 23 (CNA) (By Bear Lee & P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The European Union (EU) has decided to impose anti-dumping taxes on fax machines from Taiwan and six other Asian countries, EU sources said on Wednesday.
The decision was made earlier in the day at the conference of ministers -- the policymaking body of the organization -- by a vote of nine to six.
The six other affected countries are Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, mainland China and Thailand.
The EU is expected to formally announce the decision before April 30, with the measures becoming effective on May 1 and lasting for a period of five years.

Under the punitive tariffs, Taiwan-originating fax machines will be generally levied with a 36.6 percent tariff except those from Kinpo Electronics Co. and Sampo Co., which will be subject to tariffs of 6 percent and 35.5 percent, respectively.

After a preliminary investigation, the EU on Nov. 1 last year began imposing temporary anti-dumping taxes on fax machines from several Asian exporters, following complaints by the Netherlands-based Phillips company.

According to EU practices, the Executive Commission has to complete its final investigation on the dumping allegations and make a formal suggestion on whether to formally impose the punitive tariffs within six months of its temporary tariffs going into effect.
On March 13, the EU anti-dumping committee voted to abolish the temporary tariffs, but this resolution was vetoed by EU ministers.
Phillips and one of its subsidiaries in Austria have been the major fax machine supplier to EU member countries.
EU statistics show that the seven Asian countries sold a total 978,000 machines to the EU in 1996, increasing to 1.69 million units in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPOTENCE CURE TO BE MARKETED IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Viagra -- the world's first oral pill for impotence and which has become one of the fastest selling drugs in US medical history -- will be marketed in Australia in 1999.

The drug is selling like hot cakes after only two weeks in the US market. Doctors predict similar enthusiasm for the drug -- which helps men sustain erections -- when it goes on sale early next year in Australia.

Sexual physician Chris McMahon of the Australian Center for Sexual Health said there would be a groundswell of demand for the drug among Australian men -- particularly those who had decided not to use current treatments.
"One of the first questions every man with impotence asks is: When will a tablet be available?" he told the mass circulation newspaper The Australian on Thursday.

He said that in the United States, doctors have been deluged with requests for Viagra -- which has obvious benefits over other drugs, which have to be injected into the penis or inserted into the urethra.

He said the pill-popping simplicity of Viagra has apparently captured the attention of American men -- both the impotent and not-so-impotent -- who are looking for ways to enhance their sexual virility.
Australian medical analysts said many of those men seeking the drug are not clinically impotent but are simply hoping the drug will make them as virile as they were in their youth.
The drug helps block an enzyme, phosphodiesterase 5, that makes erections wilt.
Trials in the United States and Australia have shown the drug works for 70 percent of men, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HACKERS WARN THEY HAVE ACCESS TO US MILITARY SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Hackers have been able to break into a high security us military computer system that controls military satellites, according to the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC).
A CBC-TV report on Wednesday said the hackers are from a group that calls itself MOD, or Masters of Downloading. "They called the military last week to brag about their exploits," the report said.
It noted this could be one of the most serious breaches of US defense systems ever.
The group is made up of about 15 people who are from the United States, Britain and Russia. They claimed they stole key operating software last October, the CBC said.
It quoted a member of the group as saying, "I think international terrorist groups would be interested in the data we could gain access to."
US military experts say the hackers' claims are genuine, the CBC added.

The report quoted MOD members as saying the stolen software, known as the Defense Information Systems Network Equipment Manager, is the key to the US network of military Global Positioning System (GPS) satellites.
These systems are used to pinpoint missile strikes, guide troops and assess ground conditions.
The GPS system covers dozens of satellites and is seen as an important US beachhead in the new realm of space warfare.
"It's very dangerous in the wrong hands," one MOD member was quoted as saying in an on-line interview.

"At this point in time, we'd just like this to be a reminder to the Department of Defense that we can down their entire network from a remote location, i.e. anywhere on the earth's surface," the hacker said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALCOHOLISM UP AMONG ABORIGINES, ESPECIALLY THE YOUNG

TEXT.P: The prevalence of alcoholism among Taiwan's tribesmen has increased significantly over the past few years, while the average age of aborigines addicted to alcohol has been declining, a medical scholar warned in Kaohsiung on Thursday.

Professor Ko Ying-ching of Kaohsiung Medical College's public health department cited a Mennonite Christian Hospital report as saying that drinking problems among the island's aboriginal people are no longer confined to the adult population.
Several aboriginal youths around 15 years old have been treated at the Hualien-based hospital for cirrhosis and hypertension, according to the report.
They were all found to be suffering from the diseases due to excessive drinking, Ko said.

A survey conducted four years ago among aborigines older than 16 showed a 66 percent rate of alcoholism among aboriginal males in northern Taiwan and a 25 percent among aboriginal females in the same area, Ko noted.

In southern Taiwan, according to the same survey, half of tribesmen and some 28 percent of tribeswomen were found to be addicted to alcohol, the scholar said, stressing that these figures have risen since that time.

Most of Taiwan's aboriginal residents are genetically predisposed to alcoholism, the medical professor said, adding that under his survey about 3 percent to 6 percent of aborigines who are alcoholics suffer from insomnia and muscle spasms if they do not get regular doses of alcohol.
To effectively resolve the problem, Ko recommended establishing special hospitals to treat alcoholism and training medical personnel to help people stay on the wagon.

DOC.HEADLINE: PR FIRM FORECASTS GAINS IN TAIWAN, M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Hill & Knowlton Inc., a public-relations agency owned by WPP Group PLC of Britain, said it expects its business to grow strongly in mainland China and Taiwan over the next three years, helping to offset any downturns in the rest of the Asia-Pacific region.

Hill & Knowlton CEO Howard Paster was quoted in a Wall Street Journal story on Wednesday as saying that the New York company expects to have "low double-digit growth" in revenue from the region in 1998.

The company's clients are mostly multinational concerns operating in the region. Currently, Asia-Pacific business, excluding Australia and New Zealand, accounts for less than 10 percent of Hill & Knowlton's worldwide revenue. Paster said he expects that proportion to remain "stable or go down a point or so," partly because the company's expanding business in places such as Latin America and Russia is expected to make a bigger contribution to total revenue.

In Asia, meanwhile, Hill & Knowlton sees "a lot of growth" in its business coming from mainland China and Taiwan over the next three years, as multinational companies continue to seek advice on how to launch various product lines in those markets, according to Clifton Kagawa, Hill & Knowlton's Hong Kong-based chief executive for Asia.
In the year ahead, Hill & Knowlton expects the number of staff it employs across Asia to be "flat or grow a little," Kagawa said, adding, "It shouldn't drop."

One big hole on the personnel front, Kagawa said, is a lack of people with information-technology backgrounds who can be hired to act as consultants to the company's computer-industry clients in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILO: DEMOCRACY ESSENTIAL FOR ENSURING GREATER SOCIAL EQUITY

TEXT.P: "Democracy is essential for preventing the harmful distortion of market processed by government, and is also essential for ensuring greater social equity in the development process" Michel Hansenne, director-general of the International Labor Organization (ILO), said here on Wednesday.

At the opening ceremony of the three-day Tripartite Meeting on Social Responses to the Financial Crisis in East and Southeast Asian Countries, Hansenne said that in the worst-affected countries, such as South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand, real GDP growth has turned abruptly from over 7 percent per annum to zero or a negative figure.

Pointing to massive lay-offs, sharp rises in unemployment and the absence of meaningful social safety nets in the worst-affected countries, Hansenne predicted that the financial crisis "will reverse the impressive trends in poverty reduction achieved in recent years."
"Full respect for basic labor standards and the fostering of a strong and free labor movement" are key elements on the road to recovery, the ILO leader stressed.

"The ILO stands ready to assist the governments of our member states in the region to face up to the vigorous structural reforms required, to enhance the necessary dialogue on economic and social policies between governments, and to put in place social safety nets which not only soften the blow of the crisis but contribute to preventing them from occurring," said Hansenne.
The three-day meeting convened by the ILO will examine the social dimension of the Asian financial crisis and review the reform policies adopted in its wake.

Participants from eight countries and regions -- mainland China, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, the Republic of Korea, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, and the Hong Kong Special Administration Region, will formulate specific recommendations aimed at mitigating the suffering of the poor and those thrown into unemployment and at laying the foundation of more equitable -- and sustainable -- patterns of development.
Also participating in the meeting are senior representatives of the Asian Development Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP TO SUPPORT PROF. TIEN CHANGLIN AS US ENERGY SECRETARY

TEXT.P: The Chinese American Civil Rights Organization (CACRO) on Wednesday held a press conference in downtown Los Angeles to express its support for the appointment of Prof. Tien Changlin as secretary of the department of energy in the US federal government.

After hearing that incumbent Energy Secretary Federico Pena has resigned from his current post, CACRO mailed a letter to President Bill Clinton recommending Tien, described as a renowned energy engineering expert, a distinguished educator and an able administrator.
The letter also reminded Clinton that during his campaign, he said he wanted a cabinet which "reflects the diversity of his country," and said now is his opportunity to do something about it.
The CARCO emphasized its mission of affirming equal rights, dignity and fairness for all, without regard to color, race, religion, social or economic status.
The CARCO also said it believes in promoting understanding and cooperation and bridging the social, cultural and language gaps between the Chinese community and mainstream America.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WOULD WELCOME VIETNAM BECOMING APEC MEMBER

TEXT.P: Australia's Foreign Minister Alexander Downer will visit Vietnam April 24-28 and meet with Vietnamese leaders to discuss a range of bilateral issues, including Canberra's aid programs and how Hanoi could become a member of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
In a statement faxed to CNA, Downer said his visit takes place during the 25th anniversary year of the establishment of formal diplomatic relations between Australia and Vietnam.
He said Australia would welcome Vietnam becoming an APEC member.

"While in Vietnam, I will discuss the details of Australia's aid program with Vietnam and explore ways in which Australia and Vietnam can work together in the further economic and social development of Vietnam," he said.

He said Australian businesses are well represented in Vietnam in construction and building supplies, telecommunications, banking, accounting, brewing, manufacturing, dairy products, and education and training.
"I will seek to encourage Vietnamese government leaders to continue their commitment to economic reform which will further open up opportunities for two-way trade and investment," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI RECEIVES HIGH MARKS IN ADB REPORT

TEXT.P: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) said in a report released on Thursday that Taiwan, along with its push for high-technology industries, is also aiming for stable relations, and even direct business and transport links with Beijing.

The report said the ADB believes that positive developments in this direction will help improve the general business climate, adding that the environment for implementing the objectives of the Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center plan will also be more favorable.

In its report entitled "Asian Development Outlook, 1998," the ADB noted that Asia's financial crisis has left Taiwan largely untouched. It said that historically, Taiwan's financial liberalization has been gradual; some critics may even find them too slow, but such a step-by-step policy has probably played a major role in protecting its economy from the financial turmoil of l997.
To sum up, the ADB said, from a long-term perspective, Taiwan is continuing the transition from labor-intensive activities to capital-intensive and high-technology activities.
Although this transition may have posed complex problems of competitiveness, skill bottlenecks, and internal and external balance, an export-driven, high-technology future appears to be attainable.
The report forecast that Taiwan's real GDP growth will recover in 1999, after a slight decline to 5.8 percent in 1998.

With aggregate demand increasing as a result of sustained economic growth, depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar and continued steady growth in service sector prices, the ADB expects Taiwan's consumer price index to grow at 3.2 percent in 1998 and 2.2 percent in 1999.
The ADB report also pointed out that Taiwan saw one of the lowest inflation rates among the newly industrialized economies, 0.9 percent in 1997, down from 3.1 percent in 1996.

The report basically gave Taiwan a positive assessment in its 1997 performance, saying that not only has Taiwan survived this turbulent period, its economy grew at 6.8 percent during 1997, slightly faster than in the previous two years.

Although unemployment rose to 2.7 percent, a little higher than in 1996, the current rate is still relatively low by international standards, and future unemployment rates are not expected to be much higher.
While government investment increased by less than 2 percent, the growth rate of private investment, by contrast, more than doubled in 1997 compared with 1996, to just under 13 percent.

Exports grew by more than 5 percent in 1997, with exports of heavy industrial products holding up particularly well. In sharp contrast, agricultural and processed agricultural exports continued their slowdown, shrinking respectively by as much as 19 and 34 percent.

The value of imports, on the other hand, rebounded in 1997, growing by about 10 percent after stagnating in 1996, with principal imports being machinery, electrical equipment, and chemicals, which together accounted for more than 45 percent of total imports in 1997.
As in 1996, imports of consumer goods grew more, the report observed, adding that this may reflect an increasing consumerist orientation in a maturing economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WILL CONTINUE TO STICK TO TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT: SEF

TEXT.P: The US government is showing intense concern over cross-Taiwan Strait relations and will continue to stick to the assurances provided for in the Taiwan Relations Act, Shi Hwei-yow, secretary-general of the Republic of China's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), has said.
Shi made the comment in an interview in Taipei with The Straits Times, which published the transcript of the interview in its Thursday edition.
When asked about Washington urging Taipei to resume talks with Beijing, Shi replied: "The US government is definitely showing its concern in a more intense manner now than ever before.
"This is understandable, for stable cross-strait relations are certainly in the American interest.
"However, concern and pressure are two different things. Until now, I do not think that this concern is being translated into pressure.
"From our formal channel of dialogue, we understand that the official US position is to stick to the assurances provided for in the Taiwan Relation Act."
Commenting on the cross-strait situation, the ranking SEF official pointed out that the prospects for sustained cross-strait peace and stability "are still clouded with uncertainties."
The immediate prospects for resumption of an orderly cross-strait dialogue seem more certain, he said.
For the latter, he added, "optimistic factors seem to slightly outweigh the pessimistic ones."

Asked what has prompted Beijing to adjust its posture on cross-strait relations, Hsu said that "domestic political dynamics of the three respective cross-strait players, namely the mainland, Taiwan and the United States, as well as the interaction among them, have contributed to this adjustment."
He said that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin "knows that he is no Mao Zedong or Deng Xiaoping, both of whom had bequeathed to China a huge historical legacy."
To leave "his own mark" in history, Jiang has to make some major breakthrough, and Taiwan is the "most obvious choice," Shi noted.
Besides, he commented, a cross-strait rapprochement "will weaken the independence movements in Tibet and Xinjiang."
Then, he added, "there is the American factor."
Shi said that after the summit between Jiang and US President Bill Clinton last October, Beijing tried to put pressure on Taiwan through the United States.
As Clinton's term of office is going to expire in two years' time, "Beijing would like to make the most of his remaining term," he noted.
Likewise, he pointed out, by projecting an image that "Beijing is making compromises in dealing with Taipei, it is trying to neutralize the pro-Taiwan lobby in Washington."
Shi said Beijing's current position is "political issues."
Talks should first tackle the preparatory matters for the political issues; before that, exchanges of ideas on economic and cultural issues may take place in seminars, he added.

"We prefer to move forward step by step: normalization of SEF-ARATS exchanges; followed by the visit between Koo Chen-fu and Wang Daohan, the heads of both the SEF and the Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) respectively; and finally, the second round of Koo-Wang talks," Shi said.

"Our position is simple: Any issue that stands in the way of a smooth cross-strait exchange, be it political or functional, could be brought up for discussion. However, any talks cannot be divorced from reality.
"If we disregard day-to-day issues and indulge in abstract matters, it will also lead to nowhere.

"A problem-oriented approach is more practical. A good example is the hoisting of flags by ships plying between the two sides. It is a highly sensitive political issue, yet it is resolved satisfactorily," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRETORIA URGED TO SIGN INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGREEMENT WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang on Thursday called on the South African government to sign an investment guarantee agreement with Taipei at an early date.
Wang's call comes amid concern over the worsening social order in South Africa which has threatened the lives of thousands of Taiwan businessmen and their families living there.

The minister warned that if the South African government continues to turn a deaf ear to the demand for an investment guarantee agreement and if the Taiwan businessmen based in that country want to relocate their operations to other countries, the Economics Ministry will offer them the necessary assistance.

He said Pretoria shouldn't forget that before severing diplomatic relations with Taipei, it promised to maintain the highest-level relations, second only to formal ties, with Taiwan, but pointed out that it doesn't seem to be keeping its promise at the moment. South Africa switched diplomatic recognition to mainland China at the beginning of this year.

Wang said that his ministry has expressed its concern to the South African government over the security of Taiwan businessmen there and has demanded that Pretoria strengthen security measures to provide Taiwan businessmen and overseas Chinese there with a safe living environment.

According to news reports, a group of some 3,000 Taiwan businessmen in KawZulu-Natal Province are preparing to stage a demonstration to protest the recent murder of a Taiwan businessman, as well as the country's worsening social order.

The death of Taiwan textile merchant Wang Neng-shih, 47, who was murdered on April 18 by three unidentified gunmen in an industrial park in the province, has sent another shock wave through the Chinese community. Taiwan businessmen are now seriously considering moving their operations out of the country, probably to neighboring Swaziland or Botswana, following a series of attacks targeting businessmen from the island.

On March 14, Cheng Yuan-yuan and her South African fiance were attacked by four men at their bar in Welkom, Orange Free State. Cheng was shot dead at the scene, while her fiance was seriously injured. Earlier in the month, Taiwan businessman Chen Lian-fu, his wife and their children were taken hostage when five armed men broke into their house. In February, artist Chia Lun-sheng was killed by robbers at his residence in Johannesburg.

There are currently 620 Taiwan-financed companies operating in South Africa, involving some 30,000 people from the island. Taiwan investments are worth about US$1.56 billion and have provided 41,240 job opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NOT FOLLOWING IN TOKYO'S FOOTSTEPS

TEXT.P: As the US trade deficit with mainland China continues to increase, concern is mounting that mainland China will soon replace Japan as America's major trade headache.

Such concerns are fed by an image of mainland China as another Japan -- a country pursuing a mercantilist development strategy based on closed markets, an undervalued currency, and a structural trade surplus, according to Prof. Laura D'Andrea Tyson of economics and business administration at the University of California at Berkeley.

Contributing an article to the current issue of Business Week, Tyson pointed out that mainland China is not following in Japan's footsteps. The evidence reveals compelling economic differences. First, although mainland China's system poses structural barriers to foreign competition, as does Japan's, mainland China does not enjoy a persistent current account surplus, a defining characteristic of a mercantilist state. Rather, mainland China's current account balance exhibits cyclical swings, alternating between years of deficit and surplus.

Second, Tyson said, in contrast to Japan, mainland China has opened its door to foreign direct investment. Third, mainland China and Japan have responded very differently to the Asian economic crisis, which hit at a difficult time for both countries. Japan, unable to change policy, is sinking into recession, while mainland China is embarking on a painful path of restructuring its loss-ridden banks and state-owned enterprises and is laying off millions of underemployed workers.

Tyson said mainland China's outward-looking policy courage stands in stark relief to the inward-looking timidity of Japan. Mainland China is rapidly emerging as the dominant economic power in postcrisis Asia, and its participation in the World Trade Organization, like its presence in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, will bolster the strength of the multilateral system, She added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SISY CHEN TO VIE FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) spokeswoman Sisy Chen announced on Thursday that she will run for the party's top post and abandon her bid to seek the party's nomination for the year-end legislative elections.

Chen told a news conference that she will register as a candidate for DPP chairman on Friday. "I'll simultaneously withdraw my bid for the party's nomination for the parliamentary election to avert speculation that my DPP chairmanship bid is nothing more than a campaign gimmick to win the party's nomination for the legislative race."

Chen outlined her goals behind her decision to join the DPP chairmanship race -- offering new thinking and new concepts, proving that women can lead a major political party, demonstrating her courage to pursue her dreams, and reviving the DPP's idealism.

A confident, articulate Chen said the future DPP chairman will have two lofty missions: to help maintain Taiwan's political stability and to boost the island's economic development in the years ahead.

Asserting that the ruling Kuomintang is doomed to fall apart because of power struggles among its middle-aged politicians, Chen said the DPP, as Taiwan's largest opposition party, should assume the responsibility of helping to preserve political stability. "So the next DPP chairman must be a capable, charismatic leader to win popular support and trust."

Chen lamented that over the past 11 years, factional strength and debate over candidates' moral stature and character have dominated the DPP chairmanship election. "Nowadays, we live in a different political climate and face different challenges. We need a capable leader with vision and ideals."

Moreover, Chen said, the future DPP chairperson must have a clear grasp of major economic issues. "All former DPP leaders were only familiar with democracy, human rights and political topics," she criticized.

Chen vowed to be a unique political figure. "I have taken part in opposition political activities for 20 years. I fully understand how political power operates. It's regrettable that women still play a limited role in Taiwan's politics. I feel compelled to join the DPP chairmanship race to prove that women also have political wisdom and know-how."

Chen predicted frankly she will certainly lose the contest, but added that she will make the battle more interesting. "My function in the party is to be the leader of concept and opinion. Even if I lose the race, my views will still be the winner."
Two DPP male politicians -- top party adviser Lin Yi-hsiung and Legislator Yen Chi-fu -- already registered for the chairmanship contest. The registration will close on Friday.

This will be the first time the DPP chairman is elected directly by the party members, who are estimated to number slightly more than 80,000. Before the voting takes place on May 24, the DPP headquarters will hold three rounds of televised debates for all candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST QUARTER UNEMPLOYMENT AT 2.42 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate declined further in the first quarter of this year to 2.42 percent, down 0.39 percentage points from the same period of last year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced on Thursday.
However, the consumer price index (CPI) grew only 1.55 percent during the three months, lower than the projected 2.1 percent, it said.

The lower unemployment and CPI growth enabled Taiwan to register a lower misery index, at only 3.97 percent, for the three-month period, compared to the 4.5 percent registered for the same period of last year.

The misery index, a combination of the unemployment rate and the CPI, is a measurement of the degree of a nation's economic difficulties, with an index of over 20 percent being "miserable," and an index of less than 10 percent being "excellent."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT DENIES THAT NT$36.28 MILLION LOAN WAS POLITICAL DONATION

TEXT.P: Vice President Lian Chan said on Thursday that in the 1993 local election, he lent more than NT$30 million to the Kuamintang candidate Wu Tse-yuan, former chief of Pingtung County, because Wu did not have enough fund for his campaign.
He made the remarks after visiting the Bethany nursery in Pingtung, Taiwan's southernmost county.

The vice president told reporters that during 1993 when he was serving as premier, the KMT was having difficulty fielding a candidate for Pingtung County. He said that in order to allow Wu to run in the election, he promised to lend him money, and that more than NT$30 million was later remitted to Wu through a bank account belonging to Wu Chin-jan, Wu's younger brother.
"This is a simple matter," he said, urging the public not to develop a distorted view of the issue.
Asked whether the matter involved the question of a political donation, Lien replied: "That is not the way to look at it."

The issue was raised a day earlier when National Assemblyman Lee Wen-chung held a press conference during which he presented two bank documents as proof that Lien and Wu may have had an "improper financial transaction."

Lee went to the Control Yuan on Thursday to inform the highest-level government watchdog body that Fang Yui, Lien's wife, had remitted a total of NT$36.28 million to Wu Chin-jan. He was received by Control Yuan member Lin Meng-kui, who said Lee wanted to know whether the transaction was legal.

Commenting on the matter, Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen said on Thursday that although political donations surpassing the legal amount are illegal, there are no penalties involved, and that if the money was a personal loan, then nothing unlawful took place.

Based on the election law, personal political donations cannot exceed NT$20,000, while donations from businesses cannot exceed NT$300,000. In addition, tax laws governing this situation prohibit any individual from receiving more than NT$1 million in a single year.

Pingtung Legislator Cheng Chao-ming of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party meanwhile asked the Finance Ministry to investigate whether the ministry lost NT$7.47 million in taxes if the money was indeed a grant.
Huang said he will ask the Pingtung election committee to investigate and make a report within a week on Wu's election funds during the period at issue.

Meanwhile, the former Pingtung County chief issued a statement explaining the details of the transactions between Lien and himself. He stressed that the money was a loan which he has been unable to repay, thereby implicating his former superior and leaving himself wracked with guilt.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER, SIEMENS ANNOUNCE JOINT VENTURE PARTNERSHIP

TEXT.P: Taiwan computer giant Acer on Thursday announced an international joint venture partnership, saying that it will sign a formal accord with the Germany-based Siemens Nixdorf in June to acquire that company's personal computer division.

Describing the joint venture as a mutually beneficial labor-division alliance, Acer Chairman Stan Shih said Taiwan should play a value-added supplier role in the highly competitive global information industry market, pointing out that Acer is strong in PC production, while Siemens Nixdorf has the advantage in product programming, marketing, and after-sale service.

Siemens Nixdorf President Gerhard Schulmeyer said Siemens's decision to sell its PC division to Acer does not mean that the group is set to withdraw from the international PC market, but rather, the cooperative venture will allow it to provide customers with more competitive products.

Under the terms of the agreement, Acer will acquire Siemens Nixdorf's PC division, including its production, assembly, research and development, purchasing, and resourcing facilities, which are based in Augsburg, southern Germany.

Acer will in future be in charge of manufacturing about 1.4 million desktop PCs for Siemens Nixdorf per year, with the focus on the European market, while Siemens Nixdorf will control product marketing and after-sale service.

Lin Hsien-ming, general manager of Acer's information industry department, said the joint venture will ensure that Acer will obtain long-term orders from Siemens Nixdorf, and allow the company to own a European stronghold for production and assembly.

The addition of the Augsburg plant following the establishment of similar production centers in mainland China, the Philippines, Mexico, and the United States, means that Acer's plan to build a global manufacturing network has almost been accomplished, Lin noted.

Local industry sources said the strategic alliance is expected to greatly boost Acer's output, helping it take a big step toward its goal of setting up a global management and sourcing network and becoming one of the world's top five PC companies. Acer is currently the world's seventh-largest computer firm, with an annual output of more than six million PCs.
Siemens Nixdorf is Europe's biggest PC company, selling 1.1 million PCs last year in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO'S VISIT TO MAINLAND CHINA AGREED IN CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: A landmark visit by Taiwan's top liaison officer with mainland China, Koo Chen-fu, will be arranged by the end of the year, according to consensus reached on Thursday at a meeting between officials of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the SEF's mainland counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), had a 30 minute meeting which focused on a possible visit to Beijing by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu.

Jan, who arrived in Beijing on Wednesday afternoon for a three-day ice-breaking visit, said after the meeting that Tang accepted the SEF proposal, first made last November, that Koo should make a visit to the mainland by the end of the year.

He also said that Tang is hopeful that Koo's visit can be "simplified," and that the ARATS vice chairman agreed to give up an earlier condition that cross-strait talks on political issues should be held prior to Koo's visit.

Describing the meeting as making significant progress in the cross-strait relations stalled for the past three years, Jan said at a press briefing that he is hopeful that the two sides will be able to hammer out the details of Koo's visit during further discussions.

The SEF chairman's visit is expected to lead to a long-expected meeting between Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan. Koo and Wang first met in April, 1993 in Singapore, where they signed four agreements laying a framework for resolving non-political issues resulting from increasing cross-strait exchanges. However, a second round of talks failed to materialize after mainland authorities unilaterally suspended contacts to vent Beijing's anger over a trip to the United States by ROC President Lee Teng-hui in June, 1995.
In the absence of official ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, contacts are handled by the SEF and the ARATS, both of which are semi-official bodies.

Tang told reporters after the meeting that the ARATS welcomes the proposal that Koo should lead a delegation on a visit to the mainland, and said he hopes that Taiwan can present a timetable for the trip so that the mainland side can make the necessary preparations. He added that the mainland authorities have not set up any obstacles to the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY COURTS TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Paraguayan Industry and Commerce Minister Atilio Fernandez on Thursday urged Taiwan businesses to invest in his country and promised to help those who are already operating there to expand into the Southern Common Market.
Fernandez made the remarks while attending the 10th ROC-Paraguay Economic Cooperation Conference, which opened here on Thursday and is being co-chaired by his ROC counterpart Wang Chih-kang.
Fernandez said Taiwan businesses should consider investing in Paraguay as the country is competitive in many fields.

According to Fernandez, Paraguay has an abundant young workforce and cheap electricity. As a member state located in the center of the Southern Common Market, it can also serve as a gateway into neighboring member countries such as Argentina, Brazil, and Uruguay.

Fernandez promised to help the more than 70 Taiwan companies currently operating in Paraguay to explore the Southern Common Market, the population of which will increase to about 200 million with the forthcoming entry of Chile and Bolivia.

Foreign investors in Paraguay will enjoy the same investment incentives as local people, and Paraguay will provide adequate investment guarantees to foreign companies under the framework of the World Trade Organization, he pointed out.

For his part, Wang said bilateral trade and economic cooperation has increased noticeably since the ninth ROC-Paraguay economic cooperation meeting was held last year in Asuncion, the capital city of the South American country.

Wang expressed the hope that more Taiwan businesses will invest in Paraguay, as a Taiwan-funded industrial park in Eastern City in southern Paraguay is scheduled to be inaugurated in August, which he said can serve as a base from which to break into the Southern Common Market.

Officials with the Ministry of Economic Affairs said the two countries are expected to discuss joint efforts to crack down on commercial piracy and bilateral cooperation in the small business and agricultural sectors on Friday, the closing day of the meeting.
Fernandez arrived in Taipei on Wednesday for a weeklong visit, during which he is scheduled to visit ranking ROC government officials including President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC YOUNG LEADERS CONFERENCE SLATED FOR APRIL 27-30

TEXT.P: The Asia-Pacific Young Leaders Conference 1998 is scheduled to be held in Taipei on April 27-30 with 135 representatives from 18 nations and areas participating.

Premier Vincent Siew will deliver a keynote speech on April 27 to officially kick off the event, while Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will press a button to open the Asia-Pacific Young Leaders Information Exchange Center on-line service. The website can be found at: www.apyl.org.tw.

Under the theme "Hand-in-Hand Toward Development," the annual conference will be highlighted this year by the launch of the Taiwan-initiated cyberspace service and a meeting of Asian Pacific officials in charge of youth-related affairs, said Lee Chi-chu, chairperson of the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission, which sponsors the regional gathering.

According to Lee, youth services officials from throughout the region have been invited to the roundtable, where they will discuss various issues relating to young people and policies to enhance cooperation and exchanges among nations and areas in the Asia-Pacific region.
So far, officials from New Zealand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Vietnam have confirmed their attendance at the meeting, Lee noted.
Jay Wickliff, chairman of the Presidential Classroom, headquartered in Washington, D.C., will be on hand to deliver a keynote speech on the character and roles of young leaders in the 21st century.
Wickliff is also scheduled to visit Taipei's most prestigious secondary school, the Chien Kuo High School, on April 28, to deliver a speech and talk with students.
On April 28, ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu will given an overview of youth-related affairs within the Asia-Pacific context.

Lee said the conference will receive added significance as her commission has arranged a workshop on transcentury economic and financial prospects in Taiwan and other Asia-Pacific countries. The moderators will include Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, and a panel of leading Taiwan-based economists and scholars.

Among the 135 expected participants at the regional conference, there will be around 60 overseas guests from 17 countries and areas. These are Australia, Canada, Fiji, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Tonga, Vietnam and the United States.
On the last two days of the gathering, the conference goers will make field visits to cultural and economic establishments in northern and central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 19 CASES OF DENGUE FEVER FOUND IN TAIWAN THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: A total of 19 people in Taiwan have been treated for dengue fever so far this year, with all of them found to have contracted the ailment overseas, a spokesman for the Department of Health (DOH) indicated on Friday.

The spokesman noted that all of the cases originated from countries in Southeast Asia. Seven persons contracted the sometimes-fatal disease in Indonesia, five in the Philippines, four in Malaysia, two in Thailand and one in Myanmar.
The DOH accordingly urges local people to take precautionary measures against mosquito bites when traveling in Southeast Asia, the official said.

According to DOH data on dengue fever, the infectious illness carried by mosquitoes in tropical climates has been a leading cause of death in Indonesia. Outbreaks of the disease on the densely populated island of Java are most common in March and April.
DOH cited Indonesian medical statistics as saying that 85 dengue fever cases, which resulted in four deaths, were reported in the western Java area during the January-March period this year.
In southern Sumatra, a total of 3,009 people have been infected with dengue fever this year, with 116 fatalities resulting from the disease, the DOH said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAN COMMITTED TO DEMOCRATIC DEVELOPMENT IN MAINLAND
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 23 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Prominent mainland China dissident Wang Dan said here on Thursday that he is committed to the democratic development of his homeland, and that he plans to continue his studies in the United States.

Wang, who arrived in the United States last week, appeared in high spirits and spoke openly in a press conference about his optimism for the development of freedom and democracy in the mainland, but declined to give a timetable for achieving that goal.
However, the 29-year-old dissident said he believes progress in democratic development on the Chinese mainland will come faster than many observers have predicted.
Citing the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, he said the leaders in Beijing can no longer suppress the Chinese people's aspirations for democracy and freedom.

Wang also said he considers his role in the 1989 Tiananmen Square events to have more demirits than merits, and he expressed "lifelong remorse" for the hundreds of students demonstrators who were killed indiscriminately in an army crackdown on the protest.
He claimed he had been young and naive then, and that if he could relive those events, he probably could handle the situation differently so that no one would be killed in vain.

But Wang stressed that the leadership in Beijing should ultimately bear the blame, vowing to fight all his life for democracy and human rights on the mainland, in order to atone for the guilt he holds for those who were killed at Tiananmen Square.
He described newly installed Premier Zhu Rongji as the "most pragmatic, and determined" mainland leader he has seen, and urged Zhu to promote political as well as economic reforms on the mainland.

Wang said pressure from the international community has helped improve the human rights situation there. He urged people everywhere not to forget those dissidents, especially Liu Nianchun, Liu Xiaobo, Kao Yi and Li Hai, that continue to languish in prison, even though he himself is now free.

Wang urged US President Bill Clinton to continue voicing concern for the political prisoners and prisoners of conscience on the mainland, and to prod Beijing for their release when he visits there in June.

As to why he had changed his mind and agreed to go into exile in the United States, Wang stressed that he was reluctant to leave the mainland, but made the decision because he felt his studies were lagging after long years in prison. He also indicated that his high-profile put him under constant surveillance by security officials, which meant that he could no longer contribute to the democracy movement in the mainland.
In addition, Wang said he worried about his aging parents, who had to travel a long distance from Beijing to visit him in prison.

Wang said he has mixed feelings at present. On one hand, he is happy to breathe the air of freedom in the United States, and on the other hand he is sad over being separated from his homeland, family and friends.

Wang said he is most happy to be a free intellectual, asserting that intellectuals can play a major role in the development of the mainland. He revealed that one of his biggest hopes is to publish a magazine in the mainland.

Wang also said that he wants to pursue advanced studies in the United States, but that he will not accept financial assistance from any partisan group. Rather, Wang said he would support himself by working part-time.

Wang was sentenced to four years in prison for his role in the Tiananmen Square protests. After his release, he was charged with subversion last year and sentenced to 11-year imprisonment. He was released last week on medical grounds and sent directly to Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit for a physical checkup.
Wang was released after two days in the hospital with a clean bill of health and flew to New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA REAFFIRMS PRAGMATIC DIPLOMATIC POLICY

TEXT.P: The government will continue its pragmatic diplomatic policy of reaching out to the international community, Roy Wu, spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.
Wu's comments followed the remarks by Premier Vincent Siew that he has instructed the MOFA to step up arrangements for overseas visits by him.
Wu noted that the MOFA is actively watching for opportunities for the ROC president, vice president, premier and other senior government officials to travel abroad.
He stressed that the target areas for such contacts will not be confined to any particular countries or region, but will be global in scope.
He said that as a sovereign state, the Republic of China must maintain a presence within the international community, and that it has always kept close communications with other nations.
Wu said that plans for a trip by Premier Siew to some of the ROC's diplomatic allies are currently in progress, and that the MOFA will announce details in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEES RECORD NUMBER OF SPOONBILLS WINTERING

TEXT.P: A total of 330 black-faced spoonbills, an endangered species of migratory bird, migrated to wetlands in southern Taiwan to winter during the past season, the highest number on record, the Chinese Wild Bird Federation (CWBF) reported on Friday.

A CWBF spokesman quoted the latest tallies of the BirdLife Asia Council as showing that the population of black-faced spoonbills has increased by some 100 to a total of about 650 worldwide during 1997-98.
