The number of the wading birds spending the winter in Taiwan's wetlands was also found to have increased the most among the areas comprising its habitat, the spokesman said.

Beginning in late September each year, large numbers of black-faced spoonbills arrive at the mouth of Tsengwen Creek in Chiku Village, Tainan, and the coastal wetlands of Putai, Chiayi, southern Taiwan, to winter, making those areas the primary habitat of the species.

According to the BirdLife Asia Council, other black-faced spoonbills, believed to have migrated from scattered areas of North Asia, including the Korean Peninsula, also flew to Japan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Vietnam for their winter stay.

To better understand the behavioral patterns and natural habitat of the rare birds, a species endemic to Asia, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture has cooperated with Japanese ornithological societies in using transmitters to trace their movements.
COA officials said they have been able to pinpoint the whereabouts of the usually elusive birds with the help of the transmitters attached to the their backs.
At present, three black-faced spoonbills carrying the devices are still in the southern Taiwan wetland and have not returned to their northern home, according to the CWBF.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NO HASTE, BE PATIENT' POLICY SHOULD STAND: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Despite the huge trade surplus Taiwan has enjoyed with the mainland over the past decade, the ROC government's "no haste, be patient" policy toward investing there should stand, the top official in charge of mainland policy said on Friday.
Chang King-yu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks when speaking at a seminar in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Chang said that current mainland policy was formulated in accordance with the National Unification Guidelines, which charts the course of Taiwan's unification with the mainland in stages.
He said trade across the Taiwan Strait has reached US$140 billion over the past decade, and that US$26.4 billion in goods were exchanged last year alone, with Taiwan enjoying huge trade surplus.

In addition, at least 20,000 Taiwan manufacturers have invested more than US$11 billion on the mainland. Chang pointed out that if each manufacturer were to station 10 employees there, that would translate into 200,000 Taiwan residents living under the political influence of the mainland Chinese system.
He stressed that without economic security, there can be no political security, and that without economic independence, there can be no political freedom.

As the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are unable to sign an investment guarantee agreement at the moment, the ROC government has to adopt a diversification strategy that takes into consideration the overall interests of Taiwan residents when working out its mainland policy, Chang said.

He expressed hope that this week's visit to the mainland by Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the semiofficial Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), will help revive the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.
Meanwhile, the opposition New Party will hold a seminar on mainland China policy Sunday.

Jaw Shau-kong, the party's campaign manager for year-end elections, noting that Taiwan enjoyed a trade surplus of US$16.6 billion with the mainland last year, said that huge imbalance was created through the efforts by Taiwan businessmen, even though they have had little government support.

Jaw also criticized the industrial policy of the rival opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which opened a three-day meeting on industrial policy Friday. He described the DPP outlook as "limited in both vision and scope," saying the party focuses only on Taiwan.

Jaw claimed that economic progress in Taiwan cannot be confined to local development, saying the island should consider giving the mainland a helping hand at a time when the newly installed Premier Zhu Rongji has stressed economic reforms. He added that this approach would be beneficial to both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MEMBERS OF CONGRESS SPEAK OUT ON RELEASE OF MAINLAND DISSIDENTS

TEXT.P: US Senator Connie Mack (R-Fla.) and Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) objected Thursday to what they claim is a US policy of striking deals with Beijing to obtain the parole of famous dissidents such as Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan, while overlooking the thousands still in prisons and forced labor camps.

However, they said in a joint statement on the release of Wang that, "We are pleased to see Wang Dan on the free soil of the United States where he can join the chorus of voices calling for freedom, democracy, and respect for human dignity within the People's Republic of China."

Wang and Wei have been repeatedly nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize in recent years "because of their courageous commitment to human rights and fundamental freedoms. Together, these two men symbolize the defining core of China's contemporary pro-democracy movement," according to the statement.

But the two US Congress members stressed their release does not warrant praise for Beijing, adding that, "Wang Dan was not freed, he was expelled from his country; and he has not been cleared of the charges against him, he is out of prison only for 'medical reasons.'"

They described Wang Dan's release over the weekend as "the moral equivalent of someone robbing a bank and expecting praise for offering to return the stolen money in the form of a loan." Then they asked, "Are we supposed to thank Beijing for expelling a man from his home after he was wrongfully imprisoned in the first place?"

The joint statement continued that Wang's release "represents Beijing's attempts, with some American complicity, to deflect human rights criticism as we approach President Clinton's planned trip to Beijing. We cannot let this hollow act succeed."

They said Wang is a great hero of freedom and democracy not only for the people of mainland China, but for the world. As strong advocates for his release, the pair said they are pleased to see him out of prison. Both Mack and Pelosi said they are certain congressional pressure on the administration had a great deal to do with his release.

But they concluded that: "We must remain vigilant in our opposition to the enemies of freedom in the world. Wang Dan symbolizes all who are oppressed in China, but his release does not mean that the political climate has changed."

DOC.HEADLINE: ADB OFFICIAL SHUNS USE OF ROC NAME

TEXT.P: Asian Development Bank (ADB) Vice President Bong-Suh Lee declined comment Thursday on the Republic of China's efforts to change the name "Taipei, China," which it is required to use at ADB functions.
Officials from the ROC claim the name implies it is subordinated to mainland China.
But Lee noted that the ROC is one of the ADB's founding members and that Taiwan is a "strong pillar" of the Asian economy.

Speaking at a press conference on release of the ADB's annual publication "The Asian Development Outlook," Lee pointed out that Taiwan is an important member of the ADB, and that it has been least affected among regional economies by the current Asian financial crisis.
But Lee shunned from discussion of all matters involving "designations with commas or without commas."
According to the ADB report, Taiwan will likely maintain its growth momentum with the GDP growth rate projected at 5.8 percent in 1998 and 6.2 percent in 1999. Its GDP grew by 6.8 percent in 1997.

The report also noted that the strength of the economy of mainland China and its currency will become an anchor for regional economic stability in 1998. The mainland economy is projected to remain healthy, although its GDP growth rate may fall slightly to 7.2 percent in 1998, and to 6.8 percent in 1999, from 8.8 percent in 1997.

It also forecasted that the Hong Kong dollar and the mainland renminbi to he subjected to more speculative attacks, saying, "The success with which the authorities defend these exchange rates will have important implications for the recovery of the Asian economies."

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BARRIERS SET FOR KOO-WANG MEETING: CHANG KING-YUH

TEXT.P: There are no barriers set for the meeting between Koo Chen-fu and Wang Daohan, the chief negotiators across the Taiwan Strait, and having the meeting take place at a seminar has not been ruled out either, said Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Taipei-based cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), on Thursday.

Chang made the statement in response to remarks by Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), about the matter. Tang said he hopes Taipei will not to set barriers to the Koo-Wang meeting.

Whenever the time is proper, said Chang, a meeting between Koo and Wang can go ahead. The top negotiators of the two sides of the strait, however, must arrange for and confirm matters prior to the meeting, he added.

Koo is the chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), while Wang, his mainland counterpart, is head of ARATS. The SEF and ARATS are the semi-official organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of government-to-government contacts between the two sides.

Jan Jyh-horng, the newly appointed deputy secretary-general of the SEF, met with his mainland counterpart Li Yafei and ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei on Thursday. Later that evening, Koo presided over a meeting of high-ranking SEF and MAC officials. Chang made his remarks after the latter meeting when he met the press.

In view of the understanding reached by the two quasi-official cross-strait bodies that they will do their best to make the Koo-Wang meeting a reality, Koo said to the press with a smile that since a common understanding has been reached, more effort will be made to push the matter forward. The timing of the meeting, he added, will be discussed later.

Chang said that as early as last year, Taipei indicated that a meeting between Koo and Wang can be held "whenever it is proper" and that Taipei has set no barriers to it. He said he hopes that Koo can make a visit to the Chinese mainland by the end of 1998.

Taipei has not ruled out a meeting between Koo and Wang that takes place by means of the two attending some kind of seminar, noted Chang, adding that although this method is possible, it would take much more time than a single visit or panel discussion. He added that he hopes a series of exchanges between the two sides will start as soon as the deputy secretary-generals of both sides have completed their discussions.

Chang, in the meantime, stressed that a chairman-level meeting between the two sides should be paved by the vice chairmen of the two cross-strait negotiating bodies, indicating that Taipei believes a meeting between Tang and his Taiwan counterpart, SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow, is mandatory.

Chang went a step further by saying that according to the rules of systematic contacts between the two sides, regular exchanges between the two vice chairmen is essential, citing the need to communicate protocol matters easily.

Shi echoed Chang's remarks, saying that it is necessary to hold the Shi-Tang meeting first so that details of the Koo-Wang meeting can be confirmed. The Beijing authorities have not ruled out Shi-Tang meeting, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Market (TAIEX), with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 22.15 points to close at 8,636.11.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 8,571.02 and experienced a high of 8,640.38.
Gainers outnumbered losers by 246 to 155, with 87 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.84 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$101.68 billion (US$3.08 billion), increasing in volume but decreasing in value from the previous session, which saw 1.83 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$112.44 billion.

Six of the eight major categories gained ground, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.8 percent, construction issues at 0.6 percent, both cement shares and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.2 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, both the bank and insurance category and electrical stocks remained unchanged.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Friday's trading were Ever Fortune Industries, Mitac International Corp., ASE, Shin Yih Fiber, China Manmade Fibers, ACER, Chuntex Electronic Co., Compal Electronic Inc., Jen Hsian Construction and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT THANKS MJIB AGENTS FOR BUSTING COUNTERFEITING RING

TEXT.P: A senior official with the de facto American embassy in Taiwan paid a visit to the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) on Friday, expressing gratitude for the bureau's busting of a Motorola cellular phone parts counterfeiting ring here on Thursday.

David Harrison, head of the intellectual property rights (IPR) protection division at the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), said the breakup of the ring has once again manifested Taiwan's determination to eradicate commercial piracy.
Harrison said the United States is more than willing to cooperate with Taiwan in fighting crime and improving IPR protection.

Investigators with the MJIB's Taipei outpost busted a counterfeiting ring in Taipei and arrested three key suspects involved in counterfeiting cellular phone parts and trademarks of several world-renowned companies, including Motorola of the United States and Ericsson of Sweden.

The investigators confiscated more than 200 cases of bogus Motorola and Ericsson cellular phone parts at Chao-hsuan Industrial Co., which allegedly had produced the fake goods for export to Italy, Hong Kong and Malaysia.

Harrison asked the MJIB to provide data concerning plants in those countries which allegedly would assemble the Taiwan-originated bogus parts into cellular phones. Harrison said he will transfer the information to American law-enforcement authorities for further investigation.
The AIT is a semiofficial body founded by the US to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PRAISES SEF NEGOTIATOR'S BEIJING TRIP

TEXT.P: The cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday praised the recent visit to Beijing by the deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Jan Jyh-horng, as an example of "benign interaction" and said it will be conducive to the resumption of the cross-strait dialogue.

MAC Chairman Chang King-yuh characterized Jan's April 22-24 visit to mainland China, during which Jan and his Beijing counterparts reached a consensus that SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu will visit Beijing within the year, as "fairly good."

Meanwhile, MAC Vice Chairman and spokesman Sheu Ke-sheng lauded the Beijing journey of Jan and an eight-member delegation, calling it "an important step forward" toward closer interaction between the SEF and its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS). The meeting marked the end to a 34-month hiatus in such cross-strait gatherings.
During his meeting with ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei Thursday afternoon, Jan formally invited ARATS Deputy Secretary-General Li Yafei to visit Taipei. The invitation has been received favorably.

Jan, who is scheduled to return to Taipei around 8:50 p.m. Friday, however, would not elaborate on why the Beijing authorities said they would "skip" a meeting between Tang and his Taipei counterpart, Shi Hwei-yow, that was to precede the meeting between Koo and his mainland counterpart, ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.
Beijing authorities apparantly want to have Koo and Wang meet directly, without any other "procedural arrangements in advance," observers in Taipei said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DENIES SUSPENDING ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: As the latest round of arms sales discussions in Washington between the United States and the Republic of China drew to what was described as a successful conclusion, a senior US official Thursday flatly denied reports that Washington was suspending military sales to Taiwan in preparation for US President Bill Clinton's visit to Beijing in June.
Asked whether there was any possibility of the administration halting arms sales to Taiwan, albeit temporarily, the senior State Department official said simply, "No."

The denial came after a Japanese newspaper, Sankei Shimbun, quoted unnamed US sources as saying that the US government intended to suspend sales of military hardware to Taiwan in anticipation of a June summit meeting between Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin. Earlier this week, the Defense News, a well-informed weekly based in Springfield, VA, carried a similar report.

It also followed recent assurances given by other administration officials that the US policy on arms sales to Taiwan remains unchanged. The United States had promised, though privately, that there would not be a date by which it would end arms sales to Taiwan and that Washington would not consult Beijing prior to such transactions.

The terse reassurance, given at a background briefing on Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's visit to East Asia next week, is likely to dispel some of the nervousness felt by many in Taipei over the rapid warming of relations between Washington and Beijing since Jiang's visit to the United States last November.

As always, little has been revealed about the latest talks between US and ROC military personnel on Taiwan's defense requirements. Sources would only say that the talks went smoothly earlier this week and that some conclusions had been reached. One well-placed source also told CNA that part of the Defense News article was incorrect.

The source was referring to the claim, quoted in the article, that approved sales to Taiwan could be delayed indefinitely with the administration focused on the presidential visit. Even though the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act stipulates that the US government should provide Taiwan with defensive weapons, Beijing has taken exception to continued US arms sales to the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.05 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Friday, closing at NT$32.986.
The greenback opened at 32.99, and was traded between 32.97 and 33.00.
The interbank trading reached US$225 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S IC INDUSTRY TO INVEST US$79.2 BILLION WITHIN 13 YEARS

TEXT.P: The domestic IC industry plans to invest a total of US$79.2 billion (NT$2.61 trillion) between now and the year 2010, the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) reported on Friday.

The IDB reported the investment figure during a meeting on Friday titled "Developing Taiwan to Become the Manufacturing Center of the Asia-Pacific Region," which was hosted by Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang.
The domestic IC industry has proposed investing a total of US$79.2 billion within the next 10 to 13 years, mainly in the opening of 8- and 12-inch wafer plants and IC assembly plants, it said.
The individual investments are as follows:

United Micro Electronics plans to invest US$18.8 billion within the next ten years, mainly to build one or two 8-inch wafer plants and five 12-inch wafer plants in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park (TSIP).
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. will invest US$14.5 billion in the next ten years to build an 8-inch wafer plant and five 12-inch wafer plants in the TSIP.
Texas Instruments-ACER will invest US$9 billion in the next ten years to build three 12-inch wafer plants in the same industrial park.
Macronix International will invest US$7.2 billion in the next ten years to build one 8-inch wafer plant and two to three 12-inch wafer plants in the TSIP and Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.
ASE will invest US$11.9 billion over the next 13 years to build several assembly testing plants in the TSIP.
Winbond Electronics Corp. will invest US$5.8 billion in the next ten years to build one 8-inch wafer and two 12-inch wafer plants in the TSIP.
Mosel Vitelic Inc. will invest US$3.6 billion to build one 12-inch wafer plant and assembly testing plant in the TSIP.
Meanwhile, three other companies will invest another US$8.4 billion in 8- and 12-inch wafer plants.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS COMMUNITY TURNS COLD SHOULDER TO DPP MEETING

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) opened a three-day seminar on Taiwan's economic and industrial development policy and strategy on Friday.

The seminar, aimed at helping the pro-independence party shake off an anti-commerce image, brought together economists, industry executives and DPP politicians to discuss economy- and industry-related topics.

Speaking at the opening ceremony, DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said the DPP doesn't have any anti-commerce complex as some people have alleged. "On the contrary, the DPP has consistently deemed it an important party mission to help sustain Taiwan's robust economy."

Hsu said the DPP has sponsored the seminar to solicit opinions of the academic and business communities about strategies and tactics to cope with economic problems and challenges faced by Taiwan. "We'll refer to their opinions in formulating our party's economic platform," he stated.
In preparation for the meeting, Hsu said he has visited a number of business heavyweights in recent weeks to exchange views on major economic topics.

Hsu recalled Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Y. C. Wang had told him that Taiwan doesn't need an industrial policy. "What the business community wants is complete economic liberalization," Hsu quoted Wang as asserting.

At present, Hsu said, the government still imposes too many restrictions on economic activities. "I hope the current seminar will help the DPP forge an intraparty consensus on Taiwan's future economic development direction."

Hsu expressed regret over the business community's cool response to the DPP seminar. Few senior business leaders showed up at Friday's meeting as most local tycoons are members or supporters of the ruling Kuomintang. Kao Ching-yuan, president of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, originally agreed to attend the opening session, but he failed to honor his promise.

Hsu ridiculed Kao's absence, saying he didn't have the courage to defy the KMT's stance. "This kind of attitude will only hinder the development of Taiwan's party politics and will even harm local enterpertises' interests," he claimed, adding: "I earnestly hope all local business magnates will learn to avert party consideration and give priority to national interests and their corporate policies."
Speaking on the same occasion, former DPP spokeswoman Sisy Chen said the DPP must actively woo the support of local business community for its economic policy.

Noting that the DPP's toughest challenge in the economic field is to harmonize environmental concerns with industrial development. "A core problem we face now is the conflict between the development of highly polluting and energy-consuming petrochemical industry and environmental protection," she noted.
Chen further said the DPP must cultivate a heavyweight politican who can fully represent and speak for salaried people. "By so doing, the DPP will be able to win more popular support."
Although the KMT has traditionally played a dominant role in the local business community, Chen said she is convinced that this trend will gradually fade in the years ahead.

A number of DPP legislators also presented their views at the seminar, calling for an end to unnecessary restrictions to private investment in mainland China. "Except for those investment activities that may threaten our national security, the government should not restrict trade and investment across the Taiwan Strait," said Legislator Hung Chi-chang.
The DPP lawmakers also called for upgrading of Taiwan's industries and continued economic liberalization and globalization. Many scholars and experts presented papers at the seminar for discussion.

Friday's meeting focused on exploring Taiwan's future economic development direction. The participants will discuss other topics, inclduing industrial upgrading, land rezoning and development, policy toward mainland investment, environmental protection and industrial development and balanced regional development, in the next two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAITI PRESIDENT VISITS AGRICULTURAL SITES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Friday led his honored guests from Haiti on an agricultural tour of central Taiwan, introducing them to the modern technologies and equipment that local farmers use to gain high-quality farm production.
Haiti President Rene Preval and his wife arrived in Taiwan Tuesday for a four-day visit and were given a grand, red-carpet welcome in downtown Taipei by Lee on the following day.

The two presidents, accompanied by Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei and Peng Chou-kui, chairman of the Council of Agriculture, as well as by several other high-level agricultural officials, made their first stop on the Friday trip at a vegetable farm in Ta Yia township Taichung County.
The farm, which covers more than 8,000 square meters, uses hydroponics to raise vegetables in a nonpolluting way. Its owner, Chang Chuen-tsang, received last year's "model farmer" award.

Lee, who holds a Ph.D. in agricultural economics, explained hydroponics and its practical applications to Preval during the visit, after which they drove to a poultry farm in Shen Kang township, also in Taichung County.
Chen Tun-fang, owner of the 51-year-old Ching Tan chicken farm, reported to the two leaders that the farm hatches 200,000 chickens for sale and 50,000 chickens for producing eggs every week.

As chairman of a development foundation for the poultry industry, Chen also appealed to Lee for help, asking that the government help poultry farmers deal with the impact that the scheduled opening of Taiwan's farm market to foreign exports is expected to have.
As part of its bid for membership in the World Trade Organization, Taiwan has agreed to import chicken from the United States, something that the local industry sees as a threat to its profits.
Chen asked the government to take a gradual and orderly approach to the imports, and to set up a warning system to reduce local farmers' losses.

He said his foundation is planning to raise NT$3 billion (US$90.9 million) for an "adjustment fund" to help maintain the stability of local chicken prices after the US products enter the island's market.
During their stay at the modern chicken farm, Lee and Preval also visited the facilities and operation systems for breeding, sanitation and environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIER PREDICTS CENTRAL BANK WILL LOWER RESERVE REQUIREMENTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) forecast on Friday that the Central Bank of China will be adopting small, incremental adjustments to lower bank reserve requirements.

The adjustments are to be made in unison with the release of postal savings money market funds to stabilize interest rates in the face of tighter capital requirements during the second half of the year due to the expenditure of several large-scale governmental development projects.
TIER also announced its predictions for this year's economic prospects, revising a previous estimate of 6.25 percent economic growth down to 6.01 percent.

The Consumer Price Index is now expected to climb 2.98 percent, lower than the previously announced rate of 3.08 percent. TIER cited a small adjustment in wages, the Central Bank's cautious policy of stabilizing commodity prices and the expectation that consumer goods and service industry price increases will be limited as the key factors behind the downward adjustment. The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER) has also adjusted its estimate for this year's growth in the Consumer Price Index down to 2.7 percent.

The target rate adopted by the Executive Yuan's Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is 3 percent, while the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) set the target rate at 3.01 percent.

Taiwan's foreign trade is showing signs of regression because of the Asian economic crisis, TIER said, noting that the island just suffered its first single-quarter trade deficit in 17 years. The first quarter economic growth rate is estimated to be lower than 5 percent, it said.

Due to the continued prosperity of the domestic market this year, consumer spending and private investments have been growing steadily. Peaking compared to recent years are major investments totaling NT$450 billion, a sevenfold increase from last year, illustrating the stability and growth of the domestic economy, TIER said.
TIER's forecast for this year's quarterly growth rates is as follows: first quarter, 4.32 percent; second, 5.89 percent; third, 6.93 percent; and fourth, 7.08 percent.

TIER's estimate for the growth rate for private investments is 18.03 percent, higher than both the DGBAS estimate of 16.67 percent and the CEPD target of 14 percent. Accordingly, the institute said, the consumer growth rate will increase moderately to 7.38 percent, also higher than the DGBAS estimate.
Regarding foreign trade, TIER estimated this year's export growth to be 5.91 percent and import growth to be 6.89 percent.

TIER said it believes that international oil prices will continue to grow steadily throughout the year, and many imported agricultural raw products will be priced low. With exchange rates in Asian countries stabilized, the annual wholesale price index is estimated will grow 4.73 percent, indicating that the predicted 6.74 percent growth for the first half of 1998 will decline in the third and fourth quarters.

With regard to exchange rates, the first quarter has seen some fluctuations due to factors such as a robust US dollar, public speculation, developments in the Asian economic situation and seasonal capital requirements, largely continuing the depreciation trends of last year's fourth quarter.

The New Taiwan dollar fell 5.8 percent in the first quarter of this year, TIER noted, predicting that 1998's average exchange rate will be NT$32.45 to US$1 in the face of the further stabilization of Asian stock markets and the increased capital requirement (in NT$) in the second half of the year.
TIER had originally estimated this year's exchange rate at NT$32 against the greenback. CHIER has also adjusted its estimate, moving it to NT$32.5.

If the Japanese yen and Southeast Asian currencies stabilize, the domestic market's interest rate fluctuations may also see a decrease in foreign pressures. The estimated discount rate may thereby continue at the current 5.25 percent, TIER said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE MEDIA REPORT PROGRESS ON CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Leading Australian newspapers ran reports Friday on the progress of talks between Taiwan and mainland China, which have resumed after a lapse of nearly three years.
The mass circulation daily The Australian ran a seven-column report on Friday headlined "Trade Gives China, Taiwan Common Cause."

The daily carried an AFP story that said negotiators from mainland China and Taiwan achieved early progress Thursday in their first direct talks in three years when they agreed to work to upgrade negotiations immediately in a bid to improve cross-strait relations.

The AFP quoted Li Yafei, deputy secretary-general of mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, as saying: "The most important thing we are here to talk about today is Mr. (C.F.) Koo's visit to the mainland and arrangement for it."
Taiwan's chief negotiator in Beijing, Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation, also expressed optimism for a high-level meeting.

The Australian Financial Review, Australia's leading business newspaper, on Friday carried an AP picture that shows Jan addressing reporters at a news conference in Beijing. He was quoted as saying, "This development is indeed a cause for celebration."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, SLOVAKIA SIGN MOU ON CUSTOMS COOPERATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the Slovak Republic on Friday signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on customs cooperation aimed at strengthening exchanges of customs information and training of customs personnel.
The MOU was signed in Taipei by Jan De-ho, head of the Directorate General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance, and his Slovak counterpart, Jaromir Kaliciak.

The officials on hand to witness the signing ceremony included Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang, and Liu Chun-man, deputy director of the European Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Under the terms of the MOU, both sides agreed to:
1. Exchange information on trade statistics, customs laws and regulations, and smuggling, as well as commercial fraud.
2. Enhance exchange visits and training of customs officials.
In addition, and following consultations with related agencies, both sides will further study the possibilities of signing a formal customs cooperation agreement.
Similar MOUs were signed between the ROC and the Republic of Hungary last year, and between the ROC and the Czech Republic in March this year.

The Directorate General of Customs pointed out that the signing of the MOU is expected to help upgrade substantive relations and develop mutual trade, in addition to making effective use of human resources and enhancing both sides' efforts to fight smuggling.
Accompanied by his colleague Alexander Vajda, director of Slovakia's international affairs office, Kaliciak arrived in Taipei on April 19 for a six-day visit.

During their stay in Taiwan, the Slovak officials are scheduled to visit the Board of Foreign Trade, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and other related agencies. They are also making first-hand studies of the operations of the customs bureaus in the cities of Keelung, Taipei and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-TECH SECTOR TO ACCOUNT FOR 40 PERCENT OF MANUFACTURING OUTPUT

TEXT.P: Output of technology-intensive industries will account for 40 percent of the manufacturing sector by the turn of the century, the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) predicted on Friday.

Reporting at a meeting convened by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on the government's plan to develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific manufacturing center, IDB officials reported that production in Taiwan's manufacturing sector is estimated to be US$300 billion in 2000, 40 percent of which will come from the high-tech sector. Basic industries will make up 35 percent of the total, while traditional industries will account for 25 percent, they added.

Output from the manufacturing sector totaled US$92.5 billion in 1986, at which time the high-tech sector accounted for only 24 percent, IDB statistics show. Basic and traditional industries made up for 36 percent and 24.5 percent, respectively.

The manufacturing sector's production had risen to more than US$220 billion by 1997, with 38.8 percent coming from technology-intensive industries. The ratio contributed by the basic and traditional industry sectors dropped to 36.7 percent and 24.5 percent, respectively, according to the tallies.

However, the IDB officials warned of the possible impact on Taiwan of mainland China's recent adjustment of its industrial policy, which has shifted its focus from labor-intensive industries to technology-intensive industries.

Yeh Huey-ching, executive secretary of the MOEA's Committee of Economic Research and Development, said the mainland's newly set industrial policy may pose a threat to Taiwan, which has been actively developing industries related to the electronics and computer sectors.
He stressed that Taiwan should pay close heed to the future course of mainland China's economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES DROP FOR SECOND MONTH

TEXT.P: Although its foreign exchange reserves have fallen for the second consecutive month, Taiwan still maintains its position as holder of the world's third-largest foreign exchange reserves, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported on Friday.

CBC statistics show that Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$83.615 billion as of the end of March, a reduction of US$396 million from the previous month. The figure in February also represented a decrease of US$19 million from January.
Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves have eroded by US$6.41 billion over the past three months, from US$90.025 billion at the end of last year to US$83.615 billion in March.
Chou Ar-Ting, director of the CBC's Foreign Exchange Department, attributed the fall to the depreciation of the Japanese yen and the German mark against the US dollar.

Chou said that Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves are lagging behind those of Japan and mainland China. Japan's foreign exchange reserves amounted to US$223.14 billion as of the end of February, while mainland China posted a distant second with US$140.3 billion during the same period.
Chou predicted an increase in Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves in April, basing his forecast on signs that the greenback won't maintain its current strong trend against other foreign currencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING EXPECTED TO SIGN ASEAN'S NUCLEAR-FREE PACT: REPORT

TEXT.P: Mainland China is expected to be the first nuclear power to embrace the nuclear-free concept of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), a Bangkok-based English newspaper revealed Friday.

The Nation reported in a special article, titled "China Wins Over ASEAN Partner," that after initial disagreements over the draft treaty, amendments have been made by ASEAN that have narrowed the gap between the association and Beijing.
More discussions and negotiations on the treaty, however, are required with the world's other nuclear powers, the daily said.

The paper said that in the just-concluded fourth consultative meeting between ASEAN and mainland China in Kuala Lumpur, Beijing responded "constructively" regarding major political issues, such as the South China Sea disputes, Treaty of Amity and Cooperation in Southeast Asia (TAC), Southeast Asian Nuclear Weapons Free Zone and major powers' relations.

"Strange as it may seem, the South China Sea dispute was not discussed this time as one might have expected," it said, adding that before the meeting, Vietnam levied harsh criticism against mainland China for Beijing's plan to turn the disputed South China Sea islands into tourist spots.
After years of rejections, Beijing has become more willing to discuss the TAC and mainland China's possible future inclusion in it.

The grouping has finally agreed to the much-awaited protocol to amend the TAC so as to allow non-Southeast Asian countries to associate with the 1976 document, which outlines ways to strengthen cooperation and use peaceful means to solve conflicts. The TAC is currently limited to ASEAN members and Papua New Guinea.

"The Kuala Lumpur ASEAN-China meeting has confirmed one home truth: China is here to stay and it will remain proactive in engaging the regional grouping," Kavi Chongkittavorn, the executive editor of The Nation, wrote in the article.
"Beijing wants and will become a very influential partner in the overall schemes of things in the region," he concluded.
During the meeting, Beijing agreed to dispatch two high-powered missions later this month and next month respectively to Southeast Asia.
Beijing also pledged to earmark US$750 billion for infrastructure and other development projects for the next three years and invited ASEAN countries to participate in these mega-projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6 HOPEFULS REGISTER FOR DPP CHAIR RACE

TEXT.P: The race for the chairmanship of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took dramatic twists and turns on Friday, with four additional contestants registering as candidates.
As a result, a total of six hopefuls, inclduing two female politicians, will vie for the chairmanship of Taiwan's largest opposition party.

Legislator-at-large Chang Chun-hung announced his decision to run for the DPP's top post at an early morning news conference. Chang said the upcoming chairmanship election is a "historic occasion" that he would not absent himself from it.
"This will be the first time that the DPP chairman will be directly elected by all party members. I would not absent myself from this 'democratic feast," Chang noted.

Chang, a former DPP secretary-general and a prominent member of incumbent chairman Hsu Hsin-liang's dominant "Formosa" faction, further said his chairmanship bid is not for power, but aimed at helping stimulate Taiwan's rejuvenation.

"Although many party elders have advised me not to enter the race to avert possible harm to his political stature, I still decides to run out of a strong sense of mission," Chang said, adding if he is elected, he will lead the DPP to transform itself from an opposition force to a ruling party.

Chang, who once temporarily served as acting party chairman in early 1996 after former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh resinged to assume political responsibility for the DPP's poor performance in nationwide presidential and National Assembly elections, is widely believed to be the strongest competitor to Lin Yi-hsiung, the party's top adviser who was the first to register for the chairmanship race.

Both Chang and Lin were former members of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly. "I'm convinced that I and my former colleague will set a model for future party chair elections. We'll make the race a 'gentlemen's competition.'"

Taoyuan County Magistrate Lu Hsiu-lien also registered for the DPP chairmanship election scheduled for May 24, but she said she will not mount any campaign activities. "I have registered as a candidate mainly to facilitate my support for Lin Yi-hsiung. I hope Lin will be our party's next leader. I hope his high moral stature will help revive the DPP's idealism," Lu noted.
Former DPP spokeswoman Sisy Chen and Huang Fu, president of a radical pro-Taiwan independence subgroup in the DPP, also completed registrations as candidates on Friday, the last day for registration.
Legislator Yen Chin-fu, like Lin, registered his candidacy shortly after the registration opened four days ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATERFRONT DISPUTE SEEN NARROWING AUSTRALIA'S TRADE DEFICIT

TEXT.P: The current waterfront battle between the Howard government, Patrick Stevedores Ltd. and the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA) is expected to help Australia narrow the trade gap because imported goods are being hit harder than exports at major Australian ports, according to a report from economists at HSBC Markets in Sydney.

The Federal Court on Thursday ordered Patrick to reinstate its sacked workers, but Patrick and the Howard government appealed the legal battle at the High Court Friday, causing the waterfront problem to remain unsolved despite Thursday's major victory for the union workers.
The economists said 11,000 containers are stuck on the wharves of major terminals in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide.

Most of the imported goods are containerized, while most of the Australian exports -- including iron ore, coal and mineral products -- are shipped in bulk carriers that are unaffected by the waterfront dispute, they said.

Those affected are Australian exports of manufactured goods, including motor vehicles and auto parts, aluminum and dairy products, beef, seafood, and raw materials such as cotton, the economists said.
And some of these exports have been diverted to the terminals of P&O Ports, the largest stevedoring firm unaffected in the waterfront dispute, they noted.

They said only 5 percent of Australian exports have been stranded at major ports during the three-week dispute, in which members of the MUA and sacked unionized workers and other union workers blocked cargoes at Patrick's terminals.
But 10 percent of Australia's imports are stranded at the same major ports.
The economists said the dispute is bad for Australia's image as a trading nation, and that the only good news is that the country could narrow the trade gap as a result of the waterfront battle.
The MUA won a major victory Thursday against Patrick and the Howard government when the presiding judge of the Federal Court ordered Patrick to reinstate the 2,000 union workers it fired.
But the battle is not over yet, because Patrick appealed to the High Court of Australia Thursday night to delay the Federal Court decision.
The matter is now becoming uncertain, although some of the sacked workers may return to work under different operators.

In the meantime, Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith said the MUA victory did not mean that the government under Prime Minister John Howard will change its reforms on the Australian waterfront policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT LOOKING TO CONTINUE STRATEGIC DIALOGUE WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright will seek to expand a strategic dialogue with mainland China when she arrives in Beijing later this month to pave the way for President Bill Clinton's visit in June, a senior State Department official said on Thursday.

The official said that apart from summit preparations, Albright's visit will have another purpose to which he said there has not been enough attention paid -- strategic dialogue. In other words, "we sit down with China the way we do with other important relationships" and discuss world issues, he said.

The key point of the secretary of state's trip to Beijing from April 29 to May 1, however, is to finalize the agenda of the second Clinton-Jiang summit in eight months. The official, who could not be named, said that priority issues would remain human rights, non-proliferation and trade, although the US would also like to give "considerable attention" to such issues as the environment and the rule of law.

On human rights, the official said that the US will continue to press mainland China for improvements. "We have never stated that the release of one or two dissidents checks the box and that that's the end of the human rights concerns in China," he said in response to a question that lesser-known political prisoners might be ignored now that Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng, two of the most famous Chinese dissidents, have been released.

"The main thing is to make progress across the board on human rights issues, and we're going to be raising more than just a couple of dissidents," the senior official added. However, he would not say whether Albright will seek the release of any individuals.

This will be Albright's second trip to mainland China as secretary of state and is part of an eight-day tour of four East Asian countries. She leaves on Sunday night for Japan and, after mainland China, she will go on to South Korea and Mongolia, returning to Washington on May 3.
Answering questions at a State Department background briefing, the official described the current relationship between the US and mainland China as being "on the right trajectory."
While Washington pursues a policy of active engagement with mainland China, the official said, "there is every indication that the Chinese are serious about wanting this engagement."

As part of that engagement policy, Clinton is due to visit Beijing, Shanghai, Xian and Hong Kong from late June to early July. An announcement on details of the visit is expected after the secretary of state's return.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO GIVE US$1 MILLION AID TO PARAGUAY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 23 (CNA) (By Jay Chen) (By Raymond Huang)

TEXT.P: Asuncion, April 23 (CNA): An aid package worth US$1 million promised last September by ROC President Lee Teng-hui during his tour of four Latin American countries will soon be handed over to the Paraguayan Agriculture Ministry, following the presentation of an integrated plan in which ROC agricultural technical missions will help local farmers produce export-oriented items.
He said the ROC offered the aid with the ultimate purpose of increasing Paraguayan farmers' per capita income, thus raising their standards of living.
"The money will be used for market investigation, construction of a laboratory for agricultural products, and the establishment of a data bank for local farmers and businessmen," Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PROVIDES RELIEF TO MAROONED PARAGUAYAN INDIANS

TEXT.P: More than 15,000 thousand Indian families in northern Paraguay have been marooned by floods caused by recent rainstorms, motivating ROC philanthropists living in Paraguay to raise 600 kg of rice and 500 kg of noodles to provide relief for the flood victims.
The food was donated in the name of the Tzu Chi Foundation, a Buddhist charitable organization based in the eastern Taiwan city of Hualien.

Osmar Alcides Pintos M, president of the Indigenous Friendship Association, accepted the donation on behalf of the Indians, but pointed out that the food is insufficient and that the flood victims also need warm clothing.
He also thanked the ROC Embassy for its part in arranging the donation. He said his association has to date collected 5,000 kg of food, donated by various embassies and churches.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ANTI-NUKE MARCH TO BE HELD APRIL 26

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Anti Nuclear Action Coalition said on Friday that it will hold an anti nuclear march at 1:00 p.m. on April 26, 1998, to mark the 12th anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

The coalition, which is organized by more than 40 Taiwan environmental and anti nuclear groups, pointed out at a press conference that in addition to remembering the Chernobyl disaster, the march is also aimed at opposing construction of a fourth nuclear reactor in Taiwan.

The coalition noted that the Chernobyl disaster, which occurred on April 25, 1986, resulted in heavy casualties and wide-ranging nuclear pollution, and has been described as the biggest disaster on earth. It added that Taiwan, which has an area of only 36,000 square kilometers, and already has three nuclear plants, will suffer unthinkable damage if there is a nuclear accident.

The marchers are scheduled to gather at 1:00 p.m. at the main gates of National Taiwan University, at the intersection of Roosevelt Road and Hsinsheng South Road. The parade will travel along Roosevelt Road, past the Taiwan Power Company building, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and end in front of the Presidential Palace on Katagalan Avenue, where a rally will be held.
Prior to the parade, a memorial service will be held for the victims of the Chernobyl disaster, while dances and skits will be performed at the rally.
According to the coalition, many countries have stopped building nuclear reactors, but they still have enough electrical power.

It added that Taiwan, with its high density of population and small area, should not build more nuclear plants but should develop other forms of power generation instead, such as solar and wind energy. At the same time, the public should also learn to conserve energy in order to allow their children to enjoy a better life and permit the conservation of the natural environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC DENIES BOASTING OF ITS SUCCESS IN WEATHERING FINANCIAL TURMOIL

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) on Friday denied that it has ever boasted of its ability to keep Taiwan out of the financial turmoil which has swept Southeast Asia.
The CBC said in a statement that it has simply claimed that "the harm to Taiwan resulting from the financial shakeup is relatively small" compared with some of the other countries in the region.

The statement was issued in response to foreign wire service reports that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) gave Taiwan a warning that it should not boast of having already weathered the financial storm.

The CBC said that the effects of the upheaval have already been felt in a variety of Taiwan's economic activities, citing the fact that Taiwan's economic growth for 1998 has been adjusted downward to between 6.2 and 6 percent by government and private economic research agencies.

At a time when boosting exports has become difficult, the government has turned its attention on how to stimulate local demand as part of efforts to raise economic growth. A series of investment incentives has been adopted, including measures to avoid double taxation, and combining income and corporate tax, as well as using the build-operate-transfer system to encourage private participation in large-scale public construction projects, it noted.

It went on to say that the government will continue to implement determined policies of seeking financial and economic liberalization, adding that the CBC will carefully observe the economic situations at home and abroad in order to adopt the correct adjustment measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 PERCENT OF TEENAGE GIRLS VICTIMS OF DATE RAPE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: About 5 percent of female teenage students admit to having been victims of date rape, according to the results of a survey made public on Friday.

The survey also revealed that 20 percent of the male teenage students polled admitted that they might conduct sexual offenses against their dates, while 5 percent of them admitted that they have actually done so or have attempted to do so.

Some 21 percent of the male adolescents said they would insist on having sex with their dates if they knew for sure that no one else would find out. In contrast, 50 percent of the males claimed that they would never rape their dates or conduct any sexual misconduct.

The poll also found that males tend to have a more lenient attitude toward date rape, as 13 percent of them think that date rape is forgivable if they have spent a lot money on their dates, while only 5 percent of the females surveyed agreed with this.

According to the survey, around 22 percent of male teenagers and 10 percent of female teenagers opined that date rape is forgivable if the girl is already "out of control because of sexual excitement," while 15 percent and 7 percent of male and female adolescents, respectively, think that sexual misconduct is forgivable if "the girl is already drunk to the point of unconsciousness."

At the same time, 29 percent of males and 15 percent of females said they would forgive the rapist if the couple had been dating for a long time, while 67 percent of males and 59 percent of females said date rape is forgivable if "she agrees to go to a love hotel with him."
The survey, conducted by Shihhsin University, sampled 2,985 teenage students from 27 local high schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FEARS EXPORT BOOM MAY BE ENDING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's days of large trade surpluses may be nearing an end as Asia's financial crisis begins to restrain exports and threatens to hold back economic growth, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Friday.

Exports fell 6.4 percent in the first quarter of 1998 while imports were flat, chalking up a rare trade deficit of US$70 million against a surplus of US$1.8 billion in the first quarter of 1997, the WTO report said.
The government aims for 4 percent export growth this year, but finance ministry officials have warned that this target may be hard to meet, the report said.
Private economists suggest the economic gloom in Japan and across the region could torpedo Taiwan's trade balance into deficit this year for the first time since 1975.
Exports to Asia were the hardest hit, with exports to Southeast Asia sliding 27.1 percent and those to Japan falling 23.7 percent in the first quarter of 1998.

In spite of the alarming numbers, both government and private analysts remain sanguine about Taiwan's prospects. Relative strength in the domestic economy and the favorable structure of exports will help shield Taiwan from the worst of the fallout from the region's financial turmoil.

The economy may be affected later this year by uncertainties over key elections, but the launch of public works such as a US$15 billion high-speed rail project, combined with the island's high-technology juggernaut, will help maintain growth, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOWCASES RICE CULTIVATION TECHNOLOGY FOR HAITIAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Friday showcased Taiwan's rice cultivation technology for visiting Haitian President Rene Preval in Changhua, central Taiwan.
Lee personally escorted Preval to the government-run Taichung District Agricultural Improvement Station in Changhua.
The agricultural expert-turned president explained Taiwan's progress in rice cultivation techniques to Preval in detail.

Interested himself in the latest developments in rice cultivation technology, Preval asked many questions of his host and said that the Taichung Shan-10 strain of rice, developed in Taiwan and now being grown in Haiti, is the best rice he has ever eaten.
After touring the agricultural improvement station, Lee also accompanied Preval on a visit to a local farmers association.
Preval and his wife arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a four-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TAIWAN FILM DIRECTORS TO COMPETE AT CANNES
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) (By Maubo Chang) (By Tzou Ming-jhie)

TEXT.P: Paris, April 23 (CAN) Veteran Taiwan film directors Hou Hsiao-Hsien and Tsai Ming-liang are competing with their respective films -- "Flowers of Shanghai" and "The Hole" -- for the Palme d'Or at the 51st Cannes Film Festival which will start on May 13 in the French Riviera city.

Another local director, the much younger Lin jun-hong, has also had a three-minute short, entitled "Child, Scribble, Photos of Family" selected by the festival committee to compete in the short film section.

Gilles Jacob, spokesman for the festival committee, revealed the 22 officially selected full-length films and 15 short films for the competition at a press conference at the Grand Hotel of Paris on Thursday. He said the festival is widely supported by the international film-producing community, with a total of 1,074 films being presented for selection.
The 12-day festival will open with Mike Nichols' "Primary Colors," and end with Roland Emmerich's monster movie "Godzilla."

A nine-member jury will include Chen Kaige from mainland China, and be presided over by American director Martin Scorsese who had won the 1976 Palme d'Or with "Taxi Driver." The 22 full-length films include four from the United States, four from France, two each from Denmark, the United Kingdom, the ROC and Italy, and one each from Colombia, Australia, Greece, and Russia, as well as one co-produced by Argentine and Brazil.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN HONORS CONTROL YUAN'S RIGHT OF INVESTIGATION

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Friday expressed his willingness to make amends for the late filing of a report on a loan to Wu Tse-yuan, former chief of Pingtung County, and said he will accept any penalty resulting from the late filing.
Lien also said through Liao Feng-teh, director of the vice presidential office, that he will respect the right of the Control Yuan to investigate the matter.

Accompanied by Hsu Li-teh, senior advisor to the president, Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, and Tien Ching-yi, head of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) Pingtung County Committee, the vice president visited Chun Ji township in Pingtung County and attended a seminar with local residents.

Meanwhile, Nantou County Legislator Tsai Huang-lang of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suggested on Friday that the Legislative Yuan should set up a special group to examine whether or not Lien's loan was illegal.

According to Tsai, it is impossible for the Control Yuan to impeach Lien, who is the convener of the nominating committee for members of the Control Yuan; and it is also impossible for Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao to investigate, because he is subordinate to Lien.
Taichung City Legislator Fong Ting-kuo from the opposition New Party suggested that Lien should make a report on the matter to the Legislative Yuan.

Meanwhile, KMT lawmakers, including Keelung City Legislator Hsu Chao-ping and Yunlin County Legislator Liao Fuw-peen, argued very hard in Lien's defense, urging the opposition party to treat the matter "rationally" and not to "try to tarnish the image" of the vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC GOVERNOR PREDICTS 6 PERCENT ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is estimated to grow by 6 percent in 1998, provided the growth rate of the consumer price index (CPI) is kept under 3 percent per year, Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Fai-nan Perng said on Friday.

The monetary policymaker's forecast came one day after the Asian Development Bank (ADB) predicted in its annual report that the island is to post a growth rate of 5.8 percent while a local economic think tank, the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research put the figure at 5.95 percent.
He also denied that Taiwan's real term interest rate, which is calculated by subtracting the annual CPI increase from major banks' interest rates on one-year-term deposits, is too high.
Taiwan's real term interest rate, which currently stands at about 3.6 percent, is lower than the 4.18 percent in the United States, said Perng.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN CHAN TO LEAVE FOR COSTA RICA ON MAY 5

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan will leave for Costa Rica on May 5 to attend the inauguration of President-elect Miguel Angel Rodriguez, slated for May 8.

Lien will make a two-night stopover in New York before flying on to Costa Rica on May 7. Following the inauguration ceremony, he will then proceed to the Caribbean island nation of Grenada on May 9 for a three-day official visit.
It will be Lien's third overseas visit since the beginning of this year. He visited Singapore in January, and made a trip to Jordan and Malaysia in March.
Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, Vice Presidential Secretary-General Su Chi, and Vice Chairman Lin Shiang-nung of the Council of Agriculture will accompany Lien on the trip.

Meanwhile, the foreign affairs minister of Grenada, Raphael Fletcher, will conclude a weeklong visit on Saturday. He has visited several high-ranking government officials while here, including President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien, Premier Vincent Siew and Foreign Affairs Minister Hu.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET RESIGNATION WILL FOLLOW FORMATION OF NEW LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew and his Cabinet will resign to the newly elected Legislative Yuan earlier next year following the year-end legislative elections, a high-ranking executive official said on Friday.

The official, who requested anonymity, said that although constitutional amendments passed last year by the National Assembly have stripped the lawmakers of the right to approve the appointment of the premier, no amendments were made regarding the resignation of the Cabinet.
He pointed out, however, that to show respect to the new legislators, Siew, who assumed the post of head of the Executive Yuan last September, will lead his Cabinet in a mass resignation.

The issue of a Cabinet resignation was raised on Thursday when Siew was asked by reporters if the Cabinet will resign after the new legislature is formed in February next year. Siew replied that he will "act in accordance with the regulations set forth in the Constitution."

The official asserted that the year-end legislative election will serve as an important indicator of whether Siew will retain the current post, adding that the Cabinet, which Siew has dubbed his "Action Cabinet," will need to make an all-out effort to upgrade its overall image.
He also denied rumors that Siew is planning a Cabinet reshuffle by the middle of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF MISSION RETURNS TO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Jan Jyh-horng, a deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), concluded a three-day ice-breaking visit to mainland China and returned to Taipei on Friday night.

Jan said at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that he believes the visit by the eight-member SEF delegation has given the two sides a better understanding of each other's basic stance on the future exchange of officials from the SEF and its mainland counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Jan said that in his meetings with ARATS officials, they also discussed other issues including illegal mainland immigrants and the smuggling of mainland goods into Taiwan. Although the ARATS gave no clear answers to the issues, Jan said that this was just the beginning.

Jan's visit was the first high-level contact between the SEF and the ARATS after a nearly three-year hiatus. The two semi-official bodies are responsible for handling cross-strait contacts in the absence of official ties.

The highlight of Jan's visit was a meeting with ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei on Thursday. In the 30-minute talks, they both agreed that a landmark visit by Taiwan's top liaison officer with the mainland, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu, will be arranged by the end of the year, although he pointed out that the details of Koo's visit have yet to be hammered out.

After the meeting, Tang told reporters that the ARATS welcomes the proposal that Koo should lead a delegation to the mainland, and said he hopes that Taiwan can present a timetable for the trip so that the mainland side can make the necessary preparations. He added that the mainland authorities have not set up any obstacles to the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SUSPENDS DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH GUINEA BISSAU

TEXT.P: The Foreign Affairs Ministry on Friday announced the suspension of diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and the African nation of Guinea Bissau.
The ministry said in a statement issued late Friday night that it is regrettable that the West African country has conceded to pressure from mainland China.

"We have instructed our ambassador to Guinea Bissau, Weng Ting-long, to lodge our strongest protest with the Guinea Bissau government, and have decided to suspend our formal relations and all cooperative programs with that country immediately," it said.

The ministry also condemned Beijing for "intentionally hurting the passions of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait by playing a double-handed policy" -- strongly calling for the resumption of cross-strait negotiations on one hand while luring the ROC's diplomatic allies on the other.
"The move by Beijing will surely undermine the harmonious atmosphere between the two sides and result in a negative impact on future interaction between them," the ministry statement warned.
"We should have no illusions about Beijing, since it has never ceased its attempts to blockade the ROC in the international community," the statement said.
The ministry pledged that it will continue with its policy of expanding its foreign relations in order to ensure national survival.

According to wire service reports, Guinea Bissau Foreign Affairs Minister Fernando Delfim Da Silva signed a communique on forging official ties with his mainland counterpart, Tang Jiaxuan, in Beijing on Thursday.
News of the new Guinea Bissau-mainland China ties came as a complete surprise to Taipei as there had been no warning signals beforehand.
Foreign Minister Jason Hu in a hastily convened press conference late Friday night admitted that his ministry had "no advance knowledge of the change."
Hu said that he "has the feeling of having been cheated by Guinea Bissau," especially since the wife of Guinea Bissau President Joao Bernendo Vieira concluded a six-day visit to Taipei on Thursday.

The foreign minister said he has reported the diplomatic setback to President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew, adding that he and his ministry will shoulder full responsibility for the situation.
Guinea Bissau established formal relations with the ROC in May, 1990.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS FOURTH-LARGEST LONG-TERM ECONOMIC GROWTH WORLDWIDE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 24 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Eight Asian economies, including the four "Asian tigers," have been placed among the top 10 of a World Bank ranking for long-term economic growth.

Latest World Bank statistics on the average economic growth of every economy in the world over the past 30 years show that Taiwan enjoyed an average 8.6 percent rise in economic development, placing it fourth in the world.
The African nation of Botswana came first, with 13 percent, ahead of Oman in the Middle East, with 9.5 percent; and South Korea, with 8.9 percent.

The statistics show that mainland China, which posted 8.5 percent average economic growth over the past 30 years, ranked fifth, followed by Singapore with 8.3 percent, Hong Kong with 7.5 percent, Thailand with 7.3 percent, Malaysia with 6.8 percent, and Indonesia with 6.7 percent.
The four Asian tigers are Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong.

In the Group of Seven (G7) richest nations in the world, Japan enjoyed the largest economic growth, at 4.5 percent over the last 30 years, while the United Kingdom, with 2.1 percent, was at the bottom. The G7 comprises Japan, Britain, the United States, Canada, France, Germany, and Italy.
Although it is the world's largest economy, the United States posted an average of only 2.4 percent economic growth over the past 30 years, the Washington-headquartered World Bank tallies show.

In other World Bank statistics referring to average annual growth of Gross National Product (GNP) per capita over the past 30 years, Taiwan took first place, with 14.6 percent GNP growth, followed by Botswana (9.2 percent), South Korea (8.9 percent), mainland China (6.7 percent), Singapore (6.3 percent), Hong Kong (5.6 percent), Thailand (5 percent), Oman (5 percent), Indonesia (4.6 percent), and Malaysia (4.1 percent).

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF FLIGHTS AT SUNGSHAN AIRPORT TO BE CUT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said on Saturday it will unveil a detailed plan for cutting the number of flights at Taipei's Sungshan Airport within three months in an effort to improve aviation safety.

CAA Acting Director-General Chang Chia-chu, who concurrently serves as vice minister of transportation and communications, made the announcement at the opening session of a flight safety strategic meeting.
Quoting CAA tallies, Chang said the number of flights at Taipei's domestic airport has increased threefold since the government implemented an open-skies policy in 1987.
For the convenience of local residents, Chang said, the government has allowed more carriers to fly domestic routes and to increase the number of flights using the airport.

"As a result, the airport is now over-used. It currently hosts an average of 580 landings and takeoffs per day, or 38 flights per hour," Chang said, adding that this flight density is even higher than at Hong Kong and Tokyo airports.

Because of the limited space at the airport, Chang said, control measures often have to be imposed at the airport. "Against this backdrop, flight delays have become all too common, and workloads for flight controllers have increased tremendously."

Following a string of air disasters here in the past few months, Chang said, flight safety has become of paramount concern. "The CAA has listed the reduction of flights at the Sungshan Airport as an important step in our all-out aviation safety upgrading project," he said, adding that a comprehensive reduction plan will be crafted in three months.

The aviation meeting was organized by a fight safety strategic task force set up by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) on April 1 to draft a package of measures to restore public confidence in domestic flight safety in the wake of two recent major air disasters which resulted in the death of 215 people.

Saturday's meeting brought together local and foreign aviation experts to review Taiwan's existing flight control measures and work out strategies to improve its aviation safety system. Among the foreign participants was a Chinese-American senior project director at NASA, Dr. Hung Chao-kuei, who has been invited to serve as convener of the MOTC's aviation safety task force.
The task force is expected to unveil an aviation safety reinforcement package on May 1.
Saturday's meeting focused discussion on Taiwan's current system of safety checks and procedures for handling flight mishaps or disasters.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT ON WANG DAN'S WISH TO VISIT HK: TUNG CHEE HWA
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 25 (CNA) (By Wu Shean-shen and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Wang Dan, 29, a mainland Chinese dissident newly released on medical parole, said Friday in New York that he hopes to take part in the activities that will be held in Hong Kong on June 4 to commemorate the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement. Neither Tung Chee Hwa, chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR), nor the HKSAR Immigration Department would comment on this matter Friday.
The Hong Kong Citizens' Patriotic Pro-Democracy Movement Federation, which sponsors an observance each year of the student demonstrations, said it believes the possibility of Wang's visit is slim.

Wang told the press in New York Friday that he is eager to join the forthcoming memorial occasion in Hong Kong. He added, however, that whether or not he is present, he hopes "to discuss the matter with Tung."
Reporters asked Tung about Wang's possible trip both when he entered and left an office building, but both times the Hong Kong leader only smiled and evaded the sensitive question.
The immigration department of the HKSAR government meanwhile said that it was unwilling to comment on the entrance of a specific figure.
The Hong Kong federation said it is considering inviting Wang to attend the occasion, even though it doubts he would be allowed to come.

According to the rules of the HKSAR immigration department, mainland China's passport holders who wish to enter Hong Kong from foreign countries for official business must apply for visas at an embassy or consulate of mainland China, while those who wish to make a transit stop in Hong Kong on the way to the Chinese mainland or elsewhere can have a seven day visa-free stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAN HAILS TAIWAN'S DEMOCRATIC DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Prominent mainland China dissident Wang Dan in an interview on Friday hailed Taiwan's democratic development, saying it has inspired mainland Chinese and serves as a good example for the mainland's pro-democracy movement.

In an interview with the CNA, Wang, who arrived in the US last week following his release from a mainland prison on medical grounds, expressed the hope that the people of Taiwan can continue to voice concern as well as extend support to the pro-democracy movement. The future of Taiwan is closely connected with the progress of democracy on the mainland, he claimed.

The 29-year-old dissident explained that only when the mainland is no longer under one-party authoritarian rule and only when it begins to implement democracy can Taiwan emerge from the shadow of the military threat from the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

Wang said that a just-concluded ice-breaking mainland visit by Jan Jyh-horng, a deputy secretary-general of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), marked a significant step forward in cross-strait relations stalled for nearly three years. Jan and Tang Shubei, vice chairman of SEF's mainland counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), also agreed that SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu should pay a visit to the mainland by the end of the year.

"It's a good thing that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are willing to sit down and talk," Wang said, adding that although the two sides have their differences, for the welfare of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, they should endeavor to find an acceptable compromise. He stressed that Taiwan and the mainland should avoid any form of military confrontation.

Wang said that he has a good impression of Taiwan, but added that all his knowledge of the island is based on conversations with Taiwan businessmen and reporters he met in mainland China. He expressed the hope that some day he will have an opportunity to visit Taiwan to "experience the island's democratic achievements."

Should he visit Taiwan, what he most wants to learn about is the process of the island's democratic development and the problems that Taiwan democracy currently faces, Wang said. Meanwhile, he said he would like to contact people from different parties and from different sectors of society to absorb the "Taiwan experience" in democratic reforms.

Wang expressed optimism over the prospects for the mainland pro-democracy movement. He stressed that the mainland authorities cannot reverse the trend of democratic reforms, especially when they have undertaken economic reforms. He called on the people of the mainland to fight for their freedom and rights and also urged mainland Chinese Premier Zhu-Rongji to promote political reforms along with the economic reforms, noting that the two are inseparable.

In addition, Wang said that pressure from the international community has helped improve the human rights situation there. He agreed that Washington should engage with Beijing, which will in turn give it the opportunity to pressure and influence the mainland authorities.

However, he pointed out that the US government should know the improvement of human rights record doesn't lie in the release of political prisoners; rather it lies in the inauguration and implementation of legal systems that provide adequate protection for human rights.

The dissident, one of the student leaders in the 1989 pro-democracy movement which ended in a bloody military crackdown in Tiananmen Square, said that compared with 1989, government control on people and society has relaxed somewhat, but he warned that this relaxation is a result of pressure on the mainland authorities and that they might tighten their control at any time should they feel the need.

On the future of overseas pro-democracy groups, Wang confirmed the contributions these groups have made to the democracy movement on the mainland, citing the fact that they always play a vital part in prompting the release of political prisoners.

Wang said that he doesn't think the overseas pro-democracy groups have lost their goals, adding that the mainland activists still count on their overseas compatriots to help them push for democratic development on the mainland.

The exiled activist said that what he can do now for the democratic development of his homeland is to urge the mainland authorities to release more political prisoners. He also said he plans to continue his studies in history in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW TO TRAVEL TO MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew and his wife will leave for Malaysia on Saturday afternoon for a private visit, sources from the Executive Yuan said.

The high-ranking sources revealed that Siew will be accompanied by several entrepreneurs in the commercial and industrial sectors. He is scheduled to call on Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and Deputy Prime Minister and Financial Minister Anwar Ibrahim during the trip, they said.

Siew is expected to exchange views with the Malaysian leaders on issues including trade and economic relations between Taipei and Kuala Lumpur, ways to reduce the impact of the Asian financial crisis and Taiwan's possible aid to Malaysia.
Siew will return home on Monday, the sources said.
