In the wake of the outbreak of the financial crisis in Asia last year, the premier has visited the Philippines and Indonesia to see what assistance Taiwan can provide those Southeast Asian countries, whose economies were badly damaged in the financial attack.

Taiwan, which enjoys healthy economic and financial fundamentals, is one of the few regional economies to sustain only minor damage from the crisis. The island has therefore volunteered to contribute aid and the knowledge it gained in successfully fending off the financial assault to the countries stuck in economic recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO'S GROUP, MICROSOFT JOINTLY DEVELOP CABLE-BASED BROADBAND SERVICES

TEXT.P: Ho Shin Gigamedia Center Inc. (Gigamedia), an affiliate of Taiwan's giant Koo's Group, signed a strategic partnership agreement on Friday with Microsoft Corp. to develop quality cable-based broadband network services here.
Microsoft will provide technical assistance, and both companies will jointly develop advanced set-top boxes which will set a national standard for others to follow.

Present at the signing ceremony were President Hsiao Hsiang-ping, Vice President Chang Jui-chan, and Chairman Koo Chi-yun of Gigamedia, while Microsoft was represented by Asian Region Deputy Director Pieter Knook, Microsoft ICU Global Affairs Director Stephen Wu, and Microsoft Taiwan President Fan Cheng-chu.

Although not present at the signing, Microsoft CEO Bill Gates expressed in a pre-recorded videotape his belief that the partnership between Microsoft and Gigamedia will provide clients with faster, more reliable cable-based broadband network services than traditional dial-up networks. With a hundredfold increase in access speeds, Gates believes this kind of high-speed broadband network service will bring more convenience, more efficiency, and more fulfillment to people's daily lives.

For his part, Koo said that Koo's Group has been actively involved in the cable industry for a decade, and that this new partnership with Microsoft will provide the Taiwan public with faster quality network services. Content-wise, he said, value-added network services will be added to Koo's Group subsidiaries in the financial, tourism, and real estate industries in the future.

Koo stressed the importance of a country's implementation of information technology in the twenty-first century. With the high-speed information superhighway being developed by Koo's Group, he said, Taiwan will become more competitive in the information age, and the public will also be able to enjoy new standards of living with the introduction of distance-learning, distance-medical care, and other educational and entertainment opportunities.

According to Koo, Microsoft will provide its network technology laboratories in Redmond, Wash. to help Gigamedia set up its network structure. Microsoft will also provide its expertise in areas such as newly developed network application programs, server software, technology platforms, and network operating systems to assist Gigamedia with the installation of its cable-based broadband networks.

The joint venture between the two giants also has plans to develop advanced set-top boxes in the future. Hsiao stressed that set-top boxes will become an important peripheral product, especially with the impending arrival of digital television sets. With a set-top box, a regular television set can become a PC TV or a Web TV. Through their partnership, he said, Gigamedia and Microsoft hope to develop international and domestic standards that support Microsoft's operating platforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIATION SAFETY MEETING OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Aviation safety is far more important than open skies, Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said on Saturday.

Liu made the remarks at the opening session of a three-day flight safety strategic meeting organized by the Ministry of Transportantion and Communications (MOTC) to seek measures for upgrading Taiwan's aviation safety.

Liu pointed out that Taiwan's economic prosperity has stimulated the demand for air traffic. Both domestic and international flights have increased substantially over the past decades. "However, a recent spate of air disasters here has indicated that our flight safety management and control systems are far from perferct."

Noting that aviation safety requires constant concern and incessant work, Liu said obtaining a flight safety certificate from the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) couldn't ensure that Taiwan's civil aviation services would be mishap- or disaster-free all the time. "We must continue devoting full energies to safety work in order to restore public confidence in our civil aviation services."

Speaking on the same occasion, MOTC Minister Lin Feng-cheng said the ministry will join forces with other relevant government agencies and local carriers to imporve domestic flight safety. "We hope our aviation safety will be able to meet the top world standard within a year."

The three-day meeting brought together more than 100 local and foreign civil aviation experts, administraters and airline executives to review Taiwan's existing flight control measures and mull strategies to improve its overall safety management and crontol systems.

Among the foreign experts was Dr. Hung Chao-kuei, a Chinese-American senior project director at NASA, who has also been invited to serve as convener of an MOTC flight safety reinforcement task force inaugurated on April 1.
Lin said the ministry will refer to all the opinions presented at the meeting in drafting steps to reinforce aviaition safety.

Meanwhile, Acting Director-General Chang Chia-chu of the MOTC's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said at the meeting the CAA will unveil a detailed plan for cutting the number of flights at Taipei's Sungshan Airport within three months in an effort to improve aviation safety.
Quoting CAA tallies, Chang, also an MOTC vice minister, said the number of flights at Taipei's domestic airport has increased threefold since the government implemented an open-skies policy in 1987.
For the convenience of local residents, Chang said, the government has allowed more carriers to fly domestic routes and to increase the number of flights using the airport.

"As a result, the airport is now over-used. It currently hosts an average of 580 landings and takeoffs per day, or 38 flights per hour," Chang said, adding that this flight density is even higher than at Hong Kong and Tokyo airports.

Because of the limited space at the airport, Chang said, control measures often have to be imposed at the airport. "Against this backdrop, flight delays have become all too common, and workloads for flight controllers have increased tremendously."

Following a string of air disasters here in the past few months, Chang said, flight safety has become of paramount concern. "The CAA has listed the reduction of flights at the Sungshan Airport as an important step in our all-out aviation safety upgrading project," he said, adding that a comprehensive reduction plan will be crafted in three months.
The MOTC's flight safety task force is expected to unveil an aviation safety reinforcement package on May 1.
Saturday's meeting focused discussion on Taiwan's current system of safety checks and procedures for handling flight mishaps or disasters.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAN'S BEIJING TRIP BENEFICIAL TO CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: MAC

TEXT.P: The trip that Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made to Beijing April 22-24 was highly successful, Chang King-yuh, chairman of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Friday evening.

A renewal of contacts, exchanges and dialogue between the SEF and its mainland counterpart, the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, will be conducive to the development of cross-strait relations, Chang noted.

Sheu Ke-sheng, the MAC's vice chairman and spokesman, remarked at a press conference that the meeting between the deputy secretary-generals of the two semi-official organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing respectively to handle bilateral exchanges symbolized a restart of the dialogue system.

Sheu added that the Taipei authorities are glad a common understanding has been reached on the mainland visit of SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and the exchanges between the staffs of the two cross-strait organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY RAIN HITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Heavy downpours attacked Taiwan Saturday, resulting in flooding in several places in the north of the island.
One of the floods had threatened the lives of eight local workers at a construction site in Tayuan in Taoyuan County. They were stranded by a flash flood while constructing a dike.
A rescue team rushed to the site and saved them from being swept away by the high water, according to local police.
Meteorologists with the Central Weather Bureau predicted that the rainy weather will last through Monday.
They warned that residents in northern and central Taiwan should be aware that heavy rains and rapid weather changes are possible.
The bureau released a heavy rain alert on Saturday.

Wang was sentenced to four years in prison for his role in the Tiananmen Square protests. He served that sentence, but was charged with subversion last year and sentenced to 11 years. He was released last week on medical grounds and sent directly to the Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit for a physical checkup.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NO HASTE, BE PATIENT' POLICY WORKING: MOEA

TEXT.P: The average size of mainland-bound investment projects approved between January and March posted a nearly 37 percent cut from the year-earlier level, signaling the success of the "no haste, be patient" economic policy toward investment in mainland China, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Friday.

Statistics made public by the MOEA's Investment Commission show that a total of 156 proposed investment projects in the mainland were approved during the first quarter of this year with an accumulated value reaching US$347.23 million. Compared with the same period of last year, the number of approved projects doubled, while the total value increased 26.17 percent.

The average value of approved projects in the first quarter of this year stood at US$2.22 million, much lower than the US$3.52 million registered during the same period of last year, a cut of 36.93 percent. This reduction indicates that the new investments are centered on small- and medium-sized enterprises.

An MOEA official said that the statistics regarding investment from Taiwan compiled by the mainland's Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation also testify to the fact that the size of the proposed investment projects by Taiwan businessmen has shrunk.

The mainland figures show that between January and September of 1997, the actual investment value contributed by Taiwan businessmen rose 0.49 percent from the same period of the previous year. The number of newly-approved projects proposed by Taiwan businessmen during the nine-month period, however, fell 9.1 percent, while the combined value showed a whopping 54 percent drop.
According to the "no haste, be patient" policy announced in the second half of 1996, investment projects in the mainland are not allowed to surpass US$50 million in value.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHORING UP TIES WITH ALLIES TOP DIPLOMATIC WORK: SIEW

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Saturday he will personally chair a meeting in the near future to chart a new diplomatic work plan.

Siew, who left for Malaysia Saturday afternoon for a private visit, made the statement in response to the establishment of diplomatic ties between mainland China and one of Taiwan's former allies, Guinea Bissau, on Friday.

Acknowledging that the Republic of China on Taiwan faces a diplomatic plight, Siew said he will chair a meeting to pool resources of relevant government agencies to further expand the country's external relations.

Siew said the government will give top priority to consolidating official ties with the ROC's current diplomatic allies, which number less than 30 following the switch of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing by three African allies so far this year -- South Africa, the Central African Republic and Guinea Bissau.

"We'll also continue to promote substantive relations with countries with which we do not maintain formal diplomatic relations, as well as to press ahead with our bid to join major international organizations," Siew said.

Given its economic strength and suscessful political democratization, Siew said the ROC deserves a decent place in the international community. He also urged all fellow countrymen to join forces with the government to expand Taiwan's diplomatic frontiers and upgrade its status in the world community.
Meanwhile, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said he sees no reasons to change the ROC's current pragmatic diplomatic policy and strategy.

"For our national survival and development, we must reach out to the world," a confident Hu stressed, adding that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will do its utmost to shore up the country's full-fledged diplomatic ties with its allies while expanding exchanges and cooperation with countries which recognize rival mainland China.
Hu said the ROC should not link its diplomatic work to mainland China's attitude. "We must do whatever we should do, even though such actions may offend or anger Beijing."

Asserting Guinea Bissau's switch of diplomatic allegiance is only a temporary setback, Hu said that the ROC will not be daunted by it. "A temporary setback doesn't mean a long-term failure. We are confident that we'll be able to open a new diplomatic frontier."
Asked whether the ROC has plans to forge formal diplomatic ties with other countries in the near future, Hu said: "Let's see."

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL OF LABOR AFFAIRS TO BE UPGRADED TO MINISTERIAL LEVEL

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew announced on Saturday that the Council of Labor Affairs will be upgraded to the Ministry of Labor Affairs (CLA).
Siew made the remarks in a seminar attended by government officials and representatives of the island's laborers, during which an exchange of views on labor-related issues took place.
Siew said that the government is also considering shortening the workweek and instituting unemployment insurance next year as part of efforts to upgrade workers' welfare.

Siew said that currently the Labor Standards Law limits the workweek to a maximum of 48 hours. The Executive Yuan, after careful study, agreed in principle that the limit can be reduced to 44 hours on the condition that productivity isn't affected, he said.

Siew said that he was glad to have the chance to discuss a variety of issues with representatives of Taiwan's laborers. He stressed that the government's labor policies protect the rights and interests of workers and promote harmonious relations between labor and management, as well as help upgrade productivity, protect the safety of workers on the job and promote improvements in the quality of life of laborers.

Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, CLA Chairman Chan Hou-sheng and Enviromental Protection Administration Chairman Tsai Hsung-hsiung were present at the seminar, which was broadcast live by China Television Company.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP CALLS FOR DISMISSAL OF JAPANESE AMBASSADOR TO US

TEXT.P: The Global Alliance for Preserving the History of World War II in Asia on Friday demanded a formal apology from the Japanese government and the immediate dismissal of Kunihiko Saito, Japan's ambassador to the United States, over his remarks about the incident known as the "Rape of Nanking."
Iris Chang, author of "The Rape of Nanking: The Forgotten Holocaust of World War II," said she was stunned by Saito's statements and challenged him to debate her on national television.

The book's publisher, Basic Books, also said in a press release that the book is the first comprehensive account written in English of the December 1937 massacre, in which the Japanese soldiers invading Nanking killed over 260,000 Chinese civilians and raped an estimated 20,000-80,000 women.

According to international and Japanese media reports, Saito stated at a press conference on April 21 that the book's description of atrocities committed by the Japanese Imperial Army in Nanking is inaccurate and biased.
Saito also called the contents of the book one-sided.

In addition, the ambassador warned US congressmen not to back any resolution concerning the sexual slavery of Asian women by the Japanese military during World War II. House Concurrent Resolution 126, which calls on the Japanese government to offer a formal apology and pay compensation to its World War II victims, is currently being cosponsored by more than 60 representatives from both sides of the aisle.

The Global Alliance said that Saito's comments were not only a repetition of grave misbehavior by Japanese high officials concerning their attitude toward history but also the first time a top diplomat has issued a warning against the parliamentarians of the country that hosts his embassy.
Saito's remarks are the most serious insult to both Americans and Chinese in modern history, the Alliance said. "Therefore, he must be held accountable for his public statements."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ACER PURCHASES SIEMENS PC PLANT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's computer giant Acer and the German electronics multinational Siemens have reached agreement that Acer will take over the personal computer (PC) plant belonging to Siemens-Nixdorf Information System (SNI) in Augsburg, southern Germany.

The news was reported by all the leading German media outlets. SNI has a work force of 2,000 with an annual production capacity of 1.4 million PCs. Acer will take over SNI production lines as well as its R&D department. SNI will maintain its marketing and planning departments, and the SNI-produced PCs will still be marketed under the SNI brand name. The two parties are expected to sign the acquisition contract in mid 1998.

Acer is now the world's third-largest PC and notebook producer. With the acquisition of the SNI plant, Acer will move up to second place, behind only Compaq. Acer is especially strong in Southeast Asian and Latin American markets, although the company is definitely a world player in computer manufacturing and marketing.

The corporation set up by Stan Shih in 1976 with only five employees has developed into a multinational enterprise with 23,000 on its payroll and annual sales amounting to US$6.3 billion. With branches in over 100 countries, the corporation has its own R&D department and some 1,600 research specialists who have developed more than 400 international patents.

In early 1997, Acer purchased the notebook sector of Texas Instruments and set up a daughter company -- Netxus -- in America. In Germany, Acer also set up a daughter company -- Acer Computer GmbH -- in Ahrenburg, with assembly lines employing a staff of 250.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO FOCUS ON RESUMING CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: An influential US congressman on Friday called on Taiwan to focus on resuming dialogue with mainland China and to avoid provocative actions. He also added to the recent debate over US arms sales to Taiwan by saying that the island's military does not need an upgrade.

Answering a question on how to maintain stability in the Taiwan Strait, Douglas Bereuter (R-Neb), chairman of the House Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific, cautioned against exaggerating the problems in the area.

"There is no significant need for an upgrade in Taiwanese military equipment," he added. Although mainland China's military is undergoing some modernization, he said the purpose is to give mainland China the capacity to deal with a "potential Taiwan conflict" and that Beijing is "far from having that capacity."
However, he did not say whether he thinks the US, as Taiwan's major arms supplier, should not sell particular types of weapons to Taiwan.
The congressman said that a more important focus for Taiwan should be to continue its dialogue with mainland China and avoid provocative actions.

"We have a prescription for China but we also have a prescription for Taiwan," he said, referring to the US position that while the mainland's use of force against Taiwan would not be acceptable, Taipei would be ill-advised to seek independence, something which Beijing has said would incur a military invasion.
Speaking to reporters at the Heritage Foundation in Washington, Bereuter disclosed that his subcommittee will hold a hearing next month on the US-ROC-PRC relationship.

As the administration prepares for President Bill Clinton's summit meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in June, he said: "We think it's appropriate to examine the issues, to give some encouragement to continued progress before the presidential visit."

He also acknowledged that there is "a lot of uneasiness" in Taiwan about the possibility that the US administration, to the detriment of Taiwan's interests, might make some concessions to Beijing in order to improve relations.
The congressman said, however: "I see no indication and I hear contrary expressions by the administration on that concern."
The hearing will be held amid concerns on Capitol Hill that the administration is moving too fast in its engagement with mainland China.

Critics of the Clinton administration say that too many concessions have been made by the US while Beijing still has a long way to go on issues such as human rights, non-proliferation and bilateral trade.

On Wednesday, five senators tabled a resolution calling on President Clinton to demand the immediate release of all political prisoners in mainland China when he meets with his counterpart in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW ON 3-DAY 'VACATION' VISIT TO MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew left for Malaysia on Saturday for a three-day private "vacation" visit.
Siew was accompanied by his wife, Fiannce Minister Chiu Cheng-hsiung and a group of business heavyweights.
The Malaysia trip followed his visits to the Philippines and Indonesia earlier this year.

The premier was tight-lipped on his low-profile Malaysia visit, saying he wished to keep the trip low key now that the Republic of China on Taiwan doesn't maintain formal diplomatic ties with Malaysia.

During his stay in Malaysia, Siew is expected to meet with Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamed, Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim and other Malaysian government officials as well as buisness leaders to exchange views on bilateral trade, economic relations, measures to cope with the Asia financial crisis, possible ROC assistance to Malaysia to tide over their current financial woes.

Scores of chief executive officers of large local private and state-owned enterprises, including Chinese Petroleum Corp., China Steel Corp. and Shin Kong Life Insurance Group, as well as heads of several major business and industry associations, are accompanying Siew on his Malaysia visit to explore trade, investment or joint-venture opportunities.

Despite the absence of diplomatic ties, substantive relations between the ROC and Malaysia have been very close. Vice President Lien Chan managed to make a four-day visit to the Southeast Asian country in March on his way back from a Middle East journey. Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar also made a private visit to Taiwan earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, HAITI REAFFIRM TIES

TEXT.P: Haiti President Rene Garcia Preval on Saturday reaffirmed his country's support for the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations and other major international organizations.
Preval made the pledge in a joint communique signed with ROC President Lee Teng-hui at the conclusion of his four-day state visit to Taiwan.
Acknowledging Taiwan's efforts to become a member of the UN and other international organizations, Preval said his Caribbean nation will continue throwing its support behind such a drive.
The two presidents said in the communique they are satisfied with progress in various bilateral cooperative programs. They also agreed to further expand cooperation in various fields.

According to the communique, the two countries will hold a meeting next spring to discuss new cooperative programs and evaluate all existing cooperative projects in accordance with a bilateral cultural and technological agreement signed in 1983.
Preval also invited President Lee to visit Haiti at a time of his convenience. Lee has accepted the invitation.
The ROC and Haiti have enjoyed longstanding friendship, establishing diplomatic ties more than 42 years ago.
Preval's visit was aimed at attracting Taiwan businesspeople to invest in his country.

Preval and his entourage left for home Saturday evening. In the morning, President Lee presided over a grand ceremony to bid farewell to the Haiti head of state, in which he was accorded full military honors.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE IN US VISITS SOUTH CAROLINA

TEXT.P: After nearly 50 years of hard work, the republic of China on Taiwan, now a democratic and prosperous nation, continues to believe in China's reunification but will only consider it under circumstances that ensure freedom, equality and the rule of law, the ROC's leading official in the United States said Friday.

Stephen Chen, who heads the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO) in the United States, made the remarks in Columbia, South Carolina. He was there at the invitation of the World Affairs Association to deliver a speech titled "The Development and Changes of the Republic of China."

Chen expressed in his speech that Taiwan is not against the development of relations between mainland China and the United States but that it strongly hopes Washington will maintain a parallel relations approach and refrain from sacrificing Taiwan's benefits for others' gains.
He later visited Columbia's leading newspaper to discuss Taiwan's perspective on relations between Washington and Beijing and on the Asian financial crisis with the publisher and editors.

Chen said that President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew have recently expressed Taipei's willingness to work together with Beijing to help Southeast Asian countries come up with solutions to the financial crisis.

According to Chen, Taiwan was able to weather the financial storm without suffering major setbacks because of strong fundamentals, such as its huge foreign exchange reserves, low inflation, low unemployment, high savings rates, low foreign debt, democratization and freedom of the press.

Chen denied adamantly that the depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar was an attempt to destabilize Hong Kong. The ROC's central bank had tried to stabilize the local currency's foreign exchange rate before strong market forces finally led it to decide to allow the local unit to follow the market, he pointed out.
Because Taiwan is not a member of the International Monetary Fund, he said, it must consider the fact that in the event of a financial crisis, that organization will not be on hand to bail it out.
In actuality, Chen continued, Beijing's decision to devalue the yuan by 40 percent in 1994 led many foreign investors to leave Southeast Asia and was a major cause of the Asian financial crisis.
Chen also visited the chancellor of the University of South Carolina Friday to exchange opinions on topics such as academic exchanges and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Chen is scheduled to meet South Carolina's governor on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA SLAMS DOOR ON DIRECT-SALES FIRMS

TEXT.P: "For now at least in China, Avon is banned from calling, Amway has lost its way, Mary Kay has been KO'd and the parties are over for Tupperware," the Los Angeles Times announced on its front page Friday.
The four giant US direct-sales companies, which have enjoyed phenomenal growth across mainland China, were ordered this week to stop operating under a broad new directive banning "pyramid selling."

Beijing's order that all direct-sales companies wind up their operations by Oct. 31 -- a declaration that US officials had protested in advance of its issue -- came the day before US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky arrived in Beijing for another round of trade talks.

According to Rone Tempest, the L.A. Times' Beijing bureau chief, Barshefsky's trade team responded to this ban and spent much of Thursday consulting with US executives and pressing Beijing officials to find a solution that will not harm the companies, which have been officially licensed and have invested millions of dollars in developing sales networks there.
The direct-sales conflict is the latest stress point to emerge as mainland China attempts its massive conversion from a command to a market economy, the daily said.

Although such grass-roots marketing plans featuring low-cost products are a perfect match for mainland China's developing economy, they thrive in an atmosphere that also lends itself easily to fraud -- as has happened in the similarly evolving economies of Russia and Albania, it noted.

News of the ban jolted some share prices on Wall Street. An Amway representative said the company's stock value dropped US$150 million in two days and attributed this to the mainland Chinese ban on direct sales. Avon shares, which were at US$83.88 on April 15, had fallen to US$79.25 by Tuesday but have since rebounded to US$82.63.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI GRAND HYATT WINS BEST BUSINESS HOTEL AWARD

TEXT.P: The Grand Hyatt Hotel in Taipei won the "Best Business Hotel" Award, one of the 38 Travel Awards presented at the PATA Travel Mart '98, which closed in Singapore Saturday.
The awards ceremony was held on board the Sun Vista, a cruise ship operated by Sun Cruises, in the Singapore Port Friday night.
The annual awards honor outstanding performers in the Asia-Pacific travel industry.
Twenty new awards were added this year. Among the winners of the 12 Best Travel Agency awards (by country or area) was Taiwan Travel International, which won the Best Travel Agency award for Taiwan.
The winners were picked by 40,000 readers of several travel trade publications: Travel Trade Gazette (TTG) Asia, PATA Travel News Asia-Pacific and Travel Week Australia.
Started in 1989, the annual awards are organized and presented by Miller Freeman, which publishes travel trade publications such as TTG Asia.
The following are some of the 1998 Travel Awards:
Travel Personality of the Year -- Joao Manuel Costa Antunes, director of the Macau Government Tourist Organization.
Destination of the Year -- Thailand.
Best Airline (Overall) -- Singapore Airlines.
Best European Airline -- Swissair.
Best North American Airline -- United Airlines.
Best Middle-Eastern/African Airline -- Emirates.
Best Asian Airline -- Singapore Airlines.
Best Pacific Airline -- Air New Zealand.
Best Hotel Chain -- Shangri-La Hotels & Resorts.
Best Resort Hotel -- Banyan Tree Phuket.
Best Individual Hotel -- Raffles Hotel (Singapore).
Best New City Hotel -- Palace of the Gold Horses, Malaysia.
Best New Resort Hotel -- Le Meridien Nirwana Bali, Indonesia.
Best Meetings & Convention Hotel -- Westin Hotel Plaza & Stamford Singapore.
Best Convention & Exhibition Center -- Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center.
Best Destination Management Company -- Asian Overland Services Tours & Travel, Malaysia.
Best Theme Attraction -- Tokyo Disneyland.
Best Airline -- Business Class -- Cathay Pacific Airways.
Best Business Hotel -- Grand Hyatt Taipei.
Best Corporate Travel Agency -- American Express Travel Service.
Best Car Rental Company -- Hertz Asia-Pacific.
Best National Tourist Organization -- Singapore Tourism Board.
Best Airport -- Singapore Changi Airport.
Best Cruise Operator -- Star Cruises.
Best Computerized Reservation System -- Abacus.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TECHNIQUE MAY ALLOW TRANSPLANT OF PIG ORGANS INTO HUMANS

TEXT.P: Australian scientists have discovered ways to transplant pig organs into people without acute rejection problems.

The mass circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald reported Saturday that a Melbourne-based research team using a new technique has successfully carried out heart transplants between normal and genetically engineered mice.
This should allow the breeding of transgenic donor pigs with the universal type O blood group -- meaning that pig organs could be transplanted into humans within a few years.
"All of our small animal models now suggest that this is the way to go," said Dr. Mauro Sandrin, a senior researcher at the Austin Research Institute in Melbourne.
"Our mouse model is directly analog to putting a pig's heart into a human," he said.
Demand for human donor organs now far exceeds supply, and many would-be recipients are dying while waiting for surgery, forcing medical doctors to look to other species to bridge the gap, he said.

Pigs are the most suitable, but so far such transplants have not been possible because a "hyperacute rejection" can turn the transplanted organ into a blackened, lifeless lump within minutes, he said.

Sandrin said he and his team discovered that this severe reaction occurs because the human immune system is primed with antibodies that immediately attack a key sugar, known as GAL, found on the surface of pig cells.
GAL is not found in humans and some other primates, but occurs in pigs, sheep and mice, he said.
The research team bred special experimental mice with an added human gene that virtually eliminated the GAL and effectively changed the mouse's blood group to type O.
The researchers then transplanted hearts from the transgenic animals into normal mice, which remained alive for more than 100 days and suffered no hyperacute rejection, Sandrin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STEVEDORE FIRM CLOSES SEVEN AUSTRALIAN WHARVES

TEXT.P: The recent victory of the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA) seems to have been short-lived, as the parent company of Patrick Stevedores Ltd. on Friday announced it will close seven terminals at its five ports.

Lang Corp. advised the Australian Stock Exchange that it was suspending indefinitely operations in Adelaide, Port Kembla and Newcastle in New South Wales, Bell Bay and Burnie ports in Tasmania, Geraldton Port in Western Australia and Port Alma in Queensland.
Lang blamed the MUA picketing of Patrick terminals for its decision to shut down the port operations.

The waterfront dispute was started by Patrick when it dismissed all 2,000 of its dock workers after the workers refused Patrick's request that they improve efficiency in the handling of container cargoes.
The sacking enraged the MUA, which mobilized thousands of its members to stage a series of protests which blocked access to Patrick's terminals in major Australian ports.
The MUA also received support from several domestic union groups and international labor organizations.

The Federal Court this week ordered Patrick to reinstate all its sacked workers, but the company appealed to the High Court, which extended a freeze on the Federal Court order pending a further appeal by the stevedoring firm.
The High Court decision means the MUA now has the problem of providing a rescue package for the sacked unionized workers.

The feasibility of any rescue was further jeopardized by Lang's notification that the insolvent companies (four Patrick subsidiaries) had been technically in breach of loan covenants since the appointment of the administrators -- the device used by Patrick to jettison its union workforce.
Lang's statement to the Australian Stock Exchange said the companies' banks had "reserved their position" in terms of dealing with the administrators of Patrick Stevedores' terminal operations.
Waterfront analysts said it will make any rescue package very difficult to implement, pointing out that although the sacked workers may have won the battle, they might still lose the war.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC GOVERNOR HEADS FOR ADB MEETING

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan will depart for Geneva Sunday night at the head of a 14-member delegation to attend the 31st annual conference of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).

During the course of the event, slated for Wednesday through Friday, participants will discuss ways to resolve the Asian financial crisis. The Republic of China delegation plans to raise a proposal whereby Taiwan will purchase bonds, issued by crisis-hit ADB member states and underwritten by the bank, to help those countries through the current economic downturn.

Perng, in his capacity as CBC governor and ADB board member, will protest the change of the ROC's membership designation at the ADB during a meeting with ADB President Sato Mitsuo. The ROC delegation will also lodge an open protest on the occasion of the conference's individual country reports.
The ADB unilaterally changed the ROC's designation from "Republic of China" to "Taipei, China" in 1986, following the admission of mainland China into the organization in that same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK BOX OF CRASHED PLANE FOUND

TEXT.P: After more than one month of searching, the digital flight data recorder of a domestic plane has been retrieved off Hsinchu in northern Taiwan, an official of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) confirmed on Sunday.

CAA Deputy Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng said he was informed by the salvage team that the flight data recorder of the Formosa Airline plane was retrieved Sunday morning, near the site where large pieces of the plane's fuselage were detected several days ago.
Chang said slight damage to the casing of the "black box" will not affect the reading of information contained inside.
Searchers are still looking for the plane's cockpit voice recorder, which they expect to retrieve later Sunday.
Chang said that because the retrieved device had been submerged on the sea floor for so long, it will have to undergo a desalination process before it can be sent overseas for analysis.
The black box will be sent to the National Transportation Safety Board of the United States on Tuesday at the latest to help determinate the cause of the accident.

The Saab-340 plane, carrying eight passengers and five crew, crashed off Nanliao, Hsinchu, shortly after taking off from Hsinchu airport en route to Taiwan's southern city of Kaohsiung on March 18, killing all aboard.
A search team found large pieces of the plane last week, but have been unable to salvage the wreckage due to rough seas.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), left for Australia on Sunday for a weeklong visit at the invitation of the Taipei-based Australian Commerce and Industry Office.

While there, Hsu will visit Australian government officials and opinion leaders, as well as meet Taiwan businesspeople and give a speech on cross-strait and regional cooperation at the University of New South Wales.

Hsu, who will hand over the DPP chairmanship at the end of June, has been actively promoting his philosophy of regional cooperation and cross-strait ties in a bid to boost international relations. He recently visited Japan and has plans to travel to northern Europe after concluding his current Australia tour. It is expected that Hsu will also visit mainland China after stepping down from the top DPP post.

Several ranking DPP cadres, including Sisy Chen, former director of the party's public relations department, and Hsiao Bi-khim , director of its international relations department, will accompany Hsu on the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), left for Australia on Sunday for a weeklong visit at the invitation of the Taipei-based Australian Commerce and Industry Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER SIEW MEETS MALAYSIAN PRIME MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, April 26 (CNA) (By C.P. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew met with Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamed on Sunday morning.
The two leaders exchanged views on wide ranging issues of mutual concern, including the strengthening of bilateral relations and ways to cope with the financial crisis in Southeast Asia.
Siew, who arrived here along with his delegation Saturday, has kept his three-day visit low-profile amid protests from Beijing over the trip.
He did not show up for a scheduled tour of one of Malaysia's developmental megaprojects, the Multimedia Super Corridor (MSC).

He was accompanied by Malaysian property and hotel tycoon Lee Kim Yew and officials of the Prime Minister Office to meet with Mahathir, after dodging a phalanx of Taiwan and Malaysian reporters waiting outside at his hotel.

Siew deliberately kept the meeting with Mahathir hush-hush to avoid offending Beijing. He is also expected to meet with Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim and other senior officials during his visit here.

Siew, who once served as the ROC consul general in Kuala Lumpur, met briefly with the media at his hotel Sunday morning, saying only that his visit is for vacation and to meet old friends. He would not comment on whether he planned to meet with Malaysian officials.

ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who accompanied Siew on the journey, said that Siew's visit also aims to explore the local investment climate and seek ways to sort out the financial turmoil that swept through Southeast Asia beginning in mid-1997.

Members of Siew's delegation, including Hu and Finance Minister Paul Chiu, as well as the chief executives from several private and state-owned enterprises in Taiwan, such as Chinese Petroleum Corp., China Steel Corp. and Shin Kong Life Insurance Group, went as scheduled to meet with their Malaysian counterparts as they toured the MSC on Sunday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-MALAYSIA TRADE TIES CLOSE, BUT HURDLES REMAIN

TEXT.P: Malaysia is one of the major trading partners of the Republic of China, but difficulties to economic exchanges between the two nations remain, economic officials said here Sunday.

The officials made the remarks as Premier Vincent Siew and his members of his delegation, including Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Finance Minister Paul Chiu, and several business leaders, left for Malaysia on Saturday for a three-day visit.

Statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) show that bilateral trade between the two nations amounted to nearly US$7.3 billion in 1997. Of that total, Taiwan imported US$4.23 billion in products from Malaysia, while exporting goods worth US$3.04 billion to the Southeast Asian nation.
That accounted for a two-way trade surplus of US$1.19 billion for Malaysia last year and made Taiwan its fourth largest trade partner, next only to Japan, Singapore and the United States.
Malaysia is the seventh largest trade partner of Taiwan, following the United States, Japan, Hong Kong, Germany, Singapore and South Korea.
Taiwan has US$8 billion worth of total investments in Malaysia, highlighting the close trade ties between the two nations.
To protect the interests of Taiwan businessmen there, Taipei and Kuala Lumpur signed an investment guarantee agreement in 1993, and inked an agreement to avoid double taxation in 1996.
But ROC economics officials said there are still major hurdles to smooth trade relations between the two nations.

They pointed out that revised regulations passed by Malaysia in 1996 allow foreign financial institutions to own no more than a 20 percent stake in local banks. That makes it more difficult for Taiwan businessmen to obtain loans in Malaysia and affects their willingness to invest in that country.
Also, the Malaysia government has yet to sign an agreement with Taiwan for the temporary admission of goods, they said.

In addition, although Kuala Lumpur has granted 72-hour visa-free treatment to ROC nationals, manufacturers here are seeking a simplified process for obtaining work visas and visa extensions by Taiwan technicians going to Malaysia.
Taiwan has also complained that Malaysia imposes tariff and nontariff hurdles to Taiwan products.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAUDI ARABIA PLANS BAN ON LASER PENS

TEXT.P: Health authorities in Saudi Arabia have endorsed plans to impose a ban on the import and sale of laser pens, toys and appliances which emit laser rays.
The Health Ministry of Saudi Arabia said: "Laser rays are harmful to the eyes. These rays can damage the retina and canker the surface of the cornea.
"Exposure to laser rays has been linked to cancer, especially among pregnant women," it said, quoting reports from experts.

The Health Ministry has recommended a series of measures to enforce the proposed ban, including restrictions on the sale of laser pens and other items that emit laser rays, and efforts to prevent the exchange of laser pens and toys in schools so as to check their use by children.
Laser pens are widely available in toy stores and book shops. Their prices range from US$16 to nearly US$60.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S ECONOMIC GROWTH SLOWS

TEXT.P: The lumbering economy of mainland China has slowed to its lowest growth rate in nearly eight years, a Canadian newspaper reported Saturday.

It is beset by rising unemployment, woeful inefficiency among state-owned enterprises, growing stockpiles of unwanted products and the continuing impact of financial troubles in other parts of Asia, the Globe and Mail said.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily quoted Qiu Xiaohua, chief economist at the State Statistical Bureau, as confirming that the country's once-skyrocketing economic growth fell to 7.2 percent during the first three months of 1998, the 16th consecutive quarterly downturn.

This falls considerably short of the government's target of 8 percent, which most economists feel is the minimum increase the mainland needs to cope with millions of new employees entering the work force every year, the report said.
It quoted a Western diplomat as saying, "If I were a Chinese leader, I'd be worried about the 7.2 percent growth figure."

The reason, according to the Mail, is that the Chinese mainland is already in the midst of its highest unemployment in many years. Other worrisome figures cast clouds over Qiu's optimism that it will eventually realize its 8 percent growth target this year, the daily added.

These include industrial losses which rose nearly 22 percent during the first two months of 1998 over the same period of last year, a stunning 82.8 percent plunge in profits during January and February, and the first-quarter rise of 14.2 percent in the value of industrial goods gathering dust in mainland Chinese warehouses. The last amounted to nearly US$70 billion, or almost 7 percent of the mainland's gross domestic product.

It quoted Qiu as explaining that the products do not have markets because many companies lack the speed necessary to react to changes in the marketplace. The problem prompts many economists to discount Beijing's growth figures by as much as 2 percent to 3 percent, in order to account for products that merely move from the factory to the warehouse, it noted.
The daily quoted a Hong Kong analyst as estimating, "When you take out the inventory buildup, China's growth is about 5 percent. That's worse than Southeast Asian countries."

Still, the mainland economy is far from going bust, the Mail pointed out. One reason is -- if you trust Beijing's figures -- export growth is down but still healthy, and foreign investment continues to pour into the country. Another factor is the mainland's massive foreign exchange reserves, now about US$143 billion, the third highest in the world, the report said.

What concerns Beijing leaders is the gradual decline in what was recently the world's fastest-growing economy during a time of painful restructuring, it said. If meaningful new jobs cannot be found for the estimated 10 million workers expected to be laid off in the coming year, the country could face serious social unrest, it observed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY TO SEND DELEGATION TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The opposition New Party plans to take a more aggressive stance toward mainland policy, NP official Chen Kuei-miao said on Sunday.

Chen also said that the NP will send a delegation to visit Beijing in early June to discuss means of protecting the interests of Taiwan residents doing business on the mainland. He made the remarks at the first of a series of seminars on cross-strait policy at the Taipei International Convention Center.
The seminars are aimed at canvassing the opinions of the industrial, academic and government sector in Taiwan for reference in mapping out the NP's mainland policy.

Jaw Shau-kong, NP campaign manager for year-end elections, claimed the ROC government has overlooked numerous difficulties faced by local businessmen operating on the mainland, who he said have helped to earn precious foreign reserves for Taiwan and have fought to raise the island's international profile.
Jaw said that the NP will pay close attention to the needs of Taiwan businessmen, and will identify the party with their interests.
Chen also said the NP will attempt to shed the popular view that it is preoccupied with the goal of national unification by taking a more aggressive stance in its mainland policy.

He criticized the government's "no haste, be patient" policy toward investment on the Chinese mainland, and said the NP will send a fact-finding delegation to Beijing by early June. It will discuss Taiwan business operations on the mainland and a range of bilateral economic issues.
Among other things, the delegation will ask Beijing officials to map out more substantial measures to protect Taiwan investors doing business on the mainland.

Chou Yang-shan, convener of NP's election and development committee, said the NP will also organize an observation team in the near future to study the reform of state-owned enterprises on the mainland for reference in drafting the NP's cross-strait policy.

In addition to NP officials, Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Lin Nung-chung, director-general of the Industrial Development and Investment Center, as well as other economics officials and local businessmen, attended the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADHERENTS RAVE OVER BENEFITS OF URINE CONSUMPTION

TEXT.P: Some 40 percent of patients interviewed have seen their conditions improve after undergoing treatment that involves drinking urine, the National Health Research Institute (NHRI) said in announcing the results of a study Sunday.

The NHRI said that although some patients afflicted with periodontal disease, high blood pressure, diabetes and retrogressive arthritis have experienced reduced symptoms after drinking urine, more studies are needed to establish the efficacy of the treatment.

The practice of drinking urine to cure or alleviate these maladies first become popular in Japan, and has recently found an increasing number of followers in Taiwan. It is estimated that 200,000 people in Taiwan have tried the method either to combat the effects of aging or to help fight all kinds of chronic diseases.
NHRI researchers surveyed 290 members of a group who had tried the urine treatment in order to learn more about their motives and assess the effectiveness of the method.
Some 43 percent of those surveyed said they tried the method to cure a variety of aliments, while 25 percent said they hoped to improve their overall physical fitness.
Some 6.9 percent had consumed their own urine in hopes of staying young, while 8.3 percent said they had done so out of curiosity or because it is in vogue.
Over half of those surveyed said they have drunken their own urine for a period of between one and three years.
Researcher Lai chi-ming said that from those surveyed, the benefits from drinking urine seem to substantiate the usefulness of the practice.

Lai said that among 294 persons surveyed, 194 suffered from a specific illness. Based on his interviews, the method was claimed to have cured 17 of them. Some 122 reported that their conditions improved, while 26 practitioners of the treatment reported no apparent change. In addition, 29 of the subjects said their conditions had improved but felt that had nothing to do with their drinking urine.

Lai said the treatment involves drinking the first urine sample collected in the morning. It apparently works best for persons afflicted with periodontal diseases, including gingivitis, or inflammation of the gums, followed by those patients with diabetes and chronic hepatitis.
However, he said diabetes patients might find a more "tasteful" means of controlling blood sugar levels by turning to a lighter light diet and avoiding red meat and fried foods.

Lai was also baffled by some of the benefits attributed to urine consumption, such as stoppage of bleeding gums, quick improvement of bad breath and a reduction in the amount of medication needed to control high blood pressure.
Some practitioners of the method who suffer mild cases of arthritis reported that their conditions had improved, but persons with more serious forms of the condition showed no obvious effects.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIPLOMATIC WAR CRITICIZED

TEXT.P: Academics and scholars attending a seminar Sunday urged Taipei and Beijing to cease their diplomatic war and called on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to include the issue on the agenda of cross-strait talks.

Speaking at a symposium sponsored by the Chinese Culture Council (CCC) on cross-strait ties, Chiu Chao-lin, a researcher of international relations with Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic research institute, said people on Taiwan should pay heed to trends in international society, as global developments exercise much influence on cross-strait relations.

Recent moves by the United States indicate Washington will not sit idle and allow cross-strait ties to develop naturally, and it remains to be seen whether Taiwan and mainland China will be able to eventually meet at the negotiating table for unification talks, she pointed out.

In a bid to reduce the fierce pressure from the mainland to isolate Taiwan in the international community, Chiu urged the government not to change foreign ministers too frequently so that the person occupying the post may be fully devoted to the job. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs, she added, should keep a low key even if President Lee Teng-hui is invited by other countries to visit.

Academics attending the seminar, which followed the suspension of diplomatic ties between the Republic of China and Guinea-Bissau on Friday, unanimously opined that Taiwan and mainland China should stop their "diplomatic battle."

Pan Hsi-tang, professor of mainland Chinese affairs at Tamkang University, said the renewal of diplomatic relations between Guinea-Bissau and mainland China on Thursday is additional proof that diplomatic wrangling between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has not eased with improvement in bilateral ties.
Although the government's determination to carry out "pragmatic diplomacy" policy is correct, Pan said, it should adjust its strategies and measures.

As the mainland is working hard to force Taiwan into political negotiations by restricting its presence in the international community, Pan said, the government's pragmatic diplomacy should be more "intensified" and "selective." He added that the issue of the two sides' international presence should be put high on the agenda of cross-strait talks.

National Taiwan University Prof. Chang Lin-cheng also stated that the two sides should stop the diplomatic war, urging the government to forswear the mentality of confrontation in its dealings with the mainland on the diplomatic front.
International relations and cross-strait ties should be built on a mutually beneficial basis and neither side should treat the other side as a "conspirator."

Echoing Pan's view, CCC Chairman C.H. Ma said he agrees that Taiwan and the mainland must stop their diplomatic wrangle, as the "zero-sum game" will hurt both sides, thus igniting the independence movement in Taiwan and reducing the chances of China's unification.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSJACKER SURRENDERS TO POLICE AFTER 3-HOUR STANDOFF

TEXT.P: A man hijacked a bus on Monday morning and kept police at a standoff in downtown Taipei for more than three hours before surrendering.
It is believed to be the first case of a bus hijacking in Taiwan.
The man in his 20s, identified as Chen Nung-ping, commandeered the Route No. 243 bus belonging to the Taipei Transportation Co. at 7:45 a.m. in Yungho, Taipei County.

Chen, wielding three knives, forced the bus driver to divert his course to the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) building on Chunghsiao East Road in downtown Taipei, saying he wanted to talk to CIB Deputy Director Ho You-yi.
A contingent of police patrol cars escorted the hijacked bus to the front of the government tax office at Chunghsiao East Road, near the CIB.

After arriving at the building, Chen released the bus driver and several passengers. He forced the remaining passengers to stay seated in the rear section of the bus, before eventually releasing them at 10:30 a.m.
Police sent an elite squad to surround the bus and tried to calm the hijacker, who was pacing around the interior of the bus mumbling to himself.
Chen, claiming to be a follower of the opposition New Party, demanded to talk with party heavyweights Jaw Shau-kong, Wang Chien Hsuan or Hau Lung-ping.
Chen finally surrendered at 11:04 a.m. after meeting with Hau and Jaw.

An initial interrogation by police indicated that Chen may suffer from paranoid delusions. He suspected that he and his best friend, surnamed Hsieh, were being followed by persons intent upon harming them.
The released passengers said Chen had told them that he was not a lunatic and repeatedly apologized for his actions.
But according to Hsieh, Chen suffers from mental illness and had tried to start a fire at Hsieh's home with a container of gasoline Monday morning just prior to the hijacking incident.
