DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW MUM ON PRESIDENT LEE'S VISIT TO MALAYSIA
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, April 27 (CNA) (By C.P. Hung & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew on Monday would not comment on reports that President Lee Teng-hui will visit Malaysia in June or July this year.

Siew, who is on the third and final day of his current Malaysian trip, said a visit by the head of state to a nonallied nation is highly sensitive affair, and it would be improper to speculate on relevant matters.
Siew, who led a Taiwan delegation to Malaysia on Saturday for a private, recreational visit, meanwhile called his journey "fruitful and successful."

The premier, who has kept his visit low-profile to avoid offending Beijing, met with Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamed, Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim and other senior ministers in Kuala Lumpur over a lunch Sunday which lasted nearly four hours.

During the gathering, Siew exchanged views with the Malaysian officials over a wide range of issues, including ways to bolster bilateral ties and jointly deal with the Southeast Asian economic crisis.

On Sunday evening, Siew and his entourage were honored by ROC Representative in Malaysia Paul J.K. Tso, at a dinner which was also attended by ROC Finance Minister Paul Chiu, Foreign Minister Jason Hu, a group of chief executives from private and state-owned enterprises in Taiwan, and several Malaysian officials.
The dinner took place amid a rare thunderstorm in drought-plagued Malaysia. A lighthearted Siew likened his visit to the rain shower, saying both of them are "timely and welcomed."
Siew said he has found that bilateral ties between Taiwan and Malaysia are now much closer than some thirty years ago, when he was the ROC consul general in Kuala Lumpur.

Describing Taiwan and Malaysia as "true friends in trying times," Siew said Taiwan is always confident in Malaysia, even though the country is experiencing economic difficulties. With its robust institutionalized system and basic economic infrastructure, however, Malaysia is expected to overcome the temporary hard times and stand tall again quite soon, Siew noted.
Siew is scheduled to tee off Monday morning at Malaysia's top golf course, the Mines Golf Country Club, which is the venue of the 1999 World Golf Tournament.
Siew, his wife and the Taiwan delegation are scheduled to return to Taipei late Monday afternoon, concluding their three-day unofficial visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILLING TO HELP WITH FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said on Monday that the Republic of China is willing to help neighboring countries tackle the financial crisis and that the current visit by Premier Vincent Siew to Malaysia is reflective of such intent.

Attributing Taiwan's stability amid the regionwide financial morass to its solid economic foundation and transparent financial policy, Liu said the ROC is willing to provide assistance and share its experience with crisis-hit countries to help them through the economic downturn.
Liu made the remarks while addressing the opening ceremony of the third Asian-Pacific Youth Leaders Conference at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.
The vice premier, on behalf of Siew and the people of the ROC, also welcomed more than 60 youth representatives from countries in the Asia-Pacific to take part in the event.

C.C. Lee, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission, which sponsored the conference, said cooperation between the youth in the Asia-Pacific will secure the region's continued development and prosperity, and that the purpose of the gathering is aimed at providing an opportunity for exchanges by young leaders from across the area.

Youth affairs officials from Indonesia, New Zealand, the Philippines and Vietnam are among the delegates in town for a roundtable meeting to discuss issues related to youth policy and problems for future exchanges and cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS TO PICK UP BY END OF 2ND QUARTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports should pick up at the end of the second quarter and economic growth is expected to top 6 percent this year, Yeh Ming-feng, director of the Economic Research Department under the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Monday.
Yeh made the remarks as the CEPD released a report on the nation's overall economic situation for March.

The report showed that the leading economic index continued to drop by another 0.6 percent in March. Although the drop was modest, it is the third consecutive month that the index has shown a decrease.
Moreover, domestic manufacturers have been more conservative in their outlook for the next quarter, indicating that economic growth will slow in the short term, the report said.
But Yeh asserted that although Taiwan registered a rare trade deficit in the quarter of US$70 million, weakened exports will not be a long-term trend.
One noteworthy fact is that Taiwan suffered a first-quarter trade deficit of more than US$400 million with Southeast Asian nations, down 27 percent from the same period of last year.

Yeh attributed that situation to the financial turmoil that has swept through Southeast Asia, saying the region has suffered from capital crunch that affects the capacity of importers there to buy Taiwan products.

But he also noted that Southeast Asian countries have narrowed the trade gaps following the depreciation of their currencies in recent months, and that their capacity to import more goods will improve.
Yeh estimated that by the end of the second quarter, Taiwan's exports and overall economic situation will begin to turn for the better.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMY CONTINUES TO FLASH 'GREEN LIGHT'

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy continued to flash a "green light" in March, a sign of stable growth on a five-color composite measurement system, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported on Monday.
It was the 17th consecutive month that the local economy has received a safe green rating on the CEPD-designed scale.
March's overall economic performance received a score of 26 points, down one point from the February level.

In March, leading indicators dropped 0.6 percent, a fall of three consecutive months, hinting that the domestic economy may remain stable over the next three to five months without gaining significant momentum, according to officials from the CEPD's Economic Research Department.

Under the CEPD's five-color assessment system, a red light means the economy is overheated; a yellow-red light indicates the economy is heating up; a green light reflects steady growth; a yellow-blue rating signals an economic slowdown; and a blue light represents an economic recession.

Ratings are determined according to nine major economic indicators: export value, new export orders, industrial production, manufacturing inventories, total employment outside the agricultural sector, money supply, stock prices, the check default rate and bank lending to the private sector. The minimum score for a healthy green rating is 23 points.
During the month of March, nearly all the nine indicators showed little change, with a few posting only slight drops from the month-earlier level, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK BOX OF CRASHED AIRLINER HEADED TO US FOR ANALYSIS

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said it will send the black box from a crashed domestic plane to the National Transportation Safety Board of the United States on Tuesday for analysis.
CAA officials indicated Monday that the result of the analysis will be known in a week at the earliest.
The Saab-340 plane crashed March 18 off the coast of Nanliao, shortly after taking off from Hsinchu airport on its way to Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, killing all 13 persons aboard.

After over one month of searching, divers found large portions of the plane's fuselage last week, and were able to retrieve its digital flight data recorder and cockpit voice recorder on Sunday and Monday, respectively.

Hsinchu District Prosecutor Chen Po-hou, who is in charge of the investigation into the cause of the crash, said that from initial examinations of the wreckage collected so far, the possibility that some type of explosion had occurred is high.

Chun declined to speculate over whether the accident could have been caused by mechanical failure or other factors, saying that any conclusion will have to wait until information contained in the black box has been analyzed.

The accident came as one in a series of air disasters, notably the China Airlines crash on Feb. 16 that left 202 persons dead and a helicopter crash on March 2. The incidents prompted a national uproar for improvements in flight safety and forced the resignation of Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsay Jaw-yang and CAA Director-General Tsai Tuei.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOVE TO HELP SOUTHEAST ASIA MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL: CEPD HEAD

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said on Monday that Taiwan's offer to aid crisis-hit Southeast Asian countries is a mutually beneficial move which will also win international respect.

Although some people have questioned why the money will not be used to improve conditions at home, Chiang said the government's initiative to assist Southeast Asian countries through their economic difficulties in conjunction with the private sector will benefit Taiwan as well, and earn it respect from the international community.
Pointing to the United States and Japan as examples, Chiang said both nations have provided considerable assistance in Taiwan's economic development.

The United States has been the largest overseas market for Taiwan exports for many years, while Japan sends a team of 80 experts to Taiwan for technology transfers and receives 200 Taiwan technicians for vocational training each year, Chiang pointed out. He added that Japan also has greatly benefited from Taiwan's rapid economic development, as 30 percent of local imports come from that country.

Increased investment abroad will in turn boost outbound shipments, Chiang stressed, adding that Taiwan's deliveries to Southeast Asia have increased from 5 percent to 15 percent of its total exports, standing at approximately US$17 billion in value annually, trailing only those to the United States and Europe.
Chiang made the remarks at a workshop called by the CEPD to train police administrative and customs personnel in line with the government's Asia-Pacific operations hub plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREDIT CARD USAGE CONTINUES TO RISE, CRIMES FOLLOW

TEXT.P: With the rapid development of the credit card industry in recent years, the occurrence of related crimes has become more prevalent and increasingly sophisticated.

According to statistics announced by the Bureau of Monetary Affairs (BMA) under the Ministry of Finance, 13.76 million credit cards had been issued in Taiwan as of the end of February. The number of cards in circulation was 7.88 million, an increase of 36.09 percent from the same month of last year. Total transactions in February reached NT$37.346 billion, with approximately 111,000 businesses across Taiwan accepting credit card transactions.

Credit card-related crimes have increased as well, according to the BMA. Recent investigations have revealed a significant number of cases where dishonest brokers help clients apply for credit cards, and later use the clients' personal data to forge other applications. The fraudulent cards would then be used to conduct transactions with accomplice stores.

The bureau said that in response to the rising frequency of these practices, it has notified the Bankers Association of the ROC to quickly come up with a counter-strategy and to relay the information to credit card issuers and collection agencies.

In addition, the BMA cautioned cardholders to guard their personal data against foul play by not arbitrarily giving out such information and by staying in touch with their credit card issuing agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE DISSIDENTS MAPPING OUT PRO-DEMOCRACY PLAN
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 27 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Wang Dan, one of mainland China's leading dissidents of the 1989 Tiananmen Square pro-democracy movement who was recently released by the Beijing authorities, met with Wei Jingsheng, another prominent mainland Chinese dissident, at the Columbia University in New York on Sunday. This was the first meeting between the two after their exile, and they pledged to collaborate on pushing the democracy movement in mainland China.

Wei, who returned to the United States on Saturday evening after concluding a visit to Europe, met with his old friend Wang the next morning. During their three-hour talk, they exchanged views and tried to map out a concrete plan for the promotion of the democracy movement in mainland China. They declined to disclose details of their plan to the press prior to its implementation.

Although Wei was once invited to deliver a speech at the "democratic saloon" founded by Wang in Beijing University, the last meeting between the two took place at a Beijing prison where both men were "illegally detained" along with Lieu Nienchun, another of mainland China's leading dissidents.

Despite the passing of so many years, Wei said, Wang has not changed at all, adding that he still personifies the characteristics of the Chinese intellectual and that his sense of responsibility for mainland China's democracy movement remains undimmed.

However, he said he does not see eye to eye with Wang's view that he (Wang himself) was responsible for the failure of the student demonstration at Tiananmen Square in 1989, placing the blame instead squarely on the Beijing authorities.
The most important thing at present, remarked Wei, is to learn a lesson from the failure and never to let it happen again.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN RESIDENTS SUPPORT DIALOGUE WITH BEIJING: POLL

TEXT.P: A great majority of Taiwan people think the government should continue to engage in some kind of dialogue with mainland China for better relations across the Taiwan Strait, according to a public opinion poll released Monday.

The poll, conducted by Burke Marketing Research Ltd. at the request of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), also found that Beijing's reneging on a previous consensus that each side may hold its own interpretation of the "one China" concept is unacceptable for most Taiwan residents.

In the past, some ambiguity was tacitly allowed over the meaning of "one China." The ROC envisions a single Chinese entity as a "goal" rather than a present-day reality. It views that entity in abstract terms -- a historical, geographical and cultural China. In other words, a unified China cannot exist under present conditions, but that goal can be achieved in the future.

The poll of 1,067 adults living on the island showed that 73 percent of respondents were strongly supportive for the government to conduct a dialogue or negotiations with the Beijing authorities, and that 65 percent disagreed with Beijing's backtracking over the consensus on the "one China" concept.

More than 40 percent of the group also opined that if the cross-strait dialogue does not resume shortly, as all recent signals indicate is likely, the consequences will be adverse to prospects for future exchanges between the two sides.

About 40 percent of those polled said they would like to see the status quo in cross-strait relations be maintained. Whether Taiwan should declare independence or unite with the Chinese mainland depends on future developments; 21 percent said the status quo should be maintained for some time before moves are made toward unification; 19 percent either supported Taiwan's independence or said the status quo should be maintained for some time before Taiwan declares independence outright.

It is worth of note that the percentage of those who support the idea of "maintaining status quo for now, and then moving toward independence" has increased significantly since the previous poll conducted in November last year, to a record high.
The percentage of those who support "an early declaration of independence," however, dropped to a new low, the poll found.
Meanwhile, as much as 80 percent of those surveyed opposed Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula and felt the model being used to administer Hong Kong would not be workable for Taiwan.
The poll, conducted by telephone on April 4-5, obtained valid answers from 1,067 adults aged between 20 and 69.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION IN CANBERRA FOR ENERGY, TRADE AND INVESTMENT CONFAB

TEXT.P: ROC Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming and his 11-member delegation arrived in Canberra on Monday to attend the 5th Energy and Mineral Trade and Investment Consultations.
The annual meeting will discuss bilateral trade in energy and minerals between Taiwan and Australia and Taiwan's investment in Australian energy sector.
Henry Yang, director of the Economic Section of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canberra, told the CNA that both countries hope to increase cooperation in energy trade and investment.
Last year, two-way trade between Taiwan and Australia exceeded US$4.2 billion, up considerably from the 1996 levels.
Yang said Yin and his group would discuss with their Australian counterparts ways to increase cooperation between the two countries in the energy and mineral sectors.
Yin was not available for comment.
TECO Representative Liu Po-lun told CNA that Australia hopes to increase its exports of coal, iron ore and other energy products to Taiwan.
He said Australia also hoped Taiwan would increase its investment in this country.
At present, the state-run Taiwan Power Co. has some investment in coal mining in New South Wales.
These matters will be discussed extensively between members of Yin's delegation and their Australian counterparts during the two-day meeting in Canberra starting Monday, Liu said.
The annual meeting is held on a rotating basis between Taipei and Canberra.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.051 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at NT$33.037.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 32.985 and experienced a high of 33.05.
The interbank trading reached US$277 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA BOOSTS FINANCIAL AID TO VIETNAM AND THAILAND

TEXT.P: Australia will increase its financial aid to Vietnam and Thailand in the next few years, starting from 1998, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said last week.

He told reporters in Hanoi during his recent visit there that the amount of aid will be increased to A$236 million (more than US$157 million) between July 1998 and June 2002, up from the A$200 million (US$133 million) delivered over the last four years.

"I don't think there is as much support in Australia (for aid to Vietnam) now as there might have been 10 or 20 years ago. But the government does what it thinks is in the national interest," he said.

Meanwhile, the increase in Australian aid to Thailand was announced by Prime Minister John Howard during a visit there last weekend to commemorate ANZAC Day, which commemorates the deaths of Australian and New Zealand soldiers during World War II. He did not mention any figures.

Prior to the Asian financial crisis, Australia had planned to cease its aid to Thailand by the year 2000, he said, adding that Canberra will now continue to provide financial aid to Thailand as a result of the crisis.
The financial aid will be spent on health, education and infrastructure in both Vietnam and Thailand, Downer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN INVESTORS WARNED ON UNAUTHORIZED TAX BREAKS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Australian companies operating in mainland China should be wary of unauthorized tax breaks granted by local authorities to foreigners, according to a mainland China tax expert.

Tony Baxter, a tax partner at the Coopers and Lybrand firm in Sydney, said some Australian companies have been forced to pay back taxes after their tax-exempt status was retrospectively revoked by the central government in Beijing in a recent crackdown on unauthorized tax concessions granted by local provincial authorities.
He said: "Many Australian companies investing in China currently enjoy tax-exempt status but some tax concessions may not be valid."

"It is well known that some local government authorities in China offer tax concessions or exemptions and levy tax without proper authorization," he said, adding: "Beijing has the substantive tax powers in China and recently sent a sharp reminder to the provinces and local tax bureaus of this fact."
He said that in March this year mainland China's national tax council restated its position as the sole central legislator and administrator in tax matters, apart from some minor taxes.
He urged Australian companies with Chinese investments or joint venture firms to check the authority behind any tax concessions or exemptions they are currently relying on.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADERS TO IMPORT US PORK OFFAL BY AIR

TEXT.P: Domestic traders have decided to cash in on the high price of hog offal in local markets by importing certain products from the United States by air once it is allowed to enter Taiwan from June 1, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said on Monday.

To facilitate Taiwan's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), the island agreed during WTO talks with the US to allow entry of 5,000 tons of pork bellies and 7,500 tons of pork offal, as well as 10,000 tons of chicken and 5,000 tons of beef offal, even before the island is admitted into the WTO.

With the continued slump in pork prices following the eruption of foot-and-mouth disease in March 1997 in Taiwan, traders have shown little interest in the 5,000 tons of imported pork bellies from the US, but are eyeing with interest the pork offal, prices for which have remained high due to local demand for the delicacies.

The COA officials offered as an example the fact that a pair of domestic pork kidneys have a current retail value of between NT$200 and NT$300 in local markets, but pointed out that the price is likely to be driven down by 40 or 50 percent following the onslaught of US offal.
The officials said that the price of pork offal, including livers, stomachs, hearts, heads, and ears will be cut sharply once the US imports begin to arrive.

Local traders were originally hoping to ship frozen offal in refrigerated containers, but as some pork offal items such as hearts and kidneys quickly lose their flavor after freezing, traders are now planning to ship these products by air, which only requires them to be chilled.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 164.49 points to close at 8.471.62.
Dealers said the market experienced a day of relatively light transactions, with the prevailing uneasy sentiment triggering selling pressure and a downward trend.
The bourse opened at 8,623.61 and experienced a low of 8,453.48 and a high of 8,649.04.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 397 to 62, with 26 issues remaining unchanged.
A total of 1.74 billion stocks changed hands on a market turnover of NT$96.65 billion.

All eight major categories lost ground, with electrical shares plunging the most at 2.8 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.2 percent, plastics and chemical stocks and textile issues at 1.8 percent, construction shares at 1.7 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 1.4 percent, and the foodstuff category at 1.2 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Monday's trading were: Ever Fortune Industries; Chuntex Electronic Co., Ltd.; ASE; Compal Electronic Inc.; Mitac International Corp.; Mosel Vitelic Inc.; ACER; Winbond Electronics Corp.; China Manmade Fibers; and Jen Hsian Construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIL. TRANSFERS TO MAINLAND CHINA COULD HARM AMERICAN INTERESTS (I)

TEXT.P: The massive modernization program upon which the People's Liberation Army has embarked is likely to produce a "peer competitor" to the United States early in the next century, yet the US administration persists in approving advanced-tech transfers to mainland China, warned Oliver North, a nationally syndicated American columnist.
While visiting mainland China in June, US President Bill Clinton plans to sign a major Washington-Beijing agreement on satellite launches and cooperation in space.

Though the story has received far less notice than Clinton's sexual escapades, "it is a whole lot more important to the fate of our children" than what the interns were doing in the Oval Office, North wrote Sunday in The Washington Times.

According to an April 13 New York Times front-page article, two of America's leading aerospace companies -- Loral Space & Communications and Hughes Electronics -- are suspected of having provided "space expertise that significantly advanced Beijing's ballistic missile program."

The military significance of this technology transfer was of sufficient gravity that a criminal investigation was opened and a grand jury impaneled to consider indictments in the matter. But before formal charges could be filed, Clinton quietly authorized the export to mainland China of technology similar to that which guides a long-range nuclear missile to its target by one of the companies under investigation, noted the columnist.

The chilling effect of Clinton's action was clearly understood at the time it was taken. Defense and State Department officials argued against the export license because the technology is so sensitive. Professionals at the Department of Justice also objected that authorizing the Loral tech-transfer would make it practically impossible to prosecute the earlier case.

Despite opposition from his military, intelligence and Justice Department experts, Clinton authorized the technology transfer. "The Clinton administration's indifference to the arming of China is simply stupefying," North said.

The administration says it's OK to sell the mainland Chinese these critical technologies because of Beijing's "commitment to nonproliferation." But on April 15, Pakistan -- one of Beijing's principal technology trading partners -- announced that it successfully launched a missile with a range of 900 miles. (continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: MIL. TRANSFER (II)

TEXT.P: "Will anyone have the nerve to ask if some of the technology supplied by Loral to Beijing somehow found its way to Islamabad?" asked the columnist.

Some in Congress are finally paying attention. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Henry Hyde (R-Ill.), and Rep. Tillie Fowler (R-Fla.) of the House National Security Committee have asked Attorney General Janet Reno to investigate whether these sales have been influenced by illegal mainland Chinese efforts to divert funds to the Clinton-Gore re-election campaign.

But North said they should also ask more about the relationship between Clinton and major Clinton-Gore donor Michael Armstrong, former chief executive officer of Hughes Electronics. And has the $2.5 million contributed to Democratic candidates and causes by Loral and Hughes influenced the outcome of these tech-transfer cases in favor of Beijing?

Did the fact that Loral's CEO Bernard Schwartz was the largest personal contributor to the Democratic National Committee last year have anything to do with the president's decision to vitiate legal proceedings against his company?

The columnist concluded that "They may not be sexy, but ultimately, the answers to these questions are going to be far more important to the American people than what Monica Lewinsky did or did not do in the Oval Office."

DOC.HEADLINE: US DEFENSE WEEKLY COMMENTS ON ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The US Department of State and National Security Council have discussed a de facto moratorium on major new arms sales to Taiwan prior to President Bill Clinton's upcoming June summit with mainland Chinese leader Jiang Zemin in Beijing, according to the latest issue of US Defense News weekly.

In a two-day bilateral arms discussion here last week, Taiwan's requests for submarines and air defense missiles were once again rejected, ostensibly because the US argued that Taipei lacks a compelling national security need for the weaponry.

In a commentary entitled "No Deal on Taiwan," the Defense News urged Clinton and his foreign policy team to resist the temptation to accommodate Beijing at the expense of Taiwan's legitimate security needs.

It said since the Washington summit last fall between Clinton and Jiang, Beijing has intensified calls for a ban on arms sales to Taipei, arguing that US weapons to Taiwan constitute a form of proliferation no different or more dangerous than Beijing's sale of advanced weapons to Iran.

Curiously, this reasoning is gaining resonance in the State Department and National Security Council, where a de facto moratorium on major new arms sales to Taipei has been discussed prior to Clinton's second summit with Jiang, said the weekly.

The weekly argued that instead of ill-conceived deals or wink-and-nod diplomacy that rewards Beijing and punishes Taipei, Clinton needs to remind the people of Taiwan, mainland China and the United States that US interests are in preventing war and promoting peaceful reunification.

For Beijing leaders, it means no more live-fire military exercises perilously close to Taiwan, or worse, attempts to blockade or otherwise threaten Taiwan. For Taiwan, it means no declarations of sovereignty to provoke Beijing.

The commentary said that for the White House, it means continuing to encourage both sides to resolve their differences directly and peacefully without dragging Washington into playing the role of interlocutor. Washington also must maintain its commitment under the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act to provide Taiwan with weaponry needed to deter mainland Chinese aggression.
A Clinton clarity campaign on the issue of the US' China policy is long overdue and there's no better place to start than at the upcoming Clinton-Jiang summit, the article concludes.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA FAILS TO COLLECT ALL WEAPONS FROM PRIVATE HANDS

TEXT.P: Australia has failed to collect all the 1.5 million weapons across the country at a cost of US$333 million because nearly 60 percent of the semiautomatic and automatic guns remain in the private hands following the world's largest single massacre in 1995.

A 28-year-old Australian stunned the world by killing 35 people at a scenic spot of Port Arthur, Tasmania, in that year. The massacre prompted Prime Minister John Howard to buy back all the 1.5 million semiautomatic and automatic weapons from private hands, that resulted in strong protests from gun associations and farmers.
During the amnesty period from July 1996 to September 1997, only 643,000, or less than 43 percent of the total 1.5 million firearms, were collected by the government at a cost of US$200 million.
In New South Wales, only 155,285 guns were handed to the government, failing the target of 450,000.
Other states and territories in Australia also failed to achieve the target in the collection of firearms.

Only Western Australia saw the collection of more firearms than had been estimated at 47,218 against the targeted 43,000 and the Australian Capital Territory at 4,910 against a target of 4,500, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
The ban on semiautomatic and automatic weapons caused Australia's firearms imports to fall sharply.
Between July 1997 and March 1998, a total of 20,493 rifles and shotguns valued at US$6 million were imported, down 32 percent from the same period a year earlier.
After the massacre, the Australian government allowed people to own only shotguns and rifles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN -- ASIA'S IMPROBABLE NEW STRONGMAN

TEXT.P: "Taiwan is the most dynamic and prosperous yet relatively unknown economy in the world," according to a story which appeared in the Sunday business edition of The Los Angeles Times written by senior economics editor James Flanigan.

Flanigan described Taiwan's economy as a surprising achievement. He indicated that Taiwanese businesses have at least US$37 billion and perhaps as much as US$70 billion invested in the financially troubled countries of Southeast Asia.

But Taiwan isn't waiting for the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to help those countries. Taiwan cannot belong to the IMF because mainland China objects to any suggestion of Taiwan's being a sovereign nation. So Taiwan banks, with the encouragement of their central bank, are supporting Taiwanese company affiliates in Southeast Asia with loans in this tense period. Thus they are helping start the recovery process by financing production for export.

Flanigan also traced Taiwan's development, describing Taiwan is an island country of 21.5 million descendants of Chinese immigrants who settled here over the last four centuries -- including the Chinese Nationalists who "retreated" to Taiwan in 1949 after the communists occupied the mainland.

The Beijing regime from time to time has made the Taipei government public enemy number one. Yet Taiwan is one of mainland China's chief benefactors, with direct investment in plants and equipment totaling at least US$35 billion and probably more than US$60 billion -- the varying estimates being caused by unreported investments in factories and real estate projects on the mainland. Taiwan also buys more than US$20 billion-worth of mainland China's exports every year.

Taiwan's textile manufacturers have long used the mainland to produce garments and shoes. Now Taiwan's high-tech industries are beginning to use the mainland to manufacture integrated circuit boards and other components. Taiwan's computer giant Acer is even planning to develop software in Shanghai.
Taiwan's economy of US$284 billion in annual output of goods and services depends on foreign trade for more than 75 percent of its activity.

And the Asian crisis is hurting. Taiwan's exports to South Korea are down 50 percent, and exports to Japan are down more than 40 percent. Yet Taiwan's economy will grow 6 percent this year, slower than last year's 8 percent, but still quite healthy.
Why so robust? Because more than a third of Taiwan's output these days is in high-tech goods that keep finding markets in North and South America, mainland China and Europe.

Taiwan's high-tech industry is unparalleled in Asia, greater than that of any other country, including Japan. Pursuing high-tech investment, Taiwan's government started work 16 years ago on Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in the north of the island, where semiconductor and computer component firms can operate at low cost.

The park now has almost 300 companies, many of them started by Taiwan expatriates who returned from corporate jobs in the US for the chance to run their own companies. The companies in Hsinchu represent more than US$10 billion in aggregate investment, 90 percent of it Taiwanese and raised in the country's stock exchange and unlisted markets, which have launched more than one million small- and medium-sized companies.
However, perhaps the greatest factor in Taiwan's development has been education.

"About 15 years ago, when our appliance and textile industries were moving production overseas, we saw that we would have to move to high-tech industries, and for that we needed to stress education," says Finance Minister Paul Chiu.

Taiwan spends 15 percent of its national budget on education at the university level, and county governments spend more than 50 percent on primary and secondary education. more than 250,000 Taiwan residents graduate from college every year, and tens of thousands go to the US to pursue graduate studies.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRACKDOWN ON ILLEGAL STOCK TRADING LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Liao Chen-hao confirmed on Monday that the Investigation Bureau has targeted certain private individuals and companies in a move to crack down on illegal stock trading activities.

Liao said that the crackdown campaign has already been launched, adding that recent investigations show that illegal behind-the-scenes manipulation of stock prices, which used to be the province of large-scale organized criminal gangs, now involves individual shareholders and even some listed companies.

The justice minister added that he recently held a meeting with businessmen based in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, home to 178 listed companies, in an effort to thrash out effective measures to stem illegal stock trading.
The justice minister declined to reveal which individuals or companies have been targeted by prosecution authorities, citing the need to protect the investigation from outside interference.

However, local newspapers reported on Monday that the Investigation Bureau has been actively investigating the Core Pacific Group and the Taiwan Pineapple Corporation for the two companies' alleged roles in a variety of illegal stock trading activities.

The reports also said that "Master" Hsu Hung-ming, and "Master" Lee Cheng-lu, self-appointed stock market analysts who have built up loyal followings through their popular cable television shows and who have been accused of trading on the stock market using illegal means, have also been targeted by the prosecution authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES JAPANESE REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Monday received Japanese Representative Nakayama Masaaki and expressed his country's gratitude for the Japanese Diet member's long support for the Republic of China.

Masaaki and his wife, accompanied by Vice Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou, and Lin Chin-ching, president of the Association of East Asian Relations, were paying a courtesy call on the president at the Presidential Office.

Lee told his guests that although the Republic of China currently has no formal diplomatic ties with Japan, both countries have enjoyed for many years a close cooperative relationship in the fields of economy, trade and culture.

The president expressed his belief that through exchanges and contacts between government representatives and private citizens of both sides, relations between the two countries will continue to improve.

Masaaki, who was openly opposed to the establishment of diplomatic ties between Japan and mainland China in 1972, gave high praise to Lee for his efforts in democratic reform and pledged to continue to contribute to the promotion of friendship between Japan and the Republic of China.

Masaaki, who was openly opposed to the establishment of diplomatic ties between Japan and mainland China in 1972, gave high praise to Lee for his efforts in democratic reform and pledged to continue to contribute to the promotion of friendship between Japan and the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DEVOTED TO CROSS-STRAIT CULTURAL EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: With subsidization from the "Fund for China's Development," the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has invited 80 mainland Chinese experts and scholars to give lectures or conduct research in Taiwan since 1994, a latest official report shows.
The MAC, which set up the fund four years ago to help promote the cross-strait cultural exchanges, was reporting on the fund's current status.

The report shows during the 1994-1998 period, 50 Taiwan scholars have also visited mainland China with help from the development fund, while 48 graduates from around the island have received aid allowing them to conduct research there.

In addition to the personnel exchanges, the fund, which is aimed at promoting the development of Chinese societies, has also been used to finance various publications and studies on cross-strait relations.
The MAC said that in addition to the official exchanges, private activities in the cultural sector have also received support from the fund.

From January 1994 to February of this year, 205 proposals from Taiwan's private institutes were granted government subsidies, the MAC noted, adding that this is an example of Taiwan's goodwill and sincerity in promoting exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALGERIA PUSHES WTO MEMBERSHIP BID

TEXT.P: Algeria has finally held its first formal meeting to push its bid for World Trade Organization (WTO) membership, some 11 years after forming a working party to handle accession, according to reports of the Geneva-based world trade body Monday.
Algeria's working party met for the first time at the WTO's Geneva headquarters last week.
The group was originally formed in 1987, but negotiators did not hand over a "memorandum" to the WTO outlining the country's trade policies until 1996.
Algerian Trade Minister Bakhti Belaib, arguing the case for Algeria's membership at the meeting, outlined the package of economic reforms adopted by his government.
But he also requested that entry be on developing country terms, the WTO report said.

Since 1994, Algeria has lowered inflation, improved its budgetary balance and lifted constraints on external trade. Import restrictions have been abolished, some monopolies disbanded and privatized, and a competition law enforced.

However, Algeria -- where violence over the past six years, mainly by armed Islamic gangs, has claimed an estimated 80,000 lives -- has also been at the mercy of falling energy prices. Algeria's main export is crude oil.
Economic growth has averaged 0.4 percent a year while population growth has soared. Moreover, Algeria imports fully two-thirds of its food needs.
Algeria's application has won support from other Arab countries, notably Tunisia, Egypt, Turkey and Qatar.
The US delegation noted that negotiations in the WTO should have a positive impact on Algeria's trade regime.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO SOLVE PROBLEM OF LACK OF SAND, STONE

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Monday that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is planning to import sand and initiate digging on land provided by the Taiwan Sugar Corp. to solve the island's need for sand and stone.
He made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in answer to questions from legislators from both the ruling Kuomintang and opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

The lawmakers -- including Hsinchu County Legislator Cheng Yung-chin, Pingtung County Legislator Lin Kuo-lung, Tainan County Legislator Shih Tai-sheng, Hsinchu City Legislator Ko Chien-min, and Taipei City Legislators Yeh Chu-lan and Hsiao Yu-cheng -- expressed concern over illegal mining of riverbed material.
They suggested that the government urgently address the problem of the lack of sufficient sand and stone to meet the needs of future construction projects, including the high speed rail system.

After the MOEA noticed illegal digging had bared the foundations of some bridges and had thus threatened public safety, the ministry put further limits on digging in riverbeds, Wang replied, adding that it had also initiated plans to dig on land and to import more sand to meet domestic demand.
At present, Taiwan imports about 100,000 tons of sand per year.

Hsiao pointed that although the Chinese mainland had agreed to supply Taiwan with more than 120 million tons of sand and stone a year, the island's port facilities are not up to the job and the problem remains unsolved. She also asked how many areas are available in Taiwan for the collecting of stone and sand.

The MOEA has identified more than 10 places on the island suitable for digging, including land in southern Taiwan provided by Taiwan Sugar. The projects, however, are still being evaluated for their potential environmental impact and discussed with local residents.
Both Cheng and Ko suggested that Taiwan construct port facilities that can handle sand imports as soon as possible to solve the problem and that the MOEA should supervise this.

In his reply, Wang said that in order to meet the needs for sand and environmental preservation simultaneously, the MOEA will invite the Council of Agriculture, Environmental Protection Administration and other related government agencies to study the measures.
He added that the MOEA also plans to expand port facilities to allow for more imports of sand.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREAT CHINA FLIGHT ARSONIST INDICTED

TEXT.P: The man who attempted to set fire to a domestic flight last month was indicted on Monday on charges of attempted homicide and endangering aviation security, with the prosecutor calling for a seven-year prison term.

The offender, identified as 41-year-old Lin Chin-wen from Taipei County, was a passenger on March 23 on Great China Airlines flight No. 9565 from Taipei, northern Taiwan, to Chaiyi in the south of the island.
Around fifteen minutes after takeoff, Lin splashed two bottles of diesel fuel on the seats of the twin-propeller Dash-8 aircraft, which carried 16 passengers and four crew.

Before he could ignite the liquid, however, he was subdued by a flight attendant and several passengers. Lin, who is partially disabled, was arrested after the airplane made an emergency landing at Taichung Airport in central Taiwan.
Lin claimed that he had been attempting suicide because he could no longer endure being handicapped.

After interrogating Lin for one month, a Taichung prosecutor on Monday revealed the indictments and asked that the attempted arsonist be given seven years in prison for his disregard for the safety of others.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO MAINLAND DECLINE

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said on Monday that due to the continuing Asian financial turmoil, exports of Taiwan products to the Chinese mainland declined during January and February.

The BOFT estimated that the two-way trade across the Taiwan Strait during the first two months of this year totaled US$3.05 billion, a decrease of 4 percent in comparison to the same period last year.

Of the total, exports of Taiwan products to the mainland amounted to US$2.45 billion, a drop of 6.4 percent compared with the corresponding period of last year, while imports from the mainland reached US$596 million, an increase of 6.6 percent.
The BOFT attributed the decrease of Taiwan products to the other side of the strait to low-price competition from Southeast Asian products, as well as declining demand in the mainland market.

The main export items to the mainland from Taiwan during the two-month period were electronic and electrical appliances and accessories, machinery equipment and accessories, plastics and plastic products, man-made fiber, and steel products. These items were worth US$1.33 billion and accounted for 54.6 percent of the island's total exports to the mainland.

Taiwan exported US$143 million in steel to the mainland in January and February, a decrease of 3.9 percent in comparison with the same period last year, and US$342 million in machinery equipment and accessories, an increase of 51.5 percent.

Meanwhile, plastics and plastic products lost ground, plunging 47.1 percent, followed by textile products at 33.7 percent, electrical appliances and accessories at 21.9 percent, and raw hides at 13.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT ON REPORT TAIWAN COVERED BY US-JAPAN GUIDELINES: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) refused to comment on a Japanese news report that the Taiwan Strait is to be listed as being covered by the Guidelines for Japan-US Defense Cooperation.

The Yomiuri Shimbun reported on Monday that the Japanese government has decided to give a geographic definition of the "areas surrounding Japan" covered in the revised Guidelines for Japan-US Defense Cooperation.

The Japanese daily said that Tokyo will submit legislation related to the US-Japan defense guidelines that specifies the areas covered to be "the Far East" and "areas surrounding the Far East," which would include the Taiwan Strait, the Korean Peninsula and the disputed Spratly Islands.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said that according to the US-Japan Defense Guidelines, Washington and Tokyo would take joint action to respond to situations in areas surrounding Japan that have an important influence on Japan's peace and security.
Wu said that the guidelines, however, fail to give a clear geographic references or limits as part of efforts not to provoke neighboring countries, especially mainland China.

Though the Japanese government reportedly has decided to define the scope of "areas surrounding Japan" in its legislation, the legislation has not been submitted to or passed by the Japanese Diet, he noted, adding that the MOFA is not in a position at present to comment on the news report.

The Yomiuri Shimbun said that Tokyo and Washington expanded the scope of the guidelines' application when revising the Japan-US defense pact last year. The guidelines require the United States and Japan to take joint action when potential aggression or an emergency situation occurs in "areas surrounding Japan."
Tokyo is thus allowed to give logistical support to Washington in regional crises, including the use of Japanese minesweepers in international waters.

But in order not to provoke opposition to the expansion in the military cooperation, the two sides have avoided mention in the guidelines of any specific areas or where armed aggression might come from; instead, the scope is described only by the vague phrase "situations in areas surrounding Japan."
Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto has carefully asserted that it is hard to provide a purely geographical definition of the phrase describing the guidelines' scope.
But critics in the ruling and opposition parties have warned that the US military could exploit the vague wording for an unlimited expansion of support by Japan's Self Defense Forces, the daily said.

The Yomiuri Shimbun, quoting government sources, said that the Japanese government thus decided to define "areas surrounding Japan" in legislation related to the new guidelines, which will be submitted to the Japanese Diet for review on Tuesday.

The Japanese government's position is that the guidelines would cover action taken by US forces to deal with contingencies as far away as "the Far East and its periphery," the daily said, pointing out that this covers part of the Russian island of Sakhalin, the entire Korean Peninsula and the Taiwan Strait.

The periphery also includes Hong Kong, the Philippines, Micronesia and the Spratly Islands, located in the South China Sea. The Malacca Strait, Indonesia, Vietnam, the Middle East and the Indian Ocean remain outside the area, the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA REQUESTS WORKWEEK REDUCTION FROM 48 HOURS TO 44 HOURS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has agreed to shorten the maximum required workweek from the current 48 hours to 44 hours as part of efforts to upgrade the welfare of workers in Taiwan.
A CLA official confirmed on Monday that the council has undertaken the amendment of the Labor Standards Law in order to reduce the maximum to 44 hours.

The official said that though labor unions have demanded a 40-hour workweek, the CLA insists on step-by-step reductions. A sudden cut to 40 hours would have too much impact on enterprises and on national productivity, he added.

If the amendment passes the Legislative Yuan, an estimated 60 percent of the enterprises around the island will have to reduce the workweek they require of their employees. If the workweek were cut to 40 hours, up to 90 percent of business or industry operators would be affected.

The official said that currently 46.2 percent of employees in Taiwan have a 48-hour workweek, while 30.6 percent of workers are on the job 44 hours per week. Compared with 1995, the amount of those with a 48-hour workweek posted a 2.7 percent decrease, while the latter figure fell by 1.7 percent.
Around 53 percent of workers would benefit from a 44-hour workweek. If the limit were moved down to 40 hours, up to 90 percent of workers would have more leisure time.

Taiwan's workers averaged 2,324 hours of work in 1996, lower than 1991's 2,363 hours. The island's 1996 level is about 95 percent of those of South Korea and Singapore and almost the same as Hong Kong's.

Taiwan workers, however, are on the job many more hours than their counterparts in other advanced economies. Taiwan's yearly working hours are 20 percent higher than in Japan and 30 percent higher than in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW RETURNS FROM TRIP TO MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Monday that he believes his visit to Malaysia has been helpful in promoting substantial relations between Taiwan and Malaysia.

Siew, who made the remark Monday night in a press conference held following his return to Taipei from the 3-day "private trip," said that during his visit there, he met with Malaysian political and business heavyweights as well as Taiwan businessmen, and that this helped him gain a better understanding of the economic situation in Malaysia and in other Southeast Asian countries.

Siew said that the financial crisis in Southeast Asia has subsided but is not over completely. He said Malaysia's economic fundamentals give the country hope of attracting more foreign investment that will help the country recover from its financial and economic troubles.

Siew noted that Taiwan and Malaysia have maintained close trade and economic relations, as Taiwan is Malaysia's fourth largest trading partner and second largest investor. Taipei and Kuala Lumpur both hope that such close ties can be further upgraded, he said.

In addition, Siew said that at a seminar with Taiwan businessmen based in Malaysia, the participants recommended the Southeast Asian country as a good investment place with a highly efficient government, expressing the hope that Taiwan businessmen won't halt their investment there due to the financial crisis.

The premier made it clear that Taipei encourages Taiwan businessmen to invest in Southeast Asia, adding that if Taiwan businessmen neglect good investment opportunities abroad, they are running counter to the trend of the internationalization of enterprises.
Siew noted that Taiwan could not be totally unscathed by the financial crisis that swept Southeast Asia, pointing out that the effect of the turmoil has been felt in Taiwan's exports to the region.
The Republic of China should create mutually beneficial and interdependent relations with other countries in the area, he said.

There's no political motive behind Taipei proposing the exchange of visits of officials from the ROC and Southeast Asian countries, he stressed, nor behind its proposals for regional financial cooperation.

Siew, who assumed the post of premier last September, reiterated in the press conference the importance of "pragmatic diplomacy," saying that the ROC needs to increase its presence in the international community in order to continue to exist and develop.

Siew vowed to make more overseas visits as part of efforts to upgrade the country's international profile despite possible obstruction from Beijing, adding, "If we don't fight for our own status, it is impossible that any other country in the international community would offer us any assistance."
This was Siew's third overseas trip this year, following visits to the Philippines and Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND URGED TO COOPERATE IN SOUTHEAST ASIAN AID PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh on Tuesday urged Beijing to respond to Taipei's overtures for a concerted move with Southeast Asian countries to help stabilize the financial situation in the Asia-Pacific region.
Chang made the request at a seminar sponsored by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, a leading think tank in Taiwan.

He said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, in line with a resolution made by a crisis task force under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, should convene a financial meeting with Southeast Asian states as soon as possible to discuss the issuance of bonds to help countries in the region through the current difficulties.

The MAC head, who is in charge of charting Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, urged Beijing to forswear its politically motivated way of thinking, saying cross-strait efforts to fight the financial crisis will lay a foundation for future cooperation between the two sides.

As to whether Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China and chairman of the semiofficial Straits Exchange Foundation which is authorized by the government to handle exchanges with the mainland in the absence of formal contacts, will be able to make a much anticipated trip to the mainland in autumn, Chang said the date for such a visit remains to be decided by the two sides.
