DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES PARAGUAY DELEGATION

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui expressed confidence Tuesday that relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay can be further strengthened.
Lee made the remark when he received a Paraguay delegation which took part in a ROC-Paraguay economic meeting at the Presidential Office.

He said the two countries can enhance their substantive relations by means of increased cooperation and exchanges in the governmental and private sectors, especially through the implementation of joint economic and trade projects.

The 10th ROC-Paraguay Economic Cooperation Conference was held in Taipei last week. ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Paraguayan Industry and Commerce Minister Atilio Fernandez co-presided over the two-day event.

Fernandez said his weeklong visit here has given him a strong realization that although Taiwan lacks natural resources, it has achieved stunning results in political and economic development by utilizing its rich pool of educated and skilled human assets.
Conversely, Fernandez said, Paraguay possesses abundant natural resources, but needs to improve its personnel training and attract more foreign investment.
He echoed Lee's words in saying trade and economic cooperation projects between Taiwan and Paraguay are concrete means of ensuring deep and long-lasting ties.
The Paraguay delegation will leave Taipei on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC INTENDS TO FORGE REGIONAL, MULTILATERAL FINANCIAL RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said Monday evening the Republic of China intends to forge regional and multilateral financial relations with Malaysia and the rest of Southeast Asia.

Speaking on his return from a visit to Malaysia, Siew stressed that it is safe to participate in cooperative financial efforts in the Southeast Asian region, and that Taiwan hopes to show the spirit of helping others under this framework.
Siew expressed that Taiwan is open to the possibilities regarding high-tech cooperation with Malaysia. Financially, Taiwan encourages regional and multilateral cooperation, he said.

Siew also defended the effectiveness of the government's "go south" policy. According to Siew, in the past few years, between 8,000 and 10,000 businesses from Taiwan have invested more than US$38 billion in the Southeast Asian region. From this perspective, it cannot be said that the "go south" policy is ineffective, he said.

Siew explained that the private sector is responsible for its own risk assessments and investment initiatives, but said the government is there to provide assistance in times of need. For example, he said, should problems with residence visas and taxes arise, the government would talk to its Malaysian counterpart and help resolve the matters.
Siew led a delegation of industry representatives along with Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu and Minister of Finance Paul Chiu to Malaysia for a low-profile three-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SET UP AVIATION SAFETY COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Taiwan plans to set up an aviation safety committee modeled on the US National Transportation Safety Board to conduct fair and independent investigations into the causes of air accidents, Oung Cheng-yi, chairman-designate of the proposed committee, said Tuesday.

But Oung said a shortage of qualified personnel will make it difficult for the committee, to be formed under the Executive Yuan, to carry out a thorough investigation of two recent air crashes, one involving China Airlines which left 202 persons dead in February and one involving Formosa Airlines which killed 13 in March.

Oung made the remarks as the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) sent the black box of the Formosa Airlines plane to the United States for analysis. The results are expected by Friday at the earliest.

Oung said in a seminar on the upgrading of flight safety that after the official inauguration of the committee next month, members will have to spend at least three months learning procedural techniques before beginning to draft a set of principles to guide future investigations into air accidents.
He said the committee will seek cooperation with similar bodies in other nations, solicit foreign experts to assist in training and establish a standard procedure for handling air accidents.

Oung noted that although Taiwan has better civil aviation facilities as well as more qualified maintenance and technical personnel than do most underdeveloped countries, Taiwan's airliners have comparatively higher accident rates.
Oung attributed the bad record of aviation safety to a lack of serious-mindedness in the national work ethic.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE NAVY SHIPS TO MAKE FIRST VISIT TO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese navy is scheduled to make its first ever visit to Australia from May 4 to 9, signaling improved defense relations between Beijing and Canberra.

Gary Klintworth, visiting fellow at the Department of International Relations at the Australian National University, said one of the three mainland vessels making the port call will be a recently launched multipurpose replenishment ship, weighing 37,000 tons when fully loaded. The same vessel went to Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, and the US West Coast in March 1997.
The other two are among mainland China's most modern warships, a pair of 4,800-ton Luhu-class guided missile destroyers launched in 1996.
The three ships will visit Sydney and will be open for public display.
Klintworth said the ships will be the first military vessels to come to Australia from the Chinese mainland since Canberra switched its diplomatic ties to Beijing from Taipei in 1972.
Klintworth said the mainland Chinese navy is steadily expanding its horizons, sailing further and for longer periods of time than at any time in recent history.
He said Beijing strategists have made do with a navy that is numerically large but technologically dated.

"Furthermore, the number of warships and submarines possessed by China has been in decline in recent years. The fact is that China has fewer modern surface warships than Japan, Taiwan or Australia. It has only a handful of operational submarines and nothing to match the number or quality of Australia's Collins-class submarines when they become operational," he said.

"Besides, China warships, including those coming to Australia, have already been thoroughly inspected by regional naval intelligence specialists, including the Taiwanese, and all of them agree that the Chinese navy is not a potent threat to the regional arms balance," he added.

Klintworth said: "The Chinese navy's visit to Sydney is a symbol of the new defense relationship that now exists between China and Australia. It augurs well for increased stability and security in the Asia-Pacific region."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION CONCERNED ABOUT WATERFRONT DISPUTE IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Republic of China attending an energy and mineral conference in Canberra has raised concern over the waterfront dispute in Australia, saying it could disrupt Taiwan's trade with this country.

In an interview with the CNA Tuesday morning, Dr. Chen Chao-yih, secretary-general of the Energy Commission of the ROC Economics Ministry, said the Taiwan delegation, led by Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming, had raised the issue of the waterfront dispute in major Australian ports Monday at the 5th Australia-Taiwan Energy and Minerals Consultations meeting.

"We raised the question because Taiwan is a major importer of energy and mineral products from Australia. We are concerned that the dispute could disrupt delivery of our exports of manufactured products, especially our imports from Australia," he said.

He said the Australian delegates offered assurances that their government would try its best to resolve the current waterfront battle between the federal government, Patrick Stevedores Ltd. and the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA).

The dispute was triggered by Patrick's sacking of all 2,000 of its unionized workers about two weeks ago. The MUA, supported by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and other union groups, staged a series of protests, blocking both export and import cargo movements in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide and ports in Tasmania.
The waterfront war is still on now.
Chen said Australia is the largest supplier of coal to Taiwan, shipping about 15 million tons last year, with the figure expected to increase in the future, he said.
He said the imports are made by Taiwan Power Company, China Steel Corp. and other private power firms in Taiwan.
Australia is also a major supplier of iron ore to Taiwan along with other mineral products.

The waterfront dispute could worsen if a new battle erupts between unionized workers and another bigger stevedoring firm -- P&O Ports, which handles about 55 percent of containerized cargo in major ports across Australia.
Patrick is the second largest stevedoring firm with its handling capacity of about 40 percent.

P&O is expected to renegotiate its work practices with its unionized workers in a bid to improve the handling volume of the containerized cargo. If the workers fail to improve their productivity, which is now at an average rate of 18.5 TEUs (twenty foot equivalent units) per hour, well below the world's standard of 25 TEUs per hour, a new labor-management battle could erupt. That conflict would be even bigger than the current war between Patrick and the MUA, analysts said.

Chen said the ROC delegation was not only concerned about Taiwan's imports of energy and mineral products from Australia, but also worried about Taiwan's exports of manufactured goods, including computers and components, and sundry items, to Australia.
Last year, two-way trade between Australia and Taiwan totaled about US$4.2 billion and the figure is expected to increase steadily in coming years, trade officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN PM GREETED BY CASTRO AT HAVANA

TEXT.P: Fidel Castro, Cuba's long-time dictator, greeted Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien at a new Havana airport Sunday evening as the Canadian leader began a two-day visit.
The visit was the first by a Canadian prime minister in more than 20 years.

Chretien flew into Havana's new international airport, which was built with Canadian financial assistance. The two leaders were supposed to deliver opening remarks about the airport, but Castro seemed to go off script.

In a speech televised live in Canada and the United States, Castro criticized the United States trade embargo against Cuba, comparing it to an act of war and a "hegemonic" genocide against his people. He accused the United States of trying to impose its will on the Cubans.
A Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) journalist watching the airport scene said Chretien turned his head away from his host while Castro blasted America. The TV screen was focusing on Castro.
When Chretien spoke, he steered clear of controversy in his comments, except for a vague mention of human rights and increased democracy in Latin America.
Chretien's speech largely focused on bilateral relations, which began in the 19th century and were formalized in 1945.

"Mr. President, through good times and bad, our two countries have always chosen dialogue over confrontation, engagement over isolation, exchange over estrangement. And we have always done this in an atmosphere of mutual respect for each other's independence and sovereignty," Chretien said.
Following his speech, he was invited to cut the ribbon for the airport. He gave a piece of the ribbon to Castro, keeping one for himself.

The visit angered some American politicians, who considered it a show of support for the communist state. But back home, a CBC call-in program showed most Canadians support the Chretien move, mainly because of dislike for America's high-handed policy and a feeling that engagement is better than confrontation.

Chretien's "respect for Cuban independence" has had an immediate benefit for his country: He was expected to announce a deal Monday that will see Cuba agreeing to pay a Canadian insurance company millions of dollars in compensation.
Six Canadian insurance companies had their assets seized and their accounts frozen after Castro took power in 1959. Since then, the Canadian government has been fighting to get that money back.
Cuba now has agreed to paid back C$12 million in compensation to one of the companies.

Chretien's trip was being billed as a working visit with trade high on the agenda. Canada is a leading investor in Cuba with extensive interests in mining and oil production, as well as in the tourism industry.

The Canadian prime minister will spend less than 48 hours on the Caribbean island. He is expected to meet at least three times with the Cuban president, including a "working dinner" on Monday. Castro is known for making lengthy speeches on such occasions.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWTH RATE OF POPULATION IN TAIWAN KEPT BELOW 1 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The trends of getting married later in life and having smaller families have kept the growth rate of Taiwan's population below one percent for the last 14 years, a family planning official said on Tuesday.
Chang Ming-cheng, director of the Taiwan Province Family Planning Institute, made the remarks when fielding legislators' questions in the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
Chang said that the average age of marriage for both men and women has become higher in recent years, rising to an average of 28 for women and 31 for men.

In addition, each family now has an average of 1.7 children, with the number of births in Taiwan over the past 14 years being about 320,000 and the number of natural deaths about 120,000. The growth rate of the population has been kept under 1 percent.
In view of the situation, Chang said a new family planning policy is needed, which will promote earlier marriages, sexual awareness and reasonable numbers of children.

Assemblywoman Yang Chung-ying of the ruling Kuomintang noted that many Taiwan men go to mainland China and Southeast Asia in search of brides, and asked for statistics on the ratio of men and women in the Taiwan area.
Yang also questioned if the practice of marrying abroad will affect the quality of the local society.

Chang said that the ratio of men and women in Taiwan was 108-to-100 among births, but the ratio evens out at 100-to-100 among 50-year-olds. In the over-50 age group, women outnumber men. But in the over-60 age group, there are more men than women.

Thus, Chang said, the overall ratio of men to women in Taiwan is 105-to-100. He added that, as foreign brides from the mainland and Southeast are often members of the lower or lower-middle class, there are fears their increased numbers could affect local society in the long run.

DOC.HEADLINE: OBSERVATORY TO SHED LIGHT ON MYSTERIES OF NEUTRINOS, UNIVERSE

TEXT.P: An underground observatory able to trap minute particles from outer space will be unveiled in Ontario on Wednesday, the Canadian Press (CP) reported.

Tiny balls of light snagged in the Sudbury Neutrino Observatory, buried deep within a nickel mine, may finally answer whether neutrinos make up most of the mysterious dark matter of the universe, the CP said.
Neutrinos, along with electrons and quarks, are considered the building blocks of nature. Zillions of them produced in the core of the sun shoot through everything and everyone on Earth each second.

But neutrinos are so tiny they can pass through virtually anything. "One neutrino in a person's lifetime may stop in their body and they won't even notice -- they're completely outside people's normal experience," the CP quoted Art McDonald, a Queen's University physics professor heading the US$50 million observatory.
Building a detector sensitive enough to count the particles took more than five years and involved scientists and engineers from the United States and Britain.

"It's a fascinating project and the whole technical difficulty of doing it and building it is an amazing story in itself," commented Michael Smith, president of the Canadian Science Writers Association in Toronto.

The story so intrigued renowned physicist Stephen Hawking that he requested a private tour of the observatory painstakingly assembled inside a 10-story cavity more 2,000 meters below the Earth's surface.
Hawking, 56, a Cambridge University professor, gained international acclaim a few years ago when his book "A Brief History of Time" hit the bestseller lists.
About 200 scientists from around the world are expected to join another 25 working at the site for the observatory's opening Wednesday. The event will also be carried live in an Internet webcast.
Canada has some real natural advantages in the joint project because of the availability of a mine deep enough to block the cosmic rays that can mask the faint neutrino signals.

Canada's ready supply of heavy water used in its nuclear reactor industry gave it another leg up on other sites. The Sudbury project is the first deep-Earth observatory to use heavy water to detect neutrinos.
Scientists say the new approach will allow them to count more of the elusive particles and, for the first time, the various types.

During the next two months, 1,000 tons of heavy water on loan from the Ontario Hydro power company will be carried in small tanks down a mine elevator and poured into the main observatory sphere. The sphere, reassembled piece by piece underground, will be floated in another container filled with purified water.

About once an hour, scientists expect a neutrino passing through the heavy water will collide with an atom and emit a tiny flash of light. These sparks will be caught and analyzed by 10,000 computerized light detectors surrounding the sphere.
At that rate, McDonald expects it will take about two years to get enough information to shed some light on the mystery of dark matter.
If the data can prove neutrinos have mass, the sheer number of them could explain the age-old puzzle of why the universe does not collapse upon itself, according to Smith.
It may also tell scientists whether neutrinos have enough impact to slow or stop the expansion of the universe that began with the Big Bang.
And that could help scientists predict how many billions of years it will take for the universe to end.
"I tell people I'm studying how the sun works, the future evolution of the universe and the most microscopic parts of the universe -- all at the same time," McDonald said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AREAS NEAR BEIJING SAID SITES OF ILLEGAL LABOR CAMPS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 28 (CNA) (By Huang Kuan-chun and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The Beijing Municipal Public Security Bureau has set up illegal labor reform camps to detain some of those without a registered local residence who roam Beijing, look for part-time work there or even just visit the city, the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China charged on Monday.

Zhang Jincheng, a dissident who claims to have just escaped from an illegal labor camp outside Beijing, was quoted by the information center as saying that he was tailed and arrested by Beijing's public security servicemen after he paid a visit to Xu Wenli, a dissident in Beijing, and Wei Xiaotao, the younger brother of prominent dissident Wei Jingsheng, on April 14.
He said that before being sent to a vacation resort construction site in Changping County, suburban Beijing, he had been beaten and questioned by six public security servicemen for an entire day.

That construction site is an illegal labor reform camp, according to Zhang. More than a hundred people are detained there, most of whom were visiting Beijing, seeking a job, or just loafing about, but none of whom were registered in a local domicile, he said. They were put into the construction site to do heavy labor without any payment, having been arrested but then never allowed to go through other legal procedures, he charged.

There are many such camps in Changping County, Zhang said, citing a quarry, sand-sifting sites and chemical fertilizer plants. He said the public security police told him that after six months of forced labor, he would be sent back to his home in Anhui Province.
Zhang, however, said he escaped from the camp on April 24 because of its intolerable working conditions.

Zhang, 32, had been working as a member of the teaching staff of a Communist Party school in Anhui and was preparing a thesis about democratic systems. He visited dissidents around mainland China as part of his thesis research, he said.

Depriving people of freedom and putting them in labor camps without legal due process is obviously against the constitution of mainland China and a serious violation of civil rights, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and then moved up on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 36.95 points to close at 8,434.67.
Dealers said the market was affected by a sharp drop on Wall Street at the opening but that the index started to bounce back following continued buying of electronics shares at mid-session.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 8,327.46 and closed at the day's high of 8,434.67.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 330 to 109, with 51 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.79 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$101.49 billion (US$3.08 billion), increasing from the previous trading session, which saw 1.74 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$96.65 billion.

Five of the eight major categories lost ground, with construction shares moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 1.0 percent, bank and insurance issues at 0.9 percent, textile shares at 0.8 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.2 percent.
Meanwhile, pulp and paper issues registered a gain of 1.6 percent, while the cement category rose 0.5 percent and electrical stocks edged up 0.1 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Tuesday's trading were Ever Fortune Industries, Mosel Vitelic Inc., ASE, Kuo Feng Corp., Compal Electronic Inc., ACER, Mustek Systems Inc., Winbond Electronics Corp., Mitac International Corp. and United Micro Electronics.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEADER ATTRACTS AUSSIE MEDIA ATTENTION OVER AUSTRALIAN TRIP

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), has attracted Australian media attention over his visit to Australia.

The Australian and The Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday ran separate interviews with Hsu, who arrived in Sydney on Monday and will go to Canberra Tuesday night at the invitation of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taiwan.

In his interview with The Australian, Hsu urged Australia to be more proactive in its dealings with the politically isolated state, claiming mainland China is now in a "more realistic" mood about the international community's view of Taiwan.
Hsu said Australia adheres to a "one-China policy" more strictly than the United States.
"This is understandable, but the point is that besides the one-China policy, a lot of other things can be developed in our relationship," Hsu said.
Hsu said that mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji is a very pragmatic man.
"We believe Zhu is in favor of talks. He wants to see an improvement in cross-strait relations," he told The Australian.

In another interview, Hsu told the Sydney Morning Herald that since Taiwan is already independent in practice there is no need to declare independence. "We won't do that," he said. The DPP, unlike the ruling Kuomintang, is associated with pro-independence sentiment.
The daily said Hsu's remarks will be reassuring to Asia's big powers.
He also addressed relations between Taipei and Washington.

He said that "of course" the United States will continue to adhere to the Taiwan Relations Act. Should Taiwan "provoke" mainland China with a declaration of independence, however, "then things would be different," he said, declaring that Washington has "no obligation" to defend the island in such a case.

Hsu is expected to be a major player in the Republic of China's 2000 presidential election, in which the Kuomintang may face the first serious challenge to its control of the presidency in its 53 years of unbroken rule of the island, the daily reported.
All four major Chinese language newspapers in Sydney also ran front-page banner headlines to announce Hsu and his 11-member delegation's visit to the Down Under.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIES URGED TO USE ROC OPERATIONS CENTERS FOR ASIA-PAC MART

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has urged Australian companies to set up regional headquarters in Taiwan to boost their trade in the Asia-Pacific region.

In the fifth annual meeting of the ROC-Australia Joint Energy and Minerals Trade, Investment and Cooperation Consultations, ROC Vice Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Australian enterprises can use Taiwan as their base to expand their exports in the Asia-Pacific region.

Yiin, the leader of the 15-member ROC delegation to the conference, told his audience, which included Australian government officials and business leaders, that Taiwan has established regional operations centers for manufacturing, sea and air transportation, finance, telecommunications, and media.

He said Taiwan is located in "an advantageous strategic position among the countries of the Asia-Pacific region, and this makes it an ideal location to serve as a cargo and passenger transshipment center."
Yiin said Australia and Taiwan are complimentary, with Taiwan having a marketing network and sufficient cash while Australia is rich in natural resources.
He urged Australia to further broaden the scope of cooperation between Taipei and Canberra so that both can promote mutual prosperity.
"I am confident that we will create even brighter economic prospects through further cooperation in the future," he said.
He said Australia has been Taiwan's No. 1 coal supplier, selling about 15 million tonnes of coal in 1997 alone, which accounted for 42 percent of Taiwan's total import of the mineral.

Australia also exported 8.31 million tonnes of iron ore, 800,000 tonnes of titanium concentrates, 165,000 tonnes of aluminum, 28,000 tonnes of zinc and 30,000 tonnes of lead to Taiwan during the same period.
The total mineral exports from Australia to Taiwan were worth US$727 million in 1997, Yiin said.
"All these figures indicate the close relations that exist between our two countries in energy and mineral product trade," he said.
He told the Australian delegation that the ROC government is now paying much more attention to the emission of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases.
The ROC is searching for new areas of cooperation with Australia in reducing the emission of greenhouse gases, he said.
Australia is now Taiwan's seventh largest foreign supplier. Trade between the two rose 8.7 percent to US$5.09 billion in 1997 from US$4.68 billion in 1996.
The two-day conference will discuss Taiwan's needs for energy and mineral products from Australia and give Australia a chance to introduce its energy and mineral supplies.

As more steel plants, naphtha crackers and privately-owned power plants come on line in Taiwan, Yiin said, the island's imports of coal, liquefied natural gas and other energy and mineral products from Australia will increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO RULES AGAINST INDONESIA IN CAR CASE

TEXT.P: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has issued a final ruling that Indonesia's "national car" program violates global trade rules, according to reports of the Geneva-based world trade body Tuesday.

The ruling was handed to Indonesia and the parties that have claimed victory in the case, the United States, the European Union and Japan. The verdict upholds the trio's allegations that Indonesia broke rules governing non-discrimination, subsidies and investment measures by granting tax privileges to its "national car."

"There are no surprise," the WTO report quoted a trade official whose country is involved in the dispute as saying, pointing out that an interim ruling issued in March by the WTO panel examining the file had found Jakarta at fault on those grounds.

Indonesia can appeal the decision to the WTO Appellate Body. But the WTO report said it was not sure if this would happen, given Jakarta's pledge to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in accepting a US$43 billion bail-out package that it would respect a WTO ruling.
As part of its obligations to the IMF, Indonesia promised to dismantle its national car project.

The program allowed kits produced by troubled Kia Motors of South Korea to be imported free of duty and the assembled Timor Saloons to be sold without the luxury tax attached, making them cheaper than other foreign car imports.
The firm with sole rights to import the Kia kits, PT Timor Nasional, is owned by Indonesian President Suharto's youngest son.

The final report on the ruling will be submitted to all WTO members in about two weeks. Panel reports are adopted by the WTO's Dispute Settlement Body within 60 days unless one party decides to appeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: Prompted by the rise of the Japanese yen, the New Taiwan dollar moved up NT$0.027 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday.
The NT dollar closed at 33.01 to the greenback after sliding back and forth across the 33 mark during trading, dealers said.
Interbank trading reached US$316 million.
The yen climbed against the US dollar on the Tokyo market Tuesday to close at 131.95.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS SEE SIGNS OF DEPRECIATION OF RENMINBI

TEXT.P: A number of scholars and experts in the Republic of China said on Tuesday that the deterioration of the economic situation in mainland China has become clearer and that the country's currency, the renminbi, is showing early signs of depreciation.
They made the remarks at a seminar on economic development in mainland China in 1998 which was held at the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research.

Ing Nai-ping, a professor in the Banking Department of National Chengchi University, pointed out that based on a report by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), up to the end of March this year the renminbi has depreciated by 0.1-0.2 percent.

He attributed the recession to the poor performance of the mainland's first-quarter foreign trade. During January to March this year, exports grew about 13 percent, a drastic drop from the 25 percent recorded for the same period of last year.

The IMF has even predicted that the mainland will suffer zero growth in its trade surplus for this year. In addition, the first-quarter economic growth reached only 7.2 percent, factors which are far from conducive to the maintenance of the renminbi's value.

According to Ing, the renminbi has appreciated more than 20 percent against the currencies of Southeast Asian countries in relative terms, and he noted that if the mainland intends to safeguard its economic growth, then depreciation of the renminbi of between 10 and 15 percent will be unavoidable.

Chen Wen-lang, advisor to the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, pointed out that the renminbi will play an important role in the outcome of the Asian financial turmoil. He said he believes that the negative factors, including the possibility of a trade deficit for this year, will lead to depreciation of the renminbi sooner or later.

His view was shared by Professor Hsu Chen-ming of the Economics Department of National Taiwan University, who said that the mainland authorities can easily control the exchange rate if they want to, since mainland China does not have a fully open economy. However, if the mainland cannot resist the force of a huge trade deficit and a steep reduction of foreign capital inflow, then it can use depreciation to save itself, he added.

However, since the Beijing leadership has on many occasions reiterated its decision to maintain the current foreign exchange rates, it will face strong international pressure if it fails to stick with this decision, Hsu said, predicting that the renminbi will maintain its stability at least until July, when US President Bill Clinton is expected to visit Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION ATTENDS ADB ANNUAL MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 27 (CNA) (By Maurus Young and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The head of the Republic of China's central bank, Peng Huai-nan, arrived in Geneva, Switzerland, on Monday to attend the 1998 annual committee meeting of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).
The three-day meeting opened on Wednesday in the building that serves as the United Nations' European base, with ADB Chairman Mitsuo Sato officiating.
During his stay in Geneva, Peng will join with financial and monetary leaders from Asia-Pacific countries in discussions on the Asian financial crises erupting in mid-1997.
The Manila-based ADB is the only official international organization in which the Republic of China enjoys a seat.

According to sources within the 12-member ROC delegation, during the upcoming meeting the ROC will submit a program aimed at helping the Asian countries that are suffering from the effects of the financial assault.
Under the ROC-initiated proposal, the ADB would offer guarantees enabling the economically troubled Southeast Asian countries to release government bonds.

The endorsed bonds would lure private capital that would help the nations free themselves from the troubles that the financial turmoil brought, the sources told CNA, adding that the program, if adopted, could work to stabilize the region's financial development.

In addition to Peng, the ROC delegation includes Chen Mu-tsai, vice minister of finance; Liu Yiang-hai, chief of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Swiss representative office; Huang Jui-sung, an ADB executive member; Jeffrey Koo, chairman of Chinatrust Bank; James Lo, chairman of the Bank of Taiwan; and officials from the foreign, economic and financial sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY TO LAUNCH NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION AGAINST PREMIER SIEW

TEXT.P: The New Party announced on Tuesday that it is seeking to launch a motion of no-confidence against Premier Vincent Siew to protest a government system virtually paralyzed by corruption and inefficiency.

Speaking at a news conference with major New Party figures, Hau Lung-pin, caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, said the New Party is planning to make the move not only because of the implications of illegality brought about by the exposure of Vice President Lien Chan's alleged electioneering loan to former Pingtung County Magistrate Wu Tze-yuan, but also because the New Party holds Siew responsible for the people's discontent over the performance of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) since the holding of the National Development Conference in December 1996.

Lien's alleged illegal financial links with Wu, Hau said, unveiled that KMT officials, from the top to the grassroots levels, have ignored the government's legal framework, paralyzing the nation's justice system and arousing grave public concern over the KMT's ability to run the country.

Hau slammed Siew's leadership role in the series of constitutional reforms at the National Assembly last year, and said the New Party is determined to seek support from the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in its efforts to sack Siew's administration in order to help bring the government system back within the framework of the Constitution.

Lawmaker Chou Yang-shan, also convener of the New Party's National Campaign and Development Committee, said the KMT-led constitutional reforms last year have seriously compromised the integrity of the government sector.
The current government system is a "deteriorated mixture" which has created an all-powerful president and a powerless premier, he noted.

Although the nationwide legislative election is only a few months away, Chou said he does not believe that the planned no-confidence vote against Siew will provoke political instability, as the present political situation is already entrenched in chaos.

Meanwhile, Su Huahn-dji, DPP caucus whip at the Legislative Yuan, said the DPP is also "dissatisfied" with the "Lee-Lien team," and that the party does not rule out the possibility of calling for a no-confidence vote against Siew's administration.
Su said the DPP is cautiously assessing the timing for raising a no-confidence motion, adding that the DPP and the New Party share a similar stance toward the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE TOUTS EU MODEL FOR CHINESE UNIFICATION

TEXT.P: Former ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an on Tuesday recommended the European Union (EU) formula for an ultimate unification of Taiwan and mainland China.

Chen, who ran for the ROC presidency in March 1996 but was defeated by President Lee Teng-hui, suggested that leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should perceive cross-strait relations as part of a much wider overall picture, and follow the EU formula as a framework on which the unification process could be based.
Chen, who arrived in Beijing on April 24, is currently on a weeklong visit, primarily in order to meet with a renowned Tibetan "living Buddha" to discuss Buddhism.

The crux of the prolonged cross-strait impasse lies in each side's psychological denial of the other, Chen noted, adding that as the two sides are in strong conflict with each other psychologically, they remain in actual conflict with each other.

Chen urged the two sides to set aside this hostile mentality and try to seek a niche in which cooperation can take place. "Work towards unification by replacing confrontation with cooperation," he stressed.

He said he fully supports the idea of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait jointly tackling the Southeast Asian economic crisis, and has harbored this concept ever since the regional upheaval began last year.
Chen said he believes that the two sides should cooperate on this issue, but only when the time is right.

Meanwhile, he declined to confirm or deny allegations that he intends to run for a legislative seat in elections slated for the end of this year, saying that only the present is important, and that it is not worthwhile to speculate on events which may or may not occur in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: EL SALVADORAN PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Francisco Guillermo Flores, visiting presidential hopeful of El Salvador's ruling party, on Tuesday met with ROC Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang for discussions on ways to bolster bilateral economic cooperation.

Wang said the visit by Flores, who is considered the central American country's most-favored presidential candidate, is giving a shot in the arm to the already close relations between Taiwan and El Salvador.

In June 1994, Taiwan's Lien Chan, then premier, attended the inauguration of El Salvadoran President Armando Calderon on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui, which was followed in September 1997 by a visit by the president himself.
During Lee's trip, the two governments forged an economic cooperation agreement and agreed to sign another free-trade cooperation accord.
A month later, Wang led an investment fact-finding mission to El Salvador to investigate the feasibility of developing an export processing zone in that country.
El Salvador's Vice President Enrique Borgos visited Taipei in late January this year to seek ways of further strengthening trade and economic exchanges between the two countries.

The state-owned Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) dispatched an inspection group to El Salvador in February, and the company later decided to relocate its lucrative sugar-refining and orchid cultivation operations to that country.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and El Salvador amounted to US$60.19 million in 1997, with Taiwan enjoying a disproportionate surplus of US$59.59 million, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
Currently, 18 Taiwan companies operate manufacturing plants in El Salvador with investments totaling US$36 million. Most of the investment focuses on textile and garment manufacturing.
Three new Taiwan investment projects, including a paper-processing plant and a motorbike assembly plant, are currently underway, and they are expected to go online after June this year, said Wang.

Assessing El Salvador's investment climate, the MOEA officials found it to be a two-way street -- its advantages, including a diligent and skilled workforce and relatively sounder infrastructure than neighboring countries, are almost balanced by its shortcomings, which include worrisome public order, sporadic labor strikes, and expensive, import dependent industrial raw materials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PARAGUAY AGREE ON IPR PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the Republic of Paraguay on Tuesday issued a joint statement agreeing to enhance the protection of intellectual property rights (IPR).
The joint statement was signed by Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and visiting Paraguayan Minister of Trade and Industry Atilio Fernandez.
In order to implement the agreement, both sides have appointed special groups to take charge of information exchanges as well as crackdowns on IPR infringement.
Wang pointed out that a huge haul of Taiwan-made counterfeit "Nintendo" video game products which was seized by Paraguayan customs authorities last year has drawn complaints from the United States.

He said that in order to protect IPR, the issue was discussed at the ongoing 10th ROC-Paraguayan Conference on Economic Cooperation, at which both sides agreed to enhance information exchanges and to conduct joint efforts to crack down on counterfeiting.
On Tuesday afternoon, Wang conferred an award first-class in the form of a medal on Fernandez, in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of ROC-Paraguayan economic and trade cooperation.

After the presentation ceremony, Fernandez expressed his appreciation for the assistance the Republic of China has extended to Paraguay, and pledged to continue his efforts to promote trade and economic development between the two countries. He also expressed the hope that more Taiwan businessmen will invest in Paraguay.

Fernandez and his entourage of 13 high-ranking government officials, including Dario Peralta, Gerardo Lopez, and James Spalding, arrived in Taipei on April 22 to attend the two-day conference which began on April 23.
The delegation is scheduled to leave Taipei on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PER CAPITA SPENDING ON LIQUOR & TOBACCO REACHES US$200 IN 1997

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan spent an average of NT$6,663 (US$202) per head on liquor and tobacco last year, according to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Tuesday.
The statistics specify that Taiwan's per capita consumption of tobacco reached 92 packets in 1997, up four from a year ago, with an average cost of NT$2,634 (US$79.8).
Alcohol consumption per head amounted to 37.7 liters, up 1.4 liters, with per capita expenditure reaching NT$4,029 (US$122.09).

The DGBAS statistics revealed that since Taiwan began to open its liquor and tobacco markets in 1987, sales of locally manufactured products have gradually declined. The trend can be illustrated by the fact that their market share in 1997 dropped from 76.1 percent to 67.4 percent.

Last year, 374,000 boxes of locally produced cigarettes were sold on the island, down 13.7 percent, while 10.8 million dozen bottles of Taiwan alcoholic beverages were purchased, down 11 percent, the DGBAS figures show.

Around NT$10.8 billion (US$327.27 million)-worth of cigarettes were imported to Taiwan in 1997, up 20.9 percent from the previous year. Germany, Japan, Britain and the United States were the key exporting countries.

The DGBAS statistics also indicate that NT$17 billion (US$515.2 million)-worth of liquor was imported last year, up 27.1 percent. Most of this amount was attributed to wine imports from France, which was listed as the island's largest source of the product.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC RATED 4TH-LEAST RISKY COUNTRY IN ASIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has been rated by a Hong Kong-based consultancy firm as the overall fourth-least risky investment destination in Asia, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said on Tuesday.

Singapore was listed as the least risky state in the Comparative Country Risk report published earlier this month by the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy (PERC) Ltd.. Hong Kong came second, followed by Japan.
Lagging behind the ROC in descending order were mainland China, Malaysia, South Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, India, Indonesia and Vietnam.
The report took into account each country's market size, economic dynamics and systemic socio-political risks in reaching its conclusion.

In the economic dynamics category, which measures a country's prospects for GDP (gross national product) growth, inflation, currency fluctuation, trade growth and foreign debt, Taiwan was in second place, up one niche from last year's PERC report.

The ROC advanced from sixth to third place in terms of systemic and socio-political risk, which considers discrimination against foreign investment, protectionist policy, hardware infrastructure, labor quality, legal system, protection of intellectual property rights, possible labor-management disputes and possible social unrest.
In market size category, the ROC maintained its 1997 position of fifth.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC CASHING IN ON BANGKOK BANK CAPITAL INCREMENT

TEXT.P: Several Taiwan business groups on Tuesday decided to cash in some US$100 million on a Bangkok Bank capitalization increment project, officially pitching into the financial operations of the largest commercial bank in Southeast Asia, according to sources from China Development Corp. (CDC).

CDC Chairman Liu Tai-ying, who is also incumbent chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Business Management Committee, disclosed that CDC will put up US$100 million to acquire a 10 percent stake, or 44 million shares, of an extra 440 million shares to be created by Bangkok Bank in its drive for increased capitalization.

Of the US$100 million, said Liu, US$20 million will be put up by the Tainan-based President Group, while another US$20 million will be financed by Tuntex Group, a Taiwan business conglomerate which maintains a large number of investment operations in Thailand.
The remaining US$60 million will be offered to other private investors in Taiwan to cash in on, although CDC does not exclude the possibility of absorbing the whole amount, according to Liu.
A Singaporean corporation also agreed to contribute US$100 million to acquire one-tenth of the Bangkok Bank shares to be created by the effort to raise additional capital.

In addition to business conglomerates in Taiwan, Japan and Singapore, other leading companies in Europe and the United States have also expressed keen interest in becoming shareholders of Bangkok Bank, Liu added.
The bank is currently Thailand's largest, and the largest in Southeast Asia. It maintains 499 affiliate operations in Thailand and 22 branch offices in 13 countries and areas around the world.

The Southeast Asian financial meltdown which began to batter the region in July last year has forced the gigantic bank to resort to a drive to increase its capital options to help tide it over the current difficulties.
In March, CDC acquired a 62.5 percent stake of the Bangkok First Investment & Trust Plc., marking the first merger conducted by the Taipei company in its current foray into Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO RELEASE 15 PERCENT OF ITS STOCKS BEFORE YEAR-END

TEXT.P: W.Y. Pan, president of the China Petroleum Corp. (CPC), announced on Tuesday that his company hopes to speed up its privatization plan and will release 15 percent of its stocks before the end of this year in the first stage of the plan.
He made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan while answering interpellations from lawmakers, including Yunlin County Legislator Hsu Su-po of the ruling Kuomintang.

Hsu suggested that the projected revenue from a planned release of 18 percent of the CPC stocks should be excluded from the CPC's fiscal 1999 budget since the company cannot carry out its first stage release of 15 percent of its shares in fiscal 1998 as planned.
In his reply, Pan said his company is trying to speed up its privatization program, and is hopeful that the Economic Committee of the Legislative Yuan will approve its budget.

He noted that petrochemical products produced by CPC's rival Formosan Plastics Corp. will enter the market, while liquefied natural gas and aviation fuel will be opened to free import starting in January next year, pointing out that if the privatization of CPC is held up and the company has to compete as a state-run enterprise, it will face difficulties in coping with the new market environment.

Under the privatization plan, Pan said, the CPC will release at least 50 percent of its stocks. He added that in addition to the 15 percent of shares in the first stage of the plan, the CPC will try to seek strategic investors from abroad, offering an additional 12 to 18 percent of its stocks.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEMANDS ITS FORMAL ADB NAME BACK
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 28 (CNA) (By Maurus Young and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The governor of the Republic of China's central bank on Tuesday demanded that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) change the ROC's current membership designation back to its original name.

Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Peng Huai-nan made the demand in a meeting with ADB Chairman Mitsuo Sato, who expressed his concern over the demand but gave his word that he will try to meet the demand at the proper time.
The ADB changed the ROC's official designation to "Taipei, China" when mainland China was admitted to the financial body in 1986.

The ROC, a founder member of the international organization, rejected the change and has since attended ADB meetings under protest. It reasons that the name change is particularly unacceptable as Hong Kong will attend the upcoming ADB meeting as "Hong Kong, China."

This development can be equated with a downgrading of the ROC to a status similar to that of Hong Kong, which since July 1, 1997, has been a special administration region of mainland China, Peng said.
Peng told Sato that the ROC's efforts to win back its formal ADB name will not stop until its goal is achieved.
During the meeting, the CBC governor also disclosed that his country is very willing to cooperate with the ADB and other ADB members on the work of resolving the Asian financial crises.

He said that the ROC's sincerity in this regard can been illustrated by the fact that Taiwan banks have been purchasing the ADB-guaranteed government bonds Thailand has released to speed up its economic recovery.

The 1998 ADB meeting will open on Wednesday in Geneva, Switzerland, and Peng arrived here at the head of a 12-member delegation on Monday for the three-day conference, where they will join discussions on the Asian financial turmoil which broke out in mid-1997.
The Manila-headquartered ADB is the only official international organization in which the Republic of China holds a seat.

DOC.HEADLINE: BELGIANS DISSATISFIED WITH THEIR GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: More than half the Belgian people are dissatisfied with their federal government and consider that an election will not ameliorate the situation they face today.

According to a survey released on Tuesday by the Belgian daily Le Soir, 53 percent of Belgians want Belgian Premier Jean-Luc Dehaene to resign from his Socialist-Christian Democrats coalition government.

The Belgians have lost confidence in their government and leaders since Marc Dutroux, the country's public enemy number one, escaped last Thursday from a court where he was allowed to consult his own files.

The survey also shows that 52 percent of Belgians do not believe that legislative elections will ameliorate the current inefficiency of the government. The country is planning to hold a general election in June next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA PRESIDENT TO SPEAK AT BEIJING U.

TEXT.P: Yuan T. Lee, president of the Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in the Republic of China, is scheduled to deliver a speech at Beijing University on May 5 as part of the celebrations marking the 100th anniversary of the prestigious university.
Lee, the 1986 Nobel laureate in chemistry, will make the speech in his capacity as president of the Academia Sinica, sources from the institute reported on Wednesday.
Lee, 62, was elected head of the organization by a 50-member Academia Sinica council in December 1993.
This will be Lee's second visit to mainland China in three years. He visited Fujian Province in 1995 on an academic exchange program.

To celebrate its centennial, Beijing University has invited some 90 university presidents and executives from 22 countries and areas around the world to bless a "university presidents forum" slated for May 2.

In addition to Lee, more than 10 heads of universities in Taiwan, including National Taiwan University President Chen Wei-chao and National Tsinghua University President Liu Chun-lang, have also been invited to take part in the university presidents forum and other celebration activities.
Lee and the Taiwan academics are scheduled to leave Taipei for Beijing on May 1.

In Taipei, some extreme-right wing and pro-independence groups have voiced opposition to Lee and Chen's imminent visit to Beijing, saying the trip is "wasting the taxpayers' money" during a time when Beijing shows no sign of lessening its hostility toward Taiwan.
