DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOLUNTEERS TO REDUCE TUNA FISHING IN ATLANTIC

TEXT.P: Taiwan, in line with an international consensus for a gradual reduction in tuna fishing, has decided to cut its quota on tuna for 1998 as part of the effort to conserve the world's resources of this staple ocean product.

Officials from the cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Taiwan has recently volunteered to reduce its 1998 quota of albacore tuna by more than 2,600 metric tons to a maximum of 16,140 metric tons.
Taiwan, South Africa, Brazil and Namibia are the four major fishers of albacore in the South Atlantic, with Taiwan commanding the majority of all albacore fishing in those waters.

The International Commission of Conservation of Albacore Tuna (ICCAT) recently met and acknowledged a Taiwan proposal of a voluntary reduction on albacore fishing by 2,649 metric tons to a tune of 16,140 metric tons for 1998, said officials from the COA Fisheries Department.

The Taiwan quota constitutes 73.36 percent of the total amount of 22,000 metric tons that the ICCAT agreed to be harvested by the four major albacore fishers in the South Atlantic Ocean in 1998, the officials noted.
The ICCAT is a group comprising 40-odd economies on the rim of the Atlantic Ocean that was established in 1965 to further the cause of the conservation of albacore in the South Atlantic.
Since 1993, the ICCAT has urged a gradual reduction in the fishing of albacore, suggesting that the harvesting of this specific kind of tuna should not exceed 22,000 metric tons annually.

The ICCAT said the stocks of albacore in the South Atlantic would be maintained at an adequate level under the retrenchment initiative. Under the effort, the annual quota on albacore could hopefully be raised to 24,000 metric tons by 2005, said the officials.

Taiwan, a major fisher of albacore in the South Atlantic, at one time harvested up to 28,000 metric tons of the fish per year. Taiwan fishing boats began to cut back on their catch in 1993 in response to an ICCAT call for conservation efforts, gradually reducing its fishing volume to 18,789 metric tons last year.

Albacore is one of the many tuna species in oceans across the globe. While Taiwan fishing boats are major fishers of albacore, other types of tuna are favored elsewhere. Japanese fishing boats, for example, are major anglers of big eye tuna and yellow fin tuna in the South Atlantic, the officials noted.
In 1996, Taiwan tuna fishing boats caught some 55,000 metric tons of tuna worth NT$3 billion (US$90.9 million) in the Pacific, Indian and South Atlantic oceans.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER-STRICKEN M'LAND STOWAWAY FLOWN TO MATSU
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, April 29 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An illegal mainland Chinese immigrant who suffers from stomach cancer was helicoptered Wednesday from the Hsinchu Detention Center to Matsu, an ROC frontline island located near mainland China's Fujian Province, for quick repatriation.

Lin Kunghui, 26, weakened by gastric cancer that has reached its final stage, was carried on a stretcher by paramedics to the helicopter prepared by the Hsinchu police Wednesday morning and was flown to Matsu, from where he will be returned to mainland China by boat later in the day, said sources with the detention center.
Lin sneaked into Taiwan last year on a Fujian fishing boat after paying some 20,000 mainland Chinese yuan (US$2,420) to a human-smuggling ring.
Lin, who is in great pain from his illness, told reporters that he has "a little bit of regret" over his illegal entry into Taiwan. "The price was too high," he said.
Lin's return to mainland China marks the first time that Taiwan has used a helicopter to rush the repatriation of a mainland Chinese stowaway.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANCES SLIM FOR A JOINT CLINTON-JIANG COMMUNIQUE: MAC

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin are not expected to sign a joint communique, but may issue a joint statement at the end of their forthcoming meeting in June, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh said on Wednesday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, the head of the MAC, the highest-level government agency charting Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, said Clinton and Jiang are likely to issue a joint statement during their June summit, but added that a joint communique concerning the "three noes" issues -- no US arms sales to Taiwan, no US support for Taiwan's independence movement and no support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations -- is highly unlikely.

It is widely believed that mainland China will use the occasion of the second Clinton-Jiang meeting to push the United States to sign a formal accord on the above-mentioned "three noes" issues. Clinton and Jiang met for the first time in October, 1997.
Chang expressed the belief that the United States and mainland China will not ink such an accord, as it would greatly jeopardize Taiwan's interests and threaten the security of the Taiwan Strait.
ROC government representative offices across the United States have maintained close contacts with the US side, and will continue to reiterate Taiwan's opposition to such a pact, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS AND BEIJING'S RESPONSE

TEXT.P: Chen Yuan, the governor of mainland China's State Development Bank, told a seminar held by the Asian Development Bank in Geneva Tuesday that up till now, Beijing has "successfully fended off the Asian financial crisis."

Chen cited many figures to back up his statement. Mainland China's GDP has grown by 7.2 percent in the first quarter this year, he said. Inflation continues to be kept at low level. The retail price index has declined by 1.7 percent in the first quarter this year, while the consumer price index has risen a slight 0.3 percent over the same period. Foreign trade has continued to run a surplus of US$10.5 billion in the first quarter this year.

Mainland China's capital inflow has maintained growth momentum, with contractual and actual foreign capital inflow registering a growth of 6.8 percent and 2.2 percent in the first two months of this year, respectively, according to Chen. Moreover, he said, the foreign exchange reserve keeps rising and the exchange rate of the yuan has remained stable.

Chen said the Asian financial crisis that broke out in Thailand last July and has swept Indonesia, South Korea and other countries has also, to varying degrees, affected Hong Kong, Malaysia and the Philippines. Hong Kong, whose currency has successfully withstood pressure to devalue, is an exception in the area, where most other currencies have experienced sharp declines in value, he said.

In response to currency devaluation, the economies in the area have followed one another in raising domestic interest rates, which has in turn caused stock markets to plummet and economies to slide into recession, he said.

There are some good lessons to be drawn from the current financial crisis, Chen said. "First, excessive intervention from government must be avoided. Second, prudential regulation and oversight should go ahead of financial liberalization. Third, economic activities must be prevented from booming into bubble at any cost. Fourth, a country should adjust its economic structure before it is forced to do so."

The State Development Bank head said that Beijing has responded to the financial crisis in a responsible manner. On one hand, mainland China has on many occasions made solemn promises not to devalue its currency. On the other hand, Beijing has taken the initiative in stimulating domestic demand, deepening reform and continuing its opening policy, he said.

To attain above targets, Chen said, Beijing intends to adopt the following measures. First, domestic demand will be stimulated through nurturing new economic powerhouses. Second, prudential regulation and oversight over the financial system will be further strengthened. Third, equilibrium in balance of payment and stability in the exchange rate will be maintained. Fourth, the policy of opening up in the economic field will continue to be upheld.

He said he is confident that as long as countries in Asia take serious measures to address economic weaknesses and adhere to reform, they will soon be lifted out of their current difficulties and resume rapid growth.

Other speakers in the ADB seminar were E. Gerals Corrigan, managing director of Goldman, Sachs & Co.; Narongchai Akrasanee, an economic expert from Thailand; P. Chidambaram, member of the Indian Parliament; S. Ghon Rhee, resident scholar of the Asian Development Bank; and Professor Hans Genberg of the Graduate Institute of International Studies of Geneva.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHONE LINK BETWEEN CLINTON, JIANG EXPECTED BEFORE SUMMIT

TEXT.P: As part of the agreements reached at a summit last October between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, a direct telecommunications link between the two heads of state is expected to be in place before their next meeting in June.

Confirming that the line will be connected within the next two months, a US official said Tuesday that "direct link" would be a more suitable term than "hot line" because the latter has "the kind of connotations that are not appropriate in this case."

Nor will there be a bright red telephone set on either side of the line, as sometimes depicted in movies. Rather, the link is there just to provide a means of direct contact between the two heads of state.

"The United States and China have a very important relationship," the official said. "It is important that the two presidents have easy access to each other and it doesn't have to happen only when there is a crisis."

Clinton is known to have called other world leaders, such as the British prime minister and the Russian president, but the official said that it is difficult to draw any parallel between these connections.
US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright is due in Beijing on Wednesday to prepare for Clinton's state visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA HOPES TO PROTECT ITS CULTURE IN MULTIMEDIA AGE

TEXT.P: Canada's Minister of Heritage Sheila Copps said Tuesday that Canadian culture must be protected in the face of the growing new international media.

Copps recently concluded two days of meetings with representatives of major cultural organizations in hopes of working out a strategy that will ensure a strong Canadian presence in the borderless world of the new technology.
Referring to the new media, she said regulation is not the answer. The government's role should be to provide support for culture, she added.
John Tory, head of Rogers Media, a cable giant, said three things are needed from the government.
"The first is to make it easier for people to find financing to produce a greater quantity of Canadian content," Tory said.

"The second is to ensure ... that Canadians will be able to find that Canadian content online and in computer stores," he pointed out. He stressed that there's also a need for more people to produce Canadian-content programs.

It's habitual for the Canadian government to consult a wide range of people when mapping out a policy. Copps was collecting industry and public views on how to protect Canadian culture in the age of free trade and fast changing technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE'S MANUFACTURING OUTPUT UP BY 8.5 PERCENT IN MARCH

TEXT.P: Singapore's manufacturing output continued growing for the second consecutive month this year, up by 8.5 percent in March.
The year-on-year growth was due partly to last year's low base and growth of 31.8 percent in the chemicals sector, the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) said Tuesday.

The March tally lifted growth for the first quarter to an average of 6.1 percent, with growth in February at 16.5 percent and January's level falling a revised 5.1 percent -- down further from a sharp revision to 4.9 percent last month from an initial 3.9 percent drop.
The engineering cluster also turned in double-digit growth figures for March and the first quarter.
But output of the electronics cluster -- the mainstay of the manufacturing sector -- grew only 4.5 percent in March and 4.6 percent in the first quarter.
This was because over-supply, weak demand and relocation of producers affected the output of disk drives, pagers and consumer electronics, the EDB said.
On the other hand, the output of printers and assembled printed circuit boards was higher.

The chemicals sector powered ahead to expand 14.7 percent in the first quarter. The strong growth in pharmaceuticals, petroleum and petrochemicals was due mainly to increased production capacity resulting from plant expansion and the entry of new firms, said the board.
Production of industrial and specialty chemicals shrank 2.3 percent in March after 5.3 percent growth in the previous month.
All segments of the engineering cluster -- precision, process and transport -- grew, contributing to the sector's 11.5 percent growth in March and 13.3 percent for the first quarter, the EDB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STIFFER PENALTIES TO BE IMPOSED ON DRUNK DRIVERS

TEXT.P: In light of a sharp surge in traffic accidents caused by drunk drivers, the transportation authorities are planning to impose heavier penalties on those who are caught drinking and driving more than twice in a year.
A spokesman for the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said on Wednesday that the fine will double from the current NT$12,000 (US$364) to NT$24,000 for such repeat offenders.
The MOTC is also considering canceling the driver's licenses of repeat offenders for good, instead of only suspending the permits for six months.

Another planned strategy aimed at stemming automobile accidents resulting from drinking and driving is to extend the compulsory lecture on traffic safety to one day from the current four hours, the MOTC spokesman said.
Meanwhile, he added that the MOTC is also planning to introduce a zero-tolerance policy under which a driver whose breath is tested as containing any alcohol at all will be given a traffic ticket.

The number of alcohol-related traffic accidents in Taipei City is four-and-a-half times higher now than before the five-day workweek system was enacted at the beginning of this year, according to Taipei transportation authorities, who had raised the cry to impose harsher penalties on those who drive under the influence of alcohol.

Officials with the Taipei Bureau of Transportation said that the bureau has decided to extend the traffic safety lectures in the near future because it is convinced that this can lead some offenders to follow the rules in the future.

According to latest MOTC statistics, alcohol was a factor in 10.9 percent of all traffic accidents last year, with 11 percent of alcohol-related accidents resulting in fatalities and 13.1 percent resulting in injuries.
These figures show that drinking and driving is a major cause of traffic accidents in Taiwan, the MOTC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN AGAIN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Market (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, further declining 86.32 points to close at 8,348.35.
Dealers said the market was affected by a partial breakdown of the transaction computer system, causing share prices to close lower under heavy selling pressure.
The bourse opened at 8,466.38, and experienced a high of 8,488.81 and a low of 8,342.66.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 285 to 113, with 83 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$98.51 billion, decreasing from the previous trading session which saw 1.79 stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$101.49 billion.

All eight major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.4 percent, bank and insurance shares and textiles at 0.8 percent each, foodstuff issues at 0.7 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.3 percent, and the pulp and paper category at 0.2 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Wednesday's trading were: Ever Fortune Industries; ACER; Kuo Feng Corporation; Compal Electronic Inc.; Winbond Electronics Corp.; Mosel Vitelic Inc.; Chuntex Electronic Co., Ltd.; China Manmade Fibers; Mitac International Corp.; and Mustek Systems Inc.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DEAL GIVES NEW LEASE ON LIFE TO FORMER AUSSIE SPACE TOWN

TEXT.P: A former leading Australian space town gained a new lease on life when a leading US aerospace company signed a 12-year agreement to use the former rocket range at Woomera in South Australia for commercial satellite launchings.

Australia's Industry Minister John Moore and George Mueller, former head of NASA's manned space flight program and now chief executive officer of the Kistler Aerospace Corp., signed the agreement under which about 2,000 communications satellites will be launched at Woomera in the next five years.
The new deal between the US space company and the Australian government will not only revive the town of Woomera but also create hundreds of jobs for Australians.
Woomera was a boomtown in the 1950s and 1960s, when it was being used as the British government's rocket testing site.
At a signing ceremony Tuesday, Prime Minister John Howard said the agreement will launch Australia into the space age.
"This project will help position Australia alongside the United States, Russia and China as the top countries in space and communications technology," he said.
Aerospace industry specialists believe there will be a huge growth market for such commercial communications space technology in coming years for Australia.
Howard said the tests are expected to begin by the end of this year, with the first commercial launch next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TING SHOU-CHUNG ANNOUNCES BID TO RUN FOR TAIPEI MAYORSHIP

TEXT.P: Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Wednesday announced his bid to run for the mayorship of Taiwan's capital city of Taipei.

Ting, an incumbent KMT legislator who is serving his third term in the Legislative Yuan, urged his party in a written statement to hold intraparty primaries to choose candidates for the year-end mayoral races in Taipei and in the southern metropolis of Kaohsiung.
However, he said he will enter the race only when the KMT holds primaries, which he said is the only way to produce candidates through transparent, fair and open elections.

Ting, 44, holds a Ph.D. in international politics and diplomacy from the Fletcher School of Law & Diplomacy at Tufts University, Boston. He was appointed by the KMT to head the party's affiliated Department of Youth Affairs for two years between early 1996 and late 1997.
In his statement, Ting said he is increasingly worried, as election time is drawing nearer and the KMT has shown no sign that it is ready to decide on its candidates.

He said that technically speaking, the mayoral race, particularly in Taipei, will decide the fate of the ruling party and consequently the 2000 presidential election. The current mayor of Taipei is Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) camp, while the Kaohsiung mayorship is held by Wu Den-yih of the KMT.

Commenting on Ting's announcement, KMT spokesperson Huang Li-ching said the party has a "rounded and comprehensive" plan for the elections and added that the nomination of candidates will be conducted through "a well-defined process."

Huang said that Ting, an outstanding scholar-turned-politician, has already been nominated as a KMT candidate to run for a seat in the Legislative Yuan. She described Ting as a "piece of jade," referring to his personal integrity and high caliber.
However, she did not elaborate on whether the KMT will hold intraparty primaries to choose the mayoral candidates, while Taipei Mayor Chen declined to comment on Ting's announcement.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAN DELIGHTS IN WEST'S MANY FREEDOMS, CHOICES: REPORT

TEXT.P: Just a week ago, mainland China's No. 1 dissident had zero choices but now he can choose among prestigious US universities, a major Canadian daily reported Tuesday.
The Globe and Mail, in a dispatch from New York, said the wooing of Wang Dan is just part of his "great leap from the gulag to the great big candy store of the West."

The daily quoted Orville Schell, dean of the University of California, who flew into New York to urge Wang to attend Berkeley, as saying, "It's very difficult. What is Berkeley? What is Harvard? What is Yale? What is Democrat? What is Republican? What is Oldsmobile? What is Buick? It's a sort of pluralism gone mad."

Wang, who just completed his first full week of freedom in the United States, marveled at his wealth of choices, said the Mail's former Beijing bureau chief Jan Wong, who interviewed Wang at New York's exclusive Harvard Club.

She said Wang went underground after being labeled by Beijing as the most wanted student leader in the 1989 Tiananmen demonstrations. He was captured a month later on his way to a meeting with a Taiwan journalist, she added.

After serving three-and-a-half years, he was released a few months early, but was rearrested in 1995 and sentenced to 11 years. Among his crimes: enrolling in a correspondence course at the University of California at Berkeley. Wang said he was never afraid because he knew he was right, Wong reported.
"The government might have the instruments of dictatorship, like jails, but I knew they couldn't change my thinking," he told the Mail.

He did cry, though, when his mother was jailed for 50 days for speaking on his behalf, the Mail reported. He said he accepted "medical parole" only because he couldn't bear his parents making the grueling 10-hour journey on jammed Chinese trains each month to visit him in prison, it noted.

On April 17, prison officials told Wang he would be exiled in 18 hours. His parents, who happened to be on one of their visits, were also notified. Then Wang was driven through the night to Beijing in an 11-car procession.

"Cruelly, he sat wedged between two prison guards, in a separate car from his parents and his older sister, before boarding a flight to Detroit. His father, who had nothing ready to give, slipped off his watch and gave it to his son," Wong reported.
Wang arrived in Detroit penniless. "I still haven't got a cent in my pocket," he told Wong Monday. In Detroit, he was issued a one-year tourist visa.

When Wang embraced his parents for the last time, they urged him to study hard. That will be his priority, he told Wong. He added that he will always fight for democracy, in part because he feels "moral guilt" over the hundreds, perhaps thousands, who died at Tiananmen Square.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENT SAID DETAINED PRIOR TO BEIJING UNIVERSITY CENTENARY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 28 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Wang Youcai, a mainland Chinese dissident from Zhejiang Province, disappeared on Monday from his Beijing hotel amid signs that he has been detained by the Beijing public security police to prevent him from attending celebration activities to mark the centenary of Beijing University, which falls on May 4th.
The information was announced in a Tuesday press release from the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and the Democratic Movement in China

Wang, a former graduate student in the Physics Department of the university, was dismissed by the university for his part in the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989, but received nevertheless an invitation to the centennial celebrations, according to the press release.

Wang left his home in Hangzhou City for Beijing on April 25, but as soon as he arrived, he was tailed wherever he went by two local public security service vehicles, according to his friend Cheng Fan, who is also a Beijing University alumnus.

Cheng, who had agreed to meet Wang on Tuesday to visit another leader of the student pro-democracy movement, went to Wang's hotel --Tianfu Restaurant--when he failed to appear as planned, where an employee told him that someone checked out for Wang on Monday evening, taking his luggage with him. He has not been seen since.

Beijing University was the hothouse and center of the mainland pro-democracy movement in 1989, the information center press release said, adding that over a hundred students have been arrested since the June 4th Tiananmen demonstration, among whom 21 have been listed as criminals wanted by the Beijing authorities, and seven of whom are students from Beijing University.

It is estimated that more than 30,000 alumni will be attending the centennial celebrations, and the information center postulated that the Beijing authorities are so worried that the celebrations may turn into political activities that they have arrested Wang as a form of preemptive insurance.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.019 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.991.
The greenback opened at 33.001 and was traded between 32.96 and 33.015.
The interbank trading reached US$261 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOUNTAINS OF CONTAINERS CHOKING AUSSIE PORTS AS DOCK DISPUTE REMAINS

TEXT.P: Mountains of containers are now choking major ports across Australia as the waterfront dispute remains unsolved and shipping industry sources predict delayed shipments will continue with ships and cargo queuing at terminals, waiting to be loaded and unloaded.

They said at least 11,000 containerized cargoes are now choking Australia's major ports, locking up an estimated US$330 million worth of goods and extending delays at picket-free wharves to four days.

Liner Shipping Services (LSS), which represents more than half of Australia's shippers, has warned that the backlog will take weeks to clear even in the event of a speedy resolution of the current dock dispute between Patrick Stevedores, the Australian government and the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA).

Richard Hein, managing director of the dispute-free rival P&O Ports, the biggest stevedoring firm in Australia, said his company's terminals are under heavy strain because of extra business sub-contracted from Patrick Stevedores.
Delays in Melbourne and Sydney are up to four days, while similar delays in other major ports are between one and two days, he said.

"I think everybody's extremely nervous at the moment about ensuring they get their goods. I think a lot of them are quite relieved when they know they're going to our terminals and not to Patrick's," he told reporters.
P&O Ports now handles up to 30 percent more in volume terms and has increased its share of stevedoring volume to 70-75 percent from the previous 50-55 percent.
Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp. is one of the shipping companies affected by the prolonged waterfront dispute in Australia.
In an interview with CNA Wednesday, Frank Chang, Yang Ming's representative in Sydney, said it will take about two months to clear all the containers.
"But, for the time being, the mountains of containers are choking the ports, causing a long queue for both export and import cargoes to be loaded or unloaded," he said.
He said many shippers and shipping companies are getting worried because they do not know when their cargoes will be loaded or unloaded at major ports.

"It's now very difficult for us to calculate the amount of cargo to be loaded or unloaded thanks to such long queues. We don't know when it's our turn for either loading or unloading of our cargo until the last day," he said.
Previously they knew the schedule of the cargo handling at major ports several days in advance so that they could make precise arrangements, he added.

He said the long queues cause additional costs at the terminals but that there are also other extra costs, including transportation, because truck drivers now have to wait much longer at the ports before loading or unloading their goods.

"The waiting time was only about one hour before the waterfront dispute, but now it could be as long as four to five hours," he said. "This long wait costs money and increases additional costs for shippers."

He said Yang Ming, like other shipping companies plying routes between Australia and other countries, has to bear the additional cost of mooring their ships in Australian ports while waiting for the delivery of goods for both export and import.
"All these operating costs borne by shipping companies and exporters and importers are difficult to estimate now," he said.
Patrick said the 11,000 stranded containers include medical equipment and supplies, manufactured goods, textiles, clothing and footwear, fresh produce, electrical goods, and some personal belongings.
LSS CEO Llew Russell estimated the stockpile, mainly composed of imports, is worth from US$270 million to US$330 million.
He said the mounting costs of the blockade by the MUA at major ports in the past two weeks has yet to be calculated.

In addition to additional costs, changes of documentation for both imported and exported goods have to be made because those cargoes originally handled at the Patrick terminals have to be shifted to P&O docks.
There are also other details to be worked out, Chang said.
"We are facing considerable chaos in many operations as a result of the waterfront problem in Australia," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 MAINLAND CHINESE STOWAWAYS ARRESTED

TEXT.P: Freeway police on Wednesday arrested 15 stowaways from mainland China at toll stations in Yuanlin, Houli and Tounan townships in central Taiwan.
Police said they received reports in the early hours that four taxis carrying people behaving in a suspicious manner were driving north towards Taipei on the freeway.
The taxis were stopped at the toll booths and the occupants questioned, leading to the discovery that the passengers had all been recently smuggled onto the island from mainland China.

According to the police, the illegals said they boarded a vessel in Pingtan, Fujian Province, on Monday, at a cost of 29,000 renminbi per head, arriving at the southern Taiwan port of Tungshi in Chiayi County early on Wednesday morning, where they were picked up by taxis which had been prearranged to drive them to Taipei.
The police said they are investigating whether there is an organized smuggling ring behind the case.

Statistics from the mainland authorities in the coastal province of Fujian show that provincial law enforcement personnel cracked a total of 261 smuggling cases in 1997, leading to the arrest of 2,365 people, including so-called "snakeheads" and stowaways. "Snakehead" is the name given to those who organize and engage in human smuggling.
The statistics also show that most mainland stowaways tend to land in Kinmen and Matsu, two of Taiwan's offshore territories near Fujian.
Taiwan is regarded by many mainland Chinese as a land of milk and honey where work is easy to find and pay is high.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PICKS UP CRIMINALS FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: In line with an agreement signed with mainland China to jointly crack down on crime, Taiwan on Wednesday repatriated one mainland Chinese and took delivery of two local men wanted in Taiwan.

Taiwan Red Cross Society officials met their mainland counterparts on the ROC controlled island of Matsu, where they picked up Lin Wen-Teh and Chang Ya-chi, both 43, and handed over Ye Ganji, a 27-year-old native of Fujian Province.

Chang claimed that his fraud case stemmed from a debt dispute which has already been resolved, he added that after learning that he was wanted in Taiwan, he took the initiative and reported to the mainland authorities because he wanted to return to Taiwan to clear his name. Lin also denied any involvement in fraud.
Lin and Chang were later escorted onto a plane bound for Taiwan, where they will face justice under ROC law.
Ye, who was sentenced to 20 years in prison in Taiwan for his role in the 1990 murder of Chen Teh-hsing, skipper of a Taiwan fishing vessel, was released on parole last year.

Under the terms of the Kinmen agreement signed between the red cross societies of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in December 1990, Taiwan has so far taken delivery of 43 Taiwan criminals who had escaped local justice by fleeing to mainland China.

Taipei and Beijing drafted the agreement to deal with problems arising from increasing civilian contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the most pressing of which are criminals and illegal immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND VISIT SAID TO PAVE WAY FOR TAIPEI MAYOR'S MEETING WITH JIANG

TEXT.P: Lin Jui-tu, a Taipei City councilor with the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said on Wednesday that a recent visit to mainland China by a former Taipei City government official was aimed at secretly arranging a mainland visit for Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian.

In addition to exchanging opinions on bilateral cultural exchanges, the main purpose of the recent mainland visit by Lo Wen-chia, former director of the city government's Department of Information, was to pave the way for Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian to visit mainland China and meet mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, as well as seeking to build a channel for communication between the two men in case Chen becomes president in future, Lin claimed at a news conference.

Citing information provided by a Taiwan businessmen's association in mainland China, Lin said Lo departed from the United States for Hong Kong on April 2 and then proceeded to Beijing the next day, where he met with Yen Sheng-pang, a research fellow with the Taipei Culture Foundation who accompanied him on a series of visits there.

Lin alleged that Lo and Yen secretly met Wang Daohan and Tang Shubei, chairman and vice chairman respectively of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), and top negotiators with Taiwan, on April 12. The two men also visited Chen Yunlin of the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs on April 18 for discussions on Taiwan investment in the mainland.

According to Lin, Lo was originally planning to meet Ding Guangen, former head of the United Front Work Department and currently a Politburo member, and Wang Zhaoguo, former director of the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs and now United Front Work Department head. However, Lo's low rank denied him a meeting with the two mainland heavyweights.

In addition to his allegations that Lo was acting as Chen's secret envoy, Lin also claimed that Lo and Yen used money allocated by the Taipei Culture Foundation, which is run by the city government, to pay for their trip.

While Chen had no comments to make regarding the allegations, Lin Ching-chang, incumbent director of the city government's information department, denied Lin Jui-tu's allegations and said the mayor was unaware of Lo's recent activities.

Calling Lo's mainland trip a "personal visit," he said the information which Lin Jui-tu obtained was "untrue," and added that Chen had no knowledge of the matter until reading about it in local newspapers.

Lo, who went to the mainland in his capacity as a visiting researcher with Stanford University in the United States, did not use the foundation's money to pay for the trip, and Yen went there only to conduct personal academic research, Lin claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANEEB-COMMISSIONED POWERED GLIDER CRASH-LANDS

TEXT.P: A powered glider, or ultralight, was forced to land in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County on Wednesday morning due to engine failure, causing minor injuries to the two men on board.
The Kaohsiung-based Feihao Communications-owned craft was flying over Chiuju Township when the engine failed, forcing it to land in a parking lot, where it hit several vehicles.

Feihao Communications was commissioned by Taiwan Area National Expressway Engineering Bureau (TANEEB) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to render a bird's-eye view of the Second Highway in southern Taiwan.

Pilot Hu Chin-chi and his passenger, computer artist Chen Cheng-feng, received minor injuries but their conditions were later described as satisfactory following medical attention. The ultralight also sustained damage.

In light of the accident, Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) announced on Wednesday that ultralights are considered to be aircraft, and that operating them without a license is against the law and punishable by a NT$600,000 to NT$3 million fine.

Additional CAA regulations regarding ultralights stipulate that the craft may not tow objects or throw objects overboard during flight, and that they are not to be used for aerial photography or filming.

The CAA said that because the certification and site regulations for ultralights are as stringent as those governing helicopters and other types of aircraft, no company has ever received permission to establish ultralight flight services.

CAA Director-General Chang Chia-chu said the CAA is currently investigating the circumstances surrounding the crash-landing. Expressing mystification as to why TANEEB would commission a company to carry out aerial photography using illegal means, he said that any decision will have to await the outcome of the investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG CRITICIZES BEIJING'S TWO-FACED DEALING

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yu on Wednesday criticized Beijing for its "unfriendly" two-faced game of setting up ties with Guinea-Bissau while Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) was visiting the mainland.

Chang made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan answering interpellations by lawmakers, including Taipei City Legislator Chen Hung-chi of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), Taoyuan County Legislators Peng Sao-chin and Chiu Chui-chen of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and Changhua County Legislator Wong Chin-chu, also of the DPP.

Commenting on Jan's trip, the MAC head, who is in charge of charting Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, pointed out that the move was initiated by the ROC and that the international community should have noticed the ROC's efforts to improve relations and safeguard peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Commenting on a suggestion by Beijing for a seminar on cross-strait political negotiation, Chang said that if it is purely academic research and discussion, it should be able to proceed, but if it involves negotiation, it should be done through formal channels. He further said he believes Beijing is not ready for such negotiations.
Chang also revealed that the MAC is planning a trip to the mainland by Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China and chairman of the semiofficial SEF, later this year.

He said that Koo's meeting with his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, will not constitute official negotiations, adding that the meeting should be preceded by contact between their respective deputies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEENAGERS TALLER, FATTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan teenagers have become taller and fatter in the past decade, according to a large-scale survey presented by the Department of Health (DOH) Wednesday.
Chen Hsu-kong, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said teenagers today are on average four to six centimeters taller and 2.5 kilograms heavier than they were 10 years ago.
Chen said changing lifestyles brought on by increased wealth in Taiwan households see people eating better and exercising less, resulting in a growing number of overweight people.

The survey showed that 2.1 million adults over age 19, or one in seven Taiwan adults, are overweight. It is noteworthy that the demographic groups most affected by the problem are middle-aged and elderly women.

One in eight Taiwan adults, or 1.8 million persons, have high blood pressure and high fatty content in the blood. One in five, or 2.9 million persons, have high protein levels in their urine, and one in 25, or 580,000 adults, have diabetes.
This is the third and the largest survey to date examining the nutritional situation in Taiwan. The DOH sampled 10,080 people islandwide to obtain the results.
Although the ratio of overweight persons in Taiwan still does not equal that found in the United States, the number of overweight local people has increased alarmingly, Chen said.
He also expressed concern over the rising incidence of diabetes, high blood pressure and gout.
Chen said that although the public is much more conscious of the importance of eating a balanced diet, the consumption of proteins and fats has apparently been too high.

Although calcium intakes have increased, reflecting a heightened public awareness of the risks of osteoporosis, the national average has yet to reach recommended daily allowances. The problem of calcium deficiency is most serious among women below age 25.
The consumption of saturated fats and cholesterol has increased in recent year. And women between the ages of 13 and 34 are found to be in need of more iron.

Chen urged the public to follow a healthier regimen, meaning people should eat less and eat better. He said that the intake of oils and salt should be cut, while the consumption of milk, vegetables and fruit should be increased.
Middle-aged and elderly women, which are more prone to gain weight as they age, should do more exercise.

Taiwan teenagers also tend to eat too much fried foods, while their intake of vegetables and fruit are only half the recommended levels, which Chen said could result in obesity and related illness in later years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENTS ON MAINLAND DECLINE IN VALUE

TEXT.P: Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said Wednesday that the investment projects of Taiwan businessmen on the Chinese mainland are increasing in number but decreasing in terms of value.

Lin made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan answering interpellations by Changhua County Legislator Hsieh Tsung-min from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party who wanted to know about the investment situation of Taiwan businessmen on the mainland.

Hsieh noted that, based on information gained from friends in Japan, investments by Japanese businessmen on the mainland have drastically reduced by about one-third. He suggested that this development should serve to alert for Taiwan businessmen who are eager to invest on the mainland.

In his reply, Lin explained that the cumulative investments from Taiwan businessmen on the mainland at present total nearly US$13 billion, and that the overall investment situation appears to be one of more projects but decreasing sums of money. He said this shows that most of the Taiwan investment projects there belong to small and medium-scale enterprises.

Lin pointed out that, in fact, there are signs that fewer foreign investors are being attracted to the Chinese mainland. However, he noted that there have been very few withdrawals of investments on the mainland by Taiwan businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 'COMFORT WOMEN' TO FILE SUIT IN JAPANESE COURT

TEXT.P: A private women's group said Wednesday it has decided to file suit against the Japanese government to demand compensation for 45 women living in Taiwan who were forced into prostitution by the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II.

The Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation said it had been encouraged by the recent victory of three so-called comfort women from South Korea in a local Japanese local court. Accordingly, the foundation said it has decided to bring demands for compensation by a group of women from Taiwan to a Japanese court within one or two months. It added that a Japanese lawyers association has promised to offer assistance during the legal process.

The Yamaguchi District Court in western Japan on Monday ordered the Japanese government to pay 300,000 yen each to three of 10 South Korean plaintiffs, who had demanded a total 564 million yen and an official apology. But the court rejected the demand for an official apology in the historic ruling that nevertheless forces the government to pay compensation.

Lawyer Wang Ching-feng, counselor with the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, said the Japanese government's refusal to offer official compensation to the 300-plus surviving comfort women living in various Asian countries had prompted former sex slaves from South Korea and the Philippines to file lawsuits in Japanese courts to demand justice be served.

Wang said the foundation has decided to follow suit and believes it has a good chance of winning the case. Meanwhile, she revealed that three more women have come to the foundation for help, bringing the number of former comfort women living in Taiwan to 45. All three women are in their 70s or 80s, Wang added.
An estimated 200,000 young women, mostly from Korea, but also from mainland China, Taiwan, the Philippines and Indonesia, were forced to serve as sex slaves for the Japanese army during World War II.

In August 1996, the Japanese government set up a private "Asian Women's Foundation" that provides the equivalent of NT$500,000 in compensation to each surviving comfort woman who dares to step forward and reveal her past. Most of the wartime sex slaves, however, have refused to accept the compensation, saying that the money should come directly from the Japanese government.

The ROC government last year offered financial aid to help improve the living conditions of the surviving comfort women, a move prompted by nearly 10 years of concerted efforts by the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation as well as other groups. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs paid NT$500,000 (US$15,873) to each of the 42 women who have already applied for the funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ONE OF IDEAL PLACES FOR FOREIGNERS TO RESIDE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 29 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: A newly issued report has shown that Singapore, Malaysia and Taiwan are the top three places in Asia suitable for foreign businessmen to reside.
They were followed in descending order by Japan, Hong Kong, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, the Chinese mainland, Vietnam and South Korea.

The report, based on a survey conducted by a political and economic risk consultant firm, pointed out that Taiwan has jumped from its previous 7th place to 3rd place mainly because foreign businessmen are satisfied with Taiwan's educational system and comfortable about their personal safety.

According to the report, several high-profile murder cases occurring in Taiwan last year have raised concerns about rising crime on the island. However, since the beginning of this year the law and order situation has improved, causing foreign businessmen to regain confidence about residing in Taiwan.

Some 400 overseas businessmen living in various regions around Asia were interviewed in the survey. They were asked to comment on the level of satisfaction regarding their living environment. The survey was based on such categories as housing, schools and medical systems, as well as leisure facilities.

Hong Kong was ranked fifth in the survey, slipping from last year's fourth place finish. Although foreign businessmen generally consider Hong Kong's living conditions to be above average, they expressed dissatisfaction with expensive rent costs, overcrowding and environmental pollution.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENERGY GROUP VISITS VICTORIA TO STUDY POWER PRIVATIZATION

TEXT.P: A group of economics officials from the Republic of China arrived in Melbourne on Monday for a two-day fact-finding tour to examine the privatization of electricity stations in Victoria.

Chen Chao-yih, secretary-general of the Energy Commission of the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs, told the CNA that he and his group would visit power stations in Melbourne to study how the Victorian government privatized its state-owned enterprise.
Chen was one of the senior government officials who attended the 5th annual meeting of the ROC-Australia Joint Energy and Minerals Trade, Investment Cooperation Consultations in Canberra on April 27.

Vice Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming, the leader of the ROC delegation, said the meeting was successful because delegates from Australia and Taiwan had better understandings of the supply and demand situation for energy and minerals between the two countries.
Yiin returned to Taipei on Monday, leaving Chen to continue the trip to Victoria.
Chen said this will be the first time for a group from the ROC government to study the privatization of power stations abroad.
"We hope to learn not only the privatization of Australian power stations, but also other countries in the near future as well," he said.
Aside from studying the privatization process, the ROC group will also look into details of pricing and management at the Victorian power stations during the two-day trip, Chen said.
He said the ROC government is in the process of further opening its power industry to private hands.
Chen and his group will wind up their visit and return to Taipei on May 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT HOLD SIMILAR POSITIONS ON CRITICAL ISSUES: HSU
DOC.DATELINE: Canberra, April 29 (CNA) (By Peter Chen & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: The visiting chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday that the DPP's position on the issues of mainland relations and Taiwan independence are not entirely opposed to those of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang stressed that his party will not insist on holding a plebiscite on the Taiwan independence issue unless the status quo across the Taiwan Strait changes due to a military threat from mainland China.

Hsu made the remarks while attending a roundtable seminar with scholars and experts from political and economics circles at National Australian University. The DPP's stances on cross-strait ties, Taiwan independence and the Asian financial turmoil were the focus of discussion at the gathering.

Hsu said that the KMT and the DPP share the same belief that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state. But he added that the difference between the parties is that the KMT insists on the existence of "two Chinas," while the DPP believes in "one China, one Taiwan."

The pro-independence party leader stressed that when the DPP takes the reins of power, it will not announce the independence of Taiwan to provoke mainland China, adding that maintaining the status quo across the Taiwan Strait is the best way to maintain peace in the strait, he said.

On the "one country, two systems" scheme proposed by Beijing as a paradigm for national reunification, Hsu said that the concept is totally unacceptable to Taiwan. Saying Taiwan is not Hong Kong, Hsu pointed out that Taiwan has been separated from the mainland for over 100 years and has developed "an identity as a new country."

Asked about the possibility of the two sides improving their relations by way of forming a commonwealth or federation, Hsu said that such a proposition is not feasible at the current stage, but added it may be workable in 50 or 100 years.
He reiterated that maintaining the status quo and promoting dialogue with the mainland is the best way to reduce tension across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TALKS SHOULD BE HELD BEFORE WINTER: KOO

TEXT.P: The dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume before the winter of this year, Koo Chen-fu, Taipei's top negotiator with Beijing, said Wednesday.
Koo, chairman of the semiofficial Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made the remarks on the 5th anniversary of his historic meeting with mainland Chinese counterpart Wang Daohan.

Koo said that the time has come for him to meet once again with Wang, chairman of Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, following SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng's trip to Beijing last week to make preparations for resumption of the long-stalled talks.
Koo said that the talks should take place before the winter and that the content of such talks need not be confined to technical discussions.

He pointed out that in every previous cross-strait consultation, the two sides have never been far away from touching upon political issues. He cited as examples past discussions on fishery disputes and the repatriation of hijackers.

Koo reiterated that he would not shy away from any issue, noting that Premier Vincent Siew has also said that the SEF and the ARATS can discuss any issue related to peaceful development across the Taiwan Strait and the eventual unification of China under the principle of democracy.

On ARATS' suggestion that Koo and Wang meet in seminar forum, Koo said he personally would not oppose to the idea, but added that a seminar would demand preparations lasting six months or longer to set the agenda, venue and guest list.

He also said that if the mainland China could arrange for him to meet with President Jiang Zemin or Premier Zhu Rongji, he would be delighted to do so. But he said such an arrangement could not be part of the cross-strait talks.

Koo and Wang held an ice-breaking rendezvous in Singapore on April 22-29, 1993. During the landmark meeting, the two sides laid a framework for regular dialogues and contacts between the two intermediary bodies.

That initiative became stalled when the mainland side suspended further contact following a visit to the United States by ROC President Lee Teng-hui in June 1995, which Beijing viewed as a veiled attempt to seek Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: GENETIC DIETS SEEN AS NEXT WEAPON AGAINST FAT

TEXT.P: Genetic diets may become the next weapon to fight against fat, according to a senior nutritionist from New Zealand.

Speaking at the Dieticians Association conference in Sydney this week, Prof. Jim Mann, head of the Department of Human Nutrition at the University of Otago, said that in the 21st century, the "balanced diet" may be individually tailored to a person's genes.
He said genes affect the way our bodies react to fat and determine the sort of diet we should follow.
The genetic link could also help explain why some ethnic groups achieve lower rates of heart disease with a diet which does not benefit other ethnic groups, he said.
Mann predicted that genetic tests to devise the tailored diets may be available "within five to 10 years whereby we can identify people by means of their genetic make-up."
He said genes determine the action of enzymes, which in turn determine individual metabolisms.
Daily exercise is also important in controlling body weight, Mann noted.
The nutritionist cited a study by Prof. Robert Kushner from the School of Medicine at the University of Chicago as an example.

He said Kushner believes doing 30 minutes of exercise daily is not enough to control body weight. He suggested that to keep weight off, people need 80 minutes of moderate exercise or 35 minutes of vigorous physical activity daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMOTION CAUSED BY THAI LABORERS CALMS

TEXT.P: Activity at a textile factory in northern Taiwan returned to normal early Thursday following an outbreak of pandemonium involving a group of workers from Thailand, police said.

Wang Yi, president of the Hualon-Teijran factory in Toufen, Hsinchu, said the row started after clashes between disgruntled laborers and the security guards at the plant. Several off-duty workers had asked for permission to go to a karaoke club at around 11 p.m., in defiance of regulations prohibiting them from leaving the premises after 10:30 p.m.
Over a hundred Thai laborers then converged outside the dormitory at the plant complex, and began throwing bricks, bottles, furniture and other items.
As the Thais continued the noisy protest, the area was thrown into pandemonium. Scores of Toufen police mobilized to the scene took no action for fear of fueling the workers' already-tense emotions.
Police cordoned off roads leading to the plant and asked ambulances to stand by in case of an emergency.
General manager Wang said there had been no problems between labor and management at the plant, nor had there been any communication barriers with the Thai workers.
He said that the situation at local karaoke establishments is unpredictable, and that the factory's workers are discouraged from going to such places out of concern for their safety.
Police said the Hualon factory in Toufen employs over 1,000 Thai laborers, and there no record of negligence or improper conduct on the part of the plant's management.
They also noted that the Hualon facility has a reputation of being a model factory for foreign labor management, saying the incident appears to be an isolated case.
After emergency talks with the Thai laborers, tensions eventually subsided and the protest broke up at around 1:30 am.
Hualon management vowed Thursday to continue discussions with the workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA INTERESTED IN COOPERATING ON NUKE WASTE DISPOSAL

TEXT.P: Negotiations with Russia on the storage in that country of low-grade radioactive waste disposal from Taiwan are going smoothly, with an agreement expected shortly, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chang Chang-pang said Thursday.

According to Chang, the state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) is working closely with the Russian Academy of Sciences on the plan. If an agreement is forged, Taipower would ship low-grade radioactive waste, including contaminated resin and temperature-resistant materials, to Russia for permanent storage.

The two sides reached a preliminary understanding whereby Taipower will initially ship 5,000 barrels of the waste material to Russia. If the operation proceeds smoothly, the volume can be increased in subsequent shipments.
If all goes well, Chang noted, the first shipment is expected to be made as early as next year.

Taipower President Kuo Junne-huey, however, denied Thursday that the negotiations with Russia were "going smoothly." He said that, as in ongoing talks with mainland China on a nuclear storage deal, are a great number of "political obstacles" need to be tackled before any accord is struck.

Meanwhile, according to Taipower sources, the corporation's plan to use a receptacle in North Korea for Taiwan's nuclear waste has been shelved as a result of strong protests from South Korea. But they said the company has not yet totally given up hope of future cooperation with the North Koreans.
Taipower sealed a contract with Pyongyang on Jan. 11, 1997, to ship 60,000 barrels of low-grade radioactive waste to North Korea over a two-year period for permanent storage.
Pyongyang first contacted Taipower in 1996, offering a parcel of land near a North Korean seaport to Taipower for use as a receptacle.
The North Korean offer was viewed favorably by Taipower for the reasonable price, not-too-distant location and the convenience of not needing to pass through a third country for the shipments.

That arrangement, however, sparked a storm of protests from Seoul, which hinted that attempts to go ahead with the shipments could trigger a conflict on the high seas. South Korea also claimed the United States had been "hoodwinked" into not trying to block the Taipower-Pyongyang deal.

According to knowledgeable sources, US authorities consequently began to exert pressure on Taiwan's diplomatic arms, asking Taipei to cease the related efforts--causing the Taipower-Pyongyang contract to be shelved indefinitely.

After North Korea threatened to file a complaint with the International Court saying Taipower had reneged on the deal, Taipower officials said the company will seek to compensate Pyongyang in "other ways."

Meanwhile, Taipower has never given up the possibility of cooperating with mainland China or the Marshall Islands on a storage deal, although relevant talks have hit snags over a wide variety of problems, the sources disclosed.

Once Taipower is completely privatized, they said, it will stand a better chance of engaging in direct talks with local authorities in charge of the five existing nuclear waste dumps across mainland China for a cross-border storage plan.
At home, Taipower is also trying to persuade residents in offshore Hsiaowuchiu and Hsiaolanyu to allow those areas to be used as receptacle sites.

According to Kuo, if Hsiaowuchiu is indeed developed into a storage location, the islet, located near mainland China's Fujian Province, will be capable of accommodating nuclear waste from Taiwan for 100 years.
