DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND OUTPERFORMS TAIWAN ON EXPORTS TO EUROPE, US

TEXT.P: Despite a relative depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the renminbi, Taiwan has not seen a corresponding rise in competitiveness with exports from mainland China, according to an ROC government report.

A study on the impact of the Asian financial meltdown upon the trade performance of countries in the region was released Wednesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA). It indicates that mainland exports to Europe rose by 35 percent in the first three months of this year as compared with the same period of 1997, while a 14 percent growth was seen in shipments to the United States.
During the January-March period, Taiwan's exports to these areas posted only modest rises of 3.9 percent and 2.2 percent, respectively.
MOEA officials said the performance should serve as a warning to Taiwan's export sector.
The MOEA report also indicated that mainland China has been seeing falling export figures since the second half of last year, when the financial storm began to batter the Asian area.

Mainland exports began to shrink in early 1997, dropping from 26.2 percent growth in the first half of that year to a combined 17.1 percent in the third and fourth quarters. The downward trend continued with a lackluster 12.8 percent rise in the first quarter of 1998, according to the report.
The significant declines were attributed to reduced trade with other Asian countries.

Feeling the economic pinch, most nations in the region experienced scaled-back growth figures, downgraded financial ratings and devalued currencies, which in turn resulted in severely reduced import levels.

Although mainland China emerged as the only Asian economy to escape the problem of currency depreciation, it was nonetheless caught up in the regional financial crisis as cheaper exports from neighboring countries took a large share of its foreign trade.
The MOEA officials said the mainland's reduced export volume has slowed the pace of its manufacturing sector, an essential factor which might lead Beijing to lower its economic growth forecasts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES FORMER US DEFENSE SECRETARY

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui warmly received former US Secretary of Defense Frank Carlucci on Thursday and exchanged opinions on subjects of mutual concern.

Lee told Carlucci that the solid foundation behind the ROC's economic progress has allowed the country to go through the recent Asian financial crisis relatively unscathed. At the same time, he said, the ROC is very willing to assist South Korea and countries in Southeast Asia in the midst of trying times.

Lee pointed out that the ROC is continuing to prosper economically on Taiwan, and its progress in democratic governance has been affirmed around the world. The people on Taiwan not only lead prosperous lives, he said, they also enjoy an abundance of democracy and freedom.

Carlucci first visited Taiwan in May 1990 at the invitation of the ROC government and attended President Lee's inauguration ceremony. He said he is deeply impressed by the progress witnessed here on his return visit and expressed highest regards for Lee's outstanding leadership.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT-TANG TALK TOUCHES ON TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 30 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-cheng and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The United States will observe its promises on the issue of Taiwan, visiting US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright told mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan in a meeting on Wednesday.

Albright made the remark in response to Tang's statements during the meeting that the Taiwan issue is the most important and sensitive question in the relationship between the United States and mainland China and that he hopes all the commitments US leaders made in the three joint communiques and joint declarations between Beijing and Washington will be honored.
Albright's current trip to mainland China is aimed at paving the road for US President Bill Clinton's late-June visit there.

During his meeting with Albright, Tang remarked that for the sake of the long term interests of both the United States and mainland China, Beijing hopes that relations between the two can be viewed and handled with a strategic vision. He urged both sides to seek common points and to narrow the gap between them in the spirit of seeking common ground while reserving differences on the basis of equality and mutual respect. He went further and touched the Taiwan issue, which prompted Albright's positive reply.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN M'LAND HIT BY FALLOUT OF ASIAN FINANCIAL STORM

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen with investments in the mainland are reeling from the fallout of the Asian financial storm that began its sweep through Asia in mid-1997, according to the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) Thursday.
CETRA officials said that Taiwan businessmen in such labor-intensive industries as garment making and shoemaking have seen their orders cut by up to 30 percent.

The officials said that to learn what impact the Asian financial storm has had on Taiwan businessmen in the mainland, they recently visited Beijing, Tianjin, Dalian, Shanghai, Guangzhou Shenzhen and other major footholds of Taiwan investment to conduct a fact-finding survey.
They found that Taiwan businessmen investing in labor-intensive industries have suffered various degrees of order losses due to steep competition from South Korea and Southeast Asian nations.

The officials said that Taiwan businessmen in the knitting and garment industries have had their export orders to Japan cut by 30 percent due to competition from South Korea, and that orders for leather goods and handbags are down 20 percent due to competition from Southeast Asian nations.

Shoemaking and peripheral product manufacturing for the downstream information industry are also reeling from the financial woes in the Southeast Asian region, showing drastic declines and losses of orders.

CETRA officials said that European and American buyers have emerged as the biggest winners in the latest wave of financial troubles. Taiwan businessmen have not only suffered drastic declines in orders but also been forced to cut their prices.
The officials urged Taiwan businessmen not to put all their eggs in one basket, saying they should try to cut their risks by diversifying their investments and keeping their roots in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: US AND JAPAN AMEND LOGISTICS AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Pentagon announced Tuesday that the United States and Japan have signed an amendment to a bilateral agreement on reciprocal provision of logistics support between the Japan Self-Defense Forces and the US military.

The Defense Department said in a statement that the amendment would build upon the existing Acquisition and Cross-Servicing Agreement (ACSA) to include reciprocal provision of logistics support "during situations in areas surrounding Japan that have an important influence on Japan's peace and security".

The ACSA, originally signed in April 1996, established terms and conditions for exchange of logistics support for bilateral training and exercises, United Nations peacekeeping operations, and international humanitarian relief operations.

The Pentagon said that the amendment, which was signed by US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and Japan's Foreign Minister Keizo Obuchi on Tuesday in Tokyo, is also "designed to contribute to smooth and effective operation of the Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security, and United Nations efforts to promote international peace."
It also described the ACSA amendment as an important element in implementing the new Guidelines for US-Japan Defense Cooperation published last September.
On the other hand, apparently conscious of Beijing's suspicions about military cooperation between the United States and Japan, the Pentagon seeks to downplay the development.

"While the scope of US-Japan logistics cooperation will expand to allow US forces and the Japan Self-Defense Forces to support each other during a contingency," it said, "the new amendment will not alter the type of support already allowed under the current ACSA."
"The ACSA provides a framework for exchange of supplies and services but does not require provision of such support, or authorize new military roles or missions for US or Japanese forces," it added.
The agreement applies to the exchange of such items as food, transportation and petroleum. The provision of weapon systems or ammunition are expressly prohibited under the agreement.

There has been speculation that "the surrounding areas" mentioned in both the guidelines and the newly amended agreement include the Taiwan Strait. Neither Washington nor Tokyo, however, would be drawn in on questions over possible responses to another crisis in the Taiwan Strait.
Beijing has spoken out against foreign intervention in the Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PM MAKING LAST-DITCH EFFORTS TO SOLVE WATERFRONT DISPUTE

TEXT.P: Australia's Prime Minister John Howard is making last-ditch efforts to put an end to the lingering waterfront dispute and reduce the political damage ahead of elections later this year.

Howard on Wednesday summoned Chris Corrigan, chief executive of Patrick Stevedores, the company at the center of the dispute with the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA) after it sacked all the entire workforce of 2,000 union members about three weeks ago.

The sacking caused widespread anger among the MUA and its members and triggered a wave of protests and blockades at major wharves serviced by Patrick, causing a major disruption in both exports and imports.
The High Court is set to make a decision next Monday as to whether Patrick must reinstate the workers as mandated by the Federal Court.
During Monday's two-hour meeting with Corrigan and Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith in Canberra, Howard asked Patrick to come up with a peace deal with its sacked workers and the MUA.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MAKE RENEWED BID TO ENTER WHO

TEXT.P: The medical establishment here has appealed for the public to go on-line to drum up support from international community for Taiwan's bid to re-enter the World Health Organization (WHO).
Taiwan Medical Professional Alliance (TMPA) officials asked local people to convey their sentiments through the Internet so that the world can hear the voice of Taiwan.

The TMPA and representatives from the Dentist Association and Medical Examiners Association spoke Wednesday in a press conference to seek a national consensus on global health care and humanitarian medical relief.
The officials provided e-mail addresses of the heads of state in the United States, Canada, Japan, France and the United Kingdom for those who are concerned with the issue.

The medical professionals stressed that there should be no national boundaries for medical care, saying Taiwan's exclusion from the WHO has prevented it from participating to that organization's formulation of overall health policy, the development of sophisticated diagnostic technology and the assessment and implementation of disease control systems.

They noted that Taiwan also has no access to health information and technology that are distributed among WHO members, saying such treatment runs contrary to the spirit of universality in upgrading health standards around the world.

TMPA Secretary-General Chang Wu-hsiu said health issues have nothing to do with political affairs. He added that it was unbearable to hear the representative from mainland China at last May's WHO congress in Geneva claim that the health of Taiwan people is being watched over by Peking.

Chang also said that Taiwan's bid to enter the WHO has nothing to do with prestige, asserting that the substantial damage from exclusion by that body is significant. He cited as an example the fact that a public health hazard involving contaminated radioactive steel rods surfaced in Taiwan only in 1992, although the international community had formed a plan for handling such problems as early as 1984.

Ho Mei-hsiang, a researcher at Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan, noted that Taiwan lacks access to international coordination involving communicable disease and health, asking who would help in the event a major epidemic were to break out here.
At the same time, Ho said, Taiwan is prevented from sharing its successful experience in family planning and efforts to fight hepatitis B.

Deng Chao-feng, TMPA president and an expert on clinical toxicology, said Taiwan's bid to the WHO cannot be achieved with a single leap. He said the TMPA will keep that goal as a long-term objective by trying to gain admission to the WHO as a nongovernmental organization.

Deng also noted that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is trying to make another attempt to solicit Republic of China diplomatic allies to speak for Taiwan's admission as an WHO observer during the organization's annual assembly in Geneva on May 11-20.
The ROC lost its membership in the WHO, a specialized agency of the United Nations, after its UN seat was handed to mainland China in 1972.

Senegal, one of the ROC's allies, proposed at the WHO assembly last May that Taiwan be invited to attend the assembly as an observer. However, the request to list the item on the agenda was defeated because of opposition from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT INCLUDED ON US 'SPECIAL 301' LIST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D.C., April 29 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is not included on this year's "Special 301" blacklist, which is expected to be formally announced by the Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) on May 1, sources close to the White House executive agency said Wednesday.

Although the final list must be approved by US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky, who is currently in Paris, it was learned that Taiwan will not reappear on the Special 301 list for 1998, according to the sources.
Hong Kong, meanwhile, will be placed on the "watch list" for alleged failure to adequately crack down on commercial piracy.

Mainland China, based on provisions of Article 306 of the US Omnibus Trade Act, will be under close scrutiny regarding its implementation of an intellectual property rights (IPR) protection agreement signed between Washington and Beijing.

Earlier this year, US-based pharmaceutical company PBM suggested the USTR put Taiwan on the priority watch list for what it called an "unfair pricing system" on imported medicines and medical equipment. Nintendo US and the International IPR Alliance also demanded Taiwan's inclusion on the watch list for IPR infringements.
To investigate the complaints, a USTR delegation headed by senior adviser David Burns visited Taipei in early April.

During the visit, the US officials gained a better understanding on IPR protection efforts and related developments in Taiwan. The USTR office has also secured promises by Taipei on implementation of an export monitoring system to stem commercial piracy and other IPR infringements.
In November 1996, Taiwan was removed from a "special mention" list of countries where IPR protection is a concern, in recognition of improvements in its IPR protection efforts.

That was the first time that Taiwan has been absent from all categories of the Special 301 listings since the United States began annual reviews of IPR protective measures by its trading partners in 1989 under provisions of Article 301 of its Omnibus Trade Act.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.021 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at NT$32.97.
The greenback opened at 32.981 and was traded between 32.965 and 32.999.
The interbank trading reached US$305 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, declining 44.14 points to close at 8,304.21.
Dealers said the market was affected by electronic issues, whose performance was far from ideal during the first quarter of this year.
The bourse opened at 8,422.09 and experienced at high of 8,435.94 and a low of 8,304.21 at the closing, marking a decline of 787 points during April.
Losers outnumbered gainers in Thursday's trading by 285 to 113, with 83 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$109.88 billion (US$3.33 billion), increasing from the previous trading session, which saw 1.71 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$98.51 billion.

Six of the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by electrical shares at 0.7 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.6 percent, both plastics and chemical issues and the cement category at 0.5 percent, and textile shares at 0.3 percent.
Meanwhile, both foodstuff and construction shares remained unchanged.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Thursday's trading were Ever Fortune Industries, Picvue Electronics Corp., Winbond Electronics Corp., Mustek Systems Inc., China Manmade Fibers, Umax Data Systems Inc., Kuoyang Construction, Mitac International Corp., Chuntex Electronic Co. and Tai Yu Products.

DOC.HEADLINE: QIAN, ALBRIGHT DISCUSS TAIWAN ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 30 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-cheng and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The "Taiwan issue" was one of the topics discussed when mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen met with US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright on Wednesday evening in Beijing, with both sides expressing their stances on the matter.
However, issues concerning US arms sales to Taiwan and the new defense cooperation guidelines between Washington and Tokyo were not raised during their talk on Wednesday.

After the meeting, mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Tang Guoqiang told the press details about the talk between Qian and Albright. He quoted Qian as saying that the "Taiwan issue" is the most sensitive question in the Beijing-Washington relationship, and that engagements between the two sides will proceed smoothly if the issue is handled properly. Qian expressed the hope of the Beijing authorities, said Tang, that Washington will adhere to the bases of the three joint communiques and joint statements signed by the two sides concerning the "Taiwan issue."
Albright responded that Washington has a consistent policy on Taiwan, fully respects Beijing's stance on the "Taiwan issue," and adheres to a "one China" policy.

Prior to the talks on Wednesday between Albright and her mainland counterpart, Tang Jiaxuan, the two foreign ministers signed an agreement on the establishment of a direct secure telephone link between their two governments, in line with the joint statement signed last October -- during mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to the United States -- which included an agreement that the two sides would create a Washington-Beijing presidential communications link to facilitate direct contact.
Albright is scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji and President Jiang on Wednesday. She is scheduled to leave Beijing on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-LIBERIAN AGRICULTURAL COOPERATION AGREEMENT APPROVED

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China Thursday approved a three-year agreement with Liberia on agricultural cooperation.
Under the agreement, Taiwan will send agricultural experts to Liberia to provide technical assistance. Taiwan will also sponsor seminars on agricultural technologies for Liberians.
ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu signed the agreement with his Liberian counterpart Monie Captan in Monrovia on Feb. 19.
Meanwhile, the Executive Yuan also approved Thursday a memorandum of understanding, under which Taiwan will donate 10,000 tons of rice to Liberia to help relieve food shortages.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE'S EXPORTS TO EU TO BE GIVEN MFN TARIFF RATES

TEXT.P: Singapore will be fully graduated from the European Union's Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) scheme Friday, the Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB) announced Thursday.
All exports of Singapore origin entering the European Union (EU) on or after May 1, 1998 will be levied duties based on the most-favored-nation tariff rates, it said.

However, as a member of ASEAN (the Association of Southeast Asian Nations), Singapore can continue to enjoy GSP benefits under the regional cumulation mechanism, which is applicable to regional economic groupings as provided for in the European Commission Regulations. Products manufactured in Singapore could be used as inputs in finished products of another ASEAN beneficiary country eligible for the GSP Scheme.

The impact of full graduation from the EU GSP scheme on Singapore's exports is considered to be marginal, the TDB said. In 1997, Singapore's GSP-eligible non-oil exports to the EU represented only 2.9 percent or about S$740.4 million (US$465.7 million) of the nation's total exports to the EU.

In 1997, Singapore's total exports to the EU amounted to S$26 billion. Non-oil domestic exports accounted for S$17.7 billion. The EU is Singapore's third largest export market, accounting for about 14 percent of Singapore's global exports, the TDB said.
Apart from Singapore, South Korea and Hong Kong will also be fully graduated from the GSP scheme Friday, according to the TDB.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT MISSION TO VISIT CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: An investment and trade mission led by the President Group will visit Central America May 3-15 to examine the investment environments in the region.

The delegation is one of five planned groups -- covering the foodstuff, construction and general industrial sectors -- organized by the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), which is chaired by Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the President Group.

After President Lee Teng-hui visited Central and South America last September, he asked Kao to set up a holding company to generate investments in that area and to call on local enterprises to invest in Latin America.

According to the CNFI, the other four visiting missions will head for that region separately in May and June to study the investment and trade climates there. After all the missions return, a workshop will be held to review their findings and discuss the establishment of the planned holding company, the CNFI said.
The first CNFI mission is made up of 10 members, all of whom are high-ranking executives from President Enterprise Corp., a listed foodstuff giant under the President Group.

The executives are scheduled to tour six Central American countries -- Panama, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Guatemala and Costa Rica -- to study the trade environments related to the soft drink, fast food, retail sales and fodder sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA TREATMENT FOR FOREIGN BUSINESS PEOPLE OFFICIALLY IMPROVED

TEXT.P: Taipei has decided to make official a trial program that improved visa treatment for foreign business people by allowing them to apply for resident visas, as part of the effort to attract more business elite from overseas to Taiwan.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced on Thursday that employees of foreign corporations which maintain no direct offices or investment operations in Taiwan will be allowed to apply for resident visas instead of visitor visas, permitting them to stay on the island for longer than two months per visit.
Formerly, only those business people from foreign companies that maintained investment operations or affiliated offices in Taiwan were eligible to apply for resident visas.

In an effort to attract more foreign business elite to Taiwan, particularly to boost Taiwan's ambitious Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center plan, the MOFA began a trial program last year to grant resident visas to foreign applicants who represent business concerns that do not maintain offices or other related operations in Taiwan.
Under the trial period, 1,751 foreign business people successfully obtained resident visas, which allow them to stay as long as their contracts are valid.
The success of the trial program prompted the MOFA to make it official, effective May 1.

Foreigners who enter Taiwan on a visitor visa are eligible to remain for two months per visit, while those who are granted resident visas can technically stay as long as they want, depending on their contracts that have been approved by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, according to MOFA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SALT PLANS MULTIPURPOSE DESALINATION PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp. (TSIC) has unveiled plans to forestall possible water shortages at the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park.
The plans call for a "three-in-one" project that will not only provide fresh water but will also allow the generation of electricity and the production of salt.

According to the TSIC, a state-run enterprise, the project will include the construction of a seawater desalination plant in Tainan County's Chiku Township, a steam-generated power plant, water processing facilities for the industrial park, and seawater channeling facilities.

The project will require investments totaling NT$5.76 billion (US$175 million), with construction taking approximately two-and-a-half years to complete, according to the TSIC. The completed desalination plant will be able to supply 24,000 tons of fresh water daily.

The TSIC pointed out that the project addresses both environmental concerns and efficient resource usage. The steam produced during desalination will be used to generate electricity, while the salt-saturated byproduct of the process will be directed into the Chiku Salt Plant for salt production. In this way, the company said, available resources can be fully utilized.

Pipelines will carry the desalinated water from Chiku to the industrial park and the Binnan Industrial District. The desalination plant can also provide fresh water for public use if the necessary conduit facilities exist, the TSIC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WON'T CHANGE POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN: FORMER US OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Winston Lord, former Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said Wednesday that he does not see any evidence of change in US policy toward Taiwan.

Lord also praised the current US policy toward Taiwan and said that it should be continued. "I think our policy is basically correct over the last couple of decades," he said, adding that it is "well-entrenched" and will be pursued in the future.

Since Washington switched recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, the United States has pursued a policy of maintaining a close but unofficial relationship with the Republic of China. Under the Taiwan Relations Act, enacted that same year to govern the new relationship, Washington has provided weapons for Taiwan's self-defense.

As the ties between the United States and mainland China have become closer in recent months and as US President Bill Clinton prepares for his second summit meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in eight months, there have been reports that Washington may be rethinking its policy, in particular the question of whether to continue arms sales to Taiwan.
Answering questions after attending a seminar in Washington, the former assistant secretary of state repeatedly said that he does not see any sign of a major change.

"I would be surprised if there is any significant change in our Taiwan policy either now or during the president's trip (to Beijing in June)," said Lord, who retired last summer but was retained as a State Department consultant without pay.
He indicated that he does not speak for the government, but he also said that he has good friends in the administration and that he remains in touch with them.

US officials have repudiated recent newspaper articles claiming that Washington, which is seeking better relations with mainland China, might bow to Beijing's pressure and suspend arms sales to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO STUDY ECONOMIC COOPERATION WITH SE ASIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan on Thursday decided to set aside a special fund for a research project to study ways to enhance economic and trade cooperation with Southeast Asia.

The decision was made at a meeting between MOEA and CEPD officials following a directive from Premier Vincent Siew, who has suggested using economy and trade as the main axis to promote diplomatic relations.

The large-scale research project, to be implemented at the beginning of the new fiscal year which begins in July, will last for about three years. In the first year, the MOEA and CEPD will each appropriate NT$10 million to finance the project.

The preliminary discussion also resulted in the designation of a series of topics for research, such as the compilation of a basic database for Southeast Asian countries, the investment climate in the Southeast Asian region, the activities of banks and other financial institutions, and the operations of Taiwan businessmen in Southeast Asia.
The research project will probably be carried out by institutes such as the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research and other related organizations.

According to statistics released by the MOEA's Investment Commission, Taiwan investment in Thailand during the first quarter of this year totaled US$9.78 million, a three-fold increase over the US$2.42 million recorded in the corresponding period of last year.
Meanwhile, investment in Malaysia was up 6.6-fold, from US$970,000 during January-March last year to US$7.36 million for the same period of this year.

However, Taiwan investment in Vietnam, the Philippines and Indonesia during the first quarter of this year amounted to only US$11.5 million, a drastic reduction of 85.7 percent in comparison with the same period of last year.
The above statistics show that in the wake of the Asian financial turmoil, investment activities by Taiwan businessmen in Southeast Asian countries have been quite divergent.

In addition, the MOEA and the CEPD want to find out when will be the most favorable time for Taiwan businessmen to invest in Southeast Asia, and whether the government's go-south policy should be continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POSTS FIRST QUARTERLY DEFICIT IN 17 YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade in the first quarter of 1998 posted a deficit of US$70 million, the first quarterly deficit in 17 years, the cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Thursday.

CEPD Chairman Chiang Pin-kung reported in an Executive Yuan meeting that the effect of the Asian financial turmoil has been felt in Taiwan's exports, leading Taiwan to record a rare trade deficit of US$70 million between January and March this year, compared with a surplus of US$1.8 billion during the same period of 1997.
Chiang said that in March alone, Taiwan's exports decreased 0.5 percent, while imports edged up 0.7 percent.

Chiang noted that most countries have adjusted their economic growth for 1998 downward. The target global economic growth has been moved down to 2.4 percent from 2.9 percent, while the worldwide trade growth has also been cut to 7.1 percent from 8.2 percent, he said.

After hearing the report, Premier Vincent Siew said that with the decline in export growth, relevant government agencies should adopt measures to stimulate local demand, including accelerating of large-scale public construction projects and encouraging private investment as part of efforts to raise economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN INFLATION CREEPING UP

TEXT.P: Australia's inflation is showing signs of edging up in 1998-99 due to the weakened Australian currency and Federal Treasurer Peter Costello played down hopes of an interest rate cut despite fresh evidence that price pressures remain subdued.

Costello said consumer prices fell an average 0.2 percent in the year to March, while underlying inflation is running at just 1.5 percent -- well below the target of 2 percent to 3 percent set by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA).

Continued low inflation "means opportunities for home buyers, for young families who are taking advantage of ... historically low interest rates, and it also means that for retired people the prices are not moving against them, not eating up their savings," he said.

Costello, however, hinted that the price pressure had already reached a trough -- at 1.4 percent in the December quarter -- confirming the government's belief that inflation will edge up in 1998-99 largely under the influence of a weakened Australian dollar, which has caused imports to be more expensive.
Costello predicted the central bank will hold the current official interest rate at 5 percent.
Between July 1996 and July 1997, the RBA cut its official rate five times, lowering it to 5 percent from 7.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE UNLIKELY TO SLIP INTO RECESSION: IMF OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Singapore is unlikely to slip into recession this year even though its economy faces significant risks, a senior International Monetary Fund (IMF) official said in Singapore Wednesday.

However, this year's economic growth could be even lower than the 3.5 percent forecast by the IMF in its World Economic Outlook report only a few weeks ago, warned Flemming Larsen, deputy director of the IMF's research department.
He pointed out that the possibility of a further contraction in Singapore's growth rate is due to "tremendous uncertainty about how the situation will unfold in the region."
Falling demand, output and trade in the Asian countries most affected by the regional financial crisis will hurt Singapore, he said.

"A contraction in the Singapore economy is highly unlikely this year, even though there are significant downside risks due to Singapore's position as a trading nation," he said, adding that "a brief cooling-off period may not be bad" for the economy.
Singapore's problems are "temporary," Larsen said at a briefing session on the IMF's World Economic Outlook report Wednesday. Larsen heads the team of economists who prepared the report.

He pointed out that the Asian economic turmoil had more than halved net capital inflows into the region from their peak in 1996 and that the problems will set back by several years the five worst-affected nations: Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, South Korea and Thailand.
"We are talking about a shock (reduction in net capital flows) of about US$100 billion. That is clearly a massive shock for five small to medium-sized countries," he said.
He said 1998 will still be a difficult year for Asian countries hit by the crisis, even though there are hopeful signs from Thailand and South Korea.
"There is light at the end of the tunnel," he said.
"Next year will see some improvement, and if the pace of reforms is maintained, most of the economies could be back on track by 2000," Larsen said.
Some of Asia's previously buoyant economies could grow by 5.6 percent or 7 percent in future, but the high growth rates of the past are unlikely to be repeated, he said.
Larsen said the IMF had initially underestimated the depth of the upheaval but now recognizes it has been having a huge impact on economies across the region.

Japan's new financial stimulus package will limit downside risks for the domestic economy but it may not be sufficient for an economic turnaround, he said, asserting that Japan needs to speed up financial sector reforms and continue the deregulation and liberalization of its economy.
If the Japanese economy recovers and the yen strengthens, this may also help the soaring US economy achieve a soft landing, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MEASURES ON DRAFTEE DEPARTURES EXPECTED IN LATE JUNE

TEXT.P: A series of revised measures regulating ROC males who wish to leave the country before completing their two-year compulsory military service is expected to take effect in late June, an official with the Ministry of the Interior said on Thursday.

Chung Tai-li, director of the Conscription Department under the Interior Ministry, said the Interior and National Defense ministries have been working on the new measures to facilitate short-term overseas stays for ROC would-be draftees in order to allow them more opportunities to increase their knowledge and explore their international prospects.

The revised measures are expected to pass the Executive Yuan in mid-May and will be implemented in late June, he noted, adding that the measures will soften current restrictions on a range of issues for would-be conscripts, including departure numbers, the length of short-term overseas stays, and visa issuing and extension terms.
Chung made the remarks while answering questions during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

In response to a proposal by New Party Legislator Hau Lung-pin that the government should also allow conscripts to study abroad, Chung replied that this would have a strong impact on the current education and military service systems and that improvements should be implemented step by step, adding that the Conscription Department will review the new regulations three years after their implementation.

A Grand Jury meeting last year branded as unconstitutional a clause in the current conscription law which bans would-be draftees from going abroad, and declared that the clause will become null and void on June 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'KUNDUN' TO BE FINALLY RELEASED IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: "Kundun" -- a movie about the story of the Dalai Lama -- is finally set to be released in Australia despite a series of hurdles, including a warning by the mainland Chinese embassy, industry sources said.

Disney, the producer of the picture, had its major Australian film distributors refuse to release the controversial movie for nationwide showing in Australia because of fears of offending mainland China, the sources said.
Another factor behind the delay is that UGC, Disney's sales agent, had asked a high price for the release of "Kundun" in Australia, they said.
But UGC has reduced its price and won an agreement from the Melbourne-based independent distributor NewVision for the public showing of the movie in Australia.
UGC and NewVision have signed a deal in which the movie is scheduled to be released in Australia in June, several months after its release in other countries.

The delay is partly due to a strong warning from the mainland Chinese embassy in Canberra, which earlier threatened to take retaliatory action against Roadshow, which normally handles Disney films in Australia, the sources said.

Roadshow, an Australian company that is in an Asian cinema-building joint venture with Hong Kong company Golden Harvest, refused to release the movie, claiming the price UGC was asking for it was too high.
Industry sources, however, attributed Roadshow's action to Beijing's warning.
The news of the imminent release of the movie follows protests by the Australia Tibet Council (ATC), which alleged political censorship over the non-appearance of the movie in Australia.
NewVision managing director Frank Cox described the deal to release the movie as "a big coup."

ATC President Alex Butler on Wednesday welcomed the film deal, saying, "We're delighted it's finally going to get shown in Australia and delighted New Vision has got it because they have a very positive attitude -- we admire their independence."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GLASS ARTIST SHOWN IN LONDON MUSEUM

TEXT.P: Taiwan may not be renowned for its glass, but an exhibition in London's Victoria and Albert Museum (V&A) which opened on Wednesday is showing visitors that contemporary Chinese artists in Taiwan are trying to put themselves on the cultural map in this field.

The V&A held a reception to mark the opening of the exhibition, entitled New Glass Art from China. Fifteen contemporary glass sculptures by Loretta Yang of Taiwan's New Workshop will be on display for the next six months.

The reception also marked the museum's decision to put two of Yang's sculptures on permanent display -- an exquisite green and yellow pumpkin box made with the pate-de-verre technique, and a pure white piece called Flight of Buddha, made using the same technique.

For Yang, a former Taiwan movie star who was awarded the best actress award in Taiwan's golden horse festival for two consecutive years and also won the best actress prize in the Asian Pacific film festival, the exhibition was what she called another milestone in her struggle to find new territory in which to express herself after deciding to quit the movie industry at the peak of her career.

Yang, along with her film director husband Chang Yi and five other friends, set up Taiwan's first professional glass arts studio in 1987, with absolutely no idea they would one day revolutionize the glass industry on the island.
Her sculptures are distinctive, often featuring her favorite images of Buddha and other ancient Chinese motifs as found on ancient Chinese bronzes.
Yang's work has been exhibited in Asia, America and Europe, and in the words of critic Andrew Bolton, have succeeded in changing the traditional perception of glassmaking in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD SALES FOR PEPSI IN RIYADH

TEXT.P: A Pepsi Cola bottling company has created a new world record for the maximum number of cases of soft drinks in a single day in one supermarket.
Over 20,000 cases of Pepsi were sold in Riyadh's Euromarche, battering the previous record of 18,700 cases set in Dubai in the late 1980s.
Company spokesman Wael Sharaf said it took only 16 hours to sell all 20,000 cases.

The new one-day sales record will be listed in the Guinness Book of World Records next month, company officials said. The record sales conincided with Euromarche's anniversary, when all products in the store are sold at half price.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC CHICKEN TO BE CHALLENGED BY AMERICAN CHICKEN

TEXT.P: With the arrival of American chicken on Taiwan supermarket shelves imminent, local poultry businesses are speeding up moves to defend their market share and profits.

A spokesman for the Poultry Association of the Republic of China said on Thursday that one of their strategies is to build a certification system to label high-quality chicken meat and live domestic chickens with a logo saying that the products have been certified by the association.

The spokesman said they are also sparing no efforts in promoting these labeled products in markets islandwide, because they believe the certified chicken will enjoy a stronger competitive edge than imported chicken.
On June 1, American chicken will start entering the Taiwan market, which must open for imports as a part of the island's bid for World Trade Organization entry.

Taiwan agreed to an immediate market opening for 10,000 tons of chicken from the US per year at a tariff rate of 25 percent in bilateral trade consultations in February, and this is being seen as a worrisome threat to the monopoly enjoyed by the domestic poultry industry.

Huang Tsi-yiang, chairman of the Poultry Association, said that despite the fact that the imported chicken is expected to disturb the currently stable chicken prices, the association is convinced that local consumers will still buy local chicken at a higher price, rather than choosing the imported product.
He reasoned that local chickens, especially the free-range variety, are commonly believed to produce sweeter and tastier meat than their foreign counterparts.

Moreover, with imports to be strictly controlled by the government, the US chickens will mostly be channeled into the processed food sector, which will lessen the impact on the general market sector, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY STUDENTS PROTEST PRINCIPAL'S BEIJING VISIT

TEXT.P: Seven university students on Thursday staged a sit-in in front of the National Taiwan University to protest an upcoming visit to mainland China by the university's president.

The sit-in, which ended at around 6:30 p.m., was described by the strikers as being aimed at "repenting on behalf of National Taiwan University President Chen Wei-tzou," as he insisted on making the trip to Beijing University despite their advice.

Chen, along with the presidents of several other universities throughout the island, will leave for Beijing on Friday to attend the prestigious university's 100th anniversary. The celebrations will feature a "University President's Forum" on May 2, in which the presidents of some 60 universities around the world are expected to take part.

In an earlier meeting with Chen, the student representatives demanded that the president cancel the visit, saying that while Beijing continues its attempts to stifle Taiwan's efforts to increase its presence in the international community, the visit will "dwarf" Taiwan and hurt the island's dignity.

They also demanded that if Chen still insists on going to the capital of mainland China, he should at least sign an agreement they had drafted which states that during his visit, Chen won't do or say anything to hurt Taiwan's security, freedom and dignity.

Chen told the students that he respected their freedom to express their views on the issue, adding that while he will still make the visit, he won't do or say anything that will hurt Taiwan's dignity.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY HAILS 72-HOUR VISA-FREE TREATMENT FOR TAIWAN VISITORS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 30 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: ROC Representative to Japan Chuang Ming-yao on Thursday expressed delight over the Japanese Diet's decision to reinstate 72-hour visa-free privileges for ROC passport holders, attributing the move to efforts by the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs and all his predecessors.

Chuang also expressed appreciation for the help given by Sadanori Yamanaka, president of the non-partisan Alliance for Japan-ROC Friendship in Japan's Diet, or parliament, and praised Yamanaka's key role in the Diet's passage of the amendment bill earlier the same day to reinstate the above-mentioned treatment for ROC visitors.

The ROC's progress in democratization and economic development may also be a reason behind the Diet's decision to re-implement the privileges for Taiwan visitors, Chuang said, pointing out that the amendment was passed unanimously by all 450 dietmen at the House of Representatives who took part in the session.

The new regulations, which are expected to be promulgated within two or three weeks and become effective in mid-June, will recognize passports issued by the Republic of China as valid documents and will allow Japanese visa issuing authorities to place their stamps directly in the passports, rather than the practice employed previously of placing stamps on separate "entry certificates."

The ROC representative office in Japan has been working toward the resumption of the 72-hour visa-free treatment for Taiwan visitors for the past seven years, ever since Tokyo withdrew the privilege in 1990. The new measure is widely regarded as a big breakthrough in bilateral ties after the two countries suspended diplomatic relations in 1972.
Meanwhile, ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu also welcomed the move, describing it as a practical measure that will facilitate visits by Taiwan businessmen and tourists to that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL CRITICIZES BEIJING'S EFFORTS TO ISOLATE ROC

TEXT.P: Chang Jong-kung, director-general of the Department of Overseas Affairs under the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), on Thursday termed the containment methods used by Beijing to isolate the Republic of China diplomatically as "unwise," saying that the policy has enhanced the rationality of the existence of a Taiwan independence movement.

Chang made the remarks at a seminar sponsored by the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to mark the 5th anniversary of the historic Koo-Wang talks in Singapore. The talks between Koo Chen-fu, SEF chairman, and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), represented the first high-level cross-strait contact in more than 40 years.

The KMT official pointed out that Beijing's containment, and its continued criticism of the ROC's pragmatic diplomacy, has resulted in public repugnance, has hurt the feelings of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, and has strengthened the reasons for the existence of the Taiwan independence movement.

According to Chang, there is space for peaceful cross-strait unification, but in order to enlarge this space, it is absolutely necessary to renounce the threat of military force or diplomatic isolation.

Chang also noted that although there are political differences which are expected to exist for a long period of time, the two sides should have an equal right to function in the international community. He suggested that mainland China should carefully consider new channels and models for future cooperation in order to allow cross-strait exchanges to move forward.

Meanwhile, Yen Wan-chin, director-general of the Department of Mainland Affairs of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said it is difficult for him to be optimistic about a resumption of cross-strait talks, since Beijing still has not dropped its old way of thinking and wants only "political negotiation."

Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the opposition New Party meanwhile suggested that it is better to talk than not to talk, and said he believes Beijing also wants to talk because it is worried that Taiwan will change, and will distance itself more and more from the mainland, eventually becoming an anti-Chinese communist pawn of the Western world.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE RATED BY FOREIGNERS AS BEST PLACE TO LIVE IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Singapore is seen by foreigners as offering the highest quality of life in Asia, followed by Malaysia and Taiwan, according to a Hong Kong-based risk assessment agency.

The latest survey made public by the Hong Kong Political and Economic Risk agency shows that for foreigners, Singapore has surpassed Malaysia for its quality of life in terms of housing, school education, medical services and entertainment facilities.

Taiwan made a remarkable advance in the assessment, taken from the result of a survey of some 400 foreigners living in Asia. The island jumped from last year's ranking as the seventh-best place to live in Asia to this year's third-best. Mainland China was rated ninth among 11 countries and areas in Asia, up one notch from the last survey.

Foreigners living in Asia gave Singapore the highest grades in medical services, preschool and school education, and personal safety, while Malaysia had the advantage over Singapore in housing, gymnasium and entertainment facilities.

The 11 countries and areas were graded as follows: 1-Singapore (No. 2 in the last survey); 2-Malaysia (last year's No. 1); 3-Taiwan (No.7 last year); 4-Japan (up from No. 6); 5-Hong Kong (down from No. 4); 6-Thailand (No. 5 last year); 7-the Philippines (down from No. 3); 8-Indonesia (no change); 9-mainland China (up from No. 10); 10-Vietnam (last year's No. 11); and 11-South Korea (down from No. 9)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN PROMOTES `GO WEST' INVESTMENT POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Canberra, April 30 (CNA) (By Y.Y. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Visiting Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said here on Thursday that Taiwan should develop itself as an "economic integrator" in the Asia-Pacific region and ease restrictions on Taiwan investment in mainland China in order to grab a larger slice of that burgeoning market.

Hsu said the chances of Taiwan transforming itself into a regional business operations hub are slim and that Taiwan should take advantage of its excellent ability as an OEM manufacturer to work with US companies in exploring the vast mainland Chinese market.

Although the international community has described Taiwan's stability amid the Asian financial morass as the "Taiwan phenomenon," the DPP chairman attributed the island's brilliant performance to its small businesses, most of which are OEM contractors for world-class brand-name products.

Pointing to the semiconductor and plastics industries as examples, Hsu said Taiwan OEM manufacturers, working with their US contracting companies, have formed a strong front to compete against Japanese and South Korean businesses in global markets.

Hsu went on to say that Taiwan should ease investment restrictions to allow the services sector, including the financial and warehousing industries, to explore the promising mainland market, where they can create their own brands and marketing networks.
They would also be able to join forces with US firms to seize a larger share of the international market, he added.

As Taiwan businesses currently pour at least US$20 billion-worth of investment into mainland China every year, Taiwan's financial industry will quickly develop if Taiwan-based banks are allowed to operate negotiating services in Hong Kong, he said.

In addition, Taiwan's transport and distribution industries could also be easily upgraded should direct trade, postal and transport links be permitted across the Taiwan Strait, thus greatly increasing the chances of Taiwan developing as an economic integrator among Asian economies, he concluded.
Hsu made the remarks while answering questions from local reporters. The DPP chairman is here for a weeklong visit at the invitation of the Taipei-based Australian Commerce and Industry office.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROVINCIAL GOVERNOR SOONG SIDES WITH THOMAS JEFFERSON

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said on Thursday that he agrees with former US President Thomas Jefferson in that local government's wishes should be respected. Although the federal government is important, certain rights must be reserved for state government.
Soong made the remarks during an interview broadcast in two parts on Wednesday and Thursday by the ICRT radio station.

Answering a question on whether he felt betrayed when the government decided to reform the provincial government without consulting him, Soong said: "I really had a kind of a bad feeling about why they made that kind of decision. But I do not want to recite what has been done, because let us put aside our differences and look forward to how to patch up and also to doing things for the future."
Soong, who threatened to resign a little over a year ago because of government reforms of the provincial government, said that there are two things which he really wants to protest.
"One, I do not support the idea of abolishing the provincial government. I feel the local government understands better the wishes of the people.

"Second is the procedure. As the governor of Taiwan, I should be consulted beforehand. When we drafted a new constitutional amendment -- I was and still am a Standing Committee member of the Kuomintang and I am also the publicly elected governor of Taiwan -- that bad decision was made without prior consultation with the governor. So I think that as a democratic country, the governor at least should have the right to participate in the decision-making," he said.

Commenting on what's next in his political career, Soong said: "My term (will expire) by the end of this year. I still have a few months to go. I want to finish up, but I feel the most important thing is to do certain things for the people."
He said he will probably make a decision later this year, either to seek another office, or to engage in some other public affairs activity, or to retire to write his memoirs.
